S, s¹
/es ||; ɛs/noun [C,U] (plural S's;s's /ˈesɪz ||; ˈɛsɪz/) the nineteenth letter of the English alphabet 英语字母表的第十九个字母: ‘Sam’ begins with (an) ‘S’. school的第一个字母是Ｓ。

S²
abbr
1 small (size) （衣服）小（号、码）
2 (US 美 So) south(ern) 南方（的）: S Yorkshire 南约克郡

sabbath
/ˈsæbəθ ||; ˈsæbəθ/ the Sabbath noun [sing] the day of the week for rest and prayer in certain religions (Sunday for Christians, Saturday for Jews) 安息日（基督徒以星期日为安息日，犹太教徒以星期六为安息日）

sable
/ˈseɪbl ||; ˈsebḷ/noun
1 [C] a small animal from northern Asia with dark yellowish-brown fur 紫貂；黑貂
2 [U] the skin and fur of the sable, used for making expensive coats and artists' brushes 貂皮，貂毛﹙可制作大衣或画笔﹚

sabotage
/ˈsæbətɑ:ʒ ||; ˈsæbəˌtɑʒ/noun [U] damage that is done on purpose and secretly in order to prevent an enemy or a competitor being successful, for example by destroying machinery, roads, bridges, etc （针对敌人或竞争对手的）蓄意破坏，阴谋破坏（如破坏机器、道路、桥梁等）: industrial/economic/military sabotage 对工业╱经济╱军事的破坏 sabotage verb [T]

saboteur
/ˌsæbəˈtɜ:(r) ||; ˌsæbəˈtɝ/noun [C] a person who does deliberate damage to sth to prevent an enemy from using it, or to protest about sth 蓄意破坏者；阴谋破坏者: Saboteurs blew up a small section of the track. 有人蓄意炸毁了一小段铁路。

sabre ( US 美 saber)
/ˈseɪbə(r) ||; ˈsebɚ/noun[C]
1 a heavy sword with a curved blade ﹙弯刃﹚马刀，军刀
2 a light sword with a thin blade used in the sport of fencing ﹙击剑运动中的﹚佩剑，花剑

sac
/sæk ||; sæk/noun [C] a part inside the body of a person, an animal or a plant, that is shaped like a bag, has thin skin around it, and contains liquid or air ﹙人、动植物体内的﹚囊

saccharin
/ˈsækərɪn ||; ˈsækərɪn/noun [U] a very sweet chemical substance that can be used instead of sugar 糖精

saccharine
/ˈsækəri:n ||; ˈsækəˌrin/adj (used about people or things) too emotional in a way that seems exaggerated ﹙人或物﹚情感过分强烈而显夸张的: a saccharine smile 过于甜蜜的笑容 saccharine songs 甜得发腻的歌

sachet
/ˈsæʃeɪ; US sæˈʃeɪ ||; sæˈʃe/noun [C] a small plastic or paper packet that contains a small amount of liquid or powder 小塑料包或纸包（液体或粉末）: a sachet of shampoo/sugar/coffee 一小包洗发剂╱糖╱咖啡 ☞picture at container 见container插图

sack¹
/sæk ||; sæk/noun [C] a large bag made from a rough heavy material, paper or plastic, used for carrying or storing things （由粗质材料、纸或塑料制成的）大袋子（用以运载或贮存物品）: sacks of flour/potatoes 几袋面粉╱马铃薯 get the sack (Brit 英) to be told by your employer that you can no longer continue working for him/her (usually because you have done sth wrong) 被开除，被解雇（通常因做了不当之事）: Tony got the sack for poor work. 托尼因工作不力而被解雇。 give sb the sack (Brit 英) to tell an employee that he/she can no longer continue working for you (because of bad work, behaviour, etc) 开除，解雇（某人）（因工作、行为等不好）: Tony's work wasn't good enough and he was given the sack. 托尼因工作不力而被解雇了。
sack²
/sæk ||; sæk/ (especially US 尤为美 fire) verb [T] to tell an employee that he/she can no longer work for you (because of bad work, bad behaviour, etc) 开除，解雇（因工作、行为等不好）: Her boss has threatened to sack her if she's late again. 老板威胁说，如果她再迟到的话，就要把她解雇。

sackcloth
/ˈsækklɒθ ||; ˈsækˌklɔθ/ (also sacking /ˈsækɪŋ ||; ˈsækɪŋ/) noun [U] a rough cloth that is used for making large bags(sacks) 麻袋布；粗麻布

sacred
/ˈseɪkrɪd ||; ˈsekrɪd/adj
1 connected with God, a god or religion 与神或宗教有关的；神圣的: The Koran is the sacred book of Muslims. 《古兰经》是伊斯兰教信徒的圣经。
2 too important and special to be changed or harmed 不得改易的；不得伤害的；神圣不可侵犯的: a sacred tradition 不可改易的传统

sacrifice¹
/ˈsækrɪfaɪs ||; ˈsækrəˌfaɪs/noun[U] [C]
1 giving up sth that is important or valuable to you in order to get or do sth that seems more important; sth that you give up in this way 牺牲（品）: If we're going to have a holiday this year, we'll have to make some sacrifices. 我们要作出一些牺牲，才可以在今年度假。
2 sacrifice (to sb) the act of offering sth to a god, especially an animal that has been killed in a special way; an animal, etc that is offered in this way 献祭，供奉（尤指以宰杀的牲口）；作祭品或供品用的牲口
sacrifice²
/ˈsækrɪfaɪs ||; ˈsækrəˌfaɪs/verb
1 [T] sacrifice sth (for sb/sth) to give up sth that is important or valuable to you in order to get or do sth that seems more important 牺牲；舍弃: She is not willing to sacrifice her career in order to have children. 她不想为了生孩子而放弃自己的事业。
2 [I,T] to kill an animal and offer it to a god, in order to please the god （宰杀牲口）献祭

sacrificial
/ˌsækrˈfɪʃl ||; ˌsækrəˈfɪʃəl/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) offered as a sacrifice¹(2) 用于献祭的: a sacrificial lamb 献祭的羔羊 (figurative 比喻) Our department became the sacrificial lamb when the company decided to downsize(= we lost our jobs so that other departments could stay in business). 公司决定裁员时，我们的部门就成了牺牲品。

sacrilege
/ˈsækrəlɪdʒ ||; ˈsækrəlɪdʒ/noun [U] [sing] treating a religious object or place without the respect that it deserves （对神明的）亵渎

*sad
/sæd ||; sæd/adj (sadder;saddest)
1 sad (to do sth);sad (that...) unhappy or causing sb to feel unhappy 悲哀的；伤心的；令人难过的: We are very sad to hear that you are leaving. 听说你要离去，我们心里很难过。 I'm very sad that you don't trust me. 你不信任我，真叫我伤心。 That's one of the saddest stories I've ever heard! 那是我所听过的最悲惨的故事之一！ a sad poem/song/film 使人伤感的诗╱歌曲╱电影
2 bad or unacceptable 糟糕的；令人无法接受的: It's a sad state of affairs when your best friend doesn't trust you. 如果连最要好的朋友也不信任你，那真糟糕。 ➔sadden /ˈsædn ||; ˈsædṇ/ verb [T] (formal 正式) The news of your father's death saddened me greatly. 得悉令尊逝世，使我悲痛不已。 ➔sadness noun [C,U]

saddle
/ˈsædl ||; ˈsædḷ/noun[C]
1 a seat, usually made of leather, that you put on a horse so that you can ride it 马鞍 ☞picture at horse 见horse插图
2 a seat on a bicycle or motorbike （自行车或摩托车的）车座 ☞picture at bicycle 见bicycle插图 saddle verb [T]
saddle sb with sth to give sb a responsibility or task that he/she does not want 把责任或任务强加在某人身上

saddlebag
/ˈsædlbæg ||; ˈsædḷˌbæg/noun [C] a bag for carrying things that is attached to the saddle on a horse, bicycle or motorcycle 鞍囊；﹙自行车或摩托车上的﹚挂包

sadism
/ˈseɪdɪzəm ||; ˈsedɪzəm/noun [U] getting pleasure, especially sexual pleasure, from hurting other people 施虐狂（尤指性施虐狂） ☞Compare masochism. 与masochism比较。

sadist
/ˈseɪdɪst ||; ˈsedɪst/noun [C] a person who gets pleasure, especially sexual pleasure, from hurting other people 施虐狂者（尤指性施虐狂者） ➔sadistic /səˈdɪstɪk ||; səˈdɪstɪk/ adj ➔sadistically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

sadly
/ˈsædli ||; ˈsædlɪ/adv
1 unfortunately 不幸地；令人遗憾的是: Sadly, after eight years of marriage they had grown apart. 遗憾的是，他们结婚八年以后分手了。
2 in a way that shows unhappiness 悲哀；凄切
3 in a way that is wrong 错误地: If you think that I've forgotten what you did, you're sadly mistaken. 要是你以为我忘了你的所作所为，那就大错特错了。

sae
/ˌes eɪ ˈi: ||; ˌɛs e ˈi/abbr stamped addressed envelope 已贴上邮票的回邮信封

safari
/səˈfɑ:ri ||; səˈfɑrɪ/noun [C,U] (plural safaris) a trip to see or hunt wild animals, especially in East Africa 野生动物考察游猎（尤指在东非）: to be/go on safari 在╱去考察游猎

*safe¹
/seɪf ||; sef/adj
1 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) safe (from sb/sth) free from danger; not able to be hurt 安全；不会受到伤害: She didn't feel safe in the house on her own. 她独自呆在这房子里没有安全感。 Do you think my car will be safe in this street? 我把汽车停在这街上，你看安全不安全？ Keep the papers where they will be safe from fire. 把文件放到火烧不着的地方。
2 safe (to do sth);safe (for sb) not likely to cause danger, harm or risk 无害的；不致遭受危险、伤害或风险的: Don't sit on that chair, it isn't safe. 那张椅子不安全，别坐在上面。 I left my suitcase in a safe place and went for a cup of coffee. 我把手提箱放在安全的地方，然后喝一杯咖啡。 Is this drug safe for children? 这种药适合小孩服用吗？ She's a very safe driver. 她开车开得很稳妥。 It's not safe to walk alone in the streets at night here. 晚上独自在这条街上走路不安全。 Is it safe to drink the water here? 这儿的水能喝吗？ I think it's safe to say that the situation is unlikely to change for some time. 我想可以肯定地说情况暂时不会有变。
3 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) not hurt, damaged or lost 安然无恙；完整无损；未丢失: After the accident he checked that all the passengers were safe. 事故过后，他查看乘客的状况，知道他们都安然无恙。 After five days the child was found, safe and sound. 五天以后，这孩子给找到，安然无恙。
4 based on good evidence 有可靠的证据为基础的: a safe verdict 证据充足的判决 ➔safely adv I rang my parents to tell them I had arrived safely. 我给父母打了个电话，告诉他们我已经安全抵达。
in safe hands with sb who will take good care of you 有人好好照管 on the safe side not taking risks; being very careful 为慎重起见；非常谨慎
safe²
/seɪf ||; sef/noun [C] a strong metal box or cupboard with a special lock that is used for keeping money, jewellery, documents, etc in 保险箱（用来存放金钱、珠宝、文件等）

safeguard
/ˈseɪfgɑ:d ||; ˈsefˌgɑrd/noun [C] a safeguard (against sb/sth) something that protects against possible dangers 起保护作用的事物；防范措施 ➔safeguard verb [T] to safeguard sb's interests/rights/privacy 维护某人的利益╱权利╱隐私

ˌsafe ˈkeeping
/ˌseɪfˈki:pɪŋ ||; ˌsefˈkipɪŋ/noun [U] the fact of sth being in a safe place where it will not be lost or damaged 妥善保管；安全保护: She had put her watch in her pocket for safe keeping. 为安全起见，她把手表放进了衣袋。

*safety
/ˈseɪfti ||; ˈseftɪ/noun [U] the state of being safe; not being dangerous or in danger 安全: In the interests of safety, smoking is forbidden. 禁止吸烟，以策安全。 road safety(= the prevention of road accidents) 道路安全 New safety measures have been introduced on trains. 火车上已实行新的安全措施。

ˈsafety belt
=SEAT BELT

ˈsafety net
noun [C]
1 a net that is placed to catch sb who is performing high above the ground if he/she falls （专为高空表演者而设的）安全网
2 an arrangement that helps to prevent disaster (usually with money) if sth goes wrong 保障措施（通常指金钱方面）

ˈsafety pin
noun [C] a metal pin with a point that is bent back towards the head, which is covered so that it cannot be dangerous. 安全别针 ☞picture at pin 见pin插图

ˈsafety valve
noun [C] a device in a machine that allows steam, gas, etc to escape if the pressure becomes too great 安全阀（压力太大时可让蒸气等外溢的装置）

saffron
/ˈsæfrən ||; ˈsæfrən/noun[U]
1 a bright yellow powder from a flower(crocus), that is used in cooking to give colour to food 藏红花柱头粉（用于烹饪时加色）
2 a bright orange-yellow colour 金黄色；橘黄色 saffron adj

sag
/sæg ||; sæg/verb [I] (sagging;sagged) to hang or to bend down, especially in the middle 下垂，下弯（尤指中间部份）

saga
/ˈsɑ:gə ||; ˈsɑgə/noun [C] a very long story; a long series of events 长篇故事；一长串事件

sage¹
/seɪdʒ ||; sedʒ/noun
1 [U] a plant with flat, light green leaves that have a strong smell and are used in cooking as an herb 鼠尾草﹙可用作调料﹚: duck with sage and onion stuffing 鼠尾草洋葱填鸭
2 [C] (formal 正式) a very wise person 哲人；智者；圣人
sage²
/seɪdʒ ||; sedʒ/adj wise, especially because you have a lot of experience 睿智的；贤明的: sage comments/remarks 睿智的评论/言论 ➔sagely adv: She nodded sagely. 她点点头，一副洞悉一切的样子。

saggy
/ˈsægi ||; ˈsægɪ/adj (saggier; saggiest) (informal 非正式) no longer firm; hanging or sinking down in way that is not attractive 松垂的；松弛耷拉的；下陷的: a saggy mattress 凹陷的床垫

Sagittarius
/ˌsædʒɪˈteəriəs ||; ˌsædʒɪˈtɛrɪəs/noun [U] the ninth sign of the ZODIAC, the Archer 黄道第九宫；人马宫；人马星座

sago
/ˈseɪgəʊ ||; ˈsego/noun [U] hard white grains made from the soft inside of a type of tree(palm), often cooked with milk to make a sweet dish 西谷米；西米: sago pudding 西谷米布丁

said
past tense, past participle ofSAY¹

*sail¹
/seɪl ||; sel/verb
1 [I] (used about a boat or ship and the people on it) to travel on water in a ship or boat of any type （指船或船上的人）航行: I stood at the window and watched the ships sailing by. 我站在窗前，望着往来的船只。 to sail round the world 环球航行
2 [I,T] to travel in and control a boat with sails, especially as a sport 驾驶帆船（尤指作为一种运动）: My father is teaching me to sail. 爸爸正教我驾驶帆船。 I've never sailed this kind of yacht before. 我以前从来没有驾驶过这种游艇。 When we are talking about spending time sailing a boat for pleasure, we say go sailing We often go sailing at weekends. 驾驶帆船取乐叫做go sailing：We often go sailing at weekends.我们周末常去驾驶帆船。
3 [I] to begin a journey on water 开船；启航: When does the ship sail? 什么时候开船？ We sail for Santander at six o'clock tomorrow morning. 我们明天早上六点坐船到桑坦德去。
4 [I] to move somewhere quickly in a smooth or proud way 平滑地或顺利地快速移动；轻快地行进；神气地快步行走: The ball sailed over the fence and into the neighbour's garden. 球掠过栅栏飞进隔壁人家的花园里。 Mary sailed into the room, completely ignoring all of us. 玛丽翩然走进房间，全然不理会我们大家。
sail through (sth) to pass a test or exam easily 轻松通过测验或考试
sail²
/seɪl ||; sel/noun
1 [C] a large piece of strong material that is fixed onto a ship or boat. The wind blows against the sail and moves the ship along. 帆
2 [sing] a trip on water in a ship or boat with a sail （乘船）旅行；（船的）航程
3 [C] any of the long parts that the wind moves round that are fixed to a building (windmill) 风车的翼板 ☞picture at windmill 见windmill插图
set sail→SET¹

sailboard
/ˈseɪlbɔ:d ||; ˈselˌbɔrd/ =WINDSURFER(1)

sailing
/ˈseɪlɪŋ ||; ˈselɪŋ/noun [U] the sport of being in, and controlling, small boats with sails 帆船运动

ˈsailing boat
/ˈseɪlbəʊt ||; ˈselˌbot/ (US 美 sailboat) noun [C] a boat with a sail or sails 帆船

*sailor
/ˈseɪlə(r) ||; ˈselɚ/noun [C] a person who works on a ship or a person who sails a boat 水手；海员；驾驶船只的人

*saint
/seɪnt;snt ||; sent; sṇt/noun[C]
1 a very good or religious person who is given special respect after death by the Christian church （死后为基督教教会所尊崇的）圣徒，圣人 ☞When it is used as a title saint is written with a capital letter Saint Patrick. In the names of places, churches, etc the short form St is usually used St Andrew's Church. Before names saint is pronounced /snt/. Look at patron saint. 如用于称呼，saint冠以大写字母：Saint Patrick圣帕特里克。如用于地名、教堂名称等，一般采用缩约形式St：St Andrew's Church圣安德鲁教堂。在姓名前面，saint读作/snt/。参看patron saint。
2 a very good, kind person 宅心仁厚的大好人；道德高尚的人

saintly
/ˈseɪntli ||; ˈsentlɪ/adj (saintlier; saintliest) like a saint; very holy and good 像圣人的；非常圣洁善良的: to lead a saintly life 过着圣洁的生活

sake
/seɪk ||; sek/noun[C] for Christ's/God's/goodness'/Heaven's/pity's, etc sake(spoken 口语) used to emphasize that it is important to do sth or to show that you are annoyed （用于强调重要性或恼怒）: For goodness' sake, hurry up! 看在老天份上，还不快点！ Why have you taken so long, for God's sake? 天哪，你干吗那么久？ ☞ For God's sake and especially for Christ's sake are stronger and may offend some people. for God's sake及for Christ's sake语气较重，尤其是for Christ's sake，也许会冒犯某些人。 for the sake of sb/sth;for sb's/sth's sake in order to help sb/sth 为某人或某事物起见: Don't go to any trouble for my sake. 看在我面上，别惹麻烦。 They only stayed together for the sake of their children/for their children's sake. 他们之所以没有离婚，完全是为了孩子。 for the sake of sth/of doing sth in order to get or keep sth; for the purpose of sth 为了获得或保持某物；为了；由于: She gave up her job for the sake of her health. 她为了健康放弃了自己的工作。

*salad
/ˈsæləd ||; ˈsæləd/noun [C,U] a mixture of vegetables, usually not cooked, that you often eat together with other foods 色拉；色拉: All main courses are served with chips or salad. 全部主菜都配有炸马铃薯条或色拉。 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

ˈsalad dressing
noun [C] = dressing (2)

salamander
/ˈsæləmændə(r) ||; ˈsæləˌmændɚ/noun [C] a small thin animal with four legs and a long tail, of the type that lives both on land and in water (amphibian)Salamanders often have bright colours on their skin. 蝾螈 ☞Look at lizard. 参看lizard。 ☞picture at amphibian 见amphibian插图

salaried
/ˈsælərid ||; ˈsælərɪd/adj
1 (of a person) receiving a salary ﹙人﹚领薪水的: a salaried employee 领薪水的员工
2 (of a job) for which a salary is paid ﹙工作﹚付薪水的，带薪的: a salaried position 带薪职位 salaried employment带薪的工作

*salary
/ˈsæləri ||; ˈsælərɪ/noun [C,U] (plural salaries) the money that a person receives (usually every month) for the work he/she has done 薪金，薪水（一般指月薪） · My salary is paid directly into my bank account. 我的薪金是直接拨入我的银行户头的。 a high/low salary 高╱低薪 ☞Look at the note at pay ². 参看pay^2的注释。

salaryman
/ˈsælərimæn ||; ˈsælərɪˌmæn/noun [C] (plural salarymen /-mən ||; -mən/) (especially in Japan) a man who works in an office ﹙尤指日本的﹚白领雇员

*sale
/seɪl ||; sel/noun
1 [C,U] the action of selling or being sold; the occasion when sth is sold 销售；出售: The sale of alcohol to anyone under the age of 18 is forbidden. 禁止向18岁以下的人出售含酒精饮料。 a sale of used toys 出售旧玩具
2 sales [pl] the number of items sold 销售额: Sales of personal computers have increased rapidly. 个人计算机的销量已急剧上升。 The company reported excellent sales figures. 公司报告说销售额甚佳。
3 sales [U] (also sales department) the part of a company that deals with selling its products （公司的）销售部（门），营业部（门）: Jodie works in sales/in the sales department. 乔迪在销售部工作。 a sales representative/sales rep 销售代表
4 [C] a time when shops sell things at prices that are lower than usual （商店的）大减价: The sale starts on December 28th. 12月28日起大减价。 I got several bargains in the sales. 大减价期间我买了几件便宜货。 ☞Look at car boot sale and jumble sale. 参看car boot sale及jumble sale。
for sale offered for sb to buy 待沽；待出售: This painting is not for sale. 这幅画是非卖品。 I see our neighbours have put their house up for sale. 我看见我们的邻居已经在卖房子。 on sale
1 available for sb to buy, especially in shops 上市；出售: This week's edition is on sale now at your local newsagents. 本期周刊已公开发售，读者可向当地报贩购买。
2 (US 美) offered at a lower price than usual 削价或廉价出售

ˈsales clerk
(also clerk) (US 美) =SHOP ASSISTANT

salesman
/ˈseɪlzmən ||; ˈselzmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-men ||; -mɛn/) a man whose job is selling things to people 售货员；推销员

salesmanship
/ˈseɪlzmənʃɪp ||; ˈselzmənˌʃɪp/noun [U] skill in persuading people to buy things 推销术；销售技巧

salesperson
/ˈseɪlzpɜ:sn ||; ˈselzˌpɝsṇ/noun [C] (plural salespeople /ˈseɪlzpi:pl ||; ˈselzˌpipḷ/) a person whose job is selling things to people, especially in a shop 售货员，营业员（尤指店员）

ˈsales slip
noun [C] (US 美) = receipt(1)

saleswoman
/ˈseɪlzwʊmən ||; ˈseɪlzˌwυmən/noun [C] (plural -women /-wɪmɪn ||; -wɪmɪn/) a woman whose job is selling things to people 女售货员；女推销员

salient
/ˈseɪliənt ||; ˈselɪənt/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) most important or noticeable 最重要的；显著的；突出的

saline
/ˈseɪlaɪn ||; ˈselaɪn/adj (technical术语) containing salt 含盐的: a saline solution 盐溶液

saliva
/səˈlaɪvə ||; səˈlaɪvə/noun [U] the liquid that is produced in the mouth 唾液；口水 ☞Look at spit. 参看spit。

sallow
/ˈsæləʊ ||; ˈsælo/adj (used about a person's skin or face 指人的皮肤或脸部) having a slightly yellow colour that does not look healthy 蜡黄色的（看来不健康的）

salmon
/ˈsæmən ||; ˈsæmən/noun [C,U] (plural salmon) a large fish with silver skin and pink meat that we eat 鲑鱼；鲑鱼: smoked salmon 熏鲑鱼

salmonella
/ˌsælməˈnelə ||; ˌsælməˈnɛlə/noun [U] a type of bacteria that causes food poisoning （引致食物中毒的）沙门（氏）菌

ˌsalmon ˈpink
adj orange-pink in colour, like the flesh of a salmon 鲑肉色的；橙红色的

salon
/ˈsælɒn; US səˈlɒn ||; səˈlɑn/noun [C] a shop where you can have beauty or hair treatment or where you can buy expensive clothes 美容厅；理发厅；高级服装店

saloon
/səˈlu:n ||; səˈlun/ (US 美 sedan) noun [C] a car with a fixed roof and a separate area (boot) for luggage （有固定车顶和行李箱的）轿车 ☞picture at car 见car插图

*salt¹
/sɔ:lt;(brit also 英亦作) sɒlt ||; sɔlt; sɔlt/noun
1 [U] a common white substance that is found in sea water and the earth. Salt is used in cooking for flavouring food 盐: Season with salt and pepper. 用盐和胡椒粉调味。 Add a pinch(= a small amount)of salt. 搀点儿盐。
2 [C] (in chemistry 化学) a chemical mixture(compound)of a metal and an acid 盐（金属与酸的化合物） salt adj salt water 咸水
rub salt into the wound/sb's wounds→RUB take sth with a pinch of salt→PINCH²
salt²
/sɔ:lt;(brit also 英亦作) sɒlt||; sɔlt/verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to put salt on or in sth 在某物中加盐；用盐腌: salted peanuts 咸花生

saltwater
/ˈsɔ:ltwɔ:tə(r) ||; ˈsɔltˈwɔtɚ/adj living in the sea 海中生活的: a saltwater fish 海产鱼 ☞Compare freshwater. 与freshwater比较。

salty
/ˈsɒlti ||; ˈsɔltɪ/adj having the taste of or containing salt 咸的；含盐的: I didn't like the meat, it was too salty. 这肉太咸了，我不喜欢吃。

salubrious
/səˈlu:briəs ||; səˈlubrɪəs/adj (formal 正式) healthy, clean and pleasant 清洁而有益健康的；宜人的

salutary
/ˈsæljətri; US -teri ||; ˈsæljəˌtɛrɪ/adj (used about an experience) having a good effect on sb/sth, though often seeming unpleasant ﹙经历﹚虽不愉快但有益的: a salutary lesson/experience/warning 有益的教训/经历/告诫 The accident was a salutary reminder of the dangers of climbing. 这次事故提醒人们注意登山的种种危险，倒也不无益处。

salutation
/ˌsæljuˈteɪʃn ||; ˌsæljuˈteʃən/noun
1 [C,U] (formal 正式) something that you say to welcome or say hello to sb; the action of welcoming or saying hello to sb 致意；问候: They greeted the newcomers with friendly salutations. 他们友好地向新来的人致意。 He raised his hand in salutation. 他抬起手以示致意。
2 [C] (technical 术语) the words that are used in a letter to address the person you are writing to, for example ‘Dear Sir’ ﹙信函中的﹚称呼语

salute
/səˈlu:t ||; səˈlut/noun[C]
1 an action that a soldier, etc does to show respect, by holding his/her hand to the forehead （军人等的）敬礼，举手礼: to give a salute 敬礼
2 something that shows respect for sb 致敬的表示；致敬: The next programme is a salute to one of the world's greatest film stars. 下一个节目是向世界上最杰出的一位电影明星致敬。 salute verb [I,T] The soldiers saluted as they marched past the general. 士兵齐步经过将军面前的时候都行礼致敬。

salvage¹
/ˈsælvɪdʒ ||; ˈsælvɪdʒ/noun [U] saving things that have been or are likely to be lost or damaged, especially in an accident or a disaster; the things that are saved （对遭受破坏或可能遭受破坏的财物的）抢救（尤指在事故或灾难中）；抢救出的财物: a salvage operation/company/team 财物抢救行动；打捞公司；海上救助小组
salvage²
/ˈsælvɪdʒ ||; ˈsælvɪdʒ/verb [T] salvage sth (from sth) to manage to rescue sth from being lost or damaged; to rescue sth or a situation from disaster 设法抢救（可能失去或遭破坏的财物）；（从灾难中）挽回，挽救（事物或局面）: They salvaged as much as they could from the house after the fire. 大火过后，他们尽量收拾屋内的灾后残余物。

salvation
/sælˈveɪʃn ||; sælˈveʃən/noun
1 [U] (in the Christian religion) being saved from the power of evil （基督教）灵魂得救，拯救
2 [U] [sing] a thing or person that rescues sb/sth from danger, disaster, etc 拯救者；救星；解救办法

Samaritan
/səˈmærɪtən ||; səˈmærətṇ/noun [C] a good Samaritan a person who gives help and sympathy to people who need it 善人；乐善好施者

*same
/seɪm ||; sem/adj adv pronoun
1 the same... (as sb/sth);the same... that... not different, not another or other; exactly the one or ones that you have mentioned before 相同；同一: My brother and I had the same teacher at school. 我跟哥哥在学校里受教于同一位老师。 They both said the same thing. 他们俩都说过同样的话。 I'm going to wear the same clothes as/that I wore yesterday. 我今天要穿跟昨天相同的衣服。 This one looks exactly the same as that one. 这个跟那个看上去一模一样。
2 the same... (as sb/sth);the same... that... exactly like the one already mentioned 跟前面提及的人或事物一样: I wouldn't buy the same car again (= the same model of car). 我不会再买同一种款式的汽车。 We treat all the children in the class the same. 我们对班上所有学童一视同仁。 I had the same experience as you some time ago. 前些时我有过跟你一样的经历。 All small babies look the same. 婴儿看上去都是差不多的样子。 Is there another word that means the same as this? 还有没有别的词表达跟这个词同样的意思？
We cannot say a same ... To express this idea we use the same sort of I'd like the same sort of job as my father. 不能说a same...。如要表达这个意思，只可以说the same sort of：I'd like the same sort of job as my father.我想做我爸爸那一行。 all/just the same in spite of this/that; anyway 尽管如此；依然；无论如何: I understand what you're saying. All the same, I don't agree with you. 我明白你在说什么，可我就是不同意。 I don't need to borrow any money but thanks all the same for offering. 我不用借什么钱，你的好意我心领了。 at the same time
1 together; at one time 一起；同时: I can't think about more than one thing at the same time. 我不能一心二用。
2 on the other hand; however 可是；然而: It's a very good idea but at the same time it's rather risky. 这个主意很好，可是也很冒险。
much the same→MUCH on the same wavelength able to understand sb because you have similar ideas and opinions 跟某人具有相似观点，因而能理解对方 (the) same again(spoken 口语) a request to be served or given the same drink as before 要求再来一杯相同的饮料 same here(spoken 口语) the same thing is also true for me 我也一样: ‘I'm bored.’ ‘Same here.’ “我觉得无聊。”“我也是。” (the) same to you(spoken 口语) used as an answer when sb says sth rude to you or wishes you sth （用于回答对方的辱骂或祝愿）: ‘You idiot!’ ‘Same to you!’ “你这个蠢东西！”“彼此彼此！” ‘Have a good weekend.’ ‘The same to you.’ “周末愉快。”“也祝你愉快。”

ˌsame-ˈsex
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前)
1 of the same sex 同一性别的；同性的: The child's same-sex parent acts as a role model. 这个孩子的同性家长成了行为榜样。
2 involving people of the same sex 同性人之间的: a same-sex friendship 同性友谊

samosa
/səˈməʊsə ||; səˈmosə/noun [C] a type of spicy Indian food consisting of a triangle of pastry filled with meat or vegetables 印度三角炸饺；印度咖喱角

sample
/ˈsɑ:mpl; US ˈsæmpl ||; ˈsæmpḷ/noun [C] a small number or amount of sb/sth that is looked at, tested, examined, etc to find out what the rest is like 样本；样品: The interviews were given to a random sample of shoppers. 对顾客作随意抽样采访。 to take a blood sample 取血液样本 a free sample of shampoo 洗发剂的赠送样品 [SYN] specimen 同义词为specimen sample verb You are welcome to sample any of our wines before making a purchase. 本店各类葡萄酒皆可品尝，欢迎先试后买。

sampling
/ˈsæmplɪŋ ||; ˈsæmplɪŋ/noun [U] the process of copying and recording parts of a piece of music in an electronic form so that they can be used in a different piece of music ﹙乐曲的﹚取样﹙以用于另一首乐曲﹚

samurai
/ˈsæmuraɪ ||; ˈsæmuˌraɪ/noun [C] (plural samurai) (in the past) a member of a powerful military class in Japan ﹙旧时日本的﹚武士: a samurai sword/warrior 武士刀；武士

sanatorium
/ˌsænəˈtɔ:riəm ||; ˌsænəˈtɔrɪəm/ (US 美 sanitarium) noun [C] a type of hospital where patients who need a long period of treatment for an illness can stay 疗养院

sanction¹
/ˈsæŋkʃn ||; ˈsæŋkʃən/noun
1 [C] [usu.pl] sanctions (against sb) an official order that limits business, contact, etc with a particular country, in order to make it do sth, such as obeying international law （对违反国际法的国家实行的）制裁（如限制贸易、交往等）: Economic sanctions were imposed on any country that refused to sign the agreement. 凡是拒绝在协议上签字的国家都受到了经济制裁。 The sanctions against those countries have now been lifted. 国际上对那些国家实施的制裁现在已经撤销。
2 [U] (formal 正式) official permission to do or change sth 批准；许可
3 [C] a punishment for breaking a rule or law 制裁；惩罚
sanction²
/ˈsæŋkʃn ||; ˈsæŋkʃən/verb [T] to give official permission for sth 批准

sanctity
/ˈsæŋktəti ||; ˈsæŋktətɪ/noun[U]
1 sanctity (of sth) the state of being very important and worth protecting 神圣而应维护: the sanctity of marriage 婚姻之神圣 I believe in the sanctity of human life. 我相信人类生命的神圣。
2 the state of being holy 神圣；圣洁: a life of sanctity, like that of St Francis 圣方济各式的圣洁生活 the sanctity of the Church教会的神圣

sanctuary
/ˈsæŋktʃuəri; US -ʊerɪ ||; ˈsæŋktʃυˌɛrɪ/noun (plural sanctuaries)
1 [C] a place where birds or animals are protected from being hunted 鸟兽保护区
2 [C,U] a place where sb can be safe from enemies, the police, etc （免遭敌人、警方等追捕的）庇护所，避难所

*sand
/sænd ||; sænd/noun
1 [U] a powder consisting of very small grains of rock, found in deserts and on beaches 沙；沙粒 ☞picture on page C8 见C8页插图
2 the sands [pl] a large area of sand 沙滩；沙洲

sandal
/ˈsændl ||; ˈsændḷ/noun [C] a type of light, open shoe that people wear when the weather is warm 凉鞋 ☞picture at shoe 见shoe插图

sandalwood
/ˈsændlwʊd ||; ˈsændḷˌwυd/noun [U] a type of oil with a sweet smell that comes from a hard tropical wood and is used to make pleasant smelling liquid(perfume) 檀香油

sandbag
/ˈsændbæg ||; ˈsændˌbæg/noun [C] a bag filled with sand used to build a wall as a protection against floods or explosions ﹙用于防洪、防爆等的﹚沙袋，沙包

sandbag
/ˈsændbæg ||; ˈsændˌbæg/verb [T] (present participle sandbagging; past tense, past participle sandbagged)
1 to put sandbags in or around sth as protection against floods or explosions 在…堆沙袋；用沙袋封堵
2 (informal 非正式) to attack sb by criticizing him/her strongly; to treat sb badly 猛烈抨击；粗暴对待

sandbank
/ˈsændbæŋk ||; ˈsændˌbæŋk/noun [C] an area of sand that is higher than the sand around it in a river or the sea 沙洲；沙坝

sandbar
/ˈsændbɑ:(r) ||; ˈsændˌbɑr/noun [C] (in geography 地理学) a long mass of sand at the point where a river meets the sea that is formed by the movement of the water 河口沙洲；拦门沙

sandblast
/ˈsændblæst ||; ˈsændˌblæst/verb [T] (often passive 通常用于被动语态) to clean, polish, decorate, etc a surface by firing sand at it from a special machine 喷沙﹙用以清污、打磨等﹚: The building would have to be sandblasted to remove the black soot. 大楼需要喷沙以清除黑色油烟迹。

sandcastle
/ˈsændkɑ:sl ||; ˈsændˌkæsḷ/noun [C] a pile of sand that looks like a castle, made by children playing on a beach （小孩在沙滩上堆成的）沙堡

ˈsand dune
=DUNE

sandpaper
/ˈsændpeɪpə(r) ||; ˈsændˌpepɚ/noun [U] strong paper with sand on it that is used for rubbing surfaces in order to make them smooth 砂纸

sandstone
/ˈsændstəʊn ||; ˈsændˌston/noun [U] a type of stone that is formed of grains of sand tightly pressed together and that is used in building 沙岩

sandstorm
/ˈsændstɔ:m ||; ˈsændˌstɔrm/noun [C] a storm in a desert in which sand is blown into the air by strong winds 沙暴

*sandwich¹
/ˈsænwɪdʒ; US -wɪtʃ ||; ˈsænwɪtʃ/noun [C] two slices of bread with food between them 三明治: a ham/cheese sandwich 火腿╱干酪三明治 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图
sandwich²
/ˈsænwɪdʒ; US -wɪtʃ ||; ˈsænwɪtʃ/verb [T] sandwich sb/sth (between sb/sth) to place sb/sth in a very narrow space between two other things or people 把（某人或某物）夹在中间

ˈsandwich course
noun [C] (Brit 英) a course of study which includes periods of working in business or industry 工读交替制课程

sandy
/ˈsændi ||; ˈsændɪ/adj covered with or full of sand 覆盖着沙的；多沙的

sane
/seɪn ||; sen/adj
1 (used about a person) mentally normal; not crazy （指人）精神健全的: No sane person would do anything like that. 哪个精神健全的人都不会做那种事。
2 (used about a person or an idea, a decision, etc) sensible; showing good judgement （指人、观点、决定等）明智的，理智的 [OPP] insane 反义词为insane ☞noun sanity 名词为sanity

sang
past tense ofSING

sanitarium
/ˌsænəˈteəriəm ||; ˌsænəˈtɛrɪəm/ (US 美) =SANATORIUM

sanitary
/ˈsænətri; US -terɪ ||; ˈsænəˌtɛrɪ/adj connected with the protection of health, for example how human waste is removed 与卫生有关的: Sanitary conditions in the refugee camps were terrible. 难民营里的卫生条件十分恶劣。 ☞Look at insanitary. 参看insanitary。

ˈsanitary towel
(US 美 sanitary napkin) noun [C] a thick piece of soft material that women use to take in and hold blood lost during their period (3) 卫生巾，卫生棉（妇女月经时所用） ☞Look at tampon. 参看tampon。

sanitation
/ˌsænɪˈteɪʃn ||; ˌsænəˈteʃən/noun [U] the equipment and systems that keep places clean, especially by removing human waste 公共卫生；卫生设备

sanitize
/ˈsænɪtaɪz ||; ˈsænəˌtaɪz/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to clean sth thoroughly using chemicals to remove bacteria ﹙用化学制剂﹚消毒，使清洁
2 to remove the parts of sth that could be considered unpleasant 去除…中使人不快的内容；净化: This sanitized account of his life does not mention his time in prison. 这份生平记述对他的不光彩之处略而不表，没有提及他蹲监狱的日子。

sanity
/ˈsænəti ||; ˈsænətɪ/noun[U]
1 the state of having a normal healthy mind 精神健全
2 the state of being sensible and reasonable 明智；理性 [OPP] insanity 反义词为insanity ☞adjective sane 形容词为sane

sank
past tense ofSINK¹

Santa Claus
/ˈsæntə klɔ:z ||; ˈsæntə ˌklɔz/ =FATHER CHRISTMAS

sap¹
/sæp ||; sæp/noun [U] the liquid in a plant or tree （植物的）汁液；树液
sap²
/sæp ||; sæp/verb [T] (sapping;sapped)sap (sb of) sth to make sb/sth weaker; to destroy sth gradually 削弱；逐渐破坏: Years of failure have sapped (him of) his confidence. 多年的失败已令他信心动摇。

sapling
/ˈsæplɪŋ ||; ˈsæplɪŋ/noun [C] a young tree 幼树 ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图

/ˈsæpi ||; ˈsæpɪ/adj (sappier; sappiest) (US, informal 美，非正式) = soppy

sarcasm
/ˈsɑ:kæzəm ||; ˈsɑrkæzəm/noun [U] the use of words or expressions to mean the opposite of what they actually say. People use sarcasm in order to criticize other people or to make them look silly. 讽刺；讥讽；挖苦 ☞Look at ironic. 参看ironic。 ➔sarcastic /sɑ:ˈkæstɪk ||; sɑrˈkæstɪk/ adj a sarcastic comment 尖刻的评论 ➔sarcastically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

sardine
/ˌsɑ:ˈdi:n ||; sɑrˈdɪn/noun [C] a type of very small silver-coloured fish that we cook and eat 沙丁鱼: a tin of sardines 一罐沙丁鱼

sari
/ˈsɑ:ri ||; ˈsɑri/noun [C] a dress that consists of a long piece of cloth that women, particularly Indian women, wear around their bodies 莎丽（用一块长绸子或棉布裹在身上的妇女服装，尤其是印度妇女服装） ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图

sarong
/səˈrɒŋ ||; səˈrɔŋ/noun [C] a long piece of material folded around the body from the waist or the chest, worn by Malaysian and Indonesian men and women 莎笼（马来西亚人及印度尼西亚人的服装）

SARS
/sɑ:z ||; sɑrz/noun [U] the abbreviation for ‘severe acute respiratory syndrome’; a serious illness which causes a high fever and affects the lungs 严重急性呼吸系统综合症；非典型肺炎

sash
/sæʃ ||; sæʃ/noun [C] a long piece of material that is worn round the waist or over the shoulder, often as part of a uniform 腰带，肩带（通常是制服的一部份）

sashay
/ˈsæʃeɪ; US sæˈʃeɪ ||; sæˈʃe/verb [I] to walk in a very confident but relaxed way, especially in order to be noticed 大摇大摆地走；神气地走: I watched her as she sashayed across the room. 我看着她神气地走过房间。

sass
/sæs ||; sæs/verb [T] (informal 非正式) to speak to sb in a rude way, without respect 粗鲁地说话；出言不逊: Don't sass your mother! 跟你的母亲说话别那么无礼！

sass
/sæs ||; sæs/noun [U] (informal 非正式) behaviour or talk that is rude and lacking respect 莽撞的行为；粗鲁的话: Don't give me any of your sass! 不要在我面前撒野！

sassy
/ˈsæsi ||; ˈsæsɪ/adj (sassier; sassiest) (informal 非正式)
1 rude; showing a lack of respect 粗鲁的；无礼的
2 fashionable and confident 时髦且自信的: his sassy, streetwise daughter 他那又时髦又精明的女儿 a sassy black linen dress一件时髦的黑色亚麻连衣裙

sat
past tense, past participle ofSIT

Sat.
abbr Saturday 星期六: Sat. 2 May 5月2日星期六

Satan
/ˈseɪtn ||; ˈsetṇ/noun [sing] a name for the Devil 撒旦（魔王的名称） ☞Look at devil. 参看devil。

satanism ( also Satanism)
/ˈseɪtənɪzəm ||; ˈsetṇˌɪzəm/noun [U] the worship of Satan (the Devil) 撒旦崇拜 ➔satanist noun [C]

satchel
/ˈsætʃəl ||; ˈsætʃəl/noun [C] a bag, often carried over the shoulder, used by schoolchildren for taking books to and from school 书包

satellite
/ˈsætəlaɪt ||; ˈsætḷˌaɪt/noun[C]
1 an electronic device that is sent into space and moves around the earth or another planet for a particular purpose 人造恒星: a weather/communications satellite 气象╱通讯恒星
2 a natural object that moves round a bigger object in space 恒星

ˈsatellite dish
(also dish) noun [C] a large, circular piece of equipment that people have on the outside of their houses, that receives signals from a satellite (1) so that they can receive satellite television （接收恒星电视节目的）碟形天线

ˈsatellite television
(also satellite TV) noun [U] television programmes that are sent out using a satellite (1) 恒星电视

satin
/ˈsætɪn; US ˈsætn ||; ˈsætṇ/noun [U] a type of cloth that is smooth and shiny 缎（一种光滑的衣料）: a satin dress/ribbon 缎子连衣裙；缎带

satire
/ˈsætaɪə(r) ||; ˈsætaɪr/noun
1 [U] the use of humour to attack a person, an idea or behaviour that you think is bad or silly 讽刺；讥讽；嘲弄
2 [C] a satire (on sb/sth) a piece of writing or a play, film, etc that uses satire 讽刺文章、戏剧或电影等；讽刺作品: a satire on political life 一部讽刺政治生活的作品 ➔satirical /səˈtɪrɪkl ||; səˈtɪrɪkḷ/ adj a satirical magazine 一本讽刺杂志 ➔satirically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

satirize
/ˈsætəraɪz ||; ˈsætəˌraɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to use satire to show the faults in a person, an organization, a system, etc 讽刺（个人、组织、制度等的毛病）

*satisfaction
/ˌsætɪsˈfækʃn ||; ˌsætɪsˈfækʃən/noun [U] [C] the feeling of pleasure that you have when you have done, got or achieved what you wanted; sth that gives you this feeling 满意；满足；满足感；令人愉快或满意的事物: Roshni stood back and looked at her work with a sense of satisfaction. 罗希尼后退一步，满意地看着她自己的作品。 We finally found a solution that was to everyone's satisfaction. 我们终于找到了一个人人都满意的解决办法。 She was about to have the satisfaction of seeing her book in print. 她快要高兴地看到自己的书出版了。 [OPP] dissatisfaction 反义词为dissatisfaction

*satisfactory
/ˌsætɪsˈfæktəri ||; ˌsætɪsˈfæktərɪ/adj good enough for a particular purpose; acceptable 良好的；令人满意的；可以接受的: This piece of work is not satisfactory. Please do it again. 这件活儿做得不怎么好，请再做一次。 [OPP] unsatisfactory 反义词为unsatisfactory ➔satisfactorily /-tərəli ||; -tərəlɪ/ adv Work is progressing satisfactorily. 工作进展令人满意。

satisfied
/ˈsætɪsfaɪd ||; ˈsætɪsˌfaɪd/adj satisfied (with sb/sth) pleased because you have had or done what you wanted 满意的；满足的: a satisfied smile 心满意足的笑容 a satisfied customer 满意的顾客 [OPP] dissatisfied 反义词为dissatisfied

*satisfy
/ˈsætɪsfaɪ ||; ˈsætɪsˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle satisfying third person singular present satisfies;past tense past participle satisfied)
1 to make sb pleased by doing or giving him/her what he/she wants 使满意；使满足: Nothing satisfies him -- he's always complaining. 他对什么也不满意，总是牢骚满腹。
2 to have or do what is necessary for sth 达到，符合，满足（要求或规定）: Make sure you satisfy the entry requirementsbefore you apply to the university. 申请上大学之前，要确定自己是不是符合上大学的要求。 I had a quick look inside the parcel just to satisfy my curiosity. 只是为了满足好奇心，我朝包裹里面飞快地看了一眼。
3 satisfy sb (that...) to show or give proof to sb that sth is true or has been done 向（某人）表示，证明（某事属实或已完成）: Once the police were satisfied that they were telling the truth, they were allowed to go. 警方相信他们说的都是真话后，便让他们离去。

satisfying
/ˈsætɪsfaɪɪŋ ||; ˈsætɪsˌfaɪɪŋ/adj pleasing, giving satisfaction 令人满意的；令人满足的: I find it satisfying to see people enjoying something I've cooked. 见到大家都很喜欢吃我烧的菜，我觉得很开心。

satsuma
/sætˈsu:mə ||; sætˈsumə/noun [C] a type of small orange 蜜柑

saturate
/ˈsætʃəreɪt ||; ˈsætʃəˌret/verb[T]
1 to make sth extremely wet 使湿透
2 to fill sth so completely that it is impossible to add any more 使充满；填满；使饱和: The market is saturated with cheap imports. 市场充斥着廉价进口货。 ➔saturation /ˌsætʃəˈreɪʃn ||; ˌsætʃəˈreʃən/ noun [U]

saturated
/ˈsætʃəreɪtɪd ||; ˈsætʃəˌretɪd/adj
1 completely wet 湿透的
2 (technical术语) (used about fats in food) that are not easily dealt with by the body because of their chemical structure （指食物中的脂肪）饱和的 ☞Compare polyunsaturated and unsaturated. 与polyunsaturated及unsaturated比较。

ˌsaturated ˈfat
noun [C, usually pl] saturated fats come from meat and milk products and are not easily processed by the body when eaten because of the way their chemical structure is arranged. Saturated fats are considered less healthy than other kinds of fat because they can cause heart disease. 饱和脂肪 ☞ Look at polyunsaturated and unsaturated. 参看polyunsaturated 和 unsaturated。

ˌsatuˈration point
noun [U] [sing]
1 the stage at which no more of sth can be accepted or added because there is already too much of it or too many of them 极限；饱和点: The market for mobile phones is reaching saturation point. 移动电话的市场快要达到饱和点。
2 (in chemistry) the stage at which no more of a substance can be taken in by a liquid or VAPOUR (= a mass of very small drops of liquid in the air) （化学）饱和点

*Saturday
/ˈsætədeɪ;-di ||; ˈsætɚde; -dɪ/noun [C,U] (abbr Sat.) the day of the week after Friday 星期六 ☞Days of the week are always written with a capital letter. For examples of how to use the days of the week in sentences, look at Monday. 表示星期几的词，开头字母要大写。有关这类词在句子里的示例，参看Monday。

Saturn
/ˈsætɜ:n;-tən ||; ˈsætɝn; -tən/noun [sing] the planet that is sixth in order from the sun and that has rings around it 土星（太阳系行星，按离太阳远近次序计为第六颗） ☞picture at the solar system 见the solar system插图

*sauce
/sɔ:s ||; sɔs/noun [C,U] a thick hot or cold liquid that you eat on or with food （浓的）酱汁，调味汁: The chicken was served in a delicious sauce. 那鸡浇了美味的调味汁。 ice cream with chocolate sauce 浇巧克力汁的冰淇淋 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图 ☞Look at gravy. 参看gravy。

*saucepan
/ˈsɔ:spən; US -pæn ||; ˈsɔsˌpæn/noun [C] a round metal pot with a handle that is used for cooking things on top of a cooker （有柄的）深平底锅 ☞picture at pan 见pan插图

*saucer
/ˈsɔ:sə(r) ||; ˈsɔsɚ/noun [C] a small round plate that you put under a cup 茶杯碟；茶碟；茶托 ☞picture at cup 见cup插图

sauna
/ˈsɔ:nə ||; ˈsɔnə/noun[C]
1 a type of bath where you sit in a room that is very hot 蒸气浴；桑拿浴；三温暖: to have a sauna 沐蒸气浴
2 the room that you sit in to have a sauna 蒸气浴室；桑拿浴室；三温暖浴室

saunter
/ˈsɔ:ntə(r) ||; ˈsɔntɚ/verb [I] to walk without hurrying 漫步；闲逛

*sausage
/ˈsɒsɪdʒ ||; ˈsɔsɪdʒ/noun [C,U] a mixture of meat cut into very small pieces, spices, etc that is made into a long thin shape. Some sausage is eaten cold in slices; other types are cooked and then served whole 香肠；腊肠: garlic/liver sausage 蒜肉肠；肝泥肠: We had sausages and chips for lunch. 我们午餐吃了香肠和炸马铃薯条。 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

savage
/ˈsævɪdʒ ||; ˈsævɪdʒ/adj very cruel or violent 残酷的；凶猛的；猛烈的: He was the victim of a savage attack. 他是一次猛烈攻击的受害者。 The book received savage criticism. 那本书受到猛烈的抨击。 savage verb The boy died after being savaged by a dog. 那男孩受到一条凶猛的狗攻击，后来死了。 ➔savagely adv ➔savagery /ˈsævɪdʒri ||; ˈsævɪdʒrɪ/ noun [U]

savannah
/səˈvænə ||; səˈvænə/ (also savanna) noun [U] a wide flat open area of land, especially in Africa, that is covered with grass but has few trees 稀树草原（尤指非洲的） ☞picture at ecosystem 见ecosystem插图

*save¹
/seɪv ||; sev/verb
1 [T] save sb/sth (from sth/from doing sth) to keep sb/sth safe from death, harm, loss, etc 拯救，保全（以免死去、受伤害、损失等）: to save sb's life 挽救某人的生命 to save sb from drowning 拯救某人免于溺死 We are trying to save the school from closure. 我们正设法挽救这所学校，使它免于关闭。
2 [I,T] save (sth) (up) (for sth) to keep or not spend money so that you can use it later 存钱；储蓄: I'm saving up for a new bike. 我在为买一辆新自行车存钱。 Do you manage to save any of your wages? 你有没有设法积存部份工资？
3 [T] to keep sth for future use 保留，留下（某物作将来之用）: I'll be home late so please save me some dinner. 我要晚一点回家，请给我留一些晚饭。 Save that box. It might come in useful. 留下那个箱子吧，将来可能有用。 If you get there first, please save me a seat. 如果你先到那里，请给我留个位子。
4 [I,T] save (sb) (sth) (on) sth to avoid wasting time, money, etc 节省，避免浪费（时间、金钱等）: It will save you twenty minutes on the journey if you take the express train. 如果乘快车，路上可以节省20分钟。 You can save on petrol by getting a smaller car. 买一辆较小型的车可以节省汽油开支。 This car will save you a lot on petrol. 这辆车将可为你省下大笔汽油开支。
5 [T] save (sb) sth/doing sth to avoid, or make sb able to avoid, doing sth unpleasant or difficult （使）避免做不快或困难之事: If you make an appointment it will save you waiting. 要是你约好时间，就可以不用等候。
6 [T] to store information in a computer by giving it a special instruction （用特别指令）储存（计算机数据）: Don't forget to save the file before you close it. 别忘记在关闭文件以前存盘。
7 [T] to stop a goal being scored in sports such as football, HOCKEY, etc （足球、曲棍球等）救（球）
keep/save sth for a rainy day→RAINY save face to prevent yourself losing the respect of other people 保全面子；保持尊严
save²
/seɪv ||; sev/noun [C] (in football, etc) the action of preventing a goal from being scored （足球等）救球: The goalkeeper made a great save. 守门员成功救回一个险球。

saver
/ˈseɪvə(r) ||; ˈsevɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who saves money for future use 储蓄者: The rise in interest rates is good news for savers. 利率上升对存户来说是个好消息。
2 (often used in compounds 常用于复合词) a thing that helps you save time, money, or the thing mentioned 省时或省钱等的事物

saving
/ˈseɪvɪŋ ||; ˈsevɪŋ/noun
1 [C] a saving (of sth) (on sth) an amount of time, money, etc that you do not have to use or spend （时间、金钱等）节省下来的数量: The sale price represents a saving of 25% on the usual price. 那大减价的价钱要比平常价钱节省25%。
2 savings [pl] money that you have saved for future use 积蓄；存款: All our savings are in the bank. 我们所有的积蓄都存放在银行里。

saviour
/ˈseɪvjə(r)/ (US 美 savior) noun [C] a person who rescues or saves sb/sth from danger, loss, death, etc 救助者；拯救者

savoury
/ˈseɪvəri ||; ˈsevərɪ/ (US 美 savory) adj (used about food) having a taste that is not sweet （指食物）不甜的，咸的，辣的 ☞Look at sweet. 参看sweet。

savvy¹
/ˈsævi ||; ˈsævɪ/noun [U] (informal 非正式) practical knowledge or understanding of sth 实际知识；见识；了解: business/political savvy 商业/政治见识
savvy²
/ˈsævi ||; ˈsævɪ/adj (informal 非正式) (often in compounds 常用于构成复合词) having practical knowledge and understanding of sth; having common sense 有见识的；懂实际知识的；通情达理的: savvy shoppers/travellers 经验老道的购物者/旅行家 More people are cholesterol savvy today than five years ago. 与五年前相比，现在有更多的人了解胆固醇的危害。 He's very Web-savvy. 他在上网方面经验丰富。
*saw²
/sɔ: ||; sɔ/noun [C] a tool that is used for cutting wood, etc. A saw has a long flat metal part (a blade) with sharp teeth on it, and a handle at one or both ends. 锯 ☞picture at tool 见tool插图 saw verb [I,T] (past tense sawed;past participle sawn /sɔ:n ||; sɔn/) to saw through the trunk of a tree 锯断树干 · He sawed the log up into small pieces. 他把那圆木锯成小块。 In American English the past participle is sawed. 在美国英语，saw的过去分词为sawed。

saw¹
past tense ofSEE

sawdust
/ˈsɔ:dʌst ||; ˈsɔˌdʌst/noun [U] very small pieces of wood that fall like powder when you are cutting a large piece of wood 锯屑；木屑

sawmill
/ˈsɔ:mɪl ||; ˈsɔˌmɪl/noun [C] a factory in which wood is cut into boards using machinery 锯木厂

saxophone
/ˈsæksəfəʊn ||; ˈsæksəˌfon/ (informal 非正式sax) noun [C] a metal musical instrument that you play by blowing into it. Saxophones are especially used for playing modern music, for example JAZZ. 萨克斯管；萨克斯风: This track features Dexter Gordon on sax. 这首乐曲主要有德克斯特˙戈登的萨克管演奏。 Look at the note at piano. 参看piano的注释。 ☞picture at music 见music插图

*say¹
/seɪ ||; se/verb [T] (third person singular present says /sez ||; sɛz/ past tense past participle said /sed ||; sɛd/)
1 say sth (to sb);say that...;say sth (about sb) to speak or tell sb sth, using words 说，讲（话）: ‘Please come back,’ she said. “请回来。”她说。 The teacher said we should hand in our essays on Friday. 老师说我们要在星期五交作文。 I said goodbye to her at the station. 我在车站跟她说再见。 We can ask him, but I'm sure he'll say no. 我们可以问他，但他肯定会说不行。 He said to his mother that he would phone back later. 他对母亲说他晚一点会打电话回来。 They just sat there without saying anything. 他们只是一言不发地坐在那里。 ‘This isn't going to be easy,’ she said to herself (= she thought). “这不会是容易的事。”她心里想着。 ‘What time is she coming?’ ‘I don't know -- she didn't say.’ “她什么时候来？”“我不知道。她没有说。” It is said that cats can sense the presence of ghosts. 据说，要是有鬼，猫儿能知道。 ☞ Say or tell ? Say is often used with the actual words that were spoken or before that in indirect speech ‘I'll catch the 9 o'clock train,’ he said. He said that he would catch the 9 o'clock train. Notice that you say sth to sb He said to me that he would catch the 9 o'clock train. Tell is always followed by a noun or pronoun, showing who you were speaking to He told me that he would catch the 9 o'clock train. Tell, not say, can also be used when you are talking about giving orders or advice I told them to hurry up. She's always telling me what I ought to do. 何时用say﹖何时用tell﹖say常用于直接引述所说的话﹐或在间接引语中用于that之前﹕'I'll catch the 9 o'clock train,' he said.“我会赶上９点钟那班火车。”他说。He said that he would catch the 9 o'clock train.他说他会赶上９点钟那班火车。注意﹕对某人说什么话用say sth to sb﹕He said to me that he would catch the 9 o'clock train.他对我说他会赶上９点钟那班火车。tell总是紧接名词或代名词﹐表示你正在对谁人说话﹕He told me that he would catch the 9 o'clock train.他对我说他会赶上９点钟那班火车。tell也可用于发命令或提出建议﹐say则不可以这样用﹕I told them to hurry up.我催促他们赶快些。She's always telling me what I ought to do.她老是告诉我应该干什么。
2 to express an opinion on sth 表达，发表（意见）: I wouldn't say she's unfriendly -- just shy. 我认为她不是不友善，只是腼腆。 What is the artist trying to say in this painting? 画家究竟想用这幅画表达什么呢？ Well, what do you say ? Do you think it's a good idea? 那么，你看怎么样？你认为这是个好主意吗？ It's hard to say what I like about the book. 我喜欢这本书哪一点，这很难说清楚。 ‘When will it be finished?’ ‘ I couldn't say (= I don't know)’. “什么时候结束？”“我不知道。”
3 (used about a book, notice, etc) to give information （指书本、通知等）指示，显示，提供（信息）: What time does it say on that clock? 看那个钟上现在是几点了？ The map says the hotel is just past the railway bridge. 地图显示过了铁路桥就是酒店。 The sign clearly says ‘No dogs’. 告示牌上明确说“不准带狗”。
4 say sth (to sb) to show a feeling, a situation, etc without using words （不用言语）传达（感情、处境等）: His angry look said everything about the way he felt. 他愤怒的神情已表达了他的一切感受。
5 to imagine or guess sth about a situation; to suppose 想象；猜测；假设: We will need, say, £5000 for a new car. 我们大概需要5000英镑买一辆新车。 Say you don't get a place at university, what will you do then? 假如你考不上大学，你会怎么办？
go without saying to be clear, so that you do not need to say it 显然；不用说: It goes without saying that the children will be well looked after at all times. 不用说，孩子们时时都会得到周全的照顾。 have a lot, nothing, etc to say for yourself to have a lot, nothing, etc to say in a particular situation （在某情况下）有许多话要说或无话可说等: Late again! What have you got to say for yourself? 又迟到了！你还有什么可说的？ I must say(spoken 口语) used to emphasize your opinion （用于强调自己的看法）: I must say, I didn't believe him at first. 我要说，我起先不相信他的话。 I wouldn't say no(spoken 口语) used to say that you would like sth （表示想要某物）: ‘Coffee?’ ‘I wouldn't say no.’ “咖啡？”“好的。” Say when(spoken 口语) used to tell sb to say when you have poured enough drink in his/her glass or put enough food on his/her plate （用于叫某人示意杯中饮料或盘中食物是否已添够） that is to say... which means... 那就是说；换言之: We're leaving on Friday, that's to say in a week's time. 我们星期五走，即一星期后。
say²
/seɪ ||; se/noun [sing] [U] (a) say (in sth) the authority or right to decide sth 决定权: I'd like to have some say in the arrangements for the party. 关于聚会的安排，我希望可以有一点决定权。 have your say to express your opinion 表达意见: Thank you for your comments. Now let somebody else have their say. 多谢你的意见，现在让其他人说说他们的意见吧。

saying
/ˈseɪɪŋ ||; ˈseɪŋ/noun [C] a well known phrase that gives advice about sth or says sth that many people believe is true 格言；警句；谚语: ‘Love is blind’ is an old saying. “爱情是盲目的”是一句古老的格言。 ☞Look at proverb. 参看proverb。

ˈsay-so
noun [sing] (informal 非正式) the power or authority to make decisions and give permission for things to be done 决定权: The measure gives state government more say-so in these types of legal matters. 这一措施给州政府在这些法律事务上更多的决定权。 ordinary employees with little say-so against the management没什么能力左右管理层的普通员工 without sb's say-so without permission that sb gives to do sth 未经某人准许: Nothing could be done without her say-so.未经她准许，什么都不可以做。 She took some of his money without his say-so.她未经他许可拿了他一些钱。

scab
/skæb ||; skæb/noun [C,U] a mass of dried blood that forms over a part of the body where the skin has been cut or broken （伤口所结的）痂 ☞Look at scar. 参看scar。

scabies
/ˈskeɪbi:z ||; ˈskebiz/noun [U] a skin disease that causes small red spots and makes your skin feel uncomfortable so that you want to rub or scratch it 疥疮；疥螨病

scads
/skædz ||; skædz/noun [pl] (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) scads (of sth) large numbers or amounts of sth 大量；许多: scads of $20 bills 许多 20 元的钞票

scaffold
/ˈskæfəʊld ||; ˈskæfold/noun [C] a platform on which criminals were killed in past times by hanging 断头台；绞刑台

scaffolding
/ˈskæfəldɪŋ ||; ˈskæfḷdɪŋ/noun [U] long metal poles and wooden boards that form a structure which is put next to a building so that people who are building, painting, etc can stand and work on it 脚手架；施工架；鹰架；搭脚手架或施工架的材料；格鹰架的材料

scalar
/ˈskeɪlə(r) ||; ˈskelɚ/adj (mathematics数学) (used about a measurement or a quantity 指计量或数量) having size but no direction 纯量的；无向量的 scalar noun [C] ☞Look at the note and picture at vector. 参看vector的注释及插图。

scald
/skɔ:ld ||; skɔld/verb [T] to burn sb/sth with very hot liquid 烫伤: I scalded my arm badly when I was cooking. 我在做饭的时候把手臂严重烫伤了。 scald noun [C] ➔scalding adj scalding hot water 滚烫的水

*scale¹
/skeɪl ||; skel/noun
1 [C,U] the size of sth, especially when compared to other things （相对的）大小，规模，程度: We shall be making the product on a large scale next year. 明年我们将大规模生产这种产品。 At this stage it is impossible to estimate the full scale of the disaster. 现阶段还无法充分估计这场灾难严重性。
2 [C] a series of marks on a tool or piece of equipment that you use for measuring sth （度量衡工具上的）刻度，标度: The ruler has one scale in centimetres and one scale in inches. 直尺上有厘米的刻度和英寸的刻度。
3 [C] a series of numbers, amounts, etc that are used for measuring or fixing the level of sth （用于量度、衡量程度的一套标级数字）: The earthquake measured 6.5 on the Richter scale. 这次地震为里氏6.5级。 the new pay scale for nurses 新的护士薪级表 ☞Look at the Beaufort scale and the Richter scale. 参看the Beaufort scale及the Richter scale。
4 [C] the relationship between the actual size of sth and its size on a map or plan （实物与图表之间的）比例，比率: The map has a scale of one centimetre to a kilometre. 这地图的比例是一厘米代表一千米。 a scale of 1: 50000 (= one to fifty thousand) 比例1：50000 We need a map with a larger scale. 我们需要一张比例较大的地图。 a scale model 比例模型
5 scales [pl] a piece of equipment that is used for weighing sb/sth 秤；磅秤: I weighed it on the kitchen scales. 我把它放在厨房的秤上称。
6 [C] a series of musical notes which go up or down in a fixed order. People play or sing scales to improve their technical ability 音阶: the scale of C major C大调音阶
7 [C] one of the small flat pieces of hard material that cover the body of some fish and animals （鱼及动物身上的）鳞，鳞片: the scales of a snake 蛇鳞 ☞picture on page C1 见C1页插图
scale²
/skeɪl ||; skel/verb [T] to climb up a high wall, steep cliff, etc 攀登，攀爬（高墙、悬崖等） scale sth up/down to increase/decrease the size, number, importance, etc of sth 增加╱减少（大小、数量、重要性等）: Police have scaled up their search for the missing boy. 警方已加强搜寻那个失踪男孩。

scallion
/ˈskæliən ||; ˈskælɪən/noun [C] (US 美) = spring onion

scallop
/ˈskɒləp ||; ˈskɑləp/noun [C] a shellfish that we eat, with two flat round shells that fit together 扇贝；干贝蛤

scalp
/skælp ||; skælp/noun [C] the skin on the top of your head that is under your hair 头皮

scalpel
/ˈskælpəl ||; ˈskælpəl/noun [C] a small knife that is used by doctors (surgeons) when they are doing operations 手术刀；解剖刀

scaly
/ˈskeɪli ||; ˈskelɪ/adj (scalier; scaliest) (used about skin) covered with scales¹(7) ﹙皮肤﹚有鳞的: scaly skin/monsters 有鳞的皮肤；多鳞的怪物

scamper
/ˈskæmpə(r) ||; ˈskæmpɚ/verb [I] (used especially about a child or small animal) to run quickly （尤指孩子或小动物）奔跑，蹦蹦跳跳

scampi
/ˈskæmpi ||; ˈskæmpɪ/ (also ˌshrimp ˈscampi) noun [U] a dish of large shrimp cooked in butter and garlic 炸大虾

scan¹
/skæn ||; skæn/verb [T] (scanning;scanned)
1 to look at or read every part of sth quickly until you find what you are looking for 迅速地看；匆匆地翻阅；浏览: Vic scanned the list until he found his own name. 维克迅速地看名单，直到找到自己的名字为止。
2 (used about a machine) to examine what is inside a person's body or inside an object such as a suitcase （指机器）扫描，扫略，扫描检查（人体或对象内部）: Machines scan all the luggage for bombs and guns. 所有行李都要经机器扫描，看看有没有炸弹及枪械。
3 scan sth (into sth);scan sth (in)(computing计算机技术) to use a special machine (a scanner)to change printed words or pictures into electronic text in order to put them in the memory of a computer （用扫描仪）扫描: Text and pictures can be scanned into the computer. 文本及图片可以扫描到计算机里。
scan²
/skæn ||; skæn/noun
1 [C] a medical test in which a machine produces a picture of the inside of a person's body on a computer screen after taking X-RAYS 扫描（检查）: to do/have a brain scan 做脑部扫描
2 [C] a medical test for pregnant women in which a machine uses ULTRASOUND to produce a picture of a baby inside its mother's body （用超声波）扫描（孕妇腹中的胎儿）: The scan showed the baby was in the normal position. 扫描显示胎儿处于正常的位置。
3 [sing] the act of looking quickly through sth written or printed, usually in order to find sth 迅速看；匆匆翻阅；浏览: a scan of the newspapers 浏览报纸

scandal
/ˈskændl ||; ˈskændḷ/noun
1 [C,U] an action, a situation or behaviour that shocks people; the public feeling that is caused by such behaviour 令人震惊的行为或情况；丑闻；公愤: The chairman resigned after being involved in a financial scandal. 主席卷入一宗财务丑闻，结果辞职了。 There was no suggestion of scandal in his private life. 他的私生活与丑闻完全沾不上边儿。 The poor state of school buildings is a real scandal. 不少学校的校舍日久失修，情况令人震惊。
2 [U] talk about sth bad or wrong that sb has or may have done 流言蜚语；闲话；坏话: to spread scandal about sb 散布有关某人的流言

scandalize
/ˈskændəlaɪz ||; ˈskændḷˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to cause sb to feel shocked by doing sth that he/she thinks is bad or wrong 使震惊、愤慨或反感

scandalous
/ˈskændələs ||; ˈskændḷəs/adj very shocking or wrong 令人震惊的；太不象话的: It is scandalous that so much money is wasted. 浪费了这么多金钱太不象话。

Scandinavia
/ˌskændɪˈneɪviə/noun [sing] the group of countries in northern Europe that consists of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Sometimes Finland and Iceland are also said to be part of Scandinavia. 斯堪的纳维亚（包括丹麦、挪威和瑞典的北欧诸国，有时连芬兰和冰岛也包括在内） ➔Scandinavian adj noun [C]

scanner
/ˈskænə(r) ||; ˈskænɚ/noun [C] an electronic machine that can look at, record or send images or electronic information 扫描仪；扫描仪: The scanner can detect cancer at an early stage. 这台扫描仪可发现早期癌症。 I used the scanner to send the document by email. 我用扫描仪扫描文件后，以电子邮件形式发送出去。

scant
/skænt ||; skænt/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) not very much; not as much as necessary 不多的；不足的；缺乏的

scanty
/ˈskænti ||; ˈskæntɪ/adj too small in size or amount 过小的；过少的: We didn't learn much from the scanty information they gave us. 从他们向我们提供的一点点数据中我们所知道的东西实在不多。 ➔scantily adv I realized I was too scantily dressed for the cold weather. 我发觉自己衣服穿得太单薄，禁不住寒冷的天气。

scapegoat
/ˈskeɪpgəʊt ||; ˈskepˌgot/noun [C] a person who is punished for things that are not his/her fault 代人受过的人；替罪羊: When Alison was sacked she felt she had been made a scapegoat for all the company's problems. 艾莉森给开除时，觉得自己成了公司一大堆问题的替罪羊。

scapula
/ˈskæpjʊlə ||; ˈskæpjələ/ (formal 正式)=SHOULDER BLADE ☞picture at body 见body插图

*scar
/skɑ:(r) ||; skɑr/noun[C]
1 a mark on the skin that is caused by a cut that skin has grown over 伤痕；疤: The operation didn't leave a very big scar. 那手术没有留下很大的疤痕。 ☞Look at scab. 参看scab。
2 an area of a hill or cliff where there is rock with nothing covering it and no grass 光秃秃的山或悬崖: a mile-long limestone scar 一英里长光秃秃的灰岩 ☞picture at limestone 见limestone插图 scar verb [I,T] (scarring;scarred) William's face was scarred for life in the accident. 那宗意外在威廉脸上留下了永久的疤痕。

*scarce
/skeəs ||; skɛrs/adj not existing in large quantities; hard to find 不足的；缺乏的；稀有的: Food for birds and animals is scarce in the winter. 冬天时鸟和动物都没有足够的食物。 [OPP] plentiful 反义词为plentiful ➔scarcity /ˈskeəsəti ||; ˈskɛrsətɪ/ noun [C,U] (plural scarcities) (a) scarcity of food/jobs/resources 食物╱工作╱资源短缺

scarcely
/ˈskeəsli ||; ˈskɛrslɪ/adv
1 only just; almost not 仅仅；几乎没有: There was scarcely a car in sight. 几乎一辆车也看不见。 She's not a friend of mine. I scarcely know her. 她不是我的朋友，我不认识她。 ☞Look at hardly. 参看hardly。
2 used to suggest that sth is not reasonable or likely （用于暗示某事不合理或不可能）: You can scarcely expect me to believe that after all you said before. 听过你以前说的那许多话后，别以为我还会相信那个的。

*scare¹
/skeə(r) ||; skɛr/verb
1 [T] to make a person or an animal frightened 使（人或动物）惊恐，恐惧: The sudden noise scared us all. 那突如其来的声音把我们都吓坏了。 It scares me to think what might happen. 一想到可能会发生的事我心里就很害怕。
2 [I] to become frightened 受惊吓；感到害怕: I don't scare easily, but when I saw the gun I was terrified. 我不容易受惊吓，但看到那把枪就吓坏了。
scare sb/sth away/off to make a person or animal leave or stay away by frightening them 把（人或动物）吓跑: Don't make any noise or you'll scare the birds away. 不要弄出声响，不然的话你会把那些鸟吓跑的。
scare²
/skeə(r) ||; skɛr/noun[C]
1 a feeling of being frightened 惊恐；惊吓: It wasn't a serious heart attack but it gave him a scare. 虽然那次心脏病发作并不严重，却把他吓倒了。
2 a situation where many people are afraid or worried about sth 恐慌: Last night there was a bomb scare in the city centre. 昨晚在市中心出现炸弹恐慌。

scarecrow
/ˈskeəkrəʊ ||; ˈskɛrˌkro/noun [C] a very simple model of a person that is put in a field to frighten away the birds （竖立在田间吓走雀鸟的）稻草人

*scared
/skeəd ||; skɛrd/adj scared (of sb/sth);scared (of doing sth/to do sth) frightened 惊恐的；受惊的: Are you scared of the dark? 你怕黑吗？ She's scared of walking home alone. 她害怕单独走路回家。 Everyone was too scared to move. 大家都怕得一动不动。

scarf
/skɑ:f ||; skɑrf/noun [C] (plural scarves /skɑ:vz ||; skɑrvz/or scarfs /skɑ:fs ||; skɑrfs/)
1 a long thin piece of cloth, usually made of wool, that you wear around your neck to keep warm 围巾（长条形，通常是羊毛制的）
2 a square piece of cloth that women wear around their neck or shoulders or over their heads 披肩，围巾，头巾（方形，通常是妇女用的，以作保暖或装饰）

scarlet
/ˈskɑ:lət ||; ˈskɑrlət/adj noun [U] (of) a bright red colour 鲜红色（的）；猩红色（的）

ˌscarlet ˈfever
noun [U] a serious disease that is passed from one person to another and that makes sb very hot and get red marks on the skin 猩红热

scarp
/skɑ:p ||; skɑrp/noun [C] (in geography 地理学) a very steep piece of land 陡坡；悬崖

scary
/ˈskeəri ||; ˈskɛrɪ/adj (scarier;scariest) (informal 非正式) frightening 可怕的；使人惊恐的: a scary ghost story 可怕的鬼故事 It was a bit scary driving in the mountains at night. 晚上在山区开车，气氛有点吓人。

scathing
/ˈskeɪðɪŋ ||; ˈskeðɪŋ/adj expressing a very strong negative opinion about sb/sth; very critical 尖刻的，苛刻的，严厉的（意见等）: a scathing attack on the new leader 对新领袖的严厉抨击 scathing criticism 尖刻的批评

scatter
/ˈskætə(r) ||; ˈskætɚ/verb
1 [I] (used about a group of people or animals) to move away quickly in different directions （指一群人或动物）散开，四散
2 [T] to drop or throw things in different directions over a wide area 散播；撒播: The wind scattered the papers all over the room. 纸张被风吹得散落在房间各处。

scatterbrain
/ˈskætəbreɪn ||; ˈskætɚˌbren/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who is always losing or forgetting things and cannot think in an organized way 思想不集中的人；健忘的人 ➔scatterbrained adj

scattered
/ˈskætəd ||; ˈskætɚd/adj spread over a large area or happening several times during a period of time 散布的；零散的；零星的: There will be sunny intervals with scattered showers today. 今天天气大致晴朗，有零星阵雨。

scavenge
/ˈskævɪndʒ ||; ˈskævɪndʒ/verb [I,T] to look for food, etc among waste and rubbish （在垃圾堆中）捡拾，找寻（食物等） ➔scavenger noun [C]: Scavengers steal the food that the lion has killed. 食腐动物偷吃狮子捕猎到的食物。

SCE
/ˌes si: ˈi: ||; ˌɛs si ˈi/abbr Scottish Certificate of Education. Students in Scotland take the SCE at Standard grade at the age of about 16 and at Higher grade at about 17. 苏格兰教育证书（苏格兰学生约16岁参加普通级证书考试，约17岁参加高级证书考试）

scenario
/səˈnɑ:riəʊ; US -ˈnær- ||; sɪˈnærɪˌo/noun [C] (plural scenarios)
1 one way that things may happen in the future 事物在未来可能出现的一种情况: A likely scenario is that the company will get rid of some staff. 一种可能会出现的情况是，公司将裁掉部份员工。
2 a description of what happens in a play or film （戏剧或电影的）剧情概要，脚本

*scene
/si:n ||; sin/noun
1 [C] the place where sth happened 事发地点；事故现场: the scene of a crime/an accident 案发现场；事故现场 An ambulance was on the scene in minutes. 救护车在几分钟内到达现场。
2 [C] an occasion when sb expresses great anger or another strong emotion in public （在公开场合）发脾气，吵闹: There was quite a scene when she refused to pay the bill. 她拒绝付账，引起一场吵闹。
3 [C] one part of a book, play, film, etc in which the events happen in one place （书本、戏剧、电影等中）一场，一幕: The first scene of ‘Hamlet’ takes place on the castle walls. 《哈姆雷特》第一场的故事发生于城墙之上。
4 [C,U] what you see around you in a particular place 景物；风景；景致；环境: Her new job was no better, but at least it would be a change of scene. 虽然她的新工作不比旧的好，但至少可以换一下工作环境。
5 the scene [sing] the way of life or the present situation in a particular area of activity 某一活动领域的生活方式或现状: The political scene in Eastern Europe is very confused. 东欧的政治局势极为混乱。 the fashion scene 时装界（现况）
set the scene (for sth)
1 to create a situation in which sth can easily happen or develop （为容易发生或发展的事）创造环境: His arrival set the scene for another argument. 他的到来又导致一场争吵。
2 to give sb the information and details that he/she needs in order to understand what comes next 提供或描述背景: The first part of the programme was just setting the scene. 节目的开头部份只是在交代背景。

scenery
/ˈsi:nəri ||; ˈsinərɪ/noun[U]
1 the natural beauty that you see around you in the country 自然景物；风景: The scenery is superb in the mountains. 山区风景绝佳。
2 the furniture, painted cloth, boards, etc that are used on the stage in a theatre （舞台）布景: The scenery is changed during the interval. 幕间休息期间转换布景。 ☞We say that an area of the country has beautiful scenery when it is attractive to look at. The landscape of a particular area is the way the features of it are arranged Trees and hedges are a typical feature of the British landscape. an urban landscape (= in a city or town). You have a view of something when you look out of a window or down from a high place There was a marvellous view of the sea from our hotel room. Look also at the note at country (3). 描述某地区风景怡人﹐我们说beautiful scenery。landscape则指某个地方自然景物的分布╱地形﹕Trees and hedges are a typical feature of the British landscape. 树木和树篱是英国乡村的典型景色。an urban landscape都市景色.view用于指从窗口或高处望下去所看到的景物﹕There was a marvellous view of the sea from our hotel room.从我们的酒店房间往外望﹐可以看到壮丽的海景。另参看country(3)的注释。

scenic
/ˈsi:nɪk ||; ˈsinɪk/adj having beautiful scenery 风景优美的

scent
/sent ||; sɛnt/noun
1 [C,U] a pleasant smell 香味: This flower has no scent. 这种花没有香味。
2 [C,U] the smell that an animal leaves behind and that some other animals can follow 动物留下的气味；臭迹
3 [U] (especially Brit 尤为英) a liquid with a pleasant smell that you wear on your skin to make it smell nice 香水 [SYN] perfume 同义词为perfume
4 [sing] the feeling that sth is going to happen 迹象；预示: The scent of victory was in the air. 大家预感到将要取得胜利。 scent verb The dog scented a rabbit and shot off. 狗嗅到兔子的气味，便飞奔而去。 The press were starting to scent a scandal. ➔scented adj

sceptic
/ˈskeptɪk ||; ˈskɛptɪk/ (US 美 skeptic) noun [C] a person who doubts that sth is true, right, etc 持怀疑态度的人；怀疑论者 ➔sceptical(US 美 skeptical) /-kl ||; -kḷ/ adj sceptical (of/about sth) Many doctors are sceptical about the value of alternative medicine. 不少医生都怀疑非正规药物的价值。

scepticism
/ˈskeptɪsɪzəm ||; ˈskɛptəˌsɪzəm/ (US 美 skepticism) noun [U] a general feeling of doubt about sth; a feeling that you are not likely to believe sth 怀疑；怀疑态度

schedule¹
/ˈʃedju:l; US ˈskedʒʊl ||; ˈskɛdʒυl/noun
1 [C,U] a plan of things that will happen or of work that must be done 时间表；进度表；日程（表）: Max has a busy schedule for the next few days. 接下来的数天，马克斯的日程安排得很紧。 to be ahead of/behind schedule (= to have done more/less than was planned) 早于╱落后于预订计划
2 (US 美) =TIMETABLE
schedule²
/ˈʃedju:l ||; ˈskɛdʒυl/verb [T] schedule sth (for sth) to arrange for sth to happen or be done at a particular time 把…列入（时间表或进度表）；安排；排定: We've scheduled the meeting for Monday morning. 我们已安排在星期一早上召开会议。 The train was scheduled to arrive at 10.07. 火车定于十时零七分抵达。

ˈscheduled flight
noun [C] a plane service that leaves at a regular time each day or week 定期班机 ☞Compare charter flight. 与charter flight比较。

schematic
/ski:ˈmætɪk ||; skiˈmætɪk/adj
1 in the form of a diagram that shows the main features or relationships but not the details 略图的；简表的: a schematic diagram 略图
2 arranged according to a fixed plan or pattern 按既定模式的: The play has a very schematic plot. 这出戏的剧情非常公式化。

scheme¹
/ski:m ||; skim/noun[C]
1 a scheme (to do sth/for doing sth) an official plan or system for doing or organizing sth （正式或官方的）计划，方案: a new scheme to provide houses in the area 给这个地区供应房屋的新计划 a local scheme for recycling newspapers 当地回收利用旧报纸的计划
2 a clever plan to do sth 聪明的办事方法或计划: He's thought of a new scheme for making money fast. 他想出了一个可迅速赚钱的新办法。 ☞Look at colour scheme. 参看colour scheme。
scheme²
/ski:m ||; skim/verb [I,T] to make a secret or dishonest plan 策划阴谋；密谋: She felt that everyone was scheming to get rid of her. 她觉得人人都在耍阴谋想把她撵走。

schist
/ʃɪst ||; ʃɪst/noun [U] (technical术语) a type of rock formed of layers of different minerals, that breaks naturally into thin flat pieces 片岩

schizophrenia
/ˌskɪtsəˈfri:niə ||; ˌskɪtzəˈfrinɪə/noun [U] a serious mental illness in which a person confuses the real world and the world of the imagination and often behaves in strange and unexpected ways 精神分裂症 ➔schizophrenic /ˌskɪtsəˈfrenɪk/ adj noun [C]

schmaltz
/ʃmɔ:lts ||; ʃmɔlts/noun [U] (informal 非正式) the quality of being too sentimental (1) 过分伤感: At the end of the movie we drown in a sea of schmaltz. 电影终结时，我们沉浸在极度伤感之中。 ➔schmaltzy adj

schmuck
/ʃmʌk ||; ʃmʌk/noun [C] (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) a stupid and often clumsy person 傻瓜；笨蛋；蠢货: He's such a schmuck! 他真是个笨蛋！

scholar
/ˈskɒlə(r) ||; ˈskɑlɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who studies and has a lot of knowledge about a particular subject 学者
2 a person who has passed an exam or won a competition and has been given some money (a scholarship) to help pay for his/her studies 奖学金获得者: a British Council scholar 获英国文化协会奖学金的人 ☞Look at student. 参看student。

scholarly
/ˈskɒləli ||; ˈskɑlɚlɪ/adj
1 (used about a person 指人) spending a lot of time studying and having a lot of knowledge about an academic subject 勤奋好学的
2 connected with academic study 与学术研究有关的

scholarship
/ˈskɒləʃɪp ||; ˈskɑlɚˌʃɪp/noun
1 [C] an amount of money that is given to a person who has passed an exam or won a competition, in order to help pay for his/her studies 奖学金: to win a scholarship to Yale 获得耶鲁大学的奖学金
2 [U] serious study of an academic subject 学问；学识

scholastic
/skəˈlæstɪk ||; skəˈlæstɪk/adj (formal 正式) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with schools and education 学校的；学业的: scholastic achievements 学业成绩

*school
/sku:l ||; skul/noun
1 [C] the place where children go to be educated 学校: Where did you go to school ? 你以前在哪所学校上学？ They're building a new school in our area. 他们正在我们区内兴建一所新学校。 Do you have to wear school uniform? 你上学要穿校服吗？ Was your school co-educational (= for boys and girls) or single-sex? 你们学校是男女兼收，还是只收男生或女生？
2 [U] the time you spend at a school; the process of being educated in a school 上课时间；上学: Their children are still at school. 他们的孩子还在上学。 Children start school at 5 years old in Britain and can leave schoolat 16. 在英国，儿童5岁开始上学，到16岁才可以毕业。 School starts at 9 o'clock and finishes at about 3.30. 上课时间由早上9时开始，约下午3时半结束。 After school we usually have homework to do. 下课后，我们通常要做家庭作业。
You talk about school (no ‘ the ’) when you are talking about going there for the usual reason (that is, as a student or teacher) Where do your children go to school? I enjoyed being at school. Do you walk to school? You talk about the school if you are talking about going there for a different reason (for example, as a parent) I have to go to the school on Thursday to talk to John's teacher. You must also use a or the when more information about the school is given Rani goes to the school in the next village. She teaches at a school for children with learning difficulties. 如果是指基于一般原因到学校去﹙即是学生或老师到学校上课﹚﹐school之前不用定冠词the﹕Where do your children go to school? 你的孩子在哪儿上学﹖I enjoyed being at school. 我喜欢上学。Do you walk to school? 你是走路上学的吗﹖到学校去如果另有原因﹙如以家长身分去﹚﹐要说the school﹕I have to to to the school on Thursday to talk to John's teacher.我要在星期四到学校跟约翰的老师谈谈。当提及更多有关学校的情况时﹐也必须用a或the﹕Rani goes to the school in the next village.拉尼在邻村的学校念书。She teaches at a school for children with learning difficulties.她在一所为学习有困难的孩子开办的学校任教。
3 [sing] [with.sop] all the students and teachers in a school 学校的全体师生: The whole school cheered the winner. 全校师生向优胜者欢呼。
4 (used to form compounds 用于构成复合词) connected with school 跟学校或上学有关: children of school age 学龄儿童 The bus was full of schoolchildren. 公共汽车上挤满了学童。 It is getting increasingly difficult for school-leavers to find jobs. 现在中学毕业生找工作越来越困难。 Schoolteachers have been awarded a 2% pay rise. 中小学教师获加薪2％。 I don't have many good memories of my schooldays. 我的学生时代没有留下很多美好的回忆。
5 [C] a place where you go to learn a particular subject 专科学校: a language/driving/drama/business school 语言╱驾驶╱戏剧╱商业学校
6 [C] (US 美) a college or university 学院；大学
7 [C] a department of a university that teaches a particular subject （大学的）系: the school of geography at Leeds University 利兹大学地理系
8 [C] a group of writers, painters, etc who have the same ideas or style 学派；流派: the Flemish school of painting 佛兰德斯画派
9 [C] a large group of fish swimming together 鱼群
a school of thought the ideas or opinions that one group of people share 学派；流派: There are various schools of thought on this matter. 对于这个问题有各种不同的看法。

schoolboy
/ˈsku:lbɔɪ ||; ˈskulˌbɔɪ/noun [C] a boy who goes to school （中小学）男生

schoolgirl
/ˈsku:lgɜ:l ||; ˈskulˌgɝl/noun [C] a girl who goes to school （中小学）女生

schooling
/ˈsku:lɪŋ ||; ˈskulɪŋ/noun [U] the time that you spend at school; your education 在学校的时间；教育

school-marm
/ˈsku:l mɑ:m ||; ˈskul ˌmɑrm/noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) a woman who teaches in a school, especially one who is old-fashioned and strict ﹙尤指古板而严格的﹚女教师 ➔ˈschool-marmish adj: a school-marmish tone of voice 古板女教师式的口吻

schoolteacher
/ˈsku:lti:tʃə(r) ||; ˈskulˌtitʃɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is teaching in a school （中小学）教师

schoolwork
/ˈsku:lwɜ:k ||; ˈskulˌwɝk/noun [U] work that teachers give their students to do 课堂作业；家庭作业；课外作业

schooner
/ˈsku:nə(r) ||; ˈskunɚ/noun[C]
1 a sailing ship with two or more MASTS(= posts that support the sails) （二桅或以上的）纵帆船
2 a tall glass for beer or SHERRY (= an alcoholic drink) 大啤酒杯；雪利酒杯

schwa
/ʃwɑ: ||; ʃwɑ/noun [C] (technical术语) a vowel sound in parts of words that are not emphasized(stressed), for example the ‘a’ in ‘about’ or the ‘e’ in ‘moment’; the symbol that represents this sound, /ə/ 非重读央元音，弱元音（如about中的a，moment中的e）；非重读央元音符号

*science
/ˈsaɪəns ||; ˈsaɪəns/noun
1 [U] the study of and knowledge about the physical world and natural laws （自然）科学: Modern science has discovered a lot about the origin of life. 现代科学发现了不少有关生命起源的知识。 Fewer young people are studying science at university. 现在大学里修读理科的学生少了。 ☞Compare art. 与art比较。
2 [C] one of the subjects into which science can be divided 某一门科学；理科: Biology, chemistry and physics are all sciences. 生物、化学和物理都是理科。 ☞The study of people and society is called social science. 研究人和社会的学科叫做社会科学(social science)。

ˌscience ˈfiction
(also sci-fi) noun [U] books, films, etc about events that take place in the future, often involving travel in space 科幻小说或电影

*scientific
/ˌsaɪənˈtɪfɪk ||; ˌsaɪənˈtɪfɪk/adj
1 connected with or involving science 与科学有关的；科学的: We need more funding for scientific research. 我们需要更多经费作科学研究。 scientific instruments 科学仪器
2 (used about a way of thinking or of doing sth) careful and logical （指思想或做事方法）仔细的，合乎逻辑的: a scientific study of the way people use language 为了解人们怎样使用语言而进行的科学研究 ➔scientifically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv Sorting out the files won't take long if we do it scientifically. 如果以科学的方法来整理那些档案，那就花不了很多时间。

*scientist
/ˈsaɪəntɪst ||; ˈsaɪəntɪst/noun [C] a person who studies or teaches science, especially biology, chemistry or physics 研究或教授科学（尤指生物学、化学或物理等）的人；科学家

sci-fi
/ˈsaɪ faɪ ||; ˈsaɪ ˈfaɪ/ (informal 非正式)=SCIENCE FICTION

scintilla
/sɪnˈtɪlə ||; sɪnˈtɪlə/noun [sing] scintilla (of sth) (formal 正式) (usually in negative sentences 通常用于否定句) a very small amount of sth 极少；微量: There is not a scintilla of truth in what she says. 她的话没有半句可信。 They had not found a scintilla of evidence against him. 他们没有找到针对他的任何证据。

scintillating
/ˈsɪntɪleɪtɪŋ ||; ˈsɪntḷˌetɪŋ/adj very interesting and showing humour and intelligence 妙趣横生的；才情洋溢的: a scintillating conversation 有趣的谈话 Statistics on unemployment levels hardly make for scintillating reading. 失业统计数据读起来不大会有趣味。

*scissors
/ˈsɪzəz ||; ˈsɪzɚz/noun [pl] a tool for cutting things that consists of two long, flat, sharp pieces of metal that are joined together 剪刀 Scissors is a plural noun These scissors are blunt. We cannot say ‘a scissors’: we must say a pair of scissors. scissors为复数名词：These scissors are blunt.这把剪刀很钝。不能说a scissors。表示一把剪刀，必须说a pair of scissors。

sclerosis
/skləˈrəʊsɪs ||; skləˈrosəs/noun [U] (medical 医学) a condition in which soft tissue in the body becomes hard, in a way that is not normal 硬化；硬化症 ☞ Look at multiple sclerosis. 参看 multiple sclerosis。

scoff
/skɒf; US skɔ:f ||; skɔf/verb
1 [I] scoff (at sb/sth) to speak about sb/sth in a way that shows you think that he/she/it is stupid or ridiculous 嘲笑；讥笑；嘲弄
2 [T] (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) to eat a lot of sth quickly 狼吞虎咽地吃

scold
/skəʊld ||; skold/verb [I,T] scold sb (for sth/for doing sth) to speak angrily to sb because he/she has done something bad or wrong 责骂；斥责 ☞ Tell off is more common. tell off较常用。

scone
/skɒn;skəʊn ||; skɑn; skon/noun [C] a small, simple cake, usually eaten with butter on 小烤饼（通常涂上黄油吃）

scoop¹
/sku:p ||; skup/noun[C]
1 a tool like a spoon used for picking up ice cream, flour, grain, etc 勺子，小铲（用以舀冰淇淋、面粉、谷粒等）
2 the amount that one scoop contains 一勺的量
3 an exciting piece of news that is reported by one newspaper, television or radio station before it is reported anywhere else 抢先报道的新闻；独家新闻
scoop²
/sku:p ||; skup/verb[T]
1 scoop sth (out/up) to make a hole in sth or to take sth out by using a scoop or sth similar 挖出；舀出: Scoop out the middle of the pineapple. 舀出菠萝芯。
2 scoop sb/sth (up) to move or lift sb/sth using a continuous action 拾起；抱起: He scooped up the child and ran. 他抱起孩子就跑。
3 to win a big or important prize 赢得大奖或重要的奖: The film has scooped all the awards this year. 这部电影囊括今年的全部奖项。
4 to get a story before all other newspapers, television stations, etc 抢先获得（新闻）；独家报道

scoot¹
/sku:t ||; skut/verb [I] (informal 非正式) to go or leave somewhere in a hurry 急行；匆匆离去: I'd better scoot or I'll be late. 我得快走，不然我就迟到了。
scoot²
/sku:t ||; skut/ exclamation (informal 非正式) used to tell sb to leave or go away ﹙用于叫某人快走开﹚

scooter
/ˈsku:tə(r) ||; ˈskutɚ/noun[C]
1 a light motorbike with a small engine 小型摩托车；速克达机车 ☞picture at motorbike 见motorbike插图
2 a child's toy with two wheels that you stand on and move by pushing one foot against the ground （儿童的）踏板车

scope
/skəʊp ||; skop/noun
1 [U] scope (for sth/to do sth) the chance or opportunity to do sth 机会: The job offers plenty of scope for creativity. 那项工作有许多发挥创造力的机会。
2 [sing] the variety of subjects that are being discussed or considered （讨论或考虑的）范围: The government was unwilling to extend the scope of the inquiry. 政府不愿扩大调查范围。

scorch
/skɔ:tʃ ||; skɔrtʃ/verb [T] to burn sth so that its colour changes but it is not destroyed 烘焦；烧焦: I scorched my blouse when I was ironing it. 我把我的衬衫烫焦了。

scorching
/ˈskɔ:tʃɪŋ ||; ˈskɔrtʃɪŋ/adj very hot 酷热: It was absolutely scorching on Tuesday. 星期二骄阳似火。

*score¹
/skɔ:(r) ||; skɔr/noun
1 [C] the number of points, goals, etc that sb/sth gets in a game, competition, exam, etc （游戏、比赛、考试等的）分数，得分: What was the final score? 最后的分数是多少？ The score is 3-2 to Liverpool. 比分是3比2，利物浦队获胜。 The top score in the test was 80%. 这次测验最好的成绩是满分的80%。
2 scores [pl] very many 大量；众多: Scores of people have written to offer their support. 许多人写信表示支持。
3 [C] the written form of a piece of music 乐谱
on that score as far as that is concerned 在那一方面；为了那个缘故: Lan will be well looked after. Don't worry on that score. 莱恩会得到妥善的照顾，不必担心这一点。
*score²
/skɔ:(r) ||; skɔr/verb [I,T] to get points, goals, etc in a game, competition, exam, etc 得分；取分: The team still hadn't scored by half-time. 那队在上半场完结时仍未有任何得分。 Louise scored the highest marks in the exam. 路易丝在考试中获得最高分数。

scoreboard
/ˈskɔ:bɔ:d ||; ˈskɔrˌbɔrd/noun [C] a large board that shows the score during a game, competition, etc 记分牌

scorecard
/ˈskɔ:kɑ:d ||; ˈskɔrˌkɑrd/noun [C] a card or piece of paper that people watching or playing a game can use to write the score on, or on which the score can be officially recorded 记分卡

scorn¹
/skɔ:n ||; skɔrn/noun [U] scorn (for sb/sth) the strong feeling that you have when you do not respect sb/sth 蔑视；轻蔑
scorn²
/skɔ:n ||; skɔrn/verb[T]
1 to feel or show a complete lack of respect for sb/sth 蔑视；鄙视: The President scorned his critics. 总统蔑视批评他的人。
2 to refuse to accept help or advice, especially because you are too proud 不屑接受援助或意见: The old lady scorned all offers of help. 那老太太不屑接受任何援助。 ➔scornful /-fl ||; -fəl/ adj a scornful look/smile/remark 轻蔑的眼神╱微笑╱话 ➔scornfully /-fəli ||; -fəlɪ/ adv

Scorpio
/ˈskɔ:piəʊ ||; ˈskɔrpɪˌo/noun [U] the eighth sign of the ZODIAC, the Scorpion 黄道第八宫；天蝎宫；天蝎星座

scorpion
/ˈskɔ:piən ||; ˈskɔrpɪən/noun [C] a creature which looks like a large insect and lives in hot countries. A scorpion has a long curved tail with a poisonous sting in it. 蝎子 ☞picture at arachnid 见arachnid插图

Scot
/skɒt ||; skɑt/noun [C] a person who comes from Scotland 苏格兰人

Scotch
/skɒtʃ ||; skɑtʃ/noun [U] [C] a strong alcoholic drink (whisky) that is made in Scotland; a glass of this 苏格兰威士忌（酒） ☞Look at the note at Scottish. 参看Scottish的注释。

ˈScotch tape™
(US 美) =SELLOTAPE

Scots
/skɒts ||; skɑts/adj of or connected with people from Scotland 苏格兰人的 ☞Look at the note at Scottish. 参看Scottish的注释。

Scottish
/ˈskɒtɪʃ ||; ˈskɑtɪʃ/adj of or connected with Scotland, its people, culture, etc 苏格兰的；苏格兰人的；苏格兰文化的 ☞ Scots is usually only used about the people of Scotland a Scots piper. Scottish is used about Scotland and about both people and things that come from Scotland Scottish law/dancing/music She speaks with a strong Scottish accent. the Scottish Highlands. Scotch is used for whisky and some kinds of food, but not for people Scots通常只指苏格兰人：a Scots piper吹苏格兰风笛的人。Scottish指与苏格兰有关，以及来自苏格兰的人和事物：Scottish law／dancing／music苏格兰法律╱舞蹈╱音乐·She speaks with a strong Scottish accent.她说话带有浓重的苏格兰口音。·the Scottish Highlands苏格兰高地。 Scotch用于指苏格兰威士忌（酒）及某些食物，但不用来指苏格兰人。

scoundrel
/ˈskaʊndrəl ||; ˈskaυndrəl/noun [C] (old-fashioned 旧) a man who behaves very badly towards other people, especially by being dishonest 恶棍；无赖

scour
/ˈskaʊə(r) ||; skaυr/verb[T]
1 to clean sth by rubbing it hard with sth rough 刷净；擦亮: to scour a dirty pan 刷净骯锅
2 to search a place very carefully because you are looking for sb/sth 小心搜索；四处搜寻

scourge
/skɜ:dʒ ||; skɝdʒ/noun [C] a person or thing that causes a lot of trouble or suffering 祸端；祸根；祸害: Raul was the scourge of the United defence. 劳尔是联合队最难防守的队员。

ˈscouring pad
noun [C] a small ball of wire or stiff plastic used for cleaning pans ﹙擦洗用的﹚钢丝球，塑料丝球

scout
/skaʊt ||; skaυt/noun[C]
1 Scout(also Boy ˈScout) a member of an organization(the Scouts), originally for boys, that teaches young people how to look after themselves and encourages them to help others. Scouts do sport, learn useful skills, go camping, etc. 童子军 ☞Look at Guide. 参看Guide。
2 a soldier who is sent on in front of the rest of the group to find out where the enemy is or which is the best route to take 侦察兵

scowl
/skaʊl ||; skaυl/noun [C] a look on your face that shows you are angry or in a bad mood 不悦之色；怒容 ☞Look at frown. 参看frown。 scowl verb [I]

scrabble
/ˈskræbl ||; ˈskræbḷ/verb [I] to move your fingers or feet around quickly, trying to find sth or get hold of sth （用手指或脚）摸索着寻找: She scrabbled about in her purse for some coins. 她伸手到钱包中找寻硬币。

scraggly
/ˈskrægli ||; ˈskræglɪ/adj (scragglier; scraggliest) (US, informal 美，非正式) thin and growing in a way that is not even 稀疏凌乱的；散乱的: a scraggly beard 稀稀拉拉的胡子

scram
