/skræm ||; skræm/ exclamation (old-fashioned, informal 旧，非正式) used to tell sb to go away quickly ﹙用于叫某人快些走开﹚: Scram! I don't want you here. 滚！不要呆在我这儿。

scramble
/ˈskræmbl ||; ˈskræmbḷ/verb[I]
1 to climb quickly up or over sth using your hands to help you; to move somewhere quickly 攀登；爬: He scrambled up the hill and over the wall. 他攀上小山，攀过那道墙。 He scrambled to his feet (= off the ground) and ran off into the trees. 他赶忙站起身，跑进树林里。 The children scrambled into the car. 孩子们爬进车里。
2 scramble (for sth/to do sth) to fight or move quickly to get sth which a lot of people want 快速移动；争夺；抢夺: People stood up and began scrambling for the exits. 人们站起来，开始争相朝出口处走去。 Everyone was scrambling to get the best bargains. 人人争相抢购最合算的便宜货。 ➔scramble noun [sing]

ˌscrambled ˈegg
noun [U] (also ˌscrambled ˈeggs [pl]) eggs mixed together with milk and then cooked in a pan 炒蛋

scrap¹
/skræp ||; skræp/noun
1 [C] a small piece of sth 小片；小块: a scrap of paper/cloth 一小片纸；一小块布 scraps of food 食物碎屑
2 [U] something that you do not want any more but that is made of material that can be used again 废物，废料（其原料可再用）: The old car was sold for scrap. 那辆旧车已作废料出售了。 scrap paper 废纸
3 [C] (informal 非正式) a short fight or argument 打架；争吵
scrap²
/skræp ||; skræp/verb [T] (scrapping;scrapped) to get rid of sth that you do not want any more 抛弃；丢弃: I think we should scrap that idea. 我认为我们应该打消那种念头。

scrapbook
/ˈskræpbʊk ||; ˈskræpˌbυk/noun [C] a large book with empty pages that you can stick pictures, newspaper articles, etc in 剪贴簿

scrape¹
/skreɪp ||; skrep/verb
1 [T] scrape sth (down/out/off) to remove sth from a surface by moving a sharp edge across it firmly 刮；削；刮净: Scrape all the mud off your boots before you come in. 你进来前先刮去靴上的泥。
2 [T] scrape sth (against/along/on sth) to damage or hurt sth by rubbing it against sth rough or hard 擦破；擦伤: Mark fell and scraped his knee. 马克跌倒了，擦破了膝盖。 Sunita scraped the car against the wall. 苏尼塔开车擦到墙。
3 [I,T] scrape (sth) against/along/on sth to rub (sth) against sth and make a sharp unpleasant noise 刮擦而发出刺耳的声音: The branches scraped against the window. 树枝刮擦窗户发出刺耳的声音。
4 [T] to manage to get or win sth with difficulty 艰难地获得或赢得: I just scraped a pass in the maths exam. 我勉强通过数学考试。
scrape by to manage to live on the money you have, but with difficulty 勉强维持生计: We can just scrape by on my salary. 我们靠我的薪金只能勉强维持生计。 scrape through (sth) to succeed in doing sth with difficulty 勉强成功；好不容易才（做了某事）: to scrape through an exam (= just manage to pass it) 勉强通过考试 scrape sth together/up to get or collect sth together with difficulty 勉强得到；好不容易才筹集到
scrape²
/skreɪp ||; skrep/noun[C]
1 the action or unpleasant sound of one thing rubbing against another 刮擦；刮擦的声音
2 damage or an injury caused by rubbing against sth rough 擦坏；擦伤: I got a nasty scrape on my knee. 我把膝盖给严重擦伤了。
3 (informal 非正式) a difficult situation that was caused by your own stupid behaviour （因愚蠢行径而造成的）困境

ˈscrap heap
noun [C] a large pile of objects, especially metal, that are no longer wanted 废物堆（尤指废金属） on the scrap heap not wanted any more 不再需要；当作废物抛弃: Many of the unemployed feel that they are on the scrap heap. 许多失业的人都感到像被社会遗弃一样。

scrappy
/ˈskræpi ||; ˈskræpɪ/adj not organized or tidy and so not pleasant to see 零乱的；杂乱的: a scrappy essay/football match 杂乱无章的作文╱足球赛

*scratch¹
/skrætʃ ||; skrætʃ/verb
1 [I,T] scratch (at sth) to rub your skin with your nails, especially because it is irritating you (itching) 抓；搔；搔痒: Don't scratch at your insect bites or they'll get worse. 给虫子咬了别去搔，不然越搔越糟糕。 Could you scratch my back for me? 你可以给我搔搔背吗？ She sat and scratched her head as she thought about the problem. 她坐着一边搔头，一边想问题。
2 [I,T] to make a mark on a surface or a slight cut on a person's skin with sth sharp 抓破；划破；抓伤；划伤: The cat will scratch if you annoy it. 如果你惹恼这只猫，它会抓你的。 The table was badly scratched. 桌子被严重划花了。
3 [I] to make a sound by rubbing a surface with sth sharp 用尖物刮擦表面而发出声音: The dog was scratching at the door to go outside. 那狗在抓门，想要出去。
4 [T] to use sth sharp to make or remove a mark 用尖物刻上或刮掉痕迹: He scratched his name on the top of his desk. 他把名字刻在桌面上。 I tried to scratch the paint off the table. 我试图刮去桌上的油漆。
*scratch²
/skrætʃ ||; skrætʃ/noun
1 [C] a cut, mark or sound that was made by sb/sth sharp rubbing a surface 抓痕；划痕；刮擦声: There's a scratch on the car door. 车门上有刮痕。 ☞picture at blob 见blob插图
2 [sing] an act of scratching part of the body because it is irritating you (itching) 抓；搔痒: The dog had a good scratch. 那只狗痛痛快快地搔痒。
from scratch from the very beginning 从头做起；从零开始: I'm learning Spanish from scratch. 我正在学习西班牙语，从最基本的开始。 (be/come) up to scratch(informal 非正式) (to be/become) good enough 达到标准；令人满意

ˌscratch-and-ˈsniff
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) a scratch-and-sniff book, magazine, card, etc has a special surface which gives out a smell when it is scratched ﹙书、杂志、卡等﹚擦后可散发香味的

ˈscratch pad
noun [C] (US 美) a small book of cheap paper for writing notes on 便笺簿

scratchy
/ˈskrætʃi ||; ˈskrætʃɪ/adj (scratchier; scratchiest)
1 (used about clothes or fabric) rough and unpleasant to the touch ﹙衣服或织物﹚扎人的，粗糙刺激皮肤的: This sweater is too scratchy. 这件毛衣太扎人了。 a scratchy blanket 感觉扎人的毯子
2 (used about a record, voice, etc) making a rough, unpleasant sound like sth being scratched across a surface ﹙录音、声音等﹚带沙沙的杂音的: a scratchy recording of Mario Lanza 一盘带杂音的马里奥·兰扎演唱录音带 a scratchy pen 一支划纸的钢笔
3(used about writing or drawings) done without care ﹙字迹或图画﹚潦草的，乱画的: She had scrawled me a note in her familiar scratchy handwriting. 她用她惯常的潦草给我草草写了张便条。

scrawl
/skrɔ:l ||; skrɔl/verb [I,T] to write sth quickly in an untidy and careless way 潦草地写: He scrawled his name across the top of the paper. 他在纸的上端潦草地签上自己的名字。 scrawl noun [sing] Her signature was just a scrawl. 她的签名十分潦草。 ☞Look at scribble. 参看scribble。

scrawny
/ˈskrɔ:ni ||; ˈskrɔnɪ/adj (scrawnier; scrawniest) (of people or animals) very thin in a way that is not attractive ﹙人或动物﹚干瘦的，瘦巴巴的: He had long scrawny fingers. 他的手指瘦长。 There were a few scrawny chickens in the yard. 院子里有几只瘦巴巴的小鸡。

*scream¹
/skri:m ||; skrim/verb [I,T] scream (sth) (out) (at sb) to cry out loudly in a high voice because you are afraid, excited, angry, in pain, etc 尖叫，惊呼（因害怕、激动、生气、痛苦等）: She saw a rat and screamed out. 她看见一只老鼠，吓得尖叫起来。 [T] ‘Don't touch that,’ he screamed. 他高声喊道：“别碰那个！” She screamed at the children to stop. 她高声叫孩子们停下来。 He screamed with pain. 他痛苦得尖声喊叫。 He clung to the edge of the cliff, screaming for help. 他抓紧悬崖边，大叫救命。 ☞Look at shout. 参看shout。
scream²
/skri:m ||; skrim/noun
1 [C] a loud cry in a high voice 尖叫声: a scream of pain 痛苦的尖叫
2 [sing] (informal 非正式) a person or thing that is very funny 滑稽可笑的人或事物: Sharon's a real scream. 沙伦真是个滑稽的人。

scree
/skri: ||; skri/noun [U] [C] (in geography 地理学) a steep area of small loose stones, especially on a mountain 岩屑堆，碎石陡坡（尤指山上的）

screech
/skri:tʃ ||; skritʃ/verb[I,T] to make an unpleasant loud, high sound 尖叫；发出尖锐刺耳的声音 [T] ‘Get out of here,’ she screeched at him. 她对他尖声叫道：“滚开！” ☞Look at shriek. 参看shriek。 screech noun [sing] the screech of brakes 刺耳的煞车声

*screen¹
/skri:n ||; skrin/noun
1 [C] a flat vertical surface that is used for dividing a room or keeping sb/sth out of sight 隔板；屏；屏风: The nurse pulled the screen round the bed. 护士把屏风拉过来，围在床的周围。
2 [C] the glass surface of a television or computer where the picture or information appears 屏幕；荧光屏 ☞picture on page S2 见S2页插图
3 [C] the large flat surface on which films are shown 银幕
4 [sing] [U] films or television in general 电影；电视: Some actors look better in real life than on screen. 有些演员在现实生活中的样子要比在电影里好看。
screen²
/skri:n ||; skrin/verb[T]
1 screen sb/sth (off) (from sb/sth) to hide or protect sb/sth from sb/sth else 遮蔽；掩护: The bed was screened off while the doctor examined him. 医生替他检查身体时用屏风把病床遮蔽起来。 to screen your eyes from the sun 遮住眼睛以免阳光刺眼
2 screen sb (for sth) to examine or test sb to find out if he/she has a particular disease or if he/she is suitable for a particular job 检查（疾病）；审查；筛选；甄别；选拔: All women over 50 should be screened for breast cancer. 所有年过50的女性都应该接受乳癌检查。 The Ministry of Defence screens all job applicants. 国防部审查所有的求职者。
3 to show sth on television or in a cinema 播放；放映

ˈscreen door
noun [C] an outside door, usually on a house, that is like a frame of wire net, so that fresh air can come into the house in summer but insects cannot 纱门

screening
/ˈskri:nɪŋ ||; ˈskrinɪŋ/noun
1 [C] the act of showing a film/movie or television programme 放映；播放: This will be the movie's first screening in this country. 这将是这部电影首次在这个国家上映。
2 [C,U] the testing or examining of a large number of people or things for disease, faults, etc 筛查: breast cancer screening 乳腺癌筛查

ˈscreen saver
noun [C] a computer program that replaces what is on the screen with a moving image if the computer is not used for certain amount of time （计算机的）屏幕保护程序，荧幕保护程序

ˈscreen test
noun [C] a filmed test to see if sb is suitable to appear in a film/movie ﹙挑选演员时的﹚试镜头

screenwriter
/ˈskri:nraɪtə(r) ||; ˈskrinˌraɪtɚ/noun [C] a person who writes screenplays 电影剧本作家 ☞ Look also at scriptwriter⇒. 另参看 scriptwriter⇒。

*screw¹
/skru: ||; skru/noun [C] a thin pointed piece of metal used for fixing two things, for example pieces of wood, together. You turn a screw with a special tool (a screwdriver). 螺丝；螺丝钉 ☞picture at bolt 见bolt插图
screw²
/skru: ||; skru/verb
1 [T] screw sth (on, down, etc) to fasten sth with a screw or screws 用螺丝钉钉住或固定（某物）: The bookcase is screwed to the wall. 这个书架是用螺丝钉固定在墙上的。 The lid is screwed down so you can't remove it. 这盖子是用螺丝钉固定的，因此是摘不掉的。
2 [I,T] to fasten sth, or to be fastened, by turning 扭紧；拧紧: The legs screw into holes in the underside of the seat. 椅脚都旋入座位底部的孔里。 Make sure that you screw the top of the jar on tightly. 务须把瓶盖拧紧。
3 screw sth (up) (into sth) to squeeze sth, especially a piece of paper, into a tight ball 把某物揉成一团（尤指一张纸）: He screwed the letter up into a ball and threw it away. 他把那封信揉成一团扔掉。
screw (sth) up(slang 俚语) to make a mistake and cause sth to fail 犯错而使某事失败；搞砸: You'd better not screw up this deal. 你最好别把这笔交易搞砸。 screw your eyes, face, etc up to change the expression on your face by nearly closing your eyes, in pain or because the light is strong （因强光或痛苦而）瞇眼，脸部扭曲

screwball
/ˈskru:bɔ:l ||; ˈskruˌbɔl/noun [C] (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) a strange or crazy person 怪人；狂人: That guy's a complete screwball. 那家伙纯粹是个疯子。

*screwdriver
/ˈskru:draɪvə(r) ||; ˈskruˌdraɪvɚ/noun [C] a tool that you use for turning screws 螺丝刀；螺丝起子 ☞picture at tool 见tool插图

ˌscrewed-ˈup
adj (informal 非正式) upset and anxious, especially because of sth bad that has happened to you in the past ﹙尤指因曾遭不幸﹚焦虑而紧张的: an extremely screwed-up kid 一个十分神经质的孩子

screwy
/ˈskru:i ||; ˈskruɪ/adj (screwier; screwiest) (informal 非正式) strange or crazy 古怪的；荒诞的；疯狂的: What a screwy idea! 多荒唐的念头！

scribble
/ˈskrɪbl ||; ˈskrɪbḷ/verb[I,T]
1 to write sth quickly and carelessly 潦草地或匆匆地书写 [T] to scribble a note down on a pad 在拍纸簿上草草写下一点东西 ☞Look at scrawl. 参看scrawl。
2 to make marks with a pen or pencil that are not letters or pictures 乱涂；乱画: The children had scribbled all over the walls. 孩子们在墙壁上到处乱涂。 scribble noun [C,U]

scrimp
/skrɪmp ||; skrɪmp/verb [I] to spend very little money on the things that you need to live, especially so that you can save it to spend on sth else 省吃俭用；节衣缩食: They scrimped and saved to give the children a good education. 他们省吃俭用，为的是攒钱让孩子受到良好的教育。 scrimp on sth to spend too little money on sth or buy sth that is of poor quality 吝啬；买劣质货: If you're going to do a good job of renovating an old house, don't scrimp on materials. 假如你要好好地装修一间老房子，不要在材料上省钱。

script
/skrɪpt ||; skrɪpt/noun
1 [C] the written form of a play, film, speech, etc （戏剧、电影等的）剧本；讲稿: Who wrote the script for the movie? 这电影剧本是谁写的？
2 [C,U] a system of writing 文字体系 · Arabic/Cyrillic/Roman script 阿拉伯╱西里尔╱罗马文字的字母

scripted
/ˈskrɪptɪd ||; ˈskrɪptɪd/adj read from a script (1) 照原稿念的: a scripted discussion 照稿子念的讨论 [OPP]unscripted 反义词为unscripted

scripture
/ˈskrɪptʃə(r) ||; ˈskrɪptʃɚ/noun [U] (also the scriptures [pl]) books of religious importance for particular religions, such as the Bible for Christians （宗教）经文，圣典（例如圣经）

scriptwriter
/ˈskrɪptraɪtə(r) ||; ˈskrɪptˌraɪtɚ/noun [C] a person who writes the script (1) for films/movies, television and radio plays ﹙电影、电视剧等的﹚剧作家，编剧 ☞ Look also at screenwriter⇒. 另参看 screenwriter⇒。

scroll¹
/skrəʊl ||; skrol/noun [C] a long roll of paper with writing on it （载有书写文字的）纸卷，滚动条
scroll²
/skrəʊl ||; skrol/verb [I] scroll (up/down) to move text up and down or left and right on a computer screen （在计算机屏幕上）上下或左右移动，滚动

ˈscroll bar
/ˈskrəʊl ba:/noun [C] a tool on a computer screen that you use to move the text up and down or left and right 滚动条，滚动条（用于在计算机屏幕上上下或左右移动文件的工具） ☞picture on page S3 见S3页插图

scrotum
/ˈskrəʊtəm ||; ˈskrotəm/noun [C] the bag of skin that contains the two roundish male sex organs(testicles) 阴囊

scrounge
/skraʊndʒ ||; skraυndʒ/verb [I,T] (informal 非正式)scrounge (sth) (from/off sb) to get sth by asking another person to give it to you instead of making an effort to get it for yourself 向人索取 · Lucy is always scrounging money off her friends. 露西总是向朋友要钱。

scrub¹
/skrʌb ||; skrʌb/verb [I,T] (scrubbing;scrubbed)
1 scrub (sth) (down/out) to clean sth with soap and water by rubbing it hard, often with a brush 用力擦洗 [I,T] to scrub (down) the floor/walls 擦洗地板╱墙壁
2 scrub (sth) (off/out);scrub (sth) (off sth/out of sth) to remove sth or be removed by scrubbing 擦去；擦掉: to scrub the dirt off the walls 将墙上的污渍擦掉 I hope these coffee stains will scrub out. 我希望这些咖啡渍擦洗得掉。
scrub²
/skrʌb ||; skrʌb/noun
1 [sing] an act of cleaning sth by rubbing it hard, often with a brush 擦洗；擦净: This floor needs a good scrub. 地板需要彻底擦洗一下。
2 [U] small trees and bushes that grow in an area that has very little rain 矮树丛；灌木丛
3 (also ˈscrubland /ˈskrʌblənd ||; ˈskrʌbˌlænd/) [U] an area of dry land covered with small bushes and trees 丛林干地

scruff
/skrʌf ||; skrʌf/noun by the scruff (of the/your neck) by the back of the/your neck 抓住或拎起…的颈背

scruffy
/ˈskrʌfi ||; ˈskrʌfɪ/adj dirty and untidy 不整洁的；邋遢的: He always looks so scruffy. 他的外表总是很不整洁。 scruffy jeans 肮脏的牛仔裤

scrum
/skrʌm ||; skrʌm/noun [C] the part of a game of RUGBY when several players put their heads down in a circle and push against each other to try to get the ball （橄榄球比赛中）并列争球

scrumptious
/ˈskrʌmpʃəs ||; ˈskrʌmpʃəs/adj (informal 非正式) tasting very good 美味的；非常好吃的 [SYN]delicious 同义词为delicious

scrunch
/skrʌntʃ ||; skrʌntʃ/verb
1 [I] to make a loud sound like the one that is made when you walk on small stones (gravel) 发喀嚓喀嚓声；发出嘎吱声: The snow scrunched underfoot. 雪在脚下发出喀嚓喀嚓的声音。
2 [T] scrunch sth (up) to squeeze sth into a small round shape in your hands 把…揉成一团: He scrunched up the note and threw it on the fire. 他把便条揉成一团，扔进了火里。
3 [T] scrunch sth (up) to make sth become smaller 使蜷缩；使收缩: The hedgehog scrunched itself up into a ball. 刺猬蜷成一个圆球。
4 [T] to create a style of hair with loose curls by squeezing the hair with the hands 用手挤压﹙头发﹚使之拳曲

scrunchie
/ˈskrʌntʃi ||; ˈskrʌntʃɪ/noun [C] a circular band of elastic that is covered with fabric and is used for fastening the hair ﹙用来扎头发的﹚布制橡皮圈，布制发圈

scruples
/ˈskru:plz ||; ˈskrupḷz/noun [pl] a feeling that stops you from doing sth that you think is morally wrong 良心（上的不安）；顾忌；顾虑: I've got no scruples about asking them for money (= I don't think it's wrong). 向他们要钱，我不觉得于心不安。

scrupulous
/ˈskru:pjələs ||; ˈskrupjələs/adj
1 very careful or paying great attention to detail 小心谨慎的；一丝不苟的；认真严格的: a scrupulous investigation into the causes of the disaster 审慎地探究祸因
2 careful to do what is right or honest 审慎的；正直的 [OPP] unscrupulous 反义词为unscrupulous ➔scrupulously adv scrupulously clean/honest/tidy 十分干净╱诚实╱整洁

scrutinize
/ˈskru:tɪnaɪz; US -tənaɪz ||; ˈskrutṇˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] (written 书面语) to look at or examine sth carefully 细看；仔细检查: The customs official scrutinized every page of my passport. 海关官员把我的护照一页不漏地仔细看了一遍。 ➔scrutiny /ˈskru:təni; US skru:tənɪ ||; ˈskrutṇɪ/ noun [U]: The police kept all the suspects under close scrutiny. 警方严密监视所有疑犯。

scuba-diving
/ˈsku:bə daɪvɪŋ ||; ˈskubə ˌdaɪvɪŋ/noun [U] swimming under water using special equipment for breathing 用水肺潜水: to go scuba-diving 去戴水肺潜水 ☞picture at dive 见dive插图

scuff
/skʌf ||; skʌf/verb [T] to make a mark on your shoes or with your shoes, for example by kicking sth or by rubbing your feet along the ground 在鞋上留下痕迹；用鞋在…上留下痕迹

scuffle
/ˈskʌfl ||; ˈskʌfḷ/noun [C] a short, not very violent fight 扭打；混战

sculpted
/ˈskʌlptɪd ||; ˈskʌlptɪd/adj having a clear, smooth shape as though sculpted by an artist 轮廓清晰的: models with high, sculpted cheekbones 有着轮廓清晰的高颧骨的模特儿

sculptor
/ˈskʌlptə(r) ||; ˈskʌlptɚ/noun [C] a person who makes figures or objects (sculptures) from stone, wood, etc 雕刻家；雕塑家

sculptural
/ˈskʌlptʃərəl ||; ˈskʌlptʃərəl/adj of or relating to sculpture or appearing to have been sculpted by an artist 雕刻的；雕塑的；似雕塑的: sculptural works/decoration 雕刻作品/装饰

sculpture
/ˈskʌlptʃə(r) ||; ˈskʌlptʃɚ/noun
1 [U] the art of making figures or objects from stone, wood, clay, etc 雕刻艺术；雕塑艺术
2 [C,U] a work or works of art that were made in this way 雕刻品；雕塑品

scum
/skʌm ||; skʌm/noun[U]
1 a dirty or unpleasant substance on the surface of a liquid 浮垢；浮渣
2 (slang 俚语) an insulting word for people that you have no respect for 卑贱的人；渣滓: Drug dealers are scum. 毒品贩子都是社会渣滓。

scurry
/ˈskʌri ||; ˈskʌrɪ/verb [I] (present participle scurrying third person singular present scurries;past tense past participle scurried) to run quickly with short steps; to hurry 小步急跑；疾走

scurvy
/ˈskɜ:vi ||; ˈskɝvɪ/noun [U] a disease caused by a lack of VITAMIN C 坏血病（缺少维生素C所致）

scuttle
/ˈskʌtl ||; ˈskʌtḷ/verb [I] to run quickly with short steps or with the body close to the ground 小步急跑；身体贴近地面快跑: The spider scuttled away when I tried to catch it. 我想捉那蜘蛛的时候，它仓惶逃跑。

scuzzy
/ˈskʌzi ||; ˈskʌzɪ/adj (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) dirty and unpleasant 肮脏讨厌的；邋遢的

scythe
/saɪð ||; saɪð/noun [C] a tool with a long handle and a long, curved piece of metal with a very sharp edge (a blade). You use a scythe to cut long grass, corn etc. 长柄大镰刀

SE
abbr south-east(ern) 东南方（的）: SE Asia 东南亚

*sea
/si: ||; si/noun
1 oftenthe sea [U] the salt water that covers large parts of the surface of the earth 海；海洋: The sea is quite calm/rough today. 今天海面颇为平静╱波涛汹涌。 Do you live by the sea ? 你住在海边吗？ to travel by sea 乘船旅行 There were several people swimming in the sea. 有几个人在海里游泳。 ☞picture on page C8 见C8页插图
2 oftenSea [C] a particular large area of salt water. A sea may be part of the ocean or may be surrounded by land. 海；海洋中的一片水域；内海: the Mediterranean Sea 地中海 the Black Sea 黑海 ☞Look at ocean. 参看ocean。
3 [sing] (also seas [pl]) the state or movement of the waves of the sea 海面状况；海浪: The boat sank in heavy (= rough) seas off the Scottish coast. 那船在苏格兰近海遇上巨浪，沉没了。
4 [sing] a large amount of sb/sth close together 紧靠一起的大批人或事物
at sea
1 sailing in a ship 航行；航海: They spent about three weeks at sea. 他们在海上航行了大约三个星期。
2 not understanding or not knowing what to do 茫然；困惑；不知所措

ˈsea anemone
noun [C] a small, brightly-coloured sea creature that lives on rocks and looks like a flower 海葵 ☞Look at anemone. 参看anemone。

seabird
/ˈsi:bɜ:d ||; ˈsiˌbɝd/noun [C] any bird that lives close to the sea and gets its food from it 海鸟 ☞Compare waterbird. 与waterbird比较。

seaboard
/ˈsi:bɔ:d ||; ˈsiˌbɔrd/noun [C] the part of a country that is along its coast 沿海地区；海滨: Canada's eastern seaboard 加拿大东部沿海地区

ˌsea ˈbreeze
noun [C] a wind blowing from the sea or ocean toward the land 海风

seafood
/ˈsi:fu:d ||; ˈsiˌfud/noun [U] fish and shellfish from the sea that can be eaten 海产食物；海味；海鲜

seagull
/ˈsi:gʌl ||; ˈsiˌgʌl/ =GULL

ˈsea horse
noun [C] a small sea fish that swims in a vertical position and has a head that looks like the head of a horse 海马

seal¹
/si:l ||; sil/noun[C]
1 a grey animal with short fur that lives in and near the sea and that eats fish. Seals have no legs and swim with the help of short flat arms(flippers). 海豹
2 an official design or mark that is put on a document, an envelope, etc to show that it is genuine or that it has not been opened 封蜡；火漆
3 a small piece of paper, metal, plastic, etc on a packet, bottle, etc that you must break before you can open it 封口；封条
4 something that stops air or liquid from getting in or out of something 封塞；封口: The seal has worn and oil is escaping. 封口破损了，油正往外渗漏。
seal²
/si:l ||; sil/verb[T]
1 seal sth (up/down) to close or fasten a package, envelope, etc 封；封装: The parcel was sealed with tape. 那个包裹已用胶带封好了。 to seal (down) an envelope 给信封封口
2 seal sth (up) to fill a hole or cover sth so that air or liquid does not get in or out 封闭；密封: The food is packed in sealed bags to keep it fresh. 食物装在密封的袋子里以保鲜。
3 (formal 正式) to make sth sure, so that it cannot be changed or argued about 保证；确认: to seal an agreement 签署一项协议
seal sth off to stop any person or thing from entering or leaving an area or building 封锁；封闭: The building was sealed off by the police. 警方封锁了大厦。

ˈsea level
noun [U] the average level of the sea, used for measuring the height of places on land 海平面；海拔: The town is 500 metres above sea level. 这个镇海拔500米。

ˈsea lion
noun [C] a type of large animal that lives in the sea and on land and uses two flat arms (flippers) to move through the water 海狮

seam
/si:m ||; sim/noun[C]
1 the line where two pieces of cloth are sewn together （连接两块布的）缝，线缝，缝口 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图
2 a layer of coal under the ground 煤层

seaman
/ˈsi:mən ||; ˈsimən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) a sailor 水手；海员

seamless
/ˈsi:mləs ||; ˈsimləs/adj
1 (used about a fabric) without a seam ﹙织物﹚无接缝的: a seamless garment 无缝衣服
2 with no spaces or pauses between one part and the next 无空隙的；不停顿的: a seamless flow of talk 连贯流畅的谈话 ➔seamlessly adv

seamy
/ˈsi:mi ||; ˈsimɪ/adj (seamier; seamiest) unpleasant and immoral 污秽的；肮脏丑恶的: a seamy sex scandal 龌龊的性丑闻 the seamier side of life生活的阴暗面 [SYN]sordid 同义词为 sordid

seance
/ˈseɪ~ɒs ||; ˈseɑns/ (also séance) noun [C] a meeting at which people try to talk to the spirits of dead people 招魂会；降灵会

seaplane
/ˈsi:pleɪn ||; ˈsiˌplen/ (US also 美亦作 hydroplane) noun [C] a plane that can take off from and land on water 水上飞机

seaport
/ˈsi:pɔ:t ||; ˈsiˌpɔrt/noun [C] a town with a harbour used by large ships 海港城市: the Baltic seaports 波罗的海港口城市

sear
/sɪə(r) ||; sɪr/verb
1 [T] to burn the surface of sth in a way that is sudden and powerful 烧灼；灼伤；烤焦；轻煎: The heat of the sun seared their faces. 烈日把他们的脸都晒得起了皮。 Sear the meat first(= cook the outside of it quickly at a high temperature) to retain its juices. 先把肉稍煎一下以保持肉汁。
2 [I,T] (written 书面语) to cause sb to feel sudden and great pain 使骤然感到剧痛: The pain seared along her arm. 她的胳膊一阵剧痛。

*search¹
/sɜ:tʃ ||; sɝtʃ/verb [I,T] search (sb/sth) (for sb/sth);search (through sth) (for sth) to examine sb/sth carefully because you are looking for sth; to look for sth that is missing 搜查；搜索；搜寻 · The men were arrested and searched for drugs. 那几个男子被逮捕并搜身，看看是否带有毒品。 Were your bags searched at the airport? 你的包在机场被搜查了吗？ They are still searching for the missing child. 他们仍然在搜寻那个失踪的儿童。 She searched through the papers on the desk, looking for the letter. 她翻遍桌子上的文件，寻找那封信。 I started searching the Web for interesting sites. 我开始了在万维网上搜寻有趣的网站。
*search²
/sɜ:tʃ ||; sɝtʃ/noun
1 [C,U] an act of trying to find sb/sth, especially by looking carefully for him/her/it 搜寻；搜查；搜索: the search for the missing boy 搜寻那个失踪的儿童 She walked round for hours in search of (= looking for) her missing dog. 她到处转了几个小时，寻找她那条失踪的狗。
2 [C] (computing计算机技术) an act of looking for information in a computer DATABASE or NETWORK 查找；搜索；检索: to do a search on the Internet 在因特网上查找 a search engine(= a program that does searches) 检索引擎

ˈsearch engine
noun [C] (computing 计算机技术) a computer program that searches the Internet for information, especially by looking for documents containing a particular word or group of words 搜索引擎

searcher
/ˈsɜ:tʃə(r) ||; ˈsɝtʃɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who is looking for sb/sth 搜寻者；搜查者
2 a program that allows you to look for particular information on a computer （计算机的）搜索器，搜寻器

searching
/ˈsɜ:tʃɪŋ ||; ˈsɝtʃɪŋ/adj (used about a look, question, etc) trying to find out the truth （指神情、问题等）探究真相的: The customs officers asked a lot of searching questions about our trip. 海关人员就我们这次旅行问了许多寻根究底的问题。

searchlight
/ˈsɜ:tʃlaɪt ||; ˈsɝtʃˌlaɪt/noun [C] a powerful lamp that can be turned in any direction, used, for example, for finding people or vehicles at night 探照灯

ˈsearch party
noun [C] a group of people who look for sb who is lost or missing 搜索队

ˈsearch warrant
noun [C] an official piece of paper that gives the police the right to search a building, etc 搜查证；搜查令；搜索状

seashell
/ˈsi:ʃel ||; ˈsiˌʃɛl/noun [C] the empty shell of a small animal that lives in the sea 贝壳

seashore
/ˈsi:ʃɔ:(r) ||; ˈsiˌʃɔr/ usuallythe seashore noun [U] the part of the land that is next to the sea 海滨；海岸: We were looking for shells on the seashore. 我们在海边找贝壳。

seasick
/ˈsi:sɪk/adj feeling sick or vomiting because of the movement of a boat or ship 晕船的: to feel/get/be seasick 晕船 ☞Look at airsick, carsick and travel-sick. 参看airsick、carsick及travel-sick。

seaside
/ˈsi:saɪd ||; ˈsiˌsaɪd/noun oftenthe seaside [sing] an area on the coast, especially one where people go on holiday 海边，海滨（尤指度假的地方）: to go to the seaside 去海边 a seaside town 海滨小镇

*season¹
/ˈsi:zn ||; ˈsizṇ/noun[C]
1 one of the periods of different weather into which the year is divided （一年中的）季: In cool countries, the four seasons are spring, summer, autumn and winter. 温带地区有春、夏、秋、冬四个季节。 the dry/rainy season 旱季；雨季
2 the period of the year when sth is common or popular or when sth usually happens or is done 季节；旺季: the holiday/football season 度假旺季；足球赛季
in season
1 (used about fresh foods) available in large quantities （指新鲜食物）当令，应时
2 (used about a female animal) ready to have sex （指雌性动物）在发情期
out of season
1 (used about fresh foods) not available in large quantities （指新鲜食物）不当令，不应时
2 (used about a place where people go on holiday) at the time of year when it is least popular with tourists （指度假胜地）在游客最少的期间，在淡季
season²
/ˈsi:zn ||; ˈsizṇ/verb [T] to add salt, pepper, spices, etc to food in order to make it taste better 给食物调味 ➔seasoning noun [C,U] Add seasoning to the soup and serve with bread. 在汤里加调味品，跟面包一起端上桌。

seasonal
/ˈsi:zənl ||; ˈsizṇəl/adj happening or existing at a particular time of the year 季节性的: There are a lot of seasonal jobs in the summer. 在夏天有许多季节性的工作。

seasoned
/ˈsi:znd ||; ˈsizṇd/adj having a lot of experience of sth 经验丰富的；老练的: a seasoned traveller 经验丰富的旅行家

ˈseason ticket
noun [C] a ticket that allows you to make a particular journey by bus, train, etc or to go to a theatre or watch a sports team as often as you like for a fixed period of time 定期票，季票（在某一段时间内可无限次使用）

*seat¹
/si:t ||; sit/noun[C]
1 something that you sit on 座位: Please take a seat (= sit down). 请坐下。 the back/driving/passenger seat of a car 汽车的后排╱司机╱乘客座位 ☞pictures at car and motorbike 见car及motorbike插图
2 the part of a chair, etc that you sit on 椅子等的座部
3 a place in a theatre, on a plane, etc where you pay to sit （剧院、飞机等的）座位: There are no seats left on that flight. 那趟班机满座了。
4 a place on a council or in a parliament that you win in an election （议会或国会的）席位: to win/lose a seat 赢得╱失去一席
be in the driving seat to be the person, group, etc that has the most powerful position in a particular situation 处于统治或控制地位 take a back seat→BACK²
seat²
/si:t ||; sit/verb[T]
1 (often passive 常用于被动语态) (formal 正式) to sit down 坐下: Please be seated. 请就座。
2 to have seats or chairs for a particular number of people 有（某数量的）座位；可坐（某数量的人）

ˈseat belt
(also safety belt) noun [C] a strap that is fixed to the seat in a car or plane and that you wear around your body so that you are not thrown forward if there is an accident （汽车或飞机座位上的）安全带: to fasten/unfasten your seat belt 系上╱解开安全带 ☞Look at belt. 参看belt。 ☞picture at car 见car插图

seating
/ˈsi:tɪŋ ||; ˈsitɪŋ/noun [U] the seats or chairs in a place or the way that they are arranged 座位；座位安排或设置: The conference hall has seating for 500 people. 会议厅可坐500人左右。

ˈsea turtle
(US 美) =TURTLE

sea urchin ( also urchin)
noun [C] a small sea creature with a round shell which is covered with spines (2) 海胆

ˈsea water
noun [U] water from the sea or ocean, which is salty 海水

seaway
/ˈsi:weɪ ||; ˈsiˌwe/noun [C] a passage from the sea through the land, along which large ships can travel 海道﹙大型海轮可航行的通海河道﹚: In 1959 the St. Lawrence Seaway opened to shipping. * 1959 年，圣劳伦斯海道开航。

seaweed
/ˈsi:wi:d ||; ˈsiˌwid/noun [U] a plant that grows in the sea. There are many different types of seaweed. 海藻；海草

seaworthy
/ˈsi:wɜ:ði ||; ˈsiˌwɝðɪ/adj (used about a ship 指船) in a suitable condition to sail 适宜航海的 ➔seaworthiness noun [U]

sebaceous
/sɪˈbeɪʃəs ||; sɪˈbeʃəs/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) (technical术语) producing a substance like oil in the body 皮脂的: the sebaceous glands in the skin 皮肤中的皮脂腺

sec
/sek ||; sɛk/noun [C] (informal 非正式)=SECOND²(2)

secateurs
/ˌsekəˈtɜ:z ||; ˈsɛkəˌtɝz,/noun [pl] (Brit 英) a garden tool like a pair of strong scissors, used for cutting plants and small branches 整枝剪；修枝剪: a pair of secateurs 一把整枝剪 ☞picture at garden 见garden插图

secede
/sɪˈsi:d ||; sɪˈsid/verb [I] secede (from sth)(formal 正式) (used about a state, country, etc 指州、国家等) to officially leave an organization of states, countries, etc and become independent 退出，脱离（联邦、同盟等）: The Republic of Panama seceded from Colombia in 1903. 巴拿马共和国于1903年脱离哥伦比亚独立。

secluded
/sɪˈklu:dɪd ||; sɪˈkludɪd/adj far away from other people, roads, etc; very quiet 隐蔽的；偏僻的；僻静的: a secluded beach/garden 偏僻的海滩；僻静的花园 ➔seclusion /sɪˈklu:ʒn ||; sɪˈkluʒən/ noun [U]

*second¹
/ˈsekənd ||; ˈsɛkənd/pronoun det adv noun 2nd 第二（个）: We are going on holiday in the second week in July. 我们将于七月的第二个星期去度假。 Birmingham is the second largest city in Britain after London. 伯明翰是英国仅次于伦敦的第二大城市。 She poured herself a second cup of coffee. 她替自己倒了第二杯咖啡。 Our team finished second. 我队得到第二名。 I came second in the competition. 我在比赛中获得亚军。 Queen Elizabeth the Second 女王伊莉萨白二世 the second ofJanuary 一月二日 January the second 一月二日 second nature (to sb) something that has become a habit or that you can do easily because you have done it so many times 习性；第二天性: With practice, typing becomes second nature. 只要经过练习，打字就成为驾轻就熟的事了。 second thoughts a change of mind or opinion about sth; doubts that you have when you are not sure if you have made the right decision 重新考虑: On second thoughts, let's go today, not tomorrow. 经过重新考虑后，我想我们今天就去，不要等到明天。 I'm starting to have second thoughts about accepting their offer. 我正在重新考虑是否接纳他们的提议。
*second²
/ˈsekənd ||; ˈsɛkənd/noun
1 [C] one of the 60 parts into which a minute is divided 秒
2 (informal 非正式sec) [C] a short time 一段短时间: Wait a second, please. 请等一等。
3 [U] the second of the four or five speeds (gears) that a car can move forward in 汽车的二档: Once the car's moving, put it in second. 汽车开动以后就调到二档。
4 [C] [usu.pl] something that has a small fault and that is sold at a lower price 剔庄货；次货: The clothes are all seconds. 这些衣服全都是剔庄货。
5 [C] (formal 正式)a second (in sth) the second-best result in a British university degree （英国大学的）二等学位: to get an upper/a lower second in physics 获得物理学二等一级╱二级学位
second³
/ˈsekənd ||; ˈsɛkənd/verb [T] to support sb's suggestion or idea at a meeting so that it can then be discussed and voted on （会议上）附和（某提议、动议等）
second⁴
/sɪˈkɒnd ||; ˈsɛkənd/verb [T] second sb (from sth) (to sth) to move sb from his/her job for a fixed period of time to do another job 临时调任: Our teacher has been seconded to another school for a year. 我们的老师被临时调派到另一所学校，为期一年。 ➔secondment noun [U] [C]: to be on secondment 在调任中

*secondary
/ˈsekəndri; US -derɪ ||; ˈsɛkənˌdɛrɪ/adj
1 less important than sth else 次要的: Other people's opinions are secondary -- it's my opinion that counts. 其他人的意见是次要的，我的意见才重要。
2 caused by or developing from sth else 别的事物引致或发展而来的；继发的

ˈsecondary school
noun [C] (Brit 英) a school for children aged from 11 to 18 中学，中等学校（学生年龄由11岁至18岁）

ˌsecond-ˈbest¹
adj not quite the best but the next one after the best 仅次于最好的；居于第二位的: the second-best time in the 100 metres race 100米赛跑仅次于最快的时间 ☞Look at best. 参看best。
ˌsecond-ˈbest²
noun [U] something that is not as good as the best, or not as good as you would like 退而求其次的事物: I'm not prepared to accept second-best. 我不想退而求其次。

ˌsecond-ˈclass
adj
1 (also standard class) used about ordinary accommodation in a train, etc （火车车厢等）二等: a second-class ticket 二等票 a second-class compartment 二等车厢
2 (used about a university degree) of the level that is next after first-class （指大学学位）二等的，二级的: a second-class honours degree in geography 地理学二等学位
3 of little importance 不重要: Old people should not be treated as second-class citizens. 老年人不应该被视为次等公民。 ˌsecond-ˈclass adv to travel second-class 乘坐二等座位旅游 to send a letter second-class 按第二类邮费投寄信件

ˌsecond ˈclass
noun [U]
1 (also standard class) ordinary accommodation in a train, boat, etc （火车、船只等的）二等车厢，二等舱
2 the way of sending letters, etc that is cheaper but that takes longer than first class 第二类邮费（较第一类邮费便宜，但邮递时间较长）

ˌsecond ˈcousin
noun [C] the child of your mother's or father's COUSIN 父母的堂或表兄弟姐妹的子女

ˌsecond-deˈgree
adj (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前)
1 (especially US 尤为美) (used about murder 指谋杀罪) not of the most serious kind 二等的；二级的
2 (used about burns 指烧伤) of the second most serious of three kinds, causing the skin to form bubbles(blisters)but not leaving any permanent marks （第）二度的（三种烧伤中的第二种，皮上起水，但不留永久疤痕） ☞Look at first-degree and third-degree. 参看first-degree及third-degree。

ˌsecond ˈfloor
noun [C] the floor in a building that is two floors above the lowest floor 三楼: I live on the second floor. 我住在三楼。 a second-floor flat 三楼的公寓 In American English the second floor is next above the lowest. 在美国英语中second floor是二楼。

ˌsecond-ˈguess
verb [T]
1 to guess what sb will do before he/she does it 猜测；预言: It was impossible to second-guess the decision of the jury. 陪审团的决定不可能预测。
2 to criticize sb after a decision has been made; to criticize sth after it has happened 事后批评；耍事后聪明: There's no point in second-guessing the issue now. 现在事后就这个问题说长道短已毫无意义。

ˌsecond-ˈhand
adj adv
1 already used or owned by sb else 用过的；旧的；二手的: a second-hand car 一辆旧车 I bought this camera second-hand. 我买的这部照相机是二手货。 ☞Look at old. 参看old。
2 (used about news or information) that you heard from sb else, and did not see or experience yourself （指新闻或消息）间接获知的，二手的 ☞Look at hand. 参看hand。

ˌsecond ˈlanguage
noun [C] a language that is not the language that you learned first, as a child, but which you learn because it is used, often for official purposes, in your country 第二语言: French is the second language of several countries in Africa. 法语是几个非洲国家的第二语言。

secondly
/ˈsekəndli ||; ˈsɛkəndlɪ/adv (used when you are giving your second reason or opinion) also （用于提出第二个理由或意见）第二，其次: Firstly, I think it's too expensive and secondly, we don't really need it. 首先我认为价钱太贵了；其次我们也并不真正需要它。

ˌsecond-ˈrate
adj of poor quality 二流的: a second-rate poet 二流的诗人

secrecy
/ˈsi:krəsi ||; ˈsikrəsɪ/noun [U] being secret or keeping sth secret 秘密（状态）；保密: I must stress the importance of secrecy in this matter. 我必须强调这件事保密的重要性。
*secret²
/ˈsi:krət ||; ˈsikrət/adj
1 secret (from sb) that is not or must not be known by other people 秘密的；机密的；保密的: We have to keep the party secretfrom Carmen. 聚会的事我们不得不对卡门保密。 a secret address 秘密的地址 a secret love affair 秘密的恋情
2 used to describe actions that you do not tell anyone about 秘密进行的；不公开的: a secret drinker 偷偷喝酒的酒徒 She's got a secret admirer. 有个人暗中爱慕她。 ➔secretly adv The government secretly agreed to pay the kidnappers. 政府暗中答应给绑匪付赎金。

secret¹
/ˈsi:krət ||; ˈsikrət/noun
1 [C] something that is not or must not be known by other people 秘密；机密: to keep a secret 保守秘密 to let sb in on/tell sb a secret 向别人泄露秘密 I can't tell you where we're going -- it's a secret. 我不能告诉你我们要去哪里─这是秘密。 It's no secret that they don't like each other (= everybody knows). 他们都不喜欢对方，这已不是什么秘密。
2 [sing] the secret (of/to sth/doing sth) the only way or the best way of doing or achieving sth 秘诀；窍门: What is the secret of your success (= how did you become so successful)? 你成功的秘诀是什么？
in secret without other people knowing 秘密地；暗地里: to meet in secret 暗中见面

ˌsecret ˈagent
(also agent) noun [C] a person who tries to find out secret information especially about the government of another country 间谍；特务；特工人员 ☞Look at spy. 参看spy。

secretarial
/ˌsekrəˈteəriəl ||; ˌsɛkrəˈtɛrɪəl/adj involving or connected with the work that a secretary does 秘书的；跟秘书工作有关的: secretarial skills/work 秘书技能╱工作

secretariat
/ˌsekrəˈteəriət ||; ˌsɛkrəˈtɛrɪət/noun [C] the department of a large international or political organization, especially the office of a SECRETARY GENERAL, that manages the way the organization is run 秘书处；书记处

*secretary
/ˈsekrətri; US -rəterɪ ||; ˈsɛkrəˌtɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural secretaries)
1 a person who works in an office. A secretary types letters, answers the telephone, keeps records, etc （办公室的）秘书: the director's personal secretary 董事的私人秘书
2 an official of a club or society who is responsible for keeping records, writing letters, etc （俱乐部或其他组织的）文书，书记
3 (US 美) the head of a government department, chosen by the President （政府的）部长
4 (Brit 英) =SECRETARY OF STATE(1)

ˌSecretary ˈGeneral
noun [C] the person who is in charge of the department which runs a large international or political organization 秘书长

ˌSecretary of ˈState
noun [C]
1 (also Secretary) (in Britain) the head of one of the main government departments （英国）国务大臣: the Secretary of State for Defence 国防大臣
2 (in the US) the head of the government department that deals with foreign affairs （美国）国务卿

secrete
/sɪˈkri:t ||; sɪˈkrit/verb[T]
1 (used about a part of a plant, animal or person) to produce a liquid （指植物、动物或人体某部份）分泌（液体）
2 (formal 正式) to hide sth in a secret place 隐藏

secretion
/sɪˈkri:ʃn ||; sɪˈkriʃən/noun (formal 正式) [C,U] a liquid that is produced by a plant or an animal; the process by which the liquid is produced 分泌（物）: The frog covers itself in a poisonous secretion for protection. 青蛙身上覆盖着有毒的分泌物，起到保护作用。

secretive
/ˈsi:krətɪv ||; ˈsikrətɪv/adj liking to keep things secret from other people 爱保密的: Wendy is very secretive about her private life. 温迪对自己的私生活守口如瓶。 ➔secretively adv ➔secretiveness noun [U]

ˌsecret poˈlice
noun [C] [with.sop] a police force that works secretly to make sure that people behave as their government wants 秘密警察

sect
/sekt ||; sɛkt/noun [C] a group of people who have a particular set of religious or political beliefs. A sect has often broken away from a larger group. （宗教或政党的）派别，宗派；教派；党派

sectarian
/sekˈteəriən ||; sɛkˈtɛrɪən/adj connected with the differences that exists between religious groups 与宗教派别有关的: sectarian violence 教派性的暴力活动

*section
/ˈsekʃn ||; ˈsɛkʃən/noun[C]
1 one of the parts into which sth is divided 部份: the string section of an orchestra 管弦乐团的弦乐部份 the financial section of a newspaper 报纸的财经版 The library has an excellent reference section. 那个图书馆的参考书部藏书丰富。
2 a view or drawing of sth as if it was cut from the top to the bottom so that you can see the inside 纵切面: The illustration shows a section through a leaf. 这幅插图显示一片叶子的纵切面。

sectional
/ˈsekʃənl ||; ˈsɛkʃənḷ/adj
1 made of separate sections 组合式的: a sectional sofa 组合沙发
2 connected with one particular group within a community or an organization 某群体的；某阶层的: the sectional interests of managers and workers 管理层和广大工人的不同利益

sector
/ˈsektə(r) ||; ˈsɛktɚ/noun[C]
1 a part of the business activity of a country 国家经济的一部份；部门: The manufacturing sector has declined in recent years. 近年来制造业日渐衰落。 the public/private sector 公营╱私营部门
2 a part of an area or of a large group of people （某地区或一大群人中的）一部份: the Christian sector of the city 该市的基督徒群体
3 (mathematics数学) a part of a circle that is between two straight lines drawn from the centre to the edge 扇形 ☞picture at circle 见circle插图

secular
/ˈsekjələ(r) ||; ˈsɛkjəlɚ/adj not concerned with religion or the church 与宗教或教会无关的；世俗的

secure¹
/sɪˈkjʊə(r) ||; sɪˈkjυr/adj
1 free from worry or doubt; confident 无忧虑的；无疑虑的；有信心的: Children need to feel secure. 孩子需要安全感。 to be financially secure 经济上有保障 [OPP] insecure 反义词为insecure
2 not likely to be lost; safe 稳妥的；安全的: Business is good so his job is secure. 由于生意很好，他的职位稳固。 a secure investment 无风险的投资
3 not likely to fall or be broken; firmly fixed 牢固的；稳固的: That ladder doesn't look very secure. 那梯子看来不太稳固。
4 secure (against/from sth) well locked or protected 已锁好的；受保护的: Make sure the house is secure before you go to bed. 就寝以前必须确保房子的门窗已经关好。 ➔securely adv All doors and windows must be securely fastened. 所有门窗务须关好。
secure²
/sɪˈkjʊə(r) ||; sɪˈkjυr/verb[T]
1 secure sth (to sth) to fix or lock sth firmly 牢牢固定或锁好: The load was secured with ropes. 货物已经用绳子牢牢捆扎好了。 Secure the rope to a tree or a rock. 将绳子绑在树上或大石上。
2 secure sth (against/from sth) to make sth safe 使安全: The sea wall needs strengthening to secure the town against flooding. 要加固海堤，以保护这个市镇免被淹没。
3 to obtain or achieve sth, especially by having to make a big effort 取得，获得（尤指通过巨大努力）: The company has secured a contract to build ten planes. 公司获得了制造十架飞机的合同。

*security
/sɪˈkjʊərəti ||; sɪˈkjυrətɪ/noun (plural securities)
1 [U] the state of feeling safe and being free from worry; protection against the difficulties of life 安全感；安稳；保障: Children need the security of a stable home environment. 孩子需要安稳的家庭环境。 financial/job security 经济╱工作保障 [OPP] insecurity 反义词为insecurity
2 [U] things that you do to protect sb/sth from attack, danger, thieves, etc 安全措施；保安措施: Security was tightened at the airport before the president arrived. 总统到达前，机场的保安措施加强了。 The robbers were caught on the bank's security cameras. 这几个窃贼给银行的保安摄像机录了下来。
3 [U] the section of a large company or organization that deals with the protection of buildings, equipment and staff （公司或机构的）保安部门: If you see a suspicious bag, contact airport security immediately. 如果看到一个可疑的袋子，请马上与机场的保安部门联系。
4 [C,U] something of value that you use when you borrow money. If you cannot pay the money back then you lose the thing you gave as security 抵押品

seˈcurity blanket
noun [C] a blanket or other familiar object that makes sb feel safe and comfortable, especially a child 安乐毯﹙尤指可让小孩感觉安全舒适的绒毯或其他物品﹚

seˈcurity guard
noun [C] a person whose job is to guard money, valuables, a building, etc 保安人员

Seˈcurity Service
noun [C] a government organization that protects a country and its secrets from enemies 国家保安部门

sedan
/sɪˈdæn ||; sɪˈdæn/noun [C] (US 美) =SALOON

sedate¹
/sɪˈdeɪt ||; sɪˈdet/adj quiet, calm and well behaved 安静的；镇静的；庄重的
sedate²
/sɪˈdeɪt ||; sɪˈdet/verb [T] to give sb a drug or medicine to make him/her feel calm or want to sleep 给某人镇静剂: The lion was sedated and treated by a vet. 兽医给狮子用镇静剂，然后进行治疗。 ➔sedation /sɪˈdeɪʃn ||; sɪˈdeʃən/ noun [U]: The doctor put her under sedation. 医生用镇静剂使她安静下来。

sedative
/ˈsedətɪv ||; ˈsɛdətɪv/noun [C] a drug or medicine that makes you feel calm or want to sleep 镇静剂 ☞Look at tranquillizer. 参看tranquillizer。

sedentary
/ˈsedntri; US -terɪ ||; ˈsɛdṇˌtɛrɪ/adj involving a lot of sitting down; not active 需久坐着的；不活动的: a sedentary lifestyle/job 长期坐着缺乏运动的生活方式╱工作

sediment
/ˈsedɪmənt ||; ˈsɛdəmənt/noun [C,U] a thick substance that forms at the bottom of a liquid 沉淀物

sedimentary
/ˌsedɪˈmentri ||; ˌsɛdəˈmɛntərɪ/adj (technical术语) (used about rocks 指岩石) formed from the sand, stones, mud, etc that are at the bottom of lakes, rivers, etc 由沉积形成的 ☞Compare igneous and metamorphic. 与igneous及metamorphic比较。 ☞picture at rock 见rock插图

sedimentation
/ˌsedɪmenˈteɪʃn ||; ˌsɛdəmɛnˈteʃən/noun [U] (technical术语) the process of leaving SEDIMENT(= sand, stones, mud, etc carried by water or wind and left, for example, on the bottom of a lake, or river) 沉积，沉淀（作用）

sedition
/sɪˈdɪʃn ||; sɪˈdɪʃən/noun [U] (formal 正式) the use of words or actions that are intended to encourage people to be or act against a government （用言论或行动）煽动叛乱 ➔seditious adj

seduce
/sɪˈdju:s; US -ˈdu:s ||; sɪˈdus/verb[T]
1 seduce sb (into sth/doing sth) to persuade sb to do sth he/she would not usually agree to do 引诱；唆使: Special offers seduce customers into spending their money. 优惠价格会吸引顾客花钱。
2 to persuade sb to have sex with you 诱奸 ➔seduction /sɪˈdʌkʃn ||; sɪˈdʌkʃən/ noun [C,U]

seductive
/sɪˈdʌktɪv ||; sɪˈdʌktɪv/adj
1 sexually attractive 诱人的；性感的: a seductive smile 诱人的笑容
2 attractive in a way that makes you want to have or do sth 非常吸引人的；令人折服的: a seductive argument/opinion (= one which you are tempted to agree with) 使人折服的议论╱意见

*see
/si: ||; si/verb (past tense saw /sɔ: ||; sɔ/ past participle seen /si:n ||; sin/)
1 [I,T] to become conscious of sth, using your eyes; to use the power of sight 看见；目睹: It was so dark that we couldn't see. 太黑了，我们什么都看不见。 On a clear day you can see for miles. 天气晴朗的时候，你看得见几英里外的景物。 Have you seen my wallet anywhere? 你有没有见过我的钱包？ I've just seen a mouse run under the cooker. 我刚看见一只老鼠跑到炉子底下去了。 He looked for her but couldn't see her in the crowd. 他寻找她，但在人群中看不见她。 ☞Look at the note at look ¹. 参看look^1的注释。
2 [T] to look at or watch a film, play, television programme, etc 观看（电影、戏剧、电视节目等）: Did you see that programme on sharks last night? 昨晚你有没有看电视上那个有关鲨鱼的节目？ Have you seen Spielberg's latest film? 你有没有看过史匹堡最新的电影？
3 [T] to find out sth by looking, asking or waiting （通过看、问或等待）获悉，发现: Go and see if the postman has been yet. 去看看邮差来了没有。 We'll wait and see what happens before making any decisions. 我们先等着瞧发生什么，然后再作决定。 ‘Can we go swimming today, Dad?’ ‘I'll see.’ “爸爸，我们今天可以去游泳吗？”“让我先考虑一下。” I saw in the paper that they're building a new theatre. 我从报章上得知他们正在兴建一家新剧院。
4 [T] to spend time with sb; to visit sb 会见；探望: I saw Alan at the weekend; we had dinner together. 我周末曾与艾伦见面；我们一起吃了晚饭。 You should see a doctor about that cough. 你应该去看医生，治好咳嗽的毛病。 Is she seeing anybody (= having a romantic relationship) at the moment? 她现在在交男朋友吗？
5 [I,T] to understand sth; to realize sth 理解；领会 · Do you see what I mean ? 你明白我的意思吗？ She doesn't see the point in spending so much money on a car. 她不明白为什么要花那么多钱去买一辆汽车。 [I] ‘You have to key in your password first.’ ‘Oh, I see.’ “你必须先键入你的密码。”“噢，我明白了。”
6 [T] to have an opinion about sth 认为: How do you see the situation developing? 你认为这局势会怎么发展？
7 [T] to imagine sth as a future possibility 想象（未来的可能性）: I can't see her changing her mind. 我无法想象她会改变主意。
8 [T] to do what is necessary in a situation; to make sure that sb does sth 做必须做的事；确保: I'll see that he gets the letter. 我会确保他收到那封信。
9 [T] to go with sb, for example to help or protect him/her 陪伴（如提供帮助或保护）: He asked me if he could see me home, but I said no. 他问我可否让他送我回家，但我说不必了。 I'll see you to the door. 我送你到门口。
10 [T] to be the time when an event happens 为某事发生的时候: Last year saw huge changes in the education system. 去年教育制度出现了大改革。
as far as I can see→FAR² as far as the eye can see→FAR² let me see;let's see→LET see eye to eye (with sb) to agree with sb; to have the same opinion as sb 同意某人的看法；跟某人的看法一致: We don't always see eye to eye on political matters. 我们的政治观点不尽相同。 see if... to try to do sth 尝试: I'll see if I can find time to do it. 我会看看有没有时间做那件事。 See if you can undo this knot. 看看你能否解开这个结子。 see you around(informal 非正式) used for saying goodbye to sb you have made no arrangement to see again （与没有约定再见面的人道别时用）再见 see you (later) used for saying goodbye to sb you expect to see soon or later that day （与不久或稍后会再见面的人道别时用）再见 you see used for giving a reason （用于提出理由）: She's very unhappy. He was her first real boyfriend, you see. 她郁郁不乐，毕竟他是她第一个真正的男朋友。 see about sth/doing sth to deal with sth 处理: I've got to go to the bank to see about my traveller's cheques. 我必须去银行处理有关旅行支票的事宜。 see sb off to go with sb to the railway station, the airport, etc in order to say goodbye to him/her （到火车站、机场等）送行 see through sb/sth to be able to see that sb/sth is not what he/she/it appears 看透；看穿: The police immediately saw through his story. 警方立即看穿他是在编造故事。 see to sb/sth to do what is necessary in a situation; to deal with sb/sth 做必须做的事；处理: I'll see to the travel arrangements and you book the hotel. 我来负责安排旅行，你去订旅馆房间。

*seed
/si:d ||; sid/noun
1 [C,U] the small hard part of a plant from which a new plant of the same kind can grow 种子；籽: a packet of sunflower seeds 一包向日葵种子 ☞picture on pages C2 and C3 见C2页及C3页插图
2 [C] the start of a feeling or event that continues to grow （感受或事件的）萌芽，起因，开端
3 [C] a player in a sports competition, especially tennis, who is expected to finish in a high position 种子选手（尤指网球的）

seeded
/ˈsi:dɪd ||; ˈsidɪd/adj (used about a player or a team in a sports competition) expected to finish in a high position （指体育比赛中因有希望获得佳绩而）被选为种子选手或队的

seedless
/ˈsi:dləs ||; ˈsidləs/adj (used about fruit) having no seeds （指水果）无核的，无籽的: seedless grapes 无核葡萄

seedling
/ˈsi:dlɪŋ ||; ˈsidlɪŋ/noun [C] a very young plant or tree that has grown from a seed 幼苗

seedy
/ˈsi:di ||; ˈsidɪ/adj dirty and unpleasant; possibly connected with illegal or immoral activities 肮脏的；可能与非法或不道德活动有关的: a seedy hotel/neighbourhood 下等旅馆╱地区

seeing
/ˈsi:ɪŋ ||; ˈsiɪŋ/ (also seeing thatseeing as) conj (informal 非正式) because; as 因为: Seeing as we're going the same way, I'll give you a lift. 既然我们同路，我用车顺便送你一程吧。

seek
/si:k ||; ʃik/verb [T] (past tense past participle sought /sɔ:t ||; sɔt/) (formal 正式)
1 to try to find or get sth 试图找到或得到: Politicians are still seeking a peaceful solution. 政治家仍在寻求和平解决的方法。
2 seek sth (from sb) to ask sb for sth 寻求；请求: You should seek advice from a solicitor about what to do next. 你应该向律师征求意见，看下一步该怎样做。
3 seek (to do sth) to try to do sth 试图；设法: They are still seeking to find a peaceful solution to the conflict. 他们仍然在设法寻求和平解决这场冲突的方法。
4 -seeking (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) looking for or trying to get the thing mentioned 寻找或试图得到某物: attention-seeking behaviour 想引起注意的行为 a heat-seeking missile 热自导引导弹

seeker
/ˈsi:kə(r) ||; sikɚ/noun [C] (often used in compounds 常用于构成复合词) a person who is trying to find or get the thing mentioned 寻找者；探索者；搜查者: an attention seeker 爱出风头者 asylum seekers 寻求庇护者

*seem
/si:m ||; sim/ linking verb seem (to sb) (to be) sth;seem (like) sth (not in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时) to give the impression of being or doing sth; to appear 似乎；好像；彷佛: Emma seems (like) a very nice girl. 埃玛看上去好像是个很好的女孩子。 Emma seems to be a very nice girl. 埃玛看上去好像是个很好的女孩子。 It seems to me that we have no choice. 依我看，我们似乎没有选择的余地。 You seem happy today. 你今天好像很高兴。 This machine doesn't seem to work. 这台机器好像失灵了。

seeming
/ˈsi:mɪŋ ||; ˈsimɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) appearing to be sth 似乎是的；表面上的: Despite her seeming enthusiasm, Sandra didn't really help much. 虽然桑德拉表现得很热心，但实际上她并没有帮什么忙。 ➔seemingly adv a seemingly endless list of complaints 似乎永没完结的投诉

seen
past participle ofSEE

seep
/si:p ||; sip/verb [I] (used about a liquid) to flow very slowly through sth （指液体）慢慢渗出或泄漏: Water started seeping in through small cracks. 水开始从小缝隙渗进来。

ˈsee-saw
noun [C] an outdoor toy for children that consists of a long piece of wood that is balanced in the middle. One child sits on each end of the see-saw and one goes up while the other goes down. 跷跷板

seethe
/si:ð ||; sið/verb[I]
1 to be very angry 非常气愤: I was absolutely seething. 我非常气愤。
2 seethe (with sth) to be very crowded 拥挤: The streets were seething with people. 街上人潮如涌。

ˈsee-through
adj (used about fabric) very thin so that you can see through it ﹙织物﹚极薄的，透明的: a see-through blouse 透明的女式衬衫 This material goes see-through when it's wet. 这种布料湿的时候就透明了。

segment
/ˈsegmənt ||; ˈsɛgmənt/noun[C]
1 a section or part of sth 部份: I've divided the sheet of paper into three segments. 我把这张纸分成三部份。 a segment of the population 人口的一部份 ☞picture at circle 见circle插图
2 one of the parts into which an orange can be divided （橙子的）瓣 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

segmentation
/ˌsegmenˈteɪʃn ||; ˌsɛgmɛnˈteʃən/noun [U] [C] [usu.pl] (technical术语) the act of dividing sth into different parts; one of these parts 分裂；分化；分割；分化、分裂或分割出的一部份: the segmentation of social classes 社会阶级的分化

segregate
/ˈsegrɪgeɪt ||; ˈsɛgrɪˌget/verb [T] segregate sb/sth (from sb/sth) to separate one group of people or things from the rest 分开；分离；隔离: The two groups of football fans were segregated to avoid trouble. 那两群足球迷被分隔开，以免发生冲突。 ☞Look at integrate. 参看integrate。 ➔segregation /ˌsegrɪˈgeɪʃn ||; ˌsɛgrɪˈgeʃən/ noun [U]: racial segregation (= separating people of different races) 种族隔离

segue
/ˈsegweɪ ||; ˈsɛgwe/verb [I] to move smoothly from one song, subject, place, etc to another ﹙顺利﹚转到，接入﹙另一首歌、话题、地方等﹚: a spiritual that segued into a singalong chorus 一首转为会众集体跟唱的灵歌 He then segued into a discussion of atheism.然后他转入对无神论的讨论。 ➔segue noun [C]

seismic
/ˈsaɪzmɪk ||; ˈsaɪzmɪk/adj connected with or caused by movements in the earth's surface(earthquakes) 与地震有关的

seismograph
/ˈsaɪzməgrɑ:f ||; ˈsaɪzməˌgræf/noun [C] an instrument that measures and records information about EARTHQUAKES (= sudden, violent shaking of the earth's surface) 地震仪

seismology
/saɪzˈmɒlədʒi ||; saɪzˈmɑlədʒɪ/noun [U] the scientific study of movements in the earth's surface(earthquakes) 地震学

seize
/si:z ||; siz/verb[T]
1 to take hold of sth suddenly and firmly; to grab sth 突然抓住或捉住: The thief seized her handbag and ran off with it. 小偷抢去她的手提包跑掉了。 (figurative 比喻) to seize a chance/an opportunity 抓住机会
2 to take control or possession of sb/sth 控制；占有；夺取: The police seized 50 kilos of illegal drugs. 警方没收了50公斤违禁毒品。
3 (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) (used about an emotion) to affect sb suddenly and very strongly （指情绪）突然支配或影响: I felt myself seized by panic. 我突然感到惊惶失措。
seize (on/upon) sth to make use of a good and unexpected chance 抓住，把握（突如其来的好机会）: He seized on a mistake by the goalkeeper and scored. 他把握守门员失误的机会射进了一球。 seize up (used about a machine) to stop working because it is too hot, does not have enough oil, etc （指机器因过热或缺油等而）停止操作，卡住

seizure
/ˈsi:ʒə(r) ||; ˈsiʒɚ/noun
1 [U] using force or legal authority to take control or possession of sth 扣押；没收: the seizure of 30 kilos of heroin by police 警方没收30公斤海洛因
2 [C] a sudden strong attack of an illness, especially one affecting the brain 疾病突然发作（尤指脑部的）

seldom
/ˈseldəm ||; ˈsɛldəm/adv not often; rarely 不常；很少: There is seldom snow in Athens. 雅典很少下雪。 I very seldom go to the theatre. 我难得去看戏。

select¹
/sɪˈlekt ||; səˈlɛkt/verb [T] to choose sb/sth from a number of similar things 挑选；选择: The best candidates will be selected for interview. 最优秀的申请人将被挑选参加面试。 ☞ Select is more formal than choose and suggests that a lot of care is taken when making the decision. 与choose相比，select多用于正式场合，表示作出决定时十分小心谨慎。
select²
/sɪˈlekt ||; səˈlɛkt/adj (formal 正式)
1 carefully chosen as the best of a group 仔细挑选的；精选的: A university education is no longer the privilege of a select few. 大学教育不再是少数精英的特权。
2 used or owned by rich people 富人使用或拥有的

selection
/sɪˈlekʃn ||; səˈlɛkʃən/noun
1 [U] choosing or being chosen 选择；挑选；选拔: The manager is responsible for team selection. 领队负责球队成员的选拔工作。
2 [C] a number of people or things that have been chosen 挑选出来的人或事物: a selection of hits from the fifties and sixties 五、六十年代流行歌曲精选
3 [C] a number of things from which you can chose 可供选择的东西: This shop has a very good selection of toys. 这家商店有各种玩具可供选择。

selective
/sɪˈlektɪv ||; səˈlɛktɪv/adj
1 careful when choosing 慎重挑选的: She's very selective about who she invites to her parties. 她非常慎重地挑选出席她的聚会的客人。
2 being careful about what or who you choose 选择性的: selective schools/education 重点学校；因材施教 ➔selectively adv

selector
/sɪˈlektə(r) ||; səˈlɛktɚ/noun [C] a device in an engine, a piece of machinery, etc that allows you to choose a particular function 选择器；转换器；换挡器: a gear selector 变速器 a selector lever/switch 变速杆；选择器开关

self
/self ||; sɛlf/noun [C] (plural selves /selvz ||; sɛlvz/) a person's own nature or qualities （个人的）本性，本质，正常状态；自我；自己: It's good to see you back to your old self again (= feeling well or happy again). 见到你恢复昔日的状态真好。 Her spiteful remark revealed her true self (= what she was really like). 她那怀有恶意的言辞暴露了她的本性。

self-
prefix (used in nouns and adjectives 用于构成名词及形容词) of, to or by yourself or itself 自己；自身；自我: self-control 自制 self-addressed 写明发信人姓名地址的 self-taught 自学成才的

ˌself-abˈsorbed
adj only concerned about or interested in yourself 只顾自己的；只关心自己的

ˌself-addressed ˈenvelope
=STAMPED ADDRESSED ENVELOPE

ˌself-apˈpointed
adj giving yourself a particular title, job, etc, especially without the agreement of other people 自己任命的；自封的

ˌself-asˈsured
adj =ASSURED ➔ˌself-asˈsurance noun [U] =ASSURANCE(2)

ˌself-ˈcatering
adj (Brit 英) (used about a holiday or a place to stay) where meals are not provided for you so you cook them yourself （指度假或住宿）须自己做饭的

ˌself-ˈcentred
(US 美 self-centered) adj thinking only about yourself and not about other people 自我中心的；自私自利的 ☞Look at selfish. 参看selfish。

ˌself-conˈfessed
adj admitting that you are sth or do sth that most people consider to be bad 自己承认（做了坏事）的

ˌself-ˈconfident
adj feeling sure about your own value and abilities 自信的 ☞Look at confident. 参看confident。 ➔ˌself-ˈconfidence noun [U]: Many women lack the self-confidence to apply for senior jobs. 许多女性对申请高级职位缺少自信。

self-congratulatory
/ˌself kənˌgrætʃuˈleɪtəri ||; ˌsɛlf kənˈgrætʃələˌtɔrɪ/adj showing that you think you have done sth very well and are pleased with yourself 自我庆贺的；沾沾自喜的: The winners gave themselves a self-congratulatory round of applause. 获胜者一齐鼓掌，庆贺自己的胜利。

ˌself-ˈconscious
adj too worried about what other people think about you （因过于担心别人对自己的看法而）不自在的，不自然的 ➔self-consciously adv ➔self-consciousness noun [U]

ˌself-conˈtained
adj (Brit 英) (used about a flat, etc) having its own private entrance, kitchen and bathroom （指公寓等）设备齐全的（有独立门户、厨房、浴室等）: a self-contained apartment 设备齐全并独用的公寓

ˌself-conˈtrol
noun [U] the ability to control your emotions and appear calm even when you are angry, afraid, excited, etc 自制（能）力: to lose/keep your self-control 失去╱保持自制能力

ˌself-deˈfence
(US 美 ˌself deˈfense) noun [U] the use of force to protect yourself or your property 自恒: Lee is learning karate for self-defence. 李在学习空手道以自恒。 to shoot sb in self-defence(= because they are going to attack you) 为了自恒而枪击某人

ˌself-deˈnial
noun [U] the fact of not having or doing the things you like, either because you do not have enough money, or for moral or religious reasons 克己: a life of self-denial and sacrifice 清苦、克己的生活

ˌself-ˈdeprecating
adj (written 书面语) done in a way that makes your own achievements or abilities seem unimportant 自我贬低的；自谦的: He gave a self-deprecating shrug. 他自谦地耸耸肩。

ˌself-desˈtruct
verb [I] to destroy him-/her-/itself 自毁 ➔self-destructive adj ➔self-destruction noun [U]

ˌself-ˈdiscipline
noun [U] the ability to make yourself do sth difficult or unpleasant 自我约束；自律: It takes a lot of self-discipline to give up smoking. 戒烟需要很强的自我约束能力。

ˌself-ˈdoubt
noun [C,U] the feeling that you are not good enough 自我怀疑: His life was plagued by fear and self-doubt. 他一生担惊受怕，自我怀疑。

ˌself-efˈfacing
adj not wanting to attract attention to yourself or your abilities 谦逊的: In spite of her success, she remains self-effacing and reserved. 她虽然已有成就，但仍保持谦逊持重的本色。 a shy, self-effacing man腼腆谦逊的男子 [SYN]modest 同义词为 modest

ˌself-emˈployed
adj working for yourself and earning money from your own business 自己经营生意的；自雇的

ˌself-esˈteem
noun [U] a good opinion of your own character and abilities 自尊（心）: a man with high/low self-esteem 一个自尊心很强╱不强的人

ˌself-ˈevident
adj that does not need any proof or explanation; clear 不证自明的；不言而喻的；明显的

ˌself-exˈplanatory
adj clear and easy to understand; not needing to be explained 明白易懂的；无需解释的: The book's title is self-explanatory. 那书名无需多加解释。

ˌself-ˈimage
noun [C] the opinion or idea you have of yourself, especially of your appearance or abilities 自我形象: to have a positive/poor self-image 自我形象良好/不好

ˌself-imˈportant
adj thinking that you are more important than other people 自高自大的；高傲的 ➔ˌself-imˈportance noun [U] ➔ˌself-imˈportantly adv

ˌself-imˈprovement
noun [U] the activity of trying to improve your knowledge, social position or character by your own efforts 自我改进；自我提高

ˌself-inˈdulgent
adj allowing yourself to have or do things you enjoy (sometimes when it would be better to stop yourself) 放纵自己的 ➔self-indulgence noun [C,U]

ˌself-ˈinterest
noun [U] thinking about what is best for yourself rather than for other people 利己之心；私心

*selfish
/ˈselfɪʃ ||; ˈsɛlfɪʃ/adj thinking only about your own needs or wishes and not about other people's 自私（自利）的: a selfish attitude 自私的态度 I'm sick of your selfish behaviour! 你那自私的行为真令我讨厌！ [OPP] unselfish or selfless 反义词为unselfish或selfless ☞Look at self-centred. 参看self-centred。 ➔selfishly adv ➔selfishness noun [U]

selfless
/ˈselfləs ||; ˈsɛlflɪs/adj thinking more about other people's needs or wishes than your own 无私的

ˌself-ˈmade
adj having become rich or successful by your own efforts 白手起家的；靠个人奋斗而成功的: a self-made millionaire 白手起家的百万富翁

ˌself-ˈpity
/ˌself ˈpɪti ||; ˌsɛlf ˈpɪtɪ/noun [U] the state of thinking too much about your own problems or troubles and feeling sorry for yourself 自怜

ˌself-ˈportrait
noun [C] a picture that you draw or paint of yourself 自画像

ˌself-posˈsessed
adj able to remain calm and confident in a difficult situation 沉着的；镇定的；泰然自若的: She always seems so calm and self-possessed. 她总是显得那么镇静自若。

ˌself-preserˈvation
noun [U] the fact of protecting yourself in a dangerous or difficult situation 自我保护: She was held back by some sense of self-preservation. 一种自我保护意识使她没有贸然行动。

ˌself-raising ˈflour
(US 美 self-rising flour) noun [U] flour that contains a substance that makes cakes, etc rise during cooking 自发面粉 ☞Look at plain flour. 参看plain flour。

ˌself-reˈliant
adj not depending on help from anyone else 独立自主的；自力更生的 ☞Look at reliant. 参看reliant。

ˌself-reˈspect
noun [U] a feeling of confidence and pride in yourself 自尊（心）；自重: Old people need to keep their dignity and self-respect. 老年人需要保持尊严和自尊。 ☞Look at respect. 参看respect。 ➔self-respecting adj (often in negative sentences 常用于否定句) No self-respecting language student (= nobody who is serious about learning a language) should be without this book. 凡是真想学会一种语言的学生都应该购备这本书。

ˌself reˈstraint
noun [U] the ability to stop yourself doing or saying sth that you want to because you know it is better not to 自我克制: She exercised all her self restraintand kept quiet. 她尽力克制自己，保持缄默。

ˌself-ˈrighteous
adj believing that you are always right and other people are wrong, so that you are better than other people 自以为是的 ☞Look at righteous. 参看righteous。 ➔self-righteously adv ➔self-righteousness noun [U]

ˌself-ˈrising flour
(US 美) =SELF-RAISING FLOUR

ˌself-ˈsacrifice
noun [U] giving up what you need or want, in order to help others 自我牺牲

ˌself-ˈsatisfied
adj too pleased with yourself or with what you have done 沾沾自喜的；自鸣得意的 [SYN] smug 同义词为smug

ˌself-ˈservice
adj (used about a shop, restaurant, etc) where you serve yourself and then pay at a special desk (a cash desk) （指商店、餐馆等）自我服务的，自助的

ˌself-ˈstarter
noun [C] a person who is able to work alone and make decisions without needing anyone to tell him/her what to do 有主见的人；做事主动的人

ˌself-ˈstudy
noun [U] the activity of learning about sth without a teacher to help you 自学 self-study adj

ˌself-ˈstyled
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) using a name or title that you have given yourself, especially when you do not have the right to do it 自封的，自称的（尤指在不够格的情况下）: the self-styled king of fashion 自封的时装大王

ˌself-sufˈficient
adj able to produce or provide everything that you need without help from or having to buy from others 自给自足的

ˌself-ˈtaught
adj having learned sth by reading books, etc, rather than by sb teaching you 自学的；自修的: a self-taught artist 自学成材的艺术家

ˌself-ˈworth
noun [U] a feeling of confidence in yourself that you are a good and useful person 自我价值感: Praise your child to increase her sense of self-worth. 要多表扬你的孩子，以提高她的自信心。

*sell
/sel ||; sɛl/verb (past tense past participle sold /səʊld ||; sold/)
1 [I,T] sell (sb) (sth) (at/for sth);sell (sth) (to sb) (at/for sth) to give sth to sb who pays for it and is then the owner of it 卖；出售 · We are going to sell our car. 我们打算把汽车卖掉。 I sold my guitar to my neighbour for £200. 我以200英镑的价钱把吉他卖给了我的邻居。 Would you sell me your ticket? 你可以把票卖给我吗？ I offered them a lot of money but they wouldn't sell. 虽然我开出高价，但他们仍然不肯卖。
2 [T] to offer sth for people to buy 卖；出售；销售: Excuse me, do you sell stamps? 请问你们卖邮票吗？ to sell insurance/advertising space 出售保险╱广告版面
3 [I,T] to be bought by people in the way or in the numbers mentioned; to be offered at the price mentioned 以某方式、某数量或某价格出售: These watches sell at £1000 each in the shops but you can have this one for £500. 这些手表在商店里卖1000英镑一块，但这一块以500英镑卖给你。 Her books sell well abroad. 她的书在国外很畅销。 This newspaper sells over a million copies a day. 这份报纸每日销量超过一百万份。
4 [T] to make people want to buy sth 推销；吸引买家: They rely on advertising to sell their products. 他们依靠广告推销产品。 ☞noun for senses
1 to
4 is sale 第
1至
4义的名词皆为sale
5 [T] sell sth/yourself to sb to persuade sb to accept sth; to persuade sb that you are the right person for a job, position, etc 说服某人接受；使人相信你是（某工作、职位等的）最佳人选: Now we have to try and sell the idea to the management. 现在我们得设法让管理部门接受这个构想。
be sold on sth(informal 非正式) to be very enthusiastic about sth 对某事很热心 sell sth off to sell sth in order to get rid of it, often at a low price 廉价销售；削价出售: The shops sell their remaining winter clothes off in the spring sales. 商店往往在春季大减价时销售卖剩的冬装。 sell out; be sold out (used about tickets for a concert, football game, etc) to be all sold （指音乐会、足球赛等的票）售罄，卖光，售完: All the tickets sold out within two hours. 所有门票在两个小时里售完。 The concert was sold out weeks ago. 这场音乐会的票在几个星期前已经售完了。 sell out (of sth); be sold out (of sth) to sell all of sth so that no more is/are available to be bought 售罄；卖光: I'm afraid we've sold out of bread. 我们的面包恐怕已经售完。 sell up to sell everything you own, especially your house, your business, etc (in order to start a new life, move to another country, etc) 卖掉自己的全部东西（尤指房屋、生意等，以便开始过新生活、移居外国等）

ˈsell-by date
noun [C] (Brit 英) the date printed on food containers, packets, etc after which the food should not be sold （食物等的）销售期限，最后销售日期: This milk is past its sell-by date. 这牛奶已经过期。

seller
/ˈselə(r) ||; ˈsɛlɚ/noun[C]
1 (often in compounds 常用于构成复合词) a person or business that sells 出售者；卖方: a bookseller 书商 a flower seller 花店
2 something that is sold, especially in the amount or way mentioned 出售的商品（尤指以某数量或某方式）: This magazine is a big seller in the 25-40 age group. 这本杂志很受25岁至40岁的人欢迎。 ☞Look at best-seller. 参看best-seller。

ˈselling price
noun [C] the price at which sth is sold 售价 ☞Compare asking price and cost price. 与asking price及cost price比较。

Sellotape™
/ˈseləteɪp ||; ˈsɛloˌtep/ (US 美 Scotch tape™) noun [U] a type of clear tape that is sold in rolls and used for sticking things 透明胶带 ☞Look at tape. 参看tape。 ☞picture at stationery 见stationery插图 sellotape verb [T]

selves
plural ofSELF

semantic
/sɪˈmæntɪk ||; səˈmæntɪk/adj connected with the meaning of words and sentences 与语义（学）有关的 ➔semantically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

semantics
/sɪˈmæntɪks ||; səˈmæntɪks/noun[U]
1 the study of the meanings of words and phrases 语义学
2 the meaning of words and phrases 语义: the semantics of the language 语言的语义学

semblance
/ˈsembləns ||; ˈsɛmbləns/noun [sing] [U] (formal 正式)(a) semblance of sth the appearance of being sth or of having a certain quality 有…的外表；似有某种特质

semen
/ˈsi:men ||; ˈsimən/noun [U] the liquid that is produced by the male sex organs containing the seed (sperm) necessary for producing babies or young 精液

semester
/sɪˈmestə(r) ||; səˈmɛstɚ/noun [C] one of the two periods that the school or college year is divided into 学期（半学年）: the spring/fall semester 春季╱秋季学期

semi-
/ˈsemi ||; ˈsɛmɪ/prefix (used in adjectives and nouns 用以构成形容词及名词) half; partly 半；部份: semicircular 半圆形的 semi-final 半决赛

semi
/ˈsemi ||; ˈsɛmɪ/noun [C] (plural semis /ˈsemiz ||; ˈsɛmɪz/) (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) a house that is joined to another one with a shared wall between them, forming a pair of houses 半独立式房子（与另一房子共有一堵墙壁）

ˌsemi-ˈarid
adj (technical术语) (used about land or climate 指土地及气候) dry; with little rain 半干旱的

semibreve
/ˈsemibri:v ||; ˈsɛməˌbriv/ (US 美 whole note) noun [C] (used in music 用于音乐) a type of note 全音符 ☞Look at the note at crotchet. 参看crotchet的注释。 ☞picture at music 见music插图

semicircle
/ˈsemisɜ:kl ||; ˈsɛmɪˌsɝkḷ/noun [C] one half of a circle; something that is arranged in this shape 半圆；半圆形（的东西）: I want you all to sit in a semicircle. 我要你们大家围坐成半圆形 ☞picture at circle 见circle插图 ➔semicircular /ˌsemiˈsɜ:kjələ(r) ||; ˌsɛməˈsɝkjəlɚ/ adj

semicolon
/ˌsemiˈkəʊlən; US ˈsemɪk- ||; ˈsɛməˌkolən/noun [C] a mark (;) used in writing for separating parts of a sentence or items in a list 分号（；）

semiconductor
/ˌsemikənˈdʌktə(r) ||; ˌsɛmɪkənˈdʌktɚ/noun [C] (technical术语) a solid substance that allows heat or electricity to pass through it or along it in particular conditions 半导体 ☞Compare conductor. 与conductor比较。

ˌsemi-deˈtached
adj (used about a house) joined to another house with a shared wall on one side forming a pair of houses （指房子）半独立式的（指与另一所房子共享一堵墙壁）

ˌsemi-ˈfinal
/ˌsemi ˈfaɪnl/noun [C] one of the two games in a sports competition which decide which players or teams will play each other in the final 准决赛；半决赛 ☞Look at quarter-final and final. 参看quarter-final及final。 ➔semi-finalist /-ˈfaɪnəlɪst ||; -ˈfaɪnḷɪst/ noun [C]

seminar
/ˈsemɪnɑ:(r) ||; ˈsɛməˌnɑr/noun[C]
1 a class at a university, college, etc in which a small group of students discuss or study a subject with a teacher 研讨班: I've got a seminar on Goethe this morning. 我今天上午有个歌德问题的讨论会。
2 a meeting for business people in which working methods, etc are taught or discussed 研讨会: a one-day management seminar 为期一天的管理研讨会

semiotics
/ˌsemiˈɒtɪks ||; ˌsɛmɪˈɑtɪks/noun [U] the study of signs and symbols and of their meaning and use 符号学 ➔semiotic adj: semiotic analysis 符号分析

ˌsemi-ˈprecious
adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) (used about a jewel) less valuable than the most valuable types of jewels ﹙珠宝﹚次贵重的；半宝石的: semi-precious stones 半宝石

ˌsemi-proˈfessional
adj semi-professional musicians or sports players are paid for what they do, but do not do it as their main job ﹙音乐家或运动员﹚半职业的 ➔ˌsemi-proˈfessional noun [C]

semiquaver
/ˈsemikweɪvə(r) ||; ˈsɛməˌkwevɚ/ (US 美 sixteenth note) noun [C] (used in music 用于音乐) a type of note 十六分音符 ☞Look at the note at crotchet. 参看crotchet的注释。 ☞picture at music 见music插图

ˌsemi-ˈskilled
adj (used about workers 指工人) having some special training or QUALIFICATIONS, but less than skilled people 半熟练的

ˌsemi-ˈskimmed
adj (used about milk) that has had half the fat removed ﹙指牛奶﹚半脂的

semitone
/ˈsemitəʊn ||; ˈsɛməˌton/ (US 美 half stephalf-tone) noun [C] the shortest step between notes in a musical scale, for example between C# and D, or B♭ and B 半音（如介于C#与D或B♭与B之间的) ☞Compare tone. 与tone比较。

semolina
/ˌseməˈli:nə ||; ˌsɛməˈlinə/noun [U] large hard grains of wheat used for making sweet dishes and other food(pasta) 粗面粉（用于做甜食、面食等）

Sen.
abbr (in US politics 美国政治) Senator 参议员

senate
/ˈsenət ||; ˈsɛnɪt/noun oftenthe Senate [C] [with.sop] one of the two groups of elected politicians who make laws in the government in some countries, for example the US 参议院（如美国的） ☞Look at Congress and the House of Representatives. 参看Congress及the House of Representatives。

senator
/ˈsenətə(r) ||; ˈsɛnətɚ/noun oftenSenator(abbr Sen.) [C] a member of a group of elected politicians (the Senate)who make laws in the government in some countries, for example the US 参议员: Senator McCarthy 参议员麦卡锡

*send
/send ||; sɛnd/verb [T] (past tense past participle sent /sent ||; sɛnt/)
1 send sth (to sb/sth);send (sb) sth to make sth go or be taken somewhere, especially by mail, radio, etc 寄；发送: to send a letter/parcel/message/fax to sb 给某人寄信╱寄包裹╱发信息╱发传真 Don't forget to send me a postcard. 别忘了给我寄明信片。
2 to tell sb to go somewhere or to do sth; to arrange for sb to go somewhere 派遣；打发: My company is sending me on a training course next month. 下个月公司将派我去参加培训课程。 She sent the children to bedearly. 她早早就把孩子打发上床了。 to send sb to prison 把某人关进监狱 I'll send someone round to collect you at 10.00. 我10点钟派人过来接你。
3 to cause sb/sth to move in a particular direction, often quickly or as a reaction that cannot be prevented 使急速地或失控地（向某方向）移动: I accidentally pushed the table and sent all the drinks flying. 我无意中推动桌子，把所有饮料弄得飞散了。
4 send sb (to/into sth) to make sb have a particular feeling or enter a particular state 使有某种感觉或进入某种状态: The movement of the train sent me to sleep. 火车摇摇晃晃的，使我睡着了。
give/send sb your love→LOVE¹ send for sb/sth to ask for sb to come to you; to ask for sth to be brought or sent to you 派人去叫或去拿: Quick! Send for an ambulance! 快！快叫救护车！ send sth in to send sth to a place where it will be officially dealt with 寄或送至某处进行处理: I sent my application in three weeks ago but I still haven't had a reply. 我三星期前寄出申请信，但至今仍未收到回复。 send off (for sth); send away (to sb) (for sth) to write to sb and ask for sth to be sent to you 写信购买或索取: Let's send off for some holiday brochures. 让我们写信索取一些度假小册子。 send sb off (used in a sports match) to order a player who has broken a rule to leave the field and not to return （指体育比赛）将犯规的参赛者判罚下场: Beckham was sent off for a foul in the first half. 贝肯姆上半场犯规而被勒令下场。 send sth off to post sth 寄出: I'll send the information off today. 今天我会将资料寄出。 send sth out
1 to send sth to a lot of different people or places （将某物）发送（给许多人或地方）: We sent out the invitations two months before the wedding. 我们在举行婚礼前两个月就把请柬发出去了。
2 to produce sth, for example light, heat, sound, etc 产生，发出（光、热、声音等）
send sb/sth up (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) to make sb/sth look ridiculous or silly especially by copying him/her/it in a way that is intended to be amusing （用戏谑模仿的方式）取笑

sender
/ˈsendə(r) ||; ˈsɛndɚ/noun [C] a person who sends sth 发送人: The sender's name appears at the top of the email. 发送人的名字出现在电子函件上端。

senile
/ˈsi:naɪl ||; ˈsinaɪl/adj behaving in a confused and strange way, and unable to remember things because of old age （年老时）胡涂，健忘，衰老: I think she's going senile. 我觉得她开始老糊涂了。 ➔senility /səˈnɪləti ||; səˈnɪlətɪ/ noun [U]

senior¹
/ˈsi:niə(r) ||; ˈsinjɚ/adj
1 senior (to sb) having a high or higher position in a company, organization, etc （地位或等级）较高的: a senior lecturer/officer/manager 高级讲师╱军官╱经理 He's senior to me. 他的职位比我高。
2 oftenSenior(abbr Snr) (abbr Sr) (especially US 尤为美) used after the name of a man who has the same name as his son, to avoid confusion （父与子同名时，用于表示父辈）
3 (Brit 英) (used in schools) older （用于学校）高年级的
4 (US 美) connected with the final year at high school or college （中学或学院里）毕业班的 ☞Look at junior ¹. 参看junior^1。
senior²
/ˈsi:niə(r) ||; ˈsinjɚ/noun[C]
1 somebody who is older or of a higher position (than one or more other people) 较年长者；（地位或等级）较高者: My oldest sister is ten years my senior. 我的大姐比我大十岁。 She felt undervalued, both by her colleagues and her seniors. 她觉得同事和上级都不重视她。
2 (Brit 英) one of the older students at a school 高年级学生
3 (US 美) a student in the final year of school, college or university （学校、学院或大学里的）毕业班学生: high school seniors 中学毕业班学生 ☞Look at junior ². 参看junior^2。

ˌsenior ˈcitizen
=OLD-AGE PENSIONER

seniority
/ˌsi:niˈɒrəti; US -ˈɔ:r- ||; sinˈjɔrətɪ/noun [U] the position or importance that a person has in a company, organization, etc in relation to others 资历；年资: The names are listed below in order of seniority. 下列名字按年资排列。

sensation
/senˈseɪʃn ||; sɛnˈseʃən/noun
1 [C] a feeling that is caused by sth affecting your body or part of your body 感觉: a pleasant/unpleasant/tingling sensation 愉快╱不愉快╱刺痛的感觉
2 [U] the ability to feel when touching or being touched 知觉: For some time after the accident he had no sensation in his legs. 意外发生后，他的两条腿曾有一段时间失去了知觉。
3 [C] [usu.sing] a general feeling or impression that is difficult to explain 下意识的感觉或印象: I had the peculiar sensation that I was floating in the air. 我有一种浮在空中的奇特感觉。
4 [C] [usu.sing] great excitement, surprise or interest among a group of people; sb/sth that causes this excitement 轰动；引起轰动的人或事: The young American caused a sensation by beating the top player. 那个年轻的美国人打败了头号选手，轰动一时。

sensational
/senˈseɪʃənl ||; sɛnˈseʃənḷ/adj
1 causing, or trying to cause, a feeling of great excitement, surprise or interest among people 引起轰动的；煽情的；耸人听闻的: This magazine specializes in sensational stories about the rich and famous. 这本杂志专门报道富人和名人耸人听闻的轶事。
2 (informal 非正式) extremely good or beautiful; very exciting 极好的；极美丽的；动人的 ➔sensationally /-nəli ||; -nəlɪ/ adv

sensationalize ( also -ise)
/senˈseɪʃənəlaɪz ||; sɛnˈseʃənəˌlaɪz/verb [T] (used especially about newspapers) to exaggerate a story so that it seems more exciting or shocking than it really is ﹙尤指报纸﹚耸人听闻地夸张，大肆渲染

*sense¹
/sens ||; sɛns/noun
1 [U] the ability to think or act in a reasonable or sensible way; good judgement 理智；理性；良好的判断力: At least he had the sense to stop when he realized he was making a mistake. 他知道自己犯错后，至少懂得不继续下去。 I think there's a lot of sense in what you're saying. 我觉得你的话很有道理。 ☞Look at common sense. 参看common sense。
2 [U] [sing] the ability to understand sth; the ability to recognize what sth is or what its value is 理解力；辨别力；领悟力: She seems to have lost all sense of reality. 她似乎丧失了所有辨认现实的能力。 [sing] I like him -- he's got a great sense of humour. 我喜欢他─他很有幽默感。 I'm always getting lost. I've got absolutely no sense of direction. 由于我全无方向感，所以我老是迷路。
3 [U] sense (in doing sth) the reason for doing sth; purpose 做某事的理由；目的: There's no sense in going any further -- we're obviously lost. 再往前走也是徒然，我们显然迷路了。 What's the sense in making things more difficult for yourself? 你为什么要跟自己过不去？
4 [U] [sing] a natural ability to do or produce sth well 天生的能力；天赋的才能: Good business sense made her a millionaire. 卓越的经商能力使她成为百万富翁。 He's got absolutely no dress sense (= he dresses very badly). 他全无衣着品味。
5 [sing] a feeling or consciousness of sth 感觉；意识: I felt a tremendous sense of relief when the exams were finally over. 考试终于结束，我感到如释重负。 She only visits her family out of a sense of duty. 她只是出于责任感才探访她的家人。
6 [C] one of the five natural physical powers of sight, hearing, smell, taste and touch, that people and animals have （人或动物的）五种官能之一（五种官能是视觉、听觉、嗅觉、味觉及触觉）: I've got a cold and I've lost my sense of smell. 我患了感冒，闻不出味道。 Dogs have an acute sense of hearing. 狗的听觉很灵敏。
7 [C] (used about a word, phrase, etc) a meaning （指词、短语等）意义，意思: This word has two senses. 这个词有两种意思。
come to your senses to finally realize that you should do sth because it is the most sensible thing to do 恢复理性；醒悟过来 in a sense in one particular way but not in other ways; partly 从某个角度看；在某种意义上: In a sense you're right, but there's more to the matter than that. 你在某种意义上是对的，但事情并不就这样简单。 make sense
1 to be possible to understand; to have a clear meaning 说得通；有意义: What does this sentence mean? It doesn't make sense to me. 这个句子是什么意思？在我看来根本不通。
2 (used about an action) to be sensible or logical （指行动）合理，明智，合乎逻辑: I think it would make sense to wait for a while before making a decision. 我认为先等一会再做决定才是明智的做法。
make sense of sth to manage to understand sth that is not clear or is difficult to understand 理解，明白，弄懂（含糊或难懂的事物）: I can't make sense of these instructions. 我看不懂这些用法说明。 talk sense→TALK¹
sense²
/sens ||; sɛns/verb [T] (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时) to realize or become conscious of sth; to get a feeling about sth even though you cannot see it, hear it, etc 意识到；感觉到: I sensed that something was wrong as soon as I went in. 我一进去便觉得有点不对劲。 Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (= -ing form) Sensing a scandal, the tabloid photographers rushed to the star's hotel. 虽然这个动词不用于进行时，但它的现在分词还是常见：Sensing a scandal, the tabloid photographers rushed to the star's hotel.小报摄影记者意识到出了一宗丑闻，连忙赶往那位明星下榻的酒店。

senseless
/ˈsensləs ||; ˈsɛnsləs/adj
1 having no meaning or purpose 没有意义的；没有目的的
2 unconscious 失去知觉的；不省人事的: He was beaten senseless. 他给打昏了。

sensibility
/ˌsensəˈbɪləti ||; ˌsɛnsəˈbɪlətɪ/noun (plural sensibilities)
1 [U] [C] the ability to understand and experience deep feelings, for example in art, literature, etc 识别力，鉴赏力（如在艺术、文学等方面）
2 sensibilities [pl] a person's feelings, especially when he/she is easily offended 人的感情（尤指容易受到伤害的）

*sensible
/ˈsensəbl ||; ˈsɛnsəbḷ/adj (used about people and their behaviour) able to make good judgements based on reason and experience; practical （指人及其行为）理智的，合理的，明智的: a sensible person/decision/precaution 理智的人；明智的决定；合理的预防措施 Stop joking and give me a sensible answer. 别再开玩笑，给我一个合理的答复。 I think it would be sensible to leave early, in case there's a lot of traffic. 我认为还是早点离开比较好，以防交通拥挤。 [OPP] silly or foolish 反义词为silly或foolish ➔sensibly /-əbli ||; -əblɪ/ adv Let's sit down and discuss the matter sensibly. 让我们坐下来理智地讨论这个问题。 Compare sensible and sensitive. Sensible is connected with common sense, reasonable action and good judgement. Sensitive is connected with feelings and emotions and with the five senses of sight, hearing, touch, smell and taste. 比较sensible及sensitive。sensible与常识、合理的行动和良好的判断有关。sensitive与感觉、情绪及视觉、听觉、触觉、嗅觉、味觉五种官能有关。
*sensitive
/ˈsensətɪv ||; ˈsɛnsətɪv/adj
1 sensitive (to sth) showing that you are conscious of and able to understand people's feelings, problems, etc 能察觉和理解别人的感受、问题等的；近人情的；体贴的: It wasn't very sensitive of you to keep mentioning her boyfriend.
