You know they've just split up. 你不断提到她的男朋友，真有点不知趣。你知道吗，他们刚分了手。 to be sensitive to sb's feelings/wishes 能理解某人的感受╱心愿
2 sensitive (about/to sth) easily upset, offended or annoyed, especially about a particular subject 神经过敏的，敏感的，易生气的（尤其在某个问题上）: She's still a bit sensitive about her divorce. 她对自己离婚一事仍有点敏感。 He's very sensitive to criticism. 他对批评非常在乎。 [OPP] for senses 1 and 2 insensitive 第1及2义的反义词皆为insensitive
3 (used about a subject, a situation, etc) needing to be dealt with carefully because it is likely to cause anger or trouble （指事情、情况等）须小心处理的（因可能会引起危险或麻烦）: This is a sensitive period in the negotiations between the two countries. 两国的谈判现正处于敏感阶段。
4 sensitive (to sth) easily hurt or damaged; painful, especially if touched 易受伤害的，易损坏的，疼痛的（尤指被碰触时）: a new cream for sensitive skin 一种医治敏感皮肤的新软膏 My teeth are very sensitive to hot or cold food. 我一吃热的或冷的食物就牙齿痛。
5 (used about a scientific instrument, a piece of equipment, etc) able to measure very small changes （指科学仪器、设备等）灵敏的 ☞Look at the note at sensible. 参看sensible的注释。 ➔sensitively adv The investigation will need to be handled sensitively. 这个调查须要慎重处理。 ➔sensitivity /ˌsensəˈtɪvəti ||; ˌsɛnsəˈtɪvətɪ/ noun [U]: I think your comments showed a complete lack of sensitivity. 我认为你的意见显示出你一点也不体谅人。

sensory
/ˈsensəri ||; ˈsɛnsərɪ/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) (technical术语) connected with your physical senses 与感觉有关的: sensory organs 感觉器官 sensory deprivation 感觉剥夺

sensual
/ˈsenʃuəl ||; ˈsɛnʃυəl/adj connected with physical or sexual pleasure 与肉体享受或性快感有关的: the sensual rhythms of Latin music 拉丁音乐刺激感官的节奏 ➔sensuality /ˌsenʃuˈæləti ||; ˌsɛnʃυˈælətɪ/ noun [U]

sensuous
/ˈsenʃuəs ||; ˈsɛnʃυəs/adj giving pleasure to the mind or body through the senses 给感官以快感的；影响感官的: the sensuous feel of pure silk 纯丝的轻柔感觉 ➔sensuously adv ➔sensuousness noun [U]

sent
past tense, past participle ofSEND

*sentence¹
/ˈsentəns ||; ˈsɛntəns/noun[C]
1 (grammar语法) a group of words containing a subject and a verb, that expresses a statement, a question, etc. When a sentence is written it begins with a big (capital) letter and ends with a full stop. 句；句子 ☞Look at phrase. 参看phrase。
2 the punishment given by a judge to sb who has been found guilty of a crime 判决；判刑: 20 years in prison was a very harsh sentence. 20年监禁是很严厉的判刑。
sentence²
/ˈsentəns ||; ˈsɛntəns/verb [T] sentence sb (to sth) (used about a judge) to tell sb who has been found guilty of a crime what the punishment will be （指法官）判决，判处，判刑: The judge sentenced her to three months in prison for shoplifting. 她因店铺盗窃罪被法官判处三个月监禁。

sentiment
/ˈsentɪmənt ||; ˈsɛntəmənt/noun
1 [C,U] (often plural 常用复数形式) (formal 正式) an attitude or opinion that is often caused or influenced by emotion 态度，意见（通常指受感情影响的）: His comments expressed my sentiments exactly. 他的意见正好表达了我的感受。
2 [U] feelings such as pity, romantic love, sadness, etc that influence sb's action or behaviour (sometimes in situations where this is not appropriate) 情感（如怜悯之情、爱情、悲伤之情等，有时是不适当的）: There's no room for sentiment in business. 做生意不能感情用事。

sentimental
/ˌsentɪˈmentl ||; ˌsɛntəˈmɛntḷ/adj
1 producing or connected with emotions such as romantic love, pity, sadness, etc which may be too strong or not appropriate 滥情的；与情感有关的: How can you be sentimental about an old car! 你怎能对一辆旧车这么恋恋不舍呢！ a sentimental love song 感伤的情歌
2 connected with happy memories or feelings of love rather than having any financial value 与愉快回忆或爱情有关的（而不在于有经济价值）: The jewellery wasn't worth much but it had great sentimental value to me. 这珠宝不值多少钱，但它对我很有感情价值。 ➔sentimentality /ˌsentɪmenˈtæləti ||; ˌsɛntəmɛnˈtælətɪ/ noun [U] ➔sentimentally /-təli ||; -tḷɪ/ adv

sentry
/ˈsentri ||; ˈsɛntrɪ/noun [C] (plural sentries) a soldier who stands outside a building and guards it 哨兵

sepal
/ˈsepl ||; ˈsɛpḷ/noun [C] (technical术语) a part of a flower, like a leaf, that lies under and supports the PETALS (= the coloured parts that make up the head of the flower) （花的）萼片 ☞Look at calyx. 参看calyx。 ☞picture at flower 见flower插图

separable
/ˈsepərəbl ||; ˈsɛpərəbḷ/adj able to be separated 可分开的；可分隔的 [OPP] inseparable 反义词为inseparable

*separate¹
/ˈseprət ||; ˈsɛprɪt/adj
1 separate (from sth/sb) apart; not together 分开的；不在一起的: You should always keep your cash and credit cards separate. 你始终应该把现金和信用卡分开放。
2 different; not connected 不同的；不相关的: We stayed in separate rooms in the same hotel. 我们住在同一家旅馆，但不在同一个房间。
*separate²
/ˈsepəreɪt ||; ˈsɛpəˌret/verb
1 [I,T] separate (sb/sth) (from sb/sth) to stop being together; to cause people or things to stop being together （使）分离，分开: I think we should separate into two groups. 我想我们应该分成两组。 The friends separated at the airport. 朋友们在机场分手。 I got separated from my friends in the crowd. 我与友人在人群中失散了。
2 [T] separate sb/sth (from sb/sth) to keep people or things apart; to be between people or things with the result that they are apart 使隔开或分隔: The two sides of the city are separated by the river. 河流把这个城市分成两部份。
3 [I] to stop living together as a couple with your wife, husband or partner （夫妇或伴侣）分居: His parents separated when he was still a baby. 他还是个婴儿的时候，父母就分居了。

separated
/ˈsepəreɪtɪd ||; ˈsɛpəˌretɪd/adj not living together as a couple any more （夫妇或伴侣）分居的: My wife and I are separated. 我和妻子分居了。

separately
/ˈseprətli ||; ˈsɛpərətlɪ/adv apart; not together 分开；不在一起: Shall we pay separately or all together? 我们是各自付款还是一起付款呢？

*separation
/ˌsepəˈreɪʃn ||; ˌsɛpəˈreʃən/noun
1 [C,U] the action of separating or being separated; a situation or period of being apart 分离，分开（的期间）
2 [C] an agreement where a couple decide not to live together any more （夫妻或伴侣的）分居: a trial separation 尝试性的分居

Sept.
abbr September 九月: 2 Sept. 1920 1920年9月2日

sept-
/sept ||; sɛpt/prefix (used in nouns, adjectives and adverbs 用于构成名词、形容词及副词) seven; having seven 七；有七（个）: septet 七重唱 septennial 七年一次的

*September
/sepˈtembə(r) ||; sɛpˈtɛmbɚ/noun [U] [C] (abbr Sept.) the ninth month of the year, coming after August 九月 ☞To see how the months are used in sentences, look at the examples and the note at January. 有关句子中月份的用法，参看January的示例及注释。

septic
/ˈseptɪk ||; ˈsɛptɪk/adj infected with poisonous bacteria 脓毒性的；败毒的: The wound went septic. 伤口感染化脓。

septicaemia
/ˌseptɪˈsi:miə ||; ˌsɛptəˈsimɪə/ (US 美 septicemia) noun [U] infection of the blood by poisonous bacteria 败血病 [SYN] blood poisoning 同义词为blood poisoning

ˌseptic ˈtank
noun [C] a large container, usually underground, that holds human waste from toilets until the action of bacteria makes it liquid enough to be absorbed by the ground 化粪池

sequel
/ˈsi:kwəl ||; ˈsikwəl/noun [C] a sequel (to sth)
1 a book, film, etc that continues the story of the one before （书、电影等的）续集，续篇
2 something that happens after, or is the result of, an earlier event 继之而来的事；余波；后果

sequence
/ˈsi:kwəns ||; ˈsikwəns/noun[C]
1 a number of things (actions, events, etc) that happen or come one after another 连续发生或接连的行动、事情等: Complete the following sequence: 1, 4, 8, 13, ... 请完成下列数字序列：1、4、8、13…
2 [U] the order in which a number of things happen or are arranged 次序；顺序: The photographs are in sequence. 相片按次序排列。

sequential
/sɪˈkwenʃl ||; sɪˈkwɛnʃəl/adj (formal 正式) following in order of time or place （以时间或地点为）顺序的: sequential data processing 顺序数据处理 ➔sequentially /-ʃeli ||; -ʃɛlɪ/ adv data stored sequentially on the computer 按序存入计算机的资料

sequester
/sɪˈkwestə(r) ||; sɪˈkwɛstɚ/verb [T] to keep all the members of a jury together in a place, in order to prevent them from talking to other people about a court case, or learning about it in the newspapers, on television, etc 隔离﹙避免陪审团与公众接触﹚

sequin
/ˈsi:kwɪn ||; ˈsikwɪn/noun [C] a small shiny round piece of metal or plastic that is sewn onto clothing as decoration （金属或塑料制的）闪光饰片 ➔sequinned adj

serenade¹
/ˌserəˈneɪd ||; ˌsɛrəˈned/noun [C] a song or tune played or sung at night by a lover outside the window of the woman he loves 小夜曲
serenade²
/ˌserəˈneɪd ||; ˌsɛrəˈned/verb [T] to sing or play music to sb (as done in the past by a man singing under her window to the woman he loved) 唱小夜曲；奏小夜曲: We were serenaded by a string quartet. 弦乐四重奏乐队为我们演奏小夜曲。

serene
/səˈri:n ||; səˈrin/adj calm and peaceful 平静的；平和的: a serene smile 平和的微笑 ➔serenely adv ➔serenity /səˈrenəti ||; səˈrɛnətɪ/ noun [U]

sergeant
/ˈsɑ:dʒənt ||; ˈsɑrdʒənt/noun [C] (abbr Sgt)
1 an officer with a low position in the army or air force 中士（陆军或空军的低级军官）
2 an officer with a middle position in the police force 警长（中级警官）

serial
/ˈsɪəriəl ||; ˈsɪrɪəl/noun [C] a story in a magazine or on television or radio that is told in a number of parts over a period of time 连载小说；（电视或电台的）连续剧: the first part of a six-part drama serial 分六集播出的戏剧的第一集 ☞Look at the note at series. 参看series的注释。 ➔serialize(also -ise) /-rɪəlaɪz ||; -rɪəlˌaɪz/ verb [T]

ˈserial number
noun [C] the number marked on sth to identify it and to distinguish it from other things of the same type （同类事物的）顺序号码，编号

*series
/ˈsɪəri:z ||; ˈsɪriz/noun [C] (plural series)
1 a number of things that happen one after another and are of the same type or connected （同类或有关联事物）连续，一系列: a series of events 一连串事件 There has been a series of burglaries in this district recently. 这一区最近连续发生了多宗入户盗窃案。
2 a number of programmes on radio or television which have the same main characters and each tell a complete story 广播或电视的系列节目 ☞Compare series and serial. In a series each part is a different, complete story involving the same main characters. In a serial the same story continues in each part. 比较series及serial。series中每集的主要人物相同，但每集均为独立完整的故事。serial中同一个故事分为若干集连续播放。

*serious
/ˈsɪəriəs ||; ˈsɪrɪəs/adj
1 bad or dangerous 严重的；危险的: a serious accident/illness/offence 严重的意外╱疾病╱罪行 Pollution is a very serious problem. 污染是很严重的问题。 Her condition is serious and she's likely to be in hospital for some time. 她病得很重，可能要在医院里待一些时候。
2 needing to be treated as important, not just for fun 严肃的；认真的: Don't laugh, it's a serious matter. 不要笑，这是严肃的事情。 a serious discussion 认真的讨论
3 serious (about sth/about doing sth) (used about a person) not joking; thinking about things in a careful and sensible way （指人）正经的，严肃的: Are you serious about starting your own business (= are you really going to do it)? 你真的要创立自己的生意吗？ He's terribly serious. I don't think I've ever seen him laugh. 他严肃极了，我从来没有见过他笑。 You're looking very serious. Was it bad news? 你看来满怀心事，是不是有什么坏消息？ ➔seriousness noun [U]

*seriously
/ˈsɪəriəsli ||; ˈsɪrɪəslɪ/adv
1 in a serious way 严重；严肃；认真: Three people were seriously injured in the accident. 这起事故中有三人受重伤。 My mother is seriously ill. 我妈妈病得很重。 It's time you started to think seriously about the future. 是该认真考虑你的前途的时候了。
2 used at the beginning of a sentence for showing that you are not joking or that you really mean what you are saying （用于句首，表示认真）说真的，真的，说正经的: Seriously, I do appreciate all your help. 说正经的，我真的感激你的帮忙。 Seriously, you've got nothing to worry about. 说真的，你没有什么可担心的。
3 used for expressing surprise at what sb has said and asking if it is really true （用于表示对某人所说的感到惊奇，并求证是否属实）说真的，真的: ‘I'm 40 today.’ ‘Seriously? You look a lot younger.’ “我今天40岁了。”“真的吗？你看来年轻多了。”
take sb/sth seriously to treat sb or sth as important 重视；认真对待: You take everything too seriously! Relax and enjoy yourself. 你凡事都太认真了！要放轻松点，好好享受一下。

sermon
/ˈsɜ:mən ||; ˈsɝmən/noun [C] a speech on a religious or moral subject that is given as part of a service in church 讲道；说教

serpent
/ˈsɜ:pənt ||; ˈsɝpənt/noun [C] a snake, especially a large one 蛇（尤指大蛇）

serrated
/səˈreɪtɪd; US ˈsereɪtɪd ||; ˈsɛretɪd/adj having a row of points in V-shapes along the edge 边缘呈锯齿状的: a knife with a serrated edge 一把有锯齿的刀

serum
/ˈsɪərəm ||; ˈsɪrəm/noun (plural sera /-rə ||; -rə/or serums)
1 [U] (medical医学) the thin liquid that is left after blood has CLOTTED(= formed thick lumps) 血清
2 [U] [C] a liquid that is taken from the blood of an animal and given to people to protect them from disease, poison, etc 免疫血清；抗毒血清

servant
/ˈsɜ:vənt ||; ˈsɝvənt/noun [C] a person who is paid to work in sb's house, doing work such as cooking, cleaning, etc 佣人；仆人 ☞Look at civil servant. 参看civil servant。

*serve
/sɜ:v ||; sɝv/verb
1 [T] to give food or drink to sb during a meal; to take an order and then bring food or drink to sb in a restaurant, bar, etc （在餐馆、酒吧等里）端上食物，上菜: Breakfast is served from 7.30 to 9.00 am. 早餐供应时间由早上7时30分到9时。
2 [T] (used about an amount of food) to be enough for a certain number of people （指一份食物）可供某数目的人用: According to the recipe, this dish serves four. 按照食谱，这道菜可供四个人吃。
3 [I,T] (in a shop) to take a customer's order; to give help, sell goods, etc （在商店里）接待顾客 · There was a long queue of people waiting to be served. 人们大排长龙等着接待。
4 [I,T] to be useful or suitable for a particular purpose 适合某种用途: The judge said the punishment would serve as a warning to others. 法官说，这惩罚将对别人起警告作用。 It's an old car but it will serve our purposefor a few months. 这是一辆旧车，但还可以为我们派几个月用场。
5 [I,T] to perform a duty or provide a service for the public or for an organization （为公众或机构）履行义务，提供服务: During the war, he served in the Army. 战争期间，他在陆军服役。 She became a nurse because she wanted to serve the community. 她当了护士，因为她想要为社会服务。
6 [T] to spend a period of time in prison as punishment. 在狱中服刑: He is currently serving a ten-year sentencefor fraud. 他因欺诈罪被判十年徒刑，现正在狱中服刑。
7 [I,T] (in tennis and similar sports) to start play by hitting the ball （网球及类似的体育运动）发球
first come, first served→FIRST² serve sb right used when sth unpleasant happens to sb and you do not feel sorry for him/her because you think it is his/her own fault （表示对某人的不幸不予同情）应由某人承担，活该: ‘I feel sick.’ ‘It serves you right for eating so much.’ “我想吐。”“你吃那么多，活该。”

server
/ˈsɜ:və(r) ||; ˈsɝvɚ/noun [C] a computer that stores information that a number of computers can share 服务器；服务器 ☞Look at client. 参看client。

*service¹
/ˈsɜ:vɪs ||; ˈsɝvɪs/noun
1 [C] a system or organization that provides the public with sth that it needs; the job that an organization does 为公众提供日常生活所需的系统或组织；公用事业: There is a regular bus service to the airport. 有一条定期开往机场的公共汽车路线。 the postal service 邮政服务 the National Health Service 国民保健制度 ☞Look at the civil service. 参看the civil service。
2 [C,U] a business whose work involves doing sth for customers but not producing goods; the work that such a service does 服务业（为顾客服务但不生产商品的行业）；服务: financial/banking/insurance services 金融业；银行业；保险业 the service sector (= the part of the economy involved in this type of business) 服务部门 a service industry 服务业
3 [U] (also the services [pl]) the armed forces; the army, navy or air force; the work done by the people in them 武装部队（陆军、海军或空军）；兵役: They both joined the services when they left school. 他们俩毕业后都参军了。 Do you have to do military service in your country? 你们国家要服兵役吗？
4 [U] [C] work done for sb; help given to sb 服务；贡献；帮助: He left the police force after thirty years' service. 他在警察部队服务了三十年，然后离开了。
5 [U] the work or the quality of work done by sb when serving a customer （对顾客的）服务，服务素质: I enjoyed the meal but the service was terrible. 我喜欢那里的食物，但服务很差劲。 Is service included in the bill? 账单是否已把服务费计算在内？ A 10% service charge will be added to your bill. 账单里要加10%服务费。
6 [C] the checks, repairs, etc that are necessary to make sure that a machine is working properly （机器等的）检查，检修: We take our car for a service every six months. 我们每半年将车子送去检修一次。
7 [C] a religious ceremony, usually including prayers, singing, etc 宗教仪式；礼拜: a funeral service 葬礼
8 [C] (in tennis and similar sports) the first hit of the ball at the start of play; a player's turn to serve(7) （网球及类似体育运动的）发球（权）
9 services [pl] a place at the side of a motorway where there is a petrol station, a shop, toilets, a restaurant, etc （高速公路旁的）服务站（设有加油站、商店、厕所、餐厅等）
service²
/ˈsɜ:vɪs ||; ˈsɝvɪs/verb [T] to examine and, if necessary, repair a car, machine, etc 检查，检修（汽车、机器等）: All cars should be serviced at regular intervals. 所有汽车都该定期检修。

serviceable
/ˈsɜ:vɪsəbl ||; ˈsɝvɪsəbḷ/adj suitable to be used 能用的: The carpet is worn but still serviceable. 地毯旧了，但还能用。

serviceman
/ˈsɜ:vɪsmən ||; ˈsɝvɪsmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) a man who is a member of the armed forces 男军人

ˈservice station
=SERVICE¹(9)

servicewoman
/ˈsɜ:vɪswʊmən ||; ˈsɝvɪsˌwυmən/noun [C] (plural -women /-wɪmɪn ||; -wɪmɪn/) a woman who is a member of the armed forces 女军人

serviette
/ˌsɜ:viˈet ||; ˌsɝvɪˈɛt/noun [C] a square of cloth or paper that you use when you are eating to keep your clothes clean and to clean your mouth or hands on 餐巾 [SYN] napkin 同义词为napkin

servile
/ˈsɜ:vaɪl ||; ˈsɝvaɪl/adj wanting too much to please sb and obey him/her 奴性的；逢迎的；恭顺的: Parents have no right to demand servile obedience from their children. 父母无权要求子女对自己唯命是从。

sesame
/ˈsesəmi ||; ˈsɛsəmɪ/noun [U] a tropical plant grown for its seeds that are used in cooking and the oil that is made from them 芝麻: sesame seeds 芝麻（指种子）

session
/ˈseʃn ||; ˈsɛʃən/noun
1 [C] a period of doing a particular activity （从事某活动的）一段时间: The whole tape was recorded in one session. 整卷录音带都是在一节时间内录成的。 She has a session at the gym every week. 她每星期去健身房做一回运动。
2 [C,U] a formal meeting or series of meetings of a court of law, parliament, etc （法庭的）开庭；（议会等的）会议

*set¹
/set ||; sɛt/verb (present participle setting;past tense past participle set)
1 [T] to put sb/sth or to cause sb/sth to be in a particular place or position 放在某位置；放置；摆放: I set the box down carefully on the floor. 我把箱子小心翼翼地放在地板上。
2 [T] (often passive 常用于被动语态) to make the action of a book, play, film, etc take place in a particular time, situation, etc 设置（书本、戏剧、电影等的）背景: The film is set in 16th century Spain. 那部电影以16世纪的西班牙为背景。
3 [T] to cause a particular state or event; to start sth happening 使处于某状态；使发生: The new government set the prisoners free. 新政府释放了那些囚犯。 The rioters set a number of cars on fire. 暴徒放火焚烧多部汽车。
4 [T] to prepare or arrange sth for a particular purpose （为某目的）准备，安排: I set my alarm for 6.30. 我将闹钟调到6时30分。 to set the table(= put the plates, knives, forks, etc on it) 在桌子上摆放餐具
5 [T] to decide or arrange sth 确立；设定；安排: Can we set a limit of two hours for the meeting? 我们把会议时间定在两个小时以内行吗？ They haven't set the date for their wedding yet. 他们举行婚礼的日子还没有确定。
6 [T] to do sth good that people have to try to copy or achieve 树立；创造: Try to set a good example to the younger children. 要为小孩子树立好榜样。 He has set a new world record. 他创了新的世界纪录。 They set high standards of customer service. 他们为顾客服务树立高标准。
7 [T] to give sb a piece of work or a task 给予工作或任务: We've been set a lot of homeworkthis weekend. 这个周末我们有很多家庭作业要做。 I've set myself a targetof four hours' study every evening. 我为自己设定了一个目标，每天晚上要温习四个小时。
8 [I] to become firm or hard 凝固；变硬: The concrete will set solid / hardin just a few hours. 混凝土只要几个小时就会变硬。
9 [T] to fix a precious stone, etc in a piece of jewellery （在首饰上）镶嵌（宝石等）
10 [T] to fix a broken bone in the correct position so that it can get better 把断骨接好或复位: The doctor set her broken leg. 医生把她摔断的腿接好。
11 [I] (used about the sun) to go down below the horizon in the evening （指太阳）落到地平线下 [OPP] rise 反义词为rise
set eyes on sb/sth to see sb/sth 看见某人或某物: He loved the house the moment he set eyes on it. 他第一眼看见那所房子就喜欢上了它。 set foot (in/on sth) to visit, enter or arrive at/in a place 造访，进入，到达（某地方）: No woman has ever set foot in the temple. 从没有女人进过那座庙宇。 set your heart on sth;have your heart set on sth→HEART put/set your/sb's mind at rest→MIND¹ put/set sth right→RIGHT¹ set sail to begin a journey by sea 启航: Columbus set sail for India. 哥伦布启航前往印度。 set the scene (for sth)→SCENE set about sth to start doing sth, especially dealing with a problem or task 开始做某事（尤指处理问题或应付任务）: How would you set about tackling this problem? 你会怎样着手处理这个问题？ set sth aside to keep sth to use later 保留某物（供以后用）: I try to set aside part of my wages every week. 我争取每星期都省下部份工资。 set sb/sth back to delay sb/sth 推迟；耽搁；延误: The bad weather has set our plans back six weeks. 恶劣的天气使我们的计划推迟六个星期。 set forth(formal 正式) to start a journey 出发 set sth forth(formal 正式) to show or tell sth to sb or to make sth known 陈述；阐明；公开 set in to arrive and stay for a period of time 来临并继续一段时间: I'm afraid that the bad weather has set in. 我想天气已开始转坏了。 set off to leave on a journey 出发；启程: We set off at 3 o'clock this morning. 我们今天凌晨3点钟出发。 set sth off to do sth which starts a reaction 发动；启动: When this door is opened, it sets off an alarm. 这道门一打开，警钟就会响起。 set on/upon sb to attack sb suddenly 袭击: He was set upon by a gang of youths on his way home. 他回家路上遭到一帮年轻歹徒袭击。 set out to leave on a journey 出发；启程 set out to do sth to decide to achieve sth 立志: He set out to prove that his theory was right. 他立志要证明他的理论是正确的。 set (sth) up to start a business, organization, system, etc 创业；建立，设立（企业、机构、制度等）
*set²
/set ||; sɛt/noun[C]
1 a set (of sth) a number of things that belong together 一套；一组；一副: a set of kitchen knives 一套厨房用刀 In the first set of questions, you have to fill in the gap. 第一组问题是填充。 a spare set of keys 一套备用钥匙 a chess set 一副国际象棋
2 [with.sop] a group of people who have similar interests and spend a lot of time together socially （因志趣相同而经常交往的）一群人，一伙人 ☞Look at the jet set. 参看the jet set。
3 a piece of equipment for receiving television or radio signals 电视机；收音机: a television set 一台电视机
4 the scenery that is made for a play or film （戏剧或电影的）布景
5 (used in games such as tennis and volleyball 用于网球、排球等比赛) a group of games forming part of a match 一盘: She won in straight sets (= without losing a set). 她不失一盘取胜。
6 (mathematics数学) a group of things that have a shared quality 集；集合
7 (Brit 英) a group of school students with a similar ability in a particular subject （某学科能力相当的）学生组
set³
/set ||; sɛt/adj
1 placed in a particular position 处于某位置；坐落于: deep-set eyes 深陷的眼窝 Our house is quite set back from the road. 我们的房子远离马路。
2 fixed and not changing; firm 固定不变的: There are no set hours in my job. 我没有固定的工作时间。 I'll have the set menu(= with a fixed price and limited choice of dishes). 我要吃套餐。
3 (used about a book, text, etc) that everyone must study for an exam （指书、课文等）指定的，必修的: We have to study three set texts for French. 我们必须学习三篇指定的法语课文。
4 set (for sth);set (to do sth) ready, prepared or likely to do sth 准备就绪: Okay, I'm set -- let's go! 好了，我已经准备就绪，我们走吧！ I was all set to leave when the phone rang. 我正准备离开的时候，电话铃响了。 The Swiss team look set for victory. 瑞士队看来胜券在握。
be set against sth/doing sth to be determined that sth will not happen or that you will not do sth 反对 be set in your ways to be unable to change your habits, attitudes, etc 固执，顽固，无法改变（习惯、态度等） be set on sth/doing sth to be determined to do sth 决心: She's set on a career in acting. 她决心当演员。

ˈset square
(US 美 triangle) noun [C] an instrument for drawing straight lines and angles, made from a flat piece of plastic or metal in the shape of a triangle with one angle of 90° （制图用的）三角板

setback
/ˈsetbæk ||; ˈsɛtˌbæk/noun [C] a difficulty or problem that stops you progressing as fast as you would like 障碍；挫折: She suffered a major setback when she missed the exams through illness. 她因为生病而没能参加考试，遭受了重大挫折。

settee
/seˈti: ||; sɛˈti/noun [C] a long soft seat with a back and arms that more than one person can sit on 长沙发 [SYN] sofa 同义词为sofa

setter
/ˈsetə(r) ||; ˈsɛtɚ/noun [C] a large dog with long hair, sometimes used in hunting. There are several types of setter 蹲猎犬﹙体大毛长，有多个品种﹚: an Irish setter 爱尔兰蹲猎犬 a red setter 红毛蹲猎犬

setting
/ˈsetɪŋ ||; ˈsɛtɪŋ/noun[C]
1 the position sth is in; the place and time in which sth happens 环境；某事发生的地点与时间；背景: The hotel is in a beautiful setting, close to the sea. 那家旅馆临近大海，风景美丽。
2 one of the positions of the controls of a machine （控制机器的）调节点: Cook it in the oven on a moderate setting. 把它放进烤箱里用中等火候烤熟。

*settle
/ˈsetl ||; ˈsɛtḷ/verb
1 [I,T] to put an end to an argument or disagreement 结束争论；解决争端: They settled the dispute without going to court. 他们没有上法庭就解决了争端。 They settled out of court. 他们庭外和解。 We didn't speak to each other for years, but we've settled our differences now. 我们多年没有说话，但现在把分歧解决了。
2 [T] to decide or arrange sth finally 决定；安排好: Everything's settled. We leave on the nine o'clock flight on Friday. 一切都安排好了，我们星期五乘九点钟的飞机离开。
3 [I] to go and live permanently in a new country, area, town, etc 定居: A great many immigrants have settled in this country. 大量外来移民已经在这个国家定居。
4 [I,T] to put yourself or sb else into a comfortable position 安顿；安坐: I settled in front of the television for the evening. 我舒服地坐在电视机前度过那个晚上。 She settled herself beside him on the sofa. 她舒适地挨着他坐在沙发上。
5 [I,T] to become or to make sb/sth calm or relaxed （使）平静，放松: The baby wouldn't settle. 那个婴儿不肯安静下来。
6 [T] to pay money that you owe 清还（欠债）: to settle a bill/a debt 支付账单；清偿债务
7 [I] to land on a surface and stop moving 降落；停留: A flock of birds settled on the roof. 一群鸟儿停在屋顶上。
settle down
1 to get into a comfortable position, sitting or lying 舒适地坐下或躺下
2 to start having a quieter way of life, especially by staying in the same place or getting married 过更宁静的生活（尤指定居某地或结婚等）；安家落户；安顿下来: She had a number of jobs abroad before she eventually settled down. 她最终安顿下来前，曾在国外做过一些不同的工作。
3 to become calm and quiet 安静下来: Settle down! It's time to start the lesson. 大家安静！现在开始上课。
settle down to sth to start doing sth which involves all your attention 开始专注于做某事: Before you settle down to your work, could I ask you something? 在你开始工作之前，我可以问你一件事吗？ settle for sth to accept sth that is not as good as what you wanted （勉强）接受；将就: We're going to have to settle for the second prize. 我们只得屈居二等奖了。 settle in/into sth to start feeling comfortable in a new home, job, etc 适应，习惯（新居、新工作等）: How are the children settling in at their new school? 孩子们适应新学校的生活吗？ settle on sth to choose or decide sth after considering many different things 选择；决定 settle up (with sb) to pay money that you owe to sb 清偿债务

settled
/ˈsetld ||; ˈsɛtḷd/adj
1 not changing or not likely to change 稳定的；不大可能改变的: More settled weather is forecast for the next few days. 预测未来数天天气会较稳定。
2 comfortable; feeling that you belong (in a home, a job, a way of life, etc) 舒适的；安定的: We feel very settled here. 我们在这里感到生活非常安定。

settlement
/ˈsetlmənt ||; ˈsɛtḷmənt/noun[C,U]
1 an official agreement that ends an argument; the act of reaching an agreement （结束纠纷的）协议；达成协议: a divorce settlement 离婚协议 the settlement of a dispute 解决争端
2 a place that a group of people have built and live in, where few or no people lived before; the process of people starting to live in a place 拓居地；殖民地；拓居；殖民: There is believed to have been a prehistoric settlement on this site. 据认为这地方在史前有过一个居民点。 the settlement of the American West 美国西部的开拓

settler
/ˈsetlə(r) ||; ˈsɛtlɚ/noun [C] a person who goes to live permanently in a place where not many people live 移居者（尤指移居人口稀少的地方）: the first white settlers in Australia 第一批移居澳大利亚的白人

ˈset-up
noun [C, usually sing] (informal 非正式)
1 a way of organizing sth; a system 组织；安排；体制: I've only been here a couple of weeks and I don't really know the setup. 我刚来几个星期，对这里的组织情况不大了解。 What's the set-up in your family — who does the cooking? 你们家里是怎么安排的——谁负责烧饭？
2 a situation in which sb tricks you or makes it seem as if you have done sth wrong 诬陷；栽赃: He didn't steal the goods. It was a set-up. 他没有偷这些商品。这是诬陷。

*seven
/ˈsevn ||; ˈsɛvən/ number
1 7 七 ☞For examples of how to use numbers in sentences, look at six. 有关数词在句子里的示例，参看six。
2 (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) having seven of the thing mentioned 有七个…的: a seven-sided coin 七边形硬币

*seventeen
/ˌsevnˈti:n ||; ˌsɛvənˈtin/ number 17 十七 ☞For examples of how to use numbers in sentences, look at six. 有关数词在句子里的示例，参看six。

seventeenth
/ˌsevnˈti:nθ ||; ˌsɛvənˈtinθ/pronoun det adv 17th 第十七（个） ☞Look at the examples at sixth. 参看sixth的示例。

seventh¹
/ˈsevnθ ||; ˈsɛvənθ/noun [C] the fraction 1/7; one of seven equal parts of sth 七分之一 ☞Look at the examples at sixth. 参看sixth的示例。
seventh²
/ˈsevnθ ||; ˈsɛvənθ/pronoun det adv 7th 第七（个） ☞Look at the examples at sixth. 参看sixth的示例。

seventieth
/ˈsevntiəθ ||; ˈsɛvəntɪəθ/pronoun det adv 70th 第七十（个） ☞Look at the examples at sixth. 参看sixth的示例。

*seventy
/ˈsevnti ||; ˈsɛvəntɪ/ number 70 七十 ☞For examples of how to use numbers in sentences, look at sixty. 有关数词在句子里的示例，参看sixty。

sever
/ˈsevə(r) ||; ˈsɛvɚ/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to cut sth into two pieces; to cut sth off 切断；割断: The builders accidentally severed a water pipe. 建筑工人意外地弄断了水管。 His hand was almost severed in the accident. 他的手在事故中几乎折断了。
2 to end a relationship or communication with sb 断绝，终止（关系或联系）: He has severed all links with his former friends. 他与以前的朋友断绝了一切关系。

*several
/ˈsevrəl ||; ˈsɛvrəl/pronoun det more than two but not very many; a few 两个以上；几个；一些: It took her several days to recover from the shock. 过了几天她才从震惊中恢复过来。 There were lots of applications for the job -- several of them from very well-qualified people. 许多人申请那份工作，其中有几个的资历非常适合。 I don't think it's a good idea for several reasons. 我有几条理由认为这不是个好主意。

severance
/ˈsevərəns ||; ˈsɛvərəns/noun [sing, U] (formal 正式)
1 the act of ending a connection or relationship 断绝；中断: the severance of diplomatic relations 外交关系的断绝
2 the act of ending sb's work contract 解雇；辞退: employees given notice of severance 接到解聘通知的雇员

severe
/sɪˈvɪə(r) ||; səˈvɪr/adj
1 causing sb to suffer, be upset or have difficulties 严厉的；严格的；苛刻的: Such terrible crimes deserve the severest punishment. 这样可怕的罪行应受到最严厉的惩罚。 I think your criticism of her work was too severe. 我认为你对她的工作的批评过分严厉。
2 extremely bad or serious 极其恶劣的；十分严重的: The company is in severe financial difficulty. 公司陷入严重的财政危机。 He suffered severe injuries in the fall. 他摔了一跤，多处严重受伤。 severe weather conditions 恶劣的天气状况 ➔severely adv The roof was severely damaged in the storm. 屋顶被暴风雨严重破坏。 The report severely criticizes the Health Service. 报告猛烈抨击了保健制度。 ➔severity /sɪˈverəti ||; səˈvɛrətɪ/ noun [U]: I don't think you realize the severity of the problem. 我认为你没有意识到问题的严重性。

*sew
/səʊ ||; so/verb [I,T] (past tense sewed;past participle sewn /səʊn ||; son/or sewed)sew (sth) (on) to join pieces of cloth, or to join sth to cloth, using a needle and thread and forming stitches 缝；缝合: I can't sew. 我不会针线活。 A button's come off my shirt -- I'll have to sew it back on. 我衬衫上的钮扣掉了─我得把它重新缝上。 ☞picture at knit 见knit插图 sew sth up
1 to join two things by sewing; to repair sth by sewing two things together 缝合；缝补: The surgeon sewed up the wound. 外科医生把伤口缝合了。
2 to arrange sth so that it is certain to happen or be successful （安排或策划某事）使成功，使做成

sewage
/ˈsu:ɪdʒ ||; ˈsuɪdʒ/noun [U] the waste material from people's bodies that is carried away from their homes in water in large underground pipes (sewers) （人体排出的）污物

sewer
/ˈsu:ə(r) ||; ˈsuɚ/noun [C] an underground pipe that carries human waste to a place where it can be treated 下水道；污水管

sewing
/ˈsəʊɪŋ ||; ˈsoɪŋ/noun[U]
1 using a needle and thread to make or repair things 缝纫；缝补: I always take a sewing kit when I travel. 我出门总是带着针线包。 a sewing machine 缝纫机
2 something that is being sewn 缝制的东西

sewn
past participle ofSEW

*sex
/seks ||; sɛks/noun
1 [U] the state of being either male or female 性别: Applications are welcome from anyone, regardless of sex or race. 欢迎任何人申请，不论性别、种族。 Do you mind what sex your baby is? 你想生男还是生女？ [SYN] gender 同义词为gender
2 [C] one of the two groups consisting of all male people or all female people 男性；女性: the male/female sex 男性；女性 He's always found it difficult to get on with the opposite sex (= women). 他总觉得难以和异性相处。
3 (formal 正式coitusintercoursesexual intercourse) [U] the physical act in which the sexual organs of two people touch and which can result in a woman having a baby 性交: to have sex with somebody 与某人性交 sex education in schools 学校的性教育

ˈsex ap peal
noun [U] the quality of being attractive in a sexual way 性魅力: He exudes sex appeal. 他浑身洋溢着性魅力。

ˈsex drive
noun [U] a person's interest in sex or ability to have sex 性欲望

sexism
/ˈseksɪzəm ||; ˈsɛksɪzəm/noun [U] the unfair treatment of people, especially women, because of their sex; the attitude that causes this 性别歧视；性别偏见 ➔sexist /ˈseksɪst ||; ˈsɛksɪst/ adj a sexist attitude to women 歧视女性的态度 · sexist jokes 带性别歧视的笑话

ˈsex life
noun [C] a person's sexual activities 性生活: ways to improve your sex life 改善性生活的办法

ˈsex symbol
noun [C] a famous person who is thought by many people to be sexually attractive 性感偶像

sextet
/seksˈtet ||; sɛksˈtɛt/noun[C]
1 a group of six musicians or singers who play or sing together 六重奏乐团；六重唱组合
2 a piece of music for six musicians or singers 六重奏曲；六重唱曲

ˈsex therapy
noun [U] treatment to help people with sexual problems 性问题治疗 ➔ˈsex therapist noun [C]

sextuplet
/ˈsekstʊplət;sekˈstju:plət;-ˈstʌp- ||; ˈsɛkstυˌplɪt; sɛksˈtjuplɪt; -sˈtup-/noun [C] one of six children or animals that are born to one mother at the same time 六胞胎之一

*sexual
/ˈsekʃuəl ||; ˈsɛkʃυəl/adj connected with sex 与性有关的: sexual problems 性问题 the sexual organs 性器官 a campaign for sexual equality (= to get fair and equal treatment for both men and women) 争取男女平等的运动 ☞Compare sexy. 与sexy比较。 ➔sexually /ˈsekʃəli ||; ˈsɛkʃυəlɪ/ adv to be sexually attracted to sb 被性方面为某人所吸引

ˌsexual haˈrassment
noun [U] comments about sex, physical contact, etc usually happening at work, that a person finds annoying and offensive 性骚扰

(formal 正式)=SEX(3)

sexuality
/ˌsekʃuˈæləti ||; ˌsɛkʃυˈælətɪ/noun [U] the nature of sb's sexual activities or desires 性兴趣；性欲

ˈsex worker
noun [C] a polite way of referring to a prostitute ﹙委婉说法﹚妓女

sexy
/ˈseksi ||; ˈsɛksɪ/adj (sexier;sexiest) (informal 非正式) sexually attractive or exciting 性感的: Do you find the lead singer sexy? 你觉得这领唱歌手很性感吗？ a sexy dress 性感的连衣裙

SGML
/ˌes dʒi: em ˈel ||; ˌɛs ˌdʒi ˌɛm ˈɛl/abbr (computing 计算机技术) the abbreviation for ‘Standard Generalized Mark-up Language’; a system used for marking text on a computer so that the text can be read on a different computer system or displayed in different forms 标准通用标记语言

Sgt
abbr sergeant 中士

sh
/ʃ ||; ʃ/ exclamation used to tell sb to stop making noise （用于叫人安静）嘘，安静点: Sh! People are trying to sleep in here. 嘘！安静点！这里有人要睡觉呢。

shabby
/ˈʃæbi ||; ˈʃæbɪ/adj
1 in bad condition because of having been used or worn too much 破旧的；褴褛的: a shabby suit 一套破旧的衣服
2 (used about people) dressed in an untidy way; wearing clothes that are in bad condition （指人）衣衫褴褛的
3 (used about the way that sb is treated) unfair; not generous （指待遇）不公平的，小气的 ➔shabbily /-ɪli ||; -ɪlɪ/ adv a shabbily-dressed man 一个衣衫褴褛的男子 · She felt she'd been treated shabbily by her employers. 她觉得受到雇主的不公平对待。

shack
/ʃæk ||; ʃæk/noun [C] a small building, usually made of wood or metal, that has not been built well 简陋小屋；棚屋

*shade¹
/ʃeɪd ||; ʃed/noun
1 [U] an area that is out of direct sunlight and is darker and cooler than areas in the sun 阴凉处；背阴处: It was so hot that I had to go and sit in the shade. 天气这么热，我得坐到背阴地方去。
2 [C] something that keeps out light or makes it less bright 遮光物件: a lampshade 灯罩
3 shades [pl] (informal 非正式)=SUNGLASSES
4 [C] a shade (of sth) a type of a particular colour 某种颜色的浓淡；色度: a shade of green 绿色
5 [C] a small difference in the form or nature of sth 细微的差别: a word with various shades of meaning 一个有各种相近意思的词
6 [sing] a shade a little bit 少许；一点
shade²
/ʃeɪd ||; ʃed/verb[T]
1 to protect sth from direct light; to give shade to sth 给（某物）遮住光线: The sun was so bright that I had to shade my eyes. 阳光这么刺眼，我得遮住眼睛。
2 shade sth (in) to make an area of a drawing darker, for example with a pencil 使画的某部份颜色变深（如用铅笔）: The trees will look more realistic once you've shaded them in. 如果将树的颜色加深，会看上去更加真实。

shading
/ˈʃeɪdɪŋ ||; ˈʃedɪŋ/noun
1 [U] the use of colour, pencil lines, etc to give an impression of light and shade in a picture or to emphasize areas of a map, diagram, etc ﹙绘画的﹚明暗法；﹙地图、图表等的﹚浓淡色运用
2 shadings [pl] slight differences that exist between different aspects of the same thing 细微差别: the shadings of opinion found among church leaders 教会领袖各自不尽相同的观点

*shadow¹
/ˈʃædəʊ ||; ˈʃædo/noun
1 [C] a dark shape on a surface that is caused by sth being between the light and that surface 影子；阴影: The dog was chasing its own shadow. 那只狗在追逐自己的影子。 The shadows lengthened as the sun went down. 太阳下山的时候，影子越拉越长。 ☞Look at penumbra and umbra. 参看penumbra及umbra。 ☞picture at shade 见shade插图
2 [U] an area that is dark because sth prevents direct light from reaching it 阴暗的地方: His face was in shadow. 他的脸落在阴影里。
3 [sing] a very small amount of sth 微量；少许: I know without a shadow of doubt that he's lying. 毫无疑问，我知道他在说谎。
cast a shadow (across/over sth)→CAST¹
shadow²
/ˈʃædəʊ ||; ˈʃædo/verb [T] to follow and watch sb's actions 跟踪，监视（某人的行动）: The police shadowed the suspect for three days. 警方跟踪那个疑犯已有三日了。
shadow³
/ˈʃædəʊ ||; ˈʃædo/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (in British politics) belonging to the biggest political party that is not in power, with special responsibility for a particular subject, for example education or defence. Shadow ministers would probably become government ministers if their party won the next election. （英国政治）影子内阁的（指在野党的部份成员，各自负责某方面的事务，如教育、国防等。在野党如在下次大选中获胜，这些影子大臣便可能成为内阁大臣）: the shadow Cabinet 影子内阁

shadowy
/ˈʃædəʊi ||; ˈʃædəwɪ/adj
1 dark and full of shadows 多荫的；阴暗的: a shadowy forest 阴暗的森林
2 difficult to see because there is not much light 模糊的；难以辨认的: A shadowy figure was coming towards me. 有个人影在朝我走来。
3 that not much is known about; mysterious 神秘的；莫测高深的

shady
/ˈʃeɪdi ||; ˈʃedɪ/adj
1 giving shade; giving protection from the sun 成荫的；遮挡阳光的: I found a shady spot under the trees and sat down. 我在树下找到个阴凉地方，便坐了下来。
2 (informal 非正式) not completely honest or legal 不大正当的；不完全合法的

shaft
/ʃɑ:ft; US ʃæft ||; ʃæft/noun[C]
1 a long, narrow hole in which sth can go up and down or enter or leave 狭长的通道（可供某物上下移动或进出）: a lift shaft 升降机井 a mine shaft 矿井
2 a bar that connects parts of a machine so that power can pass between them （机器的）轴（连接机器各部份以传送动力）

shaggy
/ˈʃægi ||; ˈʃægɪ/adj
1 (used about hair, material, etc) long, thick and untidy （指毛发、物料等）浓密而不整齐的
2 covered with long, thick, untidy hair 满是乱蓬蓬长毛的: a shaggy dog 粗毛狗

*shake¹
/ʃeɪk ||; ʃek/verb (past tense shook /ʃʊk ||; ʃυk/ past participle shaken /ˈʃeɪkən ||; ˈʃekən/)
1 [I,T] to move (sb/sth) from side to side or up and down with short, quick movements 摇；摇动；震动: I was so nervous that I was shaking. 我紧张得全身发抖。 The whole building shakes when big lorries go past. 每当有大货车经过，整幢大厦都会震动起来。 [I] (figurative 比喻) His voice shook with emotion as he described the accident. 他在描述那宗惨剧时激动得声音颤抖。 Shake the bottle before taking the medicine. 服药前先将药瓶摇一摇。 She shook him to wake him up. 她摇他要把他叫醒。
2 [T] to disturb or upset sb/sth 扰乱；使心烦意乱或震惊: The scandal has shaken the whole country. 那宗丑闻使全国震惊。
3 [T] to cause sth to be less certain; to cause doubt about sth 使信心动摇；使怀疑: Nothing seems to shake her belief that she was right. 她相信自己是对的，似乎没有什么能动摇她的信心。
shake sb's hand/shake hands (with sb);shake sb by the hand to take sb's hand and move it up and down (when you meet sb, to show that you have agreed on sth, etc) 握手（以表示问候、同意等） ☞picture on page S19 见S19页插图 shake your head to move your head from side to side, as a way of saying no 摇头（以表示反对） ☞picture on page S19 见S19页插图 shake sb/sth off to get rid of sb/sth; to remove sth by shaking 摆脱；抖掉: I don't seem to be able to shake off this cold. 我似乎没法治好这次感冒了。 Shake the crumbs off the tablecloth. 抖掉桌布上的面包屑。
shake²
/ʃeɪk ||; sek/noun [C] the action of shaking sth or being shaken 摇动

shaken
/ˈʃeɪkən ||; ˈʃekən/ (also ˌshaken ˈup)adj shocked, upset or frightened by sth 震惊的；烦恼的；恐惧的: She was visibly shaken by the incidents. 很明显，她为这些事件感到震惊。 He was too shaken up to drive. 他十分恐惧，以至连车也不能开了。

shaker
/ˈʃeɪkə(r) ||; ˈʃekɚ/noun [C] (often in compounds 常用于构成复合词) a container that is used for shaking things 摇动器；作料瓶: a salt shaker 盐瓶 a cocktail shaker 鸡尾酒摇壶

ˈshake-up
noun [C] a complete change in the structure or organization of sth 彻底改变；大改组；大改革

shaky
/ˈʃeɪki ||; ˈʃekɪ/adj (shakier;shakiest)
1 shaking or feeling weak because you are frightened or ill 发抖的，震颤的，摇晃的（由于惊慌或生病）
2 not firm; weak or not very good 不稳固的；不坚定的；疲弱的: The table's a bit shaky so don't put anything heavy on it. 桌子有点摇晃，不要把重的东西放在上面。 They've had a shaky start to the season losing most of their games. 他们这一季一开始就表现很不稳定，大部份比赛都输了。 ➔shakily /-ɪli ||; -ɪlɪ/ adv

shale
/ʃeɪl ||; ʃel/noun [U] a type of soft stone that splits easily into thin flat layers 页岩

*shall
/ʃəl;strong form ʃæl ||; ʃəl; ʃæl/ modal verb (negative shall not short form shan't /ʃɑ:nt ||; ʃænt/)
1 used for asking for information or advice （用于询问数据或意见）: What time shall I come? 我该什么时候来呢？ Where shall we go for our holiday? 我们到哪里去度假呢？
2 used for offering to do sth （用于提供帮助）: Shall I help you carry that box? 我来替你搬那个箱子好吗？ Shall we drive you home? 我们开车送你回家好吗？
3 shall we used for suggesting that you do sth with the person or people that you are talking to （用于提出建议）: Shall we go out for a meal this evening? 我们今天晚上出去吃饭好吗？ ☞For more information about modal verbs, look at the Quick Grammar Reference section at the back of this dictionary. 有关情态动词的详细用法，参看本词典末“语法便览”部份。
4 (formal 正式) used with ‘I’ and ‘we’ in future tenses, instead of ‘will’ （在将来时中，I和we与shall连用而不和will连用）: I shall be very happy to see him again. 如果能再见到他我会很高兴。 We shan't be arriving until ten o'clock. 我们十点之前到不了。 At the end of this year, I shall have been working here for five years. 到了年底，我就在这里工作五年了。
5 (formal 正式) used for saying that sth must happen or will definitely happen （用于表示某事必须或必定发生）: In the rules it says that a player shall be sent off for using bad language. 根据比赛规则，运动员说粗话必须下场。

shallot
/ʃəˈlɒt ||; ʃəˈlɑt/noun [C] a vegetable like a small onion with a very strong taste 葱﹔青葱

*shallow
/ˈʃæləʊ ||; ˈʃælo/adj
1 not deep; with not much distance between top and bottom 不深的；浅的: The sea is very shallow here. 这里的海水很浅。 a shallow dish 浅盘子
2 not having or showing serious or deep thought 肤浅的；浅薄的: a shallow person/book 思想肤浅的人；内容浅薄的书 [OPP] for both senses deep 两个义项的反义词皆为deep ➔shallowness noun [U]

shaman
/ˈʃeɪmən ||; ˈʃemən/noun [C] a person in some religions and societies who is believed to be able to contact good and evil spirits and cure people of illnesses 萨满﹙据信能与善恶神灵沟通、能治病的人﹚

*shame¹
/ʃeɪm ||; ʃem/noun
1 [U] the unpleasant feeling of guilt and embarrassment that you get when you have done sth stupid or morally wrong; the ability to have this feeling 羞耻；羞愧；惭愧；羞耻心；羞愧感: She was filled with shame at the thought of how she had lied to her mother. 她一想到曾对母亲说谎就满怀羞愧。 His actions have brought shame on his whole family. 他的所作所为使全家蒙羞。 He doesn't care how he behaves in public. He's got no shame! 他当众肆意妄为，真是不知羞耻！ ☞adjective ashamed 形容词为ashamed
2 a shame [sing] a fact or situation that makes you feel disappointed 令人失望的事实或情况；憾事: It's a shame about Adam failing his exams, isn't it? 亚当考试不及格，真遗憾，对吗？ What a shame you have to leave so soon. 你这么快就要走了，真遗憾。 It would be a shame to miss an opportunity like this. 错过这样的机会是很可惜的。
shame²
/ʃeɪm ||; ʃem/verb [T] to make sb feel shame for sth bad that he/she has done 使感到羞愧或羞耻

shamefaced
/ˌʃeɪmˈfeɪst ||; ˌʃemˈfest/adj feeling or looking ashamed or embarrassed because you have done sth bad or stupid 面带愧色的；羞惭的；惭愧的: a shamefaced smile 惭愧的笑容 She looked shamefaced.她看上去面带愧色。 ➔shamefacedly adv: He smiled rather shamefacedly. 他非常羞愧地笑了笑。

shameful
/ˈʃeɪmfl ||; ˈʃemfəl/adj which sb should feel bad about; shocking 可耻的；丢脸的；令人吃惊的: a shameful waste of public money 浪费公款的可耻行为 ➔shamefully /-fəli ||; -fəlɪ/ adv

shameless
/ˈʃeɪmləs ||; ˈʃemlɪs/adj not feeling embarrassed about doing sth bad; having no shame 无耻的；不知羞耻的: a shameless display of greed and bad manners 无耻地表现出贪婪和粗鄙无礼 ➔shamelessly adv

*shampoo
/ʃæmˈpu: ||; ʃæmˈpu/noun
1 [C,U] a liquid that you use for washing your hair; a similar liquid for cleaning carpets, cars, etc 洗发剂；洗发精；（洗地毯、汽车等的）洗涤剂: shampoo for greasy/dry/normal hair 油性╱干性╱普通头发适用的洗发剂
2 [C] the action of washing sth with shampoo 用洗发剂或洗涤剂清洗 shampoo verb [T] (present participle shampooing third person singular present shampoos;past tense past participle shampooed)

shamrock
/ˈʃæmrɒk ||; ˈʃæmrɑk/noun [C,U] a plant with three leaves, which is the national symbol of Ireland 白花酢浆草（爱尔兰的国花）

shandy
/ˈʃændi ||; ˈʃændɪ/noun [C,U] (plural shandies) a drink that is a mixture of beer and a sweet, colourless drink with bubbles that is not alcoholic (lemonade) 香迪啤酒（啤酒和汽水混合而成的饮料）

shan't
short forSHALL NOT

shanty town
/ˈʃænti taʊn ||; ˈʃæntɪ ˌtaυn/noun [C] an area, usually on the edge of a big city, where poor people live in bad conditions in buildings that they have made themselves （城镇中的）棚屋区，贫民窟

*shape¹
/ʃeɪp ||; ʃep/noun
1 [C,U] the form of the outer edges or surfaces of sth; an example of sth that has a particular form 外形；形状: a round/square/rectangular shape 圆形；正方形；长方形 a cake in the shape ofa heart 心形的蛋糕 clothes to fit people of all shapes and sizes 适合各种体形的人的衣服 Squares, circles and triangles are all different shapes. 正方形、圆形和三角形都是不同的形状。 I could just make out a dark shape in the distance. 我只能隐约辨出远处的一个黑影。 The country is roughly square in shape. 这个国家大致呈正方形。
2 -shaped (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) having the shape mentioned 具有某种形状的: an L-shaped room L形的房间
3 [U] the physical condition of sb/sth; the good or bad state of sb/sth 情况；状态；状况: She was in such bad shape(= so ill) that she had to be taken to hospital. 她的身体状况很差，要送进医院治疗。 I go swimming regularly to keep in shape. 我经常游泳以保持强健的体魄。
4 [sing] the shape (of sth) the organization, form or structure of sth 组织；形式；结构
out of shape
1 not in the usual or correct shape 变形；走样: My sweater's gone out of shape now that I've washed it. 我的套头毛衣洗涤后走了样。
2 not physically fit （身体）不健康: You're out of shape. You should get more exercise. 你身体孱弱，应该多做运动。
take shape to start to develop well 成形: Plans to expand the company are beginning to take shape. 公司的扩展计划已开始有眉目。
*shape²
/ʃeɪp ||; ʃep/verb[T]
1 shape sth (into sth) to make sth into a particular form 将某物做成某形状: Shape the mixture into small balls. 将混合物搓成小球。
2 to influence the way in which sth develops; to cause sth to have a particular form or nature 影响发展；使具有某种形式或性质: His political ideas were shaped by his upbringing. 他的政见深受他幼年时所受教育的影响。

shapeless
/ˈʃeɪpləs ||; ˈʃeplɪs/adj not having a clear shape 没有固定形状的: a shapeless dress 不成样式的连衣裙

shapely
/ˈʃeɪpli ||; ˈʃeplɪ/adj (shapelier; shapeliest) (used especially about a woman's body) having an attractive curved shape ﹙尤指女子体形﹚有曲线美的，匀称的: a shapely young woman 身材优美的年轻女子 a shapely figure/leg 线条优美的体形/腿

*share¹
/ʃeə(r) ||; ʃɛr/verb
1 [T] share sth (out) to divide sth between two or more people （与人）分享，摊分: We shared the pizza out between the four of us. 我们四个人分食了那张馅饼。
2 [I,T] share (sth) (with sb) to have, use, do or pay sth together with another person or other people 共同拥有；共享；共同参与；分担 · I share a flat with four other people. 我和另外四个人合用一套公寓。 I shared my sandwiches with Jim. 我与吉姆分享我的三明治。 We share the same interests. 我们有共同的兴趣。
3 [T] share sth (with sb) to tell sb about sth; to allow sb to know sth 告诉；让某人知道: Sometimes it helps to share your problems. 有时候把自己的问题告诉别人有帮助。
*share²
/ʃeə(r) ||; ʃɛr/noun
1 [sing] share (of sth) a part or amount of sth that has been divided between several people （分享或分摊到的）一份: We each pay a share of the household bills. 我们每人支付一份家庭开支。 I'm willing to take my shareof the blame. 我愿意承担我应负的责任。
2 [C] [usu.pl] share (in sth) one of many equal parts into which the value of a company is divided, that can be sold to people who want to own part of the company 股；股份
the lion's share (of sth)→LION (more than) your fair share of sth→FAIR¹

sharecropper
/ˈʃeəkrɒpə(r) ||; ˈʃɛrˌkrɑpɚ/noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) a farmer who gives part of his/her crop as rent to the owner of the land 佃农

shareholder
/ˈʃeəhəʊldə(r) ||; ˈʃɛrˌholdɚ/noun [C] an owner of shares in a company 股东

shareware
/ˈʃeəweə(r) ||; ˈʃɛrˌwɛr/noun [U] (computing 计算机技术) computer programs, etc (software) that is available free for a user to test, after which he/she must pay if he/she wants to continue using it 共享软件 ☞ Compare freeware⇒. 与 freeware⇒ 比较。

sharia ( also shariah)
/ʃəˈri:ə ||; ʃəˈriə/noun [U] the system of religious laws that Muslims follow 伊斯兰教教法

shark
/ʃɑ:k ||; ʃɑrk/noun [C] a large, often dangerous, sea fish that has a lot of sharp teeth 鲨鱼

*sharp¹
/ʃɑ:p ||; ʃɑrp/adj
1 having a very thin but strong edge or point; that can cut or make a hole in sth easily 锋利的；尖锐的: a sharp knife 锋利的刀 sharp teeth 尖牙 [OPP] blunt 反义词为blunt
2 (used about a change of direction or level) very great and sudden （指方向或水平的改变）急剧的: a sharp rise/fall in inflation 通胀急升╱骤降 This is a sharp bend so slow down. 这是个急转弯，因此要放慢速度。
3 clear and definite 清晰的；明确的: the sharp outline of the hills 群山清晰的轮廓 a sharp contrast between the lives of the rich and the poor 贫富悬殊
4 able to think, act, understand, see or hear quickly （思维、行动、理解力、视觉或听觉）敏锐的，灵敏的: a sharp mind 敏锐的头脑 You must have sharp eyes if you can read that sign from here. 要是你从这里也看得清那个标志，你的目光一定很敏锐。
5 (used about actions or movements) quick and sudden （指行动或动作）迅速的，突然的: One short sharp blow was enough to end the fight. 只要快速地轻击一拳就能结束这场拳赛。
6 (used about words, comments, etc) said in an angry way; intended to upset sb or be critical （指措辞、评论等）严厉的，辛辣的，尖刻的
7 (used about pain) very strong and sudden （指疼痛）剧烈的，急剧的: a sharp pain in the chest 胸部剧痛 [OPP] dull 反义词为dull
8 (used about sth that affects the senses) strong; not mild or gentle, often causing an unpleasant feeling （指刺激感官的事物）强烈的，浓烈的: a sharp taste 浓烈的味道 a sharp wind 烈风
9 (symbol #) (in music) half a note higher than the stated note （音乐）升半音的: in the key of C sharp minor 用升C小调 ☞Look at flat ¹(5). 参看flat^1(5)。 ☞picture at music 见music插图
10 (in music) slightly higher than the correct note （音乐）音调偏高的: That last note was sharp. Can you sing it again? 最后一个音偏高了，再唱一次好吗？ ☞Look at flat ¹(6). 参看flat^1(6)。 ➔sharply /ˈʃɑ:pli ||; ˈʃɑrplɪ/ adv The road bends sharply to the left. 这条路向左急转弯。 Share prices fell sharply this morning. 今天早上股价大跌。 ➔sharpness noun [U]
sharp²
/ʃɑ:p ||; ʃɑrp/adv
1 (used about a time) exactly, punctually （指时间）正，准时: Be here at three o'clock sharp. 三点正到这里。
2 turning suddenly 突然（拐弯）: Go to the traffic lights and turn sharp right. 走到交通灯，然后向右急转弯。
3 (in music) slightly higher than the correct note （音乐）音调偏高 ☞Look at flat ¹(6). 参看flat^1(6)。
sharp³
/ʃɑ:p ||; ʃɑrp/noun [C] (symbol #) (in music) a note that is half a note higher than the note with the same letter （音乐）升半音 ☞Look at flat ²(2). 参看flat^2(2)。

sharpen
/ˈʃɑ:pən ||; ˈʃɑrpən/verb [I,T] to become or to make sth sharp or sharper （使）变得（更）尖锐或锋利: to sharpen a knife 磨刀 The outline of the trees sharpened as it grew lighter. 天越来越亮，树木的轮廓变得清晰了。

sharpener
/ˈʃɑ:pnə(r) ||; ˈʃɑrpənɚ/noun [C] an object or tool that is used for making sth sharp 磨具；削具: a pencil/knife sharpener 卷笔刀；磨刀石

sharpshooter
/ˈʃɑ:pʃu:tə(r) ||; ˈʃɑrpˌʃutɚ/noun [C] a person who is skilled at shooting a gun 神枪手；神射手

shatter
/ˈʃætə(r) ||; ˈʃætɚ/verb
1 [I,T] (used about glass, etc) to break or make sth break into very small pieces （指玻璃等）（使）粉碎，破碎: I dropped the glass and it shattered on the floor. 我把玻璃杯掉到地板上打碎了。 The force of the explosion shattered the windows. 爆炸的威力把窗户都震破了。
2 [T] to destroy sth completely 彻底摧毁；粉碎: Her hopes were shattered by the news. 她的希望被那个消息粉碎了。

shattered
/ˈʃætəd ||; ˈʃætɚd/adj
1 very shocked and upset 震惊不安的
2 (informal 非正式) very tired 精疲力竭的: I'm absolutely shattered. 我累死了。

ˈshatter-proof
adj designed not to shatter (1) 防碎的；不碎的: shatter-proof glass 防碎玻璃

*shave¹
/ʃeɪv ||; ʃev/verb [I,T] shave (sth) (off) to remove hair from the face or another part of the body with an extremely sharp piece of metal (a razor) （用剃刀）剃，刮（胡子、毛发等）: I cut myself shaving this morning. 今天早上我刮胡子的时候割伤了自己。 When did you shave off your moustache? 你是什么时候把八字胡子剃掉的？ [T] to shave your legs 刮掉腿上的毛 shave sth off (sth) to cut a very small amount from sth 刨下，削掉（薄薄的一层）: We'll have to shave a bit off the door to make it close properly. 我们要把门刨掉一些，使它能关好。
shave²
/ʃeɪv ||; ʃev/noun [C] [usu.sing] the action of shaving 剃；刮: to have a shave 刮胡子 I need a shave. 我需要刮刮胡子。 a close shave/thing→CLOSE³

shaven
/ˈʃeɪvn ||; ˈʃevən/adj having been shaved 剃过的: clean-shaven (= not having a beard or moustache) （把胡子）剃得干干净净的

shaver
/ˈʃeɪvə(r) ||; ˈʃevɚ/ (also electric razor) noun [C] an electric tool that is used for removing hair from the face or another part of the body 电动剃刀

ˈshaving cream
noun [U] special cream or foam for spreading over the face before shaving 剃须膏；修面霜

shavings
/ˈʃeɪvɪŋz ||; ˈʃevɪŋz/noun [pl] thin pieces cut from a piece of wood, etc using a sharp tool, especially a plane¹ (2) ﹙刨等削下的﹚削片；刨花: wood shavings 刨花

shawl
/ʃɔ:l ||; ʃɔl/noun [C] a large piece of cloth that is worn by a woman round her shoulders or head or that is put round a baby 披肩；披风；大围巾；襁褓

s/he
/ˌʃi: ə ˈhi ||; ˌʃi ɚ ˈhi/pronoun used in writing when the subject of the verb could be either female (she) or male (he) 他/她: If a person is not actively seeking work, s/he is not a member of the labour force. 假如一个人没有在积极地寻找工作，那么他/她就不是劳动力中的一员。

*she
/ʃi: ||; ʃi/pronoun (the subject of a verb) the female person who has already been mentioned （作动词的主语）她（指上文提及的女子）: ‘What does your sister do?’ ‘She's a dentist.’ “你姐姐从事哪一个行业？”“她是牙医。” I asked her a question but she didn't answer. 我问她一个问题，但她没有回答。

shear
/ʃɪə(r) ||; ʃɪr/verb [T] (past tense sheared;past participle shorn /ʃɔ:n ||; ʃɔrn/or sheared) to cut the wool off a sheep 剪羊毛

shears
/ʃɪəz ||; ʃɪrz/noun [pl] a tool that is like a very large pair of scissors and that is used for cutting things in the garden 大剪刀（用于园艺）: a pair of shears 一把大剪刀 ☞picture at garden 见garden插图

sheath
/ʃi:θ ||; ʃiθ/noun [C] (plural sheaths /ʃi:ðz ||; ʃiðz/) a cover for a knife or other sharp weapon （刀或其他利刃的）鞘，套 ☞picture at spear 见spear插图

she'd
/ʃi:d ||; ʃid/ short forSHE HAD, SHE WOULD

shed¹
/ʃed ||; ʃɛd/noun [C] a small building that is used for keeping things or animals in 棚屋，小屋（用以储物或畜养牲口）: a garden shed 花园小棚 a bicycle shed 自行车棚 a cattle shed 牛棚 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图
shed²
/ʃed ||; ʃɛd/verb [T] (present participle shedding;past tense past participle shed)
1 to lose sth because it falls off 脱落；剥落；蜕下: This snake sheds its skin every year. 这种蛇每年都蜕皮。 Autumn is coming and the trees are beginning to shed their leaves. 秋天将至，树木开始落叶。
2 to get rid of or remove sth that is not wanted 摆脱；除去
shed blood(written 书面语) to kill or injure people 杀人；伤人 shed light on sth to make sth clear and easy to understand 使清晰或容易明白 shed tears to cry 哭；落泪

sheen
/ʃi:n ||; ʃin/noun [sing, U] a soft smooth shiny quality 光泽；光辉；光彩: hair with a healthy sheen 闪着健康光泽的头发

*sheep
/ʃi:p ||; ʃip/noun [C] (plural sheep) an animal that is kept on farms and used for its wool or meat 羊；绵羊 A male sheep is a ram, a female sheep is a ewe and a young sheep is a lamb. When sheep make a noise they bleat. This is written as baa. The meat from sheep is called lamb or mutton. Look at the note at meat. 公羊叫做ram，母羊叫做ewe，小羊叫做lamb。指羊叫可用bleat，指羊的叫声可用baa。羊肉叫做lamb或mutton。参看meat的注释。
sheepdog
/ˈʃi:pdɒg ||; ˈʃipˌdɔg/noun [C] a dog that has been trained to control sheep 牧羊犬

sheepish
/ˈʃi:pɪʃ ||; ˈʃipɪʃ/adj feeling or showing embarrassment because you have done sth silly 羞惭的；局促不安的: a sheepish grin 羞惭的微笑 ➔sheepishly adv

sheepskin
/ˈʃi:pskɪn ||; ˈʃipˌskɪn/noun [uc] the skin of a sheep, including the wool, from which coats, etc are made 带毛羊皮（可制成大衣等）: a sheepskin rug/jacket 羊皮毯；羊皮袄

sheer
/ʃɪə(r) ||; ʃɪr/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) used to emphasize the size, degree or amount of sth （用于强调某物的大小、程度或数量）: It's sheer stupidity to drink and drive. 酒后驾驶完全是愚蠢的行径。 It was sheer luck that I happened to be in the right place at the right time. 我恰好在适当的时间来到适当的地方，这全凭运气。 Her success is due to sheer hard work. 她的成功全凭努力工作。 I only agreed out of sheer desperation. 我完全出于绝望才答应下来。
2 very steep; almost vertical 陡峭的；几乎垂直的: Don't walk near the edge. It's a sheer drop to the sea. 不要走近边缘，那里非常陡峭，往下去就是大海。

*sheet
/ʃi:t ||; ʃit/noun[C]
1 a large piece of material used on a bed 被单；床单 ☞picture at bed 见bed插图
2 a piece of paper that is used for writing, printing, etc on （书写、打印等用的）纸: a sheet of notepaper 一张信纸 Write each answer on a separate sheet. 答一道题用一张纸。 ☞Look at balance sheet. 参看balance sheet。
3 a flat, thin piece of any material, especially a square or rectangular one 薄片（尤指正方形或长方形的）: a sheet of metal/glass 一块金属薄板╱玻璃
4 a wide, flat area of sth 一大片: The road was covered with a sheet of ice. 路上覆盖着一层冰。

ˌsheet ˈlightning
noun [U] LIGHTNING(= flashes of light in the sky when there is a storm) that appears as a broad area of light in the sky 片状闪电 ☞Compare forked lightning. 与forked lightning比较。

ˈsheet music
noun [U] music printed on separate pieces of paper rather than in a book 活页乐谱

sheikh
/ʃeɪk; US ʃi:k ||; ʃik/ (also sheik) noun [C] an Arab ruler （阿拉伯的）酋长

sheikhdom
/ˈʃeɪkdəm;ˈʃi:k- ||; ˈʃekdəm; ˈʃik-/noun [C] an area of land ruled by a sheikh 酋长国；酋长统辖的领地

*shelf
/ʃelf ||; ʃɛlf/noun [C] (plural shelves /ʃelvz ||; ʃɛlvz/) a long flat piece of wood, glass, etc that is fixed to a wall or in a cupboard, used for putting things on （墙上或橱柜内的）架子，搁板: I put up a shelf in the kitchen. 我在厨房内搭了一个架子。 I reached up and took down the book from the top shelf. 我伸手去把书架顶层的那本书拿下来。 a bookshelf 书架 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

*shell¹
/ʃel ||; ʃɛl/noun
1 [C,U] a hard covering that protects eggs, nuts and some animals （蛋、坚果及某些动物的）壳: Some children were collecting shells on the beach. 一些孩子在海滩上捡贝壳。 a piece of eggshell 一个蛋壳 Tortoises have a hard shell. 乌龟长有硬壳。 ☞pictures at mollusc, nut and shellfish 见mollusc、nut及shellfish插图
2 [C] the walls or hard outer structure of sth （某物的）壁，坚硬的外部结构: The body shell of the car is made in another factory. 这种汽车的框架在另一个工厂制造。
3 [C] a metal container that explodes when it is fired from a large gun 炮弹
come out of your shell to become less shy and more confident when talking to other people 不再羞怯；变得比较自信 go, retreat, etc into your shell to suddenly become shy and stop talking 变得羞怯；不愿与人接触

she'll
/ʃi:l ||; ʃil/ short forSHE WILL
shell²
/ʃel ||; ʃɛl/verb[T]
1 to take the hard outer layer (shell) off a nut or other kind of food 剥…的壳: to shell peas 剥豌豆
2 to fire metal containers (shells) full of explosives from a large gun 开炮；炮轰

shellfish
/ˈʃelfɪʃ ||; ˈʃɛlˌfɪʃ/noun (plural shellfish)
1 [C] a type of animal that lives in water and has a shell 贝类水产；水生甲壳动物
2 [U] these animals eaten as food 可食用的贝类水产或甲壳动物

ˈshell shock
noun [U] a mental illness that can affect soldiers who have been in battle for a long time 炮弹休克﹙长时期作战引起的精神疾患﹚

ˈshell-shocked
adj
1 shocked, confused or anxious because of a difficult situation, and unable to think or act normally 吓昏了头的；胡涂得不知所措的；焦虑得无法应对的: I felt completely shell-shocked after I heard the news. 听到那个消息，我惊得头都昏了。
2 suffering from shell shock 患炮弹休克的

*shelter¹
/ˈʃeltə(r) ||; ˈʃɛltɚ/noun
1 [U] shelter (from sth) protection from danger or bad weather 庇护；避难；遮蔽: to give somebody food and shelter 为某人提供食物及容身之所 We looked around for somewhere to take shelter from the storm. 我们环视四周，想找个避风雨的地方。
2 [C] a small building that gives protection, for example from bad weather or attack 遮蔽所；庇护所；避难所: a bus shelter 公共汽车候车亭 an air-raid shelter 防空庇护所
shelter²
/ˈʃeltə(r) ||; ˈʃɛltɚ/verb
1 [I] shelter (from sth) to find protection or a safe place 寻求保护；躲避；避难: Let's shelter from the rain under that tree. 我们到那棵树下去避雨吧。
2 [T] shelter sb/sth (from sb/sth) to protect sb/sth; to provide a safe place away from harm or danger 保护；庇护；遮蔽: The trees shelter the house from the wind. 那些树给房子挡风。

sheltered
/ˈʃeltəd ||; ˈʃɛltɚd/adj
1 (used about a place) protected from bad weather （指地方）可遮风挡雨的
2 protected from unpleasant things in your life 与不愉快的现实隔绝的: We had a sheltered childhood, living in the country. 我们儿时住在乡村，度过了无忧无虑的童年。

shelve
/ʃelv ||; ʃɛlv/verb [T] to decide not to continue with a plan, etc, either for a short time or permanently 搁置（计划等）: Plans for a new motorway have been shelved. 兴建新高速公路的计划已搁置了。

shelves
/ʃelvz ||; ʃɛlvz/ plural ofSHELF

shelving
/ˈʃelvɪŋ ||; ˈʃɛlvɪŋ/noun [U] a set of shelves 一组架子

shepherd¹
/ˈʃepəd ||; ˈʃɛpɚd/noun [C] a person whose job is to look after sheep 牧羊人
shepherd²
/ˈʃepəd ||; ˈʃɛpɚd/verb [T] to guide and look after people so that they do not get lost 带领；引导

sherbet
/ˈʃɜ:bət ||; ˈʃɝbɪt/noun [U] (Brit 英) a flavoured powder that makes bubbles when you put it in your mouth and is eaten as a sweet 甜味汽水粉

sheriff
/ˈʃerɪf ||; ˈʃɛrɪf/noun [C] an officer of the law in a US county （美国的）县治安官，郡保安官

sherry
/ˈʃeri ||; ˈʃɛrɪ/noun [C,U] (plural sherries) a type of strong Spanish wine; a glass of this wine 雪利酒（一种西班牙葡萄酒）；一杯雪利酒

she's
/ʃi:z;ʃiz ||; ʃiz; ʃɪz/ short forSHE IS, SHE HAS

shield¹
/ʃi:ld ||; ʃild/noun[C]
1 (in past times) a large piece of metal or wood that soldiers carried to protect themselves （旧时）盾，盾牌
2 riot shield a piece of equipment made of strong plastic, that the police use to protect themselves from angry crowds 防暴盾牌
3 a person or thing that is used to protect sb/sth especially by forming a barrier 防御物；屏障: The metal door acted as a shield against the explosion. 那道金属门挡住了爆炸的威力。
4 an object or drawing in the shape of a shield, sometimes used as a prize in a sports competition 盾形对象，盾形纹徽（有时用作体育比赛的奖品） ☞picture at medal 见medal插图
shield²
/ʃi:ld ||; ʃild/verb [T] shield sb/sth (against/from sb/sth) to protect sb/sth from danger or damage 保护；遮挡: I shielded my eyes from the bright light with my hand. 我用手遮住眼睛，以免受强光照射。

shift¹
/ʃɪft ||; ʃɪft/verb[I,T]
1 to move or be moved from one position or place to another 移动: She shifted uncomfortably in her chair. 她在椅子里不自在地挪动身子。 He shifted his desk closer to the window. 他把办公桌搬近窗口。
2 to change your opinion of or attitude towards sth 改变（看法或态度）: Public attitudes towards marriage have shifted over the years. 这些年来，公众对婚姻的态度发生了变化。
shift the blame/responsibility (for sth) (onto sb) to make sb else responsible for sth you should do or for sth bad you have done 把责任或罪责推到某人身上
shift²
/ʃɪft ||; ʃɪft/noun
1 [C] a shift (in sth) a change in your opinion of or attitude towards sth （看法或态度的）改变: There has been a shift in public opinion away from war. 舆论改变了，不再支持开战。
2 [C] (in a factory, etc) one of the periods that the working day is divided into （工厂等）班，轮班: to work in shifts 轮班工作 shift work/workers 轮班的工作╱工人 to be on the day/night shift 上日班╱夜班
3 [C] [with.sop] the workers who work a particular shift 轮班职工: The night shift has/have just gone off duty. 上夜班的人刚下班。
4 [U] one of the keys that you use for writing on a computer, etc, that allows you to write a big (capital) letter （计算机等上的）移位键: the shift key 移位键

ˌshifting ˌcultiˈvation
noun [U] (technical术语) a way of farming in some tropical countries in which farmers use an area of land until it cannot be used for growing plants any more, then move on to a new area of land 轮垦

shifty
/ˈʃɪfti ||; ˈʃɪftɪ/adj (used about a person or his/her appearance) giving the impression that you cannot trust him/her （指人或其外表）不可信赖的，不老实的: shifty eyes 贼眼

shilling
/ˈʃɪlɪŋ ||; ˈʃɪlɪŋ/noun[C]
1 the basic unit of money in some countries, for example Kenya 先令（某些国家的基本货币单位，如肯尼亚）
2 a British coin worth twelve pence that was used in past times 先令（已停用的英国硬币，原值十二便士）

shimmer
/ˈʃɪmə(r) ||; ˈʃɪmɚ/verb [I] to shine with a soft light that seems to be moving 闪闪发微光: Moonlight shimmered on the sea. 月光在海面上闪烁。

shin
/ʃɪn ||; ʃɪn/noun [C] the front part of your leg from your knee to your foot 胫；胫部 ☞picture at body 见body插图

ˈshin bone
=TIBIA

*shine¹
/ʃaɪn ||; ʃaɪn/verb (past tense past participle shone /ʃɒn; US ʃəʊn ||; ʃon/)
1 [I] to send out or to send back (reflect) light; to be bright 发光；反射光线；照耀: I could see a light shining in the distance. 我看见远处亮着一盏灯。 The sea shone in the light of the moon. 海水在月光下闪闪发亮。
2 [T] to direct a light at sb/sth （用灯）照射: The policeman shone a torch on the stranger's face. 警察把手电筒往那个陌生人的脸上照射。
3 [I] shine (at/in sth) to be very good at a school subject, a sport, etc （学生在某学科、体育等方面）出类拔萃: She has always shone at languages. 她在语言方面总是名列前茅。
shine²
/ʃaɪn ||; ʃaɪn/noun[sing]
1 a bright effect caused by light hitting a polished surface 光亮；光泽
2 the act of polishing sth so that it shines 擦亮

shingle
/ˈʃɪŋgl ||; ˈʃɪŋgḷ/noun [U] small pieces of stone lying in a mass on a beach 满布海滩的小石子

shingles
/ˈʃɪŋglz ||; ˈʃɪŋgḷz/noun [U] a disease that affects the long thin threads in the body that carry messages to and from the brain(nerves)and produces a band of painful spots on the skin 带状疹（一种疾病，影响神经，皮肤上起泡）

ˈshin pad
noun [C] a thick piece of material used to protect the front part of your leg from your knee to your foot (the shin) when playing some sports （运动员的）护胫

shiny
/ˈʃaɪni ||; ˈʃaɪnɪ/adj (shinier;shiniest) causing a bright effect when in the sun or in light 发亮的；发光的: The shampoo leaves your hair soft and shiny. 这种洗发剂能使你的头发变得柔软而有光泽。 a shiny new car 闪闪发亮的新车

*ship¹
/ʃɪp ||; ʃɪp/noun [C] a large boat used for carrying passengers or cargo by sea 船；轮船: to travel by ship 乘船旅行 to launch a ship 主持新船下水仪式 ☞picture at boat 见boat插图 ☞A boat is smaller than a ship. A liner is used to carry people for long distances called voyages and a ferry is used for short distances called crossings. boat比ship小。liner（客轮）用于载客，作称之为航行(voyage)的长途旅程。ferry（渡船）则用于短程的横渡(crossing)。
ship²
/ʃɪp ||; ʃɪp/verb [T] (shipping;shipped) to send or carry sth by ship or by another type of transport 用船等运送或装运

shipbuilder
/ˈʃɪpbɪldə(r) ||; ˈʃɪpˌbɪldɚ/noun [C] a person or company who makes or builds ships 造船工人；造船公司 ➔shipbuilding noun [U]

shipload
/ˈʃɪpləʊd ||; ˈʃɪpˌlod/noun [C] as many goods or passengers as a ship can carry 船只运载量: a shipload of food and medical supplies 一船食品和医疗补给

shipment
/ˈʃɪpmənt ||; ˈʃɪpmənt/noun
1 [U] the carrying of goods from one place to another 运载（货物）
2 [C] a quantity of goods that are sent from one place to another 运载的一批货物

shipper
/ˈʃɪpə(r) ||; ˈʃɪpɚ/noun [C] a company that arranges for goods to be sent from one place to another, especially by ship but also by land and air 托运人；发货人

shipping
/ˈʃɪpɪŋ ||; ˈʃɪpɪŋ/noun[U]
1 ships in general or considered as a group 船队
2 the carrying of goods from one place to another 运载（货物）: a shipping company 航运公司

shipshape
/ˈʃɪpʃeɪp ||; ˈʃɪpˌʃep/adj clean and neat; in good order and ready to use 整洁有序的；井井有条的: They had to rush to get everything shipshape before the official opening. 他们得赶在正式开幕之前把所有事安排妥当。

shipwreck
/ˈʃɪprek ||; ˈʃɪpˌrɛk/noun [C,U] an accident at sea in which a ship is destroyed by a storm, rocks, etc and sinks 海难 ☞A person or a ship that has suffered such an accident has been shipwrecked. shipwrecked用于形容遭海难的人或船只。

shipyard
/ˈʃɪpjɑ:d ||; ˈʃɪpˌjɑrd/noun [C] a place where ships are repaired or built 船坞；造船厂

shirk
/ʃɜ:k ||; ʃɝk/verb[I,T] to avoid doing sth that is difficult or unpleasant, especially because you are too lazy 逃避（困难或厌恶的工作，尤指因为懒惰） [T] to shirk your responsibilities 逃避责任

*shirt
/ʃɜ:t ||; ʃɝt/noun [C] a piece of clothing made of cotton, etc, worn on the upper part of the body （男装）衬衫 A shirt usually has a collar at the neck, long or short sleeves, and buttons down the front. 衬衫通常有领子(collar)，分长袖(long sleeves)和短袖(short sleeves)，前幅有钮扣(button)。 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图

shirtsleeve
/ˈʃɜ:tsli:v ||; ˈʃɝtˌsliv/noun [C, usually pl] a sleeve of a shirt 衬衫的袖子: He rolled up his shirtsleeves. 他卷起了他的衬衫袖子。 in (your) shirtsleeves wearing a shirt without a jacket, etc on top of it 只穿衬衫﹙不套外衣﹚: It was a hot day and most of the men were in shirtsleeves.这一天天很热，大多数男子只穿着衬衫。

ˈshirt tail
noun [C] the part of a shirt that is below the waist and is usually inside your trousers 衬衫下摆: He ran out of the house, his tie in his hand and his shirt tail hanging out. 他跑出屋，手里拿着领带，衬衫下摆露在外面。

shish kebab
/ˈʃɪʃ kɪbæb ||; ˈʃɪʃ kəˌbɑb/noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) = kebab

shiver
/ˈʃɪvə(r) ||; ˈʃɪvɚ/verb [I] to shake slightly, especially because you are cold or frightened 颤抖，哆嗦（尤指因寒冷或恐惧）: shivering with cold/fright 冷得╱吓得发抖 shiver noun [C]: The thought sent a shiver down my spine. 那个念头使我不寒而栗。

shoal
/ʃəʊl ||; ʃol/noun [C] a large group of fish that feed and swim together 鱼群

*shock¹
/ʃɒk ||; ʃɑk/noun
1 [C,U] the feeling that you get when sth unpleasant happens suddenly; the situation that causes this feeling 震惊；惊吓；令人震惊的情况: The sudden noise gave him a shock. 突如其来的声音把他吓了一跳。 The bad news came as a shock to her. 那个坏消息使她感到震惊。 I'm still suffering from shock at the news. 那个消息至今仍然令我震惊。 His mother is in a state of shock. 他的母亲惊愕不已。
2 [U] a serious medical condition of extreme weakness caused by damage to the body 休克: He was in/went into shock after the accident. 意外发生后，他处于休克状态。
3 [C] a violent shaking movement (caused by a crash, explosion, etc) 重击，震荡（因碰撞、爆炸等造成）
4 [C] =ELECTRIC SHOCK
*shock²
/ʃɒk ||; ʃɑk/verb
1 [T] to cause an unpleasant feeling of surprise in sb 使惊愕或震惊: We were shocked by his death. 我们对他的死感到震惊。 I'm sorry, I didn't mean to shock you when I came in. 对不起，我进来让你吃了一惊，我不是有意的。
2 [I,T] to make sb feel disgusted or offended 使厌恶或生气: These films deliberately set out to shock. 这些电影有意要让人感到愤慨。 ➔shocked adj a shocked expression/look 震惊的表情╱神色

ˈshock absorber
noun [C] a device that is fitted to each wheel of a vehicle in order to reduce the effects of travelling over rough ground, so that passengers can be more comfortable （汽车的）减震器

shocking
/ˈʃɒkɪŋ ||; ˈʃɑkɪŋ/adj
1 that offends or upsets people; that is morally wrong 令人气愤或沮丧的；极丑恶的: a shocking accident 令人震惊的事故 shocking behaviour/news 令人发指的行为；令人震惊的消息
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) (informal 非正式) very bad 极坏的

ˈshock wave
noun [C] a movement of very high air pressure that is caused by an explosion, a movement of the earth's surface(an earthquake), etc （爆炸、地震等产生的）冲击波

shod
past tense, past participle ofSHOE²

shoddy
/ˈʃɒdi ||; ˈʃɑdɪ/adj
1 made carelessly or with poor quality materials 劣质的；粗制滥造的: shoddy goods 劣质货品
2 dishonest or unfair 不诚实的；不公平的 ➔shoddily adv

*shoe¹
/ʃu: ||; ʃu/noun[C]
1 a type of covering for the foot, usually made of leather or plastic 鞋子: a pair of shoes 一双鞋子 running shoes 跑鞋 What size are your shoes/What is your shoe size? 你穿哪个尺码的鞋？ I tried on a nice pair of shoes but they didn't fit. 我试穿了一双很漂亮的鞋子，可惜不合脚。
2 =HORSESHOE
in my, your, etc place/shoes→PLACE¹
shoe²
/ʃu: ||; ʃu/verb [T] (past tense past participle shod /ʃɒd ||; ʃɑd/) to fit a shoe on a horse 给（马）钉马蹄铁

shoebox
/ˈʃu:bɒks ||; ˈʃuˌbɑks/noun [C] the box in which a new pair of shoes is sold 鞋盒

shoehorn
/ˈʃu:hɔ:n ||; ˈʃuˌhɔrn/noun [C] a curved piece of plastic or metal that you use to help the back of your foot go into your shoe 鞋拔

shoelace
/ˈʃu:leɪs ||; ˈʃuˌles/ (especially US 尤为美 shoestring) noun [C] a long thin piece of material like string used to fasten a shoe 鞋带: to tie/untie a shoelace 系上╱解开鞋带 ☞picture at button 见button插图

shoemaker
/ˈʃu:meɪkə(r) ||; ˈʃuˌmekɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is making shoes and boots 鞋匠；制鞋工人

shoestring
/ˈʃu:strɪŋ ||; ˈʃuˌstrɪŋ/ (especially US 尤为美) =SHOELACE on a shoestring using very little money 用极少的钱: to live on a shoestring 靠极少的钱过日子

shone
past tense, past participle ofSHINE¹

shoo¹
/ʃu: ||; ʃu/verb [T] (past tense past participle shooed)shoo sb/sth away, off, out, etc to make sb/sth go away by saying ‘shoo’ and waving your hands 发出嘘声并挥手把…赶开: She shooed the children out of the kitchen. 她用嘘声把孩子们赶出厨房。
shoo²
/ʃu: ||; ʃu/ exclamation used to tell a child or an animal to go away 嘘（用于叫孩子或动物走开）

ˈshoo-in
noun [C] (US, informal 美，非正式) a person or team that will win easily 稳操胜券的人﹙或队﹚: He's a shoo-in for reelection. 他稳操胜券，能再度当选。

shook
past tense ofSHAKE¹

*shoot¹
/ʃu:t ||; ʃut/verb (past tense past participle shot /ʃɒt ||; ʃɑt/)
1 [I,T] shoot (sth) (at sb/sth) to fire a gun or another weapon 开枪；射击；射箭: Don't shoot! 不要开枪！ She shot an arrow at the target, but missed it. 她向靶子射了一箭，但没有射中。
2 [T] to injure or kill sb/sth with a gun 射伤；击毙: The policeman was shot in the arm. 那个警察手臂中了一枪。 The soldier was shot dead. 那个士兵被射杀。
3 [I,T] to hunt and kill birds and animals with a gun as a sport 狩猎；猎杀: He goes shooting at the weekends. 他每逢周末都去打猎。 ☞Look at hunting. 参看hunting。
4 [I,T] to move somewhere quickly and suddenly; to make sth move in this way （使）朝某方向突然快速移动: The car shot past me at 100 miles per hour. 那辆汽车以每小时100英里的速度从我身旁飞驰而过。
5 [I] (of pain) to go very suddenly along part of your body （指疼痛）剧烈: The pain shot up my leg. 我的腿一阵剧痛。 shooting pains in the chest 胸口剧痛
6 [I,T] to make a film or photograph of sth 拍摄电影或照片 · They shot the scene ten times. 那场戏他们拍了十次。
7 [I] shoot (at sth) (in football, etc) to try to kick or hit the ball into the goal （足球等）射门: He should have shot instead of passing. 他应该射门而不该把球传给别人。 ☞noun shot 名词为shot
shoot sb/sth down to make sb/sth fall to the ground by shooting him/her/it 击落；击倒: The helicopter was shot down by a missile. 那架直升机被一枚导弹击落。 shoot up to increase by a large amount; to grow very quickly 迅速增加或上升: Prices have shot up in the past year. 过去一年物价急剧上升。
shoot²
/ʃu:t ||; ʃut/noun [C] a new part of a plant or tree 嫩芽；新枝 ☞picture at flower 见flower插图

shooter
/ˈʃu:tə(r) ||; ˈʃutɚ/noun[C]
1 (especially in compounds 尤用于构成复合词) a person or weapon that shoots 射手；射击武器
2 (informal 非正式) a gun 枪
3 (sports 体育) a player who is good at throwing the ball through the basket and scoring points in basketball ﹙篮球﹚擅长投篮者: He's a good three-point shooter. 他擅长投三分球。

ˌshooting ˈstar
noun [C] a small piece of rock in space(a meteor)that travels very fast and burns with a bright light as it enters the earth's atmosphere 流星

*shop¹
/ʃɒp ||; ʃɑp/ (US 美 store) noun [C] a building or part of a building where things are bought and sold 商店；店铺: a cake/shoe shop 蛋糕店；鞋店 a corner shop (= a local shop, usually at the corner of a street) 街角的店 When do the shops open? 商店通常什么时候开门？ a butcher's/baker's shop 肉店；面包店 We usually say at the butcher's, etc instead of ‘at the butcher's shop’, etc. 通常说at the butcher's等，而不说at the butcher's shop等。 talk shop→TALK¹
*shop²
/ʃɒp ||; ʃɑp/verb [I] (shopping;shopped)shop (for sth) to go to a shop or shops in order to buy things （去商店）购物: He's shopping for some new clothes. 他正在商店选购新衣服。 Go shopping is more common than shop We go shopping every Saturday. go shopping较shop常用：We go shopping every Saturday.我们每个星期六都去购物。 ➔shopper noun [C] shop around (for sth) to look at the price and quality of an item in different shops before you decide where to buy it 逐店比较价格及质量；货比三家

shopaholic
/ˌʃɒpəˈhɒlɪk ||; ˌʃɑpəˈhɑlɪk/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who spends a lot of time shopping 购物狂

ˈshop assistant
(US 美 sales clerkclerk) noun [C] a person who works in a shop 店员

ˌshop ˈfloor
noun [sing] (Brit 英)
1 an area of a factory where the goods are made by the workers 车间；工作场所: to work on the shop floor 在车间工作
2 the workers in a factory, not the managers （工厂的）工人（非经理）

shopkeeper
/ˈʃɒpki:pə(r) ||; ˈʃɑpˌkipɚ/ (US 美 storekeeper) noun [C] a person who owns or manages a small shop 店主

shoplifter
/ˈʃɒplɪftə(r) ||; ˈʃɑpˌlɪftɚ/noun [C] a person who steals sth from a shop while pretending to be a customer 在店铺行窃的人 ☞Look at the note at thief. 参看thief的注释。

shoplifting
/ˈʃɒplɪftɪŋ ||; ˈʃɑpˌlɪftɪŋ/noun [U] the crime of stealing goods from a shop while pretending to be a customer 店铺行窃罪: He was arrested for shoplifting. 他因犯了店铺行窃罪而被捕。 ☞Look at lift ¹ (6). 参看lift^1(6)。

*shopping
/ˈʃɒpɪŋ ||; ˈʃɑpɪŋ/noun[U]
1 the activity of going to the shops and buying things 购物: We always do the shopping on a Friday night. 我们总是星期五晚上去购物。 a shopping basket/bag/trolley 购物篮╱袋╱手推车
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) the things that you have bought in a shop 从商店买到的东西

ˈshopping centre
(US 美 shopping mallmall) noun [C] a place where there are many shops, either outside or in a covered building 购物中心 ☞picture on page C8 见C8页插图

ˈshopping list
noun [C] a list that you make of all the things that you need to buy when you go shopping 购物单；采购单

*shore¹
/ʃɔ:(r) ||; ʃɔr/noun [C,U] the land at the edge of a sea or lake （海或湖的）岸，滨: The sailors went on shore (= on land). 水手上岸了。 ☞Look at ashore. 参看ashore。
shore²
/ʃɔ:(r) ||; ʃɔr/verb shore sth up
1 to support part of a building or other large structure by placing large pieces of wood or metal against or under it so that it does not fall down 用木或金属柱支撑（房子等大型结构）
2 to help support sth that is weak or going to fail 扶住，稳住（虚弱的或快要失败的事物）: The measures were aimed at shoring up the economy. 这些措施旨在稳定经济。

shoreline
/ˈʃɔ:laɪn ||; ˈʃɔrˌlaɪn/noun [C, usually sing] the edge of the ocean, a lake or a sea 海﹙或湖﹚滨线；海﹙或湖﹚岸线: a rocky shoreline 岩石嶙峋的海岸线 The road follows the shoreline for a few miles. 公路沿海岸线延伸几英里。

shorn
past participle ofSHEAR

*short¹
/ʃɔ:t ||; ʃɔrt/adj adv
1 not measuring much from one end to the other 短的: a short line/distance/dress 短线╱距离╱连衣裙 This essay is rather short. 这篇文章相当短。 short hair 短发 [OPP] long 反义词为long ☞verb shorten 动词为shorten
2 less than the average height 矮的: a short, fat man 一个又矮又胖的男人 [OPP] tall 反义词为tall
3 not lasting a long time; brief （时间）短的，短暂的: a short visit/film 短暂的访问；短片 She left a short time ago. 她不久前离开。 to have a short memory (= to only remember things that have happened recently) 有短暂的记忆（只能记住最近发生的事） [OPP] long 反义词为long ☞verb shorten 动词为shorten
4 short (of/on sth) not having enough of what is needed 不足；短缺: Because of illness, the team is two players short. 因为有队员病了，所以该队缺了两名运动员。 Good secretaries are in short supply (= there are not enough of them). 称职的秘书很缺乏。 We're a bit short of money at the moment. 我们现在手头有点紧。 Your essay is a bit short on detail. 你的文章写得有点不够详细。 ☞noun shortage 名词为shortage
5 suddenly 突然: She stopped short when she saw the accident. 她一见那宗事故连忙停下来。
6 short for sth used as a shorter way of saying sth or as an abbreviation 作…的缩写或简称: ‘Bill’ is short for ‘William’. Bill是William的简称。
7 short (with sb) (used about a person) speaking in an impatient and angry way to sb （指人）说话不耐烦或粗暴 ☞adverb shortly 副词为shortly
cut sth/sb short to not allow sb to finish speaking; to interrupt 打断（某人说话） fall short (of sth) to not be enough; to not reach sth 不足；达不到: The pay rise fell short of the workers' demands. 加薪幅度未能达到工人的要求。 for short as a short form 作…的缩写或简称: She's called ‘Diana’, or ‘Di’ for short. 她叫“黛安娜”，简称“黛”。 go short (of sth) to be without enough (of sth) 缺乏；欠缺: He made sure his family never went short of food. 他确保一家人永不缺少吃的。 in the long/short term→TERM¹ in short in a few words; briefly 简言之；总之 run short (of sth) to have used up most of sth so there is not much left 几乎用光；已快用完: We're running short of coffee. 我们的咖啡差不多喝光了。 short of sth/doing sth apart from; except for 除…外: Nothing short of a miracle will save the business now. 现在只有出现奇迹，才能挽救那家企业。 stop short of sth/doing sth→STOP¹
short²
/ʃɔ:t ||; ʃɔrt/noun[C]
1 (informal 非正式)=SHORT CIRCUIT
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) a small strong alcoholic drink 少量烈酒: I prefer wine to shorts. 我喜欢葡萄酒胜过烈酒。

shortage
/ˈʃɔ:tɪdʒ ||; ˈʃɔrtɪdʒ/noun [C] a situation where there is not enough of sth 短缺；不足: a food/housing/water shortage 食物短缺；住房短缺；缺水 a shortage of trained teachers 缺少训练有素的老师

shortbread
/ˈʃɔ:tbred ||; ˈʃɔrtˌbrɛd/noun [U] a sweet biscuit made with sugar, flour and butter 黄油酥饼

shortcake
/ˈʃɔ:tkeɪk ||; ˈʃɔrtˌkek/noun [U] (US 美) a cake with a pastry base and cream and fruit on top 水果奶油蛋糕: strawberry shortcake 草莓蛋糕

ˌshort ˈcircuit
(informal 非正式short) noun [C] a bad electrical connection that causes a machine to stop working 短路 ˌshort-ˈcircuit verb [I,T] The lights short-circuited. 电灯发生短路熄了。

shortcoming
/ˈʃɔ:tkʌmɪŋ ||; ˈʃɔrtˌkʌmɪŋ/noun [C] [usu.pl] a fault or weakness 缺点；短处

ˌshort ˈcut
noun [C] a quicker, easier or more direct way to get somewhere or to do sth 快捷方式；近路: He took a short cut to school through the park. 他穿过公园抄近路去上学。

shorten
/ˈʃɔ:tn ||; ˈʃɔrtṇ/verb [I,T] to become shorter or to make sth shorter 变短；缩短

shortfall
/ˈʃɔ:tfɔ:l ||; ˈʃɔrtˌfɔl/noun [C] shortfall (in sth) the amount by which sth is less than you need or expect 不足之数；差额

shorthand
/ˈʃɔ:thænd ||; ˈʃɔrtˌhænd/noun [U] a method of writing quickly that uses signs or short forms of words 速记法: to write in shorthand 用速写方式写 a shorthand typist 速记打字员 ☞Look at longhand. 参看longhand。

shortie
/ˈʃɔ:ti ||; ˈʃɔrtɪ/noun [C] = shorty⇒

shortlist
/ˈʃɔ:tlɪst ||; ˈʃɔrtˌlɪst/noun [C] [usu.sing] a list of the best people for a job, etc who have been chosen from all the people who want the job 决选名单（从所有应征者中挑选出的最佳候选人）: She's one of the four people on the shortlist. 她是决选名单上的四位候选人之一。 shortlist verb Six candidates were shortlisted for the post. 有六位候选人进入该职位的决选名单。

ˌshort-ˈlived
adj lasting only for a short time 短暂的；短命的

shortly
/ˈʃɔ:tli ||; ˈʃɔrtlɪ/adv
1 soon; not long 马上；不久: The manager will see you shortly. 经理很快就会接见你。
2 in an impatient, angry way 不耐烦地；粗鲁地

ˌshort-order ˈcook
noun [C] a person who works in a restaurant cooking food that can be prepared quickly 快餐厨师

ˌshort-ˈrange
adj
1 (used about weapons) designed to travel only over short distances ﹙武器﹚短程的，近程的: short-range missiles 短程导弹
2 (used about plans, etc) connected with a short period of time in the future ﹙计划等﹚短期的，近期的: a short-range weather forecast 短期天气预报 ☞ Look at long-range. 参看 long-range。

*shorts
/ʃɔ:ts ||; ʃɔrts/noun[pl]
1 a type of short trousers ending above the knee that you wear in hot weather, while playing sports, etc 短裤 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图
2 (US 美) =BOXER SHORTS
Notice that, because shorts is a plural word, we cannot say, for example, ‘a new short’. The following are possible I need to get some new shorts. I need to get a new pair of shorts. 注意﹕由于shorts是复数名词﹐所以我们不能说a mew shorts﹐但可以有以下的说法﹕I need to get some new shorts.我要买一条新短裤。I need to get a new pair of shorts.我要买一条新短裤。

ˌshort-ˈsighted
adj
