1 (especially US 尤为美 ˌnear-ˈsighted) able to see things clearly only when they are very close to you 近视的: I have to wear glasses because I'm short-sighted. 我眼睛近视，所以要戴眼镜。 [SYN]A more technical word is myopic. 较专门的用语为myopic。 [OPP] long-sighted 反义词为long-sighted ☞picture on page 1069 见1069页插图
2 not considering what will probably happen in the future 短视的；目光短浅的: a short-sighted attitude/policy 短视的态度╱政策 ➔short-sightedness noun [U]

ˌshort-ˈstaffed
adj (used about an office, a shop, etc) not having enough people to do the work （指办公室、商店等）人手不足的

ˌshort ˈstory
noun [C] a piece of writing that is shorter than a novel 短篇小说

ˌshort-ˈterm
adj lasting for a short period of time from the present 短期的: short-term plans/memory 短期计划／记忆

ˈshort wave
noun [C,U] (abbr SW) a system for sending radio signals 短波: Short wave is a radio wave of frequency greater then 3 MHz. 短波是一种频率大于3兆赫的无线电波。 ☞Look at long wave and medium wave. 参看long wave及medium wave。

shorty ( also shortie)
/ˈʃɔ:ti ||; ˈʃɔrtɪ/noun [C] (plural shorties) (slang 俚语) a person who is not very tall 矮子

*shot¹
/ʃɒt ||; ʃɑt/noun[C]
1 a shot (at sb/sth) an act of firing a gun, etc, or the noise that this makes 开枪；枪声: to take a shot at the target 朝目标开一枪 The policeman fired a warning shot into the air. 警察朝天鸣枪示警。
2 (in sport) the action of kicking, throwing or hitting a ball in order to score a point or a goal （体育）踢球，投球，击球: Owen scored with a low shot into the corner of the net. 欧文踢了个低球，将球送入网角。 Good shot! 好球！
3 a photograph or a picture in a film 镜头: I got some good shots of the runners as they crossed the line. 我拍了几个赛跑运动员冲过终点线的精彩镜头。
4 [usu.sing] (informal 非正式)a shot (at sth/at doing sth) a try at doing sth; an attempt 尝试: Let me have a shot at it (= let me try to do it). 让我试试。 Just give it your best shot (= try as hard as you can). 只管竭尽全力试一试。
5 a small amount of a drug that is put into your body using a needle 一次注射（药物）
6 oftenthe shot a heavy metal ball that is thrown as a sport (the shot-put) 铅球
a long shot→LONG¹ call the shots/tune→CALL¹ like a shot(informal 非正式) very quickly; without stopping to think about it 飞快；立即；毫不犹豫: If someone invited me on a free holiday, I'd go like a shot. 如果有人请我免费度假，我会毫不犹豫地去。
shot²
past tense, past participle ofSHOOT¹

shotgun
/ˈʃɒtgʌn ||; ˈʃɑtˌgʌn/noun [C] a long gun that is used for shooting small animals and birds 猎枪

shotgun wedding ( also ˌshotgun ˈmarriage)
noun [C] (old-fashioned, informal 旧，非正式) a wedding that has to take place quickly, e.g. because the woman is pregnant 仓促结婚﹙如因女方怀孕﹚

*should
/ʃəd;strong form ʃʊd ||; ʃəd; ʃυd/ modal verb (negative should not short form shouldn't /ˈʃʊdnt ||; ˈʃυdṇt/)
1 (used for saying that it is right or appropriate for sb to do sth, or for sth to happen) ought to （表示应该做或发生）应该: The police should do something about street crime in this area. 警方应该就这个地区的街头犯罪做点事。 Children shouldn't be left on their own. 不该把孩子们留下不管。 I'm tired. I shouldn't have gone to bed so late/I should have gone to bed earlier. 我很累，我不该那么晚才上床睡觉╱我理应早点上床睡觉。
2 used for giving or for asking for advice （用于提出或征求意见）: You should try that new restaurant. 你应该到那家新餐馆试试。 Do you think I should phone him? 你认为我应该给他打电话吗？ What should I do? 我该怎么办？
3 used for saying that you expect sth is true or will happen （用于表示期待某事属实或发生）: It's 4.30. They should be in New York by now. 现在是4时30分，他们此刻应该到了纽约。 It should stop raining soon. 雨该快停了。
4 (Brit 英) (formal 正式) used with ‘I/we’ instead of ‘would’ in ‘if’ sentences （在if句中与I或we连用，取代would）: I should be most grateful if you could send me... 如蒙惠寄…，不胜铭感。
5 (formal 正式) used after ‘if’ and ‘in case’ to refer to a possible event or situation （用于if和in case之后，表示某事可能发生）: If you should decide to accept, please phone us. 万一你决定接受，请打电话给我们。 Should you decide to accept... 万一你决定接受…
6 used as the past tense of ‘shall’ when we report what sb says （在复述他人的话时，用作shall的过去时）: He asked me if he should come today (= he asked ‘Shall I come today?’). 他问我他今天要不要来。
7 I should imagine, say, think, etc used to give opinions that you are not certain about （表示觉得没把握）我想╱我要说╱我觉得… ☞For more information about modal verbs, look at the Quick Grammar Reference section at the back of this dictionary. 有关情态动词的详细用法，参看本词典末“语法便览”部份。

*shoulder¹
/ˈʃəʊldə(r) ||; ˈʃoldɚ/noun
1 [C] the part of your body between your neck and the top of your arm 肩；肩膀: I asked him why he'd done it but he just shrugged his shoulders (= raised his shoulders to show that he did not know or care). 我问他干吗这么做，但他只是耸了耸肩膀。 She fell asleep with her head on his shoulder. 她把头枕在他的肩膀上睡着了。 ☞picture at body 见body插图
2 -shouldered (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) having the type of shoulders mentioned 有…肩的: a broad-shouldered man 一个宽肩的男人
3 [C] a part of a dress, coat, etc that covers the shoulders 衣服的肩部 ☞Look at hard shoulder. 参看hard shoulder。
a shoulder to cry on used to describe a person who listens to your problems and understands how you feel 一个能听你倾诉问题并理解你的感受的人 have a chip on your shoulder→CHIP¹ rub shoulders with sb→RUB
shoulder²
/ˈʃəʊldə(r) ||; ˈʃoldɚ/verb[T]
1 to accept the responsibility for sth 承担（责任）: to shoulder the blame/responsibility for sth 承担某事的咎责╱责任
2 to push sb/sth with your shoulder 用肩膀推

ˈshoulder bag
noun [C] a type of bag that you carry over one shoulder with a long strap 挎包；挂肩提包

ˈshoulder blade
noun [C] either of the two large flat bones on each side of your back, below your shoulders 肩胛骨 [SYN]A more technical word is scapula. 较专门的用语为scapula。 ☞picture at body 见body插图

ˈshoulder-length
adj (used especially about hair) long enough to reach your shoulders ﹙尤指头发﹚齐肩的

ˈshoulder strap
noun [C]
1 a narrow piece of material on a dress or other piece of clothing that goes over your shoulder from the front to the back （连衣裙等的）背带，肩带
2 a long narrow piece of material, leather, etc that is part of a bag so that you can carry it over your shoulder （包的）背带

*shout
/ʃaʊt ||; ʃaυt/verb
1 [I] shout (at/to sb);shout out to speak or cry out in a very loud voice 叫喊；叫嚷；吼叫: There's no need to shout -- I can hear you. 你不用叫嚷，我听得见你说什么。 The teacher shouted angrily at the boys. 老师怒斥那些男孩子。 to shout out in pain/excitement 痛得大叫；大声欢呼
2 [T] shout sth (at/to sb);shout sth out to say sth in a loud voice 大声说出: ‘Careful,’ she shouted. 她大叫：“小心！” The students kept shouting out the answers, so we stopped playing in the end. 学生们老是把答案大声说出来，所以我们最后不玩游戏了。 The captain shouted instructions to his team. 队长向队员大声发号施令。 ☞Look at scream. 参看scream。 shout noun [C]
shout sb down to shout so that sb who is speaking cannot be heard 用叫喊声淹没某人的声音: The speaker was shouted down by a group of protesters. 一群抗议者的叫喊声淹没了演讲者的声音。

shove
/ʃʌv ||; ʃʌv/verb [I,T] (informal 非正式) to push with a sudden, rough movement 推；挤；推撞: Everybody in the crowd was pushing and shoving. 人群里每个人都在推推搡搡。 The policeman shoved the thief into the back of the police car. 那个警察把小偷推进警车后部。 shove noun [C] [usu.sing] to give sb/sth a shove 大力推一下某人╱某物

shovel
/ˈʃʌvl ||; ˈʃʌvḷ/noun [C] a tool used for picking up and moving earth, snow, sand, etc 铲；铁锹 ☞Look also at spade. 另参看spade。 ☞picture at garden 见garden插图 shovel verb [I,T] (shovelling;shovelled (US 美) shoveling;shoveled)

*show¹
/ʃəʊ ||; ʃo/verb (past tense showed;past participle shown /ʃəʊn ||; ʃon/or showed)
1 [T] show sb/sth (to sb);show sb (sth) to let sb see sb/sth 使看见；出示；展示；显示: I showed the letter to him. 我把信给他看。 I showed him the letter. 我让他看那封信。 She showed me what she had bought. 她把买来的东西给我看。 They're showing his latest film at our local cinema. 本地电影院正在放映他最新的影片。 She was showing signs of stress. 她露出了精神紧张的神色。 This white T-shirt really shows the dirt. 这件T恤衫是白色的，污渍很显眼。 The picture showed him arguing with a photographer. 这张照片显示他在跟一个摄影记者争吵。
2 [T] to make sth clear; to give information about sth 清楚显示；描述；说明: Research shows that most people get too little exercise. 研究显示，大多数人运动不足。 This graph shows how prices have gone up in the last few years. 这张图表显示在过去几年里物价上涨的情况。
3 [I] to be able to be seen; to appear 显露；出现: I tried not to let my disappointment show. 我竭力不让我的失望情绪流露出来。
4 [T] to help sb to do sth by doing it yourself; to explain sth 示范；解释: Can you show me how to put the disk in the computer? 你能不能示范一下怎样将磁盘放进计算机？
5 [T] to lead sb to or round a place; to explain how to go to a place 引领（某人）；引导；指引: I'll come with you and show you the way. 我会跟你一起去，告诉你怎么走。 Shall I show you to your room? 让我带你到你的房间好吗？ A guide showed us round the museum. 导游带我们在博物馆四处参观。
show (sth) off(informal 非正式) to try to impress people by showing them how clever you are or by showing them sth that you are proud of 炫耀；夸示: John was showing off by driving his new car very fast. 约翰把新车开得飞快，以此来炫耀自己。 ☞noun show-off 名词为show-off show up(informal 非正式) to arrive, especially when sb is expecting you 到达，出现（尤指有人在等待）: I thought you'd never show up. 我还以为你不会来了。 show (sth) up to allow sth to be seen 使彰显或显现: The sunlight shows up those dirty marks on the window. 阳光使玻璃窗上那些污点显现出来。 show sb up(informal 非正式) to make sb embarrassed about your behaviour or appearance （因举止失当或仪容不整）使同伴难为情: He showed her up by shouting at the waiter. 他大声吆喝服务员，使她感到难堪。
*show²
/ʃəʊ ||; ʃo/noun
1 [C] a type of entertainment performed for an audience 演出；表演；节目: a TV comedy show 电视上的喜剧节目 a quiz show （电视、电台上的）答问比赛节目
2 [C,U] an occasion when a collection of things are brought together for people to look at 展览；展览会: a dog show 狗展 a fashion show 时装表演 Paintings by local children will be on show at the town hall next week. 下星期市政厅里将展出当地孩子的绘画作品。
3 [C,U] something that a person does or has in order to make people believe sth that is not true 表面上做出的样子；外观: Although she hated him, she put on a show of politeness. 她心里恨他，表面上却装作对他很有礼貌。 His bravery is all show (= he is not as brave as he pretends to be). 他的英勇都是装出来的。
4 [sing] an occasion when you let sb see sth 流露；显示；表示: a show of emotion/gratitude/temper 感情╱感激╱脾气的流露

show-and-tell ( also ˌshow and ˈtell)
noun [U] a teaching method in which young children are asked to bring sth to show their class and describe it to the other children 展示和讲述﹙儿童通过所带实物向同学讲述的教学方法﹚

ˈshow business
/ˈʃəʊbɪz ||; ˈʃobɪz/ (informal 非正式showbiz) noun [U] the business of entertaining people, in the theatre, in films, on television, etc 娱乐界，演艺业（指戏剧、电影、电视等）: He's been in show business since he was five years old. 他从五岁起就在演艺界做事。

showcase
/ˈʃəʊkeɪs ||; ˈʃoˌkes/noun[C]
1 a box with a glass top or sides that is used for showing objects in a shop/store, museum, etc ﹙商店、博物馆等处的﹚玻璃陈列柜
2 [usually sing] an event that presents sb's abilities or the good qualities of sth in an attractive way ﹙才能等的﹚展示场合: The festival was a showcase for young musicians. 音乐节是青年音乐家展现才华的地方。 ➔showcase verb [T]: Jack found a film role that showcased all his talents. 杰克找到一个能让他尽展才华的电影角色。

showdown
/ˈʃəʊdaʊn ||; ˈʃoˌdaυn/noun [C] a final argument, meeting or fight at the end of a long disagreement （为解决争端）摊牌，最后的较量: The management are preparing for a showdown with the union. 资方打算跟工会摊牌。

*shower¹
/ˈʃaʊə(r) ||; ˈʃaυɚ/noun[C]
1 a piece of equipment that produces a spray of water that you stand under to wash; the small room or part of a room that contains a shower 淋浴器；淋浴间: The shower doesn't work. 淋浴设备坏了。 She's in the shower. 她在淋浴间。 I'd like a room with a shower, please. 请给我一间有淋浴设备的房间。 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图
2 an act of washing yourself by standing under a shower 淋浴: I'll just have a quick showerthen we can go out. 我赶快去淋个浴，然后我们便可以出去了。
3 a short period of rain 阵雨 ☞Look at rain and acid rain. 参看rain及acid rain。
4 a lot of very small objects that fall or fly through the air together （从空中洒落的许多小物品的）一阵: a shower of sparks/broken glass 一阵火星╱碎玻璃
shower²
/ˈʃaʊə(r) ||; ˈʃaυɚ/verb
1 [I,T] shower (down) on sb/sth;shower sb with sth to cover sb/sth with a lot of small falling objects 使某物洒落某处: Ash from the volcano showered down on the town. 火山灰洒落在这个镇上。 People suffered cuts after being showered with broken glass. 碎玻璃洒落下来，很多人被割伤了。
2 [I] to wash yourself under a shower 淋浴: I came back from my run, showered and got changed. 我跑步回来，淋个浴，换了衣服。

ˈshower cap
noun [C] a plastic hat that you wear to keep your hair dry when you take a shower 淋浴帽

showgirl
/ˈʃəʊgɜ:l ||; ˈʃoˌgɝl/noun [C] a female performer who sings and dances in a musical show²(1) 歌舞女演员

showing
/ˈʃəʊɪŋ ||; ˈʃoɪŋ/noun
1 [C] an act of showing a film, etc 放映（电影等）: The second showing of the film begins at 8 o'clock. 第二场电影在8点钟开始放映。
2 [sing] how sb/sth behaves; how successful sb/sth is 表现；成绩: On its present showing, the party should win the election. 照目前的表现，那个政党当会在选举中获胜。

showjumping
/ˈʃəʊdʒʌmpɪŋ ||; ˈʃoˌdʒʌmpɪŋ/noun [U] a competition in which a person rides a horse over a series of fences (jumps) （马术竞技中的）障碍跳越

shown
past participle ofSHOW¹

ˈshow-off
noun [C] a person who tries to impress others by showing them how clever he/she is, or by showing them sth he/she is proud of 喜欢炫耀的人: She's such a show-off, always boasting about how good she is at this and that. 她是那么喜欢炫耀自己，老是吹嘘自己这方面那方面怎么能干。

showroom
/ˈʃəʊru:m;-rʊm ||; ˈʃoˌrum; -rυm/noun [C] a type of large shop where customers can look at goods such as cars, furniture and electrical items that are on sale （商品样品的）陈列室，展览室

ˈshow-stopper
noun [C] (informal 非正式) a performance that is very impressive and receives a lot of applause from the audience 受到阵阵鼓掌喝彩的节目 ➔ˈshowstopping adj: a show-stopping performance 受到长时间鼓掌的表演

showtime
/ˈʃəʊtaɪm ||; ˈʃoˌtaɪm/noun [U] the time that a theatre performance or film/movie will begin 开演时间；演出时间: It's five minutes to showtime and the theatre is packed. 离演出开始还有五分钟，剧场里已坐满了观众。 (figurative 比喻) Everybody ready? It's showtime! 大家都准备好了吗？开始！

showy
/ˈʃəʊi ||; ˈʃoɪ/adj (showier; showiest) so brightly coloured, large or exaggerated that it attracts a lot of attention 显眼的；引人注目的；艳丽的: showy flowers 艳丽的花朵

shrank
past tense ofSHRINK

shrapnel
/ˈʃræpnəl ||; ˈʃræpnəl/noun [U] small pieces of metal that fly around when a bomb explodes （炸弹爆炸后四处散开的）金属碎片，弹片

shred¹
/ʃred ||; ʃrɛd/noun
1 [C] a small thin piece of material that has been cut or torn off （撕下或切成的）细条，碎片: His clothes were torn to shreds by the rose bushes. 他的衣服给玫瑰丛扯成碎片。
2 a shred of sth [sing] (in negative sentences 用于否定句) a very small amount of sth 非常少量；一丝；一点儿: There wasn't a shred of truth in her story. 她说的话没有半点是真的。
shred²
/ʃred ||; ʃrɛd/verb [T] (shredding;shredded) to tear or cut sth into shreds 撕碎；切碎: shredded cabbage 切碎的洋白菜

shredder
/ˈʃredə(r) ||; ˈʃrɛdɚ/noun [C] a machine that tears sth into small pieces, especially paper, so that nobody can read what was printed on it 切碎机；碎纸机

shrew
/ʃru: ||; ʃru/noun[C]
1 a small animal like a mouse with a long nose 鼩鼱（一种小动物，鼻长，形似老鼠）
2 (old-fashioned 旧) a bad-tempered unpleasant woman 泼妇；悍妇

shrewd
/ʃru:d ||; ʃrud/adj able to make good decisions because you understand a situation well 能作出明智决定的；敏锐的；精明的: a shrewd thinker/decision 敏锐的思想家；明智的决定 ➔shrewdly adv

shriek
/ʃri:k ||; ʃrik/verb
1 [I] to make a short, loud, noise in a high voice 尖叫: She shrieked in fright. 她害怕得尖叫。 The children were shrieking with laughter. 孩子们尖声大笑。
2 [T] to say sth loudly in a high voice 尖声说: ‘Stop it!’ she shrieked. 她尖叫道：“停止！” ☞Look at screech. 参看screech。 ➔shriek noun [C]

shrill
/ʃrɪl ||; ʃrɪl/adj (used about a sound) high and unpleasant （指声音）高频刺耳的: a shrill cry 尖叫

shrimp
/ʃrɪmp ||; ʃrɪmp/noun[C]
1 a small sea creature with a shell and a lot of legs that turns pink when you cook it 小虾 Shrimps are smaller than prawns. shrimp比prawn（虾）小。
2 (US 美) =PRAWN ☞picture at shellfish 见shellfish插图

shrine
/ʃraɪn ||; ʃraɪn/noun [C] a place that is important to a particular person or group of people for religious reasons or because it is connected with a special person （宗教等的）圣地

shrink
/ʃrɪŋk ||; ʃrɪŋk/verb (past tense shrank /ʃræŋk ||; ʃræŋk/or shrunk /ʃrʌŋk ||; ʃrʌŋk/ past participle shrunk)
1 [I,T] to become smaller or make sth smaller （使）收缩，变小: My T-shirt shrank in the wash. 我的T恤衫洗后缩水了。 Television has shrunk the world. 电视把世界缩小了。 The rate of inflation has shrunk to 4%. 通胀率已降至4%。
2 [I] to move back because you are frightened or shocked （因惊吓）退缩: We shrank back against the wall when the dog appeared. 我们一看到那只狗便吓得缩到墙边。
shrink from sth/doing sth to not want to do sth because you find it unpleasant 退缩；回避

ˌshrink-ˈwrapped
adj covered tightly in a thin sheet of plastic 用收缩薄膜包着的: The books are shrink-wrapped so you can't open them in the shop. 这些书用薄膜包着，因此在书店里无法翻开。

shrivel
/ˈʃrɪvl ||; ˈʃrɪvḷ/verb [I,T] (shrivelling;shrivelled (US 美) shriveling;shriveled)shrivel (sth) (up) to become smaller, especially because of dry conditions 变小（尤指因为干燥）: The plants shrivelled up and died in the hot weather. 植物因天气炎热而枯死。

shroud¹
/ʃraʊd ||; ʃraυd/noun [C] a cloth or sheet that is put round a dead body before it is buried 裹尸布；寿衣
shroud²
/ʃraʊd ||; ʃraυd/verb [T] shroud sth (in sth) (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to cover or hide sth 覆盖；遮蔽

Shrove Tuesday
/ˌʃrəʊv ˈtju:zdeɪ;-di; US ˈtu:z- ||; ˈʃrov ˈtuzde; -dɪ/noun [C] the day before a period of forty days (Lent) during which some Christians do not eat certain foods 忏悔星期二（四旬斋期的前一天） In some countries the period before Shrove Tuesday is celebrated as carnival. In Britain many people eat pancakes on this day. 某些国家在这日之前的一段时间举行嘉年华会(carnival)。英国许多人在这天吃薄煎饼(pancake)。

shrub
/ʃrʌb ||; ʃrʌb/noun [C] a small bush 灌木

shrubbery
/ˈʃrʌbəri ||; ˈʃrʌbərɪ/noun [C] (plural shrubberies) an area where a lot of small bushes have been planted 灌木林；灌木丛

shrug
/ʃrʌg ||; ʃrʌg/verb [I,T] (shrugging;shrugged) to lift your shoulders as a way of showing that you do not know sth or are not interested 耸肩（以示不知道或不感兴趣） [I] ‘Who knows?’ he said and shrugged. 他耸耸肩说：“谁知道！” [T] ‘It doesn't matter to me,’ he said, shrugging his shoulders. 他耸耸肩说：“这与我无关。” ☞picture on page S19 见S19页插图 shrug noun [C] [usu.sing] I asked him if he was sorry and he just answered with a shrug. 我问他是不是感到遗憾，他只是耸一耸肩，算是回答。 shrug sth off to not allow sth to affect you in a bad way 不让某事对自己产生不利影响: An actor has to learn to shrug off criticism. 演员非得学会对批评不屑一顾不行。

shrunk
past tense, past participle ofSHRINK

shtick ( also schtick)
/ʃtɪk ||; ʃtɪk/noun [U, sing] (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式)
1 a style of humour that is typical of a particular performer ﹙演员的﹚独特的幽默风格
2 a particular ability that sb has 特长；擅长的本领: That's not my shtick. 那不是我的特长。

shudder
/ˈʃʌdə(r) ||; ˈʃʌdɚ/verb [I] to suddenly shake hard, especially because of an unpleasant feeling or thought 战栗，发抖（尤指因感受或想到不快之事）: Just to think about the accident makes me shudder. 一想到那次意外就令我不寒而栗。 The engine shuddered violently and then stopped. 引擎一阵猛烈颤动，然后停了下来。 shudder noun [C]

shuffle¹
/ˈʃʌfl ||; ˈʃʌfḷ/verb
1 [I] to walk by sliding your feet along instead of lifting them off the ground 曳足而行；拖着脚走路: The child shuffled past, wearing her mother's shoes. 小孩穿着母亲的鞋子，拖着脚走过。
2 [I,T] to move your body or feet around because you are uncomfortable or nervous （因不舒服或紧张）挪动身体或双脚: The audience were so bored that they began to shuffle in their seats. 观众感到沉闷，开始坐不安稳。
3 [I,T] to mix a pack of playing cards before a game 洗牌: It's your turn to shuffle. 轮到你洗牌了。 She shuffled the cards carefully. 她仔细洗牌。
shuffle²
/ˈʃʌfl ||; ˈʃʌfḷ/noun[C] [usu.sing]
1 a way of walking without lifting your feet off the ground 拖着脚走路
2 an act of shuffling cards 洗牌

shun
/ʃʌn ||; ʃʌn/verb [T] (shunning;shunned) (written 书面语) to avoid sb/sth; to keep away from sb/sth 避免；避开；回避: She was shunned by her family when she married him. 她嫁给他的时候，她的家人都避而不见她。

shunt
/ʃʌnt ||; ʃʌnt/verb[T]
1 to move a railway train from one track to another 使（火车）换轨
2 to make sb go from one place to another 把（某人）从一地转到另一地: He was shunted around from one hospital to another. 他被从一家医院转到另一家医院。

shush¹
/ʃʊʃ ||; ʃuʃ/ exclamation used to tell sb to be quiet ﹙叫某人安静﹚嘘: Shush! Do you want to wake everyone up? 嘘！你想吵醒所有人吗？
shush²
/ʃʊʃ ||; ʃuʃ/verb [T] to tell sb to be quiet, especially by saying ‘shush’ or by putting your finger against your lips 叫某人安静；嘘: Lyn shushed the children. 林恩“嘘”了一声，让孩子们安静下来。

*shut¹
/ʃʌt ||; ʃʌt/verb (present participle shutting;past tense past participle shut)
1 [I,T] to make sth closed; to become closed 关闭；闭上；合上；关上 · Could you shut the door, please? 请你关上门好吗？ I can't shut my suitcase. 我关不上手提箱。 Shut your books, please. 请合上书本。 He shut his eyes and tried to go to sleep. 他闭上眼睛，想要入睡。 This window won't shut properly. 这扇窗关不好。 The doors open and shut automatically. 这些门是自动开关的。
2 [I,T] (used about a shop, restaurant, etc) to stop doing business for the day; to close （指店铺、餐馆等）关门，停止营业: What time do the shops shut on Saturday? 星期六商店什么时候关门？
3 [T] to prevent sb/sth from leaving a place; to close a door on sth 使不能离开；关起来；夹住: She shut herself in her room and refused to come out. 她把自己关在房间内，不肯出来。 Tony shut his fingers in the door of the car. 托尼的手指被车门夹住。
shut sb/sth away to keep sb/sth in a place where people cannot find or see him/her/it 藏起来；隔离 shut (sth) down (used about a factory, etc) to close for a long time or for ever （指工厂等）（使）歇业，停工，关闭: Financial problems forced the business to shut down. 财务问题迫使公司关门。 shut sb/sth off (from sth) to keep sb/sth apart from sth 使隔离: He shuts himself off from the rest of the world. 他躲起来与世隔绝。 shut sb/sth out to keep sb/sth out 关在外面；排除: He tried to shut out all thoughts of the accident. 他努力不去想那次意外。 shut (sb) up(informal 非正式)
1 to stop talking; to be quiet 停止说话；住口: I wish you'd shut up! 我但愿你住口！
2 to make sb stop talking 使停止说话
shut sb/sth up (in sth) to put sb/sth somewhere and stop him/her leaving 关在或藏在某地方: He was shut up in prison for nearly ten years. 他被监禁了差不多十年。
shut²
/ʃʌt ||; ʃʌt/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前)
1 in a closed position 关闭: Make sure the door is shut properly before you leave. 离开前务必要关好门。 ☞Remember that we can use closed before a noun a closed door, but not shut. 名词前可用closed，但不能用shut：a closed door关上的门。
2 not open to the public 不对公众开放；关了门: The restaurant was shut so we went to one round the corner. 那家餐馆关了门，我们于是去了街角那家。
keep your mouth shut→MOUTH¹

ˈshut-eye
noun [U] (informal 非正式) sleep 睡眠

ˈshut-in
noun [C, usually pl] (US 美) a person who cannot leave his/her home very easily because he/she is sick or disabled 卧病在家的人；因残疾不能出门的人: He worked as a volunteer, delivering hot meals to shut-ins. 他做志愿工作，为卧病在家的人送热饭菜。

ˈshut-out
noun [C] (US 美) a sports game in which one side or team prevents the other from getting any points 输方未得分的比赛

shutter
/ˈʃʌtə(r) ||; ˈʃʌtɚ/noun[C]
1 a wooden or metal cover that is fixed outside a window and that can be opened or shut. A shop's shutter usually slides down from the top of the shop window. 百叶窗；活动遮板 ☞picture at curtain 见curtain插图
2 the part at the front of a camera that opens for a very short time to let light in so that a photograph can be taken （照相机的）快门 ☞picture at camera 见camera插图

shutterbug
/ˈʃʌtəbʌg ||; ˈʃʌtɚˌbʌg/noun [C] (US, informal 美，非正式) a person who likes to take a lot of photographs 摄影爱好者；摄影迷

shuttle
/ˈʃʌtl ||; ˈʃʌtḷ/noun [C] a plane, bus or train that travels regularly between two places 定时穿梭两地的飞机、公共汽车或火车

shuttlecock
/ˈʃʌtlkɒk ||; ˈʃʌtḷkɑk/noun [C] (in the sport of badminton) the small, light object that is hit over the net （羽毛球运动）羽毛球 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图

*shy¹
/ʃaɪ ||; ʃaɪ/adj
1 nervous and uncomfortable about meeting and speaking to people; showing that sb feels like this 害臊的；羞怯的；腼腆的: She's very shy with strangers. 她很怕生。 a shy smile 羞怯的一笑
2 shy (of/about sth/doing sth) frightened to do sth or to become involved in sth 害怕做或参与某事: She's not shy of telling people what she thinks. 她敢于把自己的想法告诉别人。 ➔shyly adv ➔shyness noun [U]: He didn't overcome his shyness till he had left school. 他中学毕业以后才克服了害羞的毛病。
shy²
/ʃaɪ ||; ʃaɪ/verb (present participle shying third person singular present shies;past tense past participle shied) [I] (used about a horse) to suddenly move back or sideways in fear （指马）因惊慌而退避 shy away from sth/from doing sth to avoid doing sth because you are afraid （因害怕而）避开，回避，退缩

shyster
/ˈʃaɪstə(r) ||; ˈʃaɪstɚ/noun [C] (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) a dishonest person, especially a lawyer or businessman 奸诈的人，不择手段的人﹙尤指律师或商人﹚

SI
/ˌes ˈaɪ ||; ˌɛs ˈaɪ/abbr (used to describe units of measurement 指计量单位) International System (from French ‘Système International’) 国际单位制（源自法文Système International）: SI units 国际单位 ☞Look at Expressions using numbers at the back of the dictionary. 参看本词典末数词用法部份。

Siamese twin
/ˌsaɪəmi:z ˈtwɪn ||; ˌsaɪəmiz ˈtwɪn/ (also conˌjoined ˈtwin) noun [C] one of two people who are born with their bodies joined together in some way, sometimes sharing the same organs 连体婴儿；连体双胞胎之一

sibling
/ˈsɪblɪŋ ||; ˈsɪblɪŋ/noun [C] (formal 正式) a brother or a sister 兄弟姐妹；同胞兄弟姐妹；手足 ☞In ordinary language we use brother(s) and sister(s) Have you got any brothers and sisters? 日常用语可以说brother(s) and sister(s)：Have you got any brothers and sisters?你有兄弟姐妹吗？

sic
/sɪk;si:k ||; sɪk; sik/adv (written after a word that you have copied from somewhere, to show that you know that the word is wrongly spelled or wrong in some other way 原文如此（放在所引之词后面，表示拼写等有错）) In the letter to parents it said: ‘The school is proud of it's [sic] record of excellence’. 在给家长的信中说：“学校为自己﹝原文如此﹞的辉煌成绩感到自豪。”

*sick¹
/sɪk ||; sɪk/adj
1 not well; ill 身体不适的；生病的: a sick child 生病的孩子 Do you get paid for days when you're off sick (= from work)? 你请病假这几天有工资吗？ You're too ill to work today -- you should phone in sick. 你病得厉害，今天不能上班，应该打个电话请病假。 ☞In British English be sick usually means ‘to bring up food from the stomach; vomit’. 注意：英国英语中be sick通常指“恶心”或“呕吐”。
2 the sick noun [pl] people who are ill 病人
3 feeling ill in your stomach so that you may bring up food through your mouth (vomit) 反胃的；恶心的: I feel sick -- I think it was that fish I ate. 我想吐，我想是吃了那尾鱼的缘故。 Don't eat any more or you'll make yourself sick. 别再吃了，不然你会难受的。 ☞Look at airsick, carsick, nausea, seasick and travel-sick. 参看airsick、carsick、nausea、seasick及travel-sick。
4 sick of sb/sth feeling bored or annoyed because you have had too much of sb/sth 感到腻烦或厌倦: I'm sick of my job. 我厌倦我的工作。 I'm sick of tidying up your mess! 整理你这些乱七八糟的东西真叫人讨厌！
5 sick (at/about sth) very annoyed or disgusted by sth 厌恶；厌倦: He felt sick at the sight of so much waste. 看见那么多废物，他感到厌恶。
6 (informal 非正式) mentioning disease, suffering, death, etc in a cruel or disgusting way 以残酷或讨厌的方式提及（疾病、痛苦、死亡等）: He offended everyone with a sick joke about blind people. 他说了个取笑盲人的笑话，弄得人人都很反感。
be sick to bring up food from the stomach; vomit 呕吐: It's common for women to be sick in the first months of pregnancy. 妇女怀孕的最初几个月里常常会呕吐。 make sb sick to make sb very angry 触怒或激怒某人: Oh, stop complaining. You make me sick! 哦，别再抱怨了，你真讨厌！ sick to death of sb/sth feeling tired of or annoyed by sb/sth 感到厌倦或厌烦: I'm sick to death of his grumbling. 他一直不停唠叨，讨厌死了。
sick²
/sɪk ||; sɪk/noun [U] food that sb has brought up from his/her stomach; vomit 呕吐物: There was sick all over the car seat. 车子的座位上布满呕吐物。

sickbay
/ˈsɪkbeɪ ||; ˈsɪkˌbe/ (also sick bay) noun [C] a room or rooms, for example on a ship or in a school, with beds for people who are sick ﹙船上、学校等的﹚病室，保健室

sickbed
/ˈsɪkbed ||; ˈsɪkˌbɛd/noun [sing] the bed on which a person who is sick is lying 病床: The President left his sickbed to attend the ceremony. 总统离开病床去出席那个仪式。

sick ˈbuilding ˌsyndrome
noun [U] a condition that affects people who work in large offices, making them feel tired and causing headaches, sore eyes and breathing problems, thought to be caused by, for example, the lack of fresh air or by chemicals in the air that people breathe 病态建筑综合症﹙办公大楼中因新鲜空气缺乏而引起的疲惫、头疼、眼睛疼痛、呼吸困难等症状﹚

sicken
/ˈsɪkən ||; ˈsɪkən/verb [T] to make sb feel disgusted 使厌恶或恶心: The sight of people fighting sickens me. 一见到有人打架我就感到厌恶。 ➔sickening adj His head made a sickening sound as it hit the road. 他的脑袋叩在路上，发出令人作呕的声音。

sickle
/ˈsɪkl ||; ˈsɪkḷ/noun [C] a tool with a short handle and a long, curved metal part with a sharp edge(a blade)that is used for cutting long grass, corn, etc 镰刀 ☞picture at scythe 见scythe插图

sickle
/ˈsɪkl ||; ˈsɪkḷ/noun [C] a tool with a curved blade and a short handle, used for cutting grass, etc 镰刀

ˈsick leave
noun [U] a period spent away from work, etc because of illness 病假: Mike's been off on sick leave since March. 三月份以来迈克一直请病假。

ˌsickle cell aˈnaemia
noun [U] a serious medical condition in which the red blood cells are damaged and change shape 镰状细胞性贫血

sickly
/ˈsɪkli ||; ˈsɪklɪ/adj
1 (used about a person) weak and often ill （指人）虚弱的，羸弱的，多病的: a sickly child 羸弱的孩子
2 unpleasant; causing you to feel ill 令人厌恶的；恶心的: the sickly smell of rotten fruit 令人作呕的烂水果气味

sickness
/ˈsɪknəs ||; ˈsɪknɪs/noun
1 [U] the state of being ill 患病；不适: A lot of workers are absent because of sickness. 许多工人因病缺勤。
2 [U] a feeling in your stomach that may make you bring up food through your mouth 恶心: Symptoms of the disease include sickness and diarrhoea. 那种疾病的症状包括上吐下泻。
3 [C,U] a particular type of illness 病；疾病: pills for seasickness 晕船药丸 ☞Look at sleeping sickness. 参看sleeping sickness。

sicko
/ˈsɪkəʊ ||; ˈsɪko/noun [C] (plural sickos) (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) a person who gets enjoyment from doing strange and cruel things 变态者: child molesters and other sickos 儿童性骚扰者和其他变态狂

ˈsick pay
noun [U] pay given to an employee who is away from work because of illness 病假工资

*side¹
/saɪd ||; saɪd/noun[C]
1 one of the flat outer surfaces of sth 物体的平面: A cube has six sides. 立方体有六个面。
2 -sided (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) having the number of sides mentioned 有…边: a six-sided coin 六边形钱币
3 one of the surfaces of sth except the top, bottom, front or back （物体除顶部及底部、正面及背面外的）侧面: I went round to the side of the building. 我绕到大厦的一侧。 The side of the car was damaged. 汽车的侧面损坏了。
4 the edge of sth, away from the middle 边；边缘；旁边: Make sure you stay at the side of the road when you're cycling. 骑自行车一定要靠马路边走。 We moved to one side to let the doctor get past. 我们靠到一边，让医生过去。
5 the area to the left or right of sth; the area in front of or behind sth 某物左边或右边、前边或后边的区域: We live (on) the other side of the main road. 我们住在大路的另一边。 It's more expensive to live on the north side of town. 住在城北比较昂贵。 In Japan they drive on the left-hand side of the road. 在日本，人们靠左行车。 She sat at the side of his bed/at his bedside. 她坐在他的床边。
6 either of the two flat surfaces of sth thin （扁平物体的）面: Write on both sides of the paper. 纸的两面都可书写。
7 the right or the left part of your body, especially from under your arm to the top of your leg 身体的侧边（尤指胳膊下至腿上端的部份）: She lay on her side. 她侧卧着。 The soldier stood with his hands by his sides. 士兵站着，两手垂在身旁。
8 either of two or more people or groups who are fighting, playing, arguing, etc against each other 敌对或参赛的一方: The two sides agreed to stop fighting. 双方同意停止战斗。 the winning/losing side 胜方；负方 Whose side are you on? (= Who do you want to win?) 你支持哪一方？
9 what is said by one person or group that is different from what is said by another 一派或一方（的说法）: I don't know whose side of the story to believe. 我不知道该相信哪一方的说法。
10 your mother's or your father's family 母亲或父亲的家族；母系；父系: There is no history of illness on his mother's side. 他母系那边没有家族病史。
get on the right/wrong side of sb to please/annoy sb 取悦╱惹恼某人: He tried to get on the right side of his new boss. 他努力取悦新老板。 look on the bright side→LOOK¹ on/from all sides;on/from every side in/from all directions 四面八方；从各方面 on the big, small, high, etc side(informal 非正式) slightly too big, small, high, etc 稍大╱小╱高… on the safe side→SAFE¹ put sth on/to one side;leave sth on one side to leave or keep sth so that you can use it or deal with it later 搁置；留下来备用: You should put some money to one side for the future. 你应该留些钱将来使用。 side by side next to each other; close together 并肩；并排；紧贴: They walked side by side along the road. 他们并肩沿着马路走去。 take sides (with sb) to show that you support one person rather than another in an argument 支持（某方）: Parents should never take sides when their children are quarrelling. 孩子争吵时父母不应袒护任何一方。
side²
/saɪd ||; saɪd/verb side with sb (against sb) to support sb in an argument 在争论中支持某方

sideboard
/ˈsaɪdbɔ:d ||; ˈsaɪdˌbɔrd/noun [C] a type of low cupboard about as high as a table, that is used for storing plates, etc in a room that is used for eating (dining room) 餐具柜 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

sideburns
/ˈsaɪdbɜ:nz ||; ˈsaɪdˌbɝnz/noun [pl] hair that grows down a man's face in front of his ears （男子的）鬓角

sidecar
/ˈsaɪdkɑ:(r) ||; ˈsaɪdˌkɑr/noun [C] a small vehicle attached to the side of a motorcycle in which a passenger can ride ﹙摩托车的﹚跨斗，边车

ˈside effect
noun [C]
1 the unpleasant effect that a drug may have in addition to its useful effects 副作用: Side effects of the drug include nausea and dizziness. 这种药物的副作用包括恶心和头晕。
2 an unexpected effect of sth that happens in addition to the intended effect 意外后果: One of the side effects when the chemical factory closed was that fish returned to the river. 化工厂关闭以后，鱼类返回河里，算是出乎意料的结果之一。 ☞Look at after-effect and effect. 参看after-effect及effect。

sideline
/ˈsaɪdlaɪn ||; ˈsaɪdˌlaɪn/noun
1 [C] something that you do in addition to your regular job, especially to earn extra money 兼职，副业（尤指为了多挣钱）: He's an engineer, but he repairs cars as a sideline. 他是工程师，但兼职修理汽车。
2 sidelines [pl] the lines that mark the two long sides of the area used for playing sports such as football, tennis, etc; the area behind this （足球场、网球场等的）边线，界外区
on the sidelines not involved in an activity; not taking part in sth 当旁观者；当局外人

sidelong
/ˈsaɪdlɒŋ ||; ˈsaɪdˌlɔŋ/adj directed from the side; sideways 横向的；斜的: a sidelong glance 斜视

ˈside road
noun [C] a small road which joins a bigger main road 支路；岔路

sideshow
/ˈsaɪdʃəʊ ||; ˈsaɪdˌʃo/noun[C]
1 a separate small show or attraction at a fair or circus where you pay to see a performance or take part in a game ﹙游园会或马戏中穿插的﹚小节目，杂耍
2 an activity or event that is much less important than the main activity or event 次要活动；附带事件

sidestep
/ˈsaɪdstep ||; ˈsaɪdˌstɛp/verb (sidestepping;sidestepped)
1 [T] to avoid answering a question or dealing with a problem 回避（问题）: Did you notice how she neatly sidestepped the question? 你有没有注意到她如何巧妙地回避了那个问题？
2 [T] [I] to avoid sth, for example being hit, by stepping to one side 闪开，避开（打击等）

ˈside street
noun [C] a narrow or less important street near a main street 小巷；小街；小路

sideswipe
/ˈsaɪdswaɪp ||; ˈsaɪdˌswaɪp/noun[C]
1 (US 美) a hit from the side 擦边撞击；侧撞: a sideswipe by a truck 卡车的擦撞
2 sideswipe (at sb/sth) (informal 非正式) a critical comment made about sb/sth while you are talking about sb/sth completely different 借机抨击；借题发挥的批评: It was a good speech, but he couldn't resist taking a sideswipe at his opponent. 他的演讲很不错，可他还是忍不住借机把对手影射了一番。 ➔sideswipe verb [T] (US 美): The bus sideswiped two parked cars. 公共汽车擦撞了两辆停着的车。

sidetrack
/ˈsaɪdtræk ||; ˈsaɪdˌtræk/verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to make sb forget what he/she is doing or talking about and start doing or talking about sth less important 转移话题；使离题

sidewalk
/ˈsaɪdwɔ:k ||; ˈsaɪdˌwɔk/ (US 美) =PAVEMENT

sideways
/ˈsaɪdweɪz ||; ˈsaɪdˌwez/adv adj
1 to, towards or from one side 横向地；斜向地: He jumped sideways to avoid being hit. 他跳到一旁以免被撞倒。
2 with one of the sides at the top 侧面朝上: We'll have to turn the sofa sideways to get it through the door. 我们必须把沙发侧过来才能搬进门去。

siding
/ˈsaɪdɪŋ ||; ˈsaɪdɪŋ/noun [C] [usu.pl] a short track at the side of a main railway line where trains go when they are not being used （铁路）侧线，岔道

sidle
/ˈsaɪdl ||; ˈsaɪdḷ/verb [I] sidle up/over (to sb/sth) to move towards sb/sth in a nervous way, as if you do not want anyone to notice you 小心翼翼地（朝某人或某物）走去（彷佛不想受到注意）

siege
/si:dʒ ||; sidʒ/noun [C,U] a situation in which an army surrounds a town for a long time or the police surround a building so that nobody can get in or out 围攻；围城

siesta
/siˈestə ||; sɪˈɛstə/noun [C] a short sleep or rest that people take in the afternoon, especially in hot countries 午睡，午休（尤指在气候炎热国家的）: to have/take a siesta 睡午觉

sieve
/sɪv ||; sɪv/noun [C] a type of kitchen tool that has a metal or plastic net, used for separating solids from liquids or very small pieces of food from large pieces 筛子；滤网: Pour the soup through a sieve to get rid of any lumps. 把汤汁倒在滤网里滤掉团块。 ☞picture at kitchen 见kitchen插图 sieve verb [T] to sieve flour 筛面粉

sift
/sɪft ||; sɪft/verb
1 [T] to pass flour, sugar or a similar substance through a SIEVE in order to remove any lumps 筛；滤: to sift flour/sugar 筛面粉╱糖
2 [I,T] sift (through) sth to examine sth very carefully 仔细检查；详细审查: It took weeks to sift through all the evidence. 细查这些证据花了多个星期。

*sigh
/saɪ ||; saɪ/verb
1 [I] to let out a long, deep breath that shows you are tired, sad, disappointed, etc （因疲劳、悲伤、失望等）叹息，叹气: She sighed with disappointment at the news. 听到这消息，她失望地叹了口气。
2 [T] to say sth with a sigh 叹息着说: ‘I'm so tired,’ he sighed. 他叹息着说：“我累极了。”
3 [I] to make a long sound like a sigh 发出叹息般的声音 ➔sigh noun [C]
heave a sigh→HEAVE¹

*sight¹
/saɪt ||; saɪt/noun
1 [U] the ability to see 视力: He lost his sight in the war(= he became blind). 他在战争中丧失了视力。 My grandmother has very poor sight. 我祖母视力很差。
2 -sighted (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) able to see in the way mentioned 有某种视力或视觉: a partially sighted child 半盲的儿童 ☞Look at long-sighted and short-sighted. 参看long-sighted及short-sighted。
3 [sing] the sight of sb/sth the act of seeing sb/sth 看见: I feel ill at the sight of blood. 我一看见血就觉得不舒服。
4 [U] a position where sb/sth can be seen 视野；视力所及处: They waited until the plane was in / within sightand then fired. 他们一直等到飞机进入视野范围内才开火。 When we get over this hill the town should come into sight. 翻过这座山以后，那个镇就该在望了。 She didn't let the child out of her sight. 她不让孩子离开自己的视线。
5 [C] something that you see 看到的东西；景象: The burned-out building was a terrible sight. 那座被烧毁的大厦真是不堪入目。
6 sights [pl] places of interest that are often visited by tourists 风景区；名胜: When you come to New York I'll show you the sights. 如果你到纽约来，我带你游览名胜。
7 a sight [sing] (informal 非正式) a person or thing that looks strange or amusing 样子古怪或令人发笑的人或物
8 [C] [usu.pl] the part of a gun that you look through in order to aim it （枪的）瞄准器
at first glance/sight→FIRST¹ catch sight/a glimpse of sb/sth→CATCH¹ in sight likely to happen or come soon 即将发生: A peace settlement is in sight. 和平解决在望。 lose sight of sb/sth→LOSE on sight as soon as you see sb/sth 一见到: The soldiers were ordered to shoot the enemy on sight. 士兵奉命一见敌人就开枪。
sight²
/saɪt ||; saɪt/verb [T] to see sb/sth, especially after looking out for him/her/it 看见，发现（尤指在寻找以后）

sighted
/ˈsaɪtɪd ||; ˈsaɪtɪd/adj
1 able to see; not blind 看得见的；有视力的: the blind parents of sighted children 视力正常的孩子们的盲人父母
2 -sighted (in compounds 用于构成复合词) able to see in the way mentioned 有…视力的；视力…的: partially sighted 有部份视力的 shortsighted 近视的 nearsighted近视的

sighting
/ˈsaɪtɪŋ ||; ˈsaɪtɪŋ/noun [C] an occasion when sb/sth is seen 看见；发现: the first sighting of a new star 一颗新星的首次发现

ˈsight-read
verb [I,T] to play or sing written music when you see it for the first time, without practising it first 视奏，视唱﹙无事先演练，见谱便演奏或演唱﹚

sightseeing
/ˈsaɪtsi:ɪŋ ||; ˈsaɪtˌsiɪŋ/noun [U] visiting the sights of a city, etc as a tourist 观光；游览: We did some sightseeing in Rome. 我们在罗马观光了一些地方。

sightseer
/ˈsaɪtsi:ə(r) ||; ˈsaɪtˌsiɚ/noun [C] a person who visits the sights of a city, etc as a tourist 观光客 ☞Look at tourist. 参看tourist。

*sign¹
/saɪn ||; saɪn/noun[C]
1 sign (of sth) something that shows that sb/sth is present, exists or may happen 迹象；征兆；征候: The patient was showing some signsof improvement. 病人有好转的迹象。 As we drove into the village there wasn't a sign of life anywhere (= we couldn't see anyone). 我们驾车入村，发现那里空无一人。
2 a piece of wood, paper, etc that has writing or a picture on it that gives you a piece of information, an instruction or a warning 指示牌；标牌；标志: What does that sign say? 牌上写的是什么？ a road sign 道路标志 Follow the signs to Banbury. 依照路标前往班伯里。 ☞picture at roundabout 见roundabout插图
3 a movement that you make with your head, hands or arms that has a particular meaning 示意的动作；手势: I made a sign for him to follow me. 我向他打个手势，叫他跟我走。 I'll give you a signwhen it's time for you to speak. 轮到你发言的时候，我会向你做个手势。
4 a type of shape, mark or symbol that has a particular meaning 符号；记号: In mathematics, a cross is a plus sign. 在数学中，十字形是表示相加的符号。
5 (also ˌsign of the ˈzodiac) one of the twelve divisions or symbols of the ZODIAC （黄道十二宫之一的）宫，星座: I'm a Leo. What sign are you? 我属于狮子座，你属于哪个星座？
*sign²
/saɪn ||; saɪn/verb
1 [I,T] to write your name on a letter, document, etc to show that you have written it or that you agree with what it says 签名；签圣猍I] ‘Could you sign here, please?’ “请在这里签名。” I forgot to sign the cheque. 我忘记在支票上签名。 The two presidents signed the treaty. 两国总统在条约上签了字。 ☞noun signature 名词为signature
2 [T] sign sb (up) to get sb to sign a contract to work for you （通过签定合约）雇用: Real Madrid have signed two new players. 皇家马德里队签约雇用两名新球员。
3 [I] to communicate using sign language （以手语）沟通，示意
sign in/out to write your name to show you have arrived at or left a hotel, club, etc 签名以示到达╱离开（旅馆、俱乐部等） sign up (for sth) to agree formally to do sth 报名参加: I've signed up for evening classes. 我报名学习夜校课程。

*signal
/ˈsɪgnəl ||; ˈsɪgnḷ/noun[C]
1 a sign, action or sound that sends a particular message 信号；暗号: When I give (you) the signal, run! 我一发出信号，你就跑！
2 an event, action or fact that shows that sth exists or is likely to happen 标志；表示: The fall in unemployment is a clear signal that the economy is improving. 失业率下降明确标志着经济在改善。
3 a set of lights used to give information to train drivers 铁路信号灯
4 a series of radio waves, etc that are sent out or received （无线电波等传送的）信号: a signal from a satellite 恒星信号 signal verb [I,T] (signalling;signalled (US 美) signaling;signaled) She was signalling wildly that something was wrong. 她拚命示意出了事。

signatory
/ˈsɪgnətri; US -tɔ:rɪ ||; ˈsɪgnəˌtɔrɪ/noun [C] (plural signatories)signatory (to sth) one of the people or countries that sign an agreement, etc 签署者；签署国；签约国

*signature
/ˈsɪgnətʃə(r) ||; ˈsɪgnətʃɚ/noun [C] a person's name, written by that person and always written in the same way 签名；签字；署名: I couldn't read his signature. 我看不清他的签名。 ☞verb sign 动词为sign

significance
/sɪgˈnɪfɪkəns ||; sɪgˈnɪfəkəns/noun [U] the importance or meaning of sth 重要性；意义；含意: Few people realized the significance of the discovery. 很少人认识到这个发现的重要意义。

*significant
/sɪgˈnɪfɪkənt ||; sɪgˈnɪfəkənt/adj
1 important or large enough to be noticed 重要的；明显的；显著的: Police said that the time of the murder was extremely significant. 警方说凶杀案发生的时间对调查极为重要。 There has been a significant improvement in your work. 你的工作有了明显的改进。
2 having a particular meaning 有某种意义或含意的: It could be significant that he took out life insurance shortly before he died. 他在临死前不久投了人寿保险，这可能意义重大。 ➔significantly adv Attitudes have changed significantly since the 1960s. 自从20世纪60年代以来，人们对事物的看法发生了重大变化。

sigˌnificant ˈother
noun [C] your husband, wife, partner or sb that you have a special relationship with 重要的另一位，另一半﹙如配偶、情人等﹚

signify
/ˈsɪgnɪfaɪ ||; ˈsɪgnəˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle signifying third person singular present signifies;past tense past participle signified) (formal 正式)
1 to be a sign of sth; to mean 表示某种意思；代表；意味: What do those lights signify? 那些灯光表示什么？
2 to express or indicate sth 表示；表明: They signified their agreement by raising their hands. 他们举手表示赞成。

ˈsign language
noun [U] a language used especially by people who cannot hear or speak, using the hands to make signs instead of spoken words 手语

signpost
/ˈsaɪnpəʊst ||; ˈsaɪnˌpost/noun [C] a sign at the side of a road that gives information about directions and distances to towns 路牌；路标 ☞picture at roundabout 见roundabout插图

Sikh
/si:k ||; sik/noun [C] a member of one of the religions of India(Sikhism)that developed from Hinduism but teaches that there is only one god 锡克教教徒 Sikh adj ➔Sikhism /ˈsi:kɪzəm ||; ˈsikɪzəm/ noun [U]

silage
/ˈsaɪlɪdʒ ||; ˈsaɪlɪdʒ/noun [U] grass or other green plants that are stored without being dried and are used to feed farm animals in winter 青贮饲料

*silence
/ˈsaɪləns ||; ˈsaɪləns/noun
1 [U] no noise or sound at all 寂静；肃静: There must be silence during examinations. 考试时必须保持肃静。
2 [C,U] a period when nobody speaks or makes a noise 一段时间的沉默或寂静: My question was met with an awkward silence. 我的提问换来一阵沉默，真令人尴尬。 We ate in silence. 我们一声不吭地吃着。
3 [U] not making any comments about sth 沉默；保持缄默 silence verb [T]

silencer
/ˈsaɪlənsə(r) ||; ˈsaɪlənsɚ/ (US 美 muffler) noun [C]
1 a device which is fixed to the long tube under a vehicle(exhaust pipe)to reduce the noise made by the engine （车辆的）排气消声器，排气消音器 ☞picture at motorbike 见motorbike插图
2 the part of a gun that reduces the noise when it is fired （枪的）消音器

*silent
/ˈsaɪlənt ||; ˈsaɪlənt/adj
1 where there is no noise; making no noise; very quiet 安静的；寂静的: The house was empty and silent. 房子内寂静无人。
2 silent (on/about sth) refusing to speak about sth 沉默的；不作声的: The policeman told her she had the right to remain silent. 警察告诉她有权保持沉默。
3 not using spoken words 不用言语的；无声的: a silent prayer/protest 默祷者；无声的抗议
4 (of a letter) not pronounced （字母）不发音的: The ‘b’ in ‘comb’ is silent. comb中的b字母不发音。 ➔silently adv

silhouette
/ˌsɪluˈet ||; ˌsɪlυˈɛt/noun [C] the dark solid shape of sb/sth seen against a light background 剪影；黑色轮廓 ➔silhouetted adj

silica
/ˈsɪlɪkə ||; ˈsɪlɪkə/noun [U] (symbol SiO₂) a chemical compound of silicon found in sand and in rocks such as QUARTZ, used in making glass and cement 二氧化硅

silicon
/ˈsɪlɪkən ||; ˈsɪlɪkən/noun [U] (symbol Si) a substance that exists as a grey solid or as a brown powder and is found in rocks and sand. It is used in making glass. 硅

ˌsilicon ˈchip
noun [C] (computing计算机技术) a very small piece of silicon that is used to carry a complicated electronic CIRCUIT 硅片

silicone
/ˈsɪlɪkəʊn ||; ˈsɪlɪkon/noun [U] a chemical compound of silicon. There are several different types of silicone, used to make paint, artificial rubber, varnish, etc. 硅酮；硅树脂: a silicone breast implant 硅酮隆胸植入物

silk
/sɪlk ||; sɪlk/noun [U] the soft smooth cloth that is made from threads produced by an insect(a silkworm) 丝；丝绸: a silk shirt/dress 丝质衬衫╱连衣裙

ˈsilk-screen
noun
1 [U] a method of printing in which ink is forced through a design cut in a piece of fine cloth 丝网印刷: silk-screen prints 丝网印刷品
2 [C] a picture, etc produced by this method 丝网印刷画: Warhol's silk-screen of Marilyn Monroe 沃霍尔制作的玛丽莲·梦鲁思网印刷肖像 ➔ˈsilk-screen verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态)

silkworm
/ˈsɪlkwɜ:m ||; ˈsɪlkˌwɝm/noun [C] a small creature with a soft body and legs(a caterpillar)that produces very thin thread(silk) 蚕

silky
/ˈsɪlki ||; ˈsɪlkɪ/adj smooth, soft and shiny; like silk 柔滑如丝的: silky hair 柔软润泽的头发

sill
/sɪl ||; sɪl/noun [C] a shelf that is at the bottom of a window, either inside or outside 窗槛；窗台: a window sill 窗台

*silly
/ˈsɪli ||; ˈsɪlɪ/adj (sillier;silliest)
1 not showing thought or understanding; foolish 愚蠢的；傻的: a silly mistake 愚蠢的错误 Don't be so silly! 别这么傻！ [OPP] sensible 反义词为sensible
2 appearing ridiculous, so that people will laugh 看起来荒谬的；引人发笑的: I'm not wearing that hat -- I'd look silly in it. 我不戴那顶帽子，戴了样子会很傻。 ➔silliness noun [U]

silo
/ˈsaɪləʊ ||; ˈsaɪlo/noun[C]
1 a tall tower on a farm used for storing grain, etc （贮存粮食等的）筒仓
2 an underground place where grass or other green plants are made into a substance(silage)that is stored until winter to feed the farm animals 青贮窖

silt
/sɪlt ||; sɪlt/noun [U] sand, soil or mud that collects at the sides or on the bottom of a river 淤泥（河流中沉积的泥沙） ☞picture at flood plain 见flood plain插图

*silver¹
/ˈsɪlvə(r) ||; ˈsɪlvɚ/noun[U]
1 (symbol Ag) a valuable grey-white metal that is used for making jewellery, coins, etc 银: a silver spoon/necklace 银匙╱项链 That's a nice ring. Is it silver? 那个戒指不错，是银的吗？
2 coins made from silver or sth that looks like silver 银币（用银或像银的材料制成）
3 objects that are made of silver, for example knives, forks, spoons, dishes 银器: The thieves stole some jewellery and some valuable silver. 那些贼偷了一些珠宝和贵重银器。
every cloud has a silver lining→CLOUD¹
*silver²
/ˈsɪlvə(r) ||; ˈsɪlvɚ/adj having the colour of silver 银色的: a silver sports car 银色跑车

ˌsilver ˈmedal
(also silver) noun [C] a small flat round piece of silver that is given to the person or team that comes second in a sports competition （体育比赛的）银牌: to win a silver medal at the Olympic Games 在奥林匹克运动会上得到银牌 ☞Look at gold medal and bronze medal. 参看gold medal及bronze medal。 ➔ˌsilver ˈmedallist noun [C]

silversmith
/ˈsɪlvəsmɪθ ||; ˈsɪlvɚˌsmɪθ/noun [C] a person who makes, repairs or sells articles made of silver 银匠；银器商

ˌsilver ˈwedding
noun [C] the 25th anniversary of a wedding 银婚（结婚25周年纪念） ☞Look at golden wedding and diamond wedding. 参看golden wedding及diamond wedding。

silvery
/ˈsɪlvəri ||; ˈsɪlvərɪ/adj having the appearance or colour of silver 像银的；银色的: an old lady with silvery hair 一头银发的老太太

SIM card
/ˈsɪm kɑ:d ||; ˈsɪm ˌkɑrd/noun [C] a plastic card inside a cellular phone that stores personal information about the person using the phone ﹙手机的﹚用户识别模块卡，用户识别卡

*similar
/ˈsɪmələ(r) ||; ˈsɪməlɚ/adj similar (to sb/sth);similar (in sth) like sb/sth but not exactly the same 相似的；类似的: Our houses are very similar in size. 我们的房子大小很相似。 Your handwriting is very similar to mine. 你的字迹跟我的很相似。 [OPP] different or dissimilar 反义词为different或dissimilar ➔similarly adv The plural of ‘shelf’ is ‘shelves’. Similarly, the plural of ‘wolf’ is ‘wolves’. shelf的复数是shelves。同样，wolf的复数是wolves。

similarity
/ˌsɪməˈlærəti ||; ˌsɪməˈlærətɪ/noun (plural similarities)
1 [U] [sing] similarity (to sb/sth);similarity (in sth) the state of being like sb/sth but not exactly the same 相似；类似: She bears a remarkable/striking similarityto her mother. 她跟她的母亲很相像。
2 [C] a similarity (between A and B);a similarity (in/of sth) a characteristic that people or things have which makes them similar 相似之处: Although there are some similarities between the two towns, there are a lot of differences too. 两个市镇虽然有些相似，但也有许多不同之处。 similarities in/of style 风格上的相似之处

simile
/ˈsɪməli ||; ˈsɪməˌlɪ/noun [C,U] (technical术语) a word or phrase that compares sth to sth else, using the words ‘like’ or ‘as’, for example ‘a face like a mask’ or ‘as white as snow’; the use of such words and phrases 明喻（一种修辞手段，使用like、as等词，如a face like a mask或as white as snow）；明喻的运用 ☞Compare metaphor. 与metaphor比较。

simmer
/ˈsɪmə(r) ||; ˈsɪmɚ/verb [I,T] to cook gently in a liquid that is almost boiling 炖

simper
/ˈsɪmpə(r) ||; ˈsɪmpɚ/verb [I] (written 书面语) to smile in a silly and annoying way 矫揉造作地笑；扭捏作态地笑: a silly simpering girl 扭捏作态、嘻嘻傻笑的女孩子 He just simpered at me. 他只是一个劲儿地冲我谄笑。

*simple
/ˈsɪmpl ||; ˈsɪmpḷ/adj
1 easy to understand, do or use; not difficult or complicated 容易明白、做或使用的；简单的: This dictionary is written in simple English. 这本词典用简单的英语编写成。 a simple task/method/solution 简单的任务╱方法╱解决办法 I can't just leave the job. It's not as simple as that. 我不能把这任务搁下不管。事情不是这样简单。
2 without decoration or unnecessary extra things; plain and basic 式样简单的: a simple black dress 朴素的黑色连衣裙 The food is simple but perfectly cooked. 食物很简单，但煮得很好。
3 used for saying that the thing you are talking about is the only thing that is important or true 纯粹的: I'm not going to buy it for the simple reason that (= only because)I haven't got enough money. 我不会买纯粹是因为我没有足够的钱。
4 (used about a person or a way of life) natural and not complicated （指人或生活方式）简朴的，朴素的: a simple life in the country 乡下的简朴生活
5 not intelligent; slow to understand 不聪明的；迟钝的
6 (grammar语法) used to describe the present or past tense of a verb that is formed without using another verb(an auxiliary verb), as in ‘She loves him’ and ‘He arrived late.’ 简单的（指动词的现在时或过去时形式不用助动词，如在She loves him及He arrived late中）: the simple present/past tense 简单现在时╱过去时

ˌsimple-ˈminded
adj not intelligent; not able to understand how complicated things are 智力低下的；头脑简单的: a simple-minded person 头脑简单的人 a simple-minded view/approach愚蠢的观点/方法

simplicity
/sɪmˈplɪsəti ||; sɪmˈplɪsətɪ/noun[U]
1 the quality of being easy to understand, do or use 简单；简易: We all admired the simplicity of the plan. 计划简单明了，我们都很赞赏。
2 the quality of having no decoration or unnecessary extra things; being natural and not complicated 简朴；无赘饰: I like the simplicity of her paintings. 她的画很简朴，我很喜欢。

simplify
/ˈsɪmplɪfaɪ ||; ˈsɪmpləˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle simplifying third person singular present simplifies;past tense past participle simplified) to make sth easier to do or understand; to make sth less complicated 简化: The process of applying for visas has been simplified. 申请签证的程序已经简化了。 ➔simplification /ˌsɪmplɪfɪˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌsɪmpləfəˈkeʃən/ noun [C,U]

simplistic
/sɪmˈplɪstɪk ||; sɪmˈplɪstɪk/adj making a problem, situation, etc seem less difficult and complicated than it really is 使显得简单的

simply
/ˈsɪmpli ||; ˈsɪmplɪ/adv
1 used to emphasize how easy or basic sth is （用于强调容易或基本）: Simply add hot water and stir. 只要加点热水一搅就成了。
2 (used to emphasize an adjective) completely; absolutely （用于强调形容词）完全，绝对，简直: That meal was simply excellent. 那顿饭简直棒透了。
3 in a way that makes sth easy to understand 简单地；简明地；浅白地: Could you explain it more simply? 你解释得浅白一点好吗？
4 in a simple, basic way; without decoration or unnecessary extra things 简朴地: They live simply, with very few luxuries. 他们生活简朴，没有多少奢侈品。
5 only; just 只是；仅仅: There's no need to get angry. The whole problem is simply a misunderstanding. 不用生气，整件事只不过是个误会。

simulate
/ˈsɪmjuleɪt ||; ˈsɪmjəˌlet/verb [T] to create certain conditions that exist in real life using computers, models, etc, usually for study or training purposes 仿造；模拟: The astronauts trained in a machine that simulates conditions in space. 航天员在模拟太空环境的机器中进行训练。 ➔simulation /ˌsɪmjuˈleɪʃn ||; ˌsɪmjəˈleʃən/ noun [C,U] a computer simulation of a nuclear attack 计算机模拟的核攻击

simulcast
/ˈsɪmlkɑ:st ||; ˈsɪmḷˌkæst/verb [T] (past tense, past participle simulcast) to broadcast sth on radio and television at the same time or on two or more channels 联播﹙节目﹚: It will be simulcast live to 201 countries. 这个节目将在 201 个国家现场联播。 ➔simulcast noun [C]

simultaneous
/ˌsɪmlˈteɪniəs; US ˌsaɪm- ||; ˌsaɪmḷˈtenɪəs/adj happening or done at exactly the same time as sth else 同时的；同时发生的 ➔simultaneously adv

sin
/sɪn ||; sɪn/noun [C,U] an action or way of behaving that is not allowed by a religion 触犯宗教戒律的行为；罪恶: He believes it is a sin for two people to live together without being married. 他认为两个人没有结婚而同居是罪孽。 sin verb [I] (sinning;sinned) ➔sinner noun [C]

*since
/sɪns ||; sɪns/adv conj prep
1 from a particular time in the past until a later time in the past or until now 自从: My parents bought this house in 1975 and we've been living here ever since. 我父母在1975年买了这所房子，我们一直就在这里住。 I've been working in a bank ever since I left school. 我中学毕业后一直在银行工作。 It was the first time they'd won since 1974. 那次是他们自1974年以来首度获胜。 I haven't seen him since last Tuesday. 我从上星期二开始就没有见过他。 She has had a number of jobs since leaving university. 她大学毕业后，做过好几份工作。 ☞We use both since and for to talk about how long something has been happening. We use since when we are talking about the beginning of the period of time, and for when we are talking about the length of the period of time I've known her since 1997. I've known her for three years. since和for用以表示某事开始了多久。说事情由某时间开始﹐可用since﹔表达持续的时间则用for﹕I've known her since 1997.我１９９７年以来就认识她。I've known her for three years. 我认识她已有三年。
2 at a time after a particular time in the past 在过去某个时间之后: We were divorced two years ago and she has since married someone else. 我们两年前离婚，后来她和别人结了婚。
3 because; as 因为；既然: Since they've obviously forgotten to phone me, I'll have to phone them. 他们显然忘记打电话给我，我只得打给他们。

*sincere
/sɪnˈsɪə(r) ||; sɪnˈsɪr/adj
1 (used about a person) really meaning or believing what you say; not pretending （指人）真诚的，诚实的: Do you think she was being sincere when she said she admired me? 她说仰慕我，你觉得她说的是真话吗？
2 (used about a person's feelings, beliefs or behaviour) true; showing what you really mean or feel （指人的感情、信念或行为）真实的，真心的: Please accept our sincere thanks/apologies. 我们竭诚致谢╱道歉，恳请接受。 [OPP] insincere 反义词为insincere ➔sincerely adv I am sincerely grateful to you for all your help. 我衷心感谢你的帮助。 Yours sincerely, ...(= at the end of a formal letter) 敬启（正式书信末的客套话） ➔sincerity /sɪnˈserəti ||; sɪnˈsɛrətɪ/ noun [U] [OPP] insincerity 反义词为insincerity

sine
/saɪn ||; saɪn/noun [C] (abbr sin) (mathematics数学) the RATIO of the length of the side opposite one of the angles in a RIGHT-ANGLED triangle (= a triangle with one angle of 90°) to the length of the longest side 正弦（三角函数之一，指直角三角形某锐角的对边与斜边之比） ☞Compare cosine and tangent. 与cosine及tangent比较。

sinew
/ˈsɪnju: ||; ˈsɪnju/noun [C] [U] a strong band of substance that joins a muscle to a bone 肌腱；筋

sinful
/ˈsɪnfl ||; ˈsɪnfəl/adj breaking a religious law; immoral 犯戒律的；不道德的

*sing
/sɪŋ ||; sɪŋ/verb [I,T] (past tense sang /sæŋ ||; sæŋ/ past participle sung /sʌŋ ||; sʌŋ/) to make musical sounds with your voice 唱；唱歌: He always sings when he's in the bath. 他在洗澡时总是唱歌。 The birds were singing outside my window. 小鸟在我窗外唱歌。 She sang all her most popular songs at the concert. 她在演唱会上唱她所有最受欢迎的歌。 ➔singing noun [U]: singing lessons 唱歌课

singalong
/ˈsɪŋəlɒŋ ||; ˈsɪŋəˌlɑŋ/noun [C] an informal occasion at which people sing songs together 众人唱歌自娱: a singalong in the local bar 当地酒吧的歌唱会

singe
/sɪndʒ ||; sɪndʒ/verb [I,T] (present participle singeing) to burn the surface of sth slightly, usually by accident; to be burned in this way 烫或烧焦某物的表面

singer
/ˈsɪŋə(r) ||; ˈsɪŋɚ/noun [C] a person who sings, or whose job is singing, especially in public 歌手；歌者: an opera singer 歌剧演员

*single¹
/ˈsɪŋgl ||; ˈsɪŋgḷ/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) only one 唯一的；一个的；单一的: He gave her a single red rose. 他送给她一枝红玫瑰。 I managed to finish the whole job in a single afternoon. 我只花了一个下午就完成整件工作。 I went to a single-sex (= for boys only or girls only) school. 我上了一所男子╱女子学校。
2 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) used to emphasize that you are talking about each individual item of a group or series （用以强调所指的是整体中的一个独立部份）每一个: You answered every single question correctly. Well done! 每一个问题你都答对了。做得好！
3 not married 未婚的；独身的: Are you married or single? 你结婚了没有？ a single man/woman 未婚男子╱女子
4 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) for the use of only one person 只供一人使用的: I'd like to book a single room, please. 我想订一间单人房。 ☞Look at the note at bed ¹. 参看bed^1的注释。
5 (also one-way) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used about a ticket or the price of a ticket) for a journey to a particular place, but not back again （指车票等或票价）单程的: How much is the single fare to Rome? 请问到罗马的单程票多少钱？ ☞Look at return ²(5). 参看return^2(5)。
in single file→FILE¹
single²
/ˈsɪŋgl ||; ˈsɪŋgḷ/noun
1 [C] a ticket for a journey to a particular place, but not back again 单程（车）票: Two singles to Hull, please. 请给我两张到赫尔的单程车票。 ☞Look at return ²(5). 参看return^2(5)。
2 [C] a CD, tape, etc that has only one song on each side; the main song on this tape or CD 单曲唱片；单曲唱片歌曲: Catatonia's new single 卡塔托尼亚的新单曲唱片 ☞Look at album. 参看album。
3 [C] a bedroom for one person in a hotel, etc （旅馆等的）单人房间 ☞Look at double ³(5). 参看double^3(5)。
4 singles [pl] people who are not married and do not have a romantic relationship with sb else 单身男子；单身女子；未婚男女
5 singles [U] a game of tennis, etc in which one player plays against one other player （网球等）单打 ☞Look at doubles. 参看doubles。
single³
/ˈsɪŋgl ||; ˈsɪŋgḷ/verb single sb/sth out (for sth) to give special attention or treatment to one person or thing from a group 选出，挑出（以特别对待）: She was singled out for criticism. 她给挑出来批评。

ˌsingle-ˈbreasted
adj (used about a jacket or a coat 指夹克或大衣) having only one row of buttons that fasten in the middle 单排钮扣的 ☞Look at double-breasted. 参看double-breasted。

ˌsingle-ˈdecker
noun [C] a bus with only one level 单层公共汽车 ☞picture at bus 见bus插图

ˌsingle-ˈhanded
adj adv on your own with nobody helping you 单人或独力进行

ˌsingle-ˈminded
adj having one clear aim or goal which you are determined to achieve 一心一意的 ➔single-mindedness noun [U]

ˌsingle ˈparent
noun [C] a person who looks after his/her child or children without a husband, wife or partner 独力照顾孩子的父亲或母亲；单亲: a single-parent family 单亲家庭

singlet
/ˈsɪŋglət ||; ˈsɪŋglɪt/noun [C] a piece of clothing without sleeves, worn under or instead of a shirt, often worn by runners, etc 无袖汗衫；背心

singly
/ˈsɪŋgli ||; ˈsɪŋglɪ/adv one at a time; individually 逐个；个别: You can buy the tapes either singly or in packs of three. 这些盒带可以单盒买，也可以买三盒一套的。

ˈsing-song
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) a sing-song voice keeps rising and falling 说话音调起伏的

singular
/ˈsɪŋgjələ(r) ||; ˈsɪŋgjəlɚ/adj
1 (grammar语法) in the form that is used for talking about one person or thing only （语法）单数的: ‘Table’ is a singular noun; ‘tables’ is a plural noun. table是单数名词；tables是复数名词。 ☞Look at plural. 参看plural。
2 (written 书面语) unusual 非凡的；不寻常的 singular noun [sing] (grammar语法) The word ‘clothes’ has no singular. clothes这个词没有单数形式。 What's the singular of ‘people’? people的单数形式是怎样的？

singularity
/ˌsɪŋgjuˈlærəti ||; ˌsɪŋgjəˈlærətɪ/noun [U] (formal 正式) the quality of sth that makes it unusual or strange 奇特；异常；奇怪: the singularity of his sculptures 他的雕塑品的异常之处

singularly
/ˈsɪŋgjələli ||; ˈsɪŋgjəlɚlɪ/adv (formal 正式) very; in an unusual way 非常；特别: The government has been singularly unsuccessful in its policy against terrorism. 政府对付恐怖主义的政策很不成功。

sinister
/ˈsɪnɪstə(r) ||; ˈsɪnɪstɚ/adj seeming evil or dangerous; making you feel that sth bad will happen 邪恶的；阴险的；不祥的: There's something sinister about him. He frightens me. 他有点邪门，使我感到害怕。

*sink¹
/sɪŋk ||; sɪŋk/verb (past tense sank /sæŋk ||; sæŋk/ past participle sunk /sʌŋk ||; sʌŋk/)
1 [I,T] to go down or make sth go down under the surface of liquid or a soft substance （使）沉入或陷入水中等: If you throw a stone into water, it sinks. 你把石子抛进水里，石子就会沉下去。 My feet sank into the mud. 我双脚陷进泥里。 ☞picture at float 见float插图
2 [I] (used about a person) to move downwards, usually by falling or sitting down （指人）往下移动（通常是跌倒或坐下）: I came home and sank into a chair, exhausted. 我回到家里，累得跌坐在椅子上。
3 [I] to get lower; to fall to a lower position or level 往下落；降低；下降: We watched the sun sink slowly below the horizon. 我们望着太阳慢慢沉到地平线下。
4 [I] to decrease in value, number, amount, strength, etc （价值、数目、数量、力气等）下降，减少
your heart sinks→HEART sink in (used about information, an event, an experience, etc) to be completely understood or realized （指消息、事件、经历等）被完全了解或明白: It took a long time for the terrible news to sink in. 过了好久那可怕的消息才被完全理解。 sink in; sink into sth (used about a liquid) to go into sth solid; to be absorbed （指液体）渗入，被吸收
*sink²
/sɪŋk ||; sɪŋk/noun [C] a large open container in a kitchen, with taps to supply water, where you wash things 洗涤槽；水槽 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图 ☞Look at washbasin. 参看washbasin。

sinkhole
/ˈsɪŋkhəʊl ||; ˈsɪŋkˌhol/noun[C]
1 a large circular hole that forms naturally in the ground 落水洞；灰岩坑
2 (informal 非正式) something that uses up a lot of money or time over a long period 长期耗费大量钱﹙或时间﹚的事情

sinus
/ˈsaɪnəs ||; ˈsaɪnɪs/noun [C] (often plural 常用复数形式) one of the spaces in the bones of your face that are connected to your nose 鼻窦: I've got a terrible cold and my sinuses are blocked. 我得了重伤风，鼻子全塞了。 a sinus infection 鼻窦感染

sip
/sɪp ||; sɪp/verb [I,T] (sipping;sipped) to drink, taking only a very small amount of liquid into your mouth at a time 小口喝或啜 · We sat in the sun, sipping lemonade. 我们一边晒太阳，一边小口小口地喝汽水。 sip noun [C]

siphon
/ˈsaɪfn ||; ˈsaɪfən/ (also syphon) verb [T]
1 siphon sth into/out of sth; siphon sth off/out to remove a liquid from a container, often into another container, through a tube 用虹吸管抽走、吸走或输送
2 siphon sth off;siphon sth (from/out of sb/sth) to take money from a company illegally over a period of time 挪用公款

*sir
/sɜ:(r) ||; sɝ/noun
1 [sing] used as a polite way of speaking to a man whose name you do not know, for example in a shop or restaurant, or to show respect 先生（对男士的礼貌称呼，尤用于招呼顾客或表示尊敬）: I'm afraid we haven't got your size, sir. 对不起，先生，我们恐怕没有你的尺码。 ☞Look at madam. 参看madam。
2 [C] used at the beginning of a formal letter to a male person or male people （用于正式信函的开头，以称呼不知姓名的男士）: Dear Sir... 敬启者 Dear Sirs... 敬启者 ☞Look at Madam. 参看Madam。
3 /sə(r) ||; sɚ/ [sing] the title that is used in front of the name of a man who has received one of the highest British honours （获颁英国最高荣誉者的称号）爵士

sire¹
/ˈsaɪə(r) ||; ˈsaɪr/noun[C]
1 (technical 术语) the male parent of an animal, especially a horse 雄性动物﹙尤指种马﹚
2 (old-fashioned 旧) a word that people used in the past when they addressed a king ﹙旧时对国王的称呼﹚陛下
sire²
/ˈsaɪə(r) ||; ˈsaɪr/verb [T] to be the male parent of an animal, especially a horse ﹙种马等雄性动物﹚生殖

siren
/ˈsaɪrən ||; ˈsaɪrən/noun [C] a device that makes a long, loud sound as a warning or signal 汽笛；警报器: an air-raid siren 空袭警报器 Three fire engines raced past, sirens wailing. 三辆消防车疾驶而过，一路鸣着警报器。

sirloin
/ˈsɜ:lɔɪn ||; ˈsɝlɔɪn/ (also ˌsirloin ˈsteak) noun [U] [C] good quality meat that is cut from a cow's back 牛里脊肉；牛上腰肉

sirocco
/sɪˈrɒkəʊ ||; səˈrɑko/ (plural siroccos) noun [C] a hot wind that blows from Africa into Southern Europe 西洛可风（一种从非洲刮至南欧的热风）

sis
/sɪs ||; sɪs/noun [C] (informal 非正式) sister (used when you are speaking to her) ﹙用于直接称呼﹚姐姐，妹妹

sisal
/ˈsaɪsl ||; ˈsaɪsḷ/noun [U] strong thin threads made from the leaves of a tropical plant and used for making rope, floor coverings, etc 西沙尔麻；剑麻；琼麻

sissy
/ˈsɪsi ||; ˈsɪsɪ/noun [C] (plural sissies) (informal 非正式) a boy that other men or boys laugh at because they think he is weak or frightened, or only interested in the sort of things girls like 柔弱﹙或怯懦﹚的男孩；女孩子气的男孩: The other boys kept calling him a sissy and a wimp. 其他的男孩不断叫他“娘娘腔”和“窝囊废”。 ➔sissy adj

*sister
/ˈsɪstə(r) ||; ˈsɪstɚ/noun[C]
1 a girl or woman who has the same parents as another person 姐妹: I've got one brother and two sisters. 我有一个弟弟，两个妹妹。 We're sisters. 我们是姐妹。 ☞Look at half-sister and stepsister. 参看half-sister及stepsister。 ☞In English there is no common word that means ‘both brothers and sisters ’ Have you got any brothers and sisters? The word sibling is very formal. 英语中没有兄弟和姐妹合称的常用词：Have you got any brothers and sisters?你有兄弟姐妹吗？sibling为非常正式的用语。
2 oftenSister (Brit 英) a female hospital nurse in a high position 医院的高级护士；护士长
3 Sister a member of certain female religious groups; a NUN 修女
4 (usually used as an adjective 通常用作形容词) a thing that belongs to the same type or group as sth else 同一类型或组织的事物: We have a sister company in Japan. 我们在日本有一家姐妹公司。
5 (informal 非正式) a woman who you feel close to because she is a member of the same society, group, etc as you （属同一社团、组织等关系亲密的成员）姐妹

sisterhood
/ˈsɪstəhʊd ||; ˈsɪstɚˌhud/noun
1 [U] the close loyal relationship between women who share ideas and aims ﹙志同道合的﹚姐妹情谊
2 [C] a group of women who live in a community together, especially a religious one 妇女团体；修女会

ˈsister-in-law
noun [C] (plural sisters-in-law)
1 the sister of your husband or wife 丈夫或妻子的姐妹；姑子；姨子
2 the wife of your brother 兄弟的妻子；嫂子；弟妇

*sit
/sɪt ||; sɪt/verb (present participle sitting;past tense past participle sat /sæt ||; sæt/)
1 [I] to rest your weight on your bottom, for example in a chair 坐: We sat in the garden all afternoon. 我们整个下午坐在花园里。 She was sitting on the sofa, talking to her mother. 她坐在沙发上和母亲交谈。
2 [T] sit sb (down) to put sb into a sitting position; make sb sit down 使坐下: He picked up his daughter and sat her down on a chair. 他抱起女儿，让她在椅子上坐下来。 She sat me down and offered me a cup of tea. 她请我坐下，给我一杯茶。
3 [I] to be in a particular place or position 在某处；处于某种状况: The letter sat on the table for several days before anybody opened it. 那封信在桌上放了好几天才有人打开来看。
4 [T] (Brit 英) to take an exam 参加考试: If I fail, will I be able to sit the exam again? 如果我不及格，可不可以重考？
5 [I] (formal 正式) (used about an official group of people) to have a meeting or series of meetings （指官方团体等）开会
sit on the fence to avoid saying which side of an argument you support 骑墙观望；对争执双方不表态 sit about/around(informal 非正式) to spend time doing nothing active or useful 闲坐: We just sat around chatting all afternoon. 我们整个下午坐在那儿聊天。 sit back to relax and not take an active part in what other people are doing 休息: Sit back and take it easy while I make dinner. 我去弄晚饭，你坐下休息。 sit down to lower your body into a sitting position 坐下: He sat down in an armchair. 他在扶手椅里坐下来。 sit sth out
1 to stay in a place and wait for sth unpleasant or boring to finish 等待不快或乏味的事结束
2 to not take part in a dance, game, etc 坐在一旁不参加（跳舞、游戏等）
sit through sth to stay in your seat until sth boring or long has finished 坐着等待无聊或冗长的事结束 sit up
1 to move into a sitting position when you have been lying down or to make your back straight 坐起来；坐直: Sit up straight and concentrate! 坐端正，集中注意力！
2 to not go to bed although it is very late 熬夜: We sat up all night talking. 我们整晚都在聊天。

sitar
/sɪˈtɑ:(r);ˈsɪtɑ:(r)||; sɪˈtɑr/noun [C] a musical instrument from India like a guitar, with a long neck and two sets of metal strings 锡塔琴，西塔琴（一种类似吉他的印度弦乐器）

sitcom
/ˈsɪtkɒm ||; ˈsɪtˌkɑm/ (formal 正式ˌsituation ˈcomedy) noun [C,U] a funny programme on television that shows the same characters in different amusing situations each week 情景喜剧（每周由同样角色表演不同有趣故事的电视节目）

site
/saɪt ||; saɪt/noun[C]
1 a piece of land where a building was, is or will be situated 建筑物等的所在地；遗址；工地: a building/construction site 建筑工地 The company is looking for a site for its new offices. 公司正在物色建新办公室的地点。
2 a place where sth has happened or that is used for sth 现场；场地: the site of a famous battle 一次著名战役的战场
3 (computing计算机技术) a place on the Internet where a company, an organization, a university, etc puts information （公司、组织、大学等发布信息的）网站 ☞Look at website. 参看website。 site verb [T] (written 书面语) They met to discuss the siting of the new school. 他们开会讨论了新学校选址的事。

sitting
/ˈsɪtɪŋ ||; ˈsɪtɪŋ/noun[C]
1 a period of time during which a court of law or a parliament meets and does its work （法庭的）开庭期；（议会的）开会期
2 a time when a meal is served in a school, hotel, etc to a number of people at the same time （学校、酒店等）一轮的用餐时间: Dinner will be in two sittings. 晚餐分两轮进行。

ˌsitting ˈduck
noun [C] a person or thing that is easy to attack 易受攻击者；易被击中的目标

ˈsitting room
(Brit 英) =LIVING ROOM

situated
/ˈsɪtʃueɪtɪd ||; ˈsɪtʃυˌetɪd/adj in a particular place or position 位于某处的；处于某种境况的: The hotel is conveniently situated close to the beach. 旅馆邻近海滩，来往很方便。

*situation
/ˌsɪtʃuˈeɪʃn ||; ˌsɪtʃυˈeʃən/noun[C]
1 the things that are happening in a particular place or at a particular time 情况；情形；状况: The situation in the north of the country is extremely serious. 该国北部的情况十分严峻。 Tim is in a difficult situationat the moment. 蒂姆此刻处于困境。 the economic/financial/political situation 经济╱财政╱政治状况
2 (written 书面语) the position of a building, town, etc in relation to the area around it 坐落的地方；（建筑物、市镇等的）环境
3 (written 书面语) (old-fashioned 旧) a job 工作岗位；职位: Situations Vacant (= the part of a newspaper where jobs are advertised) 招聘（广告栏）

ˈsit-up
noun [C] an exercise for the stomach muscles in which you lie on your back with your legs bent, then lift the top half of your body from the floor 仰卧起坐（一种运动）: to do sit-ups 做仰卧起坐 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图

*six
/sɪks ||; sɪks/ number
1 6 六: The answers are on page six. 答案在第六页。 There are six of us for dinner tonight. 今晚我们有六个人吃晚饭。 They have six cats. 他们有六只猫。 My son is six (years old) next month. 我的儿子下个月就六岁大了。 She lives at 6 Elm Drive. 她住在榆树道6号。 a birthday card with a big six on it 上面有个大大的六字的生日贺卡
2 six- (in compounds 用于构成复合词) having six of the thing mentioned 有六…: She works a six-day week. 她每星期工作六天。 ☞For more information about numbers in dates, measurements, prices, etc, look at the special section on numbers at the back of this dictionary. 有关日期、度量衡、价格等数字的详细用法，参看本词典末数词用法部份。

ˈsix-shooter
noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) a small gun that holds six bullets 六发左轮手枪

*sixteen
/ˌsɪksˈti:n ||; ˌsɪksˈtin/ number 16 十六 ☞For examples of how to use numbers in sentences, look at six. 有关数词在句子里的示例，参看six。

sixteenth
/ˌsɪksˈti:nθ ||; ˌsɪksˈtinθ/pronoun det adv 16th 第十六（个） ☞Look at the examples at sixth ¹. 参看sixth^1的示例。

ˌsixˈteenth note
(US 美) =SEMIQUAVER

sixth¹
/sɪksθ ||; sɪksθ/pronoun det adv 6th 第六（个）: I've had five cups of tea already, so this is my sixth. 我已经喝了五杯茶，这是第六杯。 This is the sixth time I've tried to phone him. 这已经是我第六次尝试打电话找他。 ☞For more information about numbers in dates, measurements, prices, etc, look at the special section on numbers at the back of this dictionary. 有关日期、度量衡、价格等数字的详细用法，参看本词典末数词用法部份。
sixth²
/sɪksθ ||; sɪksθ/noun [C] the fraction 1/6; one of six equal parts of sth 六分之一

ˈsixth form
noun [C] [usu.sing] [with.sop] (Brit 英) the final two years at secondary school for students from the age of 16 to 18 who are studying for A level exams 中学六年级（中学的最后两年，学生为16至18岁，准备参加高级程度考试） ➔ˈsixth-former noun [C]

ˌsixth ˈsense
noun [sing] a special ability to know sth without using any of the five senses that include sight, touch, etc 第六感觉；直觉: My sixth sense told me to stay here and wait. 直觉告诉我应该待在这儿等着。 Often our intuition or sixth sense warns us of impending danger. 通常我们的直觉或第六感觉会提醒我们即将到来的危险。

sixtieth
/ˈsɪkstiəθ ||; ˈsɪkstɪɪθ/pronoun det adv 60th 第六十（个） ☞Look at the examples at sixth. 参看sixth的示例。

*sixty
/ˈsɪksti ||; ˈsɪkstɪ/ number
1 60 六十: Sixty people went to the meeting. 六十人参加了会议。 There are sixty pages in the book. 这本书有六十页。 He retired at sixty. 他六十岁退休。 ☞For examples of how to use numbers in sentences, look at six. 有关数词在句子里的示例，参看six。
2 the sixties [pl] the numbers, years or temperatures between 60 and 69; the 60s 介乎60至69的数目、年数或温度；60年代: I don't know the exact number of members, but it's in the sixties. 我不知道成员的确切数目，只知道有六十多人。 The most famous pop group of the sixties was The Beatles. 六十年代最受欢迎的流行乐队是披头士。 The temperature tomorrow will be in the high sixties. 明天的气温会有六十七、八度。
in your sixties between the age of 60 and 69 60至69岁: I'm not sure how old she is but I should think she's in her sixties. 我不敢肯定她多大岁数，大概六十多岁吧。 in your early/mid/late sixties 六十一、二岁；六十五岁左右；六十七、八岁 ☞For more information about numbers in dates, measurements, prices, etc, look at the special section on numbers at the back of this dictionary. 有关日期、度量衡、价格等数字的详细用法，参看本词典末数词用法部份。

*size¹
/saɪz ||; saɪz/noun
1 [U] how big or small sth is 大小；尺寸: I was surprised at the size of the hotel. It was enormous! 那家酒店大得令我吃惊。实在太大了！ The planet Uranus is about four times the size of (= as big as) Earth. 天王星的体积是地球的四倍左右。 ☞When we ask about the size of something, we usually say, ‘How big...? ’ How big is your house? We say, ‘What size...?’ when we ask about the size of something that is produced in a number of fixed measurements What size shoes do you take ? What size are you? (= when buying clothes) 问对象有多大通常说How big...?：How big is your house?你的房子有多大？询问有关固定的尺码就说What size...?：What size shoes do you take?你穿什么尺码的鞋子？买衣服时会问：What size are you?你穿多大尺码的？
2 [C] one of a number of fixed measurements in which sth is made （固定的）尺码，尺寸: Have you got this dress in a bigger size? 这款连衣裙有大一点的尺码吗？ I'm a size 12. 我穿12号。 What size pizza would you like? Medium or large? 你要多大的意大利馅饼？中号还是大号的？
3 -sized(also -size) (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) of the size mentioned …大小或尺码的: a medium-sized flat 中等大小的公寓 a king-size bed 特大号床
size²
/saɪz ||; saɪz/verb size sb/sth up to form an opinion or judgement about sb/sth 品评；判断；估计

sizeable
/ˈsaɪzəbl ||; ˈsaɪzəbḷ/ (also sizable) adj quite large 相当大的: a sizeable sum of money 一大笔钱

sizzle
/ˈsɪzl ||; ˈsɪzḷ/verb [I] to make the sound of food frying in hot fat 发出煎炸食物的嘶嘶声

skate¹
/skeɪt ||; sket/noun[C]
1 (also ice skate) a boot with a thin sharp metal part on the bottom that is used for moving on ice 溜冰鞋
2 =ROLLER SKATE
3 a large flat sea fish that can be eaten 鳐；灰鳐
skate²
/skeɪt ||; sket/verb[I]
1 (also ice-skate) to move on ice wearing special boots (ice skates) 滑冰；溜冰: Can you skate? 你会溜冰吗？ They skated across the frozen lake. 他们溜过封冻的湖面。 Go skating is a common way of talking about skating for pleasure. 玩溜冰通常叫做go skating。
2 =ROLLER SKATE ➔skater noun [C]

skateboard
/ˈskeɪtbɔ:d ||; ˈsketˌbɔrd/noun [C] a short narrow board with small wheels at each end that you can stand on and ride as a sport 滑板 ☞picture at skate 见skate插图 ➔skateboarding noun [U]: When we were children we used to go skateboarding in the park. 我们小时候经常去公园玩滑板。

skating
/ˈskeɪtɪŋ ||; ˈsketɪŋ/noun[U]
1 (also ice skating) the activity or sport of moving on ice wearing special boots 溜冰，滑冰（运动）: Would you like to go skating this weekend? 这个周末你想去溜冰吗？
2 =ROLLER SKATING

ˈskating rink
(also ice rinkrink) noun [C] a large area of ice, or a building containing a large area of ice, that is used for skating on 滑冰场；溜冰场

*skeleton¹
/ˈskelɪtn ||; ˈskɛlətṇ/noun [C] the structure formed by all the bones in a human or animal body 骨骼: the human skeleton 人的骨骼 a dinosaur skeleton 恐龙骨架
skeleton²
/ˈskelɪtn ||; ˈskɛlətṇ/adj (used about an organization, a service, etc) having the smallest number of people that is necessary for it to operate （指机构、服务等）人员数目只够维持最基本运作的

ˈskeleton key
noun [C] a key that will open several different locks 万能钥匙

skeptic, skeptical, skepticism
(US 美) =SCEPTIC, SCEPTICAL, SCEPTICISM

sketch
/sketʃ ||; skɛtʃ/noun[C]
1 a simple, quick drawing without many details 草图；速写；素描: He drew a rough sketch of the new building on the back of an envelope. 他在信封背面画了新大厦的略图。
2 a short funny scene on television, in the theatre, etc （电视、戏剧等的）幽默短剧，小品: The drama group did a sketch about a couple buying a new house. 剧团演了一出一对夫妻买新房的小品。
3 a short description without any details 简述；速写 sketch verb [I,T] I sat on the grass and sketched the castle. 我坐在草地上画城堡的素描。

sketchbook
/ˈsketʃbʊk ||; ˈskɛtʃˌbuk/ (also sketch pad) noun [C] a book of sheets of paper for drawing on 素描簿；速写册；写生本

sketchy
/ˈsketʃi ||; ˈskɛtʃɪ/adj not having many or enough details 简略的；概要的

skew
/skju: ||; skju/verb [T] to change or influence sth with the result that it is not accurate, fair, normal, etc 歪曲；曲解；影响…的准确性: to skew the statistics 影响统计数据的准确性

skewer
/ˈskju:ə(r) ||; ˈskjuɚ/noun [C] a long thin pointed piece of metal or wood that is pushed through pieces of meat, vegetables, etc to hold them together while they are cooking （烹饪时用于串肉、蔬菜等的）扦子 skewer verb [T]

ski¹
/ski: ||; ski/verb [I] (present participle skiing;past tense past participle skied) to move over snow on skis 滑雪: When did you learn to ski? 你什么时候学会滑雪的？ They go skiing every year. 他们每年都去滑雪。 ski adj a ski resort/instructor/slope/suit 滑雪胜地╱教练╱山坡╱衣 ➔skiing noun [U]: alpine/downhill/cross-country skiing 高山╱下坡╱越野滑雪
ski²
/ski: ||; ski/noun [C] one of a pair of long, flat, narrow pieces of wood or plastic that are fastened to boots and used for sliding over snow 滑雪板: a pair of skis 一副滑雪板 ☞picture on page 1085 见1085页插图

skid
/skɪd ||; skɪd/verb [I] (skidding;skidded) (usually used about a vehicle) to suddenly slide forwards or sideways without any control （通常指车辆）失控滑向路边或一侧，打滑: I skidded on a patch of ice and hit a tree. 我的车子在结冰的地上滑向一侧，撞在一棵树上。 skid noun [C]: The car went into a skid and came off the road. 汽车失控滑到路旁。

ˌskid ˈrow
noun [U] (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) used to describe the poorest part of a town, often where homeless people, alcoholics and drug users live ﹙城市中流浪者、酒鬼、吸毒者等聚居的﹚贫民区，陋巷: to be on skid row 住在贫民区

skier
/ˈski:ə(r) ||; ˈskiɚ/noun [C] a person who skis 滑雪者: Mina's a good skier. 米纳滑雪技术高超。

ˈski jump
noun [C] a very steep artificial slope that ends suddenly and that is covered with snow. People ski down the slope, jump off the end and see how far they can travel through the air before landing. 跳台滑雪滑坡 ➔ˈski-jumper noun [C] ➔ˈski-jumping noun [U]: Is ski-jumping an Olympic sport? 跳台滑雪是不是奥运会项目？ the Canadian ski-jumping team 加拿大跳台滑雪队

*skilful
/ˈskɪlfl ||; ˈskɪlfəl/ (US 美 skillful) adj
1 (used about a person) very good at doing sth （指人）擅长做某事的: a skilful painter/politician 熟练的画家；干练的政治家 He's very skilful with his hands. 他的双手很灵巧。
2 done very well 做得好的: skilful guitar playing 巧妙的吉他弹奏 ➔skilfully /-fəli ||; -fəlɪ/ adv

ˈski lift
noun [C] a machine for taking skiers up a slope so that they can then ski down ﹙运送滑雪者上坡的﹚上山吊椅

*skill
/skɪl ||; skɪl/noun
1 [U] the ability to do sth well, especially because of training, practice, etc 技艺；技巧；技术: It takes great skill to make such beautiful jewellery. 要手艺精湛才能制造出这样漂亮的首饰。 This is an easy game to play. No skill is required. 这个游戏很简单，不需要什么技巧。
2 [C] an ability that you need in order to do a job, an activity, etc well 办事能力；（工作）技能，技术: The course will help you to develop your reading and listening skills. 这个课程有助于培养阅读和听的能力。 management skills 管理技术 Typing is a skill I have never mastered. 我从未掌握打字这门技能。

skilled
/skɪld ||; skɪld/adj
1 (used about a person) having skill; skilful （指人）有技术的，熟练的: a skilled worker 技术工人
2 (used about work, a job etc) needing skill or skills; done by people who have been trained （指工作等）需要技能或专业技术的: a highly skilled job 要求高超技术的工作 Skilled work is difficult to find in this area. 在这个地区很难找到技术工作。 [OPP] unskilled 反义词为unskilled

skillet
/ˈskɪlɪt ||; ˈskɪlɪt/ (US 美) =FRYING PAN

skim
/skɪm ||; skɪm/verb (skimming;skimmed)
1 [T] skim sth (off/from sth) to remove sth from the surface of a liquid 撇去（从液体表面去掉某物）: to skim the cream off the milk 撇去牛奶表层的油脂
2 [I,T] to move quickly over or past sth, almost touching it or touching it slightly 掠过表面 · The plane flew very low, skimming the tops of the buildings. 飞机飞得很低，在建筑物的顶部掠过。
3 [I,T] skim (through/over) sth to read sth quickly in order to get the main idea, without paying attention to the details and without reading every word 浏览；略读；翻阅: I usually just skim through the newspaper in the morning. 我早上通常只翻阅一下报纸。

ˈski mask
noun [C] a type of hat made of wool that covers most of the head, neck and face 滑雪帽: The two attackers were wearing ski masks. 两名袭击者戴着滑雪帽。
