ˌskimmed ˈmilk
noun [U] milk from which the cream has been removed 脱脂奶

skimp
/skɪmp ||; skɪmp/verb [I] skimp (on sth) to use or provide less of sth than is necessary 吝啬；节省

skimpy
/ˈskɪmpi ||; ˈskɪmpɪ/adj using or having less than is necessary; too small or few 不足的；不够的

*skin¹
/skɪn ||; skɪn/noun[C,U]
1 the natural outer covering of a human or animal body 皮肤；皮 [C,U] to have (a) fair/dark/sensitive skin 皮肤白皙╱黝黑╱敏感: skin cancer 皮肤癌
2 -skinned (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) having the type of skin mentioned 有…皮肤的: My sister's very dark-skinned. 我妹妹的皮肤很黑。
3 (often in compounds 常用于构成复合词) the skin of a dead animal, with or without its fur, used for making things （动物的）皮，毛皮（常用来制造物品）: a sheepskin jacket 羊皮袄 a bag made of crocodile skin 鳄鱼皮手提包
4 the natural outer covering of some fruits or vegetables; the outer covering of a sausage 某些水果和蔬菜的外皮；香肠的外皮: (a) banana/tomato skin 香蕉╱蕃茄皮 ☞Look at the note at rind. 参看rind的注释。 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图
5 the thin solid surface that can form on a liquid 凝结于液体表面的薄层: A skin had formed on top of the milk. 牛奶表面结了一层皮。
by the skin of your teeth(informal 非正式) (used to show that sb almost failed to do sth) only just 仅仅，刚好，勉强（做得到）: I ran into the airport and caught the plane by the skin of my teeth. 我跑进机场，刚好赶得及登上飞机。 have a thick skin→THICK¹ skin-deep (used about a feeling or an attitude) not as important or as strongly felt as it appears to be; superficial （指感受或态度）肤浅的，表面的: I knew his concern about me was only skin-deep. 我知道他对我的关心只是表面的。
skin²
/skɪn ||; skɪn/verb [T] (skinning;skinned) to remove the skin from sth 剥去表皮或毛皮 keep your eyes peeled/skinned (for sb/sth)→EYE¹

skinflint
/ˈskɪnflɪnt ||; ˈskɪnˌflɪnt/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who does not like spending money 吝啬鬼；铁公鸡 [SYN]miser 同义词为 miser

skinhead
/ˈskɪnhed ||; ˈskɪnˌhɛd/noun [C] a young person with shaved or extremely short hair 剃光头或留平头的年轻人；光头仔

skinny
/ˈskɪni ||; ˈskɪnɪ/adj (used about a person) too thin （指人）瘦削的，皮包骨的 ☞Look at the note at thin. 参看thin的注释。

ˈskinny-dipping
noun [U] (informal 非正式) swimming without any clothes on 裸泳

skint
/skɪnt ||; skɪnt/adj (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) having no money 无钱的；一文不名的

ˌskinˈtight
adj (used about a piece of clothing) fitting very tightly and showing the shape of the body （指衣物）紧身的

skip¹
/skɪp ||; skɪp/verb (skipping;skipped)
1 [I] to move along quickly and lightly in a way that is similar to dancing, with little jumps and steps, from one foot to the other 轻快地跳；蹦跳: A little girl came skipping along the road. 一个小女孩沿路蹦蹦跳跳地走来。 Lambs were skipping about in the field. 小羊在田野四处蹦蹦跳跳。
2 [I] to jump over a rope that you or two other people hold at each end, turning it round and round over the head and under the feet 跳绳: Some girls were skipping in the playground. 几个女孩子在操场上跳绳。
3 [T] to not do sth that you usually do or should do 不做常做或该做的事；略过: I got up rather late, so I skipped breakfast. 我起床太晚，所以没吃早餐。
4 [T] to miss the next thing that you would normally read, do, etc 跳过，漏掉（通常会看、做等的部份）: I accidentally skipped one of the questions in the test. 我在测验中不小心漏做一道题。
skip²
/skɪp ||; skɪp/noun[C]
1 a small jumping movement 跳跃
2 a large, open metal container for rubbish, often used during building work 大型金属容器（常用以放置建筑废料）

skipper
/ˈskɪpə(r) ||; ˈskɪpɚ/noun [C] (informal 非正式) the captain of a boat or ship, or of a sports team 船长；运动队队长

ˈskipping rope
noun [C] a rope, often with handles at each end, that you turn over your head and then jump over, for fun or for exercise 跳绳用的绳子

skirmish
/ˈskɜ:mɪʃ ||; ˈskɝmɪʃ/noun [C] a short fight between groups of people 小战役；小冲突

*skirt¹
/skɜ:t ||; skɝt/noun[C]
1 a piece of clothing that is worn by women and girls and that hangs down from the waist 裙子 ☞Look at culottes. 参看culottes。
2 an outer covering or protective part for the base of a vehicle or machine （车辆或机器底部的）围裙，挡板: the rubber skirt around the bottom of a hovercraft 气垫船底部四周的胶围裙 ☞picture at boat 见boat插图
skirt²
/skɜ:t ||; skɝt/verb [I,T] to go around the edge of sth 沿边缘走 skirt round sth to avoid talking about sth in a direct way 避免直接谈及某事: The manager skirted round the subject of our pay increase. 经理避而不谈加薪的事。

skirting board
/ˈskɜ:tɪŋ bɔ:d ||; ˈskɝtɪŋ ˌbɔrd/ (also skirting) (US 美 baseboard) noun [C,U] a narrow piece of wood that is fixed along the bottom of the walls in a house （房屋墙脚上的）护墙板，壁脚板

skittish
/ˈskɪtɪʃ ||; ˈskɪtɪʃ/adj
1 (used about horses) easily excited or frightened and therefore difficult to control ﹙马﹚易惊而难以驾驭的
2 (used about people) not very serious and with ideas and feelings that keep changing ﹙人﹚轻浮的，易变的，反复无常的
3 likely to change suddenly 说变就变的；变幻莫测的: skittish financial markets 变幻莫测的金融市场 skittish investors/traders说变就变的投资者/交易人

skittles
/ˈskɪtlz ||; ˈskɪtḷz/noun [U] a game in which players try to knock down as many bottle-shaped objects (skittles) as possible by throwing or rolling a ball at them 撞柱游戏，九柱游戏（一种游戏，玩者用球击倒尽可能多的瓶状小木柱）

skive
/skaɪv ||; skaɪv/verb [I] (Brit 英) (informal 非正式)skive (off) to not work when you should 擅离职守；无故缺勤

skulk
/skʌlk ||; skʌlk/verb [I] to stay somewhere quietly and secretly, hoping that nobody will notice you, especially because you are planning to do sth bad 潜藏，行踪隐秘（尤指为准备做坏事）

*skull
/skʌl ||; skʌl/noun [C] the bone structure of a human or animal head 头骨；颅骨: She suffered a fractured skull in the fall. 她摔了一跤，造成颅骨破裂。 ☞picture at body 见body插图

skullcap
/ˈskʌlkæp ||; ˈskʌlˌkæp/noun [C] a small round cap without a peak¹(3) worn on top of the head, especially by male Jews and Catholic bishops 无檐便帽﹙尤为犹太男子或天主教主教所戴﹚

*sky
/skaɪ ||; skaɪ/noun [C] [usu.sing] [U] (plural skies) the space that you can see when you look up from the earth, and where you can see the sun, moon and stars 天；天空: a cloudless/clear blue sky 万里无云╱晴朗的蓝天 I saw a bit of blue sky between the clouds. 我看到云缝间一小片蓝天。 I saw a plane high up in the sky. 我看见高空有一架飞机。

ˌsky-ˈblue
adj bright blue in colour, like the sky on a clear day 天蓝色的；蔚蓝色的 ➔ˌsky ˈblue noun [U]

skycap
/ˈskaɪkæp ||; ˈskaɪˌkæp/noun [C] (US 美) a person whose job is to carry people's bags at an airport 机场行李工

skydiving
/ˈskaɪdaɪvɪŋ ||; ˈskaɪˌdaɪvɪŋ/noun [U] a sport in which you jump from a plane and fall for as long as you safely can before opening your parachute 特技跳伞运动: to go skydiving 进行特技跳伞 ➔skydiver noun [C]

ˌsky-ˈhigh
adj adv very high 非常高

skyjack
/ˈskaɪdʒæk ||; ˈskaɪˌdʒæk/verb [T] to use violence or threats to take control of an aircraft, in order to force it to travel to a different place or to demand sth from a government 劫持﹙飞机﹚ [SYN]hijack 同义词为 hijack ➔skyjacker noun [C] ➔sky-jacking noun [U]

skyline
/ˈskaɪlaɪn ||; ˈskaɪˌlaɪn/noun [C] the shape that is made by tall buildings, etc against the sky 高楼等以天空为背景衬托出的轮廓: the Manhattan skyline 曼哈顿的空中轮廓线

skyscraper
/ˈskaɪskreɪpə(r) ||; ˈskaɪˌskrepɚ/noun [C] an extremely tall building 摩天大楼

skywards
/ˈskaɪwədz ||; ˈskaɪwɚdz/ (also skyward) adv toward the sky 向天空；朝天空: We all turned our gazes skywards. 我们都朝天空中看。

slab
/slæb ||; slæb/noun [C] a thick, flat piece of sth 厚片；厚板: huge concrete slabs 巨大的混凝土板 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

slack
/slæk ||; slæk/adj
1 loose; not tightly stretched 松弛的: Leave the rope slack. 让绳子放松着。
2 (used about a period of business) not busy; not having many customers （指某段时期的业务）萧条的，清淡的: Trade is very slack here in winter. 这里冬天生意很清淡。
3 not carefully or properly done 疏忽的；处理失当的: Slack security made terrorist attacks possible. 警恒松懈使恐怖分子有机可乘，发动袭击。
4 (used about a person) not doing your work carefully or properly （指人）玩忽职守的，粗心的，马虎的: You've been rather slack about your homework lately. 最近你的家庭作业做得很马虎。

slacken
/ˈslækən ||; ˈslækən/verb[I,T]
1 to become or make sth less tight （使）松弛: The rope slackened and he pulled his hand free. 绳子松了，他将手挣脱出来。
2 slacken (sth) (off) to become or make sth slower or less active （使）变得迟缓，减弱 · He slackened off his pace towards the end of the race. 快到赛跑终点的时候，他的脚步放慢了。

slacks
/slæks ||; slæks/noun [pl] trousers (especially not very formal ones) 宽松长裤: a pair of slacks 一条宽松长裤

slag¹
/slæg ||; slæg/verb slag sb off(informal 非正式) to say cruel or critical things about sb 辱骂；责难
slag²
/slæg ||; slæg/noun [U] the waste material that is left after metal has been removed from rock 熔渣；矿渣

ˈslag heap
noun [C] a hill made of slag 溶渣堆；矿渣堆

slain
past participle ofSLAY

slalom
/ˈslɑ:ləm ||; ˈslɑləm/noun [C] (in skiing, canoeing, etc) a race along a course on which competitors have to move from side to side between poles （滑雪、独木舟等）之字形弯道比赛，障碍滑雪赛，弯道回转赛

slam
/slæm ||; slæm/verb (slamming;slammed)
1 [I,T] to shut or make sth shut very loudly and with great force 砰然关上: I heard the front door slam. 我听见前门砰地一声关上了。 She slammed her book shut and rushed out of the room. 她猛然合上书，跑出了房间。
2 [T] to put sth somewhere very quickly and with great force 砰然放下；用力摔下: He slammed the book down on the table and stormed out. 他将书摔在桌上，冲了出去。 ☞Look at grand slam. 参看grand slam。

slander
/ˈslɑ:ndə(r); US ˈslæn- ||; ˈslændɚ/noun [C,U] a spoken statement about sb that is not true and that is intended to damage the good opinion that other people have of him/her; the legal offence of making this kind of statement 诽谤；诋毁 slander verb [T] ➔slanderous /-dərəs ||; -dərəs/ adj

*slang
/slæŋ ||; slæŋ/noun [U] very informal words and expressions that are more common in spoken language. Slang is sometimes used only by a particular group of people (for example students, young people, criminals) and often stays in fashion for a short time. Some slang is not polite. 俚语: ‘Fag’ is slang for ‘cigarette’ in British English. fag在英国英语里是俚语，指香烟。

slant¹
/slɑ:nt; US slænt ||; slænt/verb
1 [I] to be at an angle, not vertical or horizontal 倾斜；歪: My handwriting slants backwards. 我的字体向后倾斜。 That picture isn't straight -- it's slanting to the right. 那幅画没有挂正，向右歪了。
2 [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to describe information, events, etc in a way that supports a particular group or opinion 带有倾向性地描述 ➔slanting adj She has beautiful slanting eyes. 她有一双漂亮的丹凤眼。
slant²
/slɑ:nt ||; slænt/noun
1 [sing] a position at an angle, not horizontal or vertical 倾斜（的位置）: The sunlight fell on the table at a slant. 阳光斜照在餐桌上。
2 [C] a way of thinking, writing, etc about sth, that sees things from a particular point of view 观点

slap¹
/slæp ||; slæp/verb [T] (slapping;slapped)
1 to hit sb/sth with the inside of your hand when it is flat 掌掴；拍: She slapped him across the face. 她掴了他一记耳光。 People slapped him on the back and congratulated him on winning. 人们拍他的背，祝贺他赢得胜利。 ☞picture on page S19 见S19页插图
2 to put sth onto a surface quickly and carelessly 啪的一声放下 slap noun [C]: I gave him a slap across the face. 我掴了他一记耳光。
slap²
/slæp ||; slæp/ (also ˌslap ˈbang) adv (informal 非正式) used to show that sth happens accidentally at a bad time or place （表示某事无意中发生在不合适的时间或地点）: I hurried round the corner and walked slap into someone coming the other way. 我匆匆绕过角落，撞到了迎面而来的人。

slapdash
/ˈslæpdæʃ ||; ˈslæpˌdæʃ/adj careless, or done quickly and carelessly 马虎的；草率的；草草完成的: slapdash building methods 马虎的建筑方法 He's a bit slapdash about doing his homework on time. 他时间快到才草草做家庭作业。

ˌslap-happy
/ˌslæpˈhæpi ||; ˈslæpˌhæpɪ/adj (informal 非正式)
1 cheerful, but careless about things that should be taken seriously 快乐而随便的；大大咧咧的: a slap-happy approach to life 大大咧咧的生活态度
2 unable to think clearly; in a confused state 思维混乱的；胡涂的

slapstick
/ˈslæpstɪk ||; ˈslæpˌstɪk/noun [U] a type of humour that is based on simple physical jokes, for example people falling over or hitting each other 打闹剧

ˈslap-up
adj (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) (used about a meal) very large and very good （指饭菜）非常丰盛美味的

slash¹
/slæʃ ||; slæʃ/verb
1 [I,T] slash (at) sb/sth to make or try to make a long cut in sth with a violent movement 砍；割
2 [T] to reduce an amount of money, etc very much 大幅度削减（价钱等）: The price of coffee has been slashed by 20%. 咖啡的价格跌了约两成。
slash²
/slæʃ ||; slæʃ/noun[C]
1 a sharp movement made with a knife, etc in order to cut sb/sth （刀等的）砍，劈
2 a long narrow wound or cut （狭长的）伤口，刀伤
3 (brit also 英亦作 oblique) the symbol (/) used to show ALTERNATIVES(= various possibilities), for example ‘lunch and/or dinner’, and also to write FRACTIONS, as in ‘1/6’ 斜线号（╱）（用于表示供选择的事物，如lunch and／or dinner，也用于写分数，如在 1/6） ☞Look at backslash. 参看backslash。

ˌslash-and-ˈburn
adj
1 relating to a method of farming in which existing plants, crops etc are cut down and burned before new seeds are sown 刀耕火种的: slash-and-burn agriculture 刀耕火种农业
2 aggressive and causing a lot of harm or damage 攻击性强的；造成很大危害的: a slash-and-burn takeover 对公司造成很大损害的收购

slat
/slæt ||; slæt/noun [C] one of a series of long, narrow pieces of wood, metal or plastic, used in furniture, fences etc （家具、篱笆等的）长而窄的木头、金属或塑料板条

slate
/sleɪt ||; slet/noun
1 [U] a type of dark grey rock that can easily be split into thin flat pieces 板岩；石板；黏皮岩
2 [C] one of the thin flat pieces of slate that are used for covering roofs 石板瓦片

slather
/ˈslæɝə(r) ||; ˈslæɒɚ/verb [T] to cover sth/sb with a thick layer of a substance 在…上厚厚涂抹: hot dogs slathered with mustard 抹了厚厚一层芥末的热狗 She slathered on plenty of sunblock. 她抹上了一层厚厚的防晒霜。

slaughter
/ˈslɔ:tə(r) ||; ˈslɔtɚ/verb[T]
1 to kill an animal, usually for food 屠宰
2 to kill a large number of people at one time, especially in a cruel way 杀戮；屠杀: Men, women and children were slaughtered and whole villages destroyed. 男女老幼都被屠杀，一整个一整个的村子都被毁了。 ☞Look at the note at kill. 参看kill的注释。 slaughter noun [U]

slaughterhouse
/ˈslɔ:təhaʊs ||; ˈslɔtɚˌhaυs/ (also abattoir) noun [C] a place where animals are killed for food 屠宰场

slave¹
/sleɪv ||; slev/noun [C] (in past times) a person who was owned by another person and had to work for him/her （旧时）奴隶 ➔slavery noun [U]: the abolition of slavery in America 美国奴隶制度的废除
slave²
/sleɪv ||; slev/verb [I] slave (away) to work very hard 刻苦工作；苦干

ˈslave-driver
noun [C] a person who makes people work extremely hard 残酷的监工；逼迫他人拚命干活的人: My boss is a real slave-driver. 我的老板真会逼人拚命干活。

slave labour ( US 美 ˌslave labor)
noun [U]
1 work that is done by slaves; the slaves who do the work 奴隶劳动；干苦役的奴隶: Huge palaces were built by slave labour. 宏伟的宫殿是奴隶建造的。
2 (informal 非正式) work that is very hard and very badly paid 繁重而报酬很低的工作: I left because the job was just slave labour. 我之所以离开是因为那工作简直就是奴隶干的。

slavish
/ˈsleɪvɪʃ ||; ˈslevɪʃ/adj following or copying sb/sth exactly without having any original thought at all 无创造性的；盲从的；照搬的: slavish devotion/obedience 盲目的奉献/服从 a slavish imitation of Hitchcock's films 希区考克影片的盲目仿照

slay
/sleɪ ||; sle/verb [T] (past tense slew /slu: ||; slu/ past participle slain /sleɪn ||; slen/) (old-fashioned 旧) to kill violently; to murder 残杀；谋害

sleaze
/sli:z ||; sliz/noun [U] behaviour or conditions that are unpleasant and not socially acceptable, especially because sex is involved 堕落；污秽；乌烟瘴气: the sleaze of a town that was once a naval base 曾经是海军基地的小城里充满乌烟瘴气的社会氛围

sleazeball
/ˈsli:zbɔ:l ||; ˈslizˌbɔl/ (also sleazebag /ˈsli:zbæg ||; ˈslizˌbæg/) noun [C] (especially US, slang 尤为美，俚语) a dishonest or immoral person 卑鄙的人；下流坯

sleazy
/ˈsli:zi ||; ˈslizɪ/adj (used about a place or a person) unpleasant and probably connected with immoral activities （指地方或人）令人不快的，可能与犯罪活动有关的: a sleazy nightclub 藏污纳垢的夜总会

sledge
/sledʒ ||; slɛdʒ/ (US also 美亦作 sled /sled ||; slɛd/) noun [C] a vehicle without wheels that is used for travelling on snow. Large sledges are often pulled by dogs, and smaller ones are used for going down hills, for fun or as a sport 雪橇 ☞Look at bobsleigh and toboggan. 参看bobsleigh及toboggan。 ☞picture at sleigh 见sleigh插图 sledge verb [I]

sledgehammer
/ˈsledʒhæmə(r) ||; ˈslɛdʒˌhæmɚ/noun [C] a large heavy hammer with a long handle 大锤

sleek
/sli:k ||; slik/adj
1 (used about hair or fur) smooth and shiny because it is healthy （指毛发或毛皮）柔顺亮泽的，光滑的
2 (used about a vehicle) having an elegant, smooth shape （指车辆）造型优美的: a sleek new sports car 造型优美的新跑车

*sleep¹
/sli:p ||; slip/noun
1 [U] the natural condition of rest when your eyes are closed and your mind and body are not active or conscious 睡觉；睡眠: Most people need at least seven hours' sleep every night. 大多数人每晚至少需要睡七个小时。 I didn't get much sleep last night. 昨天晚上我没睡多久。 Do you ever talk in your sleep? 你睡觉时说梦话吗？ I couldn't get to sleep last night. 昨晚我睡不着。
2 [sing] a period of sleep 睡眠时间: You'll feel better after a good night's sleep. 你好好睡一觉就会觉得好些。 I sometimes have a short sleep in the afternoon. 我有时候在下午睡一会儿。
go to sleep
1 to start sleeping 入睡: He got into bed and soon went to sleep. 他上床不久便睡着了。
2 (used about an arm, a leg, etc) to lose the sense of feeling in it （指手臂、腿等）麻木
put (an animal) to sleep to kill an animal that is ill or injured because you want to stop it suffering 杀死动物（因动物生病或受伤，免其受折磨）
*sleep²
/sli:p ||; slip/verb (past tense past participle slept /slept ||; slɛpt/)
1 [I] to rest with your eyes closed and your mind and body not active 睡；睡觉: Did you sleep well? 你睡得好吗？ I only slept for a couple of hours last night. 昨天晚上我只睡了几个小时。 I slept solidly from 10 last night till 11 this morning. 我从昨晚10点钟一直睡到今天上午11点钟。 ☞ Asleep is usually used to describe sb who is sleeping The baby's asleep. Go to sleep is the verb we use to mean ‘start to sleep’ I was reading in bed last night, and I didn't go to sleep until about one o'clock. asleep通常指处于睡眠状态：The baby's asleep.婴儿睡着了。go to sleep指入睡：I was reading in bed last night, and I didn't go to sleep until about one o'clock.我昨晚躺在床上看书，到一点钟左右才入睡。
2 [T] (used about a place) to have enough beds for a particular number of people （指地方）可供（某数量的人）住宿
sleep/live rough→ROUGH³ sleep in to sleep until later than usual in the morning because you do not have to get up 睡懒觉 ☞Compare oversleep. 与oversleep比较。 sleep together; sleep with sb to have sex with sb (usually when you are not married to or living with that person) 与某人性交（通常指没有与对方结婚或同居的）

sleeper
/ˈsli:pə(r) ||; ˈslipɚ/noun[C]
1 (with an adjective 与形容词连用) a person who sleeps in a particular way. If you are a light sleeper you wake up easily. 某种方式之睡眠者（light sleeper为容易醒来的浅睡者）: a light/heavy sleeper 浅睡╱熟睡者
2 a bed on a train; a train with beds 火车的卧铺；卧车

ˈsleeping bag
noun [C] a large soft bag that you use for sleeping in when you go camping, etc 睡袋（野外露营用）

ˈsleeping car
(also sleeper) a railway CARRIAGE(= part of a train) with beds for people to sleep in （火车的）卧铺车厢，卧车

ˈsleeping pill
noun [C] a medicine in solid form that you swallow to help you sleep 安眠药: to take a sleeping pill 服一片安眠药

ˈsleeping sickness
noun [U] a tropical disease carried by an insect(tsetse fly)that makes you want to go to sleep and usually causes death 昏睡病（一种由采采蝇传播的疾病，使人昏昏欲睡，通常致命）

sleepless
/ˈsli:pləs ||; ˈsliplɪs/adj (used about a period, usually the night) without sleep （指一段时间，通常指夜晚）失眠的 ➔sleeplessness noun [U] ☞Look at insomnia. 参看insomnia。

sleepover
/ˈsli:pəʊvə(r) ||; ˈslipˌovɚ/noun [C] a party for children or young people when a group of them spend the night at one house ﹙儿童或年轻人在某人家玩乐并过夜的﹚聚会

sleepwalk
/ˈsli:pwɔ:k ||; ˈslipˌwɔk/verb [I] to walk around while you are asleep 梦游

sleepy
/ˈsli:pi ||; ˈslipɪ/adj
1 tired and ready to go to sleep 困的；昏昏欲睡的: These pills might make you feel a bit sleepy. 这些药丸可能会令你感到有点困。
2 (used about a place) very quiet and not having much activity （指地方）冷清的，不热闹的 ➔sleepily adv

sleepyhead
/ˈsli:pihed ||; ˈslipɪˌhɛd/noun [C] (informal 非正式) used to speak to sb, especially a child, who looks as if he/she is falling asleep ﹙尤用来唤似要睡着的孩子﹚贪睡者，懒鬼: Come on, sleepyhead. It's time for bed. 醒醒，小懒鬼，上床睡觉了。

sleet
/sli:t ||; slit/noun [U] a mixture of rain and snow 雨夹雪 ☞Look at the note at weather. 参看weather的注释。

*sleeve
/sli:v ||; sliv/noun[C]
1 one of the two parts of a piece of clothing that cover the arms or part of the arms 袖子: a blouse with long sleeves 一件长袖女衬衫 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图
2 -sleeved (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) with sleeves of a particular kind 有某种袖子的: a short-sleeved shirt 短袖衬衫

sleeveless
/ˈsli:vləs ||; ˈslivləs/adj without sleeves 无袖的: a sleeveless sweater 无袖毛衣

sleigh
/sleɪ ||; sle/noun [C] a vehicle without wheels that is used for travelling on snow and that is usually pulled by horses 雪橇，雪车（通常由马拉） ☞Look at bobsleigh. 参看bobsleigh。

slender
/ˈslendə(r) ||; ˈslɛndɚ/adj
1 (used about a person or part of sb's body) thin in an attractive way （指人或身体的某部份）纤细的，修长的，苗条的: long slender fingers 修长的手指
2 smaller in amount or size than you would like 微小的；不足的: My chances of winning are very slender. 我取胜的可能性极微。

slept
past tense, past participle ofSLEEP¹

slew
past tense ofSLAY

*slice¹
/slaɪs ||; slaɪs/noun[C]
1 a flat piece of food that is cut from a larger piece （从大块食物上切下的）薄片，块: a thick/thin slice of bread 厚厚／薄薄一片面包 Cut the meat into thin slices. 把这肉切成薄片。 ☞pictures at bread and cake 见bread及cake插图
2 a part of sth 一部份: The directors have taken a large slice of the profits. 董事们已取去利润的一大部份。
*slice²
/slaɪs ||; slaɪs/verb
1 [T] to cut into thin flat pieces 切片: Peel and slice the apples. 将苹果去皮切片。 a loaf of sliced bread 一条切成薄片的面包
2 [I,T] to cut sth easily with sth sharp 切开；割开: He sliced through the rope with a knife. 他用刀子切断绳子。 The glass sliced into her hand. 玻璃割破了她的手。
3 [T] (in ball sports) to hit the ball on the bottom or side so that it does not travel in a straight line （球类运动）削（球），使球侧旋

slick¹
/slɪk ||; slɪk/adj
1 done smoothly and well, and seeming to be done without any effort 熟练的；灵巧的
2 clever at persuading people but perhaps not completely honest 花言巧语的；圆滑的
slick²
/slɪk ||; slɪk/ =OIL SLICK

slicker
/ˈslɪkə(r) ||; ˈslɪkɚ/noun [C] (US 美) a long loose coat that keeps you dry in the rain ﹙长而宽松的﹚雨衣 ☞ Look at city slicker⇒. 参看 city slicker⇒。

*slide¹
/slaɪd ||; slaɪd/verb (past tense past participle slid /slɪd ||; slɪd/)
1 [I,T] to move or make sth move smoothly along a surface 滑；滑行: She fell over and slid along the ice. 她跌倒后在冰上一路滑去。 The doors slide open automatically. 那些门会自动滑开。
2 [I,T] to move or make sth move quietly without being noticed （使）悄悄移动: I slid out of the room when nobody was looking. 我在没有人看见的时候悄悄走出房间。 She slid her hand into her pocket and took out a gun. 她悄悄把手伸进衣袋里拿出一枝枪来。
3 [I] (used about prices, values, etc) to go down slowly and continuously （指价格、价值等）慢慢滑落，持续下降
4 [I] to move gradually towards a worse situation 渐渐陷入（更糟的境地）: The company slid into debt and eventually closed. 公司渐渐背了债，最后倒闭了。
*slide²
/slaɪd ||; slaɪd/noun[C]
1 a small piece of glass that you put sth on when you want to examine it under a MICROSCOPE (= a piece of equipment that makes things appear much bigger) （显微镜的）承物玻璃片 ☞picture at laboratory 见laboratory插图
2 a large toy consisting of a ladder and a long piece of metal, plastic, etc. Children climb up the ladder then slide down the other part. 滑梯 ☞picture at swing 见swing插图
3 a continuous slow fall, for example of prices, values, levels, etc （价钱、价值、水平等）滑落
4 a small piece of photographic film in a plastic or cardboard frame 幻灯片 ☞Look at transparency. 参看transparency。

ˈslide rule
noun [C] a long narrow instrument like a ruler, with a middle part that slides backwards and forwards, used for calculating numbers 计算尺；滑尺

ˌsliding ˈscale
noun [C] a system in which the rate at which sth is paid varies according to particular conditions （价格按特定情况调整的）浮动计算法，滑动基准: Fees are calculated on a sliding scale according to income (= richer people pay more). 费用按浮动计算法视收入多少来计算（收入越高，付费越多）。

*slight
/slaɪt ||; slaɪt/adj
1 very small; not important or serious 微小的；轻微的；不足道的: I've got a slight problem, but it's nothing to get worried about. 我有个小问题，但没什么值得担心。 a slight change/difference/increase/improvement 细微的改变╱差别╱增加╱改善 I haven't the slightest idea (= no idea at all) what you're talking about. 我一点也不知道你在说什么。
2 (used about a person's body) thin and light （指人的身体）纤瘦的: His slight frame is perfect for a long-distance runner. 他身材纤瘦，当长跑运动员正合适。
not in the slightest not at all 一点也不: ‘Are you angry with me?’ ‘Not in the slightest.’ “你生我的气吗？”“一点也不生气。”

*slightly
/ˈslaɪtli ||; ˈslaɪtlɪ/adv
1 a little 少许；稍微；略: I'm slightly older than her. 我的年纪比她略大一点。
2 a slightly-built person is small and thin a lightly-built person 是“一个身材瘦小的人”的意思

*slim¹
/slɪm ||; slɪm/adj (slimmer;slimmest)
1 thin in an attractive way 修长的；苗条的: a tall, slim woman 身材修长的女人 ☞Look at the note at thin. 参看thin的注释。
2 not as big as you would like 不够大的；小的: Her chances of success are very slim. 她成功的机会很渺茫。
slim²
/slɪm ||; slɪm/verb [I] (slimming;slimmed) to become or try to become thinner and lighter by eating less food, taking exercise, etc 减轻体重；减肥 ☞Look at diet. 参看diet。

slime
/slaɪm ||; slaɪm/noun [U] a thick unpleasant liquid 黏液；黏泥: The pond was covered with slime and had a horrible smell. 池塘里到处是烂泥，发出难闻的气味。

slimy
/ˈslaɪmi ||; ˈslaɪmɪ/adj
1 covered with slime 为黏液所覆盖的
2 (used about a person) pretending to be friendly, in a way that you do not trust or like （指人）虚伪的，谄媚的

sling¹
/slɪŋ ||; slɪŋ/noun [C] a piece of cloth that you put under your arm and tie around your neck to support a broken arm, wrist, etc 悬带，吊带（用以支撑断臂、腕等） ☞picture at health 见health插图
sling²
/slɪŋ ||; slɪŋ/verb [T] (past tense past participle slung)
1 to put or throw sth somewhere in a rough or careless way 扔；掷；抛
2 to put sth into a position where it hangs loosely 悬吊；挂

slingback
/ˈslɪŋbæk ||; ˈslɪŋbæk/noun [C] a woman's shoe that is open at the back with a strap around the heel （后帮成带状的）露跟女鞋

slingshot
/ˈslɪŋʃɒt ||; ˈslɪŋˌʃɑt/ (US 美) =CATAPULT¹

slink
/slɪŋk ||; slɪŋk/verb [I] (past tense past participle slunk) to move somewhere slowly and quietly because you do not want anyone to see you, often when you feel guilty or embarrassed 溜走（常因感到内疚或尴尬）

slinky
/ˈslɪŋki ||; ˈslɪŋkɪ/adj (slinkier; slinkiest)
1 (used about a woman's clothes) fitting closely to the body in a sexually attractive way ﹙女式服装﹚紧身而性感的: a slinky black dress 黑色紧身连衣裙
2 (used about movement or sound) smooth and slow, often in a way that is sexually attractive ﹙动作或声音﹚婀娜多姿的，柔媚的，柔美的: a slinky voice 柔美的嗓音

*slip¹
/slɪp ||; slɪp/verb (slipping;slipped)
1 [I] slip (over);slip (on sth) to slide accidentally and fall or nearly fall 失足；滑跤；滑倒: She slipped over on the wet floor. 她在湿地板上滑了一跤。 His foot slipped on the top step and he fell down the stairs. 他在最上面的一级楼梯滑倒，从楼梯上摔了下去。
2 [I] to slide accidentally out of the correct position or out of your hand 滑离原位；（从手中）滑脱: This hat's too big. It keeps slipping down over my eyes. 这顶帽子太大了，老是滑下来遮住我的眼睛。 The glass slipped out of my hand and smashed on the floor. 玻璃杯从我手中滑脱，掉在地板上摔碎了。
3 [I] to move or go somewhere quietly, quickly, and often without being noticed 悄悄溜走: While everyone was dancing we slipped away and went home. 大家在跳舞的时候，我们悄悄溜回家。
4 [T] slip sth (to sb);slip (sb) sth to put sth somewhere or give sth to sb quietly and often without being noticed 悄悄放置或给予: She picked up the money and slipped it into her pocket. 她拾起那些钱，悄悄放进口袋。
5 [I,T] slip into/out of sth;slip sth on/off to put on or take off a piece of clothing quickly and easily 迅速穿上╱脱去衣服: I slipped off my shoes. 我很快脱掉了鞋子。
6 [I] to fall a little in value, level, etc （价值、水平等）微跌
let sth slip→LET slip your mind to be forgotten 被遗忘: I'm sorry, the meeting completely slipped my mind. 对不起，我完全忘了开会的事。 slip out to accidentally say sth or tell sb sth 无意中讲出；泄漏: I didn't intend to tell them. It just slipped out. 我本不打算告诉他们，只是无意中说出来了。 slip up(informal 非正式) to make a mistake 犯错；疏忽
slip²
/slɪp ||; slɪp/noun[C]
1 a small mistake, usually made by being careless or not paying attention 小错误: to make a slip 犯小错误
2 a small piece of paper 小纸片: I made a note of her name on a slip of paper. 我将她的名字记在小纸片上。 (Brit 英) There seems to be a mistake on my payslip (= the piece of paper from your employer each month showing how much money you have been paid and how much tax, etc has been taken off). 我的工资单上似乎有个错误。
3 an act of sliding accidentally and falling or nearly falling 滑跤；失足
4 a thin piece of clothing that is worn by a woman under a dress or skirt 衬裙
give sb the slip(informal 非正式) to escape from sb who is following or trying to catch you 摆脱（尾随或跟踪的人） a slip of the tongue something that you say that you did not mean to say 口误；一时说错的话

slippage
/ˈslɪpɪdʒ ||; ˈslɪpɪdʒ/noun [C, usually sing, U] (written 书面语)
1 failure to achieve an aim or complete a task by a particular date 延误；逾期: The smallest slippage could delay completion of the project. 略微的拖延就可能令工程不能按时完工。
2 a slight or gradual fall in the amount, value, etc of sth ﹙微弱或逐渐的﹚下降，降低: There has been some slippage of support for the government's policies. 对政府政策的支持已有所下降。

ˌslipped ˈdisc
noun [C] a painful injury caused when one of the flat things(discs)between the bones in your back (spine)moves out of its correct position 椎间盘突出（一种伤痛，由脊椎间的椎间盘滑离正常位置造成）

slipper
/ˈslɪpə(r) ||; ˈslɪpɚ/noun [C] a light soft shoe that is worn inside the house 拖鞋；便鞋: a pair of slippers 一双拖鞋 ☞picture at shoe 见shoe插图

slippery
/ˈslɪpəri ||; ˈslɪpərɪ/ (informal 非正式slippy) adj (used about a surface or an object) difficult to walk on or hold because it is smooth, wet, etc （指表面或物体）滑的，湿滑的: a slippery floor 湿滑的地板

ˈslip road
(US 美 ramp) noun [C] a road that leads onto or off a motorway （连接高速公路的）岔道

ˈslip-on
adj (used about a shoe) that you can slide your feet into without having to tie laces ﹙鞋子﹚无须系带的: slip-on shoes 无带便鞋 ➔ˈslip-on noun [C]: a pair of slip-ons 一双无带便鞋

slipshod
/ˈslɪpʃɒd ||; ˈslɪpˌʃɑd/adj done without care; doing things without care 马虎的；敷衍了事的: The work was done in a slipshod manner. 工作做得粗糙马虎。 [SYN]careless 同义词为 careless

ˈslip-up
noun [C] (informal 非正式) a careless mistake 疏漏；差错: We cannot afford another slip-up like this one. 像这样的差错我们再犯不得了。

slipway
/ˈslɪpweɪ ||; ˈslɪpˌwe/noun [C] a track leading down to water, on which ships are built or pulled up out of the water for repairs, or from which they are LAUNCHED(= put into the water) 船台；（船被拖上岸修理或下水的）滑道

slit¹
/slɪt ||; slɪt/noun [C] a long narrow cut or opening 狭长的切口或开口；缝隙: a long skirt with a slit up the back 一条后面有叉口的长裙
slit²
/slɪt ||; slɪt/verb [T] (slitting;past tense past participle slit) to make a long narrow cut in sth 在…上开一道狭长的口子；切开；划开: She slit the envelope open with a knife. 她用刀子裁开信封。

slither
/ˈslɪðə(r) ||; ˈslɪðɚ/verb [I] to move by sliding from side to side along the ground like a snake （像蛇一样）蜿蜒滑行: I saw a snake slithering down a rock. 我看见一条蛇从岩石上滑行而下。

sliver
/ˈslɪvə(r) ||; ˈslɪvɚ/noun [C] a small or thin piece of sth that is cut or broken off from a larger piece 小块；薄片: slivers of glass/wood 玻璃碎片；木屑 (figurative 比喻) A sliver of light showed under the door. 门底下现出一丝亮光。

slob
/slɒb ||; slɑb/noun [C] (informal 非正式) (used as an insult) a very lazy or untidy person （侮辱话）懒虫，邋遢鬼

slog¹
/slɒg ||; slɑg/verb [I] (slogging;slogged)
1 (informal 非正式)slog (away) (at sth);slog (through sth) to work hard for a long period at sth difficult or boring 长时间做困难或枯燥的工作: I've been slogging away at this homework for hours. 我吃力地做这家庭作业已经好几个小时了。
2 slog down, up, along, etc to walk or move in a certain direction with a lot of effort 顽强艰苦地沿某方向前进
slog²
/slɒg ||; slɑg/noun [sing] a period of long, hard, boring work or a long, tiring journey 艰苦的工作或旅程

slogan
/ˈsləʊgən ||; ˈslogən/noun [C] a short phrase that is easy to remember and that is used in politics or advertising 口号；标语: Anti-government slogans had been painted all over the walls. 反政府标语涂满了墙壁。 an advertising slogan 广告口号

sloop
/slu:p ||; slup/noun [C] a small sailing ship with one MAST(= a post to support the sails) 单桅帆船

slop
/slɒp ||; slɑp/verb [I,T] (slopping;slopped) (used about a liquid) to pour over the edge of its container; to make a liquid do this （指液体）（使）溢出: He filled his glass too full and beer slopped onto the table. 他把杯倒得太满，啤酒溢到桌上去了。

*slope
/sləʊp ||; slop/noun
1 [C] a surface or piece of land that goes up or down 斜坡: The village is built on a slope. 村子建在一个斜坡上。 a steep/gentle slope 陡坡；缓坡 The best ski slopes are in the Alps. 最好的滑雪斜坡在阿尔卑斯山脉。
2 [sing] the amount that a surface is not level; the fact of not being level 斜度；坡度；倾斜 slope verb [I]: The road slopes down to the river. 这条斜坡路一直向下伸延至河边。 a sloping roof 倾斜的屋顶

sloppy
/ˈslɒpi ||; ˈslɑpɪ/adj
1 that shows lack of care, thought or effort; untidy 马虎的；草率的；不整洁的: a sloppy worker/writer/dresser 马虎的工人；草率的作家；衣着不整洁的人 a sloppy piece of work 一篇缺乏条理的作品
2 (used about clothes) not tight and without much shape （指衣服）宽松的，肥大的
3 (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) showing emotions in a silly embarrassing way 庸俗伤感的: I can't stand sloppy love songs. 我不能忍受伤感滥情的情歌。 [SYN]A more formal word is sentimental. 较正式的用语为sentimental。

slosh
/slɒʃ ||; slɑʃ/verb (informal 非正式)
1 [I] (used about a liquid) to move around noisily inside a container （指液体）在容器里晃动发出声响
2 [T] to pour or drop liquid somewhere in a careless way （把液体）泼出，溅出

sloshed
/slɒʃt ||; slɑʃt/adj (slang 俚语) drunk 喝醉的

slot¹
/slɒt ||; slɑt/noun[C]
1 a straight narrow opening in a machine, etc （机器上的）狭孔，长口，狭槽: Put your money into the slot and take the ticket. 将钱放进投币口再取出票子。 ☞picture at telephone 见telephone插图
2 a place in a list, system, organization, etc （名单、系统、组织等的）位置，职位: The single has occupied the Number One slot for the past two weeks. 该单曲在过去两周里，一直高踞排行榜第一名。
slot²
/slɒt ||; slɑt/verb [I,T] (slotting;slotted) to put sth into a particular space that is designed for it; to fit into such a space 插；插入: He slotted a tape into the VCR. 他把录像带插进录象机。 The video slotted in easily. 录像带很容易插进去。 fall/slot into place→PLACE¹

ˈslot machine
noun [C] a machine with an opening for coins that sells drinks, cigarettes, etc or on which you can play games 自动售货机；自动贩卖机；吃角子老虎

slouch
/slaʊtʃ ||; slaυtʃ/verb [I] to sit, stand or walk in a lazy way, with your head and shoulders hanging down 无精打采地坐着、站或走动

slovenly
/ˈslʌvnli ||; ˈslʌvənlɪ/adj (old-fashioned 旧) lazy, careless and untidy 懒散的；不修边幅的；邋遢的

*slow¹
/sləʊ ||; slo/adj adv
1 moving, doing sth or happening without much speed; not fast 慢的；缓慢的: The traffic is always very slow in the city centre. 市中心的车流总是很缓慢。 Haven't you finished your homework yet? You're being very slow! 你还没做完家庭作业吗？你实在太慢了！ Progress was slower than expected. 进度比预期的要缓慢。 a slow driver/walker/reader 驾车╱走路╱阅读缓慢的人 [OPP] fast 反义词为fast ☞It is possible to use slow as an adverb, but slowly is much more common. However, slow is often used in compounds slow-moving traffic. The comparative forms slower and more slowly are both common Could you drive a bit slower/more slowly, please? slow可作副词使用，但slowly远较常用。然而，slow常用于构成复合词：slow-moving traffic行车缓慢。比较级slower及more slowly同样常用：Could you drive a bit slower/more slowly, please?你可以开慢一点吗？
2 slow to do sth;slow (in/about) doing sth not doing sth immediately 迟缓；犹豫: She was rather slow to realize what was going on. 她很迟才意识到发生了什么事。 They've been rather slow in replying to my letter! 他们很迟才回我的信！
3 not quick to learn or understand 迟钝的；笨拙的: He's the slowest student in the class. 他是班上学得最慢的学生。
4 not very busy; with little action 不繁忙的；不活跃的: Business is very slow at the moment. 眼下生意很清淡。
5 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) (used about watches and clocks) showing a time that is earlier than the real time （指钟表）慢了的: That clock is five minutes slow (= it says it is 8.55 when the correct time is 9.00). 那钟慢了五分钟。 [OPP] fast 反义词为fast ➔slowness noun [U]
quick/slow on the uptake→UPTAKE
*slow²
/sləʊ ||; slo/verb [I,T] to start to move, do sth or happen at a slower speed; to cause sth to do this （使）放慢，减速: He slowed his pace a little. 他把步子放慢了一点儿。 slow (sb/sth) down/up to start to move, do sth or happen at a slower speed; to cause sb/sth to do this （使）放慢，减速: Can't you slow down a bit? You're driving much too fast. 你不能开慢一点吗？你开得太快了。 These problems have slowed up the whole process. 这些问题拖慢了整个过程。

slowdown
/ˈsləʊdaʊn ||; ˈsloˌdaun/noun[C]
1 a reduction in speed or activity 减速；减缓: a slowdown in economic growth 经济增长的减缓
2 a protest that workers make by doing their work more slowly than usual 怠工

*slowly
/ˈsləʊli ||; ˈslolɪ/adv at a slow speed; not quickly 缓慢；徐徐: He walked slowly along the street. 他沿着街道慢慢走去。

ˌslow ˈmotion
noun [U] (in a film or on television) a method of making action appear much slower than in real life （在影片或电视中）慢动作: They showed the winning goal again, this time in slow motion. 他们回放致胜的那个入球，这次用慢镜头。

ˈslow-witted
adj not able to think quickly; slow to learn or understand things 脑子反应慢的；头脑迟钝的 [OPP]quick-witted 反义词为 quick-witted

ˈslow-worm
noun [C] a small brownish animal with no legs, like a snake, that is found in Europe and Asia 慢缺肢蜥

sludge
/slʌdʒ ||; slʌdʒ/noun [U] a thick, soft unpleasant substance; mud 烂泥；淤泥

slug
/slʌg ||; slʌg/noun [C] a small black or brown animal with a soft body and no legs, that moves slowly along the ground and eats garden plants 蛞蝓；鼻涕虫 ☞picture at mollusc 见mollusc插图

sluggish
/ˈslʌgɪʃ ||; ˈslʌgɪʃ/adj moving or working more slowly than normal in a way that seems lazy 行动缓慢的；懒洋洋的

sluice
/slu:s ||; slus/ (also sluice gate) noun [C] a type of gate that you can open or close to control the flow of water out of or into a canal, etc 水闸

slum
/slʌm ||; slʌm/noun [C] an area of a city where living conditions are extremely bad, and where the buildings are dirty and have not been repaired for a long time 贫民窟；贫民区

slumber
/ˈslʌmbə(r) ||; ˈslʌmbɚ/verb [I] (old-fashioned 旧) to be deeply asleep 沉睡 ➔slumber noun [C]

ˈslumber party
noun [C] (US 美) = sleepover⇒

slump¹
/slʌmp ||; slʌmp/verb[I]
1 (used about economic activity, prices, etc) to fall suddenly and by a large amount （指经济活动、价格等）暴跌: Shares in BP slumped 33p to181p yesterday. 英国石油公司的股价昨天跌到181便士，暴跌了33便士。 The newspaper's circulation has slumped by 30%. 报纸的发行量骤减了30%。
2 to fall or sit down suddenly when your body feels heavy and weak, usually because you are tired or ill 猛然倒下或坐下（通常因身体疲累或不适）
slump²
/slʌmp ||; slʌmp/noun[C]
1 a slump (in sth) a sudden large fall in sales, prices, the value of sth, etc （销售、价格、价值等）暴跌: a slump in house prices 房屋价格暴跌
2 a period when a country's economy is doing very badly and a lot of people do not have jobs 经济不景气；经济萧条: The British car industry is in a slump. 英国汽车工业现在不景气。

slung
past tense, past participle ofSLING²

slunk
past tense, past participle ofSLINK

slur¹
/slɜ:(r) ||; slɝ/verb [T] (slurring;slurred) to pronounce words in a way that is not clear, often because you are drunk 说话含糊不清（常因醉酒）
slur²
/slɜ:(r) ||; slɝ/noun [C] a slur (on sb/sth) an unfair comment or an insult that could damage people's opinion of sb/sth 诋毁；中伤；污辱

slurp
/slɜ:p ||; slɝp/verb [I,T] (informal 非正式) to drink noisily 出声地喝；咕咚咕咚地喝

slurry
/ˈslʌri ||; ˈslɝɪ/noun [U] a thick liquid consisting of water mixed with animal waste that farmers use on their fields to make plants grow better 水粪尿（指水及动物粪便混和而成用作肥料的浆状物）

slush
/slʌʃ ||; slʌʃ/noun[U]
1 snow that has been on the ground for a time and that is now a dirty mixture of ice and water 半融化的雪；雪泥
2 (informal 非正式) films, books, feelings, etc that are considered to be silly because they are too romantic and emotional 滥情的电影、书籍、感受等 ➔slushy adj

ˈslush fund
noun [C] an amount of money that is kept to pay people illegally to do things, especially in politics 行贿基金

sly
/slaɪ ||; slaɪ/adj
1 (used about a person) acting or done in a secret or dishonest way, often intending to trick people （指人）狡诈的，阴险的 [SYN] cunning 同义词为cunning
2 (used about an action) suggesting that you know sth secret （指动作）会意的，心照不宣的: a sly smile/look 会意的微笑╱神色 ➔slyly adv

smack
/smæk ||; smæk/verb [T] to hit sb with the inside of your hand when it is flat, especially as a punishment 掴，打（尤指惩罚）: I never smack my children. 我从不掴自己的孩子。 smack noun [C]: You're going to get a smack if you don't do as I say! 如果你不照我的话办，我就掴你！ smack of sth to make you think that sb/sth has an unpleasant attitude or quality 带有令人不快的态度或质量

*small
/smɔ:l ||; smɔl/adj
1 not large in size, number, amount, etc 小的；少的: a small car/flat/town 小汽车；小公寓；小镇 a small group of people 一小群人 a small amount of money 少量金钱 That dress is too small for you. 那条连衣裙太小，你穿不下。
2 young 年轻的: He has a wife and three small children. 他有妻子和三个年幼的子女。 When I was small we lived in a big old house. 我小时候住在一所又大又旧的房子里。
3 not important or serious; slight 不重要的；不严重的；轻微的: Don't worry. It's only a small problem. 别担心，只是小问题。 ☞ Small is the most usual opposite of big or large. Little is often used with another adjective to express an emotion, as well as the idea of smallness a horrible little man a lovely little girl a nice little house. The comparative and superlative forms smaller and smallest are common, and small is often used with words like ‘ rather ’, ‘ quite ’ and ‘ very ’ My flat is smaller than yours. The village is quite small. a very small car. Little is not often used with these words and does not usually have a comparative or superlative form. small为big或large的最常用的反义词。little常和另一形容词连用以表达情感﹐同时也表示细小的意思﹕a horrible little man可怕的小个子. a lovely little girl可爱的小女孩. a nice little house很好的小房子. smaller﹙比较级﹚和smallest﹙最高级﹚也很常用。small常和rather﹑quite及very等类的词连用﹕My flat is smaller than yours.我的住所比你的小。The village is quite small.那个村庄很小。a very small car很小的汽车. little甚少和这些词连用﹐而且通常没有比较级或最高级形式。 ➔small /smɔ:l ||; smɔl/ adv She's painted the picture far too small. 她那幅画画得太小了。
in a big/small way→WAY¹

ˌsmall ˈads
noun [pl] (Brit 英) (informal 非正式)=CLASSIFIED ADVERTISEMENTS

ˈsmall arms
noun [C] [pl] small light weapons that you can carry in your hands （可随身携带的）轻武器

ˌsmall ˈchange
noun [U] coins that have a low value 面额小的硬币

smallholder
/ˈsmɔ:lhəʊldə(r) ||; ˈsmɔlˈholdɚ/noun [C] a person who owns or rents a small piece of land for farming 小自耕农；小佃农

smallholding
/ˈsmɔ:lhəʊldɪŋ ||; ˈsmɔlˈholdɪŋ/noun [C] a small piece of land that is used for farming 小块农田

ˌsmall-ˈminded
adj having fixed opinions and ways of doing things and not willing to change them or consider other people's opinions or feelings; interested in small problems and details and not in things which are really important 狭隘的；固持己见的；心胸狭窄的

smallpox
/ˈsmɔ:lpɒks ||; ˈsmɔlˌpɑks/noun [U] a serious infectious disease that causes a high temperature and leaves marks on the skin. In past times many people died from smallpox. 天花

ˌsmall-ˈscale
adj (used about an organization or activity) not large; limited in what it does （指组织或活动）小规模的，有限的

ˈsmall talk
noun [U] polite conversation, for example at a party, about unimportant things 客套话；闲聊；谈天: We had to make small talk for half an hour. 我们要花半个小时来说些客套话。

ˈsmall-town
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前)
1 not showing much interest in new ideas or what is happening outside your own environment 保守狭隘的；落后闭塞的: small-town values/views 保守狭隘的价值观/观点 [SYN]narrow-minded 同义词为 narrow-minded
2 connected with a small town 小城镇的: small-town America (= people who live in small towns in America) 美国的小城镇人口

smarmy
/ˈsmɑ:mi ||; ˈsmɑrmɪ/adj (smarmier; smarmiest) (informal 非正式) too polite in a way that is not sincere 过分殷勤的；谄媚的: a smarmy salesman/comment 逢迎讨好的推销员/话

*smart¹
/smɑ:t ||; smɑrt/adj
1 (especially Brit 尤为英) (used about a person) having a clean and tidy appearance （指人）整洁的，衣冠楚楚的: You look smart. Are you going somewhere special? 你看来衣冠楚楚，是去什么特别的地方吗？
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) (used about a piece of clothing, etc) good enough to wear on a formal occasion （指衣服等）适合正式场合穿着的: a smart suit 一套时髦的衣服
3 clever; intelligent 聪明的；脑筋灵活的: He's not smart enough to be a politician. 他不够聪明，当不了政治家。
4 (especially Brit 尤为英) fashionable and usually expensive 时髦的（通常也是昂贵的）: a smart restaurant/hotel 高档的餐馆╱酒店
5 (used about a movement or action) quick and usually done with force （指活动或行动）敏捷的，快而狠的 ➔smartly adv She's always smartly dressed. 她总是穿得整齐漂亮。
smart²
/smɑ:t ||; smɑrt/verb[I]
1 smart (from sth) to feel a stinging pain in your body 感到刺痛
2 smart (from/over sth) to feel upset or offended because of a criticism, failure, etc （因批评、失败等而）感到不快或生气

smart alec ( US 美 smart aleck)
/ˈsmɑ:t ælɪk ||; ˈsmɑrt ˌælək/ (also smartass, smart-ass /ˈsmɑ:tɑ:s ||; ˈsmɑrtˌæs/, smarty-pants) noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who thinks he/she is very clever and likes to show people this in an annoying way 自作聪明的人；好显能的人

ˈsmart card
noun [C] a plastic card, for example a CREDIT CARD, on which information can be stored in electronic form 智能卡（存有电子讯息的塑料卡，如信用卡）

smarten
/ˈsmɑ:tn ||; ˈsmɑrtṇ/verb (especially Brit 尤为英) smarten (yourself/sb/sth) up to make yourself/sb/sth look tidy and more attractive 使自己或某人整洁而漂亮

smarty-pants
/ˈsmɑ:ti pænts ||; ˈsmɑrtɪ ˌpænts/noun [C] (informal 非正式) = smart alec⇒

*smash¹
/smæʃ ||; smæʃ/verb
1 [I,T] to break sth, or to be broken violently and noisily into many pieces （哗啦一声）打碎，打破: The glass smashed into a thousand pieces. 那个玻璃杯摔得粉碎。 The police had to smash the door open. 警方不得不破门而入。
2 [I,T] smash (sth) against, into, through, etc to move with great force in a particular direction; to hit sth very hard 向某方向猛冲或猛撞: The car smashed into a tree. 汽车撞在一棵树上。 He smashed his fist through the window. 他用拳头打破窗户。
3 [T] smash sth (up) to crash a vehicle, usually causing a lot of damage 碰撞，撞毁（汽车）
4 [T] (in tennis) to hit a ball that is high in the air downwards very hard over the net （网球）打高压球，扣杀
smash²
/smæʃ ||; smæʃ/noun
1 [sing] the action or the noise of sth breaking violently 打碎；破碎声
2 [C] (in tennis, etc) a way of hitting a ball that is high in the air downwards and very hard over the net （网球等）高压球，扣球
3 (also smash ˈhit) [C] (informal 非正式) a song, play, film, etc that is very successful 极轰动的歌曲、戏剧、电影等

smashed
/smæʃt ||; smæʃt/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) (slang 俚语) very drunk or high on drugs 烂醉如泥；﹙服用毒品后﹚迷醉

smashing
/ˈsmæʃɪŋ ||; ˈsmæʃɪŋ/adj (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) extremely good; wonderful 极好的；了不起的

smattering
/ˈsmætərɪŋ ||; ˈsmætərɪŋ/noun [sing] a smattering (of sth) a small amount of sth, especially knowledge of a language ﹙尤指对语言﹚略知，浅知: I only speak a smattering of Spanish. 我只会说一点儿西班牙语。

smear¹
/smɪə(r) ||; smɪr/verb [T] smear sth on/over sth/sb;smear sth/sb with sth to spread a sticky substance across sth/sb 在…上涂上黏性物质: Her face was smeared with blood. 她的脸上都是血污。
smear²
/smɪə(r) ||; smɪr/noun[C]
1 a dirty mark made by spreading a substance across sth 污点；污渍
2 something that is not true that is said or written about an important person and that is intended to damage people's opinion about him/her, especially in politics （对重要人物的）诽谤，诋毁，抹黑（尤指在政界）: He was the victim of a smear campaign. 他是一场诽谤运动的受害者。

*smell¹
/smel ||; smɛl/verb (past tense past participle smelt /smelt ||; smɛlt/or smelled /smeld ||; smɛld/)
1 [I] smell (of sth) to have a particular smell 有某种气味: Dinner smells good! 晚餐很香！ This perfume smells of roses. 这香水散发出玫瑰的香气。 His breath smelt of whisky. 他的呼吸有一股威士忌酒气味。
2 [I] to have a bad smell 有难闻的气味；有臭味: Your feet smell. 你的脚很臭。
3 [T] to notice or recognize sb/sth by using your nose 用嗅觉闻出或辨出: He could smell something burning. 他闻到有东西烧焦的气味。 Can you smell gas? 你闻到煤气味吗？ I could still smell her perfume in the room. 我仍能在房间里闻到她的香水味。
We do not use smell or other verbs of the senses (for example taste, see, hear) in the continuous tenses. Instead we often use can, for example I can smell smoke. smell和其他表示感官的动词﹙如taste﹑see﹑hear﹚不用于进行时﹐常与can连用﹐如﹕I can smell smoke.我闻到烟味。
4 [T] to put your nose near sth and breathe in so that you can discover or identify its smell 用鼻子闻（以辨别什么气味）: I smelt the milk to see if it had gone off. 我闻了闻牛奶，看看是否坏了。
5 [I] to be able to smell 有嗅觉: I can't smell properly because I've got a cold. 我患了伤风，嗅觉不灵敏。
*smell²
/smel ||; smɛl/noun
1 [C] the impression that you get of sth by using your nose; the thing that you smell 气味: What's that smell? 这是什么气味？ a sweet/musty/fresh/sickly smell 芳香╱发霉╱新鲜╱令人作呕的气味 a strong/faint smell of garlic 浓烈╱淡淡的蒜味
2 [sing] an unpleasant smell 臭味: Ugh! What's that smell? 唷！什么东西那么臭？
Stink, stench, odour and pong are all words for unpleasant smells. Aroma, fragrance, perfume and scent refer to pleasant smells. stink、stench、odour及pong都表示难闻的气味。aroma、fragrance、perfume及scent都表示好闻的气味。
3 [U] the ability to sense things with the nose 嗅觉: Dogs have a very good sense of smell. 狗的嗅觉很灵敏。
4 [C] the action of putting your nose near sth to smell it 嗅；闻: Have a smell of this milk; is it all right? 闻一闻这牛奶，有没有变质？

ˈsmelling salts
noun [pl] a chemical with a very strong smell, kept in a small bottle, used especially in the past for putting under the nose of a person who has become unconscious (fainted) 嗅盐﹙有刺鼻的气味，旧时用作苏醒剂﹚

smelly
/ˈsmeli ||; ˈsmɛlɪ/adj (informal 非正式) having a bad smell 发出难闻气味的；有臭味的: smelly feet 臭脚

smelt¹
/smelt ||; smɛlt/verb [T] to heat and melt rock containing metal(ore)in order to get the metal out （为提取金属而）熔炼，冶炼（矿石）
smelt²
past tense, past participle ofSMELL

smelter
/ˈsmeltə(r) ||; ˈsmɛltɚ/noun [C] a piece of equipment for smelting metal 熔炉

smidgen ( also smidgeon, smidgin)
/ˈsmɪdʒən ||; ˈsmɪdʒən/noun [sing] a smidgen (of sth) (informal 非正式) a small piece or amount of sth 少量；一点点: ‘Sugar?’ ‘Just a smidgen.’ “放糖吗？”“只放一点。”

*smile¹
/smaɪl ||; smaɪl/noun [C] an expression on your face in which the corners of your mouth turn up, showing happiness, pleasure, etc 微笑: to have a smile on your face 面露笑容 ‘It's nice to see you,’ he said with a smile. 他面带笑容说：“幸会，幸会。” ☞Look at beam, grin and smirk. 参看beam、grin及smirk。
*smile²
/smaɪl ||; smaɪl/verb
1 [I] smile (at sb/sth) to make a smile appear on your face 微笑: to smile sweetly/faintly/broadly 笑得甜美；淡淡一笑；笑容可掬 She smiled at the camera. 她对着照相机笑。
2 [T] to say or express sth with a smile 面带笑容说；以微笑表示: I smiled a greeting to them. 我向他们微笑致意。

smiley
/ˈsmaɪli ||; ˈsmaɪlɪ/noun[C]
1 (computing 计算机技术) a series of keyboard symbols,:-), that represents a smiling face when you look at it sideways, used in e-mail, etc to show that the person sending the message is pleased or joking 笑容符﹙即:-)，用于电子邮件等﹚
2 = smiley face⇒

smiley face ( also smiley)
noun [C] a simple picture of a smiling face that is drawn as a circle with two eyes and a curved mouth 笑脸标志﹙圆形，有双眼和曲线形嘴﹚

smirk
/smɜ:k ||; smɝk/noun [C] an unpleasant smile which you have when you are pleased with yourself or think you are very clever 自呜得意地笑 smirk verb [I]

smog
/smɒg ||; smɑg/noun [U] dirty, poisonous air that can cover a whole city 烟雾

*smoke¹
/sməʊk ||; smok/noun
1 [U] the grey, white or black gas that you can see in the air when sth is burning 烟: Thick smoke poured from the chimney. 烟囱冒出浓烟。 a room full of cigarette smoke 香烟烟雾弥漫的房间
2 [C] [usu.sing] an action of smoking a cigarette, etc 抽烟
*smoke²
/sməʊk ||; smok/verb
1 [I,T] to breathe in smoke through a cigarette, etc and let it out again; to use cigarettes, etc in this way, as a habit 抽烟: Do you mind if I smoke? 你介意我抽烟吗？ I used to smoke 20 cigarettes a day. 我以前每天抽20根烟。
2 [I] to send out smoke 吐烟；冒烟: The oil in the pan started to smoke. 锅里的油开始冒烟。 ➔smoker noun [C]: She's a chain smoker (= she finishes one cigarette and then immediately lights another). 她是个烟不离手的人。 [OPP] non-smoker 反义词为non-smoker ➔smoking noun [U]: My doctor has advised me to give up smoking. 医生已劝我戒烟。 Would you like a table in the smoking or non-smoking section? 你要吸烟区还是禁烟区的桌子？

ˈsmoke alarm
noun [C] = smoke detector⇒

smoked
/sməʊkt ||; smokt/adj (used of certain types of food) given a special taste by being hung for a period of time in smoke from wood fires （指某几类食物）熏制的: smoked salmon/ham/cheese 熏鲑鱼；熏火腿；熏干酪

smoke detector ( also smoke alarm)
noun [C] a device that makes a loud noise if smoke is in the air to warn you of a fire 烟雾报警器

smokescreen
/ˈsməʊkskri:n ||; ˈsmokˌskrin/noun[C]
1 something that you do or say in order to hide what you are really doing or intending ﹙用以掩盖真相的﹚烟幕
2 a cloud of smoke used to hide soldiers, ships, etc during a battle ﹙战争中用以掩蔽士兵、舰船等的﹚烟幕

ˈsmoke signal
noun [C] smoke from a fire, which is used as a way of sending a message to sb who is far away 烟雾信号

ˌsmoking ˈgun
noun [sing] (informal 非正式) something that seems to prove that sb has done sth wrong or illegal 犯罪证据: This memo could be the smoking gun that investigators have been looking for. 这个备忘录可能是调查员一直在寻找的证据。

smoky
/ˈsməʊki ||; ˈsmokɪ/adj
1 full of smoke; producing a lot of smoke 烟雾弥漫的；冒烟的: a smoky room/fire 烟雾弥漫的房间；冒出浓烟的火
2 with the smell, taste or appearance of smoke 有烟味的；烟状的

smolder
(US 美) =SMOULDER

smooch
/smu:tʃ ||; smutʃ/verb [I] (informal 非正式) to kiss and hold sb closely 接吻拥抱

*smooth¹
/smu:ð ||; smuð/adj
1 having a completely flat surface with no lumps or holes or rough areas 平滑的；光滑的: smooth skin 光滑的皮肤 a smooth piece of wood 光滑的木块 [OPP] rough 反义词为rough
2 (of a liquid mixture) without lumps （液体混合物）没有团块的: Stir the sauce until it is smooth. 将调味汁搅匀。 [OPP] lumpy 反义词为lumpy
3 without difficulties 没有困难的；顺利的: The transition from the old method to the new has been very smooth. 从旧方法转变到新方法一直很顺利。
4 (of a journey in a car, etc) with an even, comfortable movement （指行车等）平稳前进的: You get a very smooth ride in this car. 这辆汽车行车平稳，一路上你会很舒适。 [OPP] bumpy 反义词为bumpy
5 too pleasant or polite to be trusted 过分圆滑的（以致不可信） ☞We use this word in a critical way, usually about a man I don't like him. He's far too smooth. 这个词用于批评，通常指人：I don't like him. He's far too smooth.我不喜欢他，他这个人太圆滑。 ➔smoothness noun [U]
take the rough with the smooth→ROUGH²
smooth²
/smu:ð ||; smuð/verb [T] smooth sth (away, back, down, out, etc) to move your hands in the direction mentioned over a surface to make it smooth 抚平

smoothie
/ˈsmu:ɝi ||; ˈsmuɒɪ/noun[C]
1 (US 美) a thick drink made of fruit or fruit juice mixed with milk, yoghurt or ice cream 果汁奶﹙水果或果汁加奶、酸奶或冰淇淋﹚: a banana smoothie 香蕉果汁奶
2 (informal 非正式) a man who talks very politely and confidently but who is often not honest or sincere 油嘴滑舌的男人；滑头: I wouldn't trust that smoothie if I were you. 假如我是你的话，我就不会相信那个油嘴滑舌的人。 He's a real smoothie. 他是个彻头彻尾的滑头。

smoothly
/ˈsmu:ðli ||; ˈsmuðlɪ/adv without any difficulty 没有困难；顺利: My work has been going quite smoothly. 我的工作一直进行得很顺利。

smother
/ˈsmʌðə(r) ||; ˈsmʌðɚ/verb[T]
1 smother sb (with sth) to kill sb by covering his/her face so that he/she cannot breathe 使窒息而死: She was smothered with a pillow. 她被人用枕头闷死。
2 smother sth/sb in/with sth to cover sth/sb with too much of sth （过量地把某物）覆盖于…上；厚厚地覆盖
3 to stop a feeling, etc from being expressed 抑制感受等
4 to stop sth burning by covering it 闷熄: to smother the flames with a blanket 用毯子把火焰闷熄

smoulder
/ˈsməʊldə(r) ||; ˈsmoldɚ/ (US 美 smolder) verb [I] to burn slowly without a flame 无火焰闷烧: a cigarette smouldering in an ashtray 在烟灰缸里慢慢燃烧的香烟

smudge
/smʌdʒ ||; smʌdʒ/verb
1 [T] to make sth dirty or untidy by touching it （用手揩擦而）弄污: Leave your painting to dry or you'll smudge it. 把图画放在一边等它干，不然你会把它弄脏。
2 [I] to become untidy, without a clean line around it 变得不整洁；变得模糊: Her lipstick smudged when she kissed him. 她吻了他，唇上的口红就抹模糊了。 smudge noun [C]

smug
/smʌg ||; smʌg/adj too pleased with yourself 沾沾自喜的；自呜得意的: Don't look so smug. 不要那样沾沾自喜。 ☞We use this word in a critical way. 这个词用于批评。 ➔smugly adv He smiled smugly as the results were announced. 成绩公布时，他得意地笑了笑。 ➔smugness noun [U]

smuggle
/ˈsmʌgl ||; ˈsmʌgḷ/verb [T] to take things into or out of a country secretly in a way that is not allowed by the law; to take a person or a thing secretly into or out of a place 走私；偷运: The drugs had been smuggled through customs. 那些毒品被偷运过海关。 ➔smuggler noun [C]: a drug smuggler 偷运毒品的人

*snack
/snæk ||; snæk/noun [C] food that you eat quickly between main meals 小吃；点心: I had a snack on the train. 我在火车上吃了点心。 snack verb [I] (informal 非正式)snack on sth

ˈsnack bar
noun [C] a type of small cafe where you can buy a small quick meal like a sandwich 小吃店

snafu
/snæˈfu: ||; snæˈfu/noun [sing] (US, informal 美，非正式) a situation in which nothing happens as planned 混乱局面: It was another bureaucratic snafu. 又让官僚主义搞成了一团糟。

snag¹
/snæg ||; snæg/noun [C] a small difficulty or disadvantage that is often unexpected or hidden 隐伏或未料到的小困难: His offer is very generous -- are you sure there isn't a snag? 他提出的条件很优厚，你肯定不会有意外的困难吗？
snag²
/snæg ||; snæg/verb [T] (snagging;snagged) to catch a piece of clothing, etc on sth sharp and tear it 钩破（衣物等）

snail
/sneɪl ||; snel/noun [C] a type of animal with a soft body and no legs that is covered by a shell. Snails move very slowly. 蜗牛 ☞picture at mollusc 见mollusc插图

ˈsnail mail
noun [U] (informal 非正式) used by people who use email to describe the system of sending letters by ordinary post 蜗牛邮件（使用电子邮件的人对普通邮件的称呼）

*snake¹
/sneɪk ||; snek/noun [C] a type of long thin animal with no legs that slides along the ground by moving its body from side to side 蛇
snake²
/sneɪk ||; snek/verb [I] (written 书面语) to move like a snake in long curves from side to side 像蛇那样曲折移动或延伸；蛇行

snakebite
/ˈsneɪkbaɪt ||; ˈsnekˌbaɪt/noun [C,U] a wound that you get when a poisonous snake bites you 蛇咬创伤: Three people have recently died from snakebites. 近来有三人死于毒蛇咬伤。 remedies for snakebite 治疗蛇咬创伤的药品

snake charmer
/ˈsneɪk tʃɑ:mə(r) ||; ˈsnek ˌtʃɑrmɚ/noun [C] an entertainer who seems to be able to control snakes and make them move by playing music to them 耍蛇人；弄蛇人

snakeskin
/ˈsneɪkskɪn ||; ˈsnekˌskɪn/noun [U] the skin of a snake, used for making expensive shoes, bags, etc 蛇皮﹙用以制作名贵的鞋、包等﹚

*snap¹
/snæp ||; snæp/verb (snapping;snapped)
1 [I,T] to break or be broken suddenly, usually with a sharp noise 啪的一声折断: The top has snapped off my pen. 我那支笔的上端啪的一声折断了。 The branch snapped. 树枝啪的一声折断了。 I snapped my shoelace when I was tying it. 我系鞋带时把鞋带扯断了。
2 [I,T] to move or be moved into a particular position, especially with a sharp noise （使）移入某个位置（尤指同时发出啪的一声） · She snapped the bag shut and walked out. 她啪的一声合上包就走出去了。
3 [I,T] snap (sth) (at sb) to speak or say sth in a quick angry way 怒气冲冲地说；严厉地说: Why do you always snap at me? 为什么你总是向我咆哮？
4 [I] to try to bite sb/sth 张口（向某人或某物）咬去: The dog snapped at the child's hand. 那只狗张口向小孩的手咬去。
5 [I,T] (informal 非正式) to take a quick photograph of sb/sth 给…拍快照: A tourist snapped the plane as it crashed. 飞机坠毁的时候，一名游客将当时情景拍了下来。
6 [I] to suddenly be unable to control your feelings any longer 突然无法控制自己的感情: Suddenly something just snapped and I lost my temper with him. 我突然间觉得无法忍受，于是对他大发脾气。
snap your fingers to make a sharp noise by moving your middle finger quickly against your thumb, especially when you want to attract sb's attention 打榧子（捻手指发出劈啪声，尤用以吸引人注意） snap sth up to buy or take sth quickly, especially because it is very cheap 抢购或迅速取去某物（尤因价廉）
snap²
/snæp ||; snæp/noun
1 [C] a sudden sharp sound of sth breaking 折断之声
2 (also snapshot /ˈsnæpʃɒt ||; ˈsnæpˌʃɑt/) [C] a photograph that is taken quickly and in an informal way 快照: I showed them some holiday snaps. 我给他们看假日里拍的几张快照。
3 [U] (Brit 英) a card game where players call out ‘Snap’ when two cards that are the same are put down by different players 喊“对儿”纸牌游戏（一种纸牌游戏，玩牌者认出发出的牌中有两张相同即喊snap）
snap³
/snæp ||; snæp/adj (informal 非正式) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) done quickly and suddenly, often without any careful thought 仓促的: a snap decision/judgement 仓促的决定；草率的判断

snare
/sneə(r) ||; snɛr/noun [C] a device (trap) used to catch birds or small animals （捕捉鸟类及小动物的）陷阱 snare verb [T]

snarl
/snɑ:l ||; snɑrl/verb [I,T] snarl (sth) (at sb) (used about an animal) to make an angry sound while showing the teeth （指动物）露齿咆哮: The dog snarled at the stranger. 那条狗对着陌生人吠叫。 snarl noun [C] [usu.sing]

snatch¹
/snætʃ ||; snætʃ/verb
1 [I,T] to take sth with a quick rough movement 夺取；抢夺 · A boy snatched her handbag and ran off. 一个男孩子抢过她的手袋逃之夭夭。 ☞Look at grab. It is similar in meaning. 参看grab。意思相近。
2 [T] to take or get sth quickly using the only time or chance that you have 抓紧时间或机会: I managed to snatch some sleep on the train. 我在火车上抓紧时间睡了一会儿。
snatch at sth to try to take hold of sth suddenly 设法抓住；抢夺: The man snatched at my wallet but I didn't let go of it. 那个男子想要夺走我的皮夹子，但是我没有松手。
snatch²
/snætʃ ||; snætʃ/noun
1 [sing] a sudden movement that sb makes when trying to take hold of sth 夺；抢夺
2 [C] [usu.pl] a short part or period of something 片段；片刻: I heard snatches of conversation from the next room. 我听到了隔壁房间传来的谈话片段。

snazzy
/ˈsnæzi ||; ˈsnæzɪ/adj (snazzier; snazziest) (informal 非正式) (used about clothes, cars, etc) fashionable, bright and modern, and attracting your attention ﹙服装、汽车等﹚时髦而漂亮的，吸引人的: a snazzy suit/car 时髦的套装；漂亮的汽车 snazzy graphics for the new computer game 为这个新的计算机游戏制作的诱人图像

sneak¹
/sni:k ||; snik/verb (past tense past participle sneaked(informal 非正式) (especially US 尤为美) snuck)
1 [I] sneak into, out of, past, etc sth;sneak in, out, away, etc to go very quietly in the direction mentioned, so that no one can see or hear you 悄悄地走；偷偷走掉: The prisoner sneaked past the guards. 那个囚犯躲过守恒溜走了。 Instead of working, he sneaked out to play football. 他不工作，溜出去踢足球了。
2 [T] (informal 非正式) to do or take sth secretly 偷偷做某事或拿某物: I tried to sneak a look at the test results in the teacher's bag. 我想要偷看老师包里的测验成绩。
sneak up (on sb/sth) to go near sb very quietly, especially so that you can surprise him/her 偷偷接近（某人）（尤指为了吓对方一跳）
sneak²
/sni:k ||; snik/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person, especially a child, who tells sb about the bad things sb has done 告密者，打小报告的人（尤指孩子） ☞This word is used in a critical way. 这个词用于批评。

sneaker
/ˈsni:kə(r) ||; ˈsnikɚ/ (US 美) =PLIMSOLL, TRAINER(1)

sneaking
/ˈsni:kɪŋ ||; ˈsnikɪŋ/adj (used about feelings) not expressed; secret （指感情）隐藏不露的，暗地里的: I've a sneaking suspicion that he's lying. 我暗自怀疑他在说谎。

ˌsneak ˈpreview
noun [C] an opportunity to see sth before it is officially shown to the public ﹙公开展示前的﹚预览机会

sneaky
/ˈsni:ki ||; ˈsnikɪ/adj (sneakier; sneakiest) (informal 非正式) behaving in a secret and sometimes dishonest or unpleasant way 悄悄的；偷偷摸摸的；鬼鬼祟祟的: That was a sneaky trick! 那种把戏可不够光明正大！ ➔sneakily adv

sneer
/snɪə(r) ||; snɪr/verb [I] sneer (at sb/sth) to show that you have no respect for sb/sth by the expression on your face or the way that you speak 蔑视；讥讽: She sneered at his attempts to speak French. 他试着学说法语，却被她嘲笑。 sneer noun [C]

sneeze
/sni:z ||; sniz/verb [I] to make air come out of your nose suddenly and noisily in a way that you cannot control, for example because you have a cold 打喷嚏: Dust makes me sneeze. 灰尘弄得我打喷嚏。 sneeze noun [C]

snide
/snaɪd ||; snaɪd/adj (used about an expression or comment) critical in an unpleasant way （指言语或评论）讥讽的，挖苦的

sniff
/snɪf ||; snɪf/verb
1 [I] to breathe air in through the nose in a way that makes a sound, especially because you have a cold or you are crying 哧哧地用鼻吸气（尤指因患伤风或哭泣）: Stop sniffing and blow your nose. 不要再呼哧呼哧的，擤一下鼻子吧。
2 [I,T] sniff (at) sth to smell sth by sniffing 嗅；闻 [T] ‘I can smell gas,’ he said, sniffing the air. 他嗅着空气说：“我闻到煤气味。” The dog sniffed at the bone. 狗嗅着那块骨头。 sniff noun [C]: Have a sniff of this milk and tell me if it's still OK. 你闻一闻这牛奶，再告诉我是不是还可以喝。

sniffle
/ˈsnɪfl ||; ˈsnɪfḷ/verb [I] to make noises by breathing air suddenly up your nose, especially because you have a cold or you are crying 吸鼻子，哧哧地用鼻子吸气（尤指因为患感冒或哭泣）

snigger
/ˈsnɪgə(r) ||; ˈsnɪgɚ/verb [I] snigger (at sb/sth) to laugh quietly and secretly in an unpleasant way 窃笑；暗笑 snigger noun [C]

snip¹
/snɪp ||; snɪp/verb [I,T] (snipping;snipped)snip (sth) (off, out, in, etc) to cut using scissors, with a short quick action （用剪刀）剪: He sewed on the button and snipped off the ends of the cotton. 他缝上钮扣，剪掉了线头。 to snip a hole in sth 在某物上剪个洞
snip²
/snɪp ||; snɪp/noun[C]
1 a small cut made with scissors 剪下的碎片: She made a small snip in the cloth. 她在布上剪了一小块。
2 (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) something that is much cheaper than expected 比预期的便宜得多的货品

sniper
/ˈsnaɪpə(r) ||; ˈsnaɪpɚ/noun [C] a person who shoots at sb from a hidden position 狙击手

snippet
/ˈsnɪpɪt ||; ˈsnɪpɪt/noun [C] a small piece of sth, especially information or news 片段（尤指消息或新闻）

snippy
/ˈsnɪpi ||; ˈsnɪpɪ/adj (snippier; snippiest) (US, informal 美，非正式) rude; not showing respect 粗野无礼的

snitch¹
/snɪtʃ ||; snɪtʃ/verb
1 [I] snitch (on sb) (to sb) to tell a parent, teacher, etc about sth wrong that another child has done ﹙向家长、教师等﹚告发，告密，告状: Johnnie snitched on me to his mom. 约翰尼在他妈妈那儿告了我的状。
2 [T] to take sth without the owner's permission, usually sth small and not important or valuable 偷﹙不太值钱的东西﹚: I snitched some of my son's Halloween candy. 我偷偷拿了一些我儿子在万圣节讨来的糖果。
snitch²
/snɪtʃ ||; snɪtʃ/noun [C] a person who tells sb in authority about sth wrong that another person has done ﹙向家长、教师等﹚告密的人，告状的人: You little snitch! I'll never tell you anything again! 你这家伙就爱告密！以后我什么话都不跟你说了！

snivel
/ˈsnɪvl ||; ˈsnɪvḷ/verb [I] (snivelling;snivelled (US 美) sniveling;sniveled) to keep crying quietly in a way that is annoying （令人讨厌地）哭哭啼啼，抽泣

snob
/snɒb ||; snɑb/noun [C] a person who thinks he/she is better than sb of a lower social class and who admires people who have a high social position 谄上欺下的人；势利的人: He's such a snob -- he wears his Oxford University tie all the time. 他真是个势利小人，老是系着他那条牛津大学的领带。 ➔snobbish adj ➔snobbishly adv ➔snobbishness noun [U]

snobbery
/ˈsnɒbəri ||; ˈsnɑbərɪ/noun [U] behaviour or attitudes typical of people who think they are better than other people in society, for example because they have more money, better education, etc 势利的行为或态度: To say that ‘all pop music is rubbish’ is just snobbery. 说“流行音乐都是垃圾”这种话真是太势利了。

snog
/snɒg ||; snɑg/verb [I,T] (snogging;snogged) (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) (used about a couple) to kiss each other for a long period of time （指夫妻或情侣）长时间地接吻 snog noun [sing]

snooker
/ˈsnu:kə(r) ||; ˈsnukɚ/noun [U] a game in which two players try to hit a number of coloured balls into pockets at the edges of a large table using a long stick (cue) 落袋台球；司诺克；撞球: to play snooker 玩落袋台球 ☞Look at billiards and pool. 参看billiards及pool。

snoop
/snu:p ||; snup/verb [I] snoop (around);snoop (on sb) to look around secretly and without permission in order to find out information, etc 窥探；打探: She suspected that her neighbours visited just to snoop on her. 她怀疑邻居前来拜访只是为了窥探她。

snooty
/ˈsnu:ti ||; ˈsnutɪ/adj (informal 非正式) acting in a rude way because you think you are better than other people 自大的；傲慢的；目中无人的

snooze
/snu:z ||; snuz/verb [I] (informal 非正式) to have a short sleep, especially during the day 小睡（尤指在白天）；打盹 snooze noun [C] [usu.sing] I had a bit of a snooze on the train. 我在火车上睡了一会儿。 ☞Look at nap. 参看nap。

snore
/snɔ:(r) ||; snɔr/verb [I] to breathe noisily through your nose and mouth while you are asleep 打鼾；打呼噜: She heard her father snoring in the next room. 她听见隔壁房里父亲在打鼾。 snore noun [C]: He's got the loudest snore I've ever heard. 他的鼾声是我听到过最响的。

snorkel
/ˈsnɔ:kl ||; ˈsnɔrkḷ/noun [C] a short tube that a person swimming just below the surface of the water can use to breathe through （潜泳者用的）水下呼吸管 We use go snorkelling to talk about swimming like this. 用水下呼吸管潜泳可以说go snorkelling。 ☞picture at dive 见dive插图

snort
/snɔ:t ||; snɔrt/verb[I]
1 (used about animals) to make a noise by blowing air through the nose and mouth （指动物）发出鼻息声
2 (used about people) to blow out air noisily as a way of showing that you do not like sth, or that you are impatient （指人）哼着鼻子（表示不喜欢或不耐烦） snort noun [C]

snot
/snɒt ||; snɑt/noun [U] (informal 非正式) the liquid produced by the nose 鼻涕

snotty
/ˈsnɒti ||; ˈsnɑtɪ/ (also ˌsnotty-ˈnosed)adj (informal 非正式)
1 = snooty
2 full of or covered in snot 流鼻涕的；满是鼻涕的: a snotty nose 流着鼻涕的鼻子 snotty kids 淌着鼻涕的小孩

snout
/snaʊt ||; snaυt/noun [C] the long nose of certain animals 某些动物的长鼻: a pig's snout 猪鼻 ☞picture at badger 见badger插图

*snow¹
/snəʊ ||; sno/noun [U] small, soft, white pieces of frozen water that fall from the sky in cold weather 雪: Three centimetres of snow fell during the night. 夜里下了三厘米厚的雪。 The snow melted before it could settle (= stay on the ground). 雪片落到地上就融化了。 ☞Look at the note at weather. 参看weather的注释。
*snow²
/snəʊ ||; sno/verb [I] (used about snow) to fall from the sky 下雪: It snowed all night. 下了一夜雪。

snowball¹
/ˈsnəʊbɔ:l ||; ˈsnoˌbɔl/noun [C] a lump of snow that is pressed into the shape of a ball and used by children for playing 雪球
snowball²
/ˈsnəʊbɔ:l ||; ˈsnoˌbɔl/verb [I] to quickly grow bigger and bigger or more and more important （滚雪球般）迅速增大、增长或增强

snowblower
/ˈsnəʊbləʊə(r) ||; ˈsnoˌbloɚ/noun [C] a machine that removes snow from roads or paths by blowing it to one side 吹雪机

snowboard
/ˈsnəʊbɔ:d/noun [C] a type of board that you fasten to both your feet and use for moving down mountains that are covered with snow 滑雪板 ➔snowboarding noun [U]: Have you ever been snowboarding? 你用滑雪板滑过雪吗？ ☞picture at ski 见ski插图

snowdrift
/ˈsnəʊdrɪft ||; ˈsnoˌdrɪft/noun [C] a deep pile of snow that has been made by the wind （风吹成的）雪堆: The car got stuck in a snowdrift. 汽车陷在雪堆里。

snowdrop
/ˈsnəʊdrɒp ||; ˈsnoˌdrɑp/noun [C] a type of small white flower that appears at the end of winter 雪花莲（残冬时开的小白花） ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图

ˌsnowed ˈin
adj not able to leave home or travel because the snow is too deep 因雪厚无法外出；被大雪困住

ˌsnowed ˈunder
adj with more work, etc than you can deal with 忙得不可开交

snowfall
/ˈsnəʊfɔ:l ||; ˈsnoˌfɔl/noun
1 [C] the snow that falls on one occasion 降雪: heavy snowfalls 大雪
2 [U] the amount of snow that falls in a particular place （某地的）降雪量

snowflake
/ˈsnəʊfleɪk ||; ˈsnoˌflek/noun [C] one of the small, soft, white pieces of frozen water that fall together as snow 雪花；雪片

ˈsnow job
noun [C] (US, informal 美，非正式) an attempt to deceive sb or to persuade sb to support sth by telling him/her things that are not true, or by praising him/her too much 花言巧语的劝说；诱骗

snowman
/ˈsnəʊmæn ||; ˈsnoˌmæn/noun [C] (plural -men /-men ||; -mɛn/) the figure of a person made out of snow （用雪堆成的）雪人

snowplough
/ˈsnəʊ plaʊ ||; ˈsnoˌplaυ/ (US 美 snowplow) noun [C] a vehicle that is used to clear snow away from roads or railways 扫雪车 ☞Look at plough. 参看plough。

snowshoe
/ˈsnəʊʃu: ||; ˈsnoˌʃu/noun [C] one of a pair of flat frames that you attach to the bottom of your shoes so that you can walk on deep snow without sinking in 雪鞋﹙可固定在鞋上，在深雪中行走时穿﹚

ˌsnow-ˈwhite
adj (written 书面语) pure white in colour 雪白的: snow-white sheets 雪白的床单

snowy
/ˈsnəʊi ||; ˈsnoɪ/adj with a lot of snow 多雪的: snowy weather 多雪的天气 a snowy scene 雪景

Snr
(also Sr) abbr (especially US 尤为美) Senior 地位较高的；较年长的；年资较深的

snub
/snʌb ||; snʌb/verb [T] (snubbing;snubbed) to treat sb rudely, for example by refusing to look at or speak to him/her 冷落 snub noun [C]: When they weren't invited to the party, they felt it was a snub. 他们没有获邀出席聚会，感到受冷落。

ˌsnub-ˈnosed
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) having a nose that is short, flat and turned up at the end 鼻子短平且上翘的: a snub-nosed child 鼻子短平且上翘的孩子 (figurative 比喻) a snub-nosed revolver(= with a short barrel) 短管左轮手枪

snuck
/snʌk ||; snʌk/ (informal 非正式 (especially US 尤为美)) past tense, past participle ofSNEAK¹

snuff
/snʌf ||; snʌf/noun [U] (especially in past times) tobacco which people breathe up into the nose in the form of a powder （尤指旧时）鼻烟

snuffle
/ˈsnʌfl ||; ˈsnʌfḷ/verb [I] (used about people and animals) to make a noise through your nose （指人或动物）发出鼻息声: The dog snuffled around the lamp post. 那只狗在灯柱四周嗅来嗅去。

snug
/snʌg ||; snʌg/adj
1 warm and comfortable 暖和舒适的: a snug little room 暖和舒适的小房间 The children were snug in bed. 孩子们舒适地躺在床上。
2 fitting sb/sth closely 紧贴的；服贴的: Adjust the safety belt to give a snug fit. 把安全带调整一下就系服贴了。 ➔snugly adv

snuggle
/ˈsnʌgl ||; ˈsnʌgḷ/verb [I] snuggle (up to sb);snuggle (up/down) to get into a position that makes you feel safe, warm and comfortable, usually next to another person 舒适地蜷伏或依偎: She snuggled up to her mother. 她依偎着母亲。 I snuggled down under the blanket to get warm. 我蜷伏在毛毯下取暖。

*so¹
/səʊ ||; so/adv
1 used to emphasize an adjective or adverb, especially when this produces a particular result （用于形容词或副词前以加强语气，尤指造成某种结果的）: She's so ill (that) she can't get out of bed. 她病得下不了床。 He was driving so fast that he couldn't stop. 他开车开得太快，以至于停不下来。 You've been so kind. How can I thank you? 你真是太好了，我怎样才能谢你？ ☞Look at the note at such. 参看such的注释。
2 used in negative sentences for comparing people or things （用于否定句以比较人或物）: She's not so clever as we thought. 她不如我们想象的那么聪明。
3 used in place of something that has been said already, to avoid repeating it （用于替代前述事物，以避免重复）: Are you coming by plane? If so, (= if you are coming by plane) I can meet you at the airport. 你搭飞机来吗？如果是这样的话，我可以到机场去接你。 ‘I failed, didn't I?’ ‘I'm afraid so.’ “我失败了，是吗？”“恐怕是的。”
In formal language, you can refer to actions that somebody has mentioned using do with so He asked me to write to him and I did so (= I wrote to him). 在正式用语中，可以用do + so来代替某人提过的动作﹕He asked me to write to him and I did so.他叫我写信给他，我照办了。
4 (not with verbs in the negative 不与动词的否定形式连用) also, too 也: He's a teacher and so is his wife. 他是个教师，他太太也是。 ‘I've been to New York.’ ‘ So have I.’ “我去过纽约。”“我也去过。” I like singing and so does Helen. 我喜欢唱歌，海伦也喜欢。 ☞For negative sentences, look at neither. 有关否定句，参看neither。
5 used to show that you agree that sth is true, especially when you are surprised （用于表示同意，尤指出乎意料的事）: ‘It's getting late.’ ‘So it is. We'd better go.’ “时间晚了。”“真的啊。我们走吧。”
6 (formal 正式) (used when you are showing sb sth) in this way; like this （用于指示）这样，这么: It was a black insect, about so big (= using your hands to show the size). 那是一种黑色的昆虫，大约有这么大（用手比画大小）。 Fold the paper in two diagonally, like so. 把这纸对角迭两折，像这样。
and so on (and so forth) used at the end of a list to show that it continues in the same way （用于表示列举未尽）诸如此类，等等: They sell pens, pencils, paper and so on. 他们卖墨水笔、铅笔、纸张等。 I told you so used to tell sb that he/she should have listened to your advice （用于告诉对方早应该听自己的忠告）我早对你说过: ‘I missed the bus.’ ‘I told you so. I said you needed to leave earlier.’ “我错过了那班车。”“我早对你说过。我说过你须要早一点出发。” it (just) so happens (used to introduce a surprising fact) by chance （引出出人意表之事）碰巧，正好: It just so happened that we were going the same way, so he gave me a lift. 我们恰好同路，所以他就载我一程。 just so→JUST¹ or so (used to show that a number, time, etc is not exact) approximately; about （用于表示不确切的数目、时间等）…左右，大概: A hundred or so people came to the meeting. 约有一百人出席了会议。 so as to do sth with the intention of doing sth; in order to do sth 为了做某事；以便做某事 so much for used for saying that sth was not helpful or successful （用于表示某事物无用或不成功）: So much for that diet! I didn't lose any weight at all. 那减肥餐不过如此！我的体重一点也没有减轻。 that is so(formal 正式) that is true 对的；不错
*so²
/səʊ ||; so/ conj
1 with the result that; therefore 结果；因此: She felt very tired so she went to bed early. 她觉得很累，因此她提早睡觉。
2 so (that) with the purpose that; in order that 为了；以便: She wore dark glasses so (that) nobody would recognize her. 她戴上墨镜以免被人认出。
3 used to show how one part of a story follows another （用于连接故事的上下文）: So what happened next? 那么，接下来呢？
so what?(informal 非正式) (showing that you think sth is not important) Who cares? （表示没有什么了不起）那又怎样？: ‘It's late.’ ‘So what? We don't have to go to school tomorrow.’ “很晚了。”“那有什么关系？我们明天不用上学。”

soak
/səʊk ||; sok/verb
1 [I,T] to become or make sth completely wet （使）湿透: Leave the dishes to soak for a while. 将碟子浸一会儿。 The dog came out of the river and shook itself, soaking everyone. 那狗从河里上来，晃了晃身子，把大家都弄湿了。
2 [I] soak into/through sth;soak in (used about a liquid) to pass into or through sth （指液体）渗透: Blood had soaked through the bandage. 血渗透了绷带。
soak sth up to take sth in (especially a liquid) 吸入（尤指液体）: I soaked the water up with a cloth. 我用布将水吸掉。

soaked
/səʊkt ||; sokt/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) extremely wet 湿透: I got soaked waiting for my bus in the rain. 我在雨里等公共汽车，全身都湿透了。

soaking
/ˈsəʊkɪŋ ||; ˈsokɪŋ/ (also ˌsoaking ˈwet) adj extremely wet 湿透的

ˈso-and-so
noun [C] (plural so-and-sos) (informal 非正式)
1 a person who is not named 某某: Imagine a Mrs So-and-so telephones. What would you say? 假设某某夫人打电话来，你会怎么说？
2 a person that you do not like 讨厌的人: He's a bad-tempered old so-and-so. 他是个坏脾气的老家伙。

*soap
/səʊp ||; sop/noun [U] a substance that you use for washing and cleaning 肥皂: He washed his hands with soap. 他用肥皂洗手。 a bar of soap 一块肥皂 soap powder (= for washing clothes) 肥皂粉 ➔soapy adj

soapbox
/ˈsəʊpbɒks ||; ˈsopˌbɑks/noun [C] a small temporary platform that sb stands on to make a speech in a public place, usually outdoors ﹙多指户外的﹚临时演讲台 get/be on your soapbox (informal 非正式) to express the strong opinions that you have about a particular subject 发表激烈的意见: She's on her soapbox about animal rights again!她又在发表有关保护动物权益的激烈演讲了！

ˈsoap opera
(informal 非正式soap) noun [C] a story about the lives and problems of a group of people which continues several times a week on television or radio （电视或电台）连续剧，肥皂剧 ☞Look at opera. 参看opera。

soapsuds
/ˈsəʊpsʌdz ||; ˈsopˌsʌdz/noun [pl] = suds

soar
/sɔ:(r) ||; sɔr/verb[I]
1 to fly high in the air 高飞；翱翔
2 to rise very fast 快速升高；剧增: Prices are soaring because of inflation. 物价因通货膨胀而急升。

sob
/sɒb ||; sɑb/verb [I] (sobbing;sobbed) to cry while taking in sudden, sharp breaths; to speak while you are crying 呜咽；啜泣: The child was sobbing because he'd lost his toy. 那个孩子在呜咽，因为他丢了自己的玩具。 sob noun [C]: It was heartbreaking to listen to her sobs. 听着她的啜泣声令人心碎。

sober¹
/ˈsəʊbə(r) ||; ˈsobɚ/adj
1 (of a person) not affected by alcohol （指人）未醉的，清醒的: He'd been drunk the first time he'd met her, but this time he was stone-cold sober. 他第一次遇见她的时候喝醉了，但这一次他完全清醒。
2 not funny; serious 不滑稽的；严肃的: a sober expression 严肃的表情 Her death is a sober reminder of just how dangerous drugs can be. 她的死使人们清楚认识到毒品的祸害。
3 (of a colour) not bright or likely to be noticed （指颜色）暗淡的，不起眼的: a sober grey suit 一套素净的灰色衣服
sober²
/ˈsəʊbə(r) ||; ˈsobɚ/verb sober (sb) up to become or make sb become normal again after being affected by alcohol （使）醒酒: I need a cup of black coffee to sober me up. 我得喝一杯黑咖啡来解酒。 There's no point talking to him until he's sobered up. 在他酒醉未醒之前跟他说话是没有意义的。

sobering
/ˈsəʊbərɪŋ ||; ˈsobərɪŋ/adj making you feel serious 使人严肃的: It is a sobering thought that over 25 million people have been killed in car accidents. 想一想超过2500万人死于车祸会令人头脑清醒。

ˈsob story
noun [C] (plural sob stories) (informal 非正式) a story that sb tells you just to make you feel sorry for him/her, especially one that does not have that effect or is not true ﹙旨在引起同情或怜悯的﹚伤感故事

Soc.
abbr Society 团体；会社；协会: Amateur Dramatic Soc. 业余剧社

ˌso-ˈcalled
adj
1 used to show that the words you describe sb/sth with are not correct （用于描述某人或某事物的用语不正确）所谓: Her so-called friends only wanted her money. 她那些所谓朋友要的是只不过是她的钱。
2 used to show that a special name has been given to sb/sth 表示有如此称呼／称号的

soccer
/ˈsɒkə(r) ||; ˈsɑkɚ/ (especially US 尤为美) =FOOTBALL(1)

ˈsoccer mom
noun [C] (US 美) a mother who spends a lot of time taking her children to activities such as playing sports and having music lessons (used as a way of referring to a typical mother from the middle classes) 足球妈妈﹙花许多时间带孩子去参加体育活动、音乐课等，指中产阶级的典型母亲﹚

sociable
/ˈsəʊʃəbl ||; ˈsoʃəbḷ/adj enjoying being with other people; friendly 喜欢交际的；友善的；合群的

*social
/ˈsəʊʃl ||; ˈsoʃəl/adj
1 connected with society and the way it is organized 与社会及其组织方式有关的；社会的: social problems/issues/reforms 社会问题╱议题╱改革
2 concerning the position of people in society 与社会地位有关的: We share the same social background. 我们有相同的社会背景。
3 connected with meeting people and enjoying yourself 与社交或交际有关的: a social club 交谊俱乐部 She has a busy social life. 她的社交活动很频繁。 Children have to develop their social skills when they start school. 孩子上学后必须培养社交能力。
4 (used about animals) living in groups （指动物）群居的 ➔socially /-ʃəli ||; -ʃəlɪ/ adv We work together but I don't know him socially. 我和他共事，但是除工作以外并没有交往。

ˌsocial deˈmocracy
noun [U] [C] a political system that combines the principles of one system(socialism)with the greater personal freedom of another system(democracy); a country that has this political system of government 社会民主主义（将社会主义制度与民主制度合而为一的政治制度）；社会民主主义国家 ➔ˌsocial ˈdemocrat noun [C]

socialism
/ˈsəʊʃəlɪzəm ||; ˈsoʃəlˌɪzəm/noun [U] the political idea that is based on the belief that all people are equal and that money and property should be equally divided 社会主义 ☞Look at communism, Marxism and capitalism. 参看communism、Marxism及capitalism。 ➔socialist adj noun [C]: socialist beliefs/policies/writers 社会主义信念╱政策╱作家 Tony was a socialist when he was younger. 托尼年轻时是个社会主义者。

socialite
/ˈsəʊʃəlaɪt ||; ˈsoʃəˌlaɪt/noun [C] a person who goes to a lot of fashionable parties and is often written about in the newspapers, etc 上流社会名人；社交名流

ˌsocial ˈscience
noun [C,U] the study of people in society 社会科学

ˌsocial seˈcurity
(US 美 welfare) noun [U] money paid regularly by the government to people who are poor, old, ill, or who have no job 社会救济金（政府发给贫穷、年老、患病或失业者的）: to live on social security 靠社会救济金生活

ˌsocial ˈservices
noun [pl] a group of services organized by local government to help people who have money or family problems 社会服务（如扶贫解困）

ˈsocial studies
noun [pl] (US 美) = social science

ˈsocial work
noun [U] paid work that involves giving help and advice to people living in the community who have financial or family problems 社会福利工作（为有经济困难或家庭问题的小区居民提供帮助及建议的有薪工作）

ˈsocial worker
noun [C] a person whose job is SOCIAL WORK 社会工作者

*society
/səˈsaɪəti ||; səˈsaɪətɪ/noun (plural societies)
1 [C,U] the people in a country or area, thought of as a group, who have shared customs and laws 社会；群体: a civilized society 文明社会 Society's attitude to women has changed considerably this century. 本世纪人们对女性的态度改变了不少。 The role of men in society is changing. 男人的社会角色正在改变。
2 [C] an organization of people who share a particular interest or purpose; a club 团体；会社；协会: a drama society 戏剧社

socio-
/ˈsəʊsiəʊ ||; ˈsoˌʃɪo/prefix (used in nouns, adjectives and adverbs 用于构成名词、形容词及副词) connected with society or the study of society 与社会或社会学有关: socio-economic 社会经济的 sociolinguistics 社会语言学

sociologist
/ˌsəʊsiˈɒlədʒɪst ||; ˌsosɪˈɑlədʒɪst/noun [C] a student of or an expert in sociology 社会学研究者；社会学家

sociology
