/ˌsəʊsiˈɒlədʒi ||; ˌsosɪˈɑlədʒɪ/noun [U] the study of human societies and social behaviour 社会学 ➔sociological /ˌsəʊsiəˈlɒdʒɪkl ||; ˌsosɪəˈlɑdʒɪkḷ/ adj

sociopath
/ˈsəʊsiəʊpæθ ||; ˈsosɪoˌpæθ/noun [C] a person who has a mental illness and who behaves in an aggressive or dangerous way toward other people ﹙因心理障碍而对他人构成危险的﹚反社会者

*sock
/sɒk ||; sɑk/noun [C] a piece of clothing that you wear on your foot and lower leg, inside your shoe 短袜: a pair of socks 一双短袜 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图 pull your socks up (Brit 英) to start working harder or better than before 加紧努力﹔努力提高

socket
/ˈsɒkɪt ||; ˈsɑkɪt/noun[C]
1 (also ˈpower point(informal 非正式)plug) a place in a wall where a piece of electrical equipment can be connected to the electricity supply 电源插座 ☞picture at plug 见plug插图
2 a hole in a piece of electrical equipment where another piece of equipment can be connected 插孔；插口
3 a hole that sth fits into 窝﹔孔: your eye socket 眼窝

sod
/sɒd ||; sɑd/noun [U,C] a layer of earth with grass growing on it; a piece of this that has been cut from the ground and is used especially for making lawns (= the area of grass in the yard) 长草的土层；﹙移植的﹚草皮

soda
/ˈsəʊdə ||; ˈsodə/noun
1 (also soda water) [U] water that has bubbles in it and is usually used for mixing with other drinks 汽水；苏打水: a whisky and soda 威士忌加苏打水
2 [C] (US 美) =FIZZY DRINK ☞Look at caustic soda. 参看caustic soda。

sodium
/ˈsəʊdiəm ||; ˈsodɪəm/noun [U] (symbol Na) a soft silver-white metal that is found naturally only in chemical mixtures(compounds), such as salt 钠

ˌsodium biˈcarbonate
(also biˌcarbonate of ˈsodabaking soda) noun [U] (symbol NaHCO₃) a white powder that is used in baking to make cakes, etc rise and become light 碳酸氢钠；小苏打

ˌsodium ˈcarbonate
(also washing soda) noun [U] (symbol Na₂CO₃) a chemical compound in the form of whiteCRYSTALSor powder that is used in making glass, soap and paper, and for making hard water soft 碳酸钠；苏打

ˌsodium ˈchloride
noun [U] (symbol NaCl) common salt (a chemical compound ofSODIUMandCHLORINE) 氯化钠；食盐

sofa
/ˈsəʊfə ||; ˈsofə/noun [C] a comfortable seat with a back and arms for two or more people to sit on 长沙发: a sofa bed (= a sofa that you can open out to make a bed) 沙发床 [SYN] settee 同义词为settee ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

*soft
/sɒft; US sɔ:ft ||; sɔft/adj
1 not hard or firm 软的；柔软的: a soft bed/seat 软床；软座 The ground is very soft after all that rain. 下过大雨后，地面十分松软。 [OPP] hard 反义词为hard
2 smooth and pleasant to touch; not rough 平滑的；柔嫩的: soft skin/hands 细嫩的皮肤；柔嫩的双手 a soft towel 松软的毛巾 [OPP] rough 反义词为rough
3 (used about sounds, voices, words, etc) quiet or gentle; not loud or angry （指声音、嗓音、言语等）低声的，轻柔的，悦耳的: She spoke in a soft whisper. 她轻声耳语。 [OPP] loud or harsh 反义词为loud或harsh
4 (used about light, colours etc) gentle and pleasant （指光线、颜色等）柔和的: The room was decorated in soft pinks and greens. 那个房间髹上了柔和的粉红色和翠绿色。 [OPP] bright 反义词为bright
5 (used about people) kind and gentle, sometimes too much so （指人）和善的，心肠软的（有时过分地）: A good manager can't afford to be too soft. 要成为能干的管理人员就不能心肠太软。 [OPP] hard or strict 反义词为hard或strict
6 (used about water 指水) not containing mineral salts and therefore good for washing as soap will make a lot of bubbles 不含无机盐的；软的 [OPP] hard 反义词为hard ➔softly adv He closed the door softly behind him. 他轻轻地随手把门关上。 ➔softness noun [U]
have a soft spot for sb/sth(informal 非正式) to have good or loving feelings towards sb/sth 对（某人或某物）怀有好感或爱意

ˌsoft ˈdrink
noun [C] a cold drink that contains no alcohol 软饮料（不含酒精的冷饮品）

ˌsoft ˈdrug
noun [C] an illegal drug, such as CANNABIS that some people take for pleasure, that is not considered very harmful or likely to cause ADDICTION 软毒品（危害不大、不易成瘾的毒品，如大麻） ☞Compare hard drug. 与hard drug比较。

soften
/ˈsɒfn; US ˈsɔ:fn ||; ˈsɔfən/verb
1 [I,T] to become softer or gentler; to make sb/sth softer or gentler （使）变软，变温和 [T] a lotion to soften the skin 一种使皮肤柔软的护肤液
2 [T] to make sth less strong and unpleasant 使温和；使缓和: Her letter sounded too angry so she softened the language. 她的信读来让人觉得她很生气，所以她把措辞缓和了一下。 The air bag softened the impact of the crash. 保险气袋减弱了撞击的影响。

softener
/ˈsɒfnə(r); US ˈsɔ:f- ||; ˈsɔfnɚ/noun [C,U] a substance that you add when washing clothes to make them feel soft ﹙衣物的﹚柔顺剂

ˌsoft ˈfruit
noun [C,U] small fruits without a large seed inside or hard skin （无核或无硬皮的）小果: raspberries, strawberries and other soft fruits 悬钩子、草莓等无核小果

ˌsoft-ˈhearted
adj kind and good at understanding other people's feelings 仁慈的；宽大的；心肠软的 [OPP] hard-hearted 反义词为hard-hearted

softie ( also softy)
/ˈsɒfti; US ˈsɔ:f- ||; ˈsɔftɪ/noun [C] (plural softies) a kind, sympathetic or emotional person 有同情心的人；心肠软的人；热心肠的人: There's no need to be afraid of him—he's a big softie. 没必要怕他——他心特软。

ˌsoft ˈoption
noun [C] the easier thing to do of two or more possibilities, but not the best one 比较省事的做法: The government has taken the soft option of agreeing to their demands. 政府采取比较省事的做法，同意了他们的要求。

ˌsoft-ˈspoken
adj having a gentle, quiet voice 嗓子柔和的；说话温柔的: He was a kind, soft-spoken man. 他是个心地善良、说话温柔的人。

software
/ˈsɒftweə(r) ||; ˈsɔftˌwɛr/noun [U] (computing计算机技术) the programs and other operating information used by a computer 软件；软件: There's a lot of new educational software available now. 现在有许多新的教育用软件。 ☞Look at hardware. 参看hardware。

softwood
/ˈsɒftwʊd ||; ˈsɔftˌwυd/noun [U] [C] wood that is cheap to produce and can be cut easily 软木材: Pine is a softwood. 松木是软木材。 ☞Compare hardwood. 与hardwood比较。

soggy
/ˈsɒgi ||; ˈsɑgɪ/adj very wet and soft and so unpleasant 湿透的

*soil¹
/sɔɪl ||; sɔɪl/noun
1 [C,U] the substance that plants, trees, etc grow in; earth 泥土；土壤: poor/dry/acid/sandy soil 贫瘠╱干旱╱酸性╱多沙的泥土 ☞Look at the note at ground ¹. 参看ground^1的注释。 ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图
2 [U] (written 书面语) the land that is part of a country 领土；国家；国土
soil²
/sɔɪl ||; sɔɪl/verb [T] (formal 正式) (often passive 常用于被动语态) to make sth dirty 弄脏

solace
/ˈsɒləs ||; ˈsɑlɪs/noun [U] [sing] (written 书面语)solace (in sth) a person or thing that makes you feel better or happier when you are sad or disappointed 给予安慰的人或物: to find/seek solace in sb/sth 找到╱寻求安慰

solar
/ˈsəʊlə(r) ||; ˈsolɚ/adj (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前)
1 connected with the sun 与太阳有关的: a solar eclipse(= when the sun is blocked by the moon) 日食
2 using the sun's energy 利用太阳能的: solar heating/power 太阳能加热╱发电 Solar panels in the roof supply the building's electricity. 屋顶的太阳能电池板为大楼提供电力。 ☞picture at energy 见energy插图

ˌsolar ˈcell
noun [C] a device that converts light and heat energy from the sun into electricity 太阳能电池

ˌsolar ˈyear
noun [C] (technical术语) the time it takes the earth to go around the sun once, approximately 3651/4 days 太阳年（地球绕太阳一周所需的时间，约为365 1/4天）

sold
past tense, past participle of SELL

solder
/ˈsəʊldə(r); US ˈsɒldə(r) ||; ˈsɑdɚ/verb [T] solder sth (to/onto sth);solder (A and B together) to join pieces of metal or wire together using a mixture of metals which is heated and melted 焊；焊接 solder noun [U]

ˈsoldering iron
noun [C] a tool that is heated and used for joining metals and wires by SOLDERING them 烙铁（焊接工具）

*soldier
/ˈsəʊldʒə(r) ||; ˈsoldʒɚ/noun [C] a member of an army 军人；士兵: The soldiers marched past. 士兵齐步走过。

sole¹
/səʊl ||; sol/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前)
1 only; single 单独的；唯一的；仅有的: His sole interest is football. 他唯一的兴趣是足球。
2 belonging to one person only; not shared 只属一人的；独有的；专用的 ➔solely adv I agreed to come solely because of your mother. 我只是看在你妈妈份上才答应来的。
sole²
/səʊl ||; sol/noun
1 [C] the bottom surface of your foot 脚掌；脚底 ☞picture at body 见body插图
2 [C] the part of a shoe or sock that covers the bottom surface of your foot 鞋底；袜底 ☞picture at shoe 见shoe插图
3 [C,U] (plural sole) a flat sea fish that we eat 鳎；鳎目鱼；鲽

solemn
/ˈsɒləm ||; ˈsɑləm/adj
1 (used about a person) very serious; not happy or smiling （指人）非常严肃的，没有笑容的: Her solemn face told them that the news was bad. 他们一见她神情严肃就知道那是坏消息。
2 sincere; done or said in a formal way 诚挚的；庄重的: to make a solemn promise 诚挚地许诺 ➔solemnity /səˈlemnəti ||; səˈlɛmnətɪ/ noun [U] ➔solemnly adv ‘I have something very important to tell you,’ she began solemnly. 她严肃地开口说：“我有很重要的事要告诉你。”

solicit
/səˈlɪsɪt ||; səˈlɪsɪt/verb
1 [T] (formal 正式) to ask sb for money, help, support, etc 恳求（金钱、帮助、支持等）: They tried to solicit support for the proposal. 他们试图寻求别人支持那个建议。
2 [I,T] (used about a woman who has sex for money) to go to sb, especially in a public place, and offer sex in return for money （指娼妓）拉客

solicitor
/səˈlɪsɪtə(r) ||; səˈlɪsətɚ/noun [C] (Brit 英) a lawyer whose job is to give legal advice, prepare legal documents and arrange the buying and selling of land, etc 事务律师（其工作包括提供法律意见、草拟法律文件、安排土地买卖等） ☞Look at the note at lawyer. 参看lawyer的注释。

*solid¹
/ˈsɒlɪd ||; ˈsɑlɪd/adj
1 hard and firm; not in the form of liquid or gas 坚固的；固体的: It was so cold that the village pond had frozen solid. 天气太冷了，村里的水塘也结了冰。
2 having no holes or empty spaces inside; not hollow 实心的；无孔的: a solid mass of rock 一大块实心的岩石
3 strong, firm and well-made 坚固的；结实的: a solid little car 牢固可靠的小汽车 (figurative 比喻) They built up a solid friendship over the years. 这些年来他们建立了牢固的友谊。
4 of good enough quality; that you can trust 可靠的；充分的: The police cannot make an arrest without solid evidence. 警方没有充分的证据不能逮捕人。
5 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) made completely of one substance, both on the inside and outside 纯质的（由里至外都用同一物质制成）: a solid gold chain 纯金链子
6 (spoken 口语) without a break or pause 无间断的；连续的: I was so tired that I slept for twelve solid hours/twelve hours solid. 我太累了，连续睡了十二个小时。 ➔solidity /səˈlɪdəti ||; səˈlɪdətɪ/ noun [U]
solid²
/ˈsɒlɪd ||; ˈsɑlɪd/noun[C]
1 a substance or object that is hard; not a liquid or gas 固体: Liquids become solids when frozen. 液体冷冻便成为固体。 The baby is not yet on solids (= solid food). 婴儿现在还不会吃固体食物。
2 an object that has length, width and height, not a flat shape 立体: A cube is a solid. 立方体是立体图形。

solidarity
/ˌsɒlɪˈdærəti ||; ˌsɑləˈdærətɪ/noun [U] solidarity (with sb) the support of one group of people for another, because they agree with their aims 支持；团结一致: Many local people expressed solidarity with the strikers. 许多本地人表示支持罢工者。

solidify
/səˈlɪdɪfaɪ ||; səˈlɪdəˌfaɪ/verb [I] (present participle solidifying third person singular present solidifies;past tense past participle solidified) to become hard or solid 凝固

solidly
/ˈsɒlɪdli ||; ˈsɑlɪdlɪ/adv
1 strongly 坚固: a solidly built house 盖得坚固的房屋
2 without stopping 连续；不停地: It rained solidly all day. 不停地下了一整天雨。

soliloquy
/səˈlɪləkwi ||; səˈlɪləkwɪ/noun [C,U] (plural soliloquies) a speech in a play in which a character, who is alone on the stage, speaks his/her thoughts aloud; the act of speaking thoughts aloud in this way （戏剧中人物独自站在舞台上）自言自语；独白: Hamlet's famous soliloquy, ‘To be or not to be...’ 《哈姆雷特》著名的独白是：“活下去还是不活…” ☞Compare monologue. 与monologue比较。 ➔soliloquize(also -ise) /səˈlɪləkwaɪz ||; səˈlɪləˌkwaɪz/ verb [I]

solitaire
/ˌsɒlɪˈteə(r); US ˈsɒlɪteə(r) ||; ˈsɑləˌtɛr/noun[U]
1 a game for one person in which you remove pieces from a special board by moving other pieces over them until you have only one piece left 单人跳棋
2 (US 美) =PATIENCE(2)

solitary
/ˈsɒlətri; US -terɪ ||; ˈsɑləˌtɛrɪ/adj
1 done alone, without other people 独力完成的: Writing novels is a solitary occupation. 写小说是一件独自工作的职业。
2 (used about a person or an animal) enjoying being alone; frequently spending time alone （指人或动物）喜欢独处的，经常独来独往的: She was always a solitary child. 她一向是个生性孤僻的孩子。
3 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) one on its/his/her own with no others around 独自一人的: a solitary figure walking up the hillside 一个孤单的身影沿山坡步行而上 [SYN] lone 同义词为lone
4 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (usually in negative sentences or questions 通常用于否定句或疑问句) only one; single 唯一的；单一的: I can't think of a solitary example (= not even one). 我一个例子也想不出来。

ˌsolitary conˈfinement
noun [U] a punishment in which a person in prison is kept completely alone in a separate cell away from the other prisoners 单独囚禁

solitude
/ˈsɒlɪtju:d; US -tu:d ||; ˈsɑləˌtud/noun [U] the state of being alone, especially when you find this pleasant 孤独，孤单，独处（尤指觉得这种状况是很愉快的）: She longed for peace and solitude. 她渴望安宁和独处。 ☞Compare loneliness and isolation. 与loneliness及isolation比较。

solo¹
/ˈsəʊləʊ ||; ˈsolo/noun [C] (plural solos) a piece of music for only one person to play or sing 独奏曲；独唱歌曲 ☞Look at duet. 参看duet。 ➔soloist noun [C]
solo²
/ˈsəʊləʊ ||; ˈsolo/adj adv
1 (done) alone; by yourself 独自（完成）；单独: a solo flight 单人飞行 to fly solo 单独飞行
2 connected with or played as a musical solo 独奏的；独唱的: a solo artist (= a singer who is not part of a group) 独唱歌手

solstice
/ˈsɒlstɪs ||; ˈsɑlstɪs/noun [C] either of the two times of the year at which the sun reaches its highest or lowest point in the sky at midday, marked by the longest and shortest days 至点（指太阳正午时在天上抵达的最高点或最低点，每年各一次，标志着这一天白天最长或最短）: the summer/winter solstice 夏至；冬至 ☞Look at equinox. 参看equinox。 ☞picture at season 见season插图

soluble
/ˈsɒljəbl ||; ˈsɑljəbḷ/adj
1 soluble (in sth) that will dissolve in liquid 可溶解的: These tablets are soluble in water. 这些药片可在水中溶解。
2 (formal 正式) (used about a problem, etc) that has an answer; that can be solved （指问题等）可以解决的，能解答的 [OPP] insoluble 反义词为insoluble

*solution
/səˈlu:ʃn ||; səˈluʃən/noun
1 [C] a solution (to sth) a way of solving a problem, dealing with a difficult situation, etc 解答或解决方法: a solution to the problem of unemployment 解决失业问题的方法
2 [C] the solution (to sth) the answer (to a game, competition etc) （游戏、比赛等的）答案: The solution to the quiz will be published next week. 测验的答案将在下星期公布。
3 [C,U] (a) liquid in which sth solid has been dissolved 溶液: saline solution 盐溶液
4 [U] the process of dissolving a solid or gas in a liquid （固体或气体在液体中的）溶解（作用）: the solution of glucose in water 葡萄糖在水中的溶解作用 ☞picture at erode 见erode插图

*solve
/sɒlv ||; sɑlv/verb[T]
1 to find a way of dealing with a problem or difficult situation 解决（困难或困境）: The government is trying to solve the problem of inflation. 政府正设法解决通胀问题。 The police have not managed to solve the crime. 警方还未能破案。 to solve a mystery 解开谜团
2 to find the correct answer to a competition, a problem in mathematics, a series of questions, etc 解答（难题或问题）: to solve a puzzle/equation/riddle 解决难题；解答方程式；猜出谜语 ☞noun solution 名词为solution ☞adjective soluble 形容词为soluble

solvent
/ˈsɒlvənt ||; ˈsɑlvənt/noun [C,U] a liquid that can dissolve another substance 溶剂

sombre
/ˈsɒmbə(r) ||; ˈsɑmbɚ/ (US 美 somber) adj
1 dark in colour; dull 灰暗的；阴沉的
2 sad and serious 忧愁的；凝重的 ➔sombrely adv

*some
/səm;strong form sʌm ||; səm; sʌm/det pronoun
1 (before uncountable nouns and plural countable nouns 用于不可数名词及复数可数名词前) a certain amount of or a number of 一些；若干: We need some butter and some potatoes. 我们需要一些黄油和马铃薯。 I don't need any more money -- I've still got some. 我不需要更多的钱─我还有一些。
In negative sentences and in questions we use any instead of some Do we need any butter? I need some more money. I haven't got any. But look at
2 for examples of questions where some is used. 在否定句和疑问句中用any，不用some：Do we need any butter? 我们需要黄油吗？·I need some money. I haven't got any.我身无分文，需要一点钱。有关some在疑问句中的示例，参看第
2义。
2 used in questions when you expect or want the answer ‘yes’ （用于预期或想要得到肯定答复的疑问句中）: Would you like some more cake? 想要再来点蛋糕吗？ Can I take some of this paper? 这纸我可以拿几张吗？
3 some (of sb/sth) used when you are referring to certain members of a group or certain types of a thing, but not all of them （指某整体中的部份）: Some pupils enjoy this kind of work, some don't. 有些学生喜欢这种作业，有些不喜欢。 Some of his books are very exciting. 他的书有些很精彩。 Some of us are going to the park. 我们有些人要去公园。
4 used with SINGULAR COUNTABLE nouns for talking about a person or thing without saying any details （与单数可数名词连用，指不具体的人或物）: I'll see you again some time, I expect. 我想我们会在某个时候再次见面。 There must be some mistake. 一定是出了什么差错。 I read about it in some newspaper or other. 我在哪份报纸上看到过这个消息。

*somebody
/ˈsʌmbədi ||; ˈsʌmbədɪ/ (also someone) pronoun a person who is not known or not mentioned by name 某人；有人: How are you? Somebody said that you'd been ill. 你好吗？有人说你病了。 She's getting married to someone she met at work. 她要和一个她工作时认识的人结婚。 There's somebody at the door. 门口有人。 I think you should talk to someone else (= another person) about this problem. 我认为这个问题你该跟别人商量。 Somebody, anybody and everybody are used with a singular verb but are often followed by a plural pronoun (except in formal language where ‘his/her’ or ‘him/her’ must be used) Somebody has left their coat behind. Has anyone not brought their books? I'll see everybody concerned and tell them the news. The difference between somebody and anybody is the same as the difference between some and any. Look at the note at some. somebody﹑anybody及everybody都和单数动词连用﹐但常配以复数代词﹙除在正式场合外﹐正式场合要用his/her或him/her﹚﹕Somebody has left their coat behind. 有人忘了大衣。Has anyone not brought their books? 有谁没有带书吗﹖I'll see everybody concerned and tell them the news. 我要见每一个有关的人﹐把这消息告诉他们。Somebody和anybody之间的区别与some和any的差别一样。参看some的注释。
ˈsome day
(also someday) adv at a time in the future that is not yet known 将来某一天；有朝一日: I hope you'll come and visit me some day. 我希望有朝一日你会来看望我。

*somehow
/ˈsʌmhaʊ ||; ˈsʌmˌhaυ/adv
1 in a way that is not known or certain 以某种方法: The car's broken down but I'll get to work somehow. 车子坏了，但我得设法上班去。 Somehow we had got completely lost. 不知怎么搞的，我们完全迷了路。
2 for a reason you do not know or understand 不知什么原因: I somehow get the feeling that I've been here before. 不知为什么我觉得我来过这里。

*someone
/ˈsʌmwʌn ||; ˈsʌmˌwʌn/ =SOMEBODY

someplace
/ˈsʌmpleɪs ||; ˈsʌmples/ (US 美) =SOMEWHERE

somersault
/ˈsʌməsɔ:lt ||; ˈsʌmɚˌsɔlt/noun [C] a movement in which you roll right over with your feet going over your head 筋斗；跟头

*something
/ˈsʌmθɪŋ ||; ˈsʌmθɪŋ/pronoun
1 a thing that is not known or not named 某事物: I've got something in my eye. 我眼睛里有东西。 Wait a minute -- I've forgotten something. 等一下─我忘了一些东西。 Would you like something else (= another thing) to drink? 你还要喝点别的什么吗？
The difference between something and anything is the same as the difference between some and any. Look at the note at some. something和anything之间的差别与some和any的差别一样。参看some的注释。
2 a thing that is important, useful or worth considering 重要、有用或值得考虑的事物: There's something in what your mother says. 你妈妈的话有点道理。 I think you've got something there -- I like that idea. 我认为你的想法有点道理，我喜欢那个主意。
3 (informal 非正式) used to show that a description, an amount, etc is not exact （用于表示某个描述、数目等不确切）: a new comedy series aimed at thirty-somethings (= people between thirty and forty years old). 一部以三十来岁的人为对象的新喜剧系列
or something(informal 非正式) used for showing that you are not sure about what you have just said （用于表示对自己刚说的话不大肯定）: ‘What's his job?’ ‘I think he's a plumber, or something.’ “他是做哪一行的？”“大概是管子工之类吧。” something like similar to 类似: A loganberry is something like a raspberry. 大杨莓跟覆盆子相类似。 something to do with connected or involved with 与…有关或相关: The programme's something to do with the environment. 这个节目的内容与环境有关。

*sometime
/ˈsʌmtaɪm ||; ˈsʌmˌtaɪm/ (also some time) adv at a time that you do not know exactly or have not yet decided 在某一时间: I'll phone you sometime this evening. 今天晚上我会打电话给你。 I must go and see her sometime. 我必须找个时间去看她。

*sometimes
/ˈsʌmtaɪmz ||; ˈsʌmˌtaɪmz/adv on some occasions; now and then 有时（候）；间或: Sometimes I drive to work and sometimes I go by bus. 我有时自己开车去上班，有时坐公共汽车。 I sometimes watch television in the evenings. 晚上我有时看电视节目。

somewhat
/ˈsʌmwɒt; US -hwɒt ||; ˈsʌmˌhwɑt/adv rather; to some degree 颇为；相当；有点: We missed the train, which was somewhat unfortunate. 我们没赶上那班火车，多少算有点倒霉。

*somewhere
/ˈsʌmweə(r); US -hweər ||; ˈsʌmˌhwɛr/ (US also 美亦作 someplace) adv
1 at, in, or to a place that you do not know or do not mention by name 在或到某地或某处: I've seen your glasses somewhere downstairs. 我在楼下什么地方看过你的眼镜。 ‘Have they gone to France?’ ‘No, I think they've gone somewhere else(= to another place) this year.’ “他们去了法国吗？”“不，我想他们今年去了别处。”
The difference between somewhere and anywhere is the same as the difference between some and any. Look at the note at some. somewhere和anywhere之间的差别与some和any的差别一样。参看some的注释。
2 used when you do not know an exact time, number, etc （用于表示不大肯定的时间、数目等）大约，左右: Your ideal weight should probably be somewhere around 70 kilos. 你的理想体重大概是70公斤左右。

*son
/sʌn ||; sʌn/noun [C] a male child 儿子 ☞Look at daughter. 参看daughter。

sonar
/ˈsəʊnɑ:(r) ||; ˈsonɑr/noun [U] equipment or a system for finding objects under water using sound waves 声纳（利用声波探测水下物体的仪器或系统） ☞Compare radar. 与radar比较。

sonata
/səˈnɑ:tə ||; səˈnɑtə/noun [C] a piece of music written for the piano, or for another instrument together with the piano 奏鸣曲

*song
/sɒŋ; US sɔ:ŋ ||; sɔŋ/noun
1 [C] a piece of music with words that you sing 歌；歌曲: a folk/love/pop song 民歌；情歌；流行歌曲
2 [U] songs in general; music for singing 歌（总称）；声乐: to burst/break into song (= to suddenly start singing) 忽然唱起歌来
3 [U] [C] the musical sounds that birds make 鸟鸣: birdsong 鸟的鸣啭

songbird
/ˈsɒŋbɜ:d; US ˈsɔ:ŋ- ||; ˈsɔŋˌbɝd/noun [C] a bird that has a musical call, for example a blackbird or thrush 鸣禽

songbook
/ˈsɒŋbʊk; US ˈsɔ:ŋ- ||; ˈsɔŋˌbuk/noun [C] a book containing the music and words of different songs 歌曲集；歌本

songwriter
/ˈsɒŋraɪtə(r) ||; ˈsɔŋˌraɪtɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is to write songs 歌曲作家

sonic
/ˈsɒnɪk ||; ˈsɑnɪk/adj (technical术语) connected with sound waves 与声波有关的

ˌsonic ˈboom
noun [C] the explosive sound that is made when an aircraft travels faster than the speed of sound 音爆，声震﹙飞机超音速飞行时发出的巨响﹚

ˈson-in-law
noun [C] (plural sons-in-law) the husband of your daughter 女儿的丈夫；女婿

sonnet
/ˈsɒnɪt ||; ˈsɑnɪt/noun [C] a poem that has 14 lines, each usually containing 10 syllables, and a fixed pattern of RHYME (= lines with the same sound at the end as other lines) 十四行诗

ˌson of a ˈgun
noun [sing] (US, informal 美，非正式)
1 a person or thing that you are annoyed with 令人烦恼的人﹙或事物﹚: My car's at the shop—the son of a gun broke down again. 我的车在维修厂呢——这破玩意儿又坏。
2 used to express the fact that you are surprised or annoyed ﹙表示惊讶或气恼﹚好家伙，他妈的: Well, son of a gun — and I thought the old guy couldn't dance! 嘿，好家伙——我还以为那老东西不会跳舞呢！

*soon
/su:n ||; sun/adv
1 in a short time from now; a short time after sth else has happened 不久: It will soon be dark. 不久便会天黑。 He left soon after me. 我走后不久他也走了。 We should arrive at your house soon after twelve. 十二点过后不久我们便可到达你的住所。 (spoken 口语) See you soon. 回头见。
2 early; quickly 早；快: Don't leave so soon. Stay for tea. 别这么快就走。留下来喝茶吧。 How soon can you get here? 你最快要多久才能到这里？
as soon as at the moment (that); when 一…就…: Phone me as soon as you hear some news. 你一听到什么消息就立即打电话给我。 I'd like your reply as soon as possible (= at the earliest possible moment). 我希望你尽快答复。 no sooner...than(written 书面语) immediately when or after 一…就…: No sooner had I shut the door than I realized I'd left my keys inside. 我一关上门就发现我把钥匙留在屋里了。 E4@@The word order is important here. The verb follows immediately after ‘No sooner’, and the subject comes after that. 这句的词序重要。动词紧随no sooner之后，然后才是主语。 sooner or later at some time in the future; one day 迟早；总有一天

soot
/sʊt ||; sυt/noun [U] black powder that comes from burning things and collects in chimneys 黑烟灰；煤灰

soothe
/su:ð ||; suð/verb[T]
1 to make sb calmer or less upset; to comfort sb 安慰；抚慰
2 to make a part of the body or a feeling less painful 减轻痛楚: The doctor gave me some skin cream to soothe the irritation. 医生给我一些皮肤药膏以减轻刺痛。 ➔soothing adj soothing music 令人心旷神怡的音乐 a soothing massage 令人舒畅的按摩 ➔soothingly adv

sophisticated
/səˈfɪstɪkeɪtɪd ||; səˈfɪstɪˌketɪd/adj
1 having or showing a lot of experience of the world and social situations; knowing about fashion, culture, etc （显得）世故的，老练的，时髦的
2 (used about machines, systems, etc) advanced and complicated （指机器、系统等）先进复杂的，精密的
3 able to understand difficult or complicated things 领悟力高的；精明的: Voters are much more sophisticated these days. 这年头选民精明多了。 ➔sophistication /səˌfɪstɪˈkeɪʃn ||; səˌfɪstɪˈkeʃən/ noun [U]

soppy
/ˈsɒpi ||; ˈsɑpɪ/adj (informal 非正式) full of unnecessary emotion; silly 滥情的；愚蠢的: a soppy romantic film 滥情的爱情文艺片

soprano
/səˈprɑ:nəʊ; US -ˈpræn- ||; səˈpræno/noun [C] (plural sopranos /-nəʊz ||; -noz/) the highest singing voice; a woman, girl, or boy with this voice 女高音（歌手）；童声高音（歌手）

sorbet
/ˈsɔ:beɪ; US ˈsɔ:rbət ||; ˈsɔrbət/noun [C,U] a sweet frozen food made from sugar, water and fruit juice, often eaten as a dessert 雪糕；冰糕

sorcerer
/ˈsɔ:sərə(r) ||; ˈsɔrsərɚ/noun [C] (in stories) a man with magic powers, who is helped by evil spirits ﹙故事中的﹚术士，男巫，巫师

sorceress
/ˈsɔ:sərəs ||; ˈsɔrsərəs/noun [C] (in stories) a woman with magic powers, who is helped by evil spirits ﹙故事中的﹚女术士，女巫，巫婆

sorcery
/ˈsɔ:səri ||; ˈsɔrsərɪ/noun [U] magic that uses evil spirits 法道；巫术: sorcery and witchcraft 巫术和妖术

sordid
/ˈsɔ:dɪd ||; ˈsɔrdɪd/adj
1 unpleasant; not honest or moral 使人不快的；卑鄙的；可耻的: We discovered the truth about his sordid past. 我们发现他过去污秽的历史。
2 very dirty and unpleasant 肮脏破败的；破破烂烂的

*sore¹
/sɔ:(r) ||; sɔr/adj (used about a part of the body) painful, especially when touched （指身体的某部位）疼痛的（尤指在触摸的时候）: to have a sore throat 喉咙痛 My feet were sore from walking so far. 走了那么远路我的脚很痛。 ➔soreness noun [U]: a cream to reduce soreness and swelling 减轻疼痛和肿胀的油膏 a sore point a subject that is likely to make sb upset or angry when mentioned 痛处；伤心事；惹某人生气的话题 stand/stick out like a sore thumb to be extremely obvious, especially in a negative way 极其明显（尤指负面地）: A big new office block would stand out like a sore thumb in the old part of town. 一座新的办公大楼将耸立在旧城区，显得格格不入。
sore²
/sɔ:(r) ||; sɔr/noun [C] a painful, often red place on your body where the skin is cut or infected （身体上的）痛处（常指割伤或感染而发红）；疮；溃疡 ☞Look at cold sore. 参看cold sore。

sorely
/ˈsɔ:li ||; ˈsɔrlɪ/adv (formal 正式) very much; seriously 非常；严重地: You'll be sorely missed when you leave. 你离开后大家会非常怀念你。

sorrow
/ˈsɒrəʊ ||; ˈsɑro/noun (formal 正式)
1 [U] a feeling of great sadness because sth bad has happened 悲痛；悲哀；忧伤
2 [C] a very sad event or situation 令人哀伤的事 ➔sorrowful adj ➔sorrowfully adv

*sorry¹
/ˈsɒri ||; ˈsɔrɪ/adj (sorrier;sorriest)
1 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) sorry (to see, hear, etc);sorry that... sad or disappointed 难过；感到遗憾；失望: I was sorry to hear that you've been ill. 听说你病了，我很难过。 I am sorry that we have to leave so soon. 很遗憾，我们那么快就得走了。 ‘Simon's mother died last week.’ ‘Oh, I am sorry.’ “西蒙的母亲上星期去世了。”“啊，真令人难过。”
2 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) sorry (for/about sth);sorry (to do sth/that...) used for excusing yourself for sth that you have done （用于道歉）: I'm awfully sorry for spilling that coffee. 我将那个咖啡洒了，实在很抱歉。 I'm sorry I've kept you all waiting. 要你们等，真对不起。 I'm sorry to disturb you so late in the evening, but I wonder if you can help me. 对不起，这么晚了我还打扰你，可是不知道你能不能帮我的忙？
3 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) used for politely saying ‘no’ to sth, disagreeing with sth or introducing bad news （用于婉拒、表示不同意或引出坏消息）: ‘Would you like to come to dinner on Friday?’ ‘I'm sorry, I'm busy that evening.’ “星期五你来吃晚饭好吗？”“对不起，那天晚上我没空。” I'm sorry, I don't agree with you. I think we should accept the offer. 对不起，我不同意你的意见。我认为我们应该接受那个建议。 I'm sorry to tell you that your application has been unsuccessful. 很抱歉，阁下的申请未获接受。
4 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) very bad 非常坏的；破破烂烂的: The house was in a sorry state when we first moved in. 我们刚搬进来时，这所房子残破不堪。 They were a sorry sight when they finally got home. 他们终于到家的时候，真是一副狼狈的样子。
be/feel sorry for sb to feel sadness or pity for sb 同情，怜悯（某人）: I feel very sorry for the families of the victims. 我很同情受害者的家人。 Stop feeling sorry for yourself! 别再自怨自怜了！
*sorry²
/ˈsɒri ||; ˈsɔrɪ/ exclamation
1 used for making excuses, apologizing, etc （用于辩解、道歉等）: Sorry, I didn't see you standing behind me. 对不起，我没有看见你站在我后面。 Sorry I'm late -- the bus didn't come on time. 对不起，我迟到了─公共汽车误点了。 He didn't even say sorry (= apologize)! 他连对不起也没说一声。
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) (used for asking sb to repeat sth that you have not heard correctly) （用于表示没有听清楚对方的话，请对方再说一遍）: ‘My name's Dave Harries.’ ‘Sorry? Dave who?’ “我的名字叫戴夫˙哈里斯。”“什么？戴夫什么？”
3 (used for correcting yourself when you have said sth wrong) （用于纠正刚说错的话）: Take the second turning, sorry, the third turning on the right. 在第二个拐弯处，对不起，是在第三个拐弯处向右边拐。

*sort¹
/sɔ:t ||; sɔrt/noun
1 [C] a sort of sb/sth a type or kind 种类；类型: What sort of music do you like? 你喜欢哪一种音乐？ She's got all sorts of problems at the moment. 她现在有各种各样的难题。 There were snacks -- peanuts, olives, that sort of thing. 有花生、橄榄之类的小吃。
2 [sing] (especially Brit 尤为英) a particular type of character; a person 某种人物；某类人 [SYN] kind 同义词为kind
a sort of sth(informal 非正式) a type of sth; sth that is similar to sth 某种；某类；类似…的事物: Can you hear a sort of ticking noise? 你听见一种嘀嗒嘀嗒的声音吗？ sort of(spoken 口语) rather; in a way 颇为；有几分: ‘Do you see what I mean?’ ‘Sort of.’ “你明白我的意思吗？”“有点明白。” I'd sort of like to go, but I'm not sure. 我有点想去，但不知该不该。
*sort²
/sɔ:t ||; sɔrt/verb[T]
1 sort sth (into sth) to put things into different groups or places, according to their type, etc; to separate things of one type from others 分类；整理: I'm just sorting these papers into the correct files. 我正在将这些文件归入合适的档案里。
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) (informal 非正式) (often passive 常用于被动语态) to find an answer to a problem or difficult situation; to organize sth/sb 找出解决方法；安排: I'll have more time when I've got things sorted at home. 我把家里的事安排好了就会有多一点时间。
sort sth out
1 to find an answer to a problem; to organize sth 找出解决办法；安排: I haven't found a flat yet but I hope to sort something out soon. 我还没找到一套公寓，但我希望很快就会找到。
2 to tidy or organize sth 整理: The toy cupboard needs sorting out. 放玩具的柜子需要好好整理。
sort through sth to look through a number of things, in order to find sth that you are looking for or to put them in order 把东西逐一查看以便整理或寻找某物

ˌso-ˈso
adj adv (informal 非正式) all right but not particularly good/well 一般；还可以；过得去: ‘How are you?’ ‘So-so.’ “你好吗？”“还好。”

soufflé
/ˈsu:fleɪ; US su:ˈfleɪ ||; suˈfle/noun [C,U] a type of food made mainly from egg whites, flour and milk, beaten together and baked until it rises 蛋奶酥

sought
past tense, past participle ofSEEK

ˈsought after
adj that people want very much, because it is of high quality or rare 竞相罗致的；很吃香的；广受欢迎的

soul
/səʊl ||; sol/noun
1 [C] the spiritual part of a person that is believed to continue to exist after the body is dead 灵魂
2 [C,U] the inner part of a person containing his/her deepest thoughts and feelings 深层的思想或感情: There was a feeling of restlessness deep in her soul. 她内心深处有一种不安定的感觉。 ☞Look at spirit. 参看spirit。
3 [C] (old-fashioned 旧) (used with adjectives) a particular type of person （与形容词连用）某种人: She's a kind soul. 她是个心地善良的人。
4 [sing] (in negative statements 用于否定句) a person 人: There wasn't a soul in sight (= there was nobody). 一个人影也没有。 Promise me you won't tell a soul. 你要向我保证不告诉任何人。
5 (also soul music) [U] a type of popular African American music 灵乐（一种美国黑人音乐）: a soul singer 一个灵乐歌手
heart and soul→HEART

soulful
/ˈsəʊlfl ||; ˈsolfḷ/adj having or showing deep feeling 深情的；充满感情的: a soulful expression 充满感情的言词

soulless
/ˈsəʊlləs ||; ˈsollɪs/adj without feeling, warmth or interest 没有感情的；没有温情的；枯燥乏味的: soulless industrial towns 没有生气的工业城镇

ˈsoul mate
noun [C] a person that you have a special friendship with because you understand each other's feelings and interests 知心朋友；知己

*sound¹
/saʊnd ||; saυnd/noun
1 [C,U] something that you hear or that can be heard 声音: the sound of voices 说话声 a clicking/buzzing/scratching sound 喀嚓声；嗡嗡声；刮擦声 After that, he didn't make a sound. 此后他就没哼过一声了。 She opened the door without a sound. 她悄悄打开门。 Light travels faster than sound. 光波比声波传送得快。 sound waves 声波 ☞picture at amplitude 见amplitude插图
2 [U] what you can hear coming from a television, radio, etc （电视机、收音机等传出的）声音，声响: Can you turn the sound up/down? 可以把声音调高╱低点吗？
by the sound of it/things judging from what sb has said or what you have read about sb/sth 根据某人所说或自己所阅读到的来判断: She must be an interesting person, by the sound of it. 听起来她该是个有趣的人。
*sound²
/saʊnd ||; saυnd/verb
1 linking verb (not usually in the continuous tenses 通常不用于进行时) to give a particular impression when heard or read about; to seem 听起来；似乎: That sounds like a child crying. 听起来好像是儿童在哭泣。 She sounded upset and angry on the phone. 听她在电话上的声音，她似乎很生气。 You sound like your father when you say things like that! 你说那种事的时候，语气十足像你父亲！ He sounds a very nice person from his letter. 从他写的信看来，他似乎是个和蔼可亲的人。 Does she sound like the right person for the job? 她看来适合做这份工作吗？ It doesn't sound as if/though he's very reliable. 他似乎不很靠得住。 ☞In spoken English, people often use ‘like’ instead of ‘as if’ or ‘as though’, especially in American English, but this is considered incorrect in written British English. 在口语中，尤其在美国英语里，常用like，而不用as if或as though。但在英国英语的书面语里，这种用法被认为是不正确的。
2 -sounding (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) seeming to be of the type mentioned, from what you have heard or read 听起来像…；读起来像…: a Spanish-sounding surname 听起来像西班牙语的姓氏
3 [T] to cause sth to make a sound; to give a signal by making a sound 使发声；发出声音作信号: to sound the horn of your car 按汽车喇叭 A student on one of the upper floors sounded the alarm. 楼上的一名学生按响了警报器。
4 [I,T] (technical术语) to measure the depth of the sea or a lake by using a line with a weight on it, or an electronic instrument （用锤或电子仪器）探测（海或湖的深度）
sound sb out (about sth) to ask sb questions in order to find out what he/she thinks or intends 试探他人的观点或意向
*sound³
/saʊnd ||; saυnd/adj
1 sensible; that you can depend on and that will probably give good results 明智的；合理的；可信赖的: sound advice 忠告 a sound investment 明智的投资
2 healthy and strong; in good condition 健康的；良好的: The structure of the bridge is basically sound. 桥梁的结构基本良好。 [OPP] unsound 反义词为unsound ➔soundness noun [U]
sound⁴
/saʊnd ||; saυnd/adv be sound asleep to be deeply asleep 沉睡；酣睡

ˈsound card
noun [C] (computing 计算机技术) a device that can be put into a computer to allow the use of sound with multimedia software 声卡

ˈsound check
noun [C] a process of checking that the equipment used for recording music, or for playing music at a concert, is working correctly and producing sound of a good quality ﹙对录音或音响设备的﹚校音

ˈsound effect
noun [C] [usu.pl] a sound that is made artificially, for example the sound of the wind, and used in a play, film or computer game to make it more realistic 音响效果

soundless
/ˈsaʊndləs ||; ˈsaundləs/adj (written 书面语) without making any sound; silent 无声的；寂静的: Her lips parted in a soundless scream. 她张开嘴想喊，但喊不出声来。 ➔soundlessly adv: He slipped soundlessly into the house. 他悄无声息地溜进了屋。

soundly
/ˈsaʊndli ||; ˈsaυndlɪ/adv completely or deeply 彻底地；深入地: The children were sleeping soundly. 孩子们正在酣睡。

soundproof
/ˈsaʊndpru:f ||; ˈsaυndˌpruf/adj made so that no sound can get in or out 隔音的: a soundproof room 隔音室

soundtrack
/ˈsaʊndtræk ||; ˈsaυndˌtræk/noun [C] the recorded sound and music from a film or computer game 电影或计算机游戏的配乐 ☞Look at track. 参看track。

*soup
/su:p ||; sup/noun [U] [C] liquid food made by cooking meat, vegetables, etc in water 汤: a tin of chicken soup 一罐鸡汤 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

*sour
/ˈsaʊə(r) ||; ˈsaυr/adj
1 having a sharp taste like that of a lemon 酸的: This sauce is quite sour. 这种调味汁很酸。
2 (used especially about milk) tasting or smelling unpleasant because it is no longer fresh （尤指牛奶）变酸的: This cream has gone sour. 这奶油变酸了。
3 (used about people) angry and unpleasant （指人）坏脾气的，令人不快的: a sour expression 难看的表情 a sour-facedold woman 面带愠色的老太太 sour verb [T] (formal 正式) The disagreement over trade tariffs has soured relations between the two countries. 贸易关税问题上的分歧使两国关系变坏了。 ➔sourly adv ➔sourness noun [U]
go/turn sour to stop being pleasant or friendly 变坏；变糟: Their relationship turned sour after a few months. 几个月后，他们的关系变坏了。 sour grapes pretending to not want sth that in fact you secretly want, because you cannot have it 酸葡萄（因为得不到而说自己不想要）

*source
/sɔ:s ||; sɔrs/noun [C] a place, person or thing where sth comes or starts from or where sth is obtained 源头；来源；根源: Britain's oil reserves are an important source of income. 英国的石油储量是重要的收入来源。 This word has its source in Greek. 这个词源于希腊语。 The television is a great source of entertainment. 电视是一种重要的娱乐。 Police have refused to reveal the source of their information. 警方拒绝透露消息来源。

*south¹
/saʊθ ||; saυθ/ (also the south) noun [sing] (abbr S)
1 the direction that is on your right when you watch the sun rise; one of the four main directions that we give names to(the points of the compass) 南；南方: warm winds from the south 南方吹来的暖风 Which way is south? 哪一边是南？ We live to the south of (= further south than) London. 我们住在伦敦以南。 ☞picture at north 见north插图
2 the South the southern part of any country, city, region or the world （国家、城市、地区或地界的）南部: Nice is in the South of France. 尼斯在法国南部。 ☞Look at north, east and west. 参看north、east及west。
south²
/saʊθ ||; saυθ/adj adv
1 (also South) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) in the south 在南方的；在南部的: the south coast of Cornwall 康沃尔市的南岸
2 to or towards the south 向南方的；朝南的: The house faces south. 那所房子朝南。 We live just south of Birmingham. 我们就住在伯明翰以南。
3 (used about a wind) coming from the south （指风）从南方吹来的

southbound
/ˈsaʊθbaʊnd ||; ˈsaυθˌbaυnd/adj travelling or leading towards the south 南行的；通往南面的

ˌsouth-ˈeast¹
(also the South-East) noun [sing] (abbr SE) the direction or a region that is halfway between south and east 东南；东南方 ☞picture at north 见north插图
ˌsouth-ˈeast²
adj adv in, from or to the south-east of a place or country 在东南；自东南；向东南: the south-east coast of Spain 西班牙东南部海岸

ˌsouth-ˈeasterly
adj
1 towards the south-east 向东南的: in a south-easterly direction 向东南方
2 (used about a wind) coming from the south-east （指风）从东南吹来的

ˌsouth-ˈeastern
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with the south-east of a place or country 与地方或国家的东南部有关的: the south-eastern states of the US 美国东南部各州

ˌsouth-ˈeastward(s)
adv towards the south-east 向东南

southerly
/ˈsʌðəli ||; ˈsʌðɚlɪ/adj
1 to, towards or in the south 向南面的；朝南面的；在南面的: Keep going in a southerly direction. 一直向南走。
2 (used about a wind) coming from the south （指风）从南方吹来的

*southern
/ˈsʌðən ||; ˈsʌðɚn/ (also Southern) adj of, in or from the south of a place 南部的；在南部的；来自南部的: a man with a southern accent 一个说话带南方口音的男子 Greece is in Southern Europe. 希腊位于南欧。

southerner
/ˈsʌðənə(r) ||; ˈsʌðɚnɚ/ (also Southerner) noun [C] a person who was born in or lives in the southern part of a country 南方人 [OPP] northerner 反义词为northerner

southpaw
/ˈsaʊθpɔ: ||; ˈsauθˌpɔ/noun [C] (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) a person who prefers to use his/her left hand rather than the right, especially in sports such as boxing or baseball ﹙尤指拳击、棒球等运动中﹚惯用左手的人，左撇子

ˌsouth-south-ˈeast
noun [sing] (abbr SSE) the direction halfway between south and south-east 南东南

ˌsouth-south-ˈwest
noun [sing] (abbr SSW) the direction halfway between south and south-west 南西南

southward
/ˈsaʊθwəd ||; ˈsaυθwɚd/ (also southwards) adj adv towards the south 向南方

ˌsouth-ˈwest¹
(also the South-West) noun [sing] (abbr SW) the direction or region halfway between south and west 西南；西南方 ☞picture at north 见north插图
ˌsouth-ˈwest²
adj adv in, from or to the south-west of a place or country 在西南；自西南；向西南: the south-west coast of France 法国西南部海岸 Our garden faces south-west. 我们的花园朝西南。

ˌsouth-ˈwesterly
adj
1 towards the south-west 向西南的: in a south-westerly direction 向西南
2 (used about a wind) coming from the south-west （指风）从西南吹来的

ˌsouth-ˈwestern
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with the south-west of a place or country 与地方或国家的西南部有关的

ˌsouth-ˈwestward(s)
adv towards the south-west 向着西南方: Follow the B409 south-westward for twenty miles. 沿着B409公路向西南方走20英里。

souvenir
/ˌsu:vəˈnɪə(r); US ˈsu:vənɪər ||; ˈsuvəˌnɪr/noun [C] something that you keep to remind you of somewhere you have been on holiday or of a special event 纪念品: I brought back a menu as a souvenir of my trip. 我带回来一份菜单作为这次旅行的纪念品。

sovereign¹
/ˈsɒvrɪn ||; ˈsɑvrɪn/noun [C] a king or queen 最高统治者；君主；元首
sovereign²
/ˈsɒvrɪn ||; ˈsɑvrɪn/adj
1 (used about a country) not controlled by any other country; independent （指国家）有主权的，独立的
2 having the highest possible authority 有最高权力的

sovereignty
/ˈsɒvrənti ||; ˈsɑvrəntɪ/noun [U] the power that a country has to control its own government 主权

sow¹
/saʊ ||; saυ/noun [C] an adult female pig 母猪 ☞Look at the note at pig. 参看pig的注释。
sow²
/səʊ ||; so/verb [T] (past tense sowed;past participle sown /səʊn ||; son/or sowed)sow A (in B);sow B (with A) to plant seeds in the ground 把植物种子埋在地里或土里；播种: to sow seeds in pots 在花盆里埋下种子 to sow a field with wheat 在田里播下小麦种子

ˈsoya bean
(US 美 soy bean) noun [C] a type of bean that can be cooked and eaten or used to make many different kinds of food, for example flour, oil and a sort of milk 大豆

spa
/spɑ: ||; spɑ/noun [C] a place where mineral water comes out of the ground and where people go to drink this water because it is considered to be healthy 矿泉

ˌsoy ˈsauce
(also ˌsoya ˈsauce) noun [U] a thin dark brown sauce that is made from soya beans and has a salty taste, used in Chinese and Japanese cooking 酱油

soya
/ˈsɔɪə ||; ˈsɔɪə/ (US 美 soy /sɔɪ ||; sɔɪ/) noun [U] a plant on which soya beans grow; the food obtained from those beans 大豆（指长大豆的植物）；大豆制品: soya flour/milk/oil 豆粉；豆奶；豆油

*space¹
/speɪs ||; spes/noun
1 [C,U] space (for sb/sth) (to do sth) a place or an area that is empty or not used 空间；空地；空白: Is there enough space for me to park the car there? 那儿有足够的地方让我停车吗？ Shelves would take up less spacethan a cupboard. 架子要比橱柜占的空间少。 a parking space 停车位 We're a bit short of space. 我们地方不大够用。 There's a space here for you to write your name. 这儿有个空白让你填上名字。 Leave a space after the comma. 逗号后面要空一格。 ☞Look at room and the note at place ¹. 参看room及place^1的注释。
2 [U] (also ˌouter ˈspace) (often used to form compound nouns 常用于构成复合名词) the area which surrounds the planet Earth and the other planets and stars 太空；外层空间: space travel 太空旅行 a spaceman/spacewoman (= a person who travels in space) 航天员；宇航员 a spacecraft/spaceship 宇宙飞船；宇宙飞船
3 [C] [usu.sing] a period of time 一段时间: Priti had been ill three times in / within the space offour months. 普里蒂在四个月内病了三次。 He's achieved a lot in a short space of time. 他在短时间内取得了巨大成就。
4 [U] time and freedom to think and do what you want 思考或做某事的时间和自由；余地: I need some space to think. 我需要有点思考的余地。
space²
/speɪs ||; spes/verb [T] space sth (out) to arrange things so that there are empty spaces between them 使隔开；留间隔

ˈspace-age
adj (informal 非正式) (used especially about design or technology) very modern and advanced ﹙尤指设计或技术﹚太空时代的，非常先进的: a space-age kitchen 太空时代的厨房

ˈspace bar
noun [C] a bar on the keyboard of a computer or typewriter that you press to make spaces between words ﹙计算机键盘或打字机的﹚空格键

spacecraft
/ˈspeɪskrɑ:ft ||; ˈspesˌkræft/noun [C] (plural spacecraft) a vehicle that travels in space 航天器；宇宙飞船；宇宙飞船

spaced
/speɪst ||; spest/ (also ˌspaced ˈout)adj (informal 非正式) not completely conscious of what is happening around you, often because of taking drugs ﹙常指吸食毒品后﹚精神恍惚的，神志迷糊的: He sat in the corner looking completely spaced out. 他坐在角落里，看来完全神志不清。

spaceman
/ˈspeɪsmæn ||; ˈspesˌmæn/noun [C] (plural spacemen /-men ||; -ˌmɛn/)
1 (informal 非正式) a man who travels into space; an astronaut 宇航员；航天员
2 (in stories) a creature that visits the earth from another planet ﹙故事中的﹚外星人 [SYN]alien 同义词为 alien

spaceship
/ˈspeɪsʃɪp ||; ˈspesˌʃɪp/noun [C] a vehicle that travels in space, carrying people （载人的）宇宙飞船，宇宙飞船

ˈspace shuttle
noun [C] a spacecraft designed to be used, e.g. for travelling between the earth and a space station 航天飞机

ˈspace station
noun [C] a large structure that is sent into space and remains above the Earth as a base for people working and travelling in space 太空站；航天站；宇航站

spacesuit
/ˈspeɪssu:t ||; ˈspesˌsut/noun [C] a special suit that covers the whole body and has a supply of air, allowing sb to survive and move around in space 航天服；宇宙飞行服

spacewalk
/ˈspeɪswɔ:k ||; ˈspesˌwɔk/noun [C] a period of physical activity by an astronaut in space outside a spacecraft 太空行走，航天器外活动

spacey ( also spacy)
/ˈspeɪsi ||; ˈspesɪ/adj (spacier; spaciest) (informal 非正式) = spaced⇒

spacing
/ˈspeɪsɪŋ ||; ˈspesɪŋ/noun[U]
1 the amount of space that is left between things, especially between the words or lines printed on a page ﹙空间﹚间隔；字距；行距: single/double spacing (= with one or two lines left between lines of type) 单行/双行行距
2 the amount of time that is left between things happening ﹙时间﹚间隔: In music, the spacing of intervals is vital. 在音乐中，音程间隔长度至关重要。

spacious
/ˈspeɪʃəs ||; ˈspeʃəs/adj having a lot of space; large in size 宽敞的；广阔的 ➔spaciousness noun [U]

spade
/speɪd ||; sped/noun
1 [C] a tool that you use for digging 铲；铁锹 ☞Look at shovel. 参看shovel。 ☞pictures at dig and garden 见dig及garden插图
2 spades [pl] the group (suit) of playing cards with pointed black symbols on them 黑桃花色的纸牌: the king of spades 黑桃K ☞Look at the note and picture at card. 参看card的注释及插图。
3 [C] one of the cards from this suit （扑克中的一张）黑桃牌: Have you got a spade? 0

spaghetti
/spəˈgeti ||; spəˈgɛtɪ/noun [U] a type of Italian food (pasta) made from flour and water that looks like long strings 意大利面条: How long does spaghetti take to cook? 煮意大利面条要花多长时间？ ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

spam
/spæm ||; spæm/verb [T] (spamming; spammed) to send the same e-mail message to a large number of people, usually in order to advertise sth 向…大量发送电邮广告 ➔spammer noun [C]

span¹
/spæn ||; spæn/noun[C]
1 the length of sth from one end to the other 跨度；跨距: the wingspan of a bird 鸟的翼展
2 the length of time that sth lasts or continues 持续的一段时间: Young children have a short attention span. 小孩子不能长时间集中精神。
span²
/spæn ||; spæn/verb [T] (spanning;spanned)
1 to form a bridge over sth 架桥
2 to last or continue for a particular period of time 持续

spaniel
/ˈspænjəl ||; ˈspænjəl/noun [C] a dog with large soft ears that hang down. There are several types of spaniel. 獚狗，西班牙猎狗﹙大耳下垂，类型甚多﹚: a cocker spaniel 猎鹬獚 a springer spaniel 惊飞獚

spank
/spæŋk ||; spæŋk/verb [T] to hit a child on his/her bottom with an open hand as a punishment （用巴掌）打小孩屁股（作为惩罚）

spanner
/ˈspænə(r) ||; ˈspænɚ/ (US 美 wrench) noun [C] a metal tool with an end shaped for turning small metal rings(nuts)and pins(bolts)that are used for holding things together 扳子；扳手；扳钳 ☞Look at adjustable spanner. 参看adjustable spanner。 ☞picture at tool 见tool插图

spar
/spɑ:(r) ||; spɑr/verb [I] (sparring; sparred)
1 to make the movements used in boxing, either in training or to test the speed of your opponent's reaction 练习拳击；虚晃一拳
2 to argue with sb, usually in a friendly way ﹙多指在友好气氛中﹚辩论，争论

*spare¹
/speə(r) ||; spɛr/adj
1 not needed now but kept because it may be needed in the future 备用的；后备的: The spare tyre is kept in the boot. 备用车胎放在行李箱里。 a spare room 备用房间
2 not used for work 工余的；闲暇的: What do you do in your spare time ? 你闲暇时做些什么？
3 not being used; free 未用的；空着的: There were no seats spare so we had to stand. 没有多出来的座位，我们只好站着。 spare noun [C]: The fuse has blown. Where do you keep your spares? 保险丝烧坏了，备用的你放在哪里？
spare²
/speə(r) ||; spɛr/verb[T]
1 spare sth (for sb);spare (sb) sth to be able to give sth to sb 腾出；拨出: I suppose I can spare you a few minutes. 我想我能抽出几分钟见你。
2 spare sb (from) sth/doing sth to save sb from having an unpleasant experience 使避免（不愉快的经历）: You could spare yourself waiting if you book in advance. 如果你事先预约，就不必等候了。
3 spare no effort, expense, etc to do sth as well as possible without limiting the money, time, etc involved 不遗余力；不惜花费: No expense was spared at the wedding. 他们不惜花费办婚礼。 He spared no effort in trying to find a job. 他不遗余力试图找一份工作。
4 spare sb/sth (from sth) to not hurt or damage sb/sth 不伤害或损坏
to spare more than is needed 多余；剩余: There's no time to spare. We must leave straight away. 没有多余时间了，我们必须立即离开。

ˌspare ˈpart
noun [C] a part for a machine, engine, etc that you can use to replace an old part which is damaged or broken 备用零件

ˌspare ˈrib
noun [C] a bone(rib)with some meat on it from a pig that we cook and eat 小排骨；带肉的猪肋骨

sparing
/ˈspeərɪŋ ||; ˈspɛrɪŋ/adj (formal 正式) using only a little of sth; careful 省着用；节省 ➔sparingly adv

spark¹
/spɑ:k ||; spɑrk/noun
1 [C] a very small bright piece of burning material 火花；火星: A spark set fire to the carpet. 火花使地毯着火。
2 [C] a flash of light that is caused by electricity 电火花；电闪光: A spark ignites the fuel in a car engine. 电火花点着了汽车发动机里的汽油。
3 [C,U] an exciting quality that sb/sth has （某人或某物所具有的）生气，活力
spark²
/spɑ:k ||; spɑrk/verb spark sth off to cause sth 造成；引发: Eric's comments sparked off a tremendous argument. 埃里克的评论引发了一场大争论。

sparkle
/ˈspɑ:kl ||; ˈspɑrkḷ/verb [I] to shine with many small points of light 闪烁；闪: The river sparkled in the sunlight. 河水在阳光下闪烁。 sparkle noun [C,U]

sparkler
/ˈspɑ:klə(r) ||; ˈspɑrklɚ/noun [C] a type of small firework that you hold in your hand and light. It burns with many bright sparks¹(1). 烟花棒

sparkling
/ˈspɑ:klɪŋ ||; ˈspɑrkḷɪŋ/adj
1 shining with many small points of light 闪烁的: sparkling blue eyes 闪闪发亮的蓝眼睛
2 (used about a drink) containing bubbles of gas （指饮料）有泡沫的: sparkling wine/mineral water 冒着泡沫的葡萄酒╱矿泉水 ☞picture at bubble 见bubble插图

ˈspark plug
noun [C] a small piece of equipment in an engine that produces a bright flash of electricity (a spark) to make the fuel burn and start the engine 火花塞（引擎内产生电火花的点火装置）

ˈsparring partner
noun [C]
1 a person that you regularly have friendly arguments or discussions with 切磋问题的对手
2 (in boxing 拳击) a person that a boxer regularly practises with during training 陪练

sparrow
/ˈspærəʊ ||; ˈspæro/noun [C] a small brown and grey bird that is common in many parts of the world 麻雀

sparse
/spɑ:s ||; spɑrs/adj small in quantity or amount 稀少的；稀疏的: a sparse crowd 一小群人 He just had a few sparse hairs on his head. 他头上只有稀稀落落的几根头发。 ➔sparsely adv a sparsely populated area 人烟稀少的地区 ➔sparseness noun [U]

spartan
/ˈspɑ:tn ||; ˈspɑrtṇ/adj (formal 正式) very simple and not comfortable 简朴的；艰苦的: spartan living conditions 简朴刻苦的生活条件

spasm
/ˈspæzəm ||; ˈspæzəm/noun [C,U] a sudden movement of a muscle that you cannot control 痉挛；抽搐: He had painful muscular spasms in his leg. 他腿部肌肉痉挛，痛得很。

spasmodic
/spæzˈmɒdɪk ||; spæzˈmɑdɪk/adj
1 happening suddenly for short periods of time; not regular or continuous 一阵阵的；阵发性的；断断续续的: There was spasmodic fighting in the area yesterday. 昨天，那一地区发生过零星的交火。
2 (technical 术语) caused by your muscles becoming tight in a way that you cannot control 痉挛﹙性﹚的: spasmodic movements 痉挛性动作 ➔spasmodically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

spat
past tense, past participle ofSPIT¹

spate
/speɪt ||; spet/noun [sing] a large number or amount of sth happening at one time （突然发生的）一连串或一大批事情: There has been a spate of burglaries in the area recently. 该区近来发生一连串入户盗窃案。

spatial
/ˈspeɪʃl ||; ˈspeʃəl/adj (formal 正式) connected with the size or position of sth 与空间有关的

spatter
/ˈspætə(r) ||; ˈspætɚ/verb [T] spatter sb/sth (with sth);spatter sth (on sb/sth) to cover sb/sth with small drops of sth wet 溅；泼

spatula
/ˈspætʃələ ||; ˈspætʃələ/noun [C] a tool with a wide flat part used in cooking for mixing and spreading things （做饭时调拌和涂敷用的）抹刀，刮勺 ☞picture at kitchen 见kitchen插图

spawn
/spɔ:n ||; spɔn/verb
1 [I] (used about fish, frogs, etc) to lay eggs ﹙鱼、蛙等﹚产卵
2 [T] to cause sth to develop or be produced 引发；引起；导致；造成: The band's album spawned a string of hit singles. 这个乐队的专辑孵化出一连串走红的单曲唱片。

*speak
/spi:k ||; spik/verb (past tense spoke /spəʊk ||; spok/ past participle spoken /ˈspəʊkən ||; ˈspokən/)
1 [I] speak (to sb) (about sb/sth);speak (of sth) to talk or say things 说话；谈话: I'd like to speak to the manager, please. 我想跟经理谈谈。 Could you speak more slowly? 你可以说得慢一点吗？ I was so angry I could hardly speak. 我气得说不出话来。 ☞ Speak and talk have almost the same meaning but we use talk more informally, to show that two or more people are having a conversation, and speak to show that only one person is saying something, especially in a formal situation I'd like to speak to the manager, please. We talked all night. The head teacher spoke to the class about university courses. speak和talk差不多同义﹐但talk用于非正式场合﹐表示两个或以上人交谈﹐speak则表示一个人说话﹐尤指在正式的场合﹕I'd like to speak to the manager, please. 我想跟经理谈谈。We talked all night.我们谈了一整夜。The head teacher spoke to the class about university courses.校长向全班学生介绍大学课程。
2 [T] (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时) to know and be able to use a language 会，懂（某种语言）: Does anyone here speak German? 这里有人会说德语吗？ She speaks (in) Greek to her parents. 她跟父母说希腊语。 a French-speaking guide 说法语的导游
3 [I] speak (on/about sth) to make a speech to a group of people 演说；演讲；讲话
4 [I] (informal 非正式)be speaking (to sb) to be friendly with sb again after an argument （争吵过后）和好
be on speaking terms (with sb) to be friendly with sb again after an argument （争吵过后）和好: Thankfully they are back on speaking terms again. 谢天谢地，他们又和好如初了。 so to speak used when you are describing sth in a way that sounds strange （用于形容不寻常的事物）可以说: She turned green, so to speak, after watching a television programme about the environment. 她看过一个有关自然环境的电视节目后，可以说是变成了环保分子。 speak for itself to be very clear so that no other explanation is needed 不言而喻: The statistics speak for themselves. 这些统计数字不言自明。 speak/talk of the devil→DEVIL speak your mind to say exactly what you think, even though you might offend sb 直言不讳 speak for sb to express the thoughts or opinions of sb else 代某人发言 speak out (against sth) to say publicly that you think sth is bad or wrong 公开反对（某事物） speak up to speak louder 提高嗓子说话

speaker
/ˈspi:kə(r) ||; ˈspikɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who makes a speech to a group of people 演说者；讲话者: Tonight's speaker is a well-known writer and journalist. 今晚的讲话人是一位著名的作家兼新闻记者。
2 a person who speaks a particular language 操某种语言的人: She's a fluent Russian speaker. 她俄语说得很流利。
3 =LOUDSPEAKER(1)

spear
/spɪə(r) ||; spɪr/noun [C] a long pole with a sharp point at one end, used for hunting or fighting 矛；标枪

spearhead
/ˈspɪəhed ||; ˈspɪrˌhɛd/noun [C] [usu.sing] a person or group that begins or leads an attack 先锋；先头部队 spearhead verb [T]

spearmint
/ˈspɪəmɪnt ||; ˈspɪrˌmɪnt/noun [U] a type of leaf with a strong fresh taste that is used in sweets, etc 留兰香；绿薄荷: spearmint chewing gum 留兰香口香糖 ☞Look at peppermint. 参看peppermint。

spec
/spek ||; spɛk/noun [C] a detailed description of sth, especially the design and materials needed to produce sth 规格: We want the machine manufactured to our own spec. 我们要求这台机器按我们自己的规格来制造。 ☞ Look at specification. 参看 specification。

*special¹
/ˈspeʃl ||; ˈspɛʃəl/adj
1 not usual or ordinary; important for some particular reason 特别的；特殊的: a special occasion 特别场合 Please take special care of it. 请予以特别关照。 Are you doing anything special tonight? 今天晚上你有特别的事吗？
2 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) for a particular purpose 专门的；特设的: Andy goes to a special school for the deaf. 安迪上专门为失聪者设立的特殊学校。 There's a special tool for doing that. 做那个要用专门的工具。
special²
/ˈspeʃl ||; ˈspɛʃəl/noun [C] something that is not of the usual or ordinary type 特别的事物: an all-night election special on TV 电视上通宵播出的选举特辑 I'm going to cook one of my specials tonight. 今天晚上我要做一道自己的拿手菜。

ˈspecial agent
noun [C] a detective who works for the federal government in the US, for example for the FBI 特工；特务

ˌspecial eduˈcation
(also informal 非正式 ˌspecial ˈed /ˌspeʃl ˈed ||; ˌspɛʃəl ˈɛd/) noun [U] the education of children who have physical or learning problems 特殊教育

ˌspecial efˈfects
noun [pl] unusual or exciting pieces of action in films/movies or television shows, that are created by computers or special photographic techniques to show things that do not normally exist or happen 特技效果

specialist
/ˈspeʃəlɪst ||; ˈspɛʃəlɪst/noun [C] a person with special or deep knowledge of a particular subject 专家: She's a specialist in diseases of cattle. 她是牛疾病的专家。 I have to see a heart specialist. 我要去看心脏专科医生。 to give specialist advice 给予专业意见

speciality
/ˌspeʃiˈæləti ||; ˌspɛʃɪˈælətɪ/noun [C] (plural specialities) (US 美 specialty plural specialties)
1 an area of study or a subject that you know a lot about 专门研究的范围；专业
2 something made by a person, place, business, etc that is very good and that he/she/it is known for 有名的产品或服务；特产: The cheese is a speciality of the region. 干酪是该区的特产。

specialize
/ˈspeʃəlaɪz ||; ˈspɛʃəlˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [I] specialize (in sth) to give most of your attention to one subject, type of product, etc 专门研究，专门从事（某科目、产品等）: This shop specializes in clothes for taller men. 这家商店专卖高身材男士穿的衣服。 ➔specialization(also -isation) /ˌspeʃəlaɪˈzeɪʃn; US -lɪˈz- ||; ˌspɛʃəlɪˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

specialized
/ˈspeʃəlaɪzd ||; ˈspɛʃəlˌaɪzd/ (also -ised) adj
1 to be used for a particular purpose 为特定用途的；专门的: a specialized system 专门系统
2 having or needing deep or special knowledge of a particular subject 专业的；专科的: We have specialized staff to help you with any problems. 任何困难我们都有专家帮助你解决。

specially
/ˈspeʃəli ||; ˈspɛʃəlɪ/ (also especially) adv
1 for a particular purpose or reason 为特别用途或理由: I made this specially for you. 我特地为你做了这个。
2 particularly; very; more than usual 特别；非常；异常: The restaurant has a great atmosphere but the food is not specially good. 这餐馆气氛挺不错，但菜并不特别好。 It's not an especially difficult exam. 这次考试并不特别难。

ˌspecial ˈneeds
noun [pl] needs that a person has because of mental or physical problems ﹙智力或身体障碍者的﹚特殊需要: She teaches children with special needs. 她教的是有特殊需要的儿童。

specialty
/ˈspeʃəlti ||; ˈspɛʃəltɪ/ (US 美) =SPECIALITY

*species
/ˈspi:ʃi:z ||; ˈspiʃiz/noun [C] (plural species) a group of plants or animals that are all the same and that can breed together （生物的）种: This conservation group aims to protect endangered species. 这个自然保护组织旨在保护濒临绝种的物种。 a rare species of frog 一种罕见的青蛙

*specific
/spəˈsɪfɪk ||; spɪˈsɪfɪk/adj
1 specific (about sth) detailed or exact 具体的；确切的；明确的: You must give the class specific instructions on what they have to do. 你必须给班上学生明确的指示该做些什么。 Can you be more specific about what the man was wearing? 你能不能说具体一点，那男人究竟穿什么衣服？
2 particular; not general 特定的；独特的: Everyone has been given a specific job to do. 每个人都获帕特定的工作。 ➔specifically /-kli ||; -kḷɪ/ adv a play written specifically for radio 专门为电台撰写的剧本

specification
/ˌspesɪfɪˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌspɛsəfəˈkeʃən/noun [C,U] detailed information about how sth is or should be built or made 规格；具体说明

specifics
/spəˈsɪfɪks ||; spəˈsɪfɪks/noun [pl] the details of a subject that you need to think about or discuss 详情；细节: Okay, that's the broad plan — let's get down to the specifics. 好，那是总的计划——下面来谈谈具体细节。

specify
/ˈspesɪfaɪ ||; ˈspɛsəˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle specifying third person singular present specifies;past tense past participle specified) to say or name sth clearly or in detail 指明；详细说明: The fire regulations specify the maximum number of people allowed in. 消防条例明确规定入场人数的上限。

specimen
/ˈspesɪmən ||; ˈspɛsəmən/noun[C]
1 an example of a particular type of thing, especially intended to be studied by experts or scientists （可代表某类事物的）标本，样本，样品（尤指供专家或科学家研究的）
2 a small amount of sth that is tested for medical or scientific purposes （用作化验或研究的）标本，抽样: Specimens of the patient's blood were tested in the hospital laboratory. 病人的血样在医院化验室作了化验。 [SYN] sample 同义词为sample

speck
/spek ||; spɛk/noun [C] a very small spot or mark 小点；斑点: a speck of dust/dirt 一粒灰尘；一点污垢

specs
/speks ||; spɛks/ (informal 非正式)=GLASSES

spectacle
/ˈspektəkl ||; ˈspɛktəkḷ/noun [C] something that is impressive or shocking to look at 壮观的场面；奇观

spectacles
/ˈspektəklz ||; ˈspɛktəkḷz/ (formal 正式)=GLASSES

spectacular
/spekˈtækjələ(r) ||; spɛkˈtækjəlɚ/adj very impressive to see 壮观的；蔚为奇观的: The view from the top of the hill is quite spectacular. 从山顶往下望，景色颇为壮观。 ➔spectacularly adv

spectate
/spekˈteɪt ||; spɛkˈtet/verb [I] to watch sth, especially a sports event 观看﹙体育比赛等﹚

*spectator
/spekˈteɪtə(r); US ˈspekteɪtər ||; ˈspɛktetɚ/noun [C] a person who is watching an event, especially a sporting event 观看者（尤指体育比赛的观众）

spectre
/ˈspektə(r) ||; ˈspɛktɚ/ (US 美 specter) noun [C]
1 something unpleasant that people are afraid might happen in the future （对未来情况的）恐惧，忧虑: the spectre of unemployment 失业的恐惧
2 (old-fashioned 旧)=GHOST

spectrum
/ˈspektrəm ||; ˈspɛktrəm/noun [C] [usu.sing] (plural spectra /ˈspektrə ||; ˈspɛktrə/)
1 the set of seven colours into which white light can be separated 光谱: You can see the colours of the spectrum in a rainbow. 从彩虹中可以看到光谱的颜色。
2 all the possible varieties of sth 系列；范围: The speakers represented the whole spectrum of political opinions. 演讲者代表着所有不同的政治见解。

speculate
/ˈspekjuleɪt ||; ˈspɛkjəˌlet/verb
1 [I,T] speculate (about/on sth);speculate that... to make a guess about sth 推测；猜测 [I] to speculate about the result of the next election 猜测下次选举的结果
2 [I] to buy and sell with the aim of making money but with the risk of losing it 投机买卖: to speculate on the stock market 在股票市场投机买卖 ➔speculation /ˌspekjuˈleɪʃn ||; ˌspɛkjəˈleʃən/ noun [U] [C] ➔speculator noun [C]

speculative
/ˈspekjələtɪv ||; ˈspɛkjəˌletɪv/adj
1 based on guessing without knowing all the facts; showing that you are trying to guess sth 推测的；猜测的: a speculative look/glance 狐疑的神情╱一瞥
2 (in business 商业) done with the aim of making money but also with the risk of losing it 投机的；冒风险的: speculative investment 有风险的投资

sped
past tense, past participle ofSPEED²

*speech
/spi:tʃ ||; spitʃ/noun
1 [C] a formal talk that you give to a group of people 演说；演讲: The Chancellor is going to make a speech to city businessmen. 财政大臣将向该市的企业家演讲。
2 [U] the ability to speak 说话能力: He lost the power of speech after the accident. 事故以后他失去了说话能力。 freedom of speech (= being allowed to express your opinions openly) 言论自由
3 [U] the particular way of speaking of a person or group of people 说话方式: She's doing a study of children's speech. 她正在研究儿童的话语。
4 [C] a group of words that one person must say in a play 台词

speechless
/ˈspi:tʃləs ||; ˈspitʃləs/adj not able to speak, for example because you are shocked, angry, etc （因震惊、愤怒等而）说不出话的

ˈspeech marks
=QUOTATION MARKS

ˌspeech ˈtherapy
noun [U] special treatment to help people who have problems in speaking clearly, for example in pronouncing particular sounds 言语治疗；言语矫治 ➔ˌspeech ˈtherapist noun [C]

speechwriter
/ˈspi:tʃraɪtə(r) ||; ˈspitʃˌraɪtɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is to write speeches for a politician or public figure 演讲稿撰写人

*speed¹
/spi:d ||; spid/noun
1 [U] fast movement 迅速: I intend to start the race slowly and gradually pick up speed. 比赛开始时我打算慢慢跑，然后渐渐加快速度。 The bus was travelling at speed when it hit the wall. 公共汽车在快速行驶时撞在墙上。
2 [C,U] the rate at which sb/sth moves or travels 速度；速率: The car was travelling at a speed of 140 kilometres an hour. 汽车正以时速140公里行驶。 to travel at top/ high/ full/ maximum speed. 以全速╱高速╱全速╱最高速度行驶
speed²
/spi:d ||; spid/verb [I] (past tense past participle sped /sped ||; spɛd/)
1 to go or move very quickly 以高速前进或移动: He sped round the corner on his bicycle. 他骑自行车急速绕过拐角。
2 (only used in the continuous tenses 只用于进行时) to drive a car, etc faster than the legal speed limit 超速行车等: The police said she had been speeding. 警方说她超速行车。
speed (sth) up (past tense past participle speeded) to go or make sth go faster 加速；加快: The new computer system should speed up production in the factory. 新的计算机系统应该能加快工厂的生产。

speedboat
/ˈspi:dbəʊt ||; ˈspidˌbot/noun [C] a small fast boat with an engine 快艇；汽艇

ˈspeed bump
noun [C] a narrow raised area across a road that is put there to make traffic go slower ﹙设在路上的﹚减速路脊

ˈspeed dial
noun [U] a feature on a telephone that allows you to dial a phone number very quickly by just pressing one or two buttons 快速拨号﹙功能﹚

speeding
/ˈspi:dɪŋ ||; ˈspidɪŋ/noun [U] driving a car, etc faster than the legal speed limit 超速行车等

ˈspeed limit
noun [C] [usu.sing] the highest speed that you may drive without breaking the law on a particular road （道路的）速度限制: He was going way over the speed limit when the police stopped him. 他被警察拦截时，正在超速行驶。

speedometer
/spi:ˈdɒmɪtə(r) ||; spiˈdɑmətɚ/noun [C] a piece of equipment in a vehicle that tells you how fast you are travelling （车辆的）速度计，速率计 ☞picture at car 见car插图

ˈspeed-read
verb [I,T] to read very quickly, paying attention to sentences and phrases rather than to every word 快速阅读 ➔ˈspeed-reading noun [U]

ˈspeed trap
noun [C] a place on a road where police use special equipment to catch drivers who are going too fast 汽车超速监视区

speedway
/ˈspi:dweɪ ||; ˈspidˌwe/noun [U] the sport of racing motorbikes around a track （在跑道上进行的）摩托车赛

speedy
/ˈspi:di ||; ˈspidɪ/adj fast; quick 快速的；迅速的: a speedy response/reply 快速反应╱回答 ➔speedily adv ➔speediness noun [U]

*spell¹
/spel ||; spɛl/verb (past tense past participle spelled /speld ||; spɛld/or spelt /spelt ||; spɛlt/)
1 [I,T] to write or say the letters of a word in the correct order 拼写: I could never spell very well at school. 我在学校时拼写总不是很好。 How do you spell your surname? 你的姓氏怎样拼？ His name is spelt P-H-I-L-I-P. 他的名字的拼法是P-H-I-L-I-P。
2 [T] (used about a set of letters) to form a particular word （指一组字母）构成某个词: If you add an ‘e’ to ‘car’ it spells ‘care’. car加个e就成了care。
3 [T] to mean sth; to have sth as a result 意味着，带来（某种结果）: Another poor harvest would spell disaster for the region. 如果再次歉收，就会给这个地区带来灾祸。
spell sth out
1 to write or say the letters of a word or name in the correct order 正确写出或说出某个词的拼法: I have an unusual name, so I always have to spell it out to people. 我的名字很特别，我总是得拼给人家听。
2 to express sth in a very clear and direct way 讲清楚（某事）
spell²
/spel ||; spɛl/noun[C]
1 a short period of time 一段短时间: a spell of cold weather 短短的一段寒冷天气
2 (especially in stories) magic words or actions that cause sb to be in a particular state or condition （尤在故事中）咒语，魔法，符咒

spellbinding
/ˈspelbaɪndɪŋ ||; ˈspɛlˌbaɪndɪŋ/adj holding your attention completely 让人着魔的；迷人的: a spellbinding performance 使人入迷的演出

spellbound
/ˈspelbaʊnd ||; ˈspɛlˌbaund/adj with your attention completely held by what you are listening to or watching 入迷的；出神的: a storyteller who can hold audiences spellbound 讲故事能让听众如痴如醉的人 The kids watched and listened spellbound to the performance. 孩子们聚精会神地观看表演。

ˈspell check
verb [I,T] to use a computer program to check your writing to see if your spelling is correct （用计算机程序）检查拼写 ➔ˈspell check noun [C] =SPELLCHECKER

spellchecker
/ˈspeltʃekə(r) ||; ˈspɛlˌtʃɛkɚ/ (also spell check) noun [C] a computer program that checks your writing to see if your spelling is correct 计算机拼写检查程序

speller
/ˈspelə(r) ||; ˈspɛlɚ/noun [C] if sb is a good/bad speller, he/she finds it easy/difficult to spell words correctly ﹙善于或不善于﹚拼写的人

spelling
/ˈspelɪŋ ||; ˈspɛlɪŋ/noun
1 [C,U] the way that letters are arranged to make a word 拼法: ‘Center’ is the American spelling of ‘centre’. center是centre的美国拼法。
2 [U] the ability to write the letters of a word correctly 拼写能力: Roger is very poor at spelling. 罗杰的拼写能力很差。

spelt
past tense, past participle ofSPELL¹

*spend
/spend ||; spɛnd/verb (past tense past participle spent /spent ||; spɛnt/)
1 [I,T] spend (sth) (on sth) to give or pay money for sth 花费（金钱） · How much do you spend on food each week? 你每星期花多少钱买食物？ You shouldn't go on spending like that. 你不该继续那样花钱。
2 [T] spend sth (on sth/doing sth) to pass time 度过，消磨（时间）: I spent a whole evening writing letters. 我花了整个晚上写信。 I'm spending the weekend at my parents' house. 我将在父母处过周末。 He spent two years in Rome. 他在罗马待了两年。 I don't want to spend too much time on this project. 我不想在这项计划上花太多时间。

spender
/ˈspendə(r) ||; ˈspɛndɚ/noun [C] a person who spends money in the particular way mentioned 花钱…的人: a big spender (= who spends a lot of money)花钱大手大脚的人

spending
/ˈspendɪŋ ||; ˈspɛndɪŋ/noun [U] the amount of money that is spent by a government or an organization 开支；支出

spendthrift
/ˈspendθrɪft ||; ˈspɛndˌθrɪft/noun [C] a person who spends too much money or who wastes money 花钱无度的人；挥霍者 ➔spendthrift adj: spendthrift governments/ institutions 花钱无度的政府机关/社会机构

sperm
/spɜ:m ||; spɝm/noun
1 [C] (plural sperm or sperms) a cell that is produced in the sex organs of a male and that can join with a female egg to produce young 精子
2 [U] the liquid that contains sperms 精液

ˈsperm bank
noun [C] a place where sperm is kept and then used to help women become pregnant artificially 精子库

spermicide
/ˈspɜ:mɪsaɪd ||; ˈspɝməˌsaɪd/noun [C,U] a substance that kills sperm, used during sex to prevent the woman from becoming pregnant 杀精子剂 ➔spermicidal /ˌspɜ:mɪˈsaɪdl ||; ˌspɝməˈsaɪdḷ/ adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前): spermicidal cream 杀精乳膏

ˈsperm whale
noun [C] a large whale that is hunted for its oil and fat 抹香鲸

spew
/spju: ||; spju/verb[I,T]
1 spew (sth) (out) to flow out quickly, or to make sth flow out quickly, in large amounts ﹙使﹚喷出，涌出: Massive chimneys were spewing out smoke. 一座座巨大的烟囱冒着烟。 Flames spewed from the aircraft's engine. 飞机发动机喷出火焰。
2 spew (sth) (up) (informal 非正式) to vomit 呕吐

sphere
/sfɪə(r) ||; sfɪr/noun[C]
1 any round object shaped like a ball 球体；球形 ☞pictures at cube and solid 见cube及solid插图
2 an area of interest or activity 兴趣或活动范围 ➔spherical /ˈsferɪkl ||; ˈsfɛrɪkḷ/ adj

spheroid
/ˈsfɪərɔɪd ||; ˈsfɪrɔɪd/noun [C] (technical术语) a solid object that is approximately the same shape as a SPHERE 扁球体；椭球体

sphincter
/ˈsfɪŋktə(r) ||; ˈsfɪŋktɚ/noun [C] (technical术语) a ring of muscle that surrounds an opening in the body and that can become tighter in order to close the opening 括约肌: the anal sphincter 肛门括约肌

sphinx
/sfɪŋks ||; sfɪŋks/noun [C] an ancient Egyptian stone statue of a creature with a human head and the body of a lion lying down （古埃及的）狮身人面像

spice¹
/spaɪs ||; spaɪs/noun
1 [C,U] a substance, especially a powder, that is made from a plant and used to give flavour to food （用于食品的）香料: I use a lot of herbs and spices in my cooking. 烹饪时我用许多香草和香料。 Pepper and paprika are two common spices. 胡椒粉和红椒粉是两种常用的香料。 ☞Look at herb. 参看herb。
2 [U] excitement and interest 乐趣；情趣；趣味: to add spice to a situation 增添情趣 ➔spicy adj Do you like spicy food? 你爱吃口味重的食物吗？
spice²
/spaɪs ||; spaɪs/verb [T] spice sth (up) (with sth)
1 to add spice to food 加香料于食物中: He always spices his cooking with lots of chilli powder. 他总是在菜肴中加许多辣椒粉。
2 to add excitement to sth 增加趣味

spick
/spɪk ||; spɪk/adj spick and span neat and clean 整洁干净的；清清爽爽的: Their house is always spick and span.他们家总是收拾得干干净净的。

spider
/ˈspaɪdə(r) ||; ˈspaɪdɚ/noun [C] a type of small animal like an insect with eight legs. Spiders make (spin) special nets (webs) to catch insects for food. 蜘蛛 ☞picture at arachnid 见arachnid插图

ˈspider's web
(especially US 美尤作 spider web) noun [C] a fine net of threads made by a spider to catch insects 蜘蛛网: (figurative 比喻) to be caught in a spider's web of confusion 陷入混乱不堪的局面

spidery
/ˈspaɪdəri ||; ˈspaɪdərɪ/adj long and thin, like the legs of a spider ﹙像蜘蛛腿一样﹚细长的: spidery fingers 修长的手指 spidery handwriting(= consisting of thin lines that are not very clear) 细长而不易辨认的笔迹

spiffy
/ˈspɪfi ||; ˈspɪfɪ/adj (US, informal 美，非正式) (spiffier; spiffiest) attractive and fashionable 漂亮而时髦的: a spiffy outfit/haircut 时髦漂亮的服装/发型

spike
/spaɪk ||; spaɪk/noun [C] a piece of metal, wood, etc that has a sharp point at one end （金属、木质等的）尖状物

ˌspike ˈheel
noun [C] a very thin high heel on a woman's shoe; a shoe with such a heel 细高跟；细高跟鞋 [SYN]stiletto 同义词为 stiletto

spiky
/ˈspaɪki ||; ˈspaɪkɪ/adj
1 having sharp points 有尖刺的: spiky leaves/plants 带刺的叶子/植物
2 (used about hair) sticking straight up from the head ﹙头发﹚刺猬式的

*spill
/spɪl ||; spɪl/verb [I,T] (past tense past participle spilt /spɪlt ||; spɪlt/or spilled)
1 (used especially about a liquid) to accidentally come out of a container; to make a liquid, etc do this （尤指液体）（使）溢出，流出，洒出，泼出: The bag split, and sugar spilled everywhere. 袋子裂开了，糖洒得到处都是。 Some water had spilled out of the bucket onto the floor. 水从桶里溢到地板上。 I've spilt some coffee on the desk. 我把咖啡泼在办公桌上。
2 [I] spill out, over, into, etc to come out of a place suddenly and go in different directions （从某处）涌出并四散而去: The train stopped and everyone spilled out. 火车停了下来，大家都涌下车。 spill noun [C]: Many seabirds died as a result of the oil spill. 泄漏的原油造成许多海鸟死亡。
spill the beans(informal 非正式) to tell a person about sth that should be a secret 泄露秘密

*spin¹
/spɪn ||; spɪn/verb (spinning;past tense past participle spun /spʌn ||; spʌn/)
1 [I,T] spin (sth) (round) to turn or to make sth turn round quickly （使）急速转动，快速旋转: Mary spun round when she heard someone call her name. 玛丽听见有人叫她的名字，连忙转过身来。 [T] to spin a ball/coin/wheel 转动球╱硬币╱轮子
2 [I,T] to make thread from a mass of wool, cotton, etc 纺纱；纺线 · A spider spins a web. 蜘蛛会结网。
3 [T] to remove water from clothes that have just been washed by turning them round and round very fast in a machine （洗衣机）旋干（衣服），脱水
spin sth out to make sth last as long as possible 使尽量延长或拖延
spin²
/spɪn ||; spɪn/noun[C,U]
1 an act of making sth spin 旋转: She put a lot of spin onthe ball. 她发的球旋转得厉害。
2 (especially in politics) a way of talking publicly about a difficult situation, a mistake, etc that makes it sound positive for you （尤指政治）（对困难、错误等所作的）正面性解释
go/take sb for a spin to go/take sb out in a car or other vehicle （带着某人）驾车出去兜风

spinal
/ˈspaɪnl ||; ˈspaɪnḷ/adj connected with the bones of your back (the spine) 与脊柱有关的

ˌspinal ˈcolumn
=SPINE(1)

ˌspinal ˈcord
noun [C] the mass of nerves inside the SPINE that connects all parts of the body to the brain 脊髓 ☞picture at body 见body插图

ˈspin doctor
noun [C] (especially in politics) a person who finds ways of talking about difficult situations, mistakes, etc in a positive way （尤指政治）对困难、错误等作正面性解释的人，舆论导向专家

ˌspin ˈdryer
noun [C] (Brit 英) a machine that removes water from wet clothes by turning them round and round very fast 旋转式脱水机（用于旋干衣服） ➔spin-dry verb [T]

spinach
/ˈspɪnɪtʃ;-ɪdʒ;-ɪtʃ ||; ˈspɪnɪtʃ; -ɪdʒ; ɝɛḷɛTɛ/noun [U] a plant with large dark green leaves that can be cooked and eaten as a vegetable 菠菜 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

spine
/spaɪn ||; spaɪn/noun[C]
1 the bones of the back of a person or animal 脊柱；脊椎 [SYN] backbone 同义词为backbone ☞picture at body 见body插图
2 one of the sharp points like needles, on some plants and animals （动植物的）刺: Porcupines use their spines to protect themselves. 豪猪用刺来保护自己。 ☞Look at prickle. 参看prickle。
3 the narrow part of the cover of a book that you can see when it is on a shelf 书脊

ˈspine-chilling
adj (used about a book, film/movie, etc) frightening in an exciting way ﹙书、电影等﹚令人毛骨悚然的

spineless
/ˈspaɪnləs ||; ˈspaɪnlɪs/adj weak and easily frightened 没有骨气的；懦弱的；容易吓倒的

spinnaker
/ˈspɪnəkə(r) ||; ˈspɪnəkɚ/noun [C] a large extra sail on a racingYACHTthat you use when the wind is coming from behind （赛艇的）大三角帆 ☞picture at boat 见boat插图

ˈspinning wheel
noun [C] a simple machine that people used in their homes in the past for twisting wool, etc. It has a large wheel operated with the foot. 纺车﹙旧时的家用纺纱机﹚

ˈspin-off
noun [C] a spin-off (from/of sth) something unexpected and useful that develops from sth else 意外收获；副产品

spinster
/ˈspɪnstə(r) ||; ˈspɪnstɚ/noun [C] (old-fashioned 旧) a woman, especially an older woman, who has never been married 未婚女子（尤指年老的）；老处女 ☞Nowadays single is the most usual word that is used to describe a man or a woman who is not married. 如今，指未婚男女最常用的词是single。 ☞Look at bachelor. 参看bachelor。

spiral
/ˈspaɪrəl ||; ˈspaɪrəl/noun [C] a long curved line that moves round and round away from a central point 螺旋形 spiral adj a spiral staircase 螺旋式楼梯 spiral verb [I] (spiralling;spiralled (US 美) spiraling;spiraled)

spire
/ˈspaɪə(r) ||; ˈspaɪr/noun [C] a tall pointed tower on the top of a church （教堂的）尖塔，塔尖

*spirit¹
/ˈspɪrɪt ||; ˈspɪrɪt/noun
1 [sing] the part of a person that is not physical; your thoughts and feelings, not your body 心灵；精神: the power of the human spirit to overcome difficulties 人类克服困难的精神力量
2 [C] the part of a person that many people believe still exists after his/her body is dead; a ghost or a being without a body 灵魂；鬼魂: It was believed that people could be possessed by evil spirits. 据认为，人可能被邪灵附身。 ☞Look at soul. 参看soul。
3 [C] the mood, attitude or state of mind of sb/sth 情绪；态度；心态: to be in high/low spirits (= in a happy/sad mood) 情绪高涨╱低落
4 -spirited (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) having the mood or attitude of mind mentioned 有某种情绪、态度或心态的: a group of high-spirited teenagers 一群生气勃勃的青少年
5 spirits [pl] (especially Brit 尤为英) strong alcoholic drinks, for example WHISKY and VODKA 烈酒（如威士忌和伏特加）
6 [U] energy, strength of mind or determination 意志；毅力；朝气: The group had plenty of team spirit. 这个组很有团队精神。
7 [sing] the typical or most important quality of sth 典型或最重要的特质: the pioneer spirit 拓荒者的精神 The painting perfectly captures the spirit of the times. 这幅画完全抓住了时代精神。
spirit²
/ˈspɪrɪt ||; ˈspɪrɪt/verb spirit sb/sth away/off to take sb/sth away secretly 秘密带走（某人或某物）

spirited
/ˈspɪrɪtɪd ||; ˈspɪrɪtɪd/adj full of energy, determination and courage 生气勃勃的；有决心的；勇敢的

spiritual
/ˈspɪrɪtʃuəl ||; ˈspɪrɪtʃυəl/adj
1 concerning deep thoughts, feelings or emotions rather than the body or physical things 精神的；心灵的；非物质的: spiritual development/growth/needs 精神发展╱成长╱需要 ☞Look at material. 参看material。
2 concerning the Church or religion 教会的；宗教的: a spiritual leader 宗教领袖 ➔spiritually /-tʃuəli ||; -tʃυəlɪ/ adv

spiritualism
/ˈspɪrɪtʃuəlɪzəm ||; ˈspɪrɪtʃυəlˌɪzəm/noun [U] the belief that people who have died can get messages to living people, usually through a special person (a medium) 唯灵论（认为死者能通过灵媒向活人传递信息） ➔spiritualist noun [C]

*spit¹
/spɪt ||; spɪt/verb [I,T] (spitting;past tense past participle spat /spæt ||; spæt/) In American English the past tense and past participle can also be spit. 在美国英语里，过去时和过去分词亦作spit。 spit (sth) (out) to force liquid, food, etc out from your mouth 吐出（液体、唾液、食物等） · He took one sip of the wine and spat it out. 他啜了一小口酒，又吐了出来。
spit²
/spɪt ||; spɪt/noun
1 [U] (informal 非正式) the liquid in your mouth 唾液；口水 ☞Look at saliva. 参看saliva。
2 [C] a long, thin piece of land that sticks out into the sea, a lake, etc （伸出大海、湖泊等的）岬，沙嘴
3 [C] a long thin metal stick that you put through meat to hold it when you cook it over a fire 烤肉叉；炙叉: chicken roasted on a spit 插在炙叉上烤的鸡

*spite
/spaɪt ||; spaɪt/noun [U] the desire to hurt or annoy sb 恶意: He stole her letters out of spite. 他出于恶意偷了她的信。 spite verb [T] in spite of used to show that sth happened although you did not expect it （用于引出出人意表的事）尽管，虽然: In spite of all her hard work, Sue failed her exam. 休虽然很用功，可是考试不及格。 [SYN] despite 同义词为despite

spiteful
/ˈspaɪtfl ||; ˈspaɪtfəl/adj behaving in a cruel or unkind way in order to hurt or upset sb 恶意的；怀恨的: He's been saying a lot of spiteful things about his ex-girlfriend. 他一直在说前女友的许多坏话。 ➔spitefully adv /-fəli ||; -fəlɪ/

*splash¹
/splæʃ ||; splæʃ/verb [I,T] (used about a liquid) to fall or to make liquid fall noisily or fly in drops onto a person or thing （指液体）（使）飞溅，溅湿: Rain splashed against the windows. 雨水溅到窗户上。 The children were splashing each other with water. 孩子们互相泼水。 Be careful not to splash paint onto the floor. 小心别把油漆泼到地板上。 splash out (on sth) (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) to spend money on sth that is expensive and that you do not really need 挥霍（金钱）
splash²
/splæʃ ||; splæʃ/noun[C]
1 the sound of liquid hitting sth or of sth hitting liquid （液体的）溅泼声: Paul jumped into the pool with a big splash. 保罗扑通一声跳进游泳池。
2 a small amount of liquid that falls onto sth 溅起的液体: splashes of oil on the cooker 溅在炉具上的油渍 ☞picture at ripple 见ripple插图
3 a small bright area of colour 鲜艳的色斑: Flowers add a splash of colour to a room. 花朵能使房间增添一点色彩。

splashy
/ˈsplæʃi ||; ˈsplæʃɪ/adj (splashier; splashiest) (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) bright and very easy to notice 鲜明醒目的；大张声势的: a splashy advertising campaign 大造声势的广告宣传攻势 a dress in a splashy print 印有醒目花样的连衣裙

splat
/splæt ||; splæt/noun [sing] (informal 非正式) the sound made by sth wet hitting a surface with force ﹙湿物落在平面上的﹚啪嗒声: The tomato hit the wall with a splat. 西红柿啪的一声打在墙上。 ➔splat adv: The omelet fell splat onto the floor. 煎蛋饼吧唧一下掉到了地上。

splatter
/ˈsplætə(r) ||; ˈsplætɚ/verb [I,T] (used about a liquid) to fly about in large drops and hit sb/sth noisily; to throw or drop water, paint etc, on sb/sth in large drops （指液体）溅泼，溅；使（水、油漆等）飞溅 · The paint was splattered all over the floor. 油漆溅了一地。 Heavy rain splattered on the roof. 大雨劈劈啪啪地敲打在屋顶上。

splay
/spleɪ ||; sple/verb [I,T] splay (sth) (out) (to cause sth) to spread out or become wide apart at one end （使）展开，张开 [T] splayed fingers 张开的手指

spleen
/spli:n ||; splin/noun
1 [C] a small organ near the stomach that controls the quality of the blood 脾: a ruptured spleen 脾破裂
2 [U] (written 书面语) anger 怒气: He vented his spleen on the assembled crowd. 他把气出在看热闹的人身上。

splendid
/ˈsplendɪd ||; ˈsplɛndɪd/adj
1 very good; excellent 出色的；绝佳的: What a splendid idea! 好主意！
2 very impressive 华丽的；壮观的；辉煌的: the splendid royal palace 雄伟的皇宫 ➔splendidly adv

splendour
/ˈsplendə(r) ||; ˈsplɛndɚ/ (US 美 splendor) noun [U] very impressive beauty 壮丽；华丽；壮观

splint
/splɪnt ||; splɪnt/noun [C] a piece of wood or metal that is tied to a broken arm or leg to keep it in the right position 夹板（用于固定折断的骨头）

splinter
/ˈsplɪntə(r) ||; ˈsplɪntɚ/noun [C] a small thin sharp piece of wood, metal or glass that has broken off a larger piece （木、金属、玻璃等的）尖锐碎片: I've got a splinter in my finger. 我的手指扎了根刺。 splinter verb [I,T]

*split¹
/splɪt ||; splɪt/verb (present participle splitting;past tense past participle split)
1 [I,T] split (sb) (up) (into sth) to divide or to make a group of people divide into smaller groups （使）分成小组: Let's split into two groups. 我们分成两组吧。
2 [T] split sth (between sb/sth);split sth (with sb) to divide or share sth 分担；分摊；分享: We split the cost of the meal between the six of us. 我们六个人分摊了这顿饭的费用。
3 [I,T] split (sth) (open) to break or make sth break along a straight line （使）裂开: My jeans have split. 我的牛仔裤破了。
