split the difference (used when agreeing on a price) to agree on an amount or figure that is halfway between the two amounts or figures already mentioned （用于议价）折中价格或数目 split hairs to pay too much attention in an argument to details that are very small and not important 吹毛求疵 ☞Usually used in a critical way. 通常用于批评。 split up (with sb) to end a marriage or relationship 分手；离异；绝交: He's split up with his girlfriend. 他和女朋友分手了。
split²
/splɪt ||; splɪt/noun[C]
1 a disagreement that divides a group of people （团体的）分裂
2 a long cut or hole in sth 裂口；裂缝

ˌsplit ˈends
noun [pl] if you have split ends some of the hairs on your head have divided into parts at the ends because they are dry or in poor condition ﹙发梢﹚分叉: shampoo for split ends 可呵护发梢分叉的洗发剂

ˌsplit inˈfinitive
noun [C] (grammar 语法) the form of the verb with to, with an adverb placed between to and the verb, as in She seems to really like it.分裂不定式﹙在 to 和动词之间插入副词，如在句子 She seems to really like it 中的不定式﹚

ˌsplit-ˈlevel
adj (used about a room, floor, etc) having parts at different levels ﹙房间、楼层等﹚错层式的

ˌsplit ˈsecond
noun [C] a very short period of time 一剎那；一瞬间；一眨眼功夫

splitting
/ˈsplɪtɪŋ ||; ˈsplɪtɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) if you have a splitting headache, you have a very bad pain in your head ﹙头痛﹚欲裂的

splutter
/ˈsplʌtə(r) ||; ˈsplʌtɚ/verb
1 [I,T] to speak with difficulty for example because you are very angry or embarrassed （因愤怒或窘迫）结结巴巴，语无伦次
2 [I] to make a series of sounds like a person coughing 发出一连串类似咳嗽之声 splutter noun [C]

*spoil
/spɔɪl ||; spɔɪl/verb [T] (past tense past participle spoilt /spɔɪlt ||; spɔɪlt/or spoiled /spɔɪld ||; spɔɪld/)
1 to change sth good into sth bad, unpleasant, useless, etc; to ruin sth 损坏；糟蹋；破坏: The new office block will spoil the view. 新的办公大楼会破坏景致。 Our holiday was spoilt by bad weather. 我们的假期给坏天气糟蹋了。 Eating between meals will spoil your appetite. 正餐之间进食会影响胃口。
2 to do too much for sb, especially a child, so that you have a bad effect on his/her character 宠坏；惯坏: a spoilt child 宠坏了的孩子
3 spoil sb/yourself to do sth special or nice to make sb/yourself happy 宠爱；纵容

spoils
/spɔɪlz ||; spɔɪlz/noun [pl] (written 书面语) things that have been stolen by thieves, or taken in a war or battle 赃物；战利品: the spoils of war 战利品

spoilsport
/ˈspɔɪlspɔ:t ||; ˈspɔɪlˌspɔrt/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who tries to stop other people enjoying themselves, for example by not taking part in an activity 扫兴的人，败兴的人，煞风景者（比如不参加某项活动）

spoke¹
/spəʊk ||; spok/noun [C] one of the thin pieces of metal that connect the centre of a wheel (the hub) to the outside edge (the rim) 辐条，轮辐（连接车轮的轮毂和轮辋） ☞picture at bicycle 见bicycle插图
spoke²
past tense ofSPEAK

spoken
past participle ofSPEAK

spokesman
/ˈspəʊksmən ||; ˈspoksmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) a person who is chosen to speak for a group or an organization 发言人

*spokesperson
/ˈspəʊkspɜ:sn ||; ˈspoksˌpɝsṇ/noun [C] (plural spokespersons or spokespeople /ˈspəʊkspi:pl ||; ˈspoksˌpipḷ/) a person who is chosen to speak for a group or an organization 发言人 ☞ Spokesperson is now often preferred to spokesman or spokeswoman because it can be used for a man or a woman. 现在常用spokesperson来指spokesman或spokeswoman，因为此词男女通用。

spokeswoman
/ˈspəʊkswʊmən ||; ˈspoksˌwυmən/noun [C] (plural -women /-wɪmɪn ||; -wɪmɪn/) a woman who is chosen to speak for a group or organization 女发言人

sponge¹
/spʌndʒ ||; spʌndʒ/noun[C,U]
1 a piece of artificial or natural material that is soft and light and full of holes and can hold water easily, used for washing yourself or cleaning sth 海绵 ☞picture at bucket 见bucket插图
2 =SPONGE CAKE
sponge²
/spʌndʒ ||; spʌndʒ/verb [T] to remove or clean sth with a wet sponge¹(1) or cloth 用海绵或湿布抹去或清洗 sponge off sb(informal 非正式) to get money, food, etc from sb without paying or doing anything in return 白拿别人的钱、吃白食等；靠某人养活；揩油

ˈsponge bag
(also toilet bag) noun [C] (Brit 英) a small bag in which you put soap, toothpaste, etc (toiletries) when you are travelling （旅行用）盥洗用品防水袋

ˈsponge cake
(also sponge) noun [C,U] a light cake made with eggs, flour and sugar, and usually no fat 松蛋糕；海绵蛋糕

spongy
/ˈspʌndʒi ||; ˈspʌndʒɪ/adj (spongier; spongiest) soft and able to absorb water easily like a sponge 海绵似的；柔软吸水的: The ground was soft and spongy. 土地松软，像海绵似的。 The bread had a spongy texture. 那种面包很松软。

sponsor
/ˈspɒnsə(r) ||; ˈspɑnsɚ/noun[C]
1 a person or an organization that helps to pay for a special sports event, etc (usually so that it can advertise its products) （体育活动等的）赞助人，赞助商 ☞Look at patron. 参看patron。
2 a person who agrees to pay money to a charity if sb else completes a particular activity 慈善活动赞助人 sponsor verb [T] a sponsored walk to raise money for children in need 为贫困儿童筹款而举行的赞助步行 ➔sponsorship noun [U]: Many theatres depend on industry for sponsorship. 许多剧院都依赖工商界资助。

spontaneous
/spɒnˈteɪniəs ||; spɑnˈtenɪəs/adj done or happening suddenly; not planned 自发的；自然的: a spontaneous burst of applause 自发的掌声 ➔spontaneously adv ➔spontaneity /ˌspɒntəˈneɪəti ||; ˌspɑntəˈniətɪ/ noun [U]

spoof
/spu:f ||; spuf/noun [C] an amusing copy of a film, television programme, etc that exaggerates its typical characteristics （夸大某电影、电视节目等特点的）讽刺性模仿作品: It's a spoof on horror movies. 这是一部讽刺恐怖电影的作品。

spook¹
/spu:k ||; spuk/noun [C] (informal 非正式)
1 a ghost 鬼: a castle haunted by spooks 闹鬼的城堡
2 a spy 间谍；特工: a CIA spook 中央情报局特工
spook²
/spu:k ||; spuk/verb [I,T] (informal 非正式) (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to frighten a person or an animal; to become frightened 惊吓；受惊: We were spooked by the strange noises and lights. 那奇怪的声音和亮光把我们吓坏了。 The horse spooked at the siren. 警报器一响，马受惊了。

spooky
/ˈspu:ki ||; ˈspukɪ/adj (informal 非正式) strange and frightening 阴森恐怖的；令人毛骨悚然的: It's spooky being in the house alone at night. 晚上独处这幢房子内令人胆战心惊。

spool
/spu:l ||; spul/noun [C] a round object which thread, film, wire, etc is put around 线轴；绕线管 ☞Look at reel. 参看reel。

*spoon
/spu:n ||; spun/noun [C] an object with a round end and a long handle that you use for eating, mixing or serving food 匙；调羹；杓: Give each person a knife, fork and spoon. 给每人发一套刀叉调羹。 a wooden spoon for cooking 烹饪用木杓 ☞picture at kitchen 见kitchen插图 spoon verb [T]

ˈspoon-feed
verb [T] (past tense, past participle spoon-fed)
1 to teach people sth in a way that gives them too much help and does not make them think for themselves 填鸭式灌输；满堂灌: The students here do not expect to be spoon-fed. 这里的学生不希望教师满堂灌。 They had information spoon-fed to them. 他们学的知识是以满堂灌的方式传授给他们的。
2 to feed sb, especially a baby, with a spoon 用勺喂﹙婴儿﹚

spoonful
/ˈspu:nfʊl ||; ˈspunˌfυl/noun [C] the amount that one spoon can hold 一匙的量: Add two spoonfuls of sugar. 加两匙糖。

sporadic
/spəˈrædɪk ||; spəˈrædɪk/adj not done or happening regularly 偶尔发生的；断断续续的 ➔sporadically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

spore
/spɔ:(r) ||; spɔr/noun [C] one of the very small cells like seeds that are produced by some plants and that develop into new plants 孢子

*sport
/spɔ:t ||; spɔrt/noun
1 [U] a physical game or activity that you do for exercise or because you enjoy it 体育运动: John did a lot of sportwhen he was at school. 约翰念书时参加许多体育活动。 Do you like sport? 你喜欢体育活动吗？
2 [C] a particular game or type of sport 某种体育活动: What's your favourite sport? 你最喜欢哪一种体育活动？ winter sports(= skiing, skating, etc) 冬季体育活动（滑雪、溜冰等） ➔sporting adj a major sporting event 一项重要的体育比赛项目

ˈsports car
noun [C] a low, fast car often with a roof that you can open 跑车；敞篷汽车

sportscast
/ˈspɔ:tskɑ:st; US -kæst ||; ˈspɔrtsˌkæst/noun [C] (US 美) a television or radio broadcast of sports news or a sports event ﹙电视台或电台的﹚体育节目 ➔sportscaster noun [C] (US 美)

ˈsports day
noun [C] (Brit 英) a day once a year on which schoolchildren take part in games, run races and do other sports activities ﹙学校的﹚运动会

sportsman
/ˈspɔ:tsmən ||; ˈspɔrtsmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) a man who does a lot of sport or who is good at sport 爱好运动的人；运动员: a keen sportsman 醉心运动的人

sportsmanlike
/ˈspɔ:tsmənlaɪk ||; ˈspɔrtsmənˌlaɪk/adj behaving in a fair, generous and polite way when you are playing a game or doing sport 有体育精神的

sportsmanship
/ˈspɔ:tsmənʃɪp ||; ˈspɔrtsmənˌʃɪp/noun [U] the quality of being fair, generous and polite when you are playing a game or doing sport 体育精神

sportswear
/ˈspɔ:tsweə(r) ||; ˈspɔrtsˌwɛr/noun [U] clothes that are worn for playing sports or in informal situations 运动服；休闲服

sportswoman
/ˈspɔ:tswʊmən ||; ˈspɔrtsˌwυmən/noun [C] (plural -women /-wɪmɪn ||; -wɪmɪn/) a woman who does a lot of sport or who is good at sport 爱好运动的女人；女运动员

sporty
/ˈspɔ:ti ||; ˈspɔrtɪ/adj (sportier; sportiest) (informal 非正式) (used about cars) fast and attractive in design ﹙汽车﹚车形优美速度快的: a sporty Mercedes 一辆又快又漂亮的梅塞德斯汽车

*spot¹
/spɒt ||; spɑt/noun[C]
1 a small round mark on a surface 小圆点；斑点: Leopards have dark spots. 豹身上有深色斑点。 a blue skirt with red spots on it 有红圆点的蓝色裙子 ☞adjective spotted 形容词为spotted
2 a small dirty mark on sth 小污点；污迹: grease/rust spots 油渍；锈斑
3 a small red or yellow lump that appears on your skin （皮肤上的）红或黄斑点；丘疹: Many teenagers get spots. 许多青少年皮肤上会出丘疹。 ☞adjective spotty 形容词为spotty
4 a particular place or area （某一个）地点，地区: a quiet/lonely/secluded spot 幽静╱偏僻╱僻静的地方
5 [usu.sing] a spot of sth (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) a small amount of sth 少量
6 =SPOTLIGHT(1)
have a soft spot for sb/sth→SOFT on the spot
1 immediately 立即；当场: Paul was caught stealing money and was dismissed on the spot. 保罗偷钱给人抓住，当场被解雇。
2 at the place where sth happened or where sb/sth is needed 在场；到场: The fire brigade were on the spot within five minutes. 消防队五分钟内抵达现场。
put sb on the spot to make sb answer a difficult question or make a difficult decision without having much time to think 迫使某人回答难题或作仓促决定
spot²
/spɒt ||; spɑt/verb [T] (spotting;spotted) (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时) to see or notice sb/sth, especially suddenly or when it is not easy to do 看见，发觉（尤指突然地或在不大容易发现的情况下）: I've spotted a couple of spelling mistakes. 我发现了一些拼写错误。 Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (= -ing form) Spotting a familiar face in the crowd, he began to push his way towards her. 虽然这个动词不用于进行时﹐但它的现在分词﹙-ing形式﹚还是十分常见﹕Spotting a familiar face in the crowd, he began to push his way towards her.他在人群中看到一张熟悉的脸﹐便开始朝她挤过去。
ˌspot ˈcheck
noun [C] a check that is made suddenly and without warning on a few things or people chosen from a group 突击抽查；抽样检查

spotless
/ˈspɒtləs ||; ˈspɑtlɪs/adj perfectly clean 一尘不染的

spotlight
/ˈspɒtlaɪt ||; ˈspɑtˌlaɪt/noun
1 (also spot) [C] a lamp that can send a single ray of bright light onto a small area. Spotlights are often used in theatres. 聚光灯（常用于舞台） ☞picture at light 见light插图
2 the spotlight [sing] the centre of public attention or interest 大家关注的焦点: to be in the spotlight 成为焦点

ˌspot ˈon
adj (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) (not before a noun 不用于名词前) exactly right 准确: Your estimate was spot on. 你的估计非常准确。

spotted
/ˈspɒtɪd ||; ˈspɑtɪd/adj (used about clothes, cloth, etc) covered with round shapes of a different colour （指衣服、布等）有斑点的，有圆点的: a spotted blouse 有圆点图案的衬衫

spotter
/ˈspɒtə(r) ||; ˈspɑtɚ/noun [C] (especially in compounds 尤用于构成复合词)
1 a person who looks for a particular type of thing or person, as a hobby or job 专门搜寻…的人: a trend/celebrity spotter 时尚搜寻者；发掘名人新闻的人
2 a person who watches and helps a gymnast to make sure he/she does not get injured ﹙体操中帮助运动员训练并确保其不受伤的﹚现场辅助员

spotty
/ˈspɒti ||; ˈspɑtɪ/adj having SPOTS(= small red or yellow lumps on your skin) 皮肤有丘疹的: a spotty teenager 皮肤有丘疹的少年

spouse
/spaʊs;spaʊs ||; spaυs; ɝɛḷɛTɛ/noun [C] (written 书面语) your husband or wife 配偶 ☞ Spouse is a formal or official word, used on forms, documents, etc. spouse用于正式场合，如表格、文件等。

spout¹
/spaʊt ||; spaυt/noun [C] a tube or pipe through which liquid comes out （供液体流出的）管，嘴: the spout of a teapot 茶壶嘴
spout²
/spaʊt ||; spaυt/verb[I,T]
1 to send out a liquid with great force; to make a liquid do this （使液体）喷出
2 (informal 非正式)spout (on/off) (about sth) to say sth, using a lot of words, in a way that is boring or annoying 喋喋不休地说；滔滔不绝地谈

sprain
/spreɪn ||; spren/verb [T] to injure part of your body, especially your wrist or your ANKLE by suddenly bending or turning it 扭伤（尤指手腕或脚踝）: to sprain your ankle 扭伤脚踝 sprain noun [C]

sprang
past tense ofSPRING²

sprawl
/sprɔ:l ||; sprɔl/verb[I]
1 to sit or lie with your arms and legs spread out in an untidy way （懒散地）伸开着四肢坐或躺: People lay sprawled out in the sun. 人们伸开手脚躺着晒太阳。
2 to cover a large area of land 延伸；伸展 ➔sprawling adj the sprawling city suburbs 杂乱地延伸的市郊

spray¹
/spreɪ ||; spre/noun
1 [U] liquid in very small drops that is sent through the air 飞沫；水花: clouds of spray from the waves 浪花的飞沫
2 [C,U] liquid in a special container (an aerosol) that is forced out under pressure when you push a button 喷雾剂: hairspray 喷发剂 ☞picture at container 见container插图
spray²
/spreɪ ||; spre/verb [I,T] (used about a liquid) to be forced out of a container or sent through the air in very small drops ; to send a liquid out in this way （指液体）（使）成雾状喷出 · The crops are regularly sprayed with pesticide. 庄稼定期喷洒杀虫剂。

*spread¹
/spred ||; sprɛd/verb (past tense past participle spread)
1 [I,T] to affect a larger area or a bigger group of people; to make sth do this （使）传播，蔓延: The fire spread rapidly because of the strong wind. 火势因强风而迅速蔓延。 Rats and flies spread disease. 老鼠和苍蝇会传播疾病。 [T] to spread rumours about sb 散布关于某人的谣言
2 [T] spread sth (out) (on/over sth) to open sth that has been folded so that it covers a larger area; to move things so that they cover a larger area 摊开；展开: Spread the map out on the table so we can all see it! 把地图摊开在桌子上，好让我们都可以看到！
3 [T] spread A on/over B;spread B with A to cover a surface with a layer of a soft substance 涂；敷: to spread jam on bread 把果酱涂在面包上 to spread bread with jam 在面包上涂果酱
4 [T] spread sth (out) (over sth) to separate sth into parts and divide them between different times or people 使分期或分批进行: You can spread your repayments over a period of three years. 你可以在三年内分期还款。
spread (sb/yourself) out to move away from the others in a group of people in order to cover a larger area （指人）分散到更大的范围: The police spread out to search the whole area. 警察散开来搜查整个地区。
spread²
/spred ||; sprɛd/noun
1 [U] an increase in the amount or number of sth that there is, or in the area that is affected by sth 伸展；蔓延；扩散: Dirty drinking water encourages the spread of disease. 肮脏的饮用水会加速疾病的传播。
2 [C,U] a soft food that you put on bread 涂面包的酱
3 [C] a newspaper or magazine article that covers one or more pages （报纸或杂志上）全版文章或跨页文章: a double-page spread 一篇横跨两页的文章

spreadsheet
/ˈspredʃi:t ||; ˈsprɛdˌʃit/noun [C] (computing计算机技术) a computer program for working with rows of numbers, used especially for doing accounts 电子表格，电子数据表，电子表格（一种计算机程序）

spree
/spri: ||; spri/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a short time that you spend doing sth you enjoy, often doing too much of it 寻欢作乐，狂欢（常指过分的）: to go on a shopping/spending spree 去大买特买东西；去大花特花钱

sprig
/sprɪg ||; sprɪg/noun [C] a small piece of a plant with leaves on it （带叶的）小枝

*spring¹
/sprɪŋ ||; sprɪŋ/noun
1 [C,U] the season of the year between winter and summer when the weather gets warmer and plants begin to grow 春天；春季: Daffodils bloom in spring. 黄水仙在春天开花。 ☞picture at season 见season插图
2 [C] a long piece of thin metal or wire that is bent round and round. After you push or pull a spring it goes back to its original shape and size. 弹簧: bed springs 床的弹簧 ☞picture at coil 见coil插图
3 [C] a place where water comes up naturally from under the ground 泉源；泉: a hot spring 温泉
4 [C] a sudden jump upwards or forwards 跳；跳跃
spring²
/sprɪŋ ||; sprɪŋ/verb [I] (past tense sprang /spræŋ ||; spræŋ/ past participle sprung /sprʌŋ ||; sprʌŋ/)
1 to jump or move quickly 跳跃；跃起: When the alarm went off, Ray sprang out of bed. 闹钟一响，雷就从床上跳下来。 to spring to your feet (= stand up suddenly) 突然站起来 (figurative 比喻) to spring to sb's defence/assistance (= to quickly defend or help sb) 立即为某人辩护╱提供援助
2 (used about an object) to move suddenly and violently （指物品）反弹: The branch sprang back and hit him in the face. 树枝弹回来，打在他的脸上。
3 to appear or come somewhere suddenly 突然出现或到来: Tears sprang to her eyes. 她双眼顿时眼泪汪汪。 Where did you just spring from? 你是从哪里冒出来的？
come/spring to mind→MIND¹ spring from sth(written 书面语) to be the result of 源自: The idea for the book sprang from an experience she had while travelling in India. 写这本书的想法源自她在印度旅行期间的一次经历。 spring sth on sb(informal 非正式) to do or say sth that sb is not expecting 突然向某人提出某事物 spring up to appear or develop quickly or suddenly 突然出现；迅速发展: Play areas for children are springing up everywhere. 供孩子们玩耍的场所到处出现。

springboard
/ˈsprɪŋbɔ:d ||; ˈsprɪŋˌbɔrd/noun[C]
1 a low board that bends and that helps you jump higher, for example before you jump into a swimming pool （游泳池等的）跳板，踏板
2 a springboard (for/to sth) something that helps you start an activity, especially by giving you ideas （成就某事的）起点，垫脚石（尤指通过出主意）

ˌspring-ˈclean
verb [T] to clean a house, room, etc very well, including the parts that you do not usually clean 彻底打扫（房子、房间等）

spring ˈonion
noun [C,U] a type of small onion with a long green central part and leaves 大葱 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

ˌspring ˈroll
noun [C] a type of Chinese food consisting of a tube of thin pastry, filled with vegetables and/or meat and fried until it is crisp 春卷

springtime
/ˈsprɪŋtaɪm ||; ˈsprɪŋˌtaɪm/noun [U] (written 书面语) the season of spring 春季；春天

springy
/ˈsprɪŋi ||; ˈsprɪŋɪ/adj going quickly back to its original shape or size after being pushed, pulled, etc 有弹性的；有弹力的: soft springy grass 柔软有弹力的草

sprinkle
/ˈsprɪŋkl ||; ˈsprɪŋkḷ/verb [T] sprinkle A (on/onto/over B);sprinkle B (with A) to throw drops of liquid or small pieces of sth over a surface 洒；撒: to sprinkle sugar on a cake 将糖撒在蛋糕上 to sprinkle a cake with sugar 在蛋糕上撒糖

sprinkler
/ˈsprɪŋklə(r) ||; ˈsprɪŋklɚ/noun [C] a device with holes in it that sends out water in small drops. Sprinklers are used in gardens, to keep the grass green, and in buildings, to stop fires from spreading. 洒水装置（用于浇花草、救火等）

sprint
/sprɪnt ||; sprɪnt/verb [I,T] to run a short distance as fast as you can （短距离）全速奔跑，冲刺 sprint noun [C]

sprite
/spraɪt ||; spraɪt/noun [C] (in stories) a small creature with magic powers, especially one that is graceful or likes playing tricks ﹙故事中的﹚小仙子，小精灵，小妖精

spritz
/sprɪts ||; sprɪts/verb [T] (especially US 尤为美) to spray very small drops of liquid on sth quickly 喷: Lightly spritz your hair with water. 往你头发上轻轻喷点水。

spritzer
/ˈsprɪtsə(r) ||; ˈsprɪtsɚ/noun [C] a drink made with wine (usually white) mixed with soda water 汽酒: a white wine spritzer 一杯白葡萄汽酒

sprout¹
/spraʊt ||; spraυt/verb [I,T] (used about a plant) to begin to grow or to produce new leaves （指植物）发芽: The seeds are sprouting. 种子发芽了。
sprout²
/spraʊt ||; spraυt/noun[C]
1 =BRUSSELS SPROUT
2 a new part that has grown on a plant 芽；苗

spruce
/spru:s ||; sprus/verb spruce (sb/yourself) up to make sb/yourself clean and tidy （把某人或自己）打扮得整齐漂亮

sprung
past participle ofSPRING²

spud
/spʌd ||; spʌd/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a potato 马铃薯

spun
past participle ofSPIN¹

spur¹
/spɜ:(r) ||; spɝ/noun[C]
1 a piece of metal that a rider wears on the back of his/her boots to encourage the horse to go faster 马刺（镶在马靴后跟的金属片，用于踢马使它快跑） ☞picture at horse 见horse插图
2 a spur (to sth) something that encourages you to do sth or that makes sth happen more quickly 激励；鞭策；鼓舞
3 (in geography 地理学) a part of a hill that sticks out from the rest, often with lower ground around it 山嘴，坡尖，山鼻子（指山的突出部份）
on the spur of the moment without planning; suddenly 一时冲动；心血来潮
spur²
/spɜ:(r) ||; spɝ/verb [T] (spurring;spurred)spur sb/sth (on/onto sth) to encourage sb or make him/her work harder or faster 激励；鞭策；催促: The letter spurred me into action. 这封信促使我采取行动。 We were spurred on by the positive feedback from customers. 顾客的正面反应令我们大受鼓舞。

spurn
/spɜ:n ||; spɝn/verb [T] (formal 正式) to refuse sth that sb has offered to you 拒绝: to spurn an offer of friendship 拒绝跟某人做朋友

spurt
/spɜ:t ||; spɝt/verb
1 [I,T] (used about a liquid) to come out quickly with great force; to make a liquid do this （指液体）（使）喷出，涌出: Blood spurted from the wound. 鲜血从伤口涌出。
2 [I] to suddenly increase your speed or effort 突然加速或更加努力 spurt noun [C]

spy¹
/spaɪ ||; spaɪ/noun [C] (plural spies) a person who tries to get secret information about another country, person or organization 间谍；密探
spy²
/spaɪ ||; spaɪ/verb (present participle spying third person singular present spies;past tense past participle spied)
1 [I] to try to get secret information about sb/sth 刺探机密情报；暗中监视某人 ☞Look at espionage. 参看espionage。
2 [T] (formal 正式) to see 看见；发现
spy on sb/sth to watch sb/sth secretly 暗中监视: The man next door is spying on us. 隔壁那个男人在监视我们。

spyhole
/ˈspaɪhəʊl ||; ˈspaɪˌhol/noun [C] a small hole in a door for looking at the person on the other side before deciding to let him/her in （门上的）观察孔

sq
abbr
1 =SQUARE²(6) 10 sq cm 10平方厘米
2 Sq.=SQUARE¹(2) 6 Hanover Sq. 汉诺威广场6号

squabble
/ˈskwɒbl ||; ˈskwɑbḷ/verb [I] squabble (over/about sth) to argue in a noisy way about sth that is not very important （为小事）争吵，大吵大闹 squabble noun [C]

squad
/skwɒd ||; skwɑd/noun [C] [with.sop] a group of people who work as a team 工作小组；小队: He's a policeman with the drugs squad. 他是一名警察，在缉毒小组工作。

squadron
/ˈskwɒdrən ||; ˈskwɑdrən/noun [C] [with.sop] a group of military aircraft or ships （空军或海军的）中队

squalid
/ˈskwɒlɪd ||; ˈskwɑlɪd/adj very dirty, untidy and unpleasant 污秽的；肮脏的: squalid housing conditions 污秽的居住环境

squall
/skwɔ:l ||; skwɔl/noun [C] a sudden storm with strong winds 狂风骤雨；飑

squalor
/ˈskwɒlə(r) ||; ˈskwɑlɚ/noun [U] the state of being very dirty, untidy or unpleasant 污秽；肮脏: to live in squalor 住在污秽的环境中

squander
/ˈskwɒndə(r) ||; ˈskwɑndɚ/verb [T] squander sth (on sth) to waste time, money, etc 挥霍，浪费（时间、金钱等）: He squanders his time on TV and computer games. 他把时间浪费在看电视和玩计算机游戏上。

*square¹
/skweə(r) ||; skwɛr/noun[C]
1 a shape that has four sides of the same length and four angles of 90 degrees(right angles) 正方形；四方形: There are 64 squares on a chess board. 国际象棋的棋盘有64个方格。 ☞picture at shape 见shape插图
2 (also Square) (abbr Sq.) an open space in a town or city that has buildings all around it 广场: Protesters gathered in the town square. 抗议者聚集在市中心广场上。 Trafalgar Square 特拉法尔加广场
3 (mathematics数学) the number that you get when you multiply another number by itself 平方: Four is the square of two. 四是二的平方。 ☞Look at squared and square root. 参看squared及square root。
*square²
/skweə(r) ||; skwɛr/adj adv
1 having four straight sides of the same length and corners of 90° 正方的；四方的: a square tablecloth 四四方方的桌布
2 shaped like a square or forming an angle of about 90° 正方形般的: a square face 方型脸 square shoulders 宽阔肩膀
3 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) not owing any money 不欠账: Here is the money I owe you. Now we're (all) square. 这是我欠你的钱，现在我们互不相欠。
4 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) having equal points (in a game, etc) （比赛等）平手，打平，比分相同: The teams were all square at half-time. 打完半场，两队平手。
5 fair or honest, especially in business matters 公平的，诚实的（尤指生意上）: a square deal 公平交易
6 (abbr sq) used for talking about the area of sth （用于指面积）平方的: If a room is 5 metres long and 4 metres wide, its area is 20 square metres. 一个5米长4米宽的房间，面积就是20平方米。
7 (used about sth that is square in shape) having sides of a particular length （指正方形物体）每边为某长度: The picture is twenty centimetres square (= each side is twenty centimetres long). 那幅画是二十厘米见方。
8 (also squarely) in an obvious and direct way 明显；直接: to look sb square in the eye 直视某人的眼睛 I think the blame falls squarely on her. 我觉得责任完全在她。
a square meal a good meal that makes you feel satisfied 丰盛的一餐
square³
/skweə(r) ||; skwɛr/verb [I,T] square (sth) with sb/sth to agree with sth; to make sure that sb/sth agrees with sth （使）相符或一致: Your conclusion doesn't really square with the facts. 你的结论和事实不相符。 If you want time off you'll have to square it with the boss. 你想请假就得和老板商量。 square up (with sb) to pay sb the money that you owe him/her 归还欠款

squared
/skweəd ||; skwɛrd/adj (mathematics数学) (used about a number) multiplied by itself （指数字）平方: Four squared is sixteen. 四的平方等于十六。 ☞Look at square ¹(3) and square root. 参看square^1(3)及square root。

ˌsquare ˈroot
noun [C] (mathematics数学) a number that produces another particular number when it is multiplied by itself 平方根: The square root of sixteen is four. 十六的平方根是四。 ☞Look at square ¹(3), squared, root and cube root. 参看square^1(3)、squared、root及cube root。

squash¹
/skwɒʃ ||; skwɑʃ/verb
1 [T] to press sth so that it is damaged, changes shape or becomes flat 压坏；压得变形；压扁: The fruit at the bottom of the bag will get squashed. 袋子底下的水果会给压烂。 Move up -- you're squashing me! 坐过去些，你把我挤扁了！ ☞picture at squeeze 见squeeze插图
2 [I,T] to go into a place, or move sb/sth to a place, where there is not much space 挤进；塞进: We all squashed into the back of the car. 我们全挤进了汽车后座。
3 [T] to destroy sth because it is a problem 打消；去除: to squash sb's suggestion/plan/idea 否定某人的建议；推翻某人的计划；打消某人的念头
squash²
/skwɒʃ ||; skwɑʃ/noun
1 [C] [sing] a lot of people in a small space 拥挤: We can get ten people around the table, but it's a bit of a squash. 一张桌子我们可以坐下十个人，但有点挤。
2 [U] [C] (Brit 英) a drink that is made from fruit juice and sugar. You add water to squash before you drink it. （饮用时加水的）果汁饮料: orange squash 橙汁饮料
3 [U] a game for two people, played in a special room(court). You play squash by hitting a small rubber ball against any one of the walls of the room. 壁球: a squash racket 壁球拍
4 [C] [U] (plural squash) a type of vegetable that grows on the ground with hard skin and orange flesh inside, or soft yellow or green skin and white flesh inside 南瓜；笋瓜；西葫芦 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

squat¹
/skwɒt ||; skwɑt/verb [I] (squatting;squatted)
1 to rest with your weight on your feet, your legs bent and your bottom just above the ground 蹲 ☞picture at kneel 见kneel插图
2 to go and live in an empty building without permission from the owner 擅自占据空屋
squat²
/skwɒt ||; skwɑt/adj short and fat or thick 矮胖的；又粗又矮的: a squat ugly building 一座又矮又难看的建筑物

squatter
/ˈskwɒtə(r) ||; ˈskwɑtɚ/noun [C] a person who is living in an empty building without the owner's permission 擅自占据空屋者

squawk
/skwɔ:k ||; skwɔk/verb [I] (used especially about a bird) to make a loud unpleasant noise （尤指鸟）吱吱大叫，嘎嘎大叫 squawk noun [C]

squeak
/skwi:k ||; skwik/noun [C] a short high noise that is not very loud 短而尖的声音；吱吱声: the squeak of a mouse 老鼠的吱吱叫声 She gave a little squeak of surprise. 她吃惊地尖叫了一声。 squeak verb [I,T] ➔squeaky adj a squeaky floorboard 嘎吱作响的地板 a squeaky voice 短而尖的说话声

squeaky
/ˈskwi:ki ||; ˈskwikɪ/adj (squeakier; squeakiest) making a short, high sound; squeaking 发短促尖叫声的；吱吱叫的；嘎吱作响的: squeaky floorboards 嘎吱作响的地板 a high squeaky voice 又高又尖的嗓子

squeal
/skwi:l ||; skwil/verb [I,T] to make a loud high noise because of pain, fear or enjoyment （因疼痛、恐惧或愉快而）尖叫: The baby squealed in delight at the new toy. 婴儿拿到新玩具，高兴得大叫起来。 squeal noun [C] ☞A squeal is louder and longer than a squeak but it is not as loud as a scream. squeal比squeak大声和持久，但没有scream那么响亮。

squeamish
/ˈskwi:mɪʃ ||; ˈskwimɪʃ/adj easily upset by unpleasant sights, especially blood 易觉得难受或不适的（尤指见到血）

squeegee
/ˈskwi:dʒi: ||; ˈskwidʒi/noun [C] a tool with a rubber edge and a handle, used for removing water from smooth surfaces such as windows 橡皮刮水刷

*squeeze¹
/skwi:z ||; skwiz/verb
1 [T] squeeze sth (out);squeeze sth (from/out of sth) to press sth hard for a particular purpose 挤；榨；: She squeezed his hand as a sign of affection. 她紧握他的手表示爱意。 to squeeze a tube of toothpaste 挤牙膏 Squeeze a lemon/the juice of a lemon into a glass. 将柠檬汁挤在杯子里。 I squeezed the water out of the cloth. 我将布拧干了。
2 [I,T] squeeze (sb/sth) into, through, etc sth;squeeze (sb/sth) through, in, past, etc to force sb/sth into or through a small space （使）挤进或挤过 · We can squeeze another person into the back of the car. 我们汽车的后座还可以多挤一个人。 There was just room for the bus to squeeze past. 地方刚好够那辆公共汽车挤过去。
squeeze²
/skwi:z ||; skwiz/noun
1 [C] an act of pressing sth firmly 挤；榨；: He gave her hand a squeeze and told her he loved her. 他紧握她的手，对她说他爱她。
2 [C] the amount of liquid that you get from squeezing an orange, a lemon, etc 榨出的汁: a squeeze of lemon 榨出来的柠檬汁
3 [sing] a situation where there is not much space 挤；拥挤: It was a tight squeeze to get everybody around the table. 大家都围着桌子坐，挤得很。
4 [C] [usu.sing] an effort to use less money, time, etc, especially with the result that there is not enough （钱、时间等的）紧缩（尤指因为不够用）

squelch
/skweltʃ ||; skwɛltʃ/verb [I] to make the sound your feet make when you are walking in deep wet mud （在黏泥中行走时）发出吧唧声

squid
/skwɪd ||; skwɪd/noun [C,U] (plural squid or squids) a sea animal that we eat with a long soft body and ten TENTACLES 鱿鱼

squiggle
/ˈskwɪgl ||; ˈskwɪgḷ/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a quickly drawn line that goes in all directions 波形曲线

squint
/skwɪnt ||; skwɪnt/verb[I]
1 squint (at sth) to look at sth with your eyes almost closed 瞇着眼看: to squint in bright sunlight 在耀眼的阳光下瞇起眼睛
2 to have eyes that appear to look in different directions at the same time 斜视 squint noun [C]

squirm
/skwɜ:m ||; skwɝm/verb [I] to move around in your chair because you are nervous, uncomfortable, etc （因为紧张、不安等）扭动身体

squirrel
/ˈskwɪrəl; US ˈskwɜ:rəl ||; ˈskwɝəl/noun [C] a small red or grey animal with a long thick tail that lives in trees and eats nuts 松鼠 ☞picture at rodent 见rodent插图

squirt
/skwɜ:t ||; skwɝt/verb [I,T] If a liquid squirts or if you squirt it, it is suddenly forced out of sth in a particular direction （指液体）（使）喷射，喷出；向…喷: I cut the orange and juice squirted out. 我切开橙子，汁就喷了出来。 She squirted water on the flames. 她往火焰上喷水。 He squirted me with water. 他朝我喷水。 squirt noun [C]: a squirt of lemon juice 喷出的柠檬汁

Sr
abbr =SNR

SSE
abbr south-south-east 南东南

SSW
abbr south-south-west 南西南

St
abbr
1 =SAINT St Peter 圣彼得
2 =STREET 20 Swan St 斯旺街20号
3 st (Brit 英) stone; a measure of weight 英石（重量单位）

stab¹
/stæb ||; stæb/verb [T] (stabbing;stabbed) to push a knife or other pointed object into sb/sth 刺；捅；戳: The man had been stabbed in the back. 那个男人背部被刺了。 He stabbed a potato with his fork. 他用叉戳马铃薯。
stab²
/stæb ||; stæb/noun[C]
1 an injury that was caused by a knife, etc 刺伤: He received stab wounds to his neck and back. 他颈部和背部被刺伤。
2 a sudden sharp pain 一阵刺痛
have a stab at sth/doing sth(informal 非正式) to try to do sth 尝试做某事

stabbing¹
/ˈstæbɪŋ ||; ˈstæbɪŋ/noun [C] an occasion when sb is injured or killed with a knife or other sharp object 利器伤人事件
stabbing²
/ˈstæbɪŋ ||; ˈstæbɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used about a pain) sudden and strong （指疼痛）突然而强烈的

stability
/stəˈbɪləti ||; stəˈbɪlətɪ/noun [U] the state or quality of being steady and not changing 稳定；稳固: After so much change we now need a period of stability. 经过这么多变动，现在我们需要一段稳定期。 The ladder is slightly wider at the bottom for greater stability. 这梯子底部稍宽，所以比较稳。 [OPP] instability 反义词为instability ☞adjective stable 形容词为stable

stabilize
/ˈsteɪbəlaɪz ||; ˈstebḷˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [I,T] to become or to make sth firm, steady and unlikely to change （使）稳定，稳固: The patient's condition has stabilized. 病人的情况已经稳定下来。 ☞Look at destabilize. 参看destabilize。

stable¹
/ˈsteɪbl ||; ˈstebḷ/adj steady, firm and unlikely to change 稳定的；牢固的；安定的: This ladder doesn't seem very stable. 这个梯子看来不太稳。 The patient is in a stable condition. 这个病人情况稳定。 [OPP] unstable 反义词为unstable ☞noun stability 名词为stability
stable²
/ˈsteɪbl ||; ˈstebḷ/noun [C] a building where horses are kept 马厩；马房

staccato
/stəˈkɑ:təʊ ||; stəˈkɑto/adj (music 音乐) with each note played separately in order to produce short, sharp sounds 断音的；断奏的 [OPP] legato 反义词为legato ➔staccato adv

stack¹
/stæk ||; stæk/noun[C]
1 a tidy pile of sth （整齐的）一迭，一堆，一摞: a stack of plates/books/chairs 一迭碟子╱书╱椅子
2 (informal 非正式) (often plural 常用复数) a lot of sth 许多: I've still got stacks of work to do. 我还有许多工作要做。
3 (in geography 地理学) a tall thin part of a cliff that has been separated from the land and stands on its own in the sea （孤零零地耸立于海面的）岩柱 ☞picture at erode 见erode插图
stack²
/stæk ||; stæk/verb [T] stack sth (up) to put sth into a tidy pile 摞成整齐的一堆: Could you stack those chairs for me? 你替我把那些椅子摞起来好吗？

stacked
/stækt ||; stækt/adj full of piles of things 堆满的: The room was stacked high with books. 房间里高高地堆满了书。

*stadium
/ˈsteɪdiəm ||; ˈstedɪəm/noun [C] (plural stadiums or stadia /-diə ||; -dɪə/) a large structure, usually with no roof, where people can sit and watch sport 运动场，体育馆（通常为露天的，设有观众席）

*staff
/stɑ:f; US stæf ||; stæf/noun[C] [usu.sing] [U]
1 the group of people who work for a particular organization 全体职员；全体员工: hotel/library/medical staff 旅馆职员；图书馆职员；医务人员 Two members of staff will accompany the students on the school trip. 两名教员将陪同学生参与学校旅行。 The hotel has over 200 people on its staff. 这家酒店有逾200名员工。 full-time/part-time staff 全职╱兼职员工 a staffroom(= in a school) （学校的）教员室 Staff is usually used in the singular but with a plural verb The staff all speak good English. staff通常作单数，但与复数动词连用：The staff all speak good English.职员都说得一口流利英语。
2 (US 美) =STAVE¹(2) staff verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) The office is staffed 24 hours a day. 这办公室昼夜都有人办公。

stag
/stæg ||; stæg/noun [C] the male of a DEER 成年雄鹿 ☞picture at deer 见deer插图

*stage¹
/steɪdʒ ||; stedʒ/noun
1 [C] one part of the progress or development of sth 阶段；时期: The first stage of the course lasts for three weeks. 课程的第一个阶段为期三星期。 I suggest we do the journey in two stages. 我建议将旅程分为两个阶段。 At this stage it's too early to say what will happen. 在现阶段推测以后的事还是言之过早。
2 [C] a platform in a theatre, concert hall, etc on which actors, musicians, etc perform 舞台
3 [sing] [U] the world of theatre; the profession of acting 戏剧界；表演行业: Her parents didn't want her to go on the stage. 她的父母不想让她当演员。 an actor of stage and screen 戏剧和电影两栖演员
stage²
/steɪdʒ ||; stedʒ/verb[T]
1 to organize a performance of a play, concert, etc for the public 公演；安排演出
2 to organize an event 筹划，举行（活动）: They have decided to stage a 24-hour strike. 他们已决定举行24小时罢工。

ˈstage fright
noun [U] nervous feelings felt by performers before they appear in front of an audience 怯场

stagehand
/ˈsteɪdʒhænd ||; ˈstedʒˌhænd/noun [C] a person whose job is to help move scenery, etc in a theatre, to prepare the stage for the next play or the next part of a play 舞台工作人员﹙负责移动布景、准备道具等﹚

ˌstage ˈmanager
noun [C] the person who is responsible for the stage, lights, scenery, etc during a theatre performance 舞台监督

ˈstage name
noun [C] a name that an actor uses instead of his/her real name ﹙演员的﹚艺名

stagger
/ˈstægə(r) ||; ˈstægɚ/verb [I] to walk with short steps as if you could fall at any moment, for example because you are ill, drunk or carrying sth heavy 蹒跚，摇摇晃晃地走（如因生病、酒醉或携重物）: He staggered across the finishing line and collapsed. 他摇摇晃晃地越过终点线，然后倒在地上。

staggered
/ˈstægəd ||; ˈstægɚd/adj
1 (informal 非正式) very surprised 诧异的；吃惊的: I was absolutely staggered when I heard the news. 听到那个消息，我十分诧异。
2 (used about a set of times, payments, etc) arranged so that they do not all happen at the same time （指时间、付款等）错开的: staggered working hours (= when people start and finish work at different times) 错开的上班时间

staggering
/ˈstægərɪŋ ||; ˈstægərɪŋ/adj that you find difficult to believe 令人吃惊的；惊人的 ➔staggeringly adv

staging
/ˈsteɪdʒɪŋ ||; ˈstedʒɪŋ/noun
1 [C,U] the way in which a play is produced and presented on stage 演出形式；演出风格: a modern staging of ‘King Lear’ 以现代风格演出的《李尔王》
2 [U] a temporary platform used for standing or working on 临时工作台﹙或工作架﹚

stagnant
/ˈstægnənt ||; ˈstægnənt/adj
1 (used about water) not flowing and therefore dirty and having an unpleasant smell （指水）不流动而发臭的
2 (used about business, etc) not active; not developing （指生意等）不景气的，死气沉沉的: a stagnant economy 经济发展停滞

stagnate
/stægˈneɪt; US ˈstægneɪt ||; ˈstægnet/verb[I]
1 to stop developing, changing or being active 停滞不前；呆滞: a stagnating economy 停滞不前的经济
2 (used about water) to be or become stagnant （指水）（因不流动而）发臭，变臭 ➔stagnation /stægˈneɪʃn ||; stægˈneʃən/ noun [U]

ˈstag night
(also stag party) noun [C] a party for men only that is given for a man just before his wedding day （为准新郎举行的）男子聚会 ☞Compare hen party. 与hen party比较。

staid
/steɪd ||; sted/adj serious, old-fashioned and rather boring 古板守旧的；严肃呆板的

*stain
/steɪn ||; sten/verb [I,T] to leave a coloured mark that is difficult to remove 染污；沾污 · Don't spill any of that red wine -- it'll stain the carpet. 不要让红酒泼出来，会弄脏地毯的。 stain noun [C]: The blood had left a stain on his shirt. 血在他的衬衫上留下了一处污迹。 ☞picture at blob 见blob插图

ˌstained ˈglass
noun [U] pieces of coloured glass that are used in church windows, etc （教堂窗户等用的）彩色玻璃，彩绘玻璃

ˌstainless ˈsteel
noun [U] a type of steel that does not RUST(= change colour or get damaged by water) 不锈钢: a stainless steel pan 不锈钢平底锅

*stair
/steə(r) ||; stɛr/noun
1 stairs [pl] a series of steps inside a building that lead from one level to another 楼梯: a flight of stairs 一段楼梯 I heard somebody coming down the stairs. 我听见有人下楼梯的声音。 She ran up the stairs. 她跑上楼梯。 ☞Look at downstairs and upstairs. 参看downstairs及upstairs。
Compare stair and step. Stairs or flights of stairs are usually inside buildings. Steps are usually outside buildings and made of stone or concrete. 比较stair及step。stairs或flights of stairs通常指建筑物内的楼梯或梯级。steps通常指建筑物外用石头或混凝土筑成的台阶等。 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图
2 [C] one of the steps in a series inside a building 梯级

staircase
/ˈsteəkeɪs ||; ˈstɛrˌkes/ (also stairway /ˈsteəweɪ ||; ˈstɛrˌwe/) noun [C] a set of stairs with rails on each side that you can hold on to （有扶手的）楼梯 ☞Look at escalator. 参看escalator。 ☞pictures at spiral and on page C7 见spiral及C7页插图

stake¹
/steɪk ||; stek/noun
1 [C] a wooden or metal pole with a point at one end that you push into the ground 柱；桩
2 [C] a part of a company, etc that you own, usually because you have put money into it （投资于公司等的）股本，股份，股权: Foreign investors now have a 20% stake inthe company. 外国投资者目前拥有公司20%的股权。
3 stakes [pl] the things that you might win or lose in a game or in a particular situation 赌注: We play cards for money, but never for very high stakes. 我们玩纸牌赌钱，但从不下大赌注。
at stake in danger of being lost; at risk 胜败攸关；有危险或风险: He thought very carefully about the decision because he knew his future was at stake. 他仔细考虑才决定，因为他知道这关系到他自己的前途。
stake²
/steɪk ||; stek/verb [T] stake sth (on sth) to put your future, etc in danger by doing sth, because you hope that it will bring you a good result 拿…下赌注；以…来押注: He is staking his political reputation on this issue. 他将自己的政治声誉押在这件事上。 stake a/your claim (to sth) to say that you have a right to have sth 声明有（某物的）拥有权 stake sth out
1 to clearly mark an area of land that you are going to use 划出某地区（供使用）
2 to make your position, opinion, etc clear to everyone 向大家阐明（立场、看法等）: In his speech, the President staked out his position on tax reform. 总统在演说中阐明自己对税制改革的立场。
3 to watch a place secretly for a period of time 暗中监视: The police had been staking out the house for months. 几个月来警方一直在监视那所房子。

stakeholder
/ˈsteɪkhəʊldə(r) ||; ˈstekˌholdɚ/noun[C]
1 a person or company that is involved in a particular organization, project, system, etc, especially because they have invested money in it ﹙组织、工程等的﹚参与人，参与方；利益相关者: All our employees are stakeholders in the company. 我们所有的员工都是公司的利益共享人。 A stakeholder economy is one in which all members of society feel that they have an interest in its success. 人人参与的经济模式指的是社会全体成员觉得其繁荣将为每个人带来利益。
2 a person who holds all the bets placed on a game or race and who pays the money to the winner 赌金保管人

ˈstake-out
noun [C] a situation in which police watch a building secretly to find evidence of illegal activities 警察监视

stalactite
/ˈstæləktaɪt ||; stəˈlæktaɪt/noun [C] (in geography 地理学) a long thin piece of rock hanging down from the roof of a CAVE （悬于岩洞顶上的）钟乳石 ☞picture at limestone 见limestone插图

stalagmite
/ˈstæləgmaɪt ||; stəˈlægmaɪt/noun [C] (in geography 地理学) a thin piece of rock pointing upwards from the floor of a CAVE （突出于岩洞地面上的）石笋 ☞picture at limestone 见limestone插图

*stale
/steɪl ||; stel/adj
1 (used about food or air) old and not fresh any more （指食物或空气）不新鲜的: The bread will go stale if you don't put it away. 面包不收起来会不新鲜。
2 not interesting or exciting any more 陈旧乏味的；没有新意的 ☞Look at fresh. 参看fresh。

stalemate
/ˈsteɪlmeɪt ||; ˈstelˌmet/noun[sing] [U]
1 a situation in an argument in which neither side can win or make any progress 僵局
2 (in chess) a position in which a game ends without a winner because neither side can move （下棋）无子可动，和局

stalk¹
/stɔ:k ||; stɔk/noun [C] one of the long thin parts of a plant which the flowers, leaves or fruit grow on （植物的）茎，梗，柄 ☞pictures on page C2 and C3 见C2及C3页插图
stalk²
/stɔ:k ||; stɔk/verb
1 [T] to move slowly and quietly towards an animal in order to catch or kill it 悄悄追踪或靠近（猎物）: a lion stalking its prey 狮子悄悄走近猎物
2 [T] to follow a person over a period of time in a frightening or annoying way 吓人或恼人地跟踪（某人）: The actress claimed the man had been stalking her for two years. 女演员声称，那个男子已经跟踪了她两年。
3 [I] to walk in an angry way 气愤地走开

stall¹
/stɔ:l ||; stɔl/noun
1 [C] a small shop with an open front or a table with things for sale 摊位；售货摊: a market stall 市场的摊子 a bookstall at the station 车站的书摊 ☞picture on page C8 见C8页插图
2 stalls [pl] the seats nearest the front in a theatre or cinema （剧院或电影院的）正厅前排座位
3 [C] [usu.sing] a situation in which a vehicle's engine suddenly stops because it is not receiving enough power （车辆等）抛锚；（发动机）熄火: The plane went into a stall and almost crashed. 飞机失速，差点坠毁。
stall²
/stɔ:l ||; stɔl/verb[I,T]
1 (used about a vehicle) to stop suddenly because the engine is not receiving enough power; to make a vehicle do this accidentally （指车辆）（使）抛锚: The bus often stalls on this hill. 公共汽车在这斜坡上常常抛锚。 I kept stalling the car. 我的汽车老是抛锚。
2 to avoid doing sth or to try to stop sth happening until a later time 回避；拖延

stallion
/ˈstæliən ||; ˈstæljən/noun [C] an adult male horse, especially one that is kept for breeding 成年雄马（尤指用来配种的种马） ☞Look at the note at horse. 参看horse的注释。

stalwart
/ˈstɔ:lwət ||; ˈstɔlwɚt/adj always loyal to the same organization, team, etc 忠诚的；忠贞的: a stalwart supporter of the club 俱乐部的忠实支持者 stalwart noun [C]

stamen
/ˈsteɪmən ||; ˈstemən/noun [C] a small thin male part in the middle of a flower that produces a fine powder(pollen) 雄蕊 ☞picture at flower 见flower插图

stamina
/ˈstæmɪnə ||; ˈstæmənə/noun [U] the ability to do sth that involves a lot of physical or mental effort for a long time 体力；耐力；持久力: You need a lot of stamina to run long distances. 长跑需要很大的耐力。

stammer
/ˈstæmə(r) ||; ˈstæmɚ/verb
1 [I,T] to speak with difficulty, repeating sounds and pausing before saying things correctly 口吃；结巴 · He stammered an apology and left quickly. 他结结巴巴地道歉，然后匆匆离去。 stammer noun [sing] to have a stammer 口吃

*stamp¹
/stæmp ||; stæmp/noun[C]
1 (formal 正式postage stamp) a small piece of paper that you stick onto a letter or package to show that you have paid for it to be posted 邮票: a first-class/second-class stamp 第一类╱第二类邮件邮票 Barry's hobby is collecting stamps. 巴里爱好集邮。 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图
In the British postal system, there are two types of stamp for posting letters, etc to other parts of Britain, first-class stamps and second-class stamps. Letters with first-class stamps are more expensive and arrive more quickly. 在英国，寄国内邮件用的邮票有两种：第一类邮件邮票(first-class stamp)和第二类邮件邮票(second-class stamp)。用第一类邮件邮票寄信较昂贵，但较快到达。
2 a small object that prints some words, a design, the date, etc when you press it onto a surface 印章；图章: a date stamp 印戳
3 the mark made by stamping sth onto a surface 印记；戳记: Have you got any visa stamps in your passport? 你护照上的签证盖印了吗？ (figurative 比喻) The government has given the project its stamp of approval. 政府已批准那项工程。
4 the stamp of sth [usu.sing] something that shows a particular quality or that sth was done by a particular person 标志；特征；印记
stamp²
/stæmp ||; stæmp/verb
1 [I,T] stamp (on sth) to put your foot down very heavily and noisily 用力踏或踩；顿足；跺脚: He stamped on the spider and squashed it. 他踩扁了那只蜘蛛。 It was so cold that I had to stamp my feet to keep warm. 天气冷极了，我只好跺着脚来驱寒保暖。 She stamped her foot in anger. 她气得直跺脚。
2 [I] to walk with loud heavy steps 重步走: She stamped around the room, shouting angrily. 她在房间里边怒吼，边跺着脚走来走去。
3 [T] stamp A (on B);stamp B (with A) to print some words, a design, the date, etc by pressing a small object (a stamp) onto a surface 打上印记；盖章: to stamp a passport 在护照上盖印
stamp sth out to put an end to sth completely 彻底消除，消灭（某事物）: The police are trying to stamp out this kind of crime. 警方正尽力杜绝这种罪行。

ˈstamp duty
noun [U] a tax in Britain on some legal documents （英国对某些法律文件所征收的）印花税

ˌstamped addressed ˈenvelope
(also ˌself-addressed ˈenvelope) noun [C] (abbr sae) an empty envelope with your own name and address and a stamp on it that you send to a company, etc when you want sth sent back to you （贴上邮票写明地址的）回邮信封（以方便人家寄回某物）

stampede
/stæmˈpi:d ||; stæmˈpid/noun [C] a situation in which a large number of animals or people start running in the same direction, for example because they are frightened or excited （一群动物或人因受惊、兴奋等）乱跑，惊窜，蜂拥 stampede verb [I]

stance
/stæns;stɑ:ns||; stæns/noun[C] [usu.sing]
1 stance (on sth) the opinions that sb expresses publicly about sth 态度；立场: the Prime Minister's stance on foreign affairs 首相在外交上的立场
2 the position in which sb stands, especially when playing a sport 站立的姿势或位置（尤指体育运动中的）

*stand¹
/stænd ||; stænd/verb [I,T] (past tense past participle stood /stʊd ||; stυd/)
1 [I] to be on your feet, not sitting or lying down; to be upright 站；站立: He was standing near the window. 他站在窗口附近。 Stand still -- I'm trying to draw you! 站着别动，我想把你画下来！ Only a few houses were left standing after the earthquake. 地震过后，只有几所房子没有倒塌。
2 [I] stand (up) to rise to your feet from another position 站起来: He stood up when I entered the room. 我走进房间时，他站了起来。
3 [T] to put sb/sth in a particular place or position 使处于某位置；放置: We stood the mirror against the wall while we decided where to hang it. 我们先将镜子靠在墙上，同时决定将它挂在何处。
4 [I] to be or to stay in a particular position or situation 位于，处于（某位置或状况）: The castle stands on a hill. 那个城堡耸立在山上。 The house has stood empty for ten years. 房子已空置了十年。
5 [I] (used about an offer, a decision, etc) to stay the same as before, without being changed （指提议、决定等）不变: Does your decision still stand? 你的决定仍维持不变吗？ The world record has stood for ten years. 这个世界纪录已保持了十年。
6 [I] stand (at) sth to be of a particular height, level, amount, etc 有，是（某高度、水平、数量等）: The world record stands at 6.59 metres. 世界纪录是6.59米。 The building stands nearly 60 metres high. 这建筑物有将近60米高。
7 [I] stand (on sth) to have an opinion or view about sth 有某种看法或观点
8 [I] stand to do sth to be in a situation where you are likely to do sth 很可能；势必: If he has to sell the company, he stands to lose a lot of money. 如果他不得不把公司出售，就势必蒙受巨大的经济损失。
9 [I] stand (for/as sth) to be one of the people hoping to be chosen in an election (a candidate) 参选；当候选人: She's standing for the European Parliament. 她参加欧洲议会选举。
10 [T] (in negative sentences and questions, with can/could 用于否定句及疑问句，与can或could连用) to not like sb/sth at all; to hate sb/sth 根本不喜欢，讨厌（某人或某事物）: I can't stand that woman -- she's so rude. 我不能容忍那个女人，她太粗鲁了。 I couldn't stand the thought of waiting another two hours so I went home. 一想到还要等两个小时我就受不了，所以我回家了。 [SYN] bear 同义词为bear
11 [T] (used especially with can/could 尤与can或could连用) to be able to survive difficult conditions 能忍受，经得起（困难）: Camels can stand extremely hot and cold temperatures. 骆驼能耐高温及严寒。 [SYN] take 同义词为take
stand around to stand somewhere not doing anything 闲站着: A lot of people were just standing around outside. 许多人无所事事地在外面站着。 stand aside to move to one side 站到一边: People stood aside to let the police pass. 人们站到一旁让警察通过。 stand back to move back 站到后面；退后: The policeman told everybody to stand back. 警察叫大家往后退。 stand by
1 to be present, but do nothing in a situation 袖手旁观: How can you stand by and let them treat their animals like that? 你怎能袖手旁观，让他们那样对待他们的动物？
2 to be ready to act 准备行动: The police are standing by in case there's trouble. 警方在场戒备以防有事发生。
stand for sth
1 to be a short form of sth 为…的缩约式；代表（某事物）: What does BBC stand for? BBC代表什么？
2 to support sth (such as an idea or opinion) 支持（主意、见解等）: I hate everything that the party stands for. 我讨厌那个党所主张的一切。
stand in (for sb) to take sb's place for a short time 暂时代替（某人） stand out to be easily seen or noticed 显眼；引人注目 stand up to be or become vertical 直立；站起来: You'll look taller if you stand up straight. 你站直了看上去高一点。 stand sb up(informal 非正式) to not appear when you have arranged to meet sb, especially a boyfriend or girlfriend 爽约（尤指跟男友或女友的约会） stand up for sb/sth to say or do sth which shows that you support sb/sth 支持；维护: I admire him. He really stands up for his rights. 我佩服他，他真的敢于维护自己的权利。 stand up to sb/sth to defend yourself against sb/sth who is stronger or more powerful 抵抗（强于自己的人或事物）
*stand²
/stænd ||; stænd/noun[C]
1 a table or an object that holds or supports sth, often so that people can buy it or look at it 摊位；摊子: a newspaper/hamburger stand 报摊；汉堡包摊子 a company stand at a trade fair 某公司在商品展览会的摊位
2 a large structure where people can watch sport from seats arranged in rows that are low near the front and high near the back （运动场的）看台
3 a stand (on/against sth) a strong effort to defend yourself or sth that you have a strong opinion about 采取行动自恒或捍恒主张: The workers have decided to take / make a standagainst further job losses. 工人们决定采取行动，反对继续裁员。

ˈstand-alone
adj (computing计算机技术) (used about computer machinery or programs) able to operate without any other machinery or programs （指计算机或程序）能独立运行或操作的

*standard¹
/ˈstændəd ||; ˈstændɚd/noun[C]
1 a level of quality 水平；水平: We complained about the low standard of service in the hotel. 我们投诉那家旅馆服务水平低劣。 This work is not up to your usual standard. 这个作品比不上你平常的水平。
2 a level of quality that you compare sth else with 标准: By European standardsthis is a very expensive city. 以欧洲的标准来说，这个城市的生活费很高。 He is a brilliant player by any standard. 以任何标准衡量，他都是个出色的运动员。
3 [usu.pl] a level of behaviour that is morally acceptable 道德标准: Many people are worried about falling standards in modern society. 许多人为现代社会道德水平日趋低落而感到忧心。
standard²
/ˈstændəd ||; ˈstændɚd/adj
1 normal or average; not special or unusual 一般的；普通的: He's got long arms, so standard sizes of shirt don't fit him. 他手臂长，因此穿普通尺寸的衬衫不称身。
2 that people generally accept as normal and correct 规范的；标准的: standard English 规范英语

standardize
/ˈstændədaɪz ||; ˈstændɚdˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to make things that are different the same 标准化；规格化: Safety tests on old cars have been standardized throughout Europe. 欧洲各地已对旧汽车使用统一的安全测试标准。 ➔standardization(also -isation) /stændədaɪˈzeɪʃn ||; ˌstændɚdəˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

ˌstandard of ˈliving
noun [C] a measure of how comfortable the life of a particular person or group is 生活水平；生活水平: There is a higher standard of living in the north than in the south. 北方的生活水平比南方高。 ☞An expression with a similar meaning is living standards. This is used in the plural Living standards have improved. living standards的意义相近，但用复数形式：Living standards have improved.生活水平已有所改善。

standby
/ˈstændbaɪ ||; ˈstændˌbaɪ/noun
1 [C] (plural standbys) a thing or person that can be used if needed, for example if sb/sth is not available or in an emergency 备用的事物；后备人员: We always keep candles as a standby in case there is a power cut. 我们总是留着蜡烛备用，以防停电。
2 [U] the state of being ready to do sth immediately if needed or if a ticket becomes available 准备就绪；随时候命: Ambulances were on standby along the route of the marathon. 马拉松赛跑时，沿途都有待命的救护车。 We were put on standby for the flight to Rome. 我们在等待候补机位飞往罗马。 standby adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) a standby ticket/passenger 候补机票；候补旅客

ˈstand-in
noun [C]
1 a person who does sb's job for a short time when he/she is not available （临时）代替人
2 a person who replaces an actor in some scenes in a film, especially dangerous ones 替身演员（尤指危险场景里的）

standing¹
/ˈstændɪŋ ||; ˈstændɪŋ/noun[U]
1 the position that sb/sth has, or how people think of him/her/it 地位；名声: The agreement has no legal standing. 这协议没有法律地位。 [SYN] status 同义词为status
2 the amount of time during which sth has continued to exist 已存在的时间
standing²
/ˈstændɪŋ ||; ˈstændɪŋ/adj that always exists; permanent 持续有效的；常备的；常设的

ˌstanding ˈorder
noun [C] an instruction to your bank to make a regular payment to sb from your account （客户给予银行的）定期付款指示

ˈstanding room
noun [U] space for people to stand in, especially in a theatre, sports stadium, etc ﹙尤指剧场、体育场等﹚站立的空间: standing room for 12,000 fans 可供12 000 名歌迷站立的地方 It was standing room onlyat the concert(= all the seats were sold). 音乐会只剩站票了。

standpoint
/ˈstændpɔɪnt ||; ˈstændˌpɔɪnt/noun [C] a particular way of thinking about sth 立场；观点 [SYN] point of view 同义词为point of view

standstill
/ˈstændstɪl ||; ˈstændˌstɪl/noun [sing] a situation when there is no movement, progress or activity 瘫痪；停顿: The traffic is at / has come to a complete standstill. 交通完全瘫痪。 grind to a halt/standstill→GRIND¹

ˈstand-up¹
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) stand-up comedy consists of one person standing in front of an audience and telling jokes 单人说笑表演的；单口的: a stand-up act 单人说笑表演 a stand-up comedian 单人说笑表演的演员
ˈstand-up²
noun
1 [C] a person who performs stand-up¹ comedy 单人说笑表演的演员；单口相声表演者
2 [U] stand-up¹ comedy 单人说笑表演；单口相声: When did you start doing stand-up? 你是什么时候开始表演单口相声的？

stank
past tense ofSTINK

stanza
/ˈstænzə ||; ˈstænzə/noun [C] (used about poetry 指诗) a group of lines in a repeated pattern that form a unit in some types of poem 诗节 [SYN] verse 同义词为verse

staple
/ˈsteɪpl ||; ˈstepḷ/noun [C] a small thin piece of bent wire that you push through pieces of paper using a special tool (stapler) in order to fasten them together 订书钉 ☞picture at stationery 见stationery插图 staple verb · Staple the letter to the application form. 将信订在申请表上。 ➔stapler noun [C] ☞picture at stationery 见stationery插图

ˌstaple ˈdiet
noun [C] [usu.sing] the main food that a person or animal normally eats 主食: a staple diet of rice and fish 以大米和鱼为主食

*star¹
/stɑ:(r) ||; stɑr/noun
1 [C] a large ball of burning gas in outer space that you see as a small point of light in the sky at night 星: It was a clear night and the stars were shining brightly. 那晚万里无云，天上的星星闪闪发亮。
2 [C] a shape, decoration, mark, etc with five or six points sticking out in a regular pattern 星形；星形饰物；星号: I've marked the possible candidates on the list with a star. 我已对名单上有可能当选的候选人做了星号。 ☞picture at shape 见shape插图
3 [C] a mark that represents a star that is used for telling you how good sth is, especially a hotel or restaurant （表示质量等级的）星（尤指酒店或餐厅）: a five-star hotel 五星级酒店
4 [C] a famous person in acting, music or sport （演艺界、音乐界或体育界的）明星: a pop/rock/film/movie star 流行音乐╱摇滚乐╱电影明星 a football/tennis star 足球╱网球明星
5 stars [pl] =HOROSCOPE
star²
/stɑ:(r) ||; stɑr/verb (starring;starred)
1 [I] star (in sth) to be one of the main actors in a play, film, etc 主演（舞台剧、电影等）: Gwyneth Paltrow is to star in a new romantic comedy. 格温内思˙帕尔特罗将主演一部新的爱情喜剧。
2 [T] to have sb as a star 由（某人）主演: The film stars Kate Winslett. 这部影片由凯特˙温斯莱特主演。

starboard
/ˈstɑ:bəd ||; ˈstɑrˌbord/noun [U] the side of a ship that is on the right when you are facing towards the front of it （船的）右舷 [OPP] port 反义词为port

starch
/stɑ:tʃ ||; stɑrtʃ/noun[C,U]
1 a white substance that is found in foods such as potatoes, rice and bread 淀粉
2 a substance that is used for making cloth STIFF 粉浆（用于浆衣服）

ˈstar-crossed
adj (in literature 文学) not able to be happy because of bad luck or fate 命运不好的；不幸的: Shakespeare's star-crossed lovers, Romeo and Juliet 罗密欧和朱丽叶这对莎士比亚笔下命运多舛的恋人

stardom
/ˈstɑ:dəm ||; ˈstɑrdəm/noun [U] the state of being a famous person in acting, music or sport 明星的地位或身分: She shot to stardom in a Broadway musical. 她在百老汇演出一部音乐剧，一下子成了明星。

stardust
/ˈstɑ:dʌst ||; ˈstɑrˌdʌst/noun [U] stars that are very far from the earth and appear like bright dust in the sky at night 星尘

*stare
/steə(r) ||; stɛr/verb [I] stare (at sb/sth) to look at sb or sth for a long time because you are surprised, shocked, etc （因吃惊等）凝视，盯住: Everybody stared at his hat. 人人都注视着他的帽子。 He didn't reply, he just stared into the distance. 他没有回答，只是凝视着远方。

starfish
/ˈstɑ:fɪʃ ||; ˈstɑrˌfɪʃ/noun [C] (plural starfish) a flat sea animal in the shape of a star with five or more arms 海星

starfruit
/ˈstɑ:fru:t ||; ˈstɑrˌfrut/noun [C] (plural starfruit) a green or yellow tropical fruit with a shape like a star 杨桃 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

stark¹
/stɑ:k ||; stɑrk/adj
1 very empty and without decoration and therefore not attractive 质朴的；荒凉的；粗陋的: a stark landscape 荒凉的景观
2 unpleasant and impossible to avoid 令人不快的；无法回避的: He now faces the stark reality of life in prison. 他现在面临坐牢这个无法回避的现实。
3 very different to sth in a way that is easy to see 明显不同的
stark²
/stɑ:k ||; stɑrk/adv completely; extremely 完全；极其: stark naked 一丝不挂 Have you gone stark raving mad? 你是不是完全疯了？

starlet
/ˈstɑ:lət ||; ˈstɑrlət/noun [C] a young woman actor who plays small parts and hopes to become famous 未成名的年轻女演员

starlight
/ˈstɑ:laɪt ||; ˈstɑrˌlaɪt/noun [U] the light that is sent out by stars in the sky 星光

starlit
/ˈstɑ:lɪt ||; ˈstɑrlɪt/adj (written 书面语) with light from the stars 星光照耀的: a starlit night 星光照耀的夜晚

starry
/ˈstɑ:ri ||; ˈstɑrɪ/adj full of stars 布满星星的: a starry night 满天星的夜晚

starship
/ˈstɑ:ʃɪp ||; ˈstɑrˌʃɪp/noun [C] (in science fiction) a large spacecraft in which people or other beings travel around space ﹙科幻小说中的﹚星际飞船

ˈstar-studded
adj (written 书面语) including many famous performers 明星荟萃的: a star-studded cast 明星荟萃的演出阵容

*start¹
/stɑ:t ||; stɑrt/verb
1 [I,T] start (sth/to do sth/doing sth) to begin doing sth 开始（做某事）: Turn over your exam papers and start now. 现在翻开试卷，开始作答。 We'll have to start (= leave) early if we want to be in Dover by 10.00 我们要在10时之前到达多佛尔的话，就必须及早动身。 Prices start at £5. 售价由5英镑起。 After waiting for an hour, the customers started to complain. 等了一个小时后，顾客开始抱怨。 She started playing the piano when she was six. 她六岁开始弹钢琴。 What time do you have to start work in the morning? 你早上得在什么时候开始工作？
2 [I,T] to begin or to make sth begin to happen （使）开始进行或发生: What time does the concert start? 音乐会什么时候开始？ I'd like to start the meeting now. 我想现在就开会。 The police think a young woman may have started the fire. 警方认为火灾可能是一个年轻女子引起的。 ☞Look at the note at begin. 参看begin的注释。
3 [I,T] start (sth) (up) (used about a machine, etc) to begin to work; to make an engine, a car, etc begin to work （指机器等）发动，开动: The car won't start. 这汽车发动不起来。 We heard an engine starting up in the street. 我们听见街上有发动引擎的声音。 He got onto his motor bike, started the engine and rode away. 他骑上摩托车，发动引擎，开车走了。
4 [I,T] start (sth) (up) to create a company, an organization, etc; to begin to exist 创立，成立（公司、组织等） · They've decided to start their own business. 他们决定自己开业做生意。 There are a lot of new companies starting up in that area now. 现在那个地区开了许多家新公司。
5 [I] to make a sudden, quick movement because you are surprised or afraid 吓一跳: A loud noise outside made me start. 外面的一声巨响吓了我一跳。
get/start off on the right/wrong foot (with sb)→FOOT¹ to start (off) with
1 used for giving your first reason for sth （用于提出第一个理由）首先，第一: ‘Why are you so angry?’ ‘Well, to start off with, you're late, and secondly you've lied to me.’ “你为什么这样生气？”“唉，首先是你迟到了。其次你说谎骗我。”
2 in the beginning; at first 起初；开始时: Everything was fine to start with, but the marriage quickly deteriorated. 起初一切顺利，但这桩婚姻很快恶化。
set/start the ball rolling→BALL start off to begin in a particular way 以某种方式开始: I'd like to start off by welcoming you all to Leeds. 首先我要欢迎你们到利兹来。 start on sth to begin doing sth that needs to be done 着手做某事 start out to begin your life, career, etc in a particular way that changed later 开始（某种生活、事业等）: She started out as a teacher in Glasgow. 她起初在格拉斯哥当教师。 start over (US 美) to begin again 重新开始
*start²
/stɑ:t ||; stɑrt/noun
1 [C] [usu.sing] the point at which sth begins 起点；开头: The chairman made a short speech at the start of the meeting. 主席在会议开始时作了简短发言。 I told you it was a bad idea from the start. 我一开始就对你说过这主意不好。
2 [C] [usu.sing] the action or process of starting 开始；开始的过程: to make a fresh start (= do sth again in a different way) 以不同的方式重新开始
3 the start [sing] the place where a race begins 起跑线；起跑地点: The athletes are now lining up at the start. 现在运动员在起跑线排成一行。
4 [C] [usu.sing] an amount of time or distance that you give to a weaker person at the beginning of a race, game, etc （比赛开始时）让予较弱一方的时间或距离 ☞Compare head start. 与head start比较。
5 [C] [usu.sing] a sudden quick movement that your body makes because you are surprised or afraid （因惊奇或恐惧而）吓一跳: She woke up with a start. 她惊醒了。
for a start(spoken 口语) (used to emphasize your first reason for sth) （用于强调第一个理由）首先: ‘Why can't we go on holiday?’ ‘Well, for a start we can't afford it...’ “为什么我们不能去度假？”“唉，首先，我们负担不起…” get off to a good, bad, etc start to start well, badly, etc 有好的╱坏的…开始 get off to a flying start→FLYING

starter
/ˈstɑ:tə(r) ||; ˈstɑrtɚ/ (US usually 美通常作 appetizer) noun [C] a small amount of food that is served before the main course of a meal 开胃菜

ˈstarting point
noun [C] starting point (for sth)
1 an idea or a topic that you use to begin a discussion with （讨论的）起点
2 the place where you begin a journey （旅程的）起点

startle
/ˈstɑ:tl ||; ˈstɑrtḷ/verb [T] to surprise sb/sth in a way that slightly shocks or frightens him/her/it 使轻微受惊: The gunshot startled the horses. 枪声使马匹受惊。 startled adj ➔startling /ˈstɑ:tlɪŋ ||; ˈstɑrtlɪŋ/ adj

startup
/ˈstɑ:tʌp ||; ˈstɑtˌʌp/noun [C] a company that is just beginning to operate, especially an Internet company 新兴公司﹙尤指网络公司﹚: dot-com startups 新兴网络公司 the fast-moving world of Internet startups迅猛发展的新兴网络公司的世界 ➔ˈstartup adj: startup costs/problems 创业初期的成本/问题

starvation
/stɑ:ˈveɪʃn ||; stɑrˈveʃən/noun [U] suffering or death because there is not enough food 饥饿；饿死: to die of starvation 饿死

*starve
/stɑ:v ||; stɑrv/verb [I,T] to suffer or die because you do not have enough food to eat; to make sb/sth suffer or die in this way （使）饥饿，饿死: Millions of people are starving in the poorer countries of the world. 在世界上的贫穷国家里，有数以百万计的人正在挨饿。 That winter many animals starved to death. 那年冬天许多动物饿死。 be starved of sth to suffer because you are not getting enough of sth that you need 缺乏（某事物）: The children had been starved of love and affection for years. 孩子们多年来都没有得到关爱。 be starving(informal 非正式) to be extremely hungry 非常饥饿

stash¹
/stæʃ ||; stæʃ/verb [T] (informal 非正式) to store sth in a safe or secret place 存放；贮藏；隐藏: She has a fortune stashed away in various bank accounts. 她有一大笔钱存在几个不同的银行账户下。 The gun was stashed under the bed. 那枝枪被藏在床底下。
stash²
/stæʃ ||; stæʃ/noun [C, usually sing] (informal 非正式) an amount of sth that is kept secretly 一批贮藏物: a stash of money 一笔存款

*state¹
/steɪt ||; stet/noun
1 [C] the mental, emotional or physical condition that sb/sth is in at a particular time 状况；状态: the state of the economy 经济状况 He is in a state of shock. 他处于休克状态。 The house is in a terrible state. 那所房子残破不堪。
2 (also State) [C] a country considered as an organized political community controlled by one government 国家: Pakistan has been an independent state since 1947. 巴基斯坦自1947年起成为独立国家。 ☞Look at the note at country. 参看country的注释。
3 especiallythe State [U] the government of a country （一国的）政府: affairs/matters of state 政务；国事 the relationship between the Church and the State 教会和政府的关系 a state-owned company 国营公司 She went to a state school. 她上国立学校。 heads of State (= government leaders) 政府首长
4 (also State) [C] an organized political community forming part of a country 州，邦（国家的一部份）: the southern States of the US 美国南方各州 ☞Compare county and province. 与county及province比较。
5 [U] the formal ceremonies connected with high levels of government or with the leaders of countries 官方的隆重仪式: The Queen is going on a state visit to China. 女王将前往中国进行国事访问。
6 the States [pl] (informal 非正式) the United States of America 美国: We lived in the States for about five years. 我们在美国住了约五年。
be in/get into a state (especially Brit 尤为英) (informal 非正式) to be or become very nervous or upset 处于紧张或不安的状态；紧张或不安起来: Now don't get into a state! I'm sure everything will be all right. 别紧张！肯定没事的。 state of affairs a situation 情况: This state of affairs must not be allowed to continue. 这种情况不容继续。 state of mind mental condition 心理状态: She's in a very confused state of mind. 她心里乱作一团。
*state²
/steɪt ||; stet/verb [T] to say or write sth, especially formally 陈述；说明；声明: Your letter states that you sent the goods on 31 March, but we have not received them. 你的信上说明3月31日已经把货寄出，但我们没有收到。

stately
/ˈsteɪtli ||; ˈstetlɪ/adj formal and impressive 庄重的；威严的；庄严的: a stately old building 庄严的古建筑

ˌstately ˈhome
noun [C] (Brit 英) a large old house that has historical interest and can be visited by the public （有历史价值、供人参观的）古老大宅

*statement
/ˈsteɪtmənt ||; ˈstetmənt/noun[C]
1 something that you say or write, especially formally 陈述，说明，声明（尤指正式的）: The Prime Minister will make a statement about the defence cuts today. 首相今天将就削减国防开支一事发表声明。
2 =BANK STATEMENT

statesman
/ˈsteɪtsmən ||; ˈstetsmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) an important and experienced politician who has earned public respect 政治家

static¹
/ˈstætɪk ||; ˈstætɪk/adj not moving, changing or developing 静态的；静止的；没有变化的: House prices are static. 房价没有变动。
static²
/ˈstætɪk ||; ˈstætɪk/noun[U]
1 sudden noises that disturb radio or television signals, caused by electricity in the atmosphere 静电干扰
2 (also ˌstatic elecˈtricity) electricity that collects on a surface 静电: My hair gets full of static when I brush it. 我梳头发时，头发上都是静电。

*station¹
/ˈsteɪʃn ||; ˈsteʃən/noun[C]
1 (also railway station) a building on a railway line where trains stop so that passengers can get on and off 火车站
2 (usually in compound nouns 通常用于构成复合名词) a building from which buses begin and end journeys （公共汽车）总站
3 (usually in compound nouns 通常用于构成复合名词) a building where a particular service or activity is based 提供某种服务或进行某种活动的地方: a police/fire station 警察局；消防站 a petrol station 加油站 a power station (= where electricity is generated) 发电站
4 (often in compound nouns 常用于构成复合名词) a radio or television company and the programmes it sends out 电台；电视台: a local radio/TV station 地方广播电台╱电视台 He tuned in to another station. 他收听另一个电台。 ☞Look at channel. 参看channel。
station²
/ˈsteɪʃn ||; ˈsteʃən/verb [T] (often passive 通常用于被动语态) to send sb, especially members of the armed forces, to work in a place for a period of time 派驻（尤指武装部队）

stationary
/ˈsteɪʃənri; US -nerɪ ||; ˈsteʃənˌɛrɪ/adj not moving 静止的；不动的: He crashed into the back of a stationary vehicle. 他撞上了一辆停着的车辆的尾部。

stationer's
/ˈsteɪʃənəz ||; ˈsteʃənɚz/noun [sing] a shop that sells writing equipment, such as paper, pens, envelopes, etc 文具店

*stationery
/ˈsteɪʃənri; US -nerɪ ||; ˈsteʃənˌɛrɪ/noun [U] writing equipment, for example pens, pencils, paper, envelopes 文具

ˈstation wagon
(US 美) =ESTATE CAR

statistics
/stəˈtɪstɪks ||; stəˈtɪstɪks/noun
1 [pl] numbers that have been collected in order to provide information about sth 统计数字: Statistics indicate that 90% of homes in this country have a television. 统计数字显示本国九成家庭有电视机。 crime statistics 罪案统计
2 [U] the science of collecting and studying these numbers 统计学 ➔statistical /stəˈtɪstɪkl ||; stəˈtɪstɪkḷ/ adj statistical information 统计资料 ➔statistically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

*statue
/ˈstætʃu: ||; ˈstætʃu/noun [C] a figure of a person or animal that is made of stone or metal and usually put in a public place 塑像；雕像；铸像 ☞picture at column 见column插图

statuesque
/ˌstætʃuˈesk ||; ˌstætʃuˈɛsk/adj (written 书面语) (usually used about a woman) tall and beautiful in an impressive way; like a statue ﹙通常指女性﹚又高又美的，雕塑般的

statuette
/ˌstætʃuˈet ||; ˌstætʃυˈɛt/noun [C] a small statue 小雕像；小塑像；小铸像

stature
/ˈstætʃə(r) ||; ˈstætʃɚ/noun [U] (written 书面语)
1 the importance and respect that sb has because people have a high opinion of his/her skill or of what he/she has done 名望；地位
2 the height of a person 身高: He's quite small in stature. 他身材矮小。

status
/ˈsteɪtəs ||; ˈstetəs/noun
1 [U] the legal position of a person, group or country （法律上的）地位，身分: Please indicate your name, age and marital status (= whether you are married or single). 请写明姓名、年龄及婚姻状况。 They were granted refugee status. 他们取得难民身分。
2 [sing] your social or professional position in relation to other people （社会或专业）地位，身分: Teachers don't have a very high status in this country. 教师在这个国家地位不高。 [SYN] standing 同义词为standing
3 [U] a high social position 崇高的社会地位: The new job gave him much more status. 新工作大大提高了他的社会地位。

ˈstatus symbol
noun [C] something that a person owns that shows that he/she has a high position in society and a lot of money 身分标志；地位象征

statute
/ˈstætʃu:t ||; ˈstætʃυt/noun [C] (formal 正式) a law or a rule 法规；法令；条例

ˈstatute law
noun [U] (technical术语) all the written laws of a parliament, etc 成文法；制定法 ☞Look at case law and common law. 参看case law及common law。

statutory
/ˈstætʃətri; US -tɔ:rɪ ||; ˈstætʃυˌtɔrɪ/adj (formal 正式) decided by law 法定的: a statutory right 法定权利

staunch
/stɔ:ntʃ ||; stɔntʃ/adj believing in sb/sth or supporting sb/sth very strongly; loyal 坚定的；忠实的

stave¹
/steɪv ||; stev/noun[C]
1 a strong stick or pole （坚实的）棍，柱: fence staves 栅栏的木柱
2 (US 美 staff) a set of five lines on which music is written 五线谱 ☞picture at music 见music插图
stave²
/steɪv ||; stev/verb stave sth off to stop sth unpleasant from happening now, although it may happen at a later time; to delay sth （暂时）防止，阻止；使延迟: to stave off hunger/illness/inflation/bankruptcy 防止饥饿；防治疾病；防止通货膨胀；防止破产

*stay¹
/steɪ ||; ste/verb[I]
1 to continue to be somewhere and not go away 逗留；停留: Patrick stayed in bed until 11 o'clock. 帕特里克11点才起床。 I can't stay long. 我不能久留。 Stay on this road until you get to Wells. 沿这条路走，一直走到韦尔斯。 Pete's staying late at the office tonight. 皮特今晚要在办公室留到很晚。
2 to continue to be in a particular state or situation without change 维持或保持（某种状态）: I can't stay awake any longer. 我实在困得非睡不可了。 I don't know why they stay together (= continue to be married or in a relationship). 我不知道他们为什么还不分手。 ☞ Remain and stay are similar in meaning but remain is more formal. remain和stay意思相近，但remain多用于正式场合。
3 to live in a place temporarily as a visitor or guest 作客: We stayed with friends in France. 我们在法国时住在朋友处。 Which hotel are you staying at ? 你住在哪家旅馆？ Can you stay for lunch? 你可以留下来吃午饭吗？ Why don't you stay the night ? 你何不留下来过夜？
stay put(informal 非正式) to continue in one place; to not leave 留在原地 stay behind to not leave a place after other people have gone （在其他人走后）留下: I'll stay behind and help you wash up. 我会留下来帮你洗碗。 stay in to be at home and not go out 留在家中: I'm going to stay in and watch TV. 我要留在家中看电视。 stay on (at...) to continue studying, working, etc somewhere for longer than expected or after other people have left 继续留下（工作或学习） stay out to continue to be away from your house, especially late at night 在外面逗留（尤指到深夜） stay up to go to bed later than usual 熬夜: I'm going to stay up to watch the late film. 我要熬夜看那部晚场电影。
stay²
/steɪ ||; ste/noun [C] a period of time that you spend somewhere as a visitor or guest 作客的时间: Did you enjoy your stay in Crete? 你喜欢在克里特逗留的日子吗？

STD
/ˌes ti: ˈdi: ||; ˌɛs ti ˈdi/abbr
1 (Brit 英) subscriber trunk dialling; the system by which you can make long-distance telephone calls direct 用户直拨长途电话系统
2 sexually transmitted disease 性传染病；性病

steadfast
/ˈstedfɑ:st; US -fæst ||; ˈstɛdˌfæst/adj not changing in your attitudes or aims 坚定的；不动摇的: steadfast loyalty 忠贞不渝 He remained steadfast in his determination to bring the killers to justice.他要把杀人凶手绳之以法的决心一直没有动摇。 ➔steadfastly adv: She steadfastly refused to speak. 她坚决不肯发言。

*steady¹
/ˈstedi ||; ˈstɛdɪ/adj (steadier;steadiest)
1 developing, growing or happening gradually and at a regular rate 有规律的；稳步的；稳定的: a steady increase/decline 稳步上升╱下降
2 staying the same; not changing and therefore safe 不变的；固定的；稳固的: a steady job/income 固定的工作╱收入
3 firmly fixed, supported or balanced; not shaking or likely to fall down 稳定的；不摇晃的: You need a steady hand to take good photographs. 手要稳才能拍好照片。 He held the ladder steady as she climbed up it. 她爬上去时，他扶稳梯子。 ➔steadily adv Unemployment has risen steadily since April 2000. 自2000年4月起，失业数字便逐步上升。
steady²
/ˈstedi ||; ˈstɛdɪ/verb [I,T] (present participle steadying third person singular present steadies;past tense past participle steadied) to stop yourself/sb/sth from moving, shaking or falling; to stop moving, shaking or falling （使）稳定，不摇晃 · She thought she was going to fall, so she put out a hand to steady herself. 她以为要摔倒，就伸出一只手稳住自己。 He had to steady his nerves/ voicebefore beginning his speech. 他得镇定一下情绪╱声音才能开始讲话。

steak
/steɪk ||; stek/noun [C,U] a thick flat piece of meat or fish 牛排；肉排；鱼排: a piece of steak 一块肉排 a cod/salmon steak 一块鳕鱼╱鲑鱼排 ☞Look at chop ². 参看chop^2。 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

steakhouse
/ˈsteɪkhaʊs ||; ˈstekˌhaus/noun [C] a restaurant that serves mainly steak 牛排餐厅

*steal
/sti:l ||; stil/verb (past tense stole /stəʊl ||; stol/ past participle stolen /ˈstəʊlən ||; ˈstolən/)
1 [I,T] steal (sth) (from sb/sth) to take sth from a person, shop, etc without permission and without intending to return it or pay for it 偷；窃 · The terrorists were driving a stolen car. 恐怖分子驾驶一辆偷来的汽车。 We found out she had been stealing from us for years. 我们发现多年来她一直在偷我们的东西。 ☞You steal things, but you rob a person or place My camera has been stolen! I've been robbed! to rob a bank 偷东西叫做steal，抢劫他人叫做rob：My camera has been stolen!我的照相机被偷走了！·I've been robbed!我被人抢劫！·to rob a bank抢劫银行
Look also at the note at thief. 另参看thief的注释。
2 [I] steal away, in, out, etc to move somewhere secretly and quietly 偷偷移动

stealth
/stelθ ||; stɛlθ/noun [U] (formal 正式) behaviour that is secret or quiet 秘密的或悄悄的行动 ➔stealthy adj a stealthy approach/movement 偷偷接近；悄悄移动 ➔stealthily adv

*steam¹
/sti:m ||; stim/noun [U] the hot gas that is produced by boiling water 水蒸气；蒸汽: Steam was rising from the coffee. 咖啡冒着热气。 a steam engine (= that uses the power of steam) 蒸汽机 let off steam(informal 非正式) to get rid of energy or express strong feeling by behaving in a noisy or wild way 发泄精力或情绪 run out of steam to gradually lose energy or enthusiasm 渐渐筋疲力尽或失去热情
steam²
/sti:m ||; stim/verb
1 [I] to send out steam 散发蒸汽；冒水汽: a bowl of steaming hot soup 一碗热腾腾的汤
2 [I,T] to place food over boiling water so that it cooks in the steam; to cook in this way 蒸（食物）: steamed vegetables/fish 蒸熟的蔬菜╱鱼 Leave the potatoes to steam for 30 minutes. 把马铃薯蒸30分钟。
be/get steamed up(informal 非正式) to be or become very angry or worried about sth （变得）愤怒或忧虑 steam (sth) up to cover sth or become covered with steam （使）蒙上蒸汽: My glasses have steamed up. 我的眼镜布满水汽。

steamer
/ˈsti:mə(r) ||; ˈstimɚ/noun[C]
1 a ship that is driven by steam 汽船；轮船
2 a metal container with small holes in it, that is placed over a pan of boiling water in order to cook food in the steam 蒸汽锅

steamroller
/ˈsti:mrəʊlə(r) ||; ˈstimˌrolɚ/noun [C] a big heavy vehicle with wide heavy wheels that is used for making the surface of a road flat 蒸汽压路机

steamship
/ˈsti:mʃɪp ||; ˈstimˌʃɪp/noun [C] (abbr SS) a ship driven by steam 汽船；轮船

*steel¹
/sti:l ||; stil/noun [U] a very strong metal that is made from iron mixed with another substance (carbon). Steel is used for making knives, tools, machines, etc. 钢
steel²
/sti:l ||; stil/verb [T] steel yourself to prepare yourself to deal with sth difficult or unpleasant 坚强起来（以面对困难或不快事情）: Steel yourself for a shock. 你要作好准备，以免大吃一惊。

ˌsteel ˈwool
(also ˌwire ˈwool) noun [U] a mass of fine steel threads that you use for cleaning pots and pans, making surfaces smooth, etc 钢棉，钢绒（用于擦洗锅子、磨光等）

steelworks
/ˈsti:lwɜ:ks ||; ˈstilˌwɝks/noun [C] [with.sop] (plural steelworks) a factory where steel is made 炼钢厂

steely
/ˈsti:li ||; ˈstilɪ/adj
1 (used about a person's character or behaviour) strong, hard and unfriendly ﹙人的性格或行为﹚强硬的；冷冰冰的: a cold, steely voice 冷冰冰的腔调 a look of steely determination 一副下定决心、不可动摇的神态
2 like steel in colour ﹙色泽﹚似钢的: steely blue eyes 灰蓝色的眼睛 The sky was cold and steely.昏暗的天空弥漫着寒意。

*steep
/sti:p ||; stip/adj
1 (used about a hill, mountain, street, etc) rising or falling quickly; at a sharp angle （指斜坡、山、街道等）坡度大的，陡峭的: I don't think I can cycle up that hill. It's too steep. 我认为我骑自行车上不了那座山，那儿太陡峭了。
2 (used about an increase or fall in sth) very big （指上升或下降幅度）很大的
3 (informal 非正式) too expensive （价格）过高的 ➔steeply adv House prices have risen steeply this year. 房价今年暴涨。 ➔steepness noun [U]

steeped
/sti:pt ||; stipt/adj steeped in sth having a lot of; full of sth 有许多的；充满的: a city steeped in history 一座历史悠久的城市

steeple
/ˈsti:pl ||; ˈstipḷ/noun [C] a tower on the roof of a church, often with a pointed top(spire) （教堂的）尖塔

*steer
/stɪə(r) ||; stɪr/verb
1 [I,T] to control the direction that a vehicle is going in 驾驶，操纵（行驶方向）: Can you push the car while I steer? 我操纵方向盘，你推车好吗？ [T] to steer a boat/ship/bicycle/motorbike 驾驶小船╱轮船╱自行车╱摩托车 ☞ Steer means to control the direction of a vehicle. If you ride a bicycle/motorbike or sail a boat you steer it and you are also in control of everything else. steer指控制车辆的方向。骑(ride)自行车╱摩托车或驾驶(sail)船只，不但控制方向，也控制其他各方面。
2 [T] to take control of a situation and try to influence the way it develops 操纵；引导: She tried to steer the conversation away from the subject of money. 她试图转移话题，不再谈金钱。
keep/stay/steer clear (of sb/sth)→CLEAR²

steering
/ˈstɪərɪŋ ||; ˈstɪrɪŋ/noun [U] the parts of a vehicle that control the direction that it moves in 转向装置: a car with power steering 有转向助力装置的汽车

ˈsteering wheel
(also wheel) noun [C] the wheel that the driver turns in a vehicle to control the direction that it moves in 方向盘 ☞picture at car 见car插图

stellar
/ˈstelə(r) ||; ˈstɛlɚ/adj (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) (technical术语) connected with the stars 与星有关的

*stem¹
/stem ||; stɛm/noun[C]
1 the main long thin part of a plant above the ground from which the leaves or flowers grow 树干；茎；梗 ☞pictures at flower and on page C2 见flower及C2页插图
2 (grammar语法) the main part of a word onto which other parts are added 词干: ‘Writ-’ is the stem of the words ‘write’, ‘writing’, ‘written’ and ‘writer’. writ-是write、writing、written和writer的词干。
stem²
/stem ||; stɛm/verb [T] (stemming;stemmed) to stop sth that is increasing or spreading 阻止（某物增加或蔓延） stem from sth (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时) to be the result of sth 是…的结果；由…导致或引起 Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (= -ing form) He was treated for depression stemming from his domestic and business difficulties. 虽然这个动词不用于进行时，但它的现在分词还是常见：He was treated for depression stemming from his domestic and business difficulties.他在接受治疗，因为他在家庭生活及生意上遇到许多难题，得了抑郁症。
stench
/stentʃ ||; stɛntʃ/noun [C] [sing] a very unpleasant smell 恶臭

stencil
/ˈstensl ||; ˈstɛnsḷ/noun [C] a thin piece of metal, plastic or card with a design cut out of it, that you put onto a surface and paint over, so that the design is left on the surface; the pattern or design that is produced in this way （印刷图案等用的）模版；用模版印刷的图案 stencil verb [T] (stencilling;stencilled (US 美) stenciling;stenciled)

step-
/step- ||; stɛp/prefix (used in compound nouns 用于构成复合名词) related as a result of one parent marrying again 因父亲或母亲再婚而有亲属关系

*step¹
/step ||; stɛp/noun[C]
1 the action of lifting one foot and putting it down in a different place 脚步: Nick took a step forward and then stopped. 尼克向前走一步，然后停下来。 I heard steps outside the window. 我听见窗外有脚步声。 We were obviously lost so we decided to retrace our steps(= go back the way we had come). 我们显然迷了路，因此决定往回走。
2 one action in a series of actions that you take in order to achieve sth 步骤: This will not solve the problem completely, but it is a step in the right direction. 这不会彻底解决问题，但朝着正确的方向迈了一步。
3 one of the surfaces on which you put your foot when you are going up or down stairs 梯级；台阶: on the top/bottom step 在最上面的╱最底下的一级 ☞Look at the note at stair. 参看stair的注释。
in/out of step (with sb/sth) moving/not moving your feet at the same time as other people when you are marching, dancing, etc （与某人或某事物）步伐一致╱不一致 step by step (used for talking about a series of actions) moving slowly and gradually from one action or stage to the next （指一连串行动）按部就班，逐步: clear step-by-step instructions 清楚的逐步指令 take steps to do sth to take action in order to achieve sth 采取一连串行动或措施（以达到目的） watch your step
1 to be careful about where you are walking 小心行走
2 to be careful about how you behave 谨慎行事
*step²
/step ||; stɛp/verb [I] (stepping;stepped)
1 to lift one foot and put it down in a different place when you are walking 迈步；踏: Be careful! Don't step in the mud. 小心！不要踩上泥。 to step forward/back 向前走；往后退 Ouch! You stepped on my foot! 哎哟！你踩着我的脚了！
2 to move a short distance; to go somewhere 移动短距离；去某处: Could you step out of the car please, sir? 请你下车好吗，先生？ I stepped outside for a minute to get some air. 我到外面透一会儿气。
step down to leave an important job or position and let sb else take your place 辞职；下台 step in to help sb in a difficult situation or to become involved in a dispute 介入（纠纷） step sth up to increase the amount, speed, etc of sth 增加（数目、速度等）: The Army has decided to step up its security arrangements. 军队已决定加强保安措施。

stepbrother
/ˈstepbrʌðə(r) ||; ˈstɛpˌbrʌðɚ/noun [C] the son from an earlier marriage of sb who has married your mother or father 继父与前妻或继母与前夫所生的儿子 ☞Compare half-brother. 与half-brother比较。

stepchild
/ˈsteptʃaɪld ||; ˈstɛpˌtʃaɪld/noun [C] (plural stepchildren) the child from an earlier marriage of your husband or wife 妻子与前夫或丈夫与前妻所生的孩子

stepdaughter
