/ˈstepdɔ:tə(r) ||; ˈstɛpˌdɔtɚ/noun [C] the daughter from an earlier marriage of your husband or wife 妻子与前夫或丈夫与前妻所生的女儿

stepfather
/ˈstepfɑ:ðə(r) ||; ˈstɛpˌfɑðɚ/noun [C] the man who has married your mother when your parents are divorced or your father is dead 继父；后父

stepladder
/ˈsteplædə(r) ||; ˈstɛpˌlædɚ/noun [C] a short ladder with two parts, one with steps, that are joined together at the top so that it can stand on its own and be folded up when you are not using it. 活梯

stepmother
/ˈstepmʌðə(r) ||; ˈstɛpˌmʌðɚ/noun [C] the woman who has married your father when your parents are divorced or your mother is dead 继母；后母

steppe
/step ||; stɛp/noun [C] [usu.pl] [U] a large area of land with grass but few trees, especially in south-east Europe and Siberia 干草原（尤指欧洲东南部及西伯利亚的）

ˈstepping stone
noun [C]
1 one of a line of flat stones that you can step on in order to cross a river （过河时的）踏脚石
2 something that allows you to make progress or helps you to achieve sth 进身之阶；达到目的的途径

stepsister
/ˈstepsɪstə(r) ||; ˈstɛpˌsɪstɚ/noun [C] the daughter from an earlier marriage of sb who has married your mother or father 继父与前妻或继母与前夫所生的女儿 ☞Compare half-sister. 与half-sister比较。

stepson
/ˈstepsʌn ||; ˈstɛpˌsʌn/noun [C] the son from an earlier marriage of your husband or wife 妻子与前夫或丈夫与前妻所生的儿子

stereo
/ˈsteriəʊ ||; ˈstɛrɪo/ (plural stereos) noun
1 (also stereo system) [C] a machine that plays CDs or cassettes, or a radio that has two boxes (speakers) so that you hear separate sounds from each 立体声音响设备；立体声唱机；立体声收音机: a car/personal stereo 汽车╱个人音响
2 [U] the system for playing recorded music, speech etc in which the sound is divided in two parts 立体声音响: This programme is broadcast in stereo. 这个节目用立体声广播。 ☞Look at mono. 参看mono。 stereo adj a stereo television 立体声电视机

stereotype
/ˈsteriətaɪp ||; ˈstɛrɪəˌtaɪp/noun [C] a fixed idea about a particular type of person or thing, which is often not true in reality 固定的形象或模式（常与现实不符） stereotype verb · In advertisements, women are often stereotyped as housewives. 在广告中，妇女通常被定型为家庭主妇。

sterile
/ˈsteraɪl;ˈsterəl/adj
1 not able to produce young animals or babies 不育的
2 completely clean and free from bacteria 消过毒的；无菌的: All equipment used during a medical operation must be sterile. 手术中所用的全部器材必须彻底消毒。
3 not producing any useful result 无结果的: a sterile discussion/argument 毫无结果的讨论／争论 ➔sterility /stəˈrɪləti/ noun [U]

sterilize
/ˈstərəlaɪz ||; ˈstɛrəˌlaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T]
1 to make sb/sth completely clean and free from bacteria 杀菌；消毒
2 (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to perform an operation on a person or an animal so that he/she/it cannot have babies （通过手术）使失去生殖能力，使绝育 ➔sterilization(also -isation) /ˌsterəlaɪˈzeɪʃn; US -ləˈz- ||; ˌstɛrələˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

sterling¹
/ˈstɜ:lɪŋ ||; ˈstɝlɪŋ/noun [U] the system of money that is used in Britain, that uses the pound as its basic unit （以英镑为基本单位的）英国货币
sterling²
/ˈstɜ:lɪŋ ||; ˈstɝlɪŋ/adj of very high quality 质量极高的: sterling work 优秀作品

stern¹
/stɜ:n ||; stɝn/adj very serious; not smiling 严肃的；严厉的: a stern expression/warning 严肃的表情；严厉的警告 ➔sternly adv
stern²
/stɜ:n ||; stɝn/noun [C] the back end of a ship or boat 船尾 ☞Look at bow ². 参看bow^2。 ☞picture at boat 见boat插图

sternum
/ˈstɜ:nəm ||; ˈstɝnəm/noun [C] (formal 正式) the long flat bone in the middle of your chest that the seven top pairs of curved bones(ribs)are connected to 胸骨 [SYN]A less formal word is breastbone. 不大正式的场合用breastbone。 ☞picture at body 见body插图

steroid
/ˈsterɔɪd ||; ˈstɛrɔɪd/noun [C] a chemical substance produced naturally in the body. There are several different types of steroids. They can be used to treat various diseases and are also sometimes used illegally by people playing sports to improve their performance. 类固醇（体内产生的一种化学物质，种类很多，能治疗各种疾病，有时运动员将其作为兴奋剂服用） ☞Look at anabolic steroid. 参看anabolic steroid。

stethoscope
/ˈsteθəskəʊp ||; ˈstɛθəˌskop/noun [C] the piece of equipment that a doctor uses for listening to your breathing and heart 听诊器

stew
/stju:; US stu: ||; stu/noun [C,U] a type of food that you make by cooking meat and/or vegetables in liquid for a long time 炖肉或菜 stew verb [I,T]

steward
/ˈstju:əd; US ˈstu:ərd ||; ˈstuɚd/noun[C]
1 a man whose job is to look after passengers on an aircraft, a ship or a train （飞机、轮船、火车等的）男乘务员，男服务员
2 (Brit 英) a person who helps to organize a large public event, for example a race 管事，干事（负责筹备赛马等大型公开活动的人）

stewardess
/ˌstju:əˈdes;ˈstju:ə-; US ˈstu:ərdəs ||; ˈstuɚdəs/noun[C]
1 a woman whose job is to look after passengers on an aircraft （飞机上的）女乘务员，女服务员，空中小姐 [SYN] air hostess 同义词为air hostess
2 a woman who looks after the passengers on a ship or train （轮船、火车的）女乘务员，女服务员

*stick¹
/stɪk ||; stɪk/verb (past tense past participle stuck /stʌk ||; stʌk/)
1 [I,T] stick (sth) in/into (sth) to push a pointed object into sth; to be pushed into sth （把尖物）刺，刺入，插进 · Stick a fork into the meat to see if it's ready. 将叉子插进肉里看熟了没有。
2 [I,T] to fix sth to sth else by using a special substance (glue); to become fixed to sth else （用胶水）贴上，黏住 · I stuck a stamp on an envelope. 我把邮票黏在信封上。
3 [T] (informal 非正式) to put sth somewhere, especially quickly or carelessly 放置（尤指迅速或随便地）: Stick your bags in the bedroom. 把你的包放在卧室里。 Just at that moment James stuck his head round the door. 就在那时，詹姆斯从门缝里探头进来。
4 [I] stick (in sth) (used about sth that can usually be moved) to become fixed in one position so that it cannot be moved （指通常可以移动的东西）固定于某位置不能动: The car was stuck in the mud. 汽车陷入泥中。 This drawer keeps sticking. 这抽屉老是卡住。
5 [T] (informal 非正式) (often in negative sentences and questions 常用于否定句及疑问句) to stay in a difficult or unpleasant situation 忍受: I can't stick this job much longer. 我不能再忍受这份工作了。
poke/stick your nose into sth→NOSE¹ stick/put your tongue out→TONGUE stick around(informal 非正式) to stay somewhere, waiting for sth to happen or for sb to arrive 在某处逗留或等待 stick at sth(informal 非正式) to continue working at sth even when it is difficult 坚持做某事 stick by sb(informal 非正式) to continue to give sb help and support even in difficult times 坚决支持或忠于某人 stick out(informal 非正式) to be very noticeable and easily seen 显眼；突出: The new office block really sticks out from the older buildings around it. 新办公大楼屹立于旧建筑之中显得尤其突出。 stick (sth) out to be further out than sth else; to push sth further out than sth else （使）突出，伸出: The boy's head was sticking out of the window. 那个男孩子把头伸出窗外。 stick it/sth out(informal 非正式) to stay in a difficult or unpleasant situation until the end 忍耐到底 stick to sth(informal 非正式) to continue with sth and not change to anything else 坚持（某事物） stick together(informal 非正式) (used about a group of people) to stay friendly and loyal to each other （指一群人）彼此忠诚，团结一致 stick up to point upwards 竖起: You look funny. Your hair's sticking up! 你的样子很滑稽。头发都竖起来了！ stick up for yourself/sb/sth(informal 非正式) to support or defend yourself/sb/sth 支持；维护: Don't worry. I'll stick up for you if there's any trouble. 别担心。有问题我会支持你。
*stick²
/stɪk ||; stɪk/noun[C]
1 a small thin piece of wood from a tree 树枝
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) =WALKING STICK
3 (in hockey and some other sports) a long thin piece of wood that you use for hitting the ball （曲棍球等体育活动的）球棒，球棍: a hockey stick 曲棍球棍 ☞Look at bat ¹(1), club ¹(4) and racket (3). 参看bat^1(1)、club^1(4)及racket(3)。 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图
4 a long thin piece of sth 一根；一支: a stick of celery/dynamite 一根芹菜；一管炸药

sticker
/ˈstɪkə(r) ||; ˈstɪkɚ/noun [C] a piece of paper with writing or a picture on one side that you can stick onto sth 黏贴标签；贴纸

ˈsticker price
noun [C] (US 美) the price that is marked on sth, especially a car ﹙尤指汽车的﹚标价

stickler
/ˈstɪklə(r) ||; ˈstɪklɚ/noun [C] a person who thinks that a particular quality or type of behaviour is very important and expects other people to think and behave in the same way 非常着重﹙某质量或行为﹚的人: She's a stickler for punctuality. 她是个非常注重守时的人。

stickpin
/ˈstɪkpɪn ||; ˈstɪkˌpɪn/noun [C] (US 美) a decorative pin that is worn on a tie to keep it in place, or as a piece of jewellery ﹙领带的﹚装饰别针

ˈstick-up
noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) = hold-up (2)

*sticky
/ˈstɪki ||; ˈstɪkɪ/adj (stickier;stickiest)
1 used for describing a substance that easily becomes joined to things that it touches, or sth that is covered with this kind of substance 黏的；黏糊糊的: These sweets are very sticky. 这些糖果非常黏。 sticky tape 黏胶带
2 (informal 非正式) (used about a situation) difficult or unpleasant （指处境）困难的，叫人为难的

*stiff¹
/stɪf ||; stɪf/adj
1 (used about material, paper, etc) firm and difficult to bend or move （指物质、纸张等）坚硬的，不易弯曲或移动的: My new shoes feel rather stiff. 我的新鞋子穿起来感到有点硬。 The door handle is stiff and I can't turn it. 这门把很紧，我转不动。
2 (used about parts of the body) not easy to move （指身体某部位）僵硬的: My arm feels really stiff after playing tennis yesterday. 昨天打过网球后，我的手臂感到很僵硬。
3 (used about a liquid) very thick; almost solid （指液体）浓的，稠的: Beat the egg whites until they are stiff. 将蛋白打到变稠为止。
4 more difficult or stronger than usual 艰难的；强劲的；激烈的: The firm faces stiff competition from its rivals. 公司面临对手的激烈竞争。 a stiff breeze/wind 紧吹的微风；烈风
5 (used about sb's behaviour) not relaxed or friendly; formal （指行为）拘谨的，板着脸的，一本正经的
6 (used about an alcoholic drink) strong （指酒）烈性的: a stiff whisky 烈性威士忌酒 ➔stiffness noun [U]
stiff²
/stɪf ||; stɪf/adv (informal 非正式) extremely 极端: to be bored/frozen/scared/worried stiff 无聊╱僵冻╱害怕╱担心得厉害

stiffen
/ˈstɪfn ||; ˈstɪfən/verb
1 [I] (used about a person) to suddenly stop moving and hold your body very straight, usually because you are afraid or angry （指人）（因恐惧或愤怒）突然发僵
2 [I,T] to become rigid; to make sth rigid so that it will not bend （使）变硬，僵硬

stiffly
/ˈstɪfli ||; ˈstɪflɪ/adv in an unfriendly formal way 拘谨: He smiled stiffly. 他拘谨地笑。

stifle
/ˈstaɪfl ||; ˈstaɪfḷ/verb
1 [T] to stop sth happening, developing or continuing 扼杀；阻止；抑制: Her strict education had stifled her natural creativity. 她所受的严厉教育方式扼杀了她天生的创造力。 to stifle a yawn/cry/giggle 忍住呵欠╱哭╱笑
2 [I,T] to be or to make sb unable to breathe because it is very hot and/or there is no fresh air （使）窒息，无法呼吸 · Richard was almost stifled by the smoke. 理查德德差点被烟窒息。 ➔stifling /ˈstaɪflɪŋ ||; ˈstaɪflɪŋ/ adj The heat was stifling. 热得令人窒息。

stigma
/ˈstɪgmə ||; ˈstɪgmə/noun
1 [C,U] bad and often unfair feelings that people in general have about a particular illness, way of behaving, etc （对某种疾病、行为方式等的）偏见，诋毁，污名: There is still a lot of stigma attached to being unemployed. 仍然有很多人认为失业是耻辱。
2 [C] the top of the CARPEL(= the female part in the middle of a flower) where POLLEN is received （雌蕊的）柱头 ☞picture at flower 见flower插图

stiletto
/stɪˈletəʊ ||; stɪˈlɛto/noun [C] (plural stilettos or stilettoes)
1 a woman's shoe with a very high narrow heel; the heel on such a shoe 细高跟女鞋；细高跟 [SYN]spike heel 同义词为 spike heel
2 a small knife with a narrow pointed blade 短剑；匕首

*still¹
/stɪl ||; stɪl/adv
1 continuing until now or until the time you are talking about and not finishing 仍然；还是: Do you still live in London? 你还住在伦敦吗？ It's still raining. 仍在下雨。 I've eaten all the food but I'm still hungry. 我已把东西全部吃光，但仍然觉得饿。 In 1997 Zoran was still a student. 1997年佐兰还是个学生。
2 in addition; more 还有: There are still ten days to go until my holiday. 还有十天我才放假。
3 in spite of what has just been said 虽然如此；然而: He had a bad headache but he still went to the party. 他的头疼得很厉害，但他仍然去参加聚会。
4 used for making a COMPARATIVE adjective stronger （用于强化比较级形容词）: It was very cold yesterday, but today it's colder still. 昨天很冷，但今天更加冷。 There was still more bad news to come. 更坏的消息还在后头。
*still²
/stɪl ||; stɪl/adj adv
1 not moving 不动；静止: Stand still! I want to take a photograph! 站着别动！我想拍张照！ Children find it hard to keep / stay stillfor long periods. 儿童觉得很难长时间保持不动。
2 quiet or calm 宁静；静止: The water was perfectly still. 这水完全静止。
3 (used about a drink) not containing gas （指饮料）不含气体的，无汽的: still mineral water 无汽矿泉水 ☞Look at fizzy and sparkling. 参看fizzy及sparkling。 ☞picture at bubble 见bubble插图 ➔stillness noun [U]
still³
/stɪl ||; stɪl/noun [C] a single photograph that is taken from a film or video 剧照；定格画面

stillborn
/ˈstɪlbɔ:n ||; ˈstɪlˌbɔrn/adj (used about a baby) dead when it is born （指婴儿）死产的

ˌstill ˈlife
noun [C,U] (plural still lifes) the art of painting or drawing arrangements of objects such as flowers, fruit, etc; a painting, etc like this 静物画技法；静物画: She prefers still life to landscape painting. 她喜欢静物画胜过风景画。 a still life in oils 一幅静物油画

stilt
/stɪlt ||; stɪlt/noun[C]
1 one of two long pieces of wood, with places to rest your feet on, on which you can walk above the ground 高跷: Have you tried walking on stilts ? 你踩过高跷吗？
2 one of a set of poles that support a building above the ground or water （建筑物于地面或水面上的）支柱，桩子

stilted
/ˈstɪltɪd ||; ˈstɪltɪd/adj (used about a way of speaking or writing) not natural or relaxed; too formal （指说话或写作方式）不自然的，生硬的，矫揉造作的

stimulant
/ˈstɪmjələnt ||; ˈstɪmjələnt/noun [C] a drug or medicine that makes you feel more active 兴奋剂

stimulate
/ˈstɪmjuleɪt ||; ˈstɪmjəˌlet/verb[T]
1 to make sth active or more active 刺激: Exercise stimulates the blood circulation. 运动刺激血液循环。 The government has decided to cut taxes in order to stimulate the economy. 政府决定减税以刺激经济。
2 to make sb feel interested and excited about sth 引起兴趣或兴致: The lessons don't really stimulate him. 这些课文未能真正激发他的兴趣。 ➔stimulation /ˌstɪmjuˈleɪʃn ||; ˌstɪmjəˈleʃən/ noun [U]

stimulating
/ˈstɪmjuleɪtɪŋ ||; ˈstɪmjəˌletɪŋ/adj interesting and exciting 激发兴趣的；令人兴奋的: a stimulating discussion 激发兴趣的讨论

stimulus
/ˈstɪmjələs ||; ˈstɪmjələs/noun [C,U] (plural stimuli /-laɪ ||; -laɪ/) something that causes activity, development or interest 刺激物；刺激因素: Books provide children with ideas and a stimulus for play. 书籍赋予孩子们思想，对玩耍起刺激作用。

*sting¹
/stɪŋ ||; stɪŋ/verb [I,T] (past tense past participle stung /stʌŋ ||; stʌŋ/)
1 (used about an insect, a plant, etc) to make a person or an animal feel a sudden pain by pushing sth sharp into his/her skin and sending poison into him/her （指昆虫、植物等）刺，螫 · Ow! I've been stung by a bee! 哎哟！我被蜜蜂螫了！ Be careful. Those plants sting. 小心，那些植物有刺。
2 to make sb/sth feel a sudden, sharp pain 使刺痛: Soap stings if it gets in your eyes. 肥皂入眼会很刺痛。
3 to make sb feel very hurt and upset because of sth you say （指言语）伤害感情，冒犯或触怒别人
*sting²
/stɪŋ ||; stɪŋ/noun[C]
1 the sharp pointed part of some insects and animals that is used for pushing into the skin of a person or an animal and putting in poison （某些昆虫、动物的）刺，螫针 ☞pictures at insect and scorpion 见insect及scorpion插图
2 the pain that you feel when an animal or insect pushes its sting into you （螫伤造成的）刺痛: I got a wasp sting on the leg. 我腿上给黄蜂螫伤，怪痛的。
3 a sharp pain that feels like a sting 刺痛

stink
/stɪŋk ||; stɪŋk/verb [I] (past tense stank /stæŋk ||; stæŋk/or stunk /stʌŋk ||; stʌŋk/ past participle stunk) (informal 非正式)stink (of sth)
1 to have a very strong and unpleasant smell 发出恶臭: It stinks in here -- open a window! 这儿臭得很，打开一扇窗子吧！ to stink of fish 有鱼的腥臭味
2 to seem to be very bad, unpleasant or dishonest 显得糟透、讨厌或不正当: The whole business stinks of corruption. 整件事带有贪污腐败的臭味。 stink noun [C]

stinker
/ˈstɪŋkə(r) ||; ˈstɪŋkɚ/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person, particularly a child, or thing that is very unpleasant or difficult 讨厌的人﹙尤指小孩﹚；棘手的事: It's been a real stinker of a day 这一天真让人受不了。 That movie was a stinker. 那部影片糟糕透了。

stinky
/ˈstɪŋki ||; ˈstɪŋkɪ/adj (stinkier; stinkiest) (informal 非正式) having a strong or bad smell 臭的；发恶臭的

stint
/stɪnt ||; stɪnt/noun [C] a fixed period of time that you spend doing sth 一段固定时间的工作；任期: He did a brief stint in the army after leaving school. 他离开学校后在军队里待过，但时间不长。

stipulate
/ˈstɪpjuleɪt ||; ˈstɪpjəˌlet/verb [T] (formal 正式) to say exactly and officially what must be done 明确规定: The law stipulates that all schools must be inspected every three years. 法律规定所有学校每三年都要接受一次检查。 ➔stipulation /ˌstɪpjuˈleɪʃn ||; ˌstɪpjəˈleʃən/ noun [C,U]

*stir¹
/stɜ:(r) ||; stɝ/verb (stirring;stirred)
1 [T] to move a liquid, etc round and round, using a spoon, etc 搅拌，搅动（液体）: She stirred her coffee with a teaspoon. 她用茶匙搅动咖啡。
2 [I,T] to move or make sb/sth move slightly （使）微微移动: She heard the baby stir in the next room. 她听见婴儿在隔壁房间翻动身体。
3 [T] to make sb feel a strong emotion 使情绪激动；激发 · The story stirred Carol's imagination. 那个故事激发了卡罗尔的遐思。 a stirring speech 激动人心的演讲
stir sth up to cause problems, or to make people feel strong emotions 惹事生非；使情绪激动: He's always trying to stir up trouble. 他老是试图惹事生非。 The article stirred up a lot of anger among local residents. 这篇文章引起当地居民极大的愤慨。
stir²
/stɜ:(r) ||; stɝ/noun
1 [C] the action of stirring 搅动；搅拌: Give the soup a stir. 把汤搅一搅。
2 [sing] something exciting or shocking that everyone talks about 轰动；惊诧

ˈstir-crazy
adj (informal 非正式) showing signs of mental illness because of being kept in prison ﹙因遭囚禁而﹚精神失常的

stirrup
/ˈstɪrəp ||; ˈstɪrəp/noun [C] one of the two metal objects that you put your feet in when you are riding a horse 马镫 ☞picture at horse 见horse插图

*stitch¹
/stɪtʃ ||; stɪtʃ/noun[C]
1 one of the small lines of thread that you can see on a piece of material after it has been sewn （缝衣物的）一针，针脚 ☞picture at knit 见knit插图
2 one of the small pieces of thread that a doctor uses to sew your skin together if you cut yourself very badly, or after an operation （缝合伤口的）缝线: How many stitches did you have in your leg? 你的腿上缝了几针？
3 one of the small circles of wool that you put round a needle when you are knitting （编织的）一针
4 [usu.sing] a sudden pain that you get in the side of your body when you are running 腹胁刺痛（奔跑后可能出现）
in stitches(informal 非正式) laughing so much that you cannot stop 忍不住大笑；捧腹大笑
stitch²
/stɪtʃ ||; stɪtʃ/verb [I,T] to sew 缝

*stock¹
/stɒk ||; stɑk/noun
1 [U] [C] the supply of things that a shop, etc has for sale （商店的）存货，库存: We'll have to order extra stock if we sell a lot more this week. 这星期卖出更多的话，我们就必须再订货。 I'm afraid that book's out of stock at the moment. Shall I order it for you? 这本书目前恐怕缺货。我要不要为你订一本？ I'll see if we have your size in stock. 我来看看你的尺寸我们有没有货。
2 [C] an amount of sth that has been kept ready to be used 备用物；储备: Food stocks in the village were very low. 村内缺乏粮食储备。
3 [C,U] a share that sb has bought in a company, or the value of a company's shares 股份；股: to invest in stocks and shares 投资于证券
4 [C,U] a liquid that made by boiling meat, bones, vegetables, etc in water, used especially for making soups and sauces （用肉、骨头、蔬菜等炖成的）汤料，高汤（尤用以做汤和调味汁）
take stock (of sth) to think about sth very carefully before deciding what to do next 三思而后行；总结；评估
stock²
/stɒk ||; stɑk/verb[T]
1 (usually used about a shop) to have a supply of sth （通常指商店）贮存货品: They stock food from all over the world. 他们供应从世界各国进口来的食物。
2 to fill a place with sth 储备；供应: a well-stocked library 藏书丰富的图书馆
stock up (on/with sth) to collect a large supply of sth for future use 储备: to stock up with food for the winter 储备粮食过冬
stock³
/stɒk ||; stɑk/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used for describing sth that sb says) used so often that it does not have much meaning （用于形容说话）陈腐的，老套的: He always gives the same stock answers. 他总是作出老一套的答复。

stockbroker
/ˈstɒkbrəʊkə(r) ||; ˈstɑkˌbrokɚ/ (also broker) noun [C] a person whose job it is to buy and sell shares in companies for other people 证券经纪人；股票经纪人

ˈstock car
noun [C] an ordinary car that has been made stronger for use in stock-car racing ﹙经加固用以参加普通汽车赛的﹚普通汽车

ˈstock-car racing
noun [U] a type of race in which the competing cars are allowed to hit and crash into each other 普通汽车赛﹙参赛车可以相互碰撞﹚

ˈstock exchange
noun [C]
1 a place where shares in companies are bought and sold 证券交易所；股票交易所: the Tokyo Stock Exchange 东京证券交易所
2 (also stock market) the business or activity of buying and selling shares in companies 证券市场；证券交易 ☞Look at exchange. 参看exchange。

stockholder
/ˈstɒkhəʊldə(r) ||; ˈstɑkˌholdɚ/noun [C] a person who owns stocks¹(3) in a business 股票持有人；股东

stocking
/ˈstɒkɪŋ ||; ˈstɑkɪŋ/noun [C] one of a pair of thin pieces of clothing that fit tightly over a woman's feet and legs （女用）长袜: a pair of stockings 一双长袜 ☞Look at tights. 参看tights。 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图

stockist
/ˈstɒkɪst ||; ˈstɑkɪst/noun [C] a shop that sells goods made by a particular company 专售某种或某公司货物的商店

stockman
/ˈstɒkmən ||; ˈstɑkmən/noun [C] (plural stockmen /-mən ||; -mən/)
1 a man whose job is to take care of farm animals 畜牧工；饲养员
2 (US 美) a man who owns farm animals 牧场主
3 (US 美) a man who is in charge of the goods in a warehouse, etc 仓库管理员

stockpile
/ˈstɒkpaɪl ||; ˈstɑkˌpaɪl/noun [C] a large supply of sth that is kept to be used in the future if necessary （大量的）贮存物资 stockpile verb [T] to stockpile food/fuel 贮存食物╱燃料

stockroom
/ˈstɒkru:m ||; ˈstɑkˌrum/noun [C] a room for storing things in a shop/store, an office, etc ﹙商店、办公室等的﹚仓库，贮藏室

stocktaking
/ˈstɒkteɪkɪŋ ||; ˈstɑkˌtekɪŋ/noun [U] the activity of counting the total supply of things that a shop or business has at a particular time 盘点（存货）: They close for an hour a month to do the stocktaking. 他们每月关门一个小时盘点存货。

stocky
/ˈstɒki ||; ˈstɑkɪ/adj (used about a person's body) short but strong and heavy （指身材）短小精悍的，粗壮的

stockyard
/ˈstɒkjɑ:d ||; ˈstɑkˌjɑrd/noun [C] a place where farm animals are kept for a short time before they are sold at a market 牲畜栏，牲畜围场﹙用以暂时安置待出售的牲畜﹚

stodgy
/ˈstɒdʒi ||; ˈstɑdʒɪ/adj (stodgier; stodgiest) (informal 非正式)
1 serious and boring; not exciting 古板的；枯燥无味的: The article was very stodgy — too many facts. 这篇文章枯燥无味——里面资料太多了。
2 (Brit 英) (used about food) heavy and making you feel very full ﹙食物﹚吃下去感觉撑的，易饱的

stoic
/ˈstəʊɪk ||; ˈsto·ɪk/ (also stoical /-kl ||; -kḷ/) adj (formal 正式) suffering pain or difficulty without complaining 坚忍而不抱怨的 ➔stoically /-kli ||; -kḷɪ/ adv ➔stoicism /ˈstəʊɪsɪzəm ||; ˈsto·ɪˌsɪzəm/ noun [U]

stoke
/stəʊk ||; stok/verb[T]
1 stoke sth (up) (with sth) to add fuel to a fire, etc （为炉火等）添加燃料: to stoke up a fire with more coal 为炉火添煤 to stoke a furnace 为炉子添燃料
2 stoke sth (up) to make people feel sth more strongly 煽起，激起（某种情绪）: to stoke up anger/envy 激起愤怒╱妒火 The publicity was intended to stoke up interest in her music. 这宣传旨在激起人们对她的音乐的兴趣。
stoke up (on/with sth)(informal 非正式) to eat or drink a lot of sth, especially so that you do not feel hungry later 大吃或大喝一顿（尤指为了可以许久不饿）: Stoke up for the day on a good breakfast. 早饭大吃一顿，以便一天不饿。

stole
past tense ofSTEAL

stolen
past participle ofSTEAL

stolid
/ˈstɒlɪd ||; ˈstɑlɪd/adj (used about a person) showing very little emotion or excitement （指人）无动于衷的，冷淡的，冷漠的 ➔stolidly adv

stoma
/ˈstəʊmə ||; ˈstomə/noun [C] (plural stomas or stomata /ˈstəʊmətə ||; ˈstomətə/) (technical术语)
1 any of the very small holes in the surface of a leaf or the STEM (= the main long thin part) of a plant that allow gases to pass in and out （植物的）气孔
2 a small opening like a mouth in some simple creatures （某些低级动物的）嘴状小孔
3 (in medicine) a hole that is made from the surface of the body to one of the tubes inside the body （医学）（手术过程中在人体切开的）人造口

*stomach¹
/ˈstʌmək ||; ˈstʌmək/ (informal 非正式tummy) noun [C]
1 the organ in your body where food goes after you have eaten it 胃: He went to the doctor with stomach pains. 他因胃痛去看了医生。 ☞picture at body 见body插图
2 the front part of your body below your chest and above your legs 肚子；腹部: She turned over onto her stomach. 她翻身俯卧。 ☞picture at body 见body插图
stomach²
/ˈstʌmək ||; ˈstʌmək/verb [T] (informal 非正式) (usually in negative sentences and questions 通常用于否定句及疑问句) to be able to watch, listen to, accept, etc sth that you think is unpleasant 忍受；容忍: I can't stomach too much violence in films. 我看不惯电影过分渲染暴力。

ˈstomach-ache
noun [C,U] a pain in your stomach 胃痛；肚子痛: I've got terrible stomach-ache. 我的胃痛得厉害。 ☞Look at the note at ache. 参看ache的注释。

stomp
/stɒmp ||; stɑmp/verb [I] (informal 非正式) to walk with heavy steps 以重步走

*stone
/stəʊn ||; ston/noun
1 [U] a hard solid substance that is found in the ground 石头: The house was built of grey stone. 那幢房子用灰石建成。 a stone wall 石墙 ☞Look at cornerstone and foundation stone. 参看cornerstone及foundation stone。
2 [C] a small piece of rock 石子；石块: The boy picked up a stone and threw it into the river. 那个男孩捡起一块石头丢进河里。
3 [C] =PRECIOUS STONE
4 [C] the hard seed inside some fruits, for example PEACHES, PLUMS, CHERRIES and OLIVES （桃、李子、樱桃、橄榄等水果内的）核，种子
5 [C] (plural stone) a measure of weight; 6.35 kilograms. There are 14 pounds in a stone. 英石（重量单位，等于6.35公斤或14磅）: I weigh eleven stone two(= 2 pounds). 我的体重是十一英石二磅。

ˌstone-ˈcold
adj completely cold, when it should be warm or hot 冰凉的；凉了的: The soup was stone cold. 汤全凉了。

stoned
/stəʊnd ||; stond/adj (slang 俚语) not behaving or thinking normally because of drugs or alcohol （服用毒品后）神志恍惚的；喝醉的

stonemason
/ˈstəʊnmeɪsn ||; ˈstonˌmesṇ/noun [C] a person whose job is cutting and preparing stone for buildings 石匠；石工

stonewashed
/ˈstəʊnwɒʃt ||; ˈstonˌwɑʃt/adj (used about jeans, etc) washed in a special way so that the cloth loses some colour and looks older ﹙牛仔裤等﹚石磨水洗的

stonework
/ˈstəʊnwɜ:k ||; ˈstonˌwɝk/noun [U] the parts of a building that are made of stone （建筑物的）石造部份

stony
/ˈstəʊni ||; ˈstonɪ/adj
1 (used about the ground) having a lot of stones in it, or covered with stones （指地面）多石的，铺石的
2 not friendly 不友善的；冷漠的: There was a stony silence as he walked into the room. 他走进房间时，四周顿时寂然无声。

stood
past tense, past participle ofSTAND¹

*stool
/stu:l ||; stul/noun [C] a seat that does not have a back or arms 凳子: a piano stool 钢琴凳

ˈstool pigeon
noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person, especially a criminal, who helps the police to catch another criminal, for example by spending time with him/her and getting secret information ﹙向警察提供情报的﹚线人，内线 [SYN]informer 同义词为informer

stoop
/stu:p ||; stup/verb [I] to bend your head and shoulders forwards and downwards 弯腰；曲背: He had to stoop to get through the low doorway. 他要弯腰才能通过那个低矮的门口。 stoop noun [sing] to walk with a stoop 弯腰行走 stoop to sth/doing sth to do sth bad or wrong that you would normally not do 堕落而做坏事

*stop¹
/stɒp ||; stɑp/verb (stopping;stopped)
1 [I,T] to finish moving or make sth finish moving （使）停，停止: He walked along the road for a bit, and then stopped. 他沿着那条路走了一段，然后停下来。 Does this train stop at Didcot? 这班列车停不停迪德科特？ My watch has stopped. 我的表停了。 I stopped someone in the street to ask the way to the station. 我在街上截住路人问去车站的路。
2 [I,T] to no longer continue or make sth not continue （使）终止；（使）不再继续: I think the rain has stopped. 我想雨已经停了。 It's stopped raining now. 现在雨停了。 Stop making that terrible noise! 别再发出那种讨厌的声音！ The bus service stops at midnight. 午夜过后，公共汽车便停止服务。 We tied a bandage round his arm to stop the bleeding. 我们将绷带缠在他的手臂上止血。
If you stop doing something you do not do it any more Stop talking and listen to me!If you stop to do something, you stop in order to do it On the way home I stopped to buy a newspaper. stop doing something表示不再做某事：Stop talking and listen to me!别再说话，听我说！stop to do something表示停下来做某事：On the way home I stopped to buy a newspaper.回家途中我停下来买报纸。
3 [T] stop sb/sth (from) doing sth to make sb/sth end or finish an activity; prevent sb/sth from doing sth 制止；阻止: They've built a fence to stop the dog getting out. 他们筑起栅栏，不让狗出去。 I'm going to go and you can't stop me. 我要走了，你拦不住我。
4 [I,T] stop (for sth);stop (and do/to do sth) to end an activity for a short time in order to do sth 暂停，中断（活动）: Shall we stop for lunch now? 我们现在停下来吃午饭好吗？ Let's stop and look at the map. 我们停下来看看地图吧。 We stopped work for half an hour to have a cup of coffee. 我们停工半小时喝杯咖啡。
stop at nothing to do anything to get what you want, even if it is wrong or dangerous 不顾一切；不择手段 stop short of sth/doing sth to almost do sth, but then decide not to do it at the last minute 在做某事前最后一分钟住手；险些做某事 stop off (at/in...) to stop during a journey to do sth 旅途中停下来 stop over (at/in...) to stay somewhere for a short time during a long journey （长途旅行中在某地）作短期停留
*stop²
/stɒp ||; stɑp/noun[C]
1 an act of stopping or state of being stopped 停；停止: Our first stop will be in Edinburgh. 我们第一站是爱丁堡。 Production at the factory will come to a stop at midnight tonight. 工厂生产将于今晚午夜停下来。 I managed to bring the car to a stopjust in time. 我及时剎住了车。
2 the place where a bus, train, etc stops so that people can get on and off 车站: a bus stop 公共汽车站 I'm getting off at the next stop. 我下一站就要下车。
pull out all the stops→PULL¹ put a stop to sth to prevent sth bad or unpleasant from continuing 停止，制止（某事物）

stopgap
/ˈstɒpgæp ||; ˈstɑpˌgæp/noun [C] a person or a thing that does a job for a short time until sb/sth permanent can be found 临时代替的人或物

stopover
/ˈstɒpəʊvə(r) ||; ˈstɑpˌovɚ/noun [C] a short stop in a journey 中途短暂停留

stoppage
/ˈstɒpɪdʒ ||; ˈstɑpɪdʒ/noun[C]
1 a situation in which people stop working as part of a protest 罢工
2 (in sport) an interruption in a game for a particular reason （体育活动中）赛事中断

stopper
/ˈstɒpə(r) ||; ˈstɑpɚ/noun [C] an object that you put into the top of a bottle in order to close it 塞子 ☞picture at Thermos 见Thermos插图

stopwatch
/ˈstɒpwɒtʃ ||; ˈstɑpˌwɑtʃ/noun [C] a watch which can be started and stopped by pressing a button, so that you can measure exactly how long sth takes 秒表

storage
/ˈstɔ:rɪdʒ ||; ˈstɔrɪdʒ/noun [U] the keeping of things until they are needed; the place where they are kept 贮藏；贮藏地；仓库: This room is being used for storage at the moment. 这个房间现在用来贮藏东西。 ☞Look at cold storage. 参看cold storage。

*store¹
/stɔ:(r) ||; stɔr/noun[C]
1 a large shop 大型商店: She's a sales assistant in a large department store. 她是一家大型百货商店的销售助理。 a furniture store 家具店 ☞Look at chain store. 参看chain store。
2 (US 美) =SHOP¹
3 a supply of sth that you keep for future use; the place where it is kept 储备；贮藏室: a good store of food for the winter 储藏大量过冬的食物 Police discovered a weapons store in the house. 警方发现这幢房子里藏着武器。
in store (for sb/sth) going to happen in the future 将会发生: There's a surprise in store for you when you get home! 你回到家里将会有令你惊喜的事！ set... store by sth to consider sth to be important 重视（某事物）: Nick sets great store by his mother's opinion. 尼克很重视他妈妈的意见。
*store²
/stɔ:(r) ||; stɔr/verb [T] to keep sth or a supply of sth for future use 储备；贮藏: to store information on a computer 把资料贮存在计算机里

storehouse
/ˈstɔ:haʊs ||; ˈstɔrˌhaus/noun[C]
1 a building where things are stored 仓库；货栈 [SYN]warehouse 同义词为 warehouse
2 (used about information, knowledge, etc) a place or thing that has or contains a lot of information ﹙信息或知识的﹚宝库: This book is a storehouse of useful information. 这本书堪称实用知识宝库。

storekeeper
/ˈstɔ:ki:pə(r) ||; ˈstɔrˌkipɚ/ (US 美) =SHOPKEEPER

storeroom
/ˈstɔ:ru:m;-rʊm ||; ˈstɔrˌrum; -rυm/noun [C] a room where things are kept until they are needed 储藏室

storey
/ˈstɔ:ri ||; ˈstɔrɪ/ (US 美 story) noun [C] (plural storeys (US 美) stories) one floor or level of a building （建筑物的）一层: The building will be five storeys high. 这幢大楼将有五层楼高。 a two-storey house 两层高的房子 a multi-storey car park 多层停车场

stork
/stɔ:k ||; stɔrk/noun [C] a large white bird with a long beak, neck and legs. Storks often make their homes (nests) on the top of buildings. 鹳

*storm¹
/stɔ:m ||; stɔrm/noun [C] very bad weather, with a lot of rain, strong winds, etc 暴风雨: Look at those black clouds. I think there's going to be a storm. 看那些乌云，我看将会有大风雨。 a hailstorm/snowstorm/sandstorm/thunderstorm 雹暴；暴风雪；沙尘暴；雷暴 ☞ Storm is the general word for very bad weather. A very strong wind is a gale. A storm with very strong winds is a hurricane. A storm with a very strong circular wind is called a cyclone, tornado, typhoon or whirlwind. A very bad snowstorm is a blizzard. storm泛指恶劣天气。强风叫gale。飓风叫hurricane。旋转式的狂风又分为cyclone（气旋）、tornado（龙卷风）、typhoon（台风）和whirlwind（旋风）。严重的暴风雪叫做blizzard。
storm²
/stɔ:m ||; stɔrm/verb
1 [I] to enter or leave somewhere in a very angry and noisy way 怒气冲冲地闯入或离开: He threw down the book and stormed out of the room. 他扔下书，怒气冲冲地离开了房间。
2 [T] to attack a building, town, etc suddenly and violently in order to take control of it 突袭；攻占

ˈstorm door
noun [C] an extra door that is fitted to the outside door of a house, etc to give protection from bad weather ﹙用来防风、挡雨等的﹚外重门

ˈstorm window
noun [C] an extra window that is fitted to a window of a house to give protection from bad weather ﹙用来防风、挡雨等的﹚外重窗

stormy
/ˈstɔ:mi ||; ˈstɔrmɪ/adj
1 used for talking about very bad weather, with strong winds, heavy rain, etc 天气恶劣的；狂风暴雨的: a stormy night 风雨交加的夜晚 stormy weather 多风暴的天气
2 involving a lot of angry argument and strong feeling 多风波的；激烈的: a stormy relationship 吵吵闹闹的关系

*story
/ˈstɔ:ri ||; ˈstɔrɪ/noun [C] (plural stories)
1 a story (about sb/sth) a description of people and events that are not real （虚构的）故事: I'll tell you a storyabout the animals that live in that forest. 我给你讲一个关于生活在那座森林里的动物的故事。 I always read the children a bedtime story. 我总是在孩子睡觉之前给他们讲故事。 a detective/fairy/ghost/love story 侦探╱童话╱鬼怪╱爱情故事
2 an account, especially a spoken one, of sth that has happened 叙述，描述（尤指口头的）: The police didn't believe his story. 警方不相信他的说法。
3 a description of true events that happened in the past （真实的）故事；事迹: He's writing his life story. 他在写自己的生平。
4 an article or report in a newspaper or magazine （报章或杂志上的）文章，报道: The plane crash was the front-page story in most newspapers. 这起坠机事件成为大多数报纸的头版新闻。
5 (US 美) =STOREY

storybook
/ˈstɔ:ribʊk ||; ˈstɔrɪˌbuk/noun [C] (used in compounds 用于构成复合词) a book of stories for children 儿童故事书；童话书: a picture in a storybook 故事书中的插图 storybook adventures(= like the ones in stories for children) 像童话书中的历险 storybook wedding/romance 童话式的婚礼/恋爱

storyteller
/ˈstɔ:ritelə(r) ||; ˈstɔrɪˌtɛlɚ/noun [C] a person who tells or writes stories 讲故事的人；故事作者 ➔storytelling noun [U]: She has a gift for storytelling. 她有讲故事的天分。 storytelling sessions 故事会

stout
/staʊt ||; staυt/adj
1 (used about a person) rather fat （指身材）相当胖的
2 strong and thick 结实的；粗壮的: stout walking boots 结实耐穿的步行靴

stove
/stəʊv ||; stov/noun[C]
1 the top part of a cooker that has gas or electric rings （烹饪用的）炉子: He put a pan of water to boil on the stove. 他将一锅水放在炉子上烧。
2 a closed metal box in which you burn wood, coal, etc for heating （取暖用的）炉子，火炉: a wood-burning stove 烧柴的炉子

stow
/stəʊ ||; sto/verb [T] stow sth (away) to put sth away in a particular place until it is needed 收藏好；放好

stowaway
/ˈstəʊəweɪ ||; ˈstoəˌwe/noun [C] a person who hides in a ship or plane so that he/she can travel without paying 偷乘船或飞机者（不付费）

straddle
/ˈstrædl ||; ˈstrædḷ/verb[T]
1 (used about a person) to sit or stand with your legs on each side of sb/sth （指人）骑，跨坐，跨立: to straddle a chair 跨坐在椅子上
2 (used about a building, bridge, etc) to cross, or exist on both sides of, a river, a road or an area of land （指建筑物、桥梁等）跨越，横跨，跨立于

straggle
/ˈstrægl ||; ˈstrægḷ/verb[I]
1 to walk, etc more slowly than the rest of the group 落伍；掉队: The children straggled along behind their parents. 孩子们落在父母后面。
2 to grow, spread or move in an untidy way or in different directions 零乱地生长、散布或移动: Her wet hair straggled across her forehead. 她的湿头发零乱地挂在前额。 ➔straggler noun [C] ➔straggly adj long straggly hair 蓬乱的长发

*straight¹
/streɪt ||; stret/adj
1 with no bends or curves; going in one direction only 直的；成直线的: a straight line 直线 He's got dark, straight hair. 他长着一头乌黑的直发。 Keep your back straight! 把背挺直！ He was so tired he couldn't walk in a straight line. 他累极了，走起路来东倒西歪的。 ☞pictures at hair and line 见hair及line插图
2 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) in an exactly horizontal or vertical position 不歪斜的；竖直的: That picture isn't straight. 那幅画挂得不正。
3 honest and direct 老实的；直接的；坦率的: Politicians never give a straight answer. 政客从来不直接回答问题。 Are you being straight with me? 你对我说的是老实话吗？
4 tidy or organized as it should be 整洁的；有条理的: It took ages to put the room straightafter we'd decorated it. 装修以后，我们花了好长时间才把房间弄整齐。
5 (informal 非正式) attracted to people of the opposite sex 非同性恋的 [SYN] heterosexual 同义词为heterosexual [OPP] gay 反义词为gay
6 (informal 非正式) used to describe a person who you think is too serious and boring （指人）过分严肃或乏味的
get sth straight to make sure that you understand sth completely 弄清楚（某事物） keep a straight face to stop yourself from smiling or laughing 忍住笑；板着脸孔 put/set the record straight→RECORD¹
*straight²
/streɪt ||; stret/adv
1 not in a curve or at an angle; in a straight line 笔直；成直线: Go straight on for about two miles until you come to some traffic lights. 一直往前走约两英里，直到有红绿灯的地方。 He was looking straight ahead. 他在往正前方看。 to sit up straight (= with a straight back) 坐得笔直
2 without stopping; directly 径直；直接: I took the children straight home after school. 放学后，我直接带孩子们回家。 to walk straight past sb/sth 从某人或某物旁边走过 I'm going straight to bed when I get home. 我打算一到家就上床睡觉。 He joined the army straight from school. 他一离开学校就从军去了。
3 in an honest and direct way 老实；直接；直率: Tell me straight, doctor -- is it serious? 跟我说实话，医生─这病是不是很严重？
go straight to become honest after being a criminal 改邪归正 right/straight away→AWAY straight out in an honest and direct way 老实；坦率: I told Asif straight out that I didn't want to see him any more. 我直截了当告诉阿西夫我不想再见他。

straighten
/ˈstreɪtn ||; ˈstretṇ/verb [I,T] straighten (sth) (up/out) to become straight or to make sth straight （使）直，平正: The road straightens out at the bottom of the hill. 那条路到了山脚就变直。 [T] to straighten your tie 将领带弄正 straighten sth out to remove the confusion or difficulties from a situation 整顿；解决问题或困难 straighten up to make your body straight and vertical 挺直身子

straightforward
/ˌstreɪtˈfɔ:wəd ||; ˌstretˈfɔrwɚd/adj
1 easy to do or understand; simple 简明易懂的；简单直接的: straightforward instructions 简明易懂的指令
2 honest and open 坦诚的，率直的: a straightforward person 坦诚的人

strain¹
/streɪn ||; stren/noun
1 [U] pressure that is put on sth when it is pulled or pushed by a physical force 拉力；推力；张力: Running downhill puts strain on the knees. 跑下山坡时膝部会绷得很紧。 The rope finally broke under the strain. 那条绳子绷紧之下终于断了。
2 [C,U] worry or pressure caused by having too much to deal with 担忧；紧张: to be under a lot of strainat work 工作压力很大
3 [C] something that makes you feel worried and tense 令人担忧和紧张的事物: I always find exams a terrible strain. 考试总是令我焦虑不安。
4 [C,U] an injury to part of your body that is caused by using it too much 劳损
5 [C] one type of animal, plant or disease that is slightly different from the other types （动植物的）系，品系；（疾病的）类型
strain²
/streɪn ||; stren/verb
1 [I,T] to make a great mental or physical effort to do sth 竭力；使劲: I was straining to see what was happening. 我竭力想看清出了什么事。 She strained her ears (= listened very hard) to catch what they were saying. 她竖起耳朵拚命想听清楚他们在说些什么。 Bend down as far as you can without straining. 在不费劲的情况下尽量弯下腰去。
2 [T] to injure a part of your body by using it too much 拉伤；扭伤；劳损: Don't read in the dark. You'll strain your eyes. 别在暗处看书，会损害眼睛的。 I think I've strained a muscle in my neck. 我想我将脖子的肌肉扭伤了。
3 [T] to put a lot of pressure on sth 造成巨大压力: Money problems have strained their relationship. 金钱问题使他们的关系紧张。
4 [T] to separate a solid and a liquid by pouring them into a special container with small holes in it 过滤: to strain tea/vegetables/spaghetti 过滤茶╱蔬菜╱意大利面条

strained
/streɪnd ||; strend/adj
1 not natural or friendly 紧张的；不自然的；不友好的: Relations between the two countries are strained. 两国的关系紧张起来。
2 worried because of having too much to deal with （因问题太多而）担忧的，紧张的: Martin looked tired and strained. 马丁看来又疲倦又紧张。

strait
/streɪt ||; stret/noun
1 [C] [usu.pl] a narrow piece of sea that joins two larger seas 海峡: the straits of Gibraltar 直布罗陀海峡
2 straits [pl] a very difficult situation, especially one caused by having no money 困境，窘迫（尤指因没有钱引起的）: The company is in financial straits. 公司处于财务困境。
be in dire straits→DIRE

straitjacket
/ˈstreɪtdʒækɪt ||; ˈstretˌdʒækɪt/ (also straightjacket) noun [C] a piece of clothing like a jacket with long arms which is put on people who are considered dangerous to prevent them from behaving violently （束缚危险人物双臂用的）约束衣，紧身衣

strait-laced
/ˌstreɪt ˈleɪst ||; ˈstret ˈlest/adj having very strict or old-fashioned ideas about people's moral behaviour 拘谨保守的；古板的

strand
/strænd ||; strænd/noun[C]
1 a single piece of cotton, wool, hair, etc 一缕，一根（棉线、毛线、头发等）
2 one part of a story, situation or idea （故事、情况或想法的）一部份，一面

stranded
/ˈstrændɪd ||; ˈstrændɪd/adj left in a place that you cannot get away from 滞留的: We were left stranded when our car broke down in the mountains. 汽车在山里抛锚，我们无处求援。

*strange
/streɪndʒ ||; strendʒ/adj
1 unusual or unexpected 奇怪的；古怪的；出乎意料的: A very strange thing happened to me on the way home. 我回家途中发生了一件非常奇怪的事。 a strange noise 古怪的声音
2 that you have not seen, visited, met, etc before 前所未见的；陌生的: a strange town 陌生的城镇 My mother told me not to talk to strange men. 妈妈叫我不要和陌生男子交谈。 ☞We do not use strange to talk about a person or thing that comes from a different country. Look at foreign. 指来自不同国家的人或事不用strange。参看foreign。 ➔strangely adv The streets were strangely quiet. 街道出奇地静。 Tim's behaving very strangely at the moment. 蒂姆的行为现在十分古怪。 ➔strangeness noun [U]

*stranger
/ˈstreɪndʒə(r) ||; ˈstrendʒɚ/noun[C]
1 a person that you do not know 陌生人: I had to ask a complete stranger to help me with my suitcase. 我不得不请一个我完全不认识的人帮我拿手提箱。 ☞We do not use stranger to talk about a person who comes from a different country. Look at foreigner. 指来自不同国家的人不用stranger。参看foreigner。
2 a person who is in a place that he/she does not know 外地人；异乡人: I'm a stranger to this part of the country. 这个地区我不熟。

strangle
/ˈstræŋgl ||; ˈstræŋgḷ/verb[T]
1 to kill sb by squeezing his/her neck or throat with your hands, a rope, etc 勒死；绞死；扼杀 [SYN] throttle 同义词为throttle ☞Look at choke 参看choke。
2 to prevent sth from developing 扼杀；抑制

*strap
/stræp ||; stræp/noun [C] a long narrow piece of leather, cloth, plastic, etc that you use for carrying sth or for keeping sth in position 带子（用以携带或固定物品）: I managed to fasten my watch strap but now I can't undo it. 我当时设法把表带系上了，但现在解不开。 strap verb [T] (strapping;strapped) The racing driver was securely strapped into the car. 那名赛车手系好安全带坐在车子里。 ☞pictures at bag, binoculars and clock 见bag、binoculars及clock插图

strapless
/ˈstræpləs ||; ˈstræpləs/adj (used especially about a dress or bra) without straps ﹙尤指连衣裙或胸罩﹚无肩带的，无吊带的

strata
plural ofSTRATUM

strategic
/strəˈti:dʒɪk ||; strəˈtidʒɪk/ (also strategical /-dʒɪkl ||; -dʒɪkḷ/) adj
1 helping you to achieve a plan; giving you an advantage 有战略意义的；策略上的: They made a strategic decision to sell off part of the company. 他们作出一个策略性决定，把公司的一部份卖掉。
2 connected with a country's plans to achieve success in a war or in its defence system 与战略或国防策略有关的
3 (used about bombs and other weapons) intended to be fired at the enemy's country rather than be used in battle （指炸弹及其他武器）战略性的 ➔strategically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv The island is strategically important. 那个岛是战略要地。

strategist
/ˈstrætədʒɪst ||; ˈstrætədʒɪst/noun [C] a person who is skilled at planning things, especially military activities 战略家；善于筹划部署的人: a military strategist 军事战略家 a brilliant political strategist 杰出的政治策略家

strategy
/ˈstrætədʒi ||; ˈstrætədʒɪ/noun (plural strategies)
1 [C] a plan that you use in order to achieve sth 对策；计划: What's your strategy for this exam? 这次考试你有什么对策？
2 [U] the action of planning how to do or achieve sth 策略；战略: military strategy 军事策略

stratification
/ˌstrætɪfɪˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌstrætəfəˈkeʃən/noun [U] (technical术语) the division of sth into different layers or groups 分层；成层: social stratification 社会分层

stratosphere
/ˈstrætəsfɪə(r) ||; ˈstrætəˌsfɪr/noun [sing] the stratosphere the layer of the earth's atmosphere between about 10 and 50 kilometres above the surface of the earth 平流层，同温层（大气层离地球表面10至50公里的部份） ☞Compare ionosphere and troposphere. 与ionosphere及troposphere比较。 ➔stratospheric /ˌstrætəˈsferɪk ||; ˌstrætəˈsfɛrɪk/ adj stratospheric clouds/ozone 平流层的云╱臭氧

stratum
/ˈstrɑ:təm ||; ˈstretəm/noun [C] (plural strata /-tə ||; -tə/) (technical术语) a layer or set of layers of rock, earth, etc in the ground 地层；岩层

stratus
/ˈstreɪtəs;ˈstrɑ:təs||; ˈstretəs/noun [U] (technical术语) a type of cloud that forms a continuous grey sheet covering the sky 层云 ☞picture at cloud 见cloud插图

*straw
/strɔ: ||; strɔ/noun
1 [U] the long, straight, central parts (stems) of plants, for example wheat, that are dried and then used for animals to sleep on or for making baskets, covering a roof, etc 稻草；禾秆；麦秆: a straw hat 草帽 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图
2 [C] one piece of straw 一根稻草
3 [C] a long plastic or paper tube that you can use for drinking through 吸管 ☞picture at container 见container插图
the last/final straw the last in a series of bad things that happen to you and that makes you decide that you cannot accept the situation any longer 使人终于忍无可忍的事

strawberry
/ˈstrɔ:bəri; US -berɪ ||; ˈstrɔˌbɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural strawberries) a small soft red fruit with small white seeds on it 草莓: strawberries and cream 奶油浇草莓

ˌstrawberry ˈblonde
(also ˌstrawberry ˈblond)adj (used about a person's hair) of a reddish yellow colour ﹙头发﹚金色略带红色的 ➔ˌstrawberry ˈblonde noun [C]

straw poll ( also ˌstraw ˈvote)
noun [C] an occasion when a number of people are asked in an informal way to give their opinion about sth or to say how they are likely to vote in an election ﹙选举前的﹚非正式民意调查

stray¹
/streɪ ||; stre/verb[I]
1 to go away from the place where you should be 走失；迷路: The sheep had strayed onto the road. 那只羊迷途走上了公路。
2 to not keep to the subject you should be thinking about or discussing 离题；走神: My thoughts strayed for a few moments. 我的思绪走了一会儿神。
stray²
/streɪ ||; stre/noun [C] a dog, cat, etc that does not have a home 走失的家畜（如流浪狗、流浪猫等） stray adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) a stray dog 流浪狗

streak¹
/stri:k ||; strik/noun[C]
1 streak (of sth) a thin line or mark 条纹；条痕；斑纹: The cat had brown fur with streaks of white in it. 那只猫一身褐毛，间有白色条纹。
2 a part of a person's character that sometimes shows in the way he/she behaves 性情或性格的某一方面: Vesna's a very caring girl, but she does have a selfish streak. 维斯娜是个很有爱心的姑娘，但也不乏自私的一面。
3 a continuous period of bad or good luck in a game of sport （体育比赛中）一阵子的运气: The team is on a losing / winning streakat the moment. 该队目前连连败北╱节节胜利。
streak²
/stri:k ||; strik/verb [I] (informal 非正式) to run fast 飞跑

streaked
/stri:kt ||; strikt/adj streaked (with sth) having lines of a different colour 带…的条纹: black hair streaked with grey 黑发中夹杂着白发

streaker
/ˈstri:kə(r) ||; ˈstrikɚ/noun [C] a person who runs through a public place with no clothes on as a way of getting attention 裸奔者

*stream¹
/stri:m ||; strim/noun[C]
1 a small river 小河；溪流: I waded across the shallow stream. 我涉水过了那条不深的小河。
2 the continuous movement of a liquid or gas （液体或气体的）不停流动: a stream of blood 一股血
3 a continuous movement of people or things （人或物的）不断移动: a stream of traffic 川流不息的车辆
4 a large number of things which happen one after another 连续出现的事物；接二连三的事物: a stream of letters/telephone calls/questions 连续不断的信件╱电话╱问题
stream²
/stri:m ||; strim/verb[I]
1 (used about a liquid, gas or light) to flow in large amounts （指液体、气体或光）大量地涌、流或射: Tears were streaming down his face. 他泪流满面。 Sunlight was streaming in through the windows. 阳光正从窗口射进来。
2 (used about people or things) to move somewhere in a continuous flow （指人或物）不停流动或涌: People were streaming out of the station. 人潮正从车站涌出。

streamer
/ˈstri:mə(r) ||; ˈstrimɚ/noun [C] a long piece of coloured paper that you use for decorating a room before a party, etc （装饰用的）彩色纸带

streamline
/ˈstri:mlaɪn ||; ˈstrimˌlaɪn/verb[T]
1 to give a vehicle, etc a long smooth shape so that it will move easily through air or water 使（车辆等）成流线型
2 to make an organization, process, etc work better by making it simpler 简化（机构、程序等）以提高效率 ➔streamlined adj

ˌstream of ˈconsciousness
noun [U] a continuous flow of ideas, thoughts and feelings, as they are experienced by a person; a style of writing that expresses this without using the usual methods of description and conversation 意识流；（不使用惯常描绘及对话的）意识流写作风格

*street
/stri:t ||; strit/noun[C]
1 a road in a town, village or city that has shops, houses, etc on one or both sides 街道: to walk along / down the street 在街上走 to cross the street 横越街道 I met Karen in the street this morning. 今天早上我在街上遇见卡伦。 a narrow street 狭长的街道 a street map of Rome 罗马街道图 ☞Look at the note at road. 参看road的注释。
2 Street(abbr St) [sing] used in the names of streets （用于街名）: 64 High Street 高街64号 The post office is in Sheep Street. 邮局在希普街。
the man in the street→MAN¹ streets ahead (of sb/sth)(informal 非正式) much better than sb/sth 远胜过（某人或某物） (right) up your street(informal 非正式) (used about an activity, subject, etc) exactly right for you because you know a lot about it, like it very much, etc （指活动、主题等）正是某人所擅长，正合某人的口味

ˈstreet light
noun [C] a light at the top of a tall post in the street 路灯；街灯

streetwise
/ˈstri:twaɪz ||; ˈstritˌwaɪz/ (US also 美亦作 streetsmart /ˈstri:tsmɑ:t ||; ˈstritˌsmɑrt/)adj (informal 非正式) having the knowledge and experience that is needed to deal with the difficulties and dangers of life in a big city 适应都市生活的；有都市人的精明劲儿的: Kids seem much more streetwise these days. 如今的孩子们比以前精明了。

*strength
/streŋθ ||; strɛŋθ/noun
1 [U] the quality of being physically strong; the amount of this quality that you have 强壮；力量；力气: He pulled with all his strength but the rock would not move. 他用尽力气拉，可是那块岩石丝毫没有移动。 I didn't have the strength to walk any further. 我没有力气再往前走了。
2 [U] the ability of an object to hold heavy weights or not to break or be damaged easily 强度；结实程度: All our suitcases are tested for strength before they leave the factory. 我们的手提箱都经过强度测试才出厂。
3 [U] the power and influence that sb has 实力；影响力: Germany's economic strength 德国的经济实力
4 [U] how strong a feeling or opinion is （情绪或意见的）强烈程度
5 [C,U] a good quality or ability that sb/sth has 优点；长处: His greatest strength is his ability to communicate with people. 他最大的优点是善于与别人沟通。 the strengths and weaknesses of a plan 一个计划的优点和缺点 [OPP] weakness 反义词为weakness
at full strength (used about a group) having all the people it needs or usually has （指一组人）达到足够人数，满员: Nobody is injured, so the team will be at full strength for the game. 无人受伤，因此这个队将全班人马参加比赛。 below strength (used about a group) not having the number of people it needs or usually has （指一组人）人数不足，未满员 on the strength of as a result of information, advice, etc 因为，由于（某种信息、意见等）

strengthen
/ˈstreŋθn ||; ˈstrɛŋθən/verb[I,T] to become stronger or to make sth stronger 加强；强化 [T] exercises to strengthen your muscles 锻炼肌肉的运动 [OPP] weaken 反义词为weaken

strenuous
/ˈstrenjuəs ||; ˈstrɛnjυəs/adj needing or using a lot of effort or energy 艰苦的；费力的: Don't do strenuous exercise after eating. 饭后不要做激烈运动。 She's making a strenuous effort to be on time every day. 她坚持做到每天都准时。 ➔strenuously adv

*stress¹
/stres ||; strɛs/noun
1 [C,U] worry and pressure that is caused by having too much to deal with 精神压力；思想负担: He's been under a lot of stresssince his wife went into hospital. 自从妻子进医院后，他便承受着很大的压力。
Look at trauma. 参看trauma。
2 [U] stress (on sth) the special attention that you give to sth because you think it is important 强调: We should put more stresson preventing crime. 我们应更加重视防止犯罪活动。
3 [C,U] (a) stress (on sth) the force that you put on a particular word or part of a word when you speak 重读；重音: In the word ‘dictionary’ the stress is on the first syllable, ‘dic’. dictionary这个词的重音在第一个音节dic。
4 [C,U] a physical force that may cause sth to bend or break （使物体弯曲或折断的）压力: Heavy lorries put too much stresson this bridge. 重型卡车使这座桥承受太大的压力。
stress²
/stres ||; strɛs/verb [T] to give sth special force or attention because it is important 强调: The minister stressed the need for a peaceful solution. 部长强调和平解决的必要性。 Which syllable is stressed in this word? 这个词哪个音节重读？ [SYN] emphasize 同义词为emphasize

stressful
/ˈstresfl ||; ˈstrɛsfəl/adj causing worry and pressure 使担心的；造成压力的: a stressful job 压力很大的工作

ˈstress mark
noun [C] a mark used to show which part of a particular word or syllable is pronounced with more force than others 重音符号

*stretch¹
/stretʃ ||; strɛtʃ/verb
1 [I,T] to pull sth so that it becomes longer or wider; to become longer or wider in this way 拉长；伸展；拉紧 · The artist stretched the canvas tightly over the frame. 画家将画布绷紧，固定在画框上。 My T-shirt stretched when I washed it. 我的T恤衫洗过后变宽了。 ☞picture at shrink 见shrink插图
2 [I,T] stretch (sth) (out) to push out your arms, legs, etc as far as possible 伸展，舒展（臂、腿等）: He switched off the alarm clock, yawned and stretched. 他关掉闹钟，打个呵欠，伸了个懒腰。 She stretched out on the sofa and fell asleep. 她舒展身子躺在沙发上睡着了。 She stretched out her arm to take the book. 她伸手去拿书。 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图
3 [I] to cover a large area of land or a long period of time 伸展，延续，绵延（大片地方或很长时间）: The long white beaches stretch for miles along the coast. 白色的沙滩沿海岸绵延数英里。
4 [T] to make use of all the money, ability, time, etc that sb has available for use 充分使用（钱、能力、时间等）: The test has been designed to really stretch students' knowledge. 测验旨在充分发挥学生的知识。
stretch your legs to go for a walk after sitting down for a long time （久坐后）散步伸一伸腿
stretch²
/stretʃ ||; strɛtʃ/noun[C]
1 a stretch (of sth) an area of land or water 一片（土地或水域）: a dangerous stretch of road 事故多的路段
2 [usu.sing] the action of making the muscles in your arms, legs, back, etc as long as possible 伸展，舒展（四肢、背部等）: Stand up, everybody, and have a good stretch. 大家站起来，舒展一下筋骨。
at a stretch without stopping 连续地；不停地: We travelled for six hours at a stretch. 我们连续走了六个小时。 at full stretch→FULL¹

stretcher
/ˈstretʃə(r) ||; ˈstrɛtʃɚ/noun [C] a piece of cloth supported by two poles that is used for carrying a person who has been injured 担架

ˈstretch limo
noun [C] (plural stretch limos) (also formal 正式ˌstretch ˈlimousine) a very large comfortable car that has been made longer so that it can have extra seats 超长豪华轿车

ˈstretch marks
noun [pl] the marks that are left on a person's skin after it has been stretched, particularly after a woman has been pregnant ﹙尤指女性生育后的﹚妊娠纹

stretchy
/ˈstretʃi ||; ˈstrɛtʃɪ/adj (used especially about clothing or fabric) that can easily be made longer or wider without tearing or breaking ﹙尤指衣物或织物﹚有弹性的: a stretchy skirt 弹性裙

strew
/stru: ||; stru/verb [T] (past tense strewed, past participle strewed or strewn)
1 (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to cover a surface with things 把…布满﹙或散布在﹚；在…上布满﹙或散播﹚: Clothes were strewn across the floor. 衣服扔得满地都是。 The streets were strewn with corpses. 街头铺满了尸体。 (figurative 比喻) The way ahead is strewn with difficulties. 前面的道路布满艰难险阻。
2 to be spread or lying over a surface 布满；撒满；散播在…上: Leaves strewed the path. 树叶落满小径。

stricken
/ˈstrɪkən ||; ˈstrɪkən/adj (formal 正式)
1 stricken (with/by sth) seriously affected by an unpleasant feeling or disease or by a difficult situation 受煎熬的；患病的；遭受挫折的: She raised her stricken face and begged for help. 她仰起苦闷的脸，乞求帮助。 Whole villages were stricken with the disease. 整村整村的人染上了这种病。 He was stricken by a heart attack on his fiftieth birthday. * 50 岁生日的那一天，他心脏病发作。 We went to the aid of the stricken boat. 我们前去救助那艘失事的船。
2 (in compounds 用于构成复合词) seriously affected by the thing mentioned 遭受…的；受…之困的: grief-stricken relatives 悲痛欲绝的亲戚们 ☞ Look also at panic-stricken and poverty-stricken. 另参看 panic-stricken 及 poverty-stricken。

*strict
/strɪkt ||; strɪkt/adj
1 not allowing people to break rules or behave badly 严厉的；严格的: Samir's very strict with his children. 沙米尔对孩子的管教很严格。 I went to a very strict school. 我上了一所很严格的学校。
2 that must be obeyed completely 必须严格遵守的: I gave her strict instructions to be home before 9.00. 我严格规定她必须在9点钟之前回家。
3 exactly correct; accurate 完全正确的；精确的: a strict interpretation of the law 对法律的精确诠释

strictly
/ˈstrɪktli ||; ˈstrɪktlɪ/adv in a strict way 严厉；严格: Smoking is strictly forbidden. 严禁吸烟。 strictly speaking to be exactly correct or accurate 严格说来；严格而言: Strictly speaking, the tomato is not a vegetable. It's a fruit. 严格说来，蕃茄不是蔬菜，是水果。

stride¹
/straɪd ||; straɪd/verb [I] (past tense strode /strəʊd ||; strod/) (not used in the perfect tense 不用于完成时) to walk with long steps, often because you feel very confident or determined. 阔步走；大步走: He strode up to the house and knocked on the door. 他大步走到那幢房子前，然后敲门。
stride²
/straɪd ||; straɪd/noun [C] a long step 一大步 get into your stride to start to do sth in a confident way and well after an uncertain beginning 开始充满信心熟练地做某事 make great strides to make very quick progress 取得很大进步 take sth in your stride to deal with a new or difficult situation easily and without worrying 从容地应付新环境或困境

strident
/ˈstraɪdnt ||; ˈstraɪdṇt/adj (used about a voice or a sound) loud and unpleasant （指声音）尖厉的，刺耳的

strife
/straɪf ||; straɪf/noun [U] (written 书面语) trouble or fighting between people or groups 冲突；纷争；争斗

*strike¹
/straɪk ||; straɪk/noun[C]
1 a period of time when people refuse to go to work, usually because they want more money or better working conditions 罢工: a one-day strike 罢工一天 Union members voted to go on strike. 工会会员投票决定罢工。
2 a sudden military attack, especially by aircraft 突袭（尤指空袭）
*strike²
/straɪk ||; straɪk/verb (past tense past participle struck /strʌk ||; strʌk/)
1 [T] (formal 正式) to hit sb/sth 打；击: The stone struck her on the head. 石头击中她的头部。 The boat struck a rock and began to sink. 船撞上礁石，开始下沉。 ☞ Hit is more common The stone hit her on the head. hit较常用：The stone hit her on the head.石头击中她的头部。
2 [I,T] to attack and harm sb/sth suddenly 突袭 · The earthquake struck Kobe in 1995. 1995年神户突然发生地震。 The building had been struck by lightning. 建筑物被闪电击中。
3 [I] to stop work as a protest 罢工: The workers voted to strike for more money. 工人们投票决定罢工争取加薪。
4 [T] strike sb (as sth) to give sb a particular impression 给某人（某种印象）: Does anything here strike you as unusual? 你觉得这里有什么不寻常吗？ He strikes me as a very caring man. 我觉得他是个很有爱心的人。
5 [T] (used about a thought or an idea) to come suddenly into sb's mind （指想法）突然在脑里出现: It suddenly struck me that she would be the ideal person for the job. 我突然想到她十分适合做那件工作。
6 [T] to produce fire by rubbing sth, especially a match, on a surface 擦出火（尤指划火柴）: She struck a match and lit her cigarette. 她划火柴点着香烟。
7 [I,T] (used about a clock) to ring a bell so that people know what time it is （指钟）敲响报时: The clock struck eight (= 8 o'clock). 钟敲了八下（八点钟了）。
8 [T] to discover gold, oil, etc in the ground 发现（黄金、石油等）
strike a balance (between A and B) to find a middle way between two extremes 找到折中办法 strike a bargain (with sb) to make an agreement with sb （和某人）达成协议 within striking distance near enough to be reached or attacked easily 在可到达或攻击的距离内 strike back to attack sb/sth that has attacked you 反击 strike up sth (with sb) to start a conversation or friendship with sb （与某人）攀谈，结交

striker
/ˈstraɪkə(r) ||; ˈstraɪkɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who has stopped working as a protest 罢工者
2 (in football) a player whose job is to score goals （足球）前锋

striking
/ˈstraɪkɪŋ ||; ˈstraɪkɪŋ/adj very noticeable; making a strong impression 显著的；令人印象深刻的: There was a striking similarity between the two men. 那两名男子有显著的相似之处。 ➔strikingly adv

*string¹
/strɪŋ ||; strɪŋ/noun
1 [C,U] a piece of long, strong material like very thin rope, that you use for tying things 细绳；线；带: a ball/piece/length of string 一团╱一根╱一段细绳 The key is hanging on a string. 钥匙挂在带子上。 ☞picture at cable 见cable插图
2 [C] one of the pieces of thin wire, etc that produce the sound on some musical instruments （乐器的）弦: A guitar has six strings. 吉他有六根弦。 ☞picture at music 见music插图
3 [C] one of the tightly stretched pieces of NYLON, etc in a RACKET (= the thing that you use to hit the ball in tennis and other sports) （网球等球拍的）弦
4 the strings [pl] the instruments in an orchestra that have strings 弦乐器
5 [C] a string of sth a line of things that are joined together on the same piece of thread 一串: a string of beads 一串珠子
6 [C] a string of sth a series of people, things or events that follow one after another 一系列；一连串；一行；一列: a string of visitors 一连串访客
7 [C] (computing计算机技术) a series of letters, numbers, words, etc. 字符串；数字符串；词串
(with) no strings attached;without strings with no special conditions 没有附带条件 pull strings→PULL¹
string²
/strɪŋ ||; strɪŋ/verb [T] (past tense past participle strung /strʌŋ ||; strʌŋ/)string sth (up) to hang up a line of things with a piece of string, etc 用绳串起悬挂 string sb/sth out to make people or things form a line with spaces between each person or thing 使人或物排成一列 string sth together to put words or phrases together to make a sentence, speech, etc 将词或短语组成句子、话语等

stringed instrument
/ˌstrɪŋd ˈɪnstrəmənt ||; ˈstrɪŋd ˈɪnstrəmənt/noun [C] any musical instrument with strings that you play with your fingers or with a BOW 弦乐器

stringent
/ˈstrɪndʒənt ||; ˈstrɪndʒənt/adj (used about a law, rule, etc) very strict （指法律、规则等）严厉的，严格的

stringy
/ˈstrɪŋi ||; ˈstrɪŋɪ/adj
1 (used about a person's hair) long and thin and looking as if it has not been washed ﹙头发﹚细长而干枯的；细长而稀疏的
2 (used about food) containing long thin pieces like string and difficult to chew ﹙食物﹚多筋的，纤维多而不嫩的: tough, stringy meat 又老筋又多的肉
3 (used about a person or part of the body) thin so that you can see the muscles ﹙人或人体部位﹚瘦得露出筋的: a stringy neck 瘦得青筋毕露的脖子

*strip¹
/strɪp ||; strɪp/noun [C] a long narrow piece of sth 狭长的一片；一条: a strip of paper 一张纸条
strip²
/strɪp ||; strɪp/verb (stripping;stripped)
1 [I,T] strip (sth) (off) to take off your clothes; to take off sb else's clothes 脱衣服: The doctor asked him to strip to the waist. 医生请他把衣服脱到腰部。 I was stripped and searched at the airport by two customs officers. 我在机场被两个海关人员脱衣检查。
2 [T] strip sb/sth (of sth) to take sth away from sb/sth 取走；褫夺: They stripped the house of all its furniture. 他们将房子内的家具都搬走了。
3 [T] strip sth (off) to remove sth that is covering a surface 除去或剥去表层: to strip the paint off a door 除去门上的油漆 to strip wallpaper 剥去墙纸

*stripe
/straɪp ||; straɪp/noun [C] a long narrow line of colour 条纹: Zebras have black and white stripes. 斑马有黑白相间的条纹。 ➔striped /straɪpt ||; straɪpt/ adj a red and white striped dress 有红白相间条纹的连衣裙

stripper
/ˈstrɪpə(r) ||; ˈstrɪpɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is to take off his/her clothes in order to entertain people 脱衣舞表演者

ˈstrip search
noun [C] an act of searching a person for illegal drugs, weapons, etc, e.g. at an airport or in a prison, after he/she has been made to take off all his/her clothes ﹙对被疑非法携带毒品、武器等的人进行的﹚裸体搜身 ➔ˈstrip-search verb [T]

striptease
/ˈstrɪpti:z ||; ˈstrɪpˌtiz/noun [C,U] entertainment in which sb takes off his/her clothes, usually to music 脱衣舞

strive
/straɪv ||; straɪv/verb [I] (past tense strove /strəʊv ||; strov/ past participle striven /ˈstrɪvn ||; ˈstrɪvən/) (formal 正式)strive (for sth/to do sth) to try very hard to do or get sth 努力；奋斗: to strive for perfection 力求完美

strode
past tense ofSTRIDE¹

*stroke¹
/strəʊk ||; strok/noun
1 [C] one of the movements that you make when you are writing or painting 一笔；一画: a brush stroke 毛笔的一笔
2 [C] one of the movements that you make when you are swimming, rowing, playing golf, etc （游泳、划船等的）一次划水；（高尔夫球等的）一次击球: Woods won by three strokes (= hits of the ball in golf). 伍兹以三杆的优势取胜。
3 [C,U] (used in compounds 用于构成复合词) one of the styles of swimming 游泳姿势；游法: I can do backstroke and breaststroke, but not front crawl. 我会仰泳和蛙泳，但不会自由泳。 ☞Look at crawl. 参看crawl。
4 [C] a sudden illness which attacks the brain and can leave a person unable to move part of his/her body, speak clearly, etc 中风: to have a stroke 中风
5 [sing] a stroke of sth a sudden successful action or event 突如其来的成功行动或事件: It was a stroke of luck finding your ring on the beach, wasn't it? 居然在海滩上找到了你的戒指，真是运气，对吗？
at a/one stroke with a single action 一举；一下子 not do a stroke (of work) to not do any work at all 一点工作也不做
stroke²
/strəʊk ||; strok/verb[T]
1 to move your hand gently over sb/sth 抚摸: She stroked his hair affectionately. 她充满怜爱地抚摸他的头发。 to stroke a dog 抚摸一只狗
2 to move sth somewhere with a smooth movement 轻轻移动（某物）

stroll
/strəʊl ||; strol/noun [C] a slow walk for pleasure 散步；漫步；溜达: to go for a stroll along the beach 到沙滩去散步 stroll verb [I]

*strong
/strɒŋ; US strɔ:ŋ ||; strɔŋ/adj
1 (used about a person) physically powerful; able to lift or carry heavy things （指人）强壮的，力气大的: I need someone strong to help me move this bookcase. 我需要个力气大的人帮我搬这个书橱。 to have strong arms/muscles 有强壮的手臂╱肌肉
2 (used about an object) not easily broken or damaged （指物件）坚固的，结实的: That chair isn't strong enough for you to stand on. 那把椅子不够结实，不能站在上面。
3 (used about a natural force) powerful （指自然力量）强劲的，猛烈的: strong winds/currents/sunlight 强风；急流；强烈的阳光
4 having a big effect on the mind, body or senses 对身心、感官有大的影响的；强烈的；浓烈的: a strong smell of garlic 浓烈的大蒜气味 strong coffee 浓咖啡 a strong drink(= with a lot of alcohol in it) 烈酒 I have the strong impression that they don't like us. 我强烈感觉到他们不喜欢我们。
5 (used about opinions and beliefs) very firm; difficult to fight against （指看法和信念）坚定的，难以抗争的: There was strong opposition to the idea. 那个意念遭到激烈的反对。 strong support for the government's plan 大力支持政府的计划。
6 powerful and likely to succeed 有力的；很有可能成功的: She's a strong candidate for the job. 她是这个职位的有力人选。 a strong team 一个强有力的班子
7 (used after a noun 用于名词后) having a particular number of people 有某数量的人 ☞noun strength for all senses 所有义项的名词皆为strength
8 used to describe the way some words are pronounced when they are emphasized. For example, the strong form ofandis /ænd/. （用于表示某些词的强读形式，如and的强读形式是/and/） ➔strongly adv The directors are strongly opposed to the idea. 董事们强烈反对那个主张。 to feel very strongly about sth 对某事物有坚定的看法
going strong(informal 非正式) continuing, even after a long time. 历久不衰: The company was formed in 1851 and is still going strong. 公司成立于1851年，历久不衰。 sb's strong point something that a person is good at 某人的长处或擅长的事物: Maths is not my strong point. 数学不是我的强项。

stronghold
/ˈstrɒŋhəʊld; US ˈstrɔ:ŋ- ||; ˈstrɔŋˌhold/noun[C]
1 an area in which there is a lot of support for a particular belief or group of people, especially a political party 有广泛支持的地方；势力强大的地方: a Republican stronghold/a stronghold of Republicanism 共和党势力强大的地区 The college is a stronghold of the child-centred approach to teaching. 这所大学大力支持以孩子为中心的教学方法。
2 a castle or a place that is strongly built and difficult to attack 堡垒；要塞；据点: Troops surrounded the mountain stronghold of the guerrillas. 军队包围了游击队的山区据点。

ˌstrong-ˈminded
adj having firm ideas or beliefs 有强烈信念的；意志坚强的

ˌstrong-ˈwilled
adj determined to do what you want to do, even if other people advise you not to 意志坚强的；坚持己见的

strontium
/ˈstrɒntiəm; US ˈstrɒnʃ- ||; ˈstrɑnʃɪəm/noun [U] (symbol Sr) a soft silver-white metal 锶

stroppy
/ˈstrɒpi ||; ˈstrɑpɪ/adj (Brit 英) (slang 俚语) (used about a person) easily annoyed and difficult to deal with （指人）脾气暴躁的，难以相处的

strove
past tense ofSTRIVE

struck
past tense, past participle ofSTRIKE²

structuralism
/ˈstrʌktʃərəlɪzəm ||; ˈstrʌktʃərəˌlɪzəm/noun [U] (in literature, language and social science 文学、语言及社会科学) a theory that considers any text as a structure whose various parts only have meaning when they are considered in relation to each other 结构主义﹙认为任何文本为一结构体系，其各个部份只有在相互关系中才有意义﹚ ➔structuralist noun [C],adj: a structuralist critic/approach 结构主义批评家/方法

*structure¹
/ˈstrʌktʃə(r) ||; ˈstrʌktʃɚ/noun
1 [C,U] the way that the parts of sth are put together or organized 结构；组织: the political and social structure of a country 国家的政治及社会结构 the grammatical structures of a language 语言的语法结构
2 [C] a building or sth that has been built or made from a number of parts 建筑物: The old office block had been replaced by a modern glass structure. 旧办公大楼已由一座新式玻璃墙建筑物所代替。 ➔structural /ˈstrʌktʃərəl ||; ˈstrʌktʃərəl/ adj
structure²
/ˈstrʌktʃə(r) ||; ˈstrʌktʃɚ/verb [T] to arrange sth in an organized way 组织；安排: a carefully-structured English course 细心编排的英语课程

*struggle¹
/ˈstrʌgl ||; ˈstrʌgḷ/verb[I]
1 struggle (with sth/for sth/to do sth) to try very hard to do sth, especially when it is difficult 奋斗；努力；使劲做某事（尤指难事）: We struggled up the stairs with our heavy suitcases. 我们提着沉重的手提箱勉强上楼梯。 Maria was struggling with her English homework. 玛丽亚正在努力应付英语功课。 The country is struggling for independence. 这个国家在为独立而斗争。
2 struggle (with sb/sth);struggle (against sth) to fight in order to prevent sth or to escape from sb 挣扎（以求阻止某事或摆脱某人）: He shouted and struggled but he couldn't get free. 他又是喊叫，又是挣扎，但无法挣脱。 A passer-by was struggling with one of the robbers on the ground. 一名过路人与一个盗贼在地上搏斗。 He has been struggling against cancer for years. 多年来他一直与癌症搏斗。
struggle on to continue to do sth although it is difficult （虽然艰难仍然）继续做某事: I felt terrible but managed to struggle on to the end of the day. 那天我觉得很不舒服，但仍然坚持奋斗到底。
struggle²
/ˈstrʌgl ||; ˈstrʌgḷ/noun[C]
1 a fight in which sb tries to do or get sth when this is difficult 奋斗；斗争；努力: All countries should join together in the struggle against terrorism. 所有国家应协力对付恐怖主义。 He will not give up the presidency without a struggle. 不经一番拚搏他不会放弃总统职位。 a struggle for independence 为独立而斗争
2 [usu.sing] sth that is difficult to achieve 难事: It will be a struggle to get there on time. 要准时到达那里是很难的事。

strum
/strʌm ||; strʌm/verb [I,T] (strumming;strummed) to play a guitar by moving your hand up and down over the strings 弹拨（吉他）

strung
past tense, past participle ofSTRING²

strut
/strʌt ||; strʌt/verb [I] (strutting;strutted) to walk in a proud way 高视阔步

strychnine
/ˈstrɪkni:n ||; ˈstrɪknin/noun [U] a poisonous substance that can be used in very small amounts as a medicine 士的宁，马钱子碱（一种有毒物质，微量可作药）

stub
/stʌb ||; stʌb/noun [C] the short piece of a cigarette or pencil that is left after the rest of it has been used 烟蒂；铅笔头

stubble
/ˈstʌbl ||; ˈstʌbḷ/noun[U]
1 the short parts of corn, wheat, etc that are left standing after the rest has been cut （谷物收割后剩在地里的）茬子，残株
2 the short hairs that grow on a man's face when he has not shaved for some time 胡茬 ☞picture at hair 见hair插图

stubborn
/ˈstʌbən ||; ˈstʌbɚn/adj not wanting to do what other people want you to do; refusing to change your plans or decisions 顽固的；固执的；倔强的: She's too stubborn to apologize. 她很顽固，不肯道歉。 [SYN] obstinate 同义词为obstinate ☞Look at pig-headed. 参看pig-headed。 ➔stubbornly adv He stubbornly refused to apologize so he was sacked. 他坚决拒绝道歉，因此被解雇了。 ➔stubbornness noun [U]

stubby
/ˈstʌbi ||; ˈstʌbɪ/adj (stubbier; stubbiest) (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) short and thick 短而粗的: stubby fingers 又短又粗的手指

stuck¹
past tense, past participle ofSTICK¹
stuck²
/stʌk ||; stʌk/adj
1 not able to move 不能移动；动弹不得: This drawer's stuck. I can't open it at all. 这个抽屉卡住了，我根本打不开。 We were stuck in traffic for over two hours. 我们陷于交通阻塞，有两个多小时无法动弹。
2 not able to continue with an exercise, etc because it is too difficult 难住了: If you get stuck, ask your teacher for help. 有困难就请教老师。

ˌstuck-ˈup
adj (informal 非正式) thinking that you are more important than other people and behaving in an unfriendly way toward them 自命不凡的；趾高气扬的 [SYN]snobbish 同义词为 snobbish

stud
/stʌd ||; stʌd/noun
1 [C] a small piece of metal that sticks out from the rest of the surface that it is fixed to 某物表面的金属突出物；饰钉: a black leather jacket with studs all over it 布满饰片的黑色皮夹克
2 [C] a small, round, solid piece of metal that you wear through a hole in your ear or other part of the body 耳环；（穿在身体其他部份的）环
3 [C] one of the pieces of plastic or metal that stick out from the bottom of football, etc boots and that help you stand up on wet ground （足球鞋等运动鞋底的）鞋钉，防滑钉
4 [C,U] a number of high quality horses or other animals that are kept for breeding young animals; the place where these horses, etc are kept 种马；配种用的动物；种马场: a stud farm 种马场

studded
/ˈstʌdɪd ||; ˈstʌdɪd/adj
1 covered or decorated with studs 镶上饰片等物件的
2 studded (with sth) containing a lot of sth 布满着，密布着（某物）

*student
/ˈstju:dnt; US ˈstu:- ||; ˈstudṇt/noun [C] a person who is studying at a college or university （大学或专科学校的）学生: Paola is a medical student at Bristol University. 保拉是布里斯托尔大学的医科学生。 a full-time/part-time student 全日制╱兼读制学生 a postgraduate/research student 研究生 ☞Compare pupil. Look also at scholar, graduate and undergraduate. 与pupil比较。另参看scholar、graduate及undergraduate。

studied
/ˈstʌdid ||; ˈstʌdɪd/adj (formal 正式) carefully planned or done, especially when you are trying to give a particular impression 精心策划的（尤指试图给人某种印象）

*studio
/ˈstju:diəʊ; US ˈstu:- ||; ˈstudɪˌo/noun [C] (plural studios)
1 a room where an artist or photographer works 画室；摄影室；工作室
2 a room or building where films or television programmes are made, or where music, radio programmes, etc are recorded （电影或电视节目的）制片厂，摄影棚；（音乐、电台节目等的）录音室: a film/TV/recording studio 电影制片厂；电视摄影棚；录音室

studious
/ˈstju:diəs; US ˈstu:- ||; ˈstudɪəs/adj (used about a person) spending a lot of time studying （指人）勤学的，好学的，用功的

studiously
/ˈstju:diəsli ||; ˈstudɪəslɪ/adv with great care 极小心

*study¹
/ˈstʌdi ||; ˈstʌdɪ/noun (plural studies)
1 [U] the activity of learning about sth 学习: One hour every afternoon is left free for individual study. 每天下午有一小时自修时间。 Physiology is the study of how living things work. 生理学是研究生物功能的学科。
2 studies [pl] the subjects that you study 学习的科目；研究科目: business/media/Japanese studies 商业╱媒体╱日本研究
3 [C] a piece of research that examines a question or a subject in detail 研究: They are doing a study of the causes of heart disease. 他们在研究心脏病的病因。
4 [C] a room in a house where you go to read, write or study 书房；书斋
*study²
/ˈstʌdi ||; ˈstʌdɪ/verb (present participle studying third person singular present studies;past tense past participle studied)
1 [I,T] study (sth/for sth) to spend time learning about sth 学习 · to study French at university 在大学学习法语 Leon has been studying hard for his exams. 利昂努力学习准备考试。
2 [T] to look at sth very carefully 细心查看: to study a map 仔细看地图

*stuff¹
/stʌf ||; stʌf/noun [U] (informal 非正式)
1 used to refer to sth without using its name 东西: What's that green stuff at the bottom of the bottle? 瓶底那绿色的东西是什么？ The shop was burgled and a lot of stuff was stolen. 那个商店被人撬窃，许多东西被偷了。 They sell stationery and stuff (like that). 他们出售文具之类的东西。 I'll put the swimming stuff in this bag. 我会把游泳用品放在这个袋子里。
2 used to refer in general to things that people do, say, think, etc 事；话；想法: I've got lots of stuff to do tomorrow so I'm going to get up early. 明天我有好多事要做，因此要早起。 I don't believe all that stuff about him being robbed. 我不信关于他被抢劫的种种说法。 I like reading and stuff. 我喜欢阅读之类的活动。
stuff²
/stʌf ||; stʌf/verb
1 [T] stuff sth (with sth) to fill sth with sth 填（满）；装（满）: The pillow was stuffed with feathers. 枕头里填满羽毛。 red peppers stuffed with rice 填有米饭的红辣椒
2 [T] (informal 非正式)stuff sth into sth to put sth into sth else quickly or carelessly 匆忙或胡乱地把（某物）放进…里: He quickly stuffed a few clothes into a suitcase. 他匆匆忙忙把几件衣服塞进一个手提箱里。
3 [T] (informal 非正式)stuff sb/yourself (with sth) to eat too much of sth; to give sb too much to eat 大吃；让某人大吃 · Barry just sat there stuffing himself with sandwiches. 巴里就坐在那里拚命吃三明治。 I can't eat any more -- I'm stuffed. 我再也吃不下了─我饱了。
4 [T] to fill the body of a dead bird or animal with special material so that it looks as if it is alive 填充鸟兽尸体以制作标本: They've got a stuffed crocodile in the museum. 博物馆里有个鳄鱼标本。

stuffing
/ˈstʌfɪŋ ||; ˈstʌfɪŋ/noun[U]
1 a mixture of small pieces of food that you put inside a chicken, vegetable, etc before you cook it 馅；填料
2 the material that you put inside cushions, soft toys, etc （软垫，软玩具等的）填充物

stuffy
/ˈstʌfi ||; ˈstʌfɪ/adj
1 (used about a room) too warm and having no fresh air （指房间）不通风的，缺乏新鲜空气的
2 (informal 非正式) (used about a person) formal and old-fashioned （指人）古板的，一本正经的，拘谨的

stumble
/ˈstʌmbl ||; ˈstʌmbḷ/verb[I]
1 stumble (over/on sth) to hit your foot against sth when you are walking or running and almost fall over 绊脚；绊了一下
2 stumble (over/through sth) to make a mistake when you are speaking, playing music, etc （说话、演奏等时）犯错: The newsreader stumbled over the name of the Russian tennis player. 新闻读稿员说错了那个俄罗斯网球选手的名字。
stumble across/on sb/sth to meet or find sb/sth by chance 偶遇；意外地发现

ˈstumbling block
noun [C] something that causes trouble or a difficulty, so that you cannot achieve what you want 障碍物；绊脚石: Money is still the stumbling block to settling the dispute. 金钱仍是解决这纠纷的障碍。

stump¹
/stʌmp ||; stʌmp/noun [C] the part that is left after sth has been cut down, broken off, etc 残余部份；残根: a tree stump 树桩 ☞picture at erode 见erode插图
stump²
/stʌmp ||; stʌmp/verb [T] (informal 非正式) to cause sb to be unable to answer a question or find a solution for a problem 难倒: I was completely stumped by question 14. 第14道题完全把我难倒了。

stun
/stʌn ||; stʌn/verb [T] (stunning;stunned)
1 to make a person or animal unconscious or confused, especially by hitting him/her/it on the head 使（人或动物）昏迷，胡涂（尤指以打击头部的方式）
2 to make a person very surprised by telling him/her some unexpected news 使震惊；使大吃一惊: His sudden death stunned his friends and colleagues. 他突然过世使他的朋友和同事们大吃一惊。 ➔stunned adj

stung
past tense, past participle ofSTING¹

ˈstun gun
noun [C] a weapon that makes a person or an animal unconscious or unable to move for a short time, usually by giving him/her/it a small electric shock 眩晕枪﹙能使人或动物短时失去知觉或无法动弹﹚

stunk
past participle ofSTINK

stunning
/ˈstʌnɪŋ ||; ˈstʌnɪŋ/adj (informal 非正式) very attractive, impressive or surprising 非常吸引人的；非常出色的；令人目瞪口呆的: a stunning view 令人瞠目的美景

stunt¹
/stʌnt ||; stʌnt/noun[C]
1 something that you do to get people's attention 意在引人注目的举动；噱头: a publicity stunt 宣传噱头
2 a very difficult or dangerous thing that sb does to entertain people or as part of a film 特技表演: Some actors do their own stunts, others use a stunt man. 有些演员自己做特技动作，有些使用特技替身演员。
stunt²
/stʌnt ||; stʌnt/verb [T] to stop sb/sth growing or developing properly 妨碍生长或发育: A poor diet can stunt a child's growth. 营养不足会妨碍儿童发育。

stuntman
/ˈstʌntmæn ||; ˈstʌntˌmæn/noun [C] (plural -men /-men ||; -mɛn/) a person who does sth dangerous in a film in the place of an actor 特技替身演员

stupendous
/stju:ˈpendəs; US stu:- ||; stuˈpɛndəs/adj very large or impressive 巨大的；宏伟的；壮观的: a stupendous achievement 伟大的成就

*stupid
/ˈstju:pɪd; US ˈstu: ||; ˈstupɪd/adj
1 not intelligent or sensible 傻的；不聪明的；愚蠢的: Don't be so stupid, of course I'll help you! 别这么傻，我当然会帮你！ He was stupid to trust her. 他信任她，那是很愚蠢的。 a stupid mistake/suggestion/question 一个愚蠢的错误╱建议╱问题
2 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (informal 非正式) used to show that you are angry or do not like sb/sth （表示生气或不喜欢）: I'm tired of hearing about his stupid car. 我再不想听他讲自己那辆破汽车。 ➔stupidity /stju:ˈpɪdəti; US stu:- ||; stuˈpɪdətɪ/ noun [U] ➔stupidly adv

stupor
/ˈstju:pə(r); US ˈstu:- ||; ˈstupɚ/noun [sing] [U] the state of being nearly unconscious or being unable to think properly 昏迷；迷糊；恍惚

sturdy
/ˈstɜ:di ||; ˈstɝdɪ/adj (sturdier;sturdiest) strong and healthy; that will not break easily 强健的；坚固的；结实的: sturdy legs 强壮的腿 sturdy shoes 结实的鞋子 ➔sturdily adv ➔sturdiness noun [U]

stutter
/ˈstʌtə(r) ||; ˈstʌtɚ/verb [I,T] to have difficulty when you speak, so that you keep repeating the first sound of a word 结结巴巴地说；口吃 stutter noun [C]: to have a stutter 口吃

sty
/staɪ ||; staɪ/ (also stye) noun [C] (plural sties or styes)
1 a painful spot on the EYELID(= the skin that covers the eye) 麦粒肿；睑腺炎
2 = PIGSTY

*style
/staɪl ||; staɪl/noun
1 [C,U] the way that sth is done, built, etc 形式；风格；式样: a new style of architecture 新颖的建筑风格 The writer's style is very clear and simple. 这位作家的文风十分简单明白。 an American-style education system 美国式教育制度
2 [C,U] the fashion, shape or design of sth 款式；样式；设计: We stock all the latest styles. 我们各种最新款式齐备。 I like your new hairstyle. 我喜欢你的新发型。
3 [U] the ability to do things in a way that other people admire 办事能力；派头；风度: He's got no sense of style. 他缺少风度感。
4 [C] (technical术语) the long thin part of the CARPEL(= the female part in the middle of a flower) that supports the STIGMA （雌蕊的）花柱 ☞picture at flower 见flower插图

stylish
/ˈstaɪlɪʃ ||; ˈstaɪlɪʃ/adj fashionable and attractive 时髦的；有派头的；优雅的: She's a stylish dresser. 她穿着很时髦。

stylistic
/staɪˈlɪstɪk ||; staɪˈlɪstɪk/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with the style an artist uses in a particular piece of art, writing or music 风格上的；文体上的: stylistic analysis/features/devices 文体分析/特征/手法

stylistics
/staɪˈlɪstɪks ||; staɪˈlɪstɪks/noun [U] the study of style and the methods used in written language 文体学；风格学

stylized
/ˈstaɪlaɪzd ||; ˈstaɪlaɪzd/adj drawn, written, etc in a way that is not natural or realistic ﹙绘画、写作等手法﹚非写实的: a stylized drawing of a house 用非写实手法画的一座房子 the highly stylized form of acting in Japanese theatre 日本戏剧中高度非写实的表演形式

stymie
/ˈstaɪmi ||; ˈstaɪmɪ/verb [T] (present participle stymieing or stymying third person singular present stymies;past tense past participle stymied) (informal 非正式) to prevent sb from doing sth that he/she has planned or wants to do; to prevent sth from happening 阻拦，阻碍（某人做某事或某事发生） [SYN] foil ² 同义词为foil^2

suave
/swɑ:v ||; swɑv/adj (usually used about a man) confident, elegant and polite, sometimes in a way that does not seem sincere （通常指男人）温文的，文雅的，文绉绉的（有时含不真诚之意）

sub-
/sʌb ||; sʌb/prefix
1 (used in nouns and adjectives 用于构成名词及形容词) below; less than 以下；少于: sub-zero temperatures 零下气温 a subtropical (= almost tropical) climate 亚热带气候 a sub lieutenant 陆军少尉
2 (used in nouns and adjectives 用于构成名词及形容词) under 底下: subway 地下铁路 submarine 潜艇
3 (used in verbs and nouns 用于构成动词及名词) making a smaller part of sth 分得更小: subdivide 再分 subset （组成大套的）小套

subcommittee
/ˈsʌbkəmɪti ||; ˈsʌbkəˌmɪtɪ/noun [C, with sing or pl verb] a smaller committee formed from a main committee in order to study a particular subject in more detail ﹙委员会内的﹚小组委员会: the House of Representatives subcommittee on taxation 众议院税收小组委员会

subconscious
/ˌsʌbˈkɒnʃəs ||; sʌbˈkɑnʃəs/ (also unconscious) noun [sing] the subconscious the hidden part of your mind that can affect the way that you behave without you realizing 潜意识；下意识 subconscious adj the subconscious mind 潜意识 · Many advertisements work at a subconscious level. 许多广告在观众的潜意识层面起作用。 ➔subconsciously adv

subcontinent
