/ˌsʌbˈkɒntɪnənt ||; sʌbˈkɑntənənt/noun [sing] a large land mass that forms part of a continent, especially the part of Asia that includes India, Pakistan and Bangladesh 次大陆（尤指亚洲，包括印度、巴基斯坦及孟加拉国国的部份）

subcontract
/ˌsʌbkənˈtrækt; US ˌsʌbˈkɑ:ntrækt ||; ˌsʌbˈkɑnˌtrækt/verb [T] subcontract sth (to sb) to pay a person or company to do some of the work that you have been given a contract to do 分包；转包: We subcontracted the work to a small engineering firm. 我们把工作转包给一家小型工程公司。 We subcontracted a small engineering firm to do the work.我们转包给了一家小型工程公司去干那项工作。 ➔subcontract noun [C]

subcontractor
/ˌsʌbkənˈtræktə(r); US sʌbˈkɑ:ntræk- ||; ˌsʌbˈkɑnˌtræktɚ/noun [C] a person or company that does part of the work given to another person or company 分包商；分包人

subculture
/ˈsʌbkʌltʃə(r) ||; ˈsʌbˌkʌltʃɚ/noun [C] the behaviour and beliefs of a particular group of people in society that are different from those of most people 亚文化行为观念；次文化: the criminal/drug/youth subculture 犯罪/吸毒/青少年亚文化

subcutaneous
/ˌsʌbkjuˈteɪniəs ||; ˌsʌbkjυˈtenɪəs/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) (technical术语) under the skin 皮下的: a subcutaneous injection 皮下注射

subdivide
/ˌsʌbdɪˈvaɪd ||; ˌsʌbdəˈvaɪd/verb [I,T] to divide or be divided into smaller parts （被）细分 ➔subdivision /ˈsʌbdɪvɪʒn ||; ˌsʌbdəˈvɪʒən/ noun [C,U]

subdue
/səbˈdju: ||; səbˈdu/verb [T] to defeat sb/sth or bring sb/sth under control 打败；制伏；抑制

subdued
/səbˈdju:d ||; səbˈdud/adj
1 (used about a person) quieter and with less energy than usual （指人）低沉的，闷闷不乐的
2 not very loud or bright 轻声的；柔和的: subdued laughter/lighting 低沉的笑声；柔和的灯光

*subject¹
/ˈsʌbdʒɪkt ||; ˈsʌbdʒɪkt/noun[C]
1 a person or thing that is being considered, shown or talked about 课题；主题: What subject is the lecture on? 这堂课讲什么问题？ What are your views on this subject? 你对这个问题有什么看法？ I've tried several times to bring up / raise the subjectof money. 我几次想要提起钱的问题。
2 an area of knowledge that you study at school, university, etc 学科；科目: My favourite subjects at school are Biology and French. 我在学校里最喜欢的科目是生物和法语。
3 (grammar语法) the person or thing that does the action described by the verb in a sentence 主语；主词: In the sentence ‘The cat sat on the mat’, ‘the cat’ is the subject. 在The cat sat on the mat一句中，the cat是主语。 ☞Look at object. 参看object。
4 a person from a particular country, especially one with a king or queen; a citizen 国民，臣民（尤指君主制国家的）；公民: a British subject 英国臣民
change the subject→CHANGE¹
subject²
/səbˈdʒekt ||; səbˈdʒɛkt/verb subject sb/sth to sth to make sb/sth experience sth unpleasant 使遭受不愉快之事: He was subjected to verbal and physical abuse from the other boys. 他遭到其他男孩的谩骂和殴打。
subject³
/ˈsʌbdʒɪkt ||; ˈsʌbdʒɪkt/adj
1 subject to sth likely to be affected by sth 易蒙受或遭受: The area is subject to regular flooding. 那地区经常发生水灾。 Smokers are more subject to heart attacks than non-smokers. 吸烟者比不吸烟者容易得心脏病。
2 subject to sth depending on sth as a condition 以…为条件；取决于: The plan for new housing is still subject to approval by the minister. 建新房屋的计划仍须获得部长的批准。
3 controlled by or having to obey sb/sth 受制于；听命于

subjective
/səbˈdʒektɪv ||; səbˈdʒɛktɪv/adj based on your own tastes and opinions instead of on facts 主观的: Try not to be so subjective in your essays. 写文章不要那么主观。 [OPP] objective 反义词为objective ➔subjectively adv

ˈsubject matter
noun [U] the ideas or information contained in a book, speech, painting, etc 题材；内容；论题

subjunctive
/səbˈdʒʌŋktɪv ||; səbˈdʒʌŋktɪv/noun [sing] the form of a verb in certain languages that expresses doubt, possibility, a wish, etc 虚拟式；虚拟语气 subjunctive adj

sublime
/səˈblaɪm ||; səˈblaɪm/adj (formal 正式) of extremely high quality that makes you admire sth very much 卓越的；出众的；令人敬佩的 ➔sublimely adv

subliminal
/ˌsʌbˈlɪmɪnl ||; sʌbˈlɪmənḷ/adj affecting your mind even though you are not aware of it 下意识的；潜意识的: subliminal advertising 隐性广告 music containing subliminal messages 蕴涵潜意识信息的音乐

submarine
/ˌsʌbməˈri:n; US ˈsʌbməri:n ||; ˈsʌbməˌrin/noun [C] a type of ship that can travel under the water as well as on the surface 潜艇；潜水艇

submerge
/səbˈmɜ:dʒ ||; səbˈmɝdʒ/verb [I,T] to go or make sth go under water 没入水中；淹没 · The fields were submerged by the floods. 农田被洪水淹没了。 ➔submerged adj

submission
/səbˈmɪʃn ||; səbˈmɪʃən/noun
1 [U] the accepting of sb else's power or control because he/she has defeated you 降服；屈从；顺从
2 [U] [C] the action of giving a plan, document, etc to an official organization so that it can be studied and considered; the plan, document, etc that you send 呈交；缴交；（呈交的）计划，文件等

submissive
/səbˈmɪsɪv ||; səbˈmɪsɪv/adj ready to obey other people and do whatever they want 服从的；顺从的

submit
/səbˈmɪt ||; səbˈmɪt/verb (submitting;submitted)
1 [T] submit sth (to sb/sth) to give a plan, document, etc to an official organization so that it can be studied and considered 提交，呈交，缴交（计划、文件等）: to submit an application/complaint/claim 提交申请；投诉；提出要求
2 [I] submit (to sb/sth) to accept sb/sth's power or control because he/she has defeated you 降服；服从；投降

subordinate¹
/səˈbɔ:dɪnət; US -dənət ||; səˈbɔrdṇɪt/adj subordinate (to sb/sth) having less power or authority than sb else; less important than sth else 权力或级别较低的；次要的；从属的 subordinate noun [C]: the relationship between superiors and their subordinates 上级和下级之间的关系
subordinate²
/səˈbɔ:dɪneɪt; US -dəneɪt ||; səˈbɔrdṇˌet/verb [T] to treat one person or thing as less important than another 视为次要

suˌbordinate ˈclause
noun [C] (grammar语法) a group of words that is not a sentence but that adds information to the main part of the sentence 从句；从属子句: In the sentence ‘We left early because it was raining’, ‘because it was raining’ is the subordinate clause. 在We left early because it was raining一句中，because it was raining是从句。

suborn
/səˈbɔ:n ||; səˈbɔrn/verb [T] to pay or persuade sb to do sth illegal, especially to tell lies in court 收买；买通；唆使﹙作伪证等﹚: to suborn a witness 收买证人

subpoena
/səˈpi:nə ||; səˈpinə/noun [C] (law法津) a written order to attend a court of law to give evidence （传唤某人出庭作证的）传票: She is appearing today under subpoena (= she has been given a subpoena to appear in court). 她已被传唤，今天将出庭作证。 ➔subpoena verb The court subpoenaed her to appear as a witness. 法庭传唤她出庭作证。

subscribe
/səbˈskraɪb ||; səbˈskraɪb/verb[I]
1 subscribe (to sth) to pay for a newspaper or magazine to be sent to you regularly 订阅（报纸或杂志）
2 (formal 正式)subscribe to sth to agree with an idea, belief, etc 同意，赞成（观点、信念等）: I don't subscribe to the view that all war is wrong. 我不赞同所有战争都是错的这种看法。

subscriber
/səbˈskraɪbə(r) ||; səbˈskraɪbɚ/noun [C] a person who pays to receive a newspaper or magazine regularly or to use a particular service （报纸或杂志的）订户: subscribers to satellite and cable television 恒星电视和有线电视的用户

subscription
/səbˈskrɪpʃn ||; səbˈskrɪpʃən/noun [C] an amount of money that you pay, usually once a year, to receive a newspaper or magazine regularly or to belong to an organization （报纸或杂志的）订阅费；（会社的）会费

subsequent
/ˈsʌbsɪkwənt ||; ˈsʌbsɪkwənt/adj (formal 正式) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) coming after or later 随后的；接续发生的: I thought that was the end of the matter but subsequent events proved me wrong. 我以为那件事已经结束，但接着发生的事件证明我错了。 ➔subsequently adv The rumours were subsequently found to be untrue. 传闻后来发现并非属实。

subservient
/səbˈsɜ:viənt ||; səbˈsɝvɪənt/adj
1 subservient (to sb/sth) too ready to obey other people 恭顺的；俯首帖耳的；低声下气的
2 (formal 正式)subservient (to sth) considered to be less important than sth else 从属的；附属的；辅助的 ➔subservience noun [U]

subside
/səbˈsaɪd ||; səbˈsaɪd/verb[I]
1 to become calmer or quieter 平静；平息: The storm seems to be subsiding. 暴风雨好像在平息下去。
2 (used about land, a building, etc) to sink down into the ground （指陆地、建筑物等）下沉，下陷 ➔subsidence /ˈsʌbsɪdns ;səbˈsaɪdns ||; ˈsʌbsədəns; səbˈsaɪdṇs/ noun [U]

subsidiary¹
/səbˈsɪdiəri; US -dɪerɪ ||; səbˈsɪdɪˌɛrɪ/adj connected with sth but less important than it 附属的；次要的
subsidiary²
/səbˈsɪdiəri; US -dɪerɪ ||; səbˈsɪdɪˌɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural subsidiaries) a business company that belongs to and is controlled by another larger company 子公司

subsidize
/ˈsʌbsɪdaɪz ||; ˈsʌbsəˌdaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] (used about a government, etc) to give money in order to keep the cost of a service low （指政府等）资助，津贴，补贴: Public transport should be subsidized. 公共交通应受补助。

subsidy
/ˈsʌbsədi ||; ˈsʌbsədɪ/noun [C,U] (plural subsidies) money that the government, etc pays to help an organization or to keep the cost of a service low 补助金；津贴；补贴: agricultural/state/housing subsidies 农业╱国家╱住房补贴

subsist
/səbˈsɪst ||; səbˈsɪst/verb [I] (formal 正式)subsist (on sth) to manage to live with very little food or money （靠极少量食物或金钱）维持生活，活下去 ➔subsistence noun [U]

subˈsistence crop
/səbˈsɪstəns krɒps ||; səbˈsɪstəns ˌkrɑps/noun [C] plants that people grow to eat or use themselves, not to sell 生存作物（种植仅为自身食用、不供出售的作物） ☞Compare cash crop. 与cash crop比较。

subsoil
/ˈsʌbsɔɪl ||; ˈsʌbˌsɔɪl/noun [U] (in geography 地理学) the layer of soil between the surface of the ground and the hard rock underneath it （土壤的）底土，心土 ☞Look at topsoil. 参看topsoil。

*substance
/ˈsʌbstəns ||; ˈsʌbstəns/noun
1 [C] a solid or liquid material 物质: poisonous substances 有毒物质 The cloth is coated in a new waterproof substance. 这种布料涂有一层新的防水物质。
2 [U] importance, value or truth 重要性；价值；事实: The commissioner's report gives substance to these allegations. 专员的报告为这些说法提供实质性内容。
3 [U] the most important or main part of sth 要点；主旨: What was the substance of his argument? 他论点的要旨是什么？

ˌsub-ˈstandard
adj of poor quality; not as good as usual or as it should be 劣质的；不够标准的

substantial
/səbˈstænʃl ||; səbˈstænʃəl/adj
1 large in amount 大量的: The storms caused substantial damage. 暴风雨造成严重破坏。 a substantial sum of money 一大笔钱
2 large or strong 大的；结实的 [OPP] insubstantial 反义词为insubstantial

substantially
/səbˈstænʃəli ||; səbˈstænʃəlɪ/adv
1 very much; greatly 大量地；大幅度: House prices have fallen substantially. 房价大幅下跌。
2 generally; in most points 一般；大体上

substitute
/ˈsʌbstɪtju:t; US -tu:t ||; ˈsʌbstəˌtut/noun [C] a substitute (for sb/sth) a person or thing that takes the place of sb/sth else 代替者；替换者；代用品；后备: One player was injured so the substitute was sent on to play. 一个球员受了伤，所以那个替补球员上场比赛。 substitute verb [T] substitute sb/sth (for sb/sth) You can substitute margarine for butter. 你可以用人造黄油代替黄油。 ➔substitution /ˌsʌbstɪˈtju:ʃn; US -ˈtu:ʃn ||; ˌsʌbstəˈtuʃən/ noun [C,U]

subterranean
/ˌsʌbtəˈreɪniən ||; ˌsʌbtəˈrenɪən/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) (formal 正式) under the ground 地下的: a subterranean cave/passage/tunnel 地洞；地道；坑道

subtext
/ˈsʌbtekst ||; ˈsʌbˌtɛkst/noun [C] a hidden meaning or reason for doing sth 字面背后的意思；潜台词；潜在原因

subtitle
/ˈsʌbtaɪtl ||; ˈsʌbˌtaɪtḷ/noun [C] [usu.pl] the words at the bottom of the picture on television or at the cinema. The subtitles translate the words of a foreign film or programme or show the words that are spoken, to help people with hearing problems. （电影或电视等的）字幕: a Polish film with English subtitles 一部有英语字幕的波兰电影 ☞Look at dub (2). 参看dub(2)。 subtitle verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) a Spanish film subtitled in English 一部有英语字幕的西班牙电影

subtle
/ˈsʌtl ||; ˈsʌtḷ/adj
1 not very noticeable; not very strong or bright 不显著的；细微的；不明亮的: subtle colours 暗色 I noticed a subtle difference in her. 我注意到她起了细微的变化。
2 very clever; and using indirect methods to achieve sth 狡诈的；诡秘的；巧妙的: Advertisements persuade us to buy things in very subtle ways. 广告用非常巧妙的方式说服我们购买东西。 ➔subtlety /ˈsʌtlti ||; ˈsʌtḷtɪ/ noun [C,U] (plural subtleties) ➔subtly /ˈsʌtli ||; ˈsʌtlɪ/ adv

subtotal
/ˈsʌbtəʊtl ||; ˈsʌbˌtotḷ/noun [C] the total of a set of numbers which is then added to other totals to give a final number 部份和；小计

*subtract
/səbˈtrækt ||; səbˈtrækt/verb [T] subtract sth (from sth) to take one number or quantity away from another 减去: If you subtract five from nine you get four. 九减五等于四。 [OPP] add 反义词为add ➔subtraction /səbˈtrækʃn ||; səbˈtrækʃən/ noun [C,U]

subtropical
/ˌsʌbˈtrɒpɪkl ||; sʌbˈtrɑpɪkḷ/adj (in geography 地理学) in or connected with regions that are near tropical parts of the world 亚热带的: subtropical forests 亚热带森林

*suburb
/ˈsʌbɜ:b ||; ˈsʌbɝb/noun [C] an area where people live that is outside the central part of a town or city 郊区；市郊: Most people live in the suburbs and work in the centre of town. 大多数人在郊区居住，在市中心工作。 ➔suburban /səˈbɜ:bən ||; səˈbɝbən/ adj ☞People often think of life in the suburbs as dull, so suburban sometimes means ‘dull and uninteresting’. 人们常觉得郊区生活乏味，所以suburban一词有时意味着“枯燥乏味”。 ➔suburbia /səˈbɜ:biə ||; səˈbɝbɪə/ noun [U]

suburbanite
/səˈbɜ:bənaɪt ||; səˈbɝbəˌnaɪt/noun [C] a person who lives in the suburbs of a city 郊区居民: middle-class suburbanites 居住在郊区的中产阶级

subversive
/səbˈvɜ:sɪv ||; səbˈvɝsɪv/adj trying to destroy or damage a government, religion or political system by attacking it secretly and in an indirect way 颠覆性的；破坏性的: subversive literature/activities 煽动性印刷品；颠覆活动 subversive noun [C] ➔subversion /səbˈvɜ:ʃn; US -ˈvɜ:rʒn ||; səbˈvɝʒən/ noun [U]

subvert
/səbˈvɜ:t ||; səbˈvɝt/verb [T] to try to destroy or damage a government, religion or political system by attacking it secretly and in an indirect way 颠覆，破坏（政府、宗教信仰或政治制度）

subway
/ˈsʌbweɪ ||; ˈsʌbˌwe/noun[C]
1 a tunnel under a busy road or railway that is for people who are walking (pedestrians) 地下人行道；地下道
2 (US 美) =UNDERGROUND³

ˌsub-ˈzero
adj (used about temperatures) below zero; freezing ﹙气温﹚零下的

*succeed
/səkˈsi:d ||; səkˈsid/verb
1 [I] succeed (in sth/doing sth) to manage to achieve what you want; to do well 成功；达到目的: Our plan succeeded. 我们的计划成功了。 A good education will help you succeed in life. 良好的教育有助将来取得成功。 to succeed in passing an exam 考试及格 [OPP] fail 反义词为fail
2 [I,T] to have a job or important position after sb else 继任；继承 · Tony Blair succeeded John Major as Prime Minister in 1997. 1997年托尼˙布莱尔接替约翰˙梅杰出任首相。

*success
/səkˈses ||; səkˈsɛs/noun
1 [U] the fact that you have achieved what you want; doing well and becoming famous, rich, etc 成功；出名；发迹: Hard work is the key to success. 勤奋是取得成功的关键。 Her attempts to get a job for the summer have not met with much success(= she hasn't managed to do it). 她尝试在夏天找一份工作，但不太顺利。 What's the secret of your success? 你取得成功的秘诀是什么？
2 [C] the thing that you achieve; sth that becomes very popular 成就；成功的事: He really tried to make a success of the business. 他确实想把这企业办成功。 The film ‘Titanic’ was a huge success. 电影《铁达尼号》大获成功。 [OPP] failure 反义词为failure

*successful
/səkˈsesfl ||; səkˈsɛsfəl/adj having achieved what you wanted; having become popular, rich, etc 成功的；受欢迎的；发迹的: a successful attempt to climb Mount Qomolangma 成功攀登珠穆朗玛峰 a successful actor 受欢迎的演员 ➔successfully /-fəli ||; -fəlɪ/ adv

succession
/səkˈseʃn ||; səkˈsɛʃən/noun
1 [C] a number of people or things that follow each other in time or order; a series 一连串；一系列: a succession of events/problems/visitors 一连串事件╱问题╱访客
2 [U] the right to have an important position after sb else 继承权
in succession following one after another 连续；接连: There have been three deaths in the family in quick succession. 那家接连死了三个人。

successor
/səkˈsesə(r) ||; səkˈsɛsɚ/noun [C] a person or thing that comes after sb/sth else and takes his/her/its place 继承者；接替者；接班人 ☞Look at predecessor. 参看predecessor。

succinct
/səkˈsɪŋkt ||; səkˈsɪŋkt/adj said clearly, in a few words 简炼的；简明的 ➔succinctly adv

succulent
/ˈsʌkjələnt ||; ˈsʌkjələnt/adj (used about fruit, vegetables and meat) containing a lot of juice and tasting very good （指水果、蔬菜和肉）鲜美多汁的

succumb
/səˈkʌm ||; səˈkʌm/verb [I] (formal 正式)succumb (to sth) to stop fighting against sth 不再抵抗；屈服

*such
/sʌtʃ ||; sʌtʃ/det pronoun
1 (used for referring to sb/sth that you mentioned earlier) of this or that type （指先前提及的人或事物）这种，那种，这样的，那样的: I don't believe in ghosts. There's no such thing. 我不相信有鬼。世界上没有这种东西。 The economic situation is such that we all have less money to spend. 经济形势是这样的：我们能花的钱都比以前少。
2 used for emphasizing the degree of sth （用于强调某事物的程度）: It was such a fascinating book that I couldn't put it down. 这本书如此吸引人，我简直爱不释手。 It seems such a long time since we last met. 自从我们上次见面以来好像已很久了。 ☞You use such before a noun or before a noun that has an adjective in front of it Simon is such a bore! Susan is such a boring woman. You use so before an adjective that is used without a noun Don't be so boring.Compare It was so cold we stayed at home. It was such a cold night that we stayed at home. such用于名词前，或用于前面有形容词的名词词组前：Simon is such a bore!西蒙真讨厌！·Susan is such a boring woman.苏珊真是个讨厌的女人。形容词后没有名词则用so：Don't be so boring.别这样讨厌！比较：It was so cold we stayed at home.太冷了，我们只好留在家中。·It was such a cold night that we stayed at home.那天晚上如此寒冷，我们只好留在家中。
3 used to describe the result of sth （指结果）: The statement was worded in such a way that it did not upset anyone. 声明措辞得宜，没有人感到不快。
as such as the word is usually understood; exactly 就其本身而论；确切地说: It's not a promotion as such, but it will mean more money. 确切地说这算不上提升，但这将意味着薪金增加。 such as for example 例如；像: Fatty foods such as chips are bad for you. 高脂肪食物如炸薯条对你没有益处。

suchlike
/ˈsʌtʃlaɪk ||; ˈsʌtʃˌlaɪk/pronoun things of the type mentioned 诸如此类的事物: You can buy brushes, paint, varnish and suchlike there. 你在那里能买到刷子、油漆、清漆之类的东西。 ➔suchlike det: food, drink, clothing and suchlike provisions 食物、饮料、服装以及其他诸如此类的日用品

*suck
/sʌk ||; sʌk/verb
1 [I,T] to pull a liquid into your mouth 吮；吸啜 [T] to suck milk up through a straw 用吸管吸牛奶 ☞picture at blow 见blow插图
2 [I,T] to have sth in your mouth and keep touching it with your tongue 含在嘴里舔着吃: He was noisily sucking (on) a sweet. 他在出声地舔吃糖果。
3 [T] to pull sth in a particular direction, using force 抽吸；卷入: Vacuum cleaners suck up the dirt. 真空吸尘器吸走灰尘。

sucker
/ˈsʌkə(r) ||; ˈsʌkɚ/noun[C]
1 (informal 非正式) a person who believes everything that you tell him/her and who is easy to trick or persuade to do sth 容易受骗的人
2 a part of some plants, animals or insects that is used for helping them stick onto a surface （动物的）吸盘；（植物的）根出条，吸根

sucrose
/ˈsu:krəʊz; US -krəʊs ||; ˈsukros/noun [U] (technical术语) the form of sugar that comes from SUGAR CANE or SUGAR BEET, and which is used to make food sweet 蔗糖 ☞Look at dextrose, fructose, glucose and lactose. 参看dextrose、fructose、glucose及lactose。

suction
/ˈsʌkʃn ||; ˈsʌkʃən/noun [U] the action of removing air or liquid from a space or container so that sth else can be pulled into it or so that two surfaces can stick together 抽吸；使两平面因中间真空而紧贴在一起: A vacuum cleaner works by suction. 真空吸尘器通过抽吸原理操作。

*sudden
/ˈsʌdn ||; ˈsʌdṇ/adj done or happening quickly, or when you do not expect it 突发的；突然的: a sudden decision/change 匆促的决定；突然的变化 ➔suddenly adv Suddenly, everybody started shouting. 突然间，大家都开始大叫。 ➔suddenness noun [U] all of a sudden quickly and unexpectedly 突然；出人意料: All of a sudden the lights went out. 灯突然熄了。 sudden death a way of deciding who wins a game where the score is equal by playing one more point or game 加赛决胜方式（比赛胜负未分而加赛后以先得分者为胜方的决胜方法）

suds
/sʌdz ||; sʌdz/noun [pl] the bubbles that you get when you mix soap and water 肥皂泡沫

sue
/su: ||; su/verb [I,T] sue (sb) (for sth) to go to a court of law and ask for money from sb because he/she has done sth bad to you, or said sth bad about you 控告（以索取赔偿） [T] to sue sb for libel/breach of contract/damages 控告某人诽谤╱违背合约╱要求赔偿损失

suede
/sweɪd ||; swed/noun [U] a type of soft leather which does not have a smooth surface and feels a little like cloth 绒面革；仿麂皮

suet
/ˈsu:ɪt ||; ˈsuɪt/noun [U] a type of hard animal fat that is used in cooking 板油，硬脂肪油（可食用动物脂肪）

*suffer
/ˈsʌfə(r) ||; ˈsʌfɚ/verb
1 [I,T] suffer (from sth);suffer (for sth) to experience sth unpleasant, for example pain, sadness, difficulty, etc 遭受不快之事（如痛苦、悲伤、困难等）: Mary often suffers from severe headaches. 玛丽常患剧烈头痛。 Our troops suffered heavy losses. 我军伤亡惨重。 He made a rash decision and now he's suffering for it. 他轻率作出决定，现在为此受苦。
2 [I] to become worse in quality （质量）变坏，下降: My work is suffering as a result of problems at home. 由于家里的麻烦事，我的工作受到影响。 ➔sufferer noun [C]: asthma sufferers 哮喘患者 ➔suffering noun [U]

sufficient
/səˈfɪʃnt ||; səˈfɪʃənt/adj (formal 正式) as much as is necessary; enough 足够的；充足的: We have sufficient oil reserves to last for three months. 我们的石油储备够用三个月。 [OPP] insufficient 反义词为insufficient ➔sufficiently adv

suffix
/ˈsʌfɪks ||; ˈsʌfɪks/noun [C] (grammar语法) a letter or group of letters that you add at the end of a word, and that changes the meaning of the word or the way it is used 后缀，词尾（置于单词后以改变其意义或用法的字母或一组字母）: To form the noun from the adjective ‘sad’, add the suffix ‘ness’. 要使形容词sad转为名词，可加上后缀ness。 ☞Look at affix ² and prefix. 参看affix^2及prefix。

suffocate
/ˈsʌfəkeɪt ||; ˈsʌfəˌket/verb [I,T] to die because there is no air to breathe; to kill sb in this way （使）窒息而死 ➔suffocating adj ➔suffocation /ˌsʌfəˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌsʌfəˈkeʃən/ noun [U]

suffrage
/ˈsʌfrɪdʒ ||; ˈsʌfrɪdʒ/noun [U] the right to vote in political elections 选举权；投票权: universal suffrage(= the right of all adults to vote) 普选权 women's suffrage 妇女的选举权

*sugar
/ˈʃʊgə(r) ||; ˈʃυgɚ/noun
1 [U] a sweet substance that you get from certain plants 食糖；糖: Do you take sugar in tea? 你喝茶加糖吗？
2 [C] (in a cup of tea, coffee, etc) the amount of sugar that a small spoon can hold; a lump of sugar （放在茶、咖啡等之中）一茶匙糖，一块方糖
3 [C] any of various sweet substances that are found naturally in plants, fruit, etc （植物、水果等中天然存在的）糖: Glucose and fructose are sugars. 葡萄糖和果糖都是糖。

ˈsugar beet
(brit also 英亦作 beet) noun [U] a plant with a large round root that sugar is made from 甜菜

ˈsugar cane
noun [U] a tall tropical plant with thick STEMS(= the long central parts that leaves grow on)that sugar is made from 甘蔗

sugary
/ˈʃʊgəri ||; ˈʃυgərɪ/adj very sweet 非常甜的

*suggest
/səˈdʒest; US səgˈdʒ- ||; səgˈdʒɛst/verb[T]
1 suggest sth (to sb);suggest doing sth;suggest that... to mention a plan or an idea that you have for sb to discuss or consider 建议；提议: Can anybody suggest ways of raising more money? 谁能提出方法来筹集更多的款项？ Tony suggested going out for a walk. 托尼建议出去散步。 Tony suggested (that) we go out for a walk. 托尼建议我们出去散步。 Tony suggested a walk. 托尼建议去散步。
2 suggest sb/sth (for/as sth) to say that a person, thing or place is suitable 认为合适；推荐: Who would you suggest for the job? 你会推荐谁来做这项工作？
You cannot ‘suggest somebody something’. 推荐某人做某事不能说suggest somebody something。 ☞Look at recommend. 参看recommend。
3 to say or show sth in an indirect way 暗示: Are you suggesting the accident was my fault? 你是不是在暗示那次意外是我造成的？

*suggestion
/səˈdʒestʃən; US səgˈdʒ- ||; səgˈdʒɛstʃən/noun
1 [C] a plan or idea that sb mentions for sb else to discuss and consider 建议；提议: May I make a suggestion ? 我可以提一个建议吗？ Has anyone got any suggestions for how to solve this problem? 这个问题怎么解决，谁有什么建议吗？
2 [U] putting an idea into a person's mind; giving advice about what to do 暗示；提示；启发
3 [sing] a slight amount or sign of sth 微量；细微的迹象

suggestive
/səˈdʒestɪv ||; səgˈdʒɛstɪv/adj
1 suggestive (of sth) making you think of sth; being a sign of sth 引起联想的；暗示的: Your symptoms are more suggestive of an allergy than a virus. 你的症状更像过敏，不像病毒。
2 making you think about sex 挑动色情的；性挑逗的: a suggestive dance/remark/posture 挑逗性的舞蹈╱话╱姿势 ➔suggestively adv

suicidal
/ˌsu:ɪˈsaɪdl ||; ˌsuəˈsaɪdḷ/adj
1 (used about a person) wanting to kill himself/herself （指人）想自杀的，有自杀倾向的: to be/feel suicidal 想自杀
2 likely to have a very bad result; extremely dangerous 后果严重的；极其危险的

*suicide
/ˈsu:ɪsaɪd ||; ˈsuəˌsaɪd/noun [U] [C] the act of killing yourself deliberately 自杀: Benjamin has tried to commit suicide several times. 本杰明曾几次试图自杀。 There have been three suicides by university students this year. 今年已有三名大学生自杀。

*suit¹
/su:t ||; sut/noun[C]
1 a formal set of clothes that are made of the same material, consisting of a jacket and either trousers or a skirt 套装；套服；西装: He always wears a suit and tie to work. 他上班总是穿西装，系领带。 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图
2 an article of clothing or set of clothes that you wear for a particular activity 参加某类活动的装束: a tracksuit/swimsuit 田径服；泳装
3 one of the four sets of 13 playing cards( hearts, clubs, diamonds)and(spades) that form a pack （红心、梅花、方块及黑桃四种花色中）同花色的一套牌或一组牌 ☞Look at the note and picture at card. 参看card的注释及插图。
follow suit→FOLLOW
*suit²
/su:t ||; sut/verb [T] (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时)
1 to be convenient or useful for sb/sth 方便；合适: Would Thursday at 9.30 suit you? 星期四9时30分你方便吗？ He will help around the house, but only when it suits him. 他会帮忙做家务，但只是在他方便的时候。
2 (used about clothes, colours, etc) to make you look attractive （指衣服、颜色等）合适，使漂亮: That dress really suits you. 你穿那套衣服真合身。

*suitable
/ˈsu:təbl ||; ˈsutəbḷ/adj suitable (for sb/sth);suitable (to do sth) right or appropriate for sb/sth 合适的；适用的: The film isn't suitable for children. 那部电影不适合儿童观看。 I've got nothing suitable to wear for a wedding. 我没有适合参加婚礼穿的衣服。 [OPP] unsuitable 反义词为unsuitable ➔suitability /ˌsu:təˈbɪləti ||; ˌsutəˈbɪlətɪ/ noun [U] ➔suitably adv

*suitcase
/ˈsu:tkeɪs ||; ˈsutˌkes/ (also case) noun [C] a box with a handle that you use for carrying your clothes, etc in when you are travelling 手提箱 ☞picture at bag 见bag插图

suite
/swi:t ||; swit/noun[C]
1 a set of rooms, especially in a hotel 套房（尤指旅馆的）: the honeymoon/penthouse suite 蜜月╱顶层套房 a suite of rooms/offices 一套房间╱办公室 ☞Look at en suite. 参看en suite。
2 a set of two or more pieces of furniture of the same style or covered in the same material 一套家具: a three-piece suite (= a sofa and two armchairs) 由三件组成的一套家具（一张沙发和两张扶手椅）

suited
/ˈsu:tɪd ||; ˈsutɪd/adj suited (for/to sb/sth) appropriate or right for sb/sth 合适；匹配

sulfur
(US 美) =SULPHUR

sulk
/sʌlk ||; sʌlk/verb [I] to refuse to speak or smile because you want people to know that you are angry about sth 愠怒；生闷气 ➔sulky adj ➔sulkily /-ɪli ||; -ɪlɪ/ adv

sullen
/ˈsʌlən ||; ˈsʌlən/adj looking bad-tempered and not wanting to speak to people 郁郁寡欢的；赌气的；愠怒的: a sullen face/expression/glare 怒容；满脸不高兴；怒目而视 ➔sullenly adv

sulphide
/ˈsʌlfaɪd ||; ˈsʌlfaɪd/ (US 美 sulfide) noun [C,U] a compound of sulphur with another chemical element 硫化物

sulphur
/ˈsʌlfə(r) ||; ˈsʌlfɚ/ (US 美 sulfur) noun [U] (symbol S) a natural yellow substance with a strong unpleasant smell 硫磺

ˌsulphur diˈoxide
(US 美 ˌsulfur diˈoxide) noun [U] (symbol SO₂) a poisonous gas with a strong smell, that is used in industry and causes air POLLUTION 二氧化硫

sulphuric acid
/sʌlˌfjʊərɪk ˈæsɪd ||; sʌlˈfjυrɪk ˈæsɪd/ (US 美 sulfuric acid) noun [U] (symbol H₂SO₄) a strong colourless acid 硫酸

sultan
/ˈsʌltən ||; ˈsʌltṇ/ (also Sultan) noun [C] the ruler in some Muslim countries 苏丹（某些穆斯林国家统治者的称号）

sultana
/sʌlˈtɑ:nə; US -ænə ||; sʌlˈtænə/noun [C] a dried grape with no seeds in it that is used in cooking 一种无籽葡萄干 ☞Look at raisin. 参看raisin。

sultry
/ˈsʌltri ||; ˈsʌltrɪ/adj
1 (used about the weather) hot and uncomfortable （指天气）闷热的，湿热的
2 (used about a woman) behaving in a way that makes her sexually attractive （指女人）性感撩人的

*sum¹
/sʌm ||; sʌm/noun[C]
1 an amount of money 一笔（钱）: The industry has spent huge sums of money modernizing its equipment. 业界已耗费巨额资金使设备现代化。
2 [usu.sing] the sum (of sth) the amount that you get when you add two or more numbers together 和；总数: The sum of two and five is seven. 二加五等于七。
3 a simple problem that involves calculating numbers 算术题: to do sums in your head 心算
sum²
/sʌm ||; sʌm/verb (summing;summed) sum (sth) up to describe in a few words the main ideas of what sb has said or written 总括: To sum up, there are three options here... 概括地说，有三种选择… sum sb/sth up to form an opinion about sb/sth 形成看法: He summed the situation up immediately. 他立即认清了当时的情况。

summary¹
/ˈsʌməri ||; ˈsʌmərɪ/noun [C] (plural summaries) a short description of the main ideas or points of sth but without any details 撮要；摘要: A brief summary of the experiment is given at the beginning of the report. 报告一开头就提出该项试验的内容撮要。 [SYN] précis 同义词为précis ➔summarize(also -ise) /ˈsʌməraɪz ||; ˈsʌməˌraɪz/ verb [I,T] Could you summarize the story so far? 你能否概述到目前为止的故事发展？
summary²
/ˈsʌməri ||; ˈsʌmərɪ/adj (formal 正式) done quickly and without taking time to consider whether it is the right thing to do or following the right process 当场的；即刻的: a summary judgment 当场裁决

*summer
/ˈsʌmə(r) ||; ˈsʌmɚ/noun [C,U] one of the four seasons of the year, after spring and before autumn. Summer is the warmest season of the year 夏天；夏季: Is it very hot here in summer ? 这儿夏天很热吗？ a summer's day 夏日 ☞picture at season 见season插图 ➔summery adj summery weather 夏季的天气 a summery dress 夏装

ˈsummer camp
noun [C,U] (in the US) a place where children go during the summer and take part in sports and other activities 夏令营

ˈsummer school
noun [C,U] courses that are held in the summer at a university or college 暑期学校；暑期班

summertime
/ˈsʌmətaɪm ||; ˈsʌmɚˌtaɪm/noun [U] the season of summer 夏季: It's busy here in the summertime. 夏季这里很热闹。

ˌsumming-ˈup
noun [C] (plural summings-up) a speech in which a judge gives a short description(summary) of what has been said in a court of law before a decision (verdict) is reached 总结性概述（法官于陪审团作出裁决前，对整个案件的证据所作的总结）

summit
/ˈsʌmɪt ||; ˈsʌmɪt/noun[C]
1 the top of a mountain 山顶；顶峰
2 an important meeting or series of meetings between the leaders of two or more countries 高峰会议；首脑会议

summon
/ˈsʌmən ||; ˈsʌmən/verb[T]
1 (formal 正式) to order a person to come to a place 召唤: The boys were summoned to the head teacher's office. 那些男孩子被召往校长室。
2 summon sth (up) to find strength, courage or some other quality that you need even though it is difficult to do so 鼓起（力量、勇气等）: She couldn't summon up the courage to leave him. 她没法鼓起勇气离开他。

summons
/ˈsʌmənz ||; ˈsʌmənz/noun [C] (plural summonses) an order to appear in a court of law （法院的）传票

sumo
/ˈsu:məʊ ||; ˈsumo/ (also ˌsumo ˈwrestling) noun [U] a Japanese style of wrestling, in which the people taking part are extremely large 相扑

*sun¹
/sʌn ||; sʌn/noun
1 the sun [sing] the star that shines in the sky during the day and that gives the earth heat and light 太阳: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west. 太阳从东方升起，在西方落下。 the rays of the sun 太阳光 ☞picture at the solar system 见the solar system插图
2 [sing] [U] light and heat from the sun 太阳的光和热 [sing] Don't sit in the sun too long. 别在阳光下坐太久。 Too much sun can be harmful. 晒太多阳光可能有害。
catch the sun→CATCH¹
sun²
/sʌn ||; sʌn/verb [T] (sunning;sunned)sun yourself sit or lie outside when the sun is shining in order to enjoy the heat 享受日光浴；晒太阳

Sun.
abbr Sunday 星期日；星期天: Sun. 5 April 4月5日星期日

sunbathe
/ˈsʌnbeɪð ||; ˈsʌnˌbeð/verb [I] to take off most of your clothes and sit or lie in the sun in order to make your skin go darker(get a tan) 作日光浴（为使皮肤晒黑） ☞picture on page C8 见C8页插图 ☞Look at bathe. 参看bathe。

sunbeam
/ˈsʌnbi:m ||; ˈsʌnˌbim/noun [C] a RAY(= a line) of sunlight 阳光；日光

sunburn
/ˈsʌnbɜ:n ||; ˈsʌnˌbɝn/noun [U] red painful skin caused by spending too long in the sun 晒伤；晒红的皮肤

sunburned
/ˈsʌnbɜ:nd ||; ˈsʌnˌbɝnd/ (also sunburnt /ˈsʌnbɜ:nt ||; ˈsʌnˌbɝnt/) adj
1 suffering from sunburn 晒伤的；日灼的
2 (used about a person or his/her skin 指人或其皮肤) having an attractive brown colour from being in the sun 晒黑的；晒红的

*Sunday
/ˈsʌndeɪ;-di ||; ˈsʌnde; -dɪ/noun [C,U] (abbr Sun.) the day of the week after Saturday 星期日；星期天 ☞Days of the week are always written with a capital letter. For examples of how to use the days of the week in sentences, look at Monday. 表示星期几的词，开头字母要大写。有关这类词在句子里的示例，参看Monday。

sundial
/ˈsʌndaɪəl ||; ˈsʌnˌdaɪəl/noun [C] a type of clock used in past times that uses the dark shape (shadow) caused by a pointed piece of metal being between the sun and the clock surface to show what the time is 日晷（仪）；日规

ˈsun-drenched
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) having a lot of hot sun 充满阳光的；阳光充足的: sun-drenched Mediterranean beaches 阳光充足的地中海海滩

sundress
/ˈsʌndres ||; ˈsʌnˌdrɛs/noun [C] a dress that does not cover the arms, neck or shoulders, worn in hot weather 太阳裙，背心裙﹙领口低、无袖﹚

ˈsun-dried
adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used especially about food) dried naturally by the heat of the sun ﹙尤指食物﹚晒干的: sun-dried tomatoes 晒干的西红柿

sundry
/ˈsʌndri ||; ˈsʌndrɪ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) of various kinds that are not important enough to be named separately 各种的 all and sundry(informal 非正式) everyone 每一个人；所有的人

sunflower
/ˈsʌnflaʊə(r) ||; ˈsʌnˌflaυɚ/noun [C] a very tall plant with large yellow flowers, often grown for its seeds and their oil, which is used in cooking 向日葵

sung
past participle ofSING

sunglasses
/ˈsʌnglɑ:sɪz ||; ˈsʌnˌglæsɪz/ (also ˌdark ˈglasses) (informal 非正式shades) noun [pl] a pair of glasses with dark glass in them to protect your eyes from bright sunlight 太阳眼镜；墨镜

sunk
past participle ofSINK¹

sunken
/ˈsʌŋkən ||; ˈsʌŋkən/adj
1 below the water 沉没的: a sunken ship 沉船
2 (used about cheeks or eyes) very far into the face as a result of illness or age （指面颊或眼睛）凹陷的
3 at a lower level than the surrounding area 凹的（低于周围）: a sunken bath/garden 沉降式浴缸╱花园

sunlight
/ˈsʌnlaɪt ||; ˈsʌnˌlaɪt/noun [U] the light from the sun 阳光

sunlit
/ˈsʌnlɪt ||; ˈsʌnˌlɪt/adj having bright light from the sun 阳光照耀下的: a sunlit terrace 阳光照耀下的露台

sunny
/ˈsʌni ||; ˈsʌnɪ/adj (sunnier;sunniest) having a lot of light from the sun 晴朗的；阳光充足的: a sunny garden 阳光照耀的花园 a sunny day 晴朗的一天

sunrise
/ˈsʌnraɪz ||; ˈsʌnˌraɪz/noun [U] the time when the sun comes up in the morning 日出（时分）: to get up at sunrise 日出时起床 ☞Look at dawn and sunset. 参看dawn及sunset。

sunroof
/ˈsʌnru:f ||; ˈsʌnˌruf/noun [C] (plural sunroofs) a part of the roof of a car that you can open to let air and light in ﹙汽车车顶可开启的﹚活动顶板，天窗

sunset
/ˈsʌnset ||; ˈsʌnˌsɛt/noun [C,U] the time when the sun goes down in the evening 日落（时分）: The park closes at sunset. 公园在黄昏关闭。 a beautiful sunset 美丽的日落

sunshine
/ˈsʌnʃaɪn ||; ˈsʌnˌʃaɪn/noun [U] heat and light from the sun 太阳的热和光；阳光；日光: We sat down in the sunshine and had lunch. 我们坐在阳光下吃中饭。

sunspot
/ˈsʌnspɒt ||; ˈsʌnˌspɑt/noun [C] a dark area that sometimes appears on the sun's surface （太阳）黑子

sunstroke
/ˈsʌnstrəʊk ||; ˈsʌnˌstrok/noun [U] an illness that is caused by spending too much time in very hot, strong sunlight 日射病；中暑: Keep your head covered or you'll get sunstroke. 要把头遮住，不然你会中暑。

suntan
/ˈsʌntæn ||; ˈsʌnˌtæn/ (also tan) noun [C] when you have a suntan, your skin is darker than usual because you have spent time in the sun （皮肤的）晒黑: to have/get a suntan 皮肤晒黑 suntan oil 防晒油 ➔suntanned(also tanned) adj

ˈsun-up
noun [U] (especially US 尤为美) the time when the sun rises and day begins 日出时分 [SYN]sunrise 同义词为 sunrise

*super
/ˈsu:pə(r) ||; ˈsupɚ/adv adj (informal 非正式)
1 (often used to form compounds) bigger, better, stronger than other things of the same type 尤其地；特别地: He's been super understanding. 他一直非常通情达理。
2 (old-fashioned 旧) very good; wonderful 极好的；绝妙的: We had a super time. 我们过了一段极开心的时光。

super-
/ˈsu:pə(r) ||; ˈsupɚ/prefix
1 (used in adjectives, adverbs and nouns 用于构成形容词、副词及名词) extremely; more or better than normal 极其；超: super-rich 极富 superhuman 超人 superglue 超强力胶
2 (used in nouns and verbs 用于构成名词及动词) above; over 上；上方: superstructure 上层建筑 superimpose 把一物放于另一物之上

superb
/su:ˈpɜ:b ||; sυˈpɝb/adj extremely good, excellent 极好的；绝佳的 ➔superbly adv

supercharged
/ˈsu:pətʃɑ:dʒd ||; ˈsupɚˌtʃɑrdʒd/adj
1 (used about an engine) powerful because it is supplied with air or fuel at a pressure that is higher than normal ﹙发动机﹚增压的，高功率的
2 (informal 非正式) stronger, more powerful or more effective than usual 异常强烈的；格外强劲的；特别有效的: supercharged words, like ‘terrorism’ or ‘eascism’ 诸如 terrorism 或 fascism 等格外强烈的词语

supercilious
/ˌsu:pəˈsɪliəs ||; ˌsupɚˈsɪlɪəs/adj showing that you think that you are better than other people 自负的；高傲的: a supercilious smile 自负的微笑 ➔superciliously adv

supercomputer
/ˈsu:pəkəmpju:tə(r) ||; ˈsupɚkəmˌpjutɚ/noun [C] a powerful computer with a large amount of memory and a very fast central processing unit 超级计算机

superconductor
/ˈsu:pəkəndʌktə(r) ||; ˌsupɚkənˈdʌktɚ/noun [C] a substance which, at very low temperatures, allows electricity to flow completely freely through it 超导体

superficial
/ˌsu:pəˈfɪʃl ||; ˌsupɚˈfɪʃəl/adj
1 not studying or thinking about sth in a deep or complete way （研究或思考）不深入的，不全面的，肤浅的: a superficial knowledge of the subject 对某一问题的皮毛知识
2 only on the surface, not deep 表面的；不深的: a superficial wound/cut/burn 表面损伤╱割伤╱烧伤
3 (used about people) not caring about serious or important things （指人）（对严肃或重要事情）不在乎的；浅薄的: He's a very superficial sort of person. 他是个见识浅陋的人。 ➔superficiality /ˌsu:pəˌfɪʃiˈæləti ||; ˌsupɚˌfɪʃɪˈælətɪ/ noun [U] ➔superficially /-ʃəli ||; -ʃəlɪ/ adv

superfluous
/su:ˈpɜ:fluəs ||; sυˈpɝflυəs/adj more than is wanted; not needed 多余的；过剩的；不需要的

superglue
/ˈsu:pəglu: ||; ˈsupɚˌglu/noun [U] a very strong glue that sticks very quickly and is used in small quantities for repairing things 强力胶

superhero
/ˈsu:pəhɪərəʊ ||; ˈsupɚˌhɪro/noun [C] (plural superheroes) a character in a story, film/movie, etc who has unusual strength or power and uses it to help people; a real person who has done sth unusually brave to help sb ﹙故事、电影等中的﹚超级英雄；﹙现实中的﹚大英雄

superhighway
/ˈsu:pəhaɪweɪ ||; ˈsupɚˌhaɪwe/noun
1 [C] a very wide road on which you can travel very fast 高速公路
2 [sing] (computing 计算机技术) = information superhighway

superhuman
/ˌsu:pəˈhju:mən ||; ˌsupɚˈhjumən/adj greater than is usual for human beings 超乎常人的: superhuman strength 超乎常人的力量

superimpose
/ˌsu:pərɪmˈpəʊz ||; ˌsupərɪmˈpoz/verb [T] superimpose sth (on sth) to put sth on top of sth else so that what is underneath can still be seen （在某物上）迭置另一物: The old street plan was superimposed on a map of the modern city. 那张旧的街道图迭置在一张现代市区图之上。

superintendent
/ˌsu:pərɪnˈtendənt ||; ˌsupərɪnˈtɛndənt/noun[C]
1 a police officer with a high position 警察长: Detective Superintendent Waters 侦缉警察长沃尔特斯
2 a person who looks after a large building （大型建筑物的）管理员

*superior¹
/su:ˈpɪəriə(r) ||; səˈpɪrɪɚ/adj
1 superior (to sb/sth) better than usual or than sb/sth else 优越的；优秀的: He is clearly superior to all the other candidates. 他很明显比其他候选人优秀。 [OPP] inferior 反义词为inferior
2 superior (to sb) having a more important position 职位较高的；上级的: a superior officer 上级官员
3 thinking that you are better than other people 自高自大的；自负的；有优越感的 ➔superiority /su:ˌpɪəriˈɒrəti ||; sυˌpɪrɪˈɔrətɪ/ noun [U]
superior²
/su:ˈpɪəriə(r) ||; sυˈpɪrɪɚ/noun [C] a person of higher position 上司；上级: Report any accidents to your superior. 发生任何事故都要向上级报告。 [OPP] inferior 反义词为inferior

superlative
/suˈpɜ:lətɪv ||; sυˈpɝlətɪv/noun [C] the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses its highest degree （形容词或副词的）最高级: ‘Most beautiful’, ‘best’ and ‘fastest’ are all superlatives. most beautiful、best及fastest都是最高级形容词。

*supermarket
/ˈsu:pəmɑ:kɪt ||; ˈsupɚˌmɑrkɪt/noun [C] a very large shop that sells food, drink, goods used in the home, etc 超级市场

supermodel
/ˈsu:pəmɒdl ||; ˈsupɚˌmɑdḷ/noun [C] a very famous and highly paid fashion model 超级名模

supernatural
/ˌsu:pəˈnætʃrəl ||; ˌsupɚˈnætʃrəl/adj
1 that cannot be explained by the laws of science 超自然的: a creature with supernatural powers 有超自然力量的生物
2 the supernatural noun [sing] events, forces or powers that cannot be explained by the laws of science 超自然物（如事件、力量、威力）: I don't believe in the supernatural. 我不相信有超自然事物。

supernova
/ˌsu:pəˈnəʊvə ||; ˌsupɚˈnovə/noun [C] (plural supernovae /-vi: ||; -vi/or supernovas) (technical术语) a star that suddenly becomes much brighter because it is exploding 超新星 ☞Look at nova. 参看nova。

superpower
/ˈsu:pəpaʊə(r) ||; ˌsupɚˈpaυɚ/noun [C] one of the countries in the world that has very great military or economic power and a lot of influence, for example the US 超级大国 ☞Look at power ¹(4) and world power. 参看power^1(4)及world power。

superscript
/ˈsu:pəskrɪpt ||; ˈsupɚˌskrɪpt/adj (technical 术语) written or printed above the normal line of writing or printing 写﹙或印﹚在正常字符上角的 ➔superscript noun [U]

supersede
/ˌsu:pəˈsi:d ||; ˌsupɚˈsid/verb [T] to take the place of sb/sth which existed or was used before and which has become old-fashioned 取代: Steam trains were gradually superseded by electric trains. 蒸汽火车渐渐被电力火车所取代。

supersonic
/ˌsu:pəˈsɒnɪk ||; ˌsupɚˈsɑnɪk/adj faster than the speed of sound 超音速的；超声波的

superstar
/ˈsu:pəstɑ:(r) ||; ˈsupɚˌstɑr/noun [C] a singer, film star, etc who is very famous and popular 超级明星；巨星

superstition
/ˌsu:pəˈstɪʃn ||; ˌsupɚˈstɪʃən/noun [C,U] a belief that cannot be explained by reason or science 迷信: According to superstition, it's unlucky to walk under a ladder. 根据迷信，从梯子下面走过是不吉利的。 ➔superstitious /ˌsu:pəˈstɪʃəs ||; ˌsupɚˈstɪʃəs/ adj I never do anything important on Friday the 13th -- I'm superstitious. 每逢13日星期五我从不做重要事，我很迷信。

superstore
/ˈsu:pəstɔ:(r) ||; ˈsupɚˌstɔr/noun [C] a very large shop that sells food or a wide variety of one particular type of goods （出售食物或某类货品的）大型商店，大型超级市场

supervise
/ˈsu:pəvaɪz ||; ˌsupɚˈvaɪz/verb [I,T] to watch sb/sth to make sure that work is being done properly or that people are behaving correctly 监督；管理 · Your job is to supervise the building work. 你的工作是监督建造工程。 ➔supervision /ˌsu:pəˈvɪʒn ||; ˌsupɚˈvɪʒən/ noun [U]: Children should not play here without supervision. 孩子若无人照管，不应在此玩耍。 ➔supervisor noun [C]

supper
/ˈsʌpə(r) ||; ˈsʌpɚ/noun [C,U] (old-fashioned 旧) the last meal of the day, either the main meal of the evening or a small meal that you eat quite late, not long before you go to bed 晚餐；夜点心（睡觉之前吃的简便晚餐）

supple
/ˈsʌpl ||; ˈsʌpḷ/adj that bends or moves easily; not stiff 易弯曲的；柔软的: Children are generally far more supple than adults. 一般说来孩子要比大人柔软得多。 ➔suppleness noun [U]

supplement
/ˈsʌplɪmənt ||; ˈsʌpləmənt/noun [C] something that is added to sth else 增补；补充；增刊: You have to pay a small supplement if you travel on a Saturday. 在星期六旅行你得付一小笔附加费。 supplement /ˈsʌplɪment ||; ˈsʌpləˌmɛnt/ verb [T] supplement sth (with sth) to supplement your diet with vitamins 在饮食以外补充维生素 ➔supplementary /ˌsʌplɪˈmentri; US -terɪ ||; ˌsʌpləˈmɛntərɪ/ adj supplementary exercises at the back of the book 书后的补充练习

supplier
/səˈplaɪə(r) ||; səˈplaɪɚ/noun [C] a person or company that supplies goods 供应者；供货商

*supply¹
/səˈplaɪ ||; səˈplaɪ/verb [T] (present participle supplying third person singular present supplies;past tense past participle supplied)supply sth (to sb);supply sb (with sth) to give or provide sth 提供；供应: The farmer supplies eggs to the surrounding villages. 那个农民向邻近的村庄供应蛋类。 He supplies the surrounding villages with eggs. 他向邻近的村庄供应蛋类。
supply²
/səˈplaɪ ||; səˈplaɪ/noun [C] (plural supplies) a store or amount of sth that is provided or available to be used 供应；供应量: The water supply was contaminated. 水供应受到污染。 Food supplies were dropped by helicopter. 食品由直升机空投。 In many parts of the country water is in short supply (= there is not much of it). 国内许多地方供水不足。

supˌply and deˈmand
noun [U] (in economics 经济学) the relationship between the amount of goods or services that are available and the amount that people want to buy, especially when this controls prices 供求关系: the law of supply and demand 供求关系律

*support¹
/səˈpɔ:t ||; səˈpɔrt/verb[T]
1 to help sb by saying that you agree with him/her/it, and sometimes giving practical help such as money 支持；支援；资助: Several large companies are supporting the project. 几家大公司在资助这项工程。 Which political party do you support? 你支持哪一个政党？
2 to give sb the money he/she needs for food, clothes, etc 赡养；供养；扶养: Jim has to support two children from his previous marriage. 吉姆得抚养和前妻所生的两个孩子。
3 to carry the weight of sb/sth 承重；支撑: Large columns support the roof. 几根巨柱支撑着屋顶。
4 to show that sth is true or correct 证明；肯定: What evidence do you have to support what you say? 你有什么证据支持你的话？
5 to have a particular sports team as your favourite 支持或拥护某体育队伍: Which football team do you support? 你支持哪一支足球队？
*support²
/səˈpɔ:t ||; səˈpɔrt/noun
1 [U] support (for sb/sth) help and encouragement that you give to a person or thing 帮助；支持；鼓励: public support for the campaign 公众对这次运动的支持 Steve spoke in support of the proposal. 斯蒂夫发言支持这项建议。
2 [C,U] something that carries the weight of sb/sth or holds sth firmly in place 支撑物；支架；支柱: a roof support 屋顶支柱 She held on to his arm for support. 她抓住他的胳膊稳住身子。
3 [U] money to buy food, clothes, etc 生活费: She has no job, no home and no means of support. 她没有工作，没有地方住，生活没有着落。
moral support→MORAL¹

supporter
/səˈpɔ:tə(r) ||; səˈpɔrtɚ/noun [C] a person who supports a political party, sports team, etc （政党、体育队伍等的）支持者，拥护者: football supporters 足球迷

supportive
/səˈpɔ:tɪv ||; səˈpɔrtɪv/adj giving help or support to sb in a difficult situation （困境中）予以帮助或支持的: Everyone was very supportive when I lost my job. 我失业以后人人都伸出援手。

*suppose
/səˈpəʊz ||; səˈpoz/verb[T]
1 to think that sth is probable 认为，以为（某事是可能的）: What do you suppose could have happened? 你认为可能发生了什么事？ I don't suppose that they're coming now. 我想他们不会来了。
2 to pretend that sth will happen or is true 假设；假定: Suppose you won the lottery. What would you do? 假定你彩票中了奖，你会做什么？
3 used to make a suggestion, request or statement less strong （用于以婉转的口气提出建议、请求或发表声明）: I don't suppose you'd lend me your car tonight, would you? 我认为你今晚不会把车子借给我，对吗？
4 used when you agree with sth, but are not very happy about it （表示勉强同意）: ‘Can we give Andy a lift?’ ‘Yes, I suppose so, if we must.’ “我们送安迪一程好吗？”“好的，一定要送就送吧。”
be supposed to do sth
1 to be expected to do sth or to have to do sth 应该或必须做某事: The train was supposed to arrive ten minutes ago. 火车应该在十分钟前就到达了。 This is secret and I'm not supposed to talk about it. 这是秘密，我不应该谈。
2 (informal 非正式) to be considered or thought to be sth 被认为是: This is supposed to be the oldest building in the city. 这被认为是该市最古老的建筑物。

supposedly
/səˈpəʊzɪdli ||; səˈpozɪdlɪ/adv according to what many people believe 根据许多人的看法；一般认为

supposing
/səˈpəʊzɪŋ ||; səˈpozɪŋ/ conj if sth happens or is true; what if 如果；假定: Supposing the plan goes wrong, what will we do then? 如果计划出错，我们应该怎么办？

supposition
/ˌsʌpəˈzɪʃn ||; ˌsʌpəˈzɪʃən/noun [C,U] an idea that a person thinks is true but which has not been shown to be true 假设

suppress
/səˈpres ||; səˈprɛs/verb[T]
1 to stop sth by using force 用强力阻止；镇压
2 to stop sth from being seen or known 隐瞒: to suppress the truth 隐瞒真相
3 to stop yourself from expressing your feelings, etc 压抑；按捺: to suppress laughter/a yawn 忍住笑╱呵欠 ➔suppression /səˈpreʃn ||; səˈprɛʃən/ noun [U]

suppressant
/səˈpresnt ||; səˈprɛsənt/noun [C] a drug that is used to prevent one of the body's functions from working normally ﹙对人体功能的﹚遏抑剂: an appetite suppressant 食欲遏抑剂

supremacist
/su:ˈpreməsɪst ||; suˈprɛməsɪst/noun [C] a person who believes that his/her own race is better than others and should be in power 种族优越论者: a white supremacist 白人至上主义者

supremacy
/su:ˈpreməsi ||; suˈprɛməsɪ/noun [U] supremacy (over sb/sth) the state of being the most powerful （权力）最高，至高无上

supreme
/su:ˈpri:m ||; suˈprim/adj the highest or greatest possible 最高的；至上的

supremely
/su:ˈpri:mli ||; suˈprimlɪ/adv extremely 极其

Supt
abbr (in the police force 警察部队) Superintendent 警官

surcharge
/ˈsɜ:tʃɑ:dʒ ||; ˈsɝˌtʃɑrdʒ/noun [C] an extra amount of money that you have to pay for sth 额外费用；附加费

*sure
/ʃɔ:(r); US ʃʊər ||; ʃυr/adj adv
1 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) having no doubt about sth; certain 肯定；有把握: You must be sure of your facts before you make an accusation. 提出指责之前必须先弄清事实。 I'm not sure what to do next. 我不敢肯定接下来该怎么办。 Craig was sure that he'd made the right decision. 克雷格深信自己作出了正确的决定。 I think I had my bag when I got off the bus but I'm not sure. 我觉得我下车时是带着提包的，但我不敢肯定。
2 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) sure of sth;sure to do sth that you will definitely get or do, or that will definitely happen 必定获得、做或发生: If you go and see them you can be sure of a warm welcome. 如果你去探望他们，你肯定会受到热烈欢迎。 If you work hard you are sure to pass the exam. 如果你肯用功，考试一定及格。 [OPP] unsure 反义词为unsure
3 that you can be certain of 包管: A noise like that is a sure sign of engine trouble. 发出那种噪音包管是发动机有毛病的迹象。
4 (informal 非正式) used to say ‘yes’ to sb （用于作肯定回答）可以，好: ‘Can I have a look at your newspaper?’ ‘Sure.’ “我看一下你的报纸可以吗？”“可以。”
Be sure to do sth Don't forget to do sth 不要忘记做某事: Be sure to write and tell me what happens. 别忘了来信告诉我那边的事。 for sure without doubt 肯定；毫无疑问: Nobody knows for sure what happened. 没有人确切知道出了什么事。 make sure
1 to find out whether sth is in a particular state or has been done 确定；查明: I must go back and make sure I closed the window. 我必须回去看看我有没有关上窗户。
2 to take the action that is necessary 确保: Make sure you are back home by 11 o'clock. 你一定要在11点之前回家。
sure enough as was expected 一如所料: I expected him to be early, and sure enough he arrived five minutes before the others. 我预计他会早些来，果然他比别人早到五分钟。 sure of yourself confident about your opinions, or about what you can do 有信心；自信 sure (thing) (US 美) (informal 非正式) yes 可以；好: ‘Can I borrow this book?’ ‘Sure thing.’ “我可以借这本书吗？”“可以。”

ˈsure-fire
adj (informal 非正式) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) certain to be successful or to happen as you expect 必定成功的；肯定会发生的: a sure-fire success 定能获得的成功 Bad behaviour is a sure-fire way of getting people's attention. 恶劣行为肯定会惹人注意的。

*surely
/ˈʃɔ:li; US ˈʃʊərlɪ ||; ˈʃυrlɪ/adv
1 without doubt 无疑: This will surely cause problems. 这一定会带来问题。
2 used for expressing surprise at sb else's opinions, plans, actions, etc （表示惊讶）: Surely you're not going to walk home in this rain? 下这么大雨，你怎么走路回家呀？ ‘Meena's looking for another job.’ ‘Surely not.’ “米纳正在找别的工作。”“不会吧。”
3 (US 美) (informal 非正式) yes; of course 可以；当然

surety
/ˈʃʊərəti ||; ˈʃurətɪ/noun [C,U] (plural sureties)
1 money given as a promise that you will pay a debt, appear in court, etc 保证金: She was granted bail with a surety of $500. 她交了 500 元保证金，获得保释。 They have offered a large amount of money as surety. 他们提供了一大笔钱作为保证金。
2 a person who accepts responsibility if sb else does not pay a debt, appear in court, etc 保证人；担保人: to act as surety for sb 为某人做担保人 She has promised to stand surety for $5,000.她已许诺担保5 000元。

surf¹
/sɜ:f ||; sɝf/noun [U] the white part on the top of waves in the sea 拍岸浪；浪花
surf²
/sɜ:f ||; sɝf/verb [I] to stand or lie on a special board(a surfboard)and ride on a wave towards the beach 冲浪（运动员在冲浪板上驭浪前行） surf the net to use the Internet 浏览因特网；上网

*surface¹
/ˈsɜ:fɪs ||; ˈsɝfɪs/noun
1 [C] the outside part of sth （物体的）表面: the earth's surface 地球表面 Teeth have a hard surface called enamel. 牙齿有一层坚硬的表面，叫做珐琅质。 This tennis court has a very uneven surface. 这网球场的地面起伏不平。
2 the surface [sing] the top part of an area of water 水面: leaves floating on the surface of a pond 浮在池塘水面上的树叶
3 [C] the flat top part of a piece of furniture, used for working on （家具的）台面: a work surface 工作台 kitchen surfaces 厨房操作台
4 [sing] the qualities of sb/sth that you see or notice, that are not hidden 表面；外观: Everybody seems very friendly but there are a lot of tensions below / beneath the surface. 每个人似乎都很友善，但在这表面之下关系却十分紧张。
surface²
/ˈsɜ:fɪs ||; ˈsɝfɪs/verb
1 [I] to come up to the surface of water 浮出水面
2 [I] to suddenly appear again or become obvious after having been hidden for a while （隐没一段时间后）再度出现，变得明显: All the old arguments surfaced again in the discussion. 所有旧论点都在这次讨论中再度出现。
3 (informal 非正式) to wake up or get up after being asleep （睡眠后）醒来，起床
4 [T] to cover the surface of sth, especially a road or a path 覆盖表面（尤指路面）

ˈsurface mail
noun [U] letters, packages, etc that go by road, rail or sea, not by air 平邮 ☞Look at airmail. 参看airmail。

surfboard
/ˈsɜ:fbɔ:d ||; ˈsɝfˌbɔrd/noun [C] a long narrow board used for the sport of riding on waves(surfing) 冲浪板

surfeit
/ˈsɜ:fɪt ||; ˈsɝfɪt/noun [sing] (written 书面语)a surfeit (of sth) too much of sth 过量

surfer
/ˈsɜ:fə(r) ||; ˈsɝfɚ/noun [C] a person who rides on waves standing on a special board (a surfboard) 冲浪运动员

surfing
/ˈsɜ:fɪŋ ||; ˈsɝfɪŋ/noun[U]
1 the sport of riding on waves while standing on a narrow board(a surfboard) 冲浪运动: to go surfing 去作冲浪运动
2 the activity of looking at different things on the Internet in order to find sth interesting （在因特网上）浏览

surge
/sɜ:dʒ ||; sɝdʒ/noun [C] [usu.sing] a surge (of/in sth)
1 a sudden strong movement in a particular direction by a large number of people or things 奔腾；涌: a surge forward 涌向前 a surge (= an increase) in the demand for electricity 电力需求激增
2 a sudden strong feeling 一种强烈的感觉 surge verb [I]: The crowd surged forward. 人群涌向前。

*surgeon
/ˈsɜ:dʒən ||; ˈsɝdʒən/noun [C] a doctor who performs medical operations (surgery) 外科医生；外科医师: a brain surgeon 脑外科医生

*surgery
/ˈsɜ:dʒəri ||; ˈsɝdʒərɪ/noun (plural surgeries)
1 [U] medical treatment in which your body is cut open so that part of it can be removed or repaired 外科；手术: to undergo surgery 接受外科手术 ☞Look at plastic surgery and operation. 参看plastic surgery及operation。
2 [C,U] the place or time when a doctor or dentist sees patients 诊所；应诊时间: Surgery hours are from 9.00 to 11.30. 应诊时间是9点至11点30分。

surgical
/ˈsɜ:dʒɪkl ||; ˈsɝdʒɪkḷ/adj connected with medical operations 与外科手术有关的；外科的: surgical instruments 外科手术器械 ➔surgically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

surly
/ˈsɜ:li ||; ˈsɝlɪ/adj unfriendly and rude 不友好的；粗野的: a surly expression 不友好的神情

surmount
/səˈmaʊnt ||; sɚˈmaυnt/verb [T] to deal successfully with a problem or difficulty 克服（问题或困难） ☞Look at insurmountable. 参看insurmountable。

*surname
/ˈsɜ:neɪm ||; ˈsɝˌnem/ (also last name) noun [C] the name that you share with other people in your family 姓；姓氏: ‘What's your surname?’ ‘Jones.’ “贵姓？”“琼斯。” ☞Look at the note at name. 参看name的注释。

surpass
/səˈpɑ:s; US -ˈpæs ||; sɚˈpæs/verb [T] (formal 正式) to do sth better than sb/sth else or better than expected 超过；胜过；优于: The success of the film surpassed all expectations. 这部影片比预期的要成功。

surplus
/ˈsɜ:pləs ||; ˈsɝpləs/noun [C,U] an amount that is extra or more than you need 盈余；剩余；过剩: the food surplus in Western Europe 西欧国家食物过剩 surplus adj They sell their surplus grain to other countries. 他们把剩余的粮食卖给别的国家。

*surprise¹
/səˈpraɪz ||; sɚˈpraɪz/noun
1 [U] the feeling that you have when sth happens that you do not expect 惊奇；惊讶: They looked up in surprise when she walked in. 她走进来时他们吃惊地抬起头来。 To my surprisethey all agreed with me. 想不到他们都同意我的看法。
2 [C] something that you did not expect or know about 意外的事；想不到的事: What a pleasant surprise to see you again! 再次见到你，真令人惊喜！ The news came as a complete surprise. 这个消息完全出乎意料之外。 a surprise visit/attack/party 出人意表的访问╱攻击╱聚会
take sb by surprise to happen or do sth when sb is not expecting it 出人意表地发生或做某事；使措手不及
surprise²
/səˈpraɪz ||; sɚˈpraɪz/verb[T]
1 to make sb feel surprised 使惊奇或感到意外: It wouldn't surprise me if you get the job. 如果你获得那份工作，我不会感到意外。
2 to attack or find sb suddenly and unexpectedly 突然袭击；突然发现；撞见

*surprised
/səˈpraɪzd ||; səˈpraɪzd/adj feeling or showing surprise 惊奇的；惊讶的: I was very surprised to see Cara there. I thought she was still abroad. 见到卡拉在那里我真诧异，我以为她还在国外。

*surprising
/səˈpraɪzɪŋ ||; səˈpraɪzɪŋ/adj that causes surprise 令人惊奇的: It's surprising how many adults can't read or write. 有这么多成人文盲真是令人意想不到。 ➔surprisingly adv Surprisingly few people got the correct answer. 答对的人少得出奇。

surreal
/səˈri:əl ||; səˈriəl/ (also surrealistic /səˌri:əˈlɪstɪk ||; səˌriəlˈɪstɪk/) adj very strange; with images mixed together in a strange way like in a dream 超现实的；荒诞的；梦幻般的: a surreal film/painting/situation 超现实主义电影；超现实主义绘画；离奇的情况

surrealism
/səˈri:əlɪzəm ||; səˈriəˌlɪzəm/noun [U] a 20th century style and movement in art and literature in which images and events that are not connected are put together in a strange or impossible way, like a dream, to try to express what is happening deep in the mind 超现实主义，超现实主义派﹙20世纪文艺流派，以离奇怪诞的方式把无关联的形象和事情串连在一起﹚ ➔surrealist adj, noun [C]: a surrealist painter/painting 超现实主义画家/绘画

surrender
/səˈrendə(r) ||; səˈrɛndɚ/verb
1 [I,T] surrender (yourself) (to sb) to stop fighting and admit that you have lost 投降；屈服: The hijackers eventually surrendered themselves to the police. 劫机者终于向警方投降。 [SYN] yield 同义词为yield
2 [T] (formal 正式)surrender sb/sth (to sb) to give sb/sth to sb else 交出；放弃: The police ordered them to surrender their weapons. 警方命令他们交出武器。 surrender noun [C,U]

surreptitious
/ˌsʌrəpˈtɪʃəs ||; ˌsʌrəpˈtɪʃəs/adj done secretly 暗中进行的: I had a surreptitious look at what she was writing. 我偷偷看了一眼她在写些什么。 ➔surreptitiously adv

surrogate
/ˈsʌrəgət ||; ˈsɝəˌget/noun [C] adj (a person or thing) that takes the place of sb/sth else 替代者；替代物: a surrogate mother (= a woman who has a baby and gives it to another woman who cannot have children) 代孕母亲（代不育女子生育的女子）

*surround
/səˈraʊnd ||; səˈraυnd/verb [T] surround sb/sth (by/with sth) to be or go all around sb/sth 包围；围住: The garden is surrounded by a high wall. 花园四周有高高的围墙。 Troops have surrounded the parliament building. 军队包围了议会大厦。

surrounding
/səˈraʊndɪŋ ||; səˈraυndɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) that is near or around sth 邻近的；附近的

surroundings
/səˈraʊndɪŋz ||; səˈraυndɪŋz/noun [pl] everything that is near or around you; the place where you live 四周；生活环境: to live in pleasant surroundings 生活在舒适的环境中 animals living in their natural surroundings (= not in zoos) 生活在自然环境中的动物 ☞Look at environment. 参看environment。

surveillance
/sɜ:ˈveɪləns ||; sɚˈveləns/noun [U] the careful watching of sb who may have done sth wrong 监视: The building is protected by surveillance cameras. 这座大楼有监视摄像机的保护。

survey¹
/ˈsɜ:veɪ ||; ˈsɝve/noun[C]
1 a study of the opinions, behaviour, etc of a group of people （民意等的）调查: Surveys have shown that more and more people are getting into debt. 调查显示，越来越多人负债。 to carry out/conduct/do a survey 作民意调查
2 the action of examining an area of land and making a map of it 测绘地形；测量
3 the action of examining a building in order to find out if it is in good condition 勘查建筑物
survey²
/səˈveɪ ||; sɚˈve/verb[T]
1 to look carefully at the whole of sth 仔细观察全貌: We stood at the top of the hill and surveyed the countryside. 我们站在山顶俯视郊野。
2 to carefully measure and make a map of an area of land （对土地的）勘测，查勘，测量
3 to examine a building carefully in order to find out if it is in good condition 查勘建筑物

surveyor
/səˈveɪə(r) ||; sɚˈveɚ/noun[C]
1 a person whose job is to examine a building to make sure its structure is in good condition or to examine and record the details of a piece of land （房产）检视员；（土地）测量员，勘测员 ☞Look at quantity surveyor. 参看quantity surveyor。
2 (Brit 英) an official whose job is to check that sth is accurate, of good quality, etc 检验员；鉴定员

surˈvival kit
noun [C] a set of emergency equipment, including food, medical supplies and tools 救生包﹙装有食物、药物、工具等﹚

*survive
/səˈvaɪv ||; sɚˈvaɪv/verb
1 [I,T] to continue to live or exist in or after a difficult or dangerous situation 存活；生还: More than a hundred people were killed in the crash and only five passengers survived. 坠机事件中超过一百人丧生，只有五名乘客生还。 How can she survive on such a small salary? 她靠这么微薄的薪金怎么活得下去呢？ [T] to survive a plane crash 在坠机事故中生还 Not many buildings survived the bombing. 轰炸以后建筑物所剩无几。
2 [T] to live longer than sb/sth 比…活得久或生存时间长 ➔survival /səˈvaɪvl ||; sɚˈvaɪvḷ/ noun [U]: A heart transplant was his only chance of survival. 他只有通过心脏移植才有可能活下来。 ➔survivor noun [C]: There were five survivors of the crash. 坠机事件中有五个人生还。

susceptible
/səˈseptəbl ||; səˈsɛptəbḷ/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) susceptible to sth easily influenced, damaged or affected by sb/sth 易受影响；易被损坏: People in a new country are highly susceptible to illness. 初到外国的人极容易得病。

sushi
/ˈsu:ʃi ||; ˈsuʃɪ/noun [U] a Japanese dish of small cakes of cold cooked rice, flavoured with vinegar and served with raw fish, etc on top 寿司: a sushi bar 寿司店

*suspect¹
/səˈspekt ||; səˈspɛkt/verb[T]
1 to believe that sth may happen or be true, especially sth bad 相信，猜想（某事可能发生或是真的，尤指坏事）: The situation is worse than we first suspected. 情况比我们起初猜想的还要坏。 Nobody suspected that she was thinking of leaving. 没有人想到她有离开的念头。 ☞Look at unsuspecting. 参看unsuspecting。
2 to not be sure that you can trust sb or believe sth 怀疑；不信任: I rather suspect his motives for offering to help. 我很怀疑他提出帮忙的动机。
3 suspect sb (of sth/of doing sth) to believe that sb is guilty of sth 怀疑某人（做坏事）: I suspect Laura of taking the money. 我怀疑劳拉拿走这笔钱。 She strongly suspected that he was lying. 她很怀疑他在说谎。 ☞noun suspicion 名词为suspicion
suspect²
/ˈsʌspekt ||; ˈsʌspɛkt/noun [C] a person who is thought to be guilty of a crime 嫌疑犯: The suspects are being questioned by police. 嫌疑犯正受到警方盘问。
suspect³
/ˈsʌspekt ||; ˈsʌspɛkt/adj possibly not true or not to be trusted 可疑的: to have suspect motives 有可疑的动机 a suspect parcel (= that may contain a bomb) 可疑的包裹

suspend
/səˈspend ||; səˈspɛnd/verb[T]
1 suspend sth (from sth) (by/on sth) to hang sth from sth else 悬挂；吊: The huge skeleton is suspended from the museum's ceiling on chains. 那巨大的骨骼用链子悬挂在博物馆的天花板上。
2 to stop or delay sth for a time 暂停；推迟: Some rail services were suspended during the strike. 罢工期间，部份火车服务暂停。 The young man was given a suspended sentence (= he will not go to prison unless he commits another crime). 那个年轻人获得缓刑。
3 suspend sb (from sth) to send sb away from his/her school, job, position, etc for a period of time, usually as a punishment 使暂时停学或停职（通常作为处分）: He was suspended from school for a week for stealing. 他因偷窃而被停学一周。 ☞noun suspension 名词为suspension

suspender
/səˈspendə(r) ||; səˈspɛndɚ/noun
1 [C] [usu.pl] (Brit 英) a short piece of elastic that women use to hold up their STOCKINGS 吊袜带（女性用于吊长袜）
2 suspenders [pl] (US 美) =BRACE¹(2)

suspense
/səˈspens ||; səˈspɛns/noun [U] the feeling of excitement or worry that you have when you feel sth is going to happen, when you are waiting for news, etc 悬念；挂虑: Don't keep us in suspense. Tell us what happened. 别让我们着急了，告诉我们发生了什么事吧。

suspension
/səˈspenʃn ||; səˈspɛnʃən/noun
1 [C,U] not being allowed to do your job or go to school for a period of time, usually as a punishment 暂时停学或停职（通常作为处分）: suspension on full pay 暂停支全薪
2 [U] delaying sth for a period of time 暂停；延缓 ☞verb suspend 动词为suspend
3 the suspension [U] the parts that are connected to the wheels of a car, etc that make it more comfortable to ride in （汽车等的）悬挂装置
4 [C,U] (technical术语) a liquid with very small pieces of solid matter floating in it; the state of such a liquid 悬浮液；（液体）悬浮状态

suˈspension bridge
noun [C] a bridge that hangs from thick steel wires that are supported by towers at each end 悬索桥；吊桥

*suspicion
/səˈspɪʃn ||; səˈspɪʃən/noun
1 [C,U] a feeling or belief that sth is wrong or that sb has done sth wrong 疑心；怀疑: I always treat smiling politicians with suspicion. 对于笑容满面的政客，我总是疑心重重。 She was arrested on suspicion of murder. 她涉嫌谋杀被捕。 He is under suspicion of being involved in drug smuggling. 他被怀疑参与毒品走私。
2 [C] a feeling that sth may happen or be true 猜想: I have a suspicion that he's forgotten he invited us. 我猜想他已经忘了他邀请过我们。 ☞verb suspect 动词为suspect

*suspicious
/səˈspɪʃəs ||; səˈspɪʃəs/adj
1 suspicious (of/about sb/sth) feeling that sb has done sth wrong, dishonest or illegal 不信任的；怀疑的: We became suspicious of his behaviour and alerted the police. 他的举止引起我们怀疑，我们报告了警方。
2 that makes you feel that sth is wrong, dishonest or illegal 可疑的: The old man died in suspicious circumstances. 那个老人在可疑的情况下死亡。 It's very suspicious that she was not at home on the evening of the murder. 谋杀案发生当晚她不在家，此点非常可疑。 a suspicious-looking person 形迹可疑的人 ➔suspiciously adv to behave suspiciously 形迹可疑

sustain
/səˈsteɪn ||; səˈsten/verb[T]
1 to keep sb/sth alive or healthy 维持（生命或健康）: Oxygen sustains life. 氧气维持生命。
2 to make sth continue for a long period of time without becoming less 使长时间持续或保持: It's hard to sustain interest for such a long time. 要维持这样长久的兴趣是件难事。
3 (formal 正式) to experience sth bad 遭受，经历（不好的事）: to sustain damage/an injury/a defeat 受到损害；受伤；遭受挫败

sustainable
/səˈsteɪnəbl ||; səsˈtenəbḷ/adj
1 involving the use of natural products and energy in a way that does not harm the environment （在利用自然资源及能源时）不损害环境的: sustainable forest management 不损害环境的森林管理
2 that can continue or be continued for a long time 可持续的 [OPP] unsustainable 反义词为unsustainable

suture
/ˈsu:tʃə(r) ||; ˈsutʃɚ/noun [C] (medical 医学) a stitch or stitches made when sewing up a wound, especially after an operation ﹙伤口的﹚缝合，缝线 ➔suture verb [T]

svelte
/svelt ||; svɛlt/adj (used about a person, especially a woman) thin in a graceful and attractive way ﹙尤指女子﹚苗条的

SW
abbr
1 =SHORT WAVE ☞picture at wavelength 见wavelength插图
2 south-west(ern) 西南方（的）: SW Australia 澳大利亚西南部

swab
/swɒb ||; swɑb/noun[C]
1 a piece of soft material used by a doctor, nurse, etc for cleaning a place where your body has been injured or cut, or for taking a substance from your body to test it 药签；拭子
2 an act of taking a substance from sb's body for testing, with a swab 用拭子取化验标本: to take a throat swab 用拭子取喉道的化验标本 swab verb [T] (present participle swabbing;past tense past participle swabbed)

swagger
/ˈswægə(r) ||; ˈswægɚ/verb [I] to walk in a way that shows that you are too confident or proud 大摇大摆地走 swagger noun [sing]

*swallow
/ˈswɒləʊ ||; ˈswɑlo/verb
1 [T] to make food, drink, etc go down your throat to your stomach 吞下；咽下: It's easier to swallow pills if you take them with water. 用水吞服比较容易把药丸咽下去。 ☞picture at lick 见lick插图
2 [I] to make a movement in your throat, often because you are afraid or surprised, etc （因害怕或惊奇等）咽口水，做吞咽动作: She swallowed hard and tried to speak, but nothing came out. 她用力咽口水，试图说话，但说不出半句来。
3 [T] to accept or believe sth too easily （轻易）接受，相信: You shouldn't swallow everything they tell you! 你不应该轻信他们所说的一切！
4 [T] to accept an insult, etc without complaining 忍受（侮辱等）；忍气吞声: I find her criticisms very hard to swallow. 我觉得她的批评难以接受。
5 [T] swallow sth (up) to use all of sth, especially money 耗尽（尤指钱）: The rent swallows up most of our monthly income. 房租耗掉了我们每月的大部分收入。 swallow noun [C]
hard to swallow→HARD¹

ˈswallow hole
noun [C] (in geography 地理学) a large hole in the ground that a river flows into, created over a long period of time by water that has fallen as rain 灰岩坑；石灰坑 ☞picture at limestone 见limestone插图

swam
past tense ofSWIM

swamp¹
/swɒmp ||; swɑmp/noun [C,U] an area of soft wet land （一片）沼泽
swamp²
/swɒmp ||; swɑmp/verb[T]
1 to cover or fill sth with water 使充满水；淹没: The fishing boat was swamped by enormous waves. 渔船被巨浪淹没。
2 swamp sb/sth (with sth) (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to give sb so much of sth that he/she cannot deal with it 使不胜负荷: We've been swamped with applications for the job. 工作申请书多得使我们穷于应付。 [SYN] inundate 同义词为inundate

swan
/swɒn ||; swɑn/noun [C] a large, usually white, bird with a very long neck that lives on lakes and rivers 天鹅 ☞picture at duck 见duck插图

swanky
/ˈswæŋki ||; ˈswæŋkɪ/ (swankier; swankiest) (also swank /swæŋk ||; swæŋk/)adj (informal 非正式) fashionable and expensive in a way that is intended to impress people 摆阔的；时髦且豪华的: a swanky hotel/car 时髦豪华的宾馆/汽车

*swap
/swɒp ||; swɑp/ (also swop) verb [I,T] (swapping;swapped)swap (sth) (with sb);swap A for B to give sth for sth else; to exchange 交换；掉换: When we finish these books shall we swap (= you have my book and I'll have yours)? 这些书我们各自看完后交换来看好不好？ Would you swap seats with me? 你跟我换一下座位好不好？ I'd swap my job for hers any day. 我愿随时和她交换工作。 swap noun [sing] Let's do a swap. 我们交换吧。 change/swap places (with sb)→PLACE¹

swarm¹
/swɔ:m ||; swɔrm/noun[C]
1 a large group of insects, especially bees, moving around together 一大群移动中的昆虫（尤指蜜蜂）: a swarm of bees/locusts/flies 一大群蜜蜂╱蝗虫╱苍蝇
2 a large number of people together 一大群人；一大堆人
swarm²
/swɔ:m ||; swɔrm/verb [I] to fly or move in large numbers 成群飞行或移动；蜂拥 swarm with sb/sth to be too crowded or full 挤满（人或物）

swash
/swɒʃ ||; swɑʃ/noun [sing] the flow of water up the beach after a wave has broken （水在海滩上的）冲刷 ☞Look at backwash. 参看backwash。 ☞picture at wave 见wave插图

swashbuckling
/ˈswɒʃbʌklɪŋ ||; ˈswɑʃˌbʌklɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used especially about films/movies) set in the past and full of action, adventure, fighting with swords, etc ﹙尤指电影﹚表现惊险打斗的，有传奇历险情节的: a swashbuckling tale of adventure on the high seas 公海上的传奇历险故事 the swashbuckling hero of Hollywood epics 好莱坞史诗片中的传奇英雄

SWAT
/swɒt ||; swɑt/ (also SWAT team) noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) (in the US) a group of police officers who are especially trained to deal with violent situations. SWAT stands for ‘Special Weapons and Tactics’. 特警队

swat
/swɒt ||; swɑt/verb [T] (swatting;swatted) to hit sth, especially an insect, with sth flat 猛击，重拍（尤指昆虫）

swatch
/swɒtʃ ||; swɑtʃ/noun [C] a small piece of fabric used to show people what a larger piece would look or feel like ﹙织物的小块﹚布样，样品

sway
/sweɪ ||; swe/verb
1 [I] to move slowly from side to side 摇晃；摇摆；摆动: The trees were swaying in the wind. 树在风中摇摆。
2 [T] to influence sb 影响；左右: Many people were swayed by his convincing arguments. 许多人听了他有力的论据都受到影响。

*swear
/sweə(r) ||; swɛr/verb (past tense swore /swɔ:(r) ||; swɔr/ past participle sworn /swɔ:n ||; swɔrn/)
1 [I] swear (at sb/sth) to use rude or bad language 咒骂: He hit his thumb with the hammer and swore loudly. 他不小心用铁锤打中了拇指，就大声咒骂起来。 There's no point in swearing at the car just because it won't start! 车子开不动，你咒骂也没用。 ☞Look at curse. 参看curse。
2 [I,T] swear (to do sth);swear that... to make a serious promise 发誓；宣誓；起誓: When you give evidence in court you have to swear to tell the truth. 在法庭作证前必须宣誓所言属实。 Will you swear not to tell anyone? 你可以发誓不告诉任何人吗？
swear by sth to believe completely in the value of sth 极其信赖某事物的价值 swear sb in (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to make sb say officially that he/she will accept the responsibility of a new position 使宣誓就职: The President will be sworn in next week. 总统将于下星期宣誓就职。

ˈswear word
(old-fashioned 旧oath) noun [C] a word that is considered rude or bad and that may offend people 骂人的话；粗话

*sweat
/swet ||; swɛt/verb[I]
1 to produce liquid through your skin because you are hot, ill or afraid 流汗；发汗；出汗
2 sweat (over sth) to work hard 努力做（某事）: I've been sweating over that problem all day. 我整天为了那个问题伤脑筋。 sweat noun [C,U] He stopped digging and wiped the sweat from his forehead. 他停止挖掘，抹掉额头上的汗水。 He woke up in a sweat. 他一觉醒来，满身是汗。 ☞Look at perspiration. 参看perspiration。
work/sweat your guts out→GUT¹

*sweater
/ˈswetə(r) ||; ˈswɛtɚ/noun [C] a warm piece of clothing with long sleeves, often made of wool, which you wear on the top half of your body 套衫；套头毛衣 ☞ Sweater, jumper, pullover and jersey are all words for the same piece of clothing. They are often made from wool or a similar material. A sweatshirt is usually made from cotton and may be worn informally or for sport. A cardigan fastens down the front. sweater、jumper、pullover和jersey都指同一种衣物，通常用羊毛之类的质料制成。sweatshirt通常是棉质的，可作便服或运动服。cardigan是对襟的。 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图

sweatshirt
/ˈswetʃɜ:t ||; ˈswɛtˌʃɝt/noun [C] a warm piece of cotton clothing with long sleeves, which you wear on the top half of your body 棉质套衫 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图

sweaty
/ˈsweti ||; ˈswɛtɪ/adj
1 wet with sweat 汗淋淋的；汗流浃背的: I was hot and sweaty after the match and needed a shower. 比赛后我热得大汗淋漓，须要洗个淋浴。
2 causing you to sweat 使出汗的: a hot sweaty day 热得出汗的一天

swede
/swi:d ||; swid/noun [C,U] a large, round, yellow vegetable that grows under the ground 芜菁甘蓝 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

*sweep¹
/swi:p ||; swip/verb (past tense past participle swept /swept ||; swɛpt/)
1 [I,T] to clean the floor, etc by moving dust, dirt, etc away with a brush 扫；打扫；清扫 [T] to sweep the floor 扫地 I'm going to sweep the leaves off the path. 我要清扫小径上的树叶。 ☞Look at the note at clean ². 参看clean^2的注释。
2 [T] to remove sth from a surface using your hand, etc （用手等）扫，拂，刮走: He swept the books angrily off the table. 他生气地用手将桌上的书扫到地上。
3 [I,T] to move quickly and smoothly over the area or in the direction mentioned 掠过；席卷；横扫: Fire swept through the building. 大火迅速蔓延至整座大楼。
4 [T] to move or push sb/sth with a lot of force 猛力移动或推进: The huge waves swept her overboard. 巨浪把她从船上冲入海中。 He was swept along by the huge crowd. 他被庞大的人群推拥着向前走。
5 [I] to move in a way that impresses or is intended to impress people 大模大样地走: Five big black Mercedes swept past us. 五辆大型黑色奔驰牌轿车从我们身旁疾驶而过。
6 [I,T] to move over an area, especially in order to look for sth 扫掠，扫视（尤指为了寻找某物） · The army were sweeping the fields for mines. 军队在田野里清除地雷。 His eyes swept quickly over the page. 他的目光快速扫视书页。
sweep (sb/sth) aside to not allow sb/sth to affect your progress or plans 漠视，全然不顾（影响进展或计划的某人或某事物） sweep sth out to remove dirt and dust from the floor of a room or building using a brush （用扫帚）清扫（房间或大楼地上的尘土） sweep over sb (used about a feeling) to suddenly affect sb very strongly （指情绪）突然强烈影响某人 sweep (sth) up to remove dirt, dust, leaves, etc using a brush （用扫帚）清扫，扫掉（尘土、树叶等）
sweep²
/swi:p ||; swip/noun[C]
1 [usu.sing] the action of moving dirt and dust from a floor or surface using a brush 打扫；清扫: I'd better give the floor a sweep. 我还是把地板打扫一下吧。
2 a long, curving shape or movement 长而弯曲的形状或动作: He showed us which way to go with a sweep of his arm. 他把手臂一挥，指给我们看走哪条路。
3 a movement over an area, especially in order to look for sth 扫视，扫掠（尤指为了寻找某事物）
4 =CHIMNEY SWEEP
a clean sweep→CLEAN¹

sweeper
/ˈswi:pə(r) ||; ˈswipɚ/noun[C]
1 a person or thing that cleans surfaces with a brush 打扫人；清扫器: He's a road sweeper. 他是个清道夫。 Do you sell carpet sweepers? 你们出售地毯清扫器吗？
2 (in football) the defending player who plays behind the other defending players （足球）自由中恒，清道夫

sweeping
/ˈswi:pɪŋ ||; ˈswipɪŋ/adj
1 (used about statements, etc) too general and not accurate enough （指说法等）笼统的，不准确的: He made a sweeping statement about all politicians being dishonest. 他一概而论地说，所有的政治家都是不诚实的。
2 having a great and important effect 影响重大的: sweeping reforms 通盘的改革

*sweet¹
/swi:t ||; swit/adj
1 containing, or tasting as if it contains, a lot of sugar 甜的；含糖的: Children usually like sweet things. 小孩子通常喜欢吃甜食。 This cake's too sweet. 这蛋糕太甜了。 ☞Look at savoury. 参看savoury。
2 (used especially about children and small things) attractive （尤指孩子和小事物）有吸引力的，可爱的: a sweet little kitten 可爱的小猫 Isn't that little girl sweet? 那个小女孩真可爱！ [SYN] cute 同义词为cute
3 having or showing a kind character 和蔼的；温柔的: a sweet smile 和蔼的微笑 It's very sweet of you to remember my birthday! 你真好，还记得我的生日！
4 (used about a smell or a sound) pleasant （指气味或声音）芳香的，悦耳的，甜美的 ➔sweetness noun [U]
have a sweet tooth to like eating sweet things 爱吃甜食
*sweet²
/swi:t ||; swit/noun
1 [C] [usu.pl] (US 美 candy [U]) a small piece of boiled sugar, chocolate, etc, often sold in a packet 糖果: He was sucking a sweet. 他含着一颗糖。 a sweet shop 糖果店
2 [C,U] sweet food served at the end of a meal （饭后）甜点，甜食 ☞Look at pudding and dessert. 参看pudding及dessert。

sweetcorn
/ˈswi:tkɔ:n ||; ˈswitˌkɔrn/ (US 美 corn) noun [U] yellow grains from a tall plant(maize)that taste sweet and are eaten as a vegetable 甜玉米 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

sweeten
/ˈswi:tn ||; ˈswitṇ/verb [T] to make sth sweet by adding sugar, etc 使变甜

sweetener
/ˈswi:tnə(r) ||; ˈswitṇɚ/noun [C,U] a substance used instead of sugar for making food or drink sweet （代替糖的）甜味剂；代糖: artificial sweeteners 人造糖

sweetheart
/ˈswi:thɑ:t ||; ˈswitˌhɑrt/noun[C]
1 used when speaking to sb, especially a child, in a very friendly way （对人的亲昵称呼）亲爱的（尤指对孩子）: Do you want a drink, sweetheart? 想喝一杯吗，亲爱的？
2 (old-fashioned 旧) a boyfriend or girlfriend 男朋友；女朋友

sweetly
/ˈswi:tli ||; ˈswitlɪ/adv in an attractive, kind or pleasant way 可爱地；和蔼地；温柔地: She smiled sweetly. 她笑得很甜。 sweetly-scented flowers 芬芳的花朵

ˌsweet poˈtato
noun [C,U] a vegetable that grows under the ground and looks like a red potato, but is yellow inside and tastes sweet 白薯；甘薯；甜薯

ˈsweet-talk
verb [T] sweet-talk sb (into sth/into doing sth) to try to persuade sb to do sth by praising him/her and saying things he/she likes to hear 对…甜言蜜语；给…灌迷魂汤: I can't believe you let him sweet-talk you into working for him! 我无法相信，他几句好听的话就哄得你为他工作！ ➔ˈsweet talk noun [U]

*swell¹
/swel ||; swɛl/verb (past tense swelled /sweld ||; swɛld/ past participle swollen /ˈswəʊlən ||; ˈswolən/or swelled)
1 [I,T] swell (up) to become or to make sth bigger, fuller or thicker （使）更大，更满，更厚: After the fall her ankle began to swell up. 她跌倒后脚腕开始肿胀起来。 Heavy rain had swollen the rivers. 大雨使河水高涨。
2 [I,T] to increase or make sth increase in number or size （使）（数目或大小）增加: The crowd swelled to 600 by the end of the evening. 到了晚上，聚集的人群增加到600人。
3 [I] (written 书面语) (used about feelings or sound) to suddenly become stronger or louder （指情绪或声音）突然高涨，突然响亮起来: Hatred swelled inside him. 他内心顿时充满仇恨。
swell²
/swel ||; swɛl/noun [sing] the slow movement up and down of the surface of the sea 海面的缓慢起伏

*swelling
/ˈswelɪŋ ||; ˈswɛlɪŋ/noun
1 [C] a place on your body that is bigger or fatter than usual because of an injury or illness 肿或肿胀的部位: I've got a nasty swelling under my eye. 我眼睛底下肿得厉害。
2 [U] the process of becoming swollen 肿（胀）: The disease often causes swelling of the ankles and knees. 这种病常会引致踝肿和膝肿。

sweltering
/ˈsweltərɪŋ ||; ˈswɛltərɪŋ/adj (informal 非正式) much too hot 热得难受的: It was sweltering in the office today. 今天办公室里热得真难受。

swept
past tense, past participle ofSWEEP¹

swerve
/swɜ:v ||; swɝv/verb [I] to change direction suddenly 突然改变方向: The car swerved to avoid the child. 那辆车突然转向，以免撞着那孩子。 swerve noun [C]

swift
/swɪft ||; swɪft/adj happening without delay; quick 迅速的；敏捷的；及时的: a swift reaction/decision/movement 及时的反应；快速的决定；敏捷的动作 a swift runner 飞毛腿 ➔swiftly adv

swig
/swɪg ||; swɪg/verb [I,T] (swigging;swigged) (informal 非正式) to take a quick drink of sth, especially alcohol 大口喝下（尤指酒）；牛饮 ➔swig noun [C]

swill
/swɪl ||; swɪl/verb [T] swill sth (out/down) to wash sth by pouring large amounts of water, etc into, over or through it 冲洗

*swim
/swɪm ||; swɪm/verb (present participle swimming;past tense swam /swæm ||; swæm/ past participle swum /swʌm ||; swʌm/)
1 [I,T] to move your body through water 游泳: How far can you swim? 你能游多远？ Hundreds of tiny fish swam past. 好几百条小鱼游过。
Go swimming is a common way of talking about swimming for pleasure We go swimming every Saturday. We can also say go for a swim when we are talking about one particular occasion I went for a swim this morning. 去游泳通常说go swimming：We go swimming every Saturday.我们每个星期六都去游泳。指某一次游泳活动可以说go for a swim：I went for a swim this morning. 今天早上我去了游泳。 picture at sport 见sport插图
2 [I] be swimming (in/with sth) to be covered with a lot of liquid 浸，泡，充溢（某种液体）: The salad was swimming in oil. 这色拉油汪汪的。
3 [I] to seem to be moving or turning 似在移动或旋转: The floor began to swim before my eyes and I fainted. 我看见眼前的地板旋转起来，然后就昏倒了。
4 [I] (used about your head) to feel confused （指头脑）迷糊，混乱: My head was swimming with so much new information. 这么多新数据，我都晕头转向了。 swim noun [sing] to go for / have a swim 去游泳 ➔swimmer noun [C]: a strong/weak swimmer 擅长╱不太擅长游泳的人

ˈswimming bath
noun [C] (also swimming baths [pl]) a public swimming pool, usually indoors （室内）公共游泳池

swimmingly
/ˈswɪmɪŋli ||; ˈswɪmɪŋlɪ/adv (informal 非正式) without any problems or difficulties 顺利地；顺顺当当地: We hope everything will go swimmingly. 我们希望一切进展顺利。

*ˈswimming pool
(also pool) noun [C] a pool that is built especially for people to swim in 游泳池: an indoor/outdoor/open-air swimming pool 室内╱室外╱露天游泳池

ˈswimming trunks
noun [pl] a piece of clothing like shorts that a man wears to go swimming （男用）游泳裤: a pair of swimming trunks 一条游泳裤 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图

swimsuit
/ˈswɪmsu:t ||; ˈswɪmˌsut/ (also swimming costume) noun [C] a piece of clothing that a woman wears to go swimming （女用）游泳衣 ☞Look at bikini. 参看bikini。 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图

swimwear
/ˈswɪmweə(r) ||; ˈswɪmˌwɛr/noun [U] (written 书面语) clothing that you wear for swimming in 泳装: a new swimwear collection 新的泳装系列

swindle
/ˈswɪndl ||; ˈswɪndḷ/verb [T] swindle sb/sth (out of sth) to trick sb in order to get money, etc 诈骗（某人的钱财等）；欺诈 swindle noun [C]: a tax swindle 逃税

swine
/swaɪn ||; swaɪn/noun
1 [C] (informal 非正式) a very unpleasant person 讨厌的人
2 [pl] (old-fashioned 旧) pigs 猪

*swing¹
/swɪŋ ||; swɪŋ/verb (past tense past participle swung /swʌŋ ||; swʌŋ/)
1 [I,T] to move backwards and forwards or from side to side while hanging from sth; to make sb/sth move in this way （使）摇摆，摆动: The rope was swinging from a branch. 绳子在树枝上晃动。 She sat on the wall, swinging her legs. 她坐在墙头，晃动着双腿。
2 [I,T] to move or make sb/sth move in a curve （使）循曲线移动: The door swung open and Rudi walked in. 门打开了，鲁迪走进来。 He swung the child up onto his shoulders. 他把孩子托到肩膀上。
3 [I] to move or change from one position or situation towards the opposite one （朝相反方向）变换（位置、情况、情绪等）: She swung round when she heard the door open. 她听见开门声，就转过身来。 His moods swing from one extreme to the other. 他的情绪大起大落。
4 [I,T] swing (sth) (at sb/sth) to try to hit sb/sth 企图击打
*swing²
/swɪŋ ||; swɪŋ/noun
1 [sing] a swinging movement or rhythm 摆动；挥动；挥击: He took a swing at the ball. 他挥棒击了一下球。
2 [C] a seat, a piece of rope, etc that is hung from above so that you can swing backwards and forwards on it 秋千: Some children were playing on the swings. 有几个孩子在荡秋千。
3 [C] a change from one position or situation towards the opposite one （位置或情况朝相反方向的）变换，改变
in full swing→FULL¹

swinging
/ˈswɪŋɪŋ ||; ˈswɪŋɪŋ/adj (informal 非正式) lively, exciting and fashionable 活跃时髦的；令人兴奋的: swinging singles 活跃时髦的单身族 the Swinging Sixties(= the period during the 1960s when people began to have more sexual freedom) 开放活跃的六十年代

swipe
/swaɪp ||; swaɪp/verb
1 [I,T] (informal 非正式)swipe (at) sb/sth to hit or try to hit sb/sth by moving your arm in a curve （试图）猛打，猛击: He swiped at the wasp with a newspaper but missed. 他用报纸扑打黄蜂，但没有打中。
2 [T] (informal 非正式) to steal sth 偷窃
3 [T] to pass the part of a plastic card on which information is stored through a special machine for reading it 刷卡（让机器读取磁卡上的数据）；将（磁卡）插入槽口: The receptionist swiped my credit card and handed me the slip to sign. 接待员刷了我的信用卡，并将收据递给我签字。 swipe noun [C]: She took a swipe at him with her handbag. 她用手提包打了他一下。

ˈswipe card
noun [C] a small plastic card on which information is stored which can be read by an electronic machine （存有数据可供机器读取的）磁卡

swirl
