/swɜ:l ||; swɝl/verb [I,T] to make or cause sth to make fast circular movements （使）旋转: Her long skirt swirled round her legs as she danced. 她跳舞时长裙环绕双腿旋转着。 He swirled some water round in his mouth and spat it out. 他用水漱漱口，然后把水吐出来。 swirl noun [C]

swish
/swɪʃ ||; swɪʃ/verb [I,T] to move quickly through the air in a way that makes a soft sound; to make sth do this ﹙使﹚唰地﹙或嗖地、呼地等﹚挥动；﹙使﹚快速空中移动: A large car swished past them and turned into the embassy gates. 一辆大型轿车嗖地从他们身边驶过，拐进了大使馆的大门。 The pony swished its tail. 小马唰唰地甩着尾巴。

Swiss cheese
/ˌswɪs ˈtʃi:z ||; ˌswɪs ˈtʃiz/noun [C,U] any hard cheese with holes in it 瑞士干酪﹙中间有孔﹚

*switch¹
/swɪtʃ ||; swɪtʃ/noun[C]
1 a small button or sth similar that you press up or down in order to turn on electricity （电路）开关: a light switch 电灯开关
2 a sudden change 突然的改变: a switch in policy 政策的骤变
*switch²
/swɪtʃ ||; swɪtʃ/verb[I,T]
1 switch (sth) (over) (to sth);switch (between A and B) to change or be changed from one thing to another 转变；改变: I'm fed up with my glasses -- I'm thinking of switching over to contact lenses. 我眼镜戴腻了，正考虑改换隐形眼镜。 Press these two keys to switch between documents on screen. 按这两个键可以在屏幕上从一个文件切换到另一个文件。 The match has been switched from Saturday to Sunday. 比赛日期已从星期六改到星期日。
2 switch (sth) (with sb/sth);switch (sth) (over/round) to exchange positions, activities, etc 交换（位置、活动等）: This week you can have the car and I'll go on the bus, and next week we'll switch over. 这个星期你用车子，我坐公共汽车，下个星期我们对调。 Someone switched the signs round and everyone went the wrong way. 有人把路标对调，结果大家都走错了路。
switch (sth) off/on to press a switch in order to start/stop electric power （用开关）接通／切断电流；打开／关掉: Don't forget to switch off the cooker. 别忘记关掉炉子。 switch (sth) over to change to a different television programme 转换电视频道

switchboard
/ˈswɪtʃbɔ:d ||; ˈswɪtʃˌbɔrd/noun [C] the place in a large company, etc where all the telephone calls are connected 电话交换台；电话总机

swivel
/ˈswɪvl ||; ˈswɪvḷ/verb [I,T] (swivelling;swivelled (US 美) swiveling;swiveled)swivel (sth) (round) to turn around a central point; to make sth do this （使）旋转或转动: She swivelled round to face me. 她转过身来面对着我。 He swivelled his chair towards the door. 他将椅子转过来对着门口。

swollen¹
past participle ofSWELL¹
swollen²
/ˈswəʊlən ||; ˈswolən/adj thicker or wider than usual 比平常厚或宽的；肿胀的: Her leg was badly swollen after the accident. 意外发生后，她的腿种得厉害。

swoop
/swu:p ||; swup/verb[I]
1 to fly or move down suddenly 飞扑；俯冲: The bird swooped down on its prey. 那只鸟突然俯冲扑向猎物。
2 (used especially about the police or the army) to visit or capture sb/sth without warning （尤指警察或军队）突然袭击、拘捕或攻占: Police swooped at dawn and arrested the man. 警察于黎明时分出击，拘捕了那个男子。 swoop noun [C]: a swoop (on sb/sth)

swoosh
/swu:ʃ ||; swuʃ/verb [I] to move quickly through the air in a way that makes a sound 嗖嗖地迅速移动: Cars and trucks swooshed past. 汽车和卡车嗖地疾驶而过。 ➔swoosh noun [sing]

swop
=SWAP

sword
/sɔ:d ||; sɔrd/noun [C] a long, very sharp metal weapon, like a large knife 剑；军刀；长刀 ☞picture at spear 见spear插图

swordfish
/ˈsɔ:dfɪʃ ||; ˈsɔrdˌfɪʃ/noun [C,U] (plural swordfish) a large sea fish that you can eat, with a very long thin sharp upper jaw 剑鱼；旗鱼

swore
past tense ofSWEAR

sworn
past participle ofSWEAR

swot¹
/swɒt ||; swɑt/verb [I,T] (swotting;swotted) (informal 非正式)swot (up) (for/on sth);swot sth up to study sth very hard, especially to prepare for an exam 用功苦读（尤指为了准备考试）: She's swotting for her final exams. 她正为期终考试而苦读。
swot²
/swɒt ||; swɑt/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who studies too hard 苦读者；刻苦用功的人

swum
past participle ofSWIM

swung
past tense, past participle ofSWING¹

syllable
/ˈsɪləbl ||; ˈsɪləbḷ/noun [C] a word or part of a word which contains one vowel sound 音节: ‘Mat’ has one syllable and ‘mattress’ has two syllables. mat有一个音节，mattress有两个音节。 The stress in ‘international’ is on the third syllable. international这个词的重音在第三个音节。

syllabus
/ˈsɪləbəs ||; ˈsɪləbəs/noun [C] (plural syllabuses) a list of subjects, etc that are included in a course of study 课程纲要 ☞Look at curriculum. 参看curriculum。

*symbol
/ˈsɪmbl ||; ˈsɪmbḷ/noun[C]
1 a symbol (of sth) a sign, object, etc which represents sth 象征；标志: The cross is the symbol of Christianity. 十字架是基督教的标志。
2 a symbol (for sth) a letter, number or sign that has a particular meaning 符号；记号: O is the symbol for oxygen. O是化学元素氧的符号。

symbolic
/sɪmˈbɒlɪk ||; sɪmˈbɑlɪk/ (also symbolical /-kl ||; -kḷ/) adj used or seen to represent sth 作为象征的；象征性的: The white dove is symbolic of peace. 白鸽是和平的象征。 ➔symbolically adv /-kli ||; -kḷɪ/

symbolism
/ˈsɪmbəlɪzəm ||; ˈsɪmbḷˌɪzəm/noun [U] the use of symbols to represent things, especially in art and literature 象征手法、作用或意义（尤指在文艺方面）

symbolize
/ˈsɪmbəlaɪz ||; ˈsɪmbḷˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to represent sth 象征: The deepest notes in music are often used to symbolize danger or despair. 最低沉的音符常用以象征危险或绝望。

symmetrical
/sɪˈmetrɪkl ||; sɪˈmɛtrɪkḷ/ (also symmetric /sɪˈmetrɪk ||; sɪˈmɛtrɪk/) adj having two halves that match each other exactly in size, shape, etc 对称的 [OPP] asymmetric 反义词为asymmetric ➔symmetrically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

symmetry
/ˈsɪmətri ||; ˈsɪmɪtrɪ/noun [U] the state of having two halves that match each other exactly in size, shape, etc 对称 ☞picture at axis 见axis插图

*sympathetic
/ˌsɪmpəˈθetɪk ||; ˌsɪmpəˈθɛtɪk/adj
1 sympathetic (to/towards sb) showing that you understand other people's feelings, especially their problems 同情的；体谅的: When Suki was ill, everyone was very sympathetic. 苏基生病时，大家都深表同情。 I felt very sympathetic towards him. 我非常同情他。 ☞In English, sympathetic does not mean ‘friendly and pleasant’. If you want to express this meaning, you say a person is nice I met Alex's sister yesterday. She's very nice. 英语中，sympathetic并非友善和礼貌的意思。表达这个意思可用nice：I met Alex's sister yesterday. She's very nice.我昨天遇到亚历克斯的姐姐，她很友善。
2 sympathetic (to sb/sth) being in agreement with or supporting sb/sth 赞同的；支持的: I explained our ideas but she wasn't sympathetic to them. 我解释了我们的构想，但她不赞同。 [OPP] unsympathetic 反义词为unsympathetic ➔sympathetically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

sympathize
/ˈsɪmpəθaɪz ||; ˈsɪmpəˌθaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [I] sympathize (with sb/sth)
1 to feel sorry for sb; to show that you understand sb's problems 同情；谅解: I sympathize with her, but I don't know what I can do to help. 我同情她，但不知道能怎样帮助她。
2 to support sb/sth 支持；赞同: I find it difficult to sympathize with his opinions. 我很难赞同他的看法。

sympathizer
/ˈsɪmpəθaɪzə(r) ||; ˈsɪmpəˌθaɪzɚ/ (also -ise) noun [C] a person who agrees with and supports an idea or aim 支持者；拥护者

*sympathy
/ˈsɪmpəθi ||; ˈsɪmpəθɪ/noun (plural sympathies)
1 [U] sympathy (for/towards sb) an understanding of other people's feelings, especially their problems 同情；谅解: Everyone feels great sympathyfor the victims of the attack. 大家都非常同情遇袭的受害者。 I don't expect any sympathy from you. 我没有指望你会谅解我。 I have no sympathyfor Mark -- it's his own fault. 我并不同情马克─他是咎由自取。
2 sympathies [pl] feelings of support or agreement 支持；赞同
in sympathy (with sb/sth) in agreement, showing that you support or approve of sb/sth 支持；赞同: Taxi drivers stopped work in sympathy with the striking bus drivers. 出租车司机不载客，以支持正在罢工的公共汽车司机。

symphony
/ˈsɪmfəni ||; ˈsɪmfənɪ/noun [C] (plural symphonies) a long piece of music written for a large orchestra 交响乐；交响曲

symposium
/sɪmˈpəʊziəm ||; sɪmˈpozɪəm/noun [C] (plural symposia or symposiums) a symposium (on sth) a meeting at which experts have discussions about a particular subject; a small conference 专题讨论会；研讨会；小型讨论会

symptom
/ˈsɪmptəm ||; ˈsɪmptəm/noun[C]
1 a change in your body that is a sign of illness 病征；症状: The symptoms of flu include a headache, a high temperature and aches in the body. 流感的症状包括头痛、发高烧及浑身酸痛。
2 a sign (that sth bad is happening or exists) （坏事的）征兆 ➔symptomatic /ˌsɪmptəˈmætɪk ||; ˌsɪmptəˈmætɪk/ adj

synagogue
/ˈsɪnəgɒg ||; ˈsɪnəˌgɔg/noun [C] a building where Jewish people go to pray or to study their religion 犹太教会堂

synchronize
/ˈsɪŋkrənaɪz ||; ˈsɪŋkrəˌnaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to make sth happen or work at the same time or speed 使步调一致；同步: We synchronized our watches to make sure we agreed what the time was. 我们互相对了对表，以确保时间一致。

syncline
/ˈsɪŋklaɪn ||; ˈsɪŋklaɪn/noun [C] (technical术语) (in geology) an area of ground where layers of rock in the earth's surface have been folded into a curve that is lower in the middle than at the ends （地质学）向斜 ☞Look at anticline. 参看anticline。

syndicate
/ˈsɪndɪkət ||; ˈsɪndɪkɪt/noun [C] a group of people or companies that work together in order to achieve a particular aim 辛迪加集团；企业联合组织

syndrome
/ˈsɪndrəʊm ||; ˈsɪndrom/noun[C]
1 a group of signs or changes in the body that are typical of an illness 综合症；症候群: Down's syndrome 唐氏综合症 Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (Aids) 后天免疫缺损综合症（艾滋病）
2 a set of opinions or a way of behaving that is typical of a particular type of person, attitude or social problem （某种人特有的）一套看法；（某种态度或社会问题的）表现形式

synonym
/ˈsɪnənɪm ||; ˈsɪnəˌnɪm/noun [C] a word or phrase that has the same meaning as another word or phrase in the same language 同义词: ‘Big’ and ‘large’ are synonyms. big和large是同义词。 ☞Compare antonym. 与antonym比较。 ➔synonymous /sɪˈnɒnɪməs ||; sɪˈnɑnəməs/ adj synonymous (with sth)

synopsis
/sɪˈnɒpsɪs ||; sɪˈnɑpsɪs/noun [C] (plural synopses /-si:z ||; -siz/) a SUMMARY (= a short description of the main points without any details) of a piece of writing, a play, etc （著作、剧本等的）梗概，大纲，提要 ➔synoptic /sɪˈnɒptɪk ||; sɪˈnɑptɪk/ adj (formal 正式)

synovial
/saɪˈnəʊviəl ||; sɪˈnovɪəl/adj (technical术语) connected with a type of JOINT(= a place where two bones meet) that has a piece of very thin skin (membrane) containing liquid between the bones, which allows the joint to move freely 与滑膜关节有关的: a synovial joint/membrane 滑膜关节；滑膜

syntax
/ˈsɪntæks ||; ˈsɪntæks/noun [U] the system of rules for the structure of a sentence in a language 句法；句子结构

synthesis
/ˈsɪnθəsɪs ||; ˈsɪnθəsɪs/noun (plural syntheses /-si:z ||; -siz/)
1 [U] [C] (a) synthesis (of sth) the act of combining separate ideas, beliefs, styles, etc; a mixture or combination of ideas, beliefs, styles, etc （不同思想、信念、风格等的）综合（体）: the synthesis of traditional and modern values 传统与现代价值的综合体 a synthesis of art with everyday life 艺术与日常生活的一种结合
2 [U] (technical术语) the natural chemical production of a substance in animals and plants 合成（指物质在动植物体内的自然化学生成过程）: protein synthesis 蛋白质的合成
3 [U] (technical术语) the artificial production of a substance that is present naturally in animals and plants 人工合成（法）: the synthesis of penicillin 青霉素的人工合成法
4 [U] the production of sounds, music or speech by electronic means （用电子设备对声音、音乐、话语等的）合成: digital/sound/speech synthesis 数字╱声音╱话语的合成

synthesize
/ˈsɪnθəsaɪz ||; ˈsɪnθəˌsaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T]
1 (technical术语) to produce a substance by artificial means 以人工方法合成（某物质）
2 to produce sounds, music or speech using electronic equipment 用电子设备合成（声音、音乐、话语）
3 to combine separate ideas, beliefs, styles, etc 综合（不同的思想、信念、风格等）

synthesizer
/ˈsɪnθəsaɪzə(r) ||; ˈsɪnθəˌsaɪzɚ/ (also -iser) noun [C] an electronic musical instrument that can produce a wide variety of different sounds 电子音响合成器

synthetic
/sɪnˈθetɪk ||; sɪnˈθɛtɪk/adj made by a chemical process; not natural 人造的；合成的: synthetic materials/fibres 合成材料╱纤维 ➔synthetically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

syphilis
/ˈsɪfɪlɪs ||; ˈsɪfḷɪs/noun [U] a serious disease that passes from one person to another by sexual contact 梅毒

syphon
=SIPHON

syringe
/sɪˈrɪndʒ ||; ˈsɪrɪndʒ/noun[C]
1 a plastic or glass tube with a needle that is used for taking a small amount of blood out of the body or for putting drugs into the body 注射器 ☞picture at health 见health插图
2 a plastic or glass tube with a rubber part at the end, used for sucking up liquid and then pushing it out （一头带橡皮套的）吸管 ☞picture at laboratory 见laboratory插图

syrup
/ˈsɪrəp ||; ˈsɪrəp/noun [U] a thick sweet liquid, often made by boiling sugar with water or fruit juice 糖水；糖浆: peaches in syrup 糖水桃子 ☞Look at treacle. 参看treacle。

*system
/ˈsɪstəm ||; ˈsɪstəm/noun
1 [C] a set of ideas or rules for organizing sth; a particular way of doing sth 制度；体系；系统: We have a new computerized system in the library. 我们图书馆安装了新的计算机化系统。 The government is planning to reform the education system. 政府打算改革教育制度。
2 [C] a group of things or parts that work together 系统；装置；组合: a central heating system 中央供暖系统 a transport system 交通运输系统
3 [C] the body of a person or animal; parts of the body that work together 身体；（身体）内部系统或组织: the central nervous system 中枢神经系统
4 the system [sing] (informal 非正式) the traditional methods and rules of a society 传统；体制: You can't beat the system (= you must accept these rules). 你无法不接受这套规定。
get sth out of your system(informal 非正式) to do sth to free yourself of a strong feeling or emotion 发泄强烈的感情或情绪

systematic
/ˌsɪstəˈmætɪk ||; ˌsɪstəˈmætɪk/adj done using a fixed plan or method 有系统的；有计划的；系统化的: a systematic search 有系统的搜索 ➔systematically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

systemic
/sɪˈstemɪk;sɪˈsti:mɪk||; sɪsˈtɛmɪk/adj (technical术语)
1 affecting or connected with the whole of sth, especially the human body 影响整体的，与整体有关的（尤指人体）
2 systemic chemicals or drugs that are used to treat diseases in plants or animals enter the body of the plant or animal and spread to all parts of it （化学品或药品）内吸的: systemic weedkillers 内吸除莠剂 ➔systemically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

ˈsystems analyst
noun [C] (computing计算机技术) a person whose job is to look carefully at the needs of a business company or an organization and then design the best way of working and completing tasks using computer programs 系统分析员
